div1.head: q

div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter q *
The twenty-first letter of the alphabet: called qaAfN. Respecting its pronunciation as the title of the fiftieth chapter of the Kur-án, see SAd, in art. Swd. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; its place of utterance is between the root of the tongue and the uvula, in the furthest part of the mouth; and it is of the strongest of the letters, and of the most certain of them in sound. (TA at the commencement of bAb AlqAf.) It is sometimes pronounced like the Pers. G, i. e. AlkaAfu Almamozuwjapu biAlqaAfi; in which case it is termed AlqaAfu AlmaqoEuwdapu [?]: this mode of pronouncing it is well known as of the dial. of the people of El-Yemen [and others]: Ibn-Khaldoon says that it is of the dial. of Mudar; and that some of the people of the [Prophet's] house are so extravagant as to assert that recitation in prayer is not rightly but with this letter thus pronounced. (MF and TA voce jul~anaArN.) It has been substituted for one letter, i. e. k, [as some say,] in the instance of A^ukonapu AlT~aAy^iri [for which they sometimes said A^uqonap]. (MF and TA at the commencement of bAb AlqAf. [It is there added that a pl. of A^ukonap has been heard, but not of A^uqonap, and this is a sign of the originality of the former: but A^uqanaAtN is mentioned as pl. of A^uqonap in art. Aqn in the TA.])

1 qaA^aba AlT~aEaAma * , (As, S, O, K,) aor.
qaAa^a , inf. n. qaA^obN, (K,) He ate the food. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b2- And qaA^aba AlmaA='a He drank the water; as also qay^ibahu: (K:) or he drank all the water that was in the vessel. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b3- And qay^iba mina Al$~araAbi, aor.
qaAa^a , inf. n. qaA^obN and qaA^abN, (K, TA,) the latter thus (muHar~akap), agreeably with analogy, (TA, [but in the CK qaA=b,]) He became filled with the beverage; (Lth, K;) as also qaA^aba minohu: (Lth:) or he drank the beverage: (TA:) and, or simply qay^iba, like Say^iba, (S,) he drank much water. (S, TA.)
qaw^uwbN * : see miqoA^abN.
A_inaA='N qawoA^abN * and ↓ qawoA^abiY~N A vessel that takes, or receives, much water: (O, K:) the latter epithet expl. by Lth as signifying taking, or receiving, much. (L.)
qawoA^abiY~N * : see what next precedes.
miqoA^abN * (S, O, K) and ↓ qaw^uwbN (K) One who drinks much water: (S, O:) or one who drinks much. (K.)

1 qab~a * , aor.
qabi3a , (M, K,) inf. n. qabiybN, (M,) or qubuwbN, (so in the K, [but see the next sentence,]) and qab~N, (TA,) said of a number of men (qawomN), They raised a clamour, or confusion of cries or shouts or noises, in contention, or litigation, (M, K,) or in dispute. (M.) And qab~a, aor.
qabi3a , inf. n. qabiybN (S, M, O, K,) and qab~N, (M, K,) said of a lion, (S, M, O, K,) and of a stallion [camel], (M, K,) He made the gnashing (qaboqabap [inf. n. of ↓ qaboqaba], S, O, or qaEoqaEap, M, K) of his canine teeth to be heard: (S, M, O, K:) and in like manner the verb (M, K) with the same inf. ns. (M) is said of the canine tooth of the stallion [camel] and of the lion, (M, K,) meaning it made a sounding, and a gnashing: (K:) and some expl. qabiybN in a general manner, saying that it signifies a sounding, or sound: (M:) qaboqabapN also, and qaboqaAbN, [both inf. ns. of ↓ qaboqaba,] (M,) or the former and qabiybN, (TA,) signify the sounding [or gnashing] of the canine teeth of the stallion [camel]: and his braying: or, as some say, the reiterating of the braying: (M, TA:) and ↓ qbqbp and qabiybN signify the sounding of the chest or belly of the horse. (S, M, O.) -A2- And qab~a, aor.
qabi3a , inf. n. qubuwbN, said of flesh-meat, It lost its moisture, (S, M, O, K,) or fresh-ness: (M, K:) and in like manner said of dates (tamor), (S, M, O, Msb, [in my copy of the last of which the inf. n. is said to be qabiyb,]) and of the skin, and of a wound: (S, O:) and hence said of the back of a man who had been beaten with the whip or some other thing, meaning the marks of the beating thereof became in a healing state, and dried. (As, O, TA.) And qab~ati Alr~uTabapu, (M, TA,) thus correctly, but in copies of the K ↓ qab~abat, (TA,) [and the CK has Alr~aTobapu for Alr~uTabapu,] is said to signify The fresh ripe date became somewhat dry after the ripening: (M, TA:) or became dry. (K.) ― -b2- And qab~a Aln~abotu, aor.
qabi3a and
qabu3a , [the latter anomalous,] inf. n. qab~N, The plant dried up. (M, L, K.) -A3- qab~a, (M, MA,) aor. yaqab~u, (M,) inf. n. qababN, (S, * M, MA, O, * K, *) He was, or became, slender in the waist, (S, * M, MA, O, * K, *) lank in the belly: (S, * M, O, * K: *) and qabibato, uncontracted, as in some other instances, said of a woman [as meaning she was, or became, slender in the waist, lank in the belly], is mentioned by IAar: (M:) and some say, of the belly of the horse, qab~a, (M, TA,) meaning his flanks became lank; (M;) or his flanks adhered to his HaAlibaAni [dual. of HaAlibN, q. v.]: (TA:) or one says, [app. of a horse,] qab~a baTonuhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. qab~N; (TA;) and qabiba, (K, TA,) inf. n. qababN, in the original uncontracted forms, anomalously, (TA,) meaning his belly became lank. (K, TA.) And one says also, qub~a baTonuhu, i. e. His (a horse's) belly was, or became, firmly compacted, so as to have a round form: and qab~ahu means He caused it to be so: (O, TA:) the aor. of the latter is
qabu3a , and the inf. n. is qab~N. (TA.) -A4- qab~a Al$~aYo'a He collected, or gathered together, the extremities of the thing; as also ↓ qab~abahu. (M, TA.) -A5- And qab~ahu, aor.
qabu3a , (S, M, O,) inf. n. qab~N, (M, K,) He cut it off; (S, M, O, K; *) and ↓ Aqtb~hu signifies the same: (M, K: *) or, [app. the latter,] as some say, peculiarly the hand, or arm: (M:) one says, Aqtb~ fulaAnN yada fulaAnK Such a one cut off the hand, or arm, of such a one: (As, S, O:) or AiqotibaAbN signifies any cutting off that does not leave aught. (M.) -A6- See also the next paragraph.

2 qb~b *
He (a man) made a qub~ap [q. v.]: (K:) or so ↓ qab~a: (TA:) and qb~b qub~apF, (M, TA,) inf. n. taqobiybN, (TA,) he made, (M,) or constructed, (TA,) a qab~ap. (M, TA.) [Hence,] AlhawaAdiju tuqab~abu [The women's camel vehicles of the kind called hwAdj have dome-like, or tent-like, coverings made to them]. (S, O.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] qb~b Zahorahu [He (a man) made his back round like a dome, lowering his head]. (S and K in art. dbx.) -A2- See also 1, in two places, near the middle and near the end.

5 tqb~b qub~apF *
He entered a qub~ap [q. v.]. (M, K.)

8 A_iqotaba3a see 1, near the end. ― -b2- IAar says, El- 'Okeylee used not to discourse of anything but I wrote it down from him; wherefore he said, A_il~aA A@notaqarahaA A_l~aA A@qotab~ahaA walaA nuqaArapF ↓ maA taraka EinodiY qaAb~apF, meaning (assumed tropical:) He did not leave with me any approved and choice word but he cut it off for himself [or appropriated it to his own use], nor any such expression but he took it for himself. (M, TA.)

R. Q. 1 qaboqaba * , and its inf. ns.: see 1, former half, in three places. Said of a stallion [camel], (O, TA,) it signifies [also] He brayed: (O, K, * TA:) and, said of a lion, (S, M, TA,) he roared; (S, K, * TA;) and he uttered a sound; (K, TA;) and (TA) he made a grating sound with his canine teeth: (M, TA:) and, said of the faroj of a woman by reason of the act of A_iylaAj, it made a sound. (IAar, O.) And, said of a sword, in a striking [therewith], It made a sound like qabo [q. v.]. (A.) -A2- Also, (said of a man, O) He was, or became, foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (O, K.)

R. Q. 2 jayo$N yataqaboqabu *
An army of which one part presses upon another. (TA in art. jEb.)
qabo * , (M, A, K,) or qabo qabo, (TA,) an expression imitative of The sound of the fall of a sword [upon an object struck therewith] (M, A, * K, TA) in fight. (TA.)

qab~N * The perforation in which runs [or rather through which passes] the pivot of the maHaAlap [or great pulley]: (M, K:) or the hole which is in the middle of the bakorap [or sheave] (M, A, K) and around which the latter revolves: (A:) or the [sheave or] perforated piece of wood which revolves around the pivot: and its pl., in these senses, is A^aqub~N, only: (M:) or the piece of wood above the teeth of the maHaAlap: (K, TA:) or [this is app. a mistake, or mistranscription, and the right explanation is] the piece of wood [i. e. the sheave] (S, O, TA) in the middle of the bakorap, (S, O,) above which are teeth (S, O, TA) of wood, (S, O,) the teeth of the mHAlp [between which teeth runs the well-rope]; thus says As. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse of Zuheyr cited voce vinaAyapN.] ― -b2- And The head [or truck] of the daqal [or mast] of a ship. (Az, TA in art. rnH.) ― -b3- And [app. as being likened to the pivot-hole of the sheave of a pulley,] (tropical:) A head, chief, or ruler, (S, M, A, O, K,) of a people, or party: (M, A:) or the greatest head or chief or ruler; (M;) or such is called Alqab~u AlA^akobaru; (S, O;) and this appellation means the $ayox [or elder, &c.,] upon [the control of] whom the affairs of the people, or party, turn. (A.) And, (K,) some say, (M,) (assumed tropical:) A king: (M, K:) and, (K,) some say, (M,) a xaliyfap [q. v.]. (M, K.) [See also qib~N.] ― -b4- And [hence, perhaps,] (assumed tropical:) A faHol [i. e. stallion, or male,] of camels and of mankind. (O, K.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The back-part of a coat of mail: so called because that part is its main support; from the qab~ of a pulley. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The piece, or pieces, inserted [i. e. sewed inside, next to the edge,] in the jayob [or opening at the neck and bosom] of a shirt. (A 'Obeyd, S, M, O, K.) [And in the present day it is likewise used to signify The collar of a shirt or similar garment; as also ↓ qab~apN.] -A2- Also The part between the two hips: (M, K:) or, between the two buttocks: (K:) or qab~u Ald~uburi means what is between the two buttocks. (M.) See also qib~N. -A3- And The hardest, or most severe, (M, O, K,) and largest, (M, K,) of lujum [i. e. bits, or bridles; pl. of lijaAmN, q. v.]. (M, O, K.) -A4- And A certain measure for corn, or grain, or other kinds of the produce of land. (TA.) -A5- watarN qab~N means [app. A bow-string] of which the several TaAqaAt [or component fascicles of fibres or the like] are even. (A.)

qib~N * , with kesr, The $ayox [or elder, &c.,] of a people, or party: (S, O, K:) but he is rather called qab~, with fet-h, as mentioned above. (TA.) -A2- And The bone that projects from the back, between the two buttocks; (S, O, K;) i. q. EajobN: (TA:) one says, A^aloziqo qib~aka biAlA^aroDi, (S, O, TA,) but it is said that in a copy of the T, in the handwriting of its author, it is ↓ qab~aka, with fet-h, (TA,) [as it is also in a copy of the A.] i. e. [Make thou] thy Eajob [to cleave to the ground], (A, TA,) meaning (tropical:) sit thou. (A.)
qab~apN * : see qab~N, last quarter.

qub~apN *
A certain kind of structure, (S, M, A, O, Msb, TA,) well known; (M, A, Msb, TA;) and applied to a round bayot [i. e. tent, or pavilion], well known among the Turkumán and the Akrád; (Msb;) it is what is called a xaroqaAhap [an Arabicized word from the Pers. xarokaAh]; (Mgh, Msb;) and signifies any round structure: (Mgh:) it is said to be a structure of skins, or tanned hides, peculiarly; (M, TA;) derived from qab~a Al$~aYo'a and qab~abahu meaning “ he collected, or gathered together, the extremities of the thing: ” (M:) accord. to IAth, it is a small round tent of the kind called xibaA='; of the tents of the Arabs: in the 'Ináyeh it is said to be what is raised for the purpose of the entering thereinto; and not to be peculiarly a structure: (TA:) [also a dome-like, or tent-like, covering of a woman's camel-vehicle of the kind called hawodaj: and a dome, or cupola, of stone or bricks: and a building covered with a dome or cupola:] the pl. is qibaAbN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and qubabN. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qub~apu Als~anaAmi (assumed tropical:) [The round, protuberant, upper portion of the camel's hump]. (A, voce qaHadapN.) ― -b3- qub~apu AlA_isolaAmi is an appellation of El-Basrah. (M, K.) ― -b4- And Alqub~apu is the name by which some of the Arabs call (assumed tropical:) The thirteen stars that compose the constellation of Corona Australis; because of their round form. (Kzw.)

qib~apu Al$~aApi * , also pronounced without teshdeed [i. e. qibap], The Hafiv [q. v.] of the sheep or goat, (S, O, K,) which has A^aTobaAq, [see, again, HafivN,] (S, O,) and which is the receptacle whereto the feces of the stomach finally pass. (TA.) [See also art. wqb.]

qubaAbN *
Sharp; (O, K;) applied to a sword and the like: (K:) from qab~a “ he cut off. ” (TA.) -A2- And A thick, large, nose. (M, K.) -A3- And, (M, O,) or ↓ qibaAbN, (K,) A species of fish, (M, O, K,) which is eaten, resembling the kanoEad. (M, O.)
qibaAbN * : see what next precedes.
qabiybN * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. -A2- Also Dry herbage: like qafiyfN. (M.) ― -b2- And [The preparation of curd called] A^aqiT of which the dry has been mixed with the fresh. (M, K.)

Alqab~aAbu *
The lion; as also ↓ Almuqaboqibu. (O, K: in the CK the latter is written Almuqaboqab.)

HimaAru qab~aAna * [The wood-louse; thus called in the present day;] a certain insect, or small creeping thing; (S, O, K;) mentioned in art. Hmr [q. v.]; (Msb;) also called Eayoru qab~aAna; (K;) a small, smoothish, blackish thing, the head of which is like that of the [beetle termed] xunofasaA=', and long, and its legs are like those of the xnfsA=', than which it is smaller; and it is said that what is called Eyr qb~An is party-coloured, black and white, with white legs, having a nose like that of the hedge-hog; when it is moved, it feigns itself dead, so that it appears like a [small] globular piece of dung; but when the voice is withheld, it goes away: (M, TA:) MF says that the appellation Eyr qb~An is used only in poetry, in a case of necessity, for the sake of the metre; and is not mentioned in the lexicons of celebrity [except the K]. but it is mentioned in the M and the L: he says also that what is called HimaAru qab~aAna is said to be a species of the [beetles termed] xanaAfis [pl. of xunofasaA='] found between Mekkeh and El-Medeeneh: (TA:) [accord. to Dmr, it is a kind of six-footed insect, round, smaller than the black beetle, with a shield-shaped back, bred in moist places: (Golius:)] it is related on the authority of Jáhidh that one species thereof is called A^abuw $aHomK, which is the small [species] thereof; and that the people of El-Yemen apply the appellation HmAr qb~An to a certain insect, or small creeping thing, above the size of a locust, of the same sort as the faraA$ [generally meaning moth]: in the Mufradát of Ibn-El-Beytár, it is said that what is called HmAr qb~An is also called HimaAru Albayoti: the reason for the appellation [HmAr qb~An] seems to be because its back resembles a qub~ap: (TA:) qab~aAn in this case is of the measure faEolaAn, from qab~a, (S, O, K,) because the Arabs imperfectly decline it, and they use it determinately; if it were of the measure faE~aAl, they would decline it perfectly; the pl. is Humuru qab~aAna. (S, O.) -A2- qab~aAnN, syn. with qusoTaAsN, see in art. qbn.

Alqub~iy~uwna * , [in the CK Alqubiy~uwna,] occurring in a trad., in the saying xayoru Aln~aAsi Alqub~iy~uwna, means, (Th, O, K,) if the trad. be correct, (Th, O,) Those who continue uninterruptedly fasting [except in the night] until their bellies become lank: (Th, O, K:)
or, accord. to one relation, it is ↓ Almuqab~abuwna, which means the same. (TA.)
AlqaAb~u * and qaAb~a: see qubaAqibN, in three places.

qaAb~apN *
A drop of rain: (AZ, ISk, S, M, A, O, K:) so in the saying maA raA^ayonaA AlEaAma qaAb~apF [We have not seen this year a drop of rain]: (AZ, ISk, S, O:) and maA A^aSaAbatonaA AlEaAma qaAb~apN [Not a drop of rain has fallen upon us this year]. (ISk, S, M, * A, * O.) ― -b2- And Thunder; (A, K;) or the sound of thunder: so in the saying maA samiEonaA AlEaAma qaAb~apF [We have not heard this year the sound of thunder]; (ISk, S, M, A, * O;) accord. to As; but only he has related this. (ISk, S, O.) -A2- See also 8.

qaboqabN * The belly; (S, M, O, K;) as also ↓ qaboqaAbN: (Suh, TA:) from ↓ qaboqabapN, [an inf. n. of R. Q. 1, q. v., and] a word imitative of the sounding [or rumbling] of the belly. (TA.) -A2- And The wood of a horse's saddle: so in the saying,
yuTay~iru AlfaArisu lawo laA qaboqabuhu
[He would make the horseman to fly off, were it not for the wood of his saddle]. (M. [But in this sense it is app. a mistranscription for qayoqabN.]) ― -b2- And A species of trees; as also ↓ qaboqabaAnN. (M. [But in this sense both are app. mistranscriptions, for qayoqabN and qayoqabaAnN.])

qiboqibN *
A certain marine shell (O, K) wherein is a flesh [i. e. mollusk] which is eaten. (O.)
qaboqabapN * : see qaboqabN.
qaboqabaAnN * : see qaboqabN.

qaboqaAbN * an inf. n. of R. Q. 1. [q. v.] ― -b2- Also A camel that brays much. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And One who talks much; as also ↓ qubaAqibN: (M, * K, TA:) or one who talks much, whether wrongly or rightly: (M, * TA:) or one who talks much and confusedly. (M, K, * TA.) ― -b4- And A liar. (O, K.) ― -b5- See also qaboqabN. ― -b6- Also The faroj [meaning external portion of the organs of generation] (M, O, K) of a woman: (O:) or [a vulva] such as is [described as being] waAsiEN kaviyru AlmaA='i, (O, K,) [because] A_i*aA A^awolaja Alr~ajulu *akarahu fiyhi qaboqaba A^aYo Saw~ata. (IAar, O.) And they also used it as an epithet; [but in what sense is not expl.;] saying *akarN qaboqaAbN. (M.) ― -b7- And The [clog, or] wooden sandal: (O, K:) [app. because of the clattering sound produced by it:] of the dial. of El-Yemen: (O, TA:) [but now in common use; applied to a kind of clog, or wooden patten, generally from four to nine inches in height, and usually ornamented with mother-ofpearl, or silver, &c.; used in the bath by men and women; and by some ladies in the house:] in this sense the word is said to be post-classical. (TA.) -A2- Also, (K,) accord. to Az, (O,) The xarazap [app. a polished stone, or a shell,] with which cloths are glazed: (O, K:) but this is called qayoqaAb. (O.)

qubAqibN * : see qaboqaAbN. ― -b2- Also, as an epithet applied to a man, (K,) i. q. jaAfK [Coarse, rough, or rude, of make, or of nature or disposition; &c.]. (O, K.) -A2- And AlqubaAqibu signifies AlEaAmu Almuqobilu [i. e. The year that is the next coming]: (K:) or [this is a mistake occasioned by an omission, and] its meaning is AlEaAmu Al~a*iY baEoda AlEaAmi Almuqobili [the year that is after that which is the next coming]; you say, laA A=tiyka AlEaAma walaA qaAbila walaA qubaAqiba [I will not come to thee this year, nor next year, nor the year after the next]; and AO cites as an ex.
AlEaAmu waAlmuqobilu waAlqubaAqibu
[This year, and the next year, and the year after the next]: (S:) or qubaAqibN [without the art. Al and perfectly decl.] signifies [thus, i. e.] AlEAmu Al~a*iY yaliY qaAbila EaAmika, and is a proper name of the year; whence the saying of Khálid Ibn-Safwán to his son, when he reproved him, A_in~aka lano tufoliHa AlEaAma ↓ walaA qaAbilFA walaA qubaAqibFA walaA muqaboqibFA [Verily thou wilt not prosper this year, nor next year, nor the year after the next, nor the year after that]; every one of these words being the name of the year after the year; thus related by As, who says that they know not what is after that: (M:) IB says that the statement of J is what is commonly known; i. e., that qubaAqib means the third year [counting the present year as the first], and that ↓ Almuqaboqibu means the fourth year: but some make ↓ AlqaAb~u the third year; and AlqubaAqibu, the fourth year; and ↓ Almuqaboqibu, the fifth year: (TA:) [thus Sgh says,] ↓ AlqaAb~u is the third year: and Khálid Ibn-Safwán [is related to have] said, walaA qubaAqiba ↓ yaA bunaY~a A_in~aka laA tufoliHu AlEaAma walaA qaAbila walaA qaAb~a ↓ walaA muqaboqiba [O my child (lit. my little son), verily thou wilt not prosper this year, nor next year, nor the year after the next, nor the year after that, nor the year after that]; (O, K; *) every one of these words being the name of the year after the year. (O.)

A^aqab~u *
Lank in the belly: (S, O:) or slender in the waist, lank in the belly: (M:) fem. qab~aA='u, (S, M, A, O, K,) applied to a woman, (S, A, O,) meaning slender in the waist; (K;) or lank in the belly; (TA;) or lank in the belly, slender in the waist: (A:) and pl. qub~N, (S, A, O, K,) applied to horses, (S, A, O,) meaning lean, or light of flesh: (S, O:) and some say that A^aqab~u applied to a horse signifies lank in his flanks. (M.)

muqab~abN * , applied to a house, or chamber, Having a qub~p [q. v.] made above it. (S, O, K.) [And in like manner applied to a woman's camel-vehicle of the kind termed hawodaj: see 2. ― -b2- And it is also an epithet applied to a solid hoof; meaning Round like a cupola: see mufij~N, and see the first sentence in art. qEb.] -A2- sur~apN muqab~abapN, (M, K, TA,) in a copy of the K erroneously written muqaboqabap, (TA,) A lean navel; as also ↓ maqobuwbapN. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also Alqub~iy~uwna.
sur~apN maqobuwbapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
muqaboqibN * : see Alqab~aAbu: -A2- and see also qubaAqibN, in four places.

qabojN * , (S, M, MA, L, Msb, K, &c.,) or, accord. to MF, qabajN, (TA,) a Pers. word, arabicized, (S, M,) originally kabok, (M,) or kaPok, (MA,) The Hajal [i. e. partridge, or partridges]; (S, M, MA, L, Msb, K;) a coll. gen. n.: (S:) n. un. qabojapN; (S, MA, Msb;) which is applied to the male and to the female; (S, Msb, K;) yaEoquwbN being specially applied to the male. (S, Msb: [but see yaEoquwbN:]) pl. qibaAjN. (MA: in which qabojN is also termed a pl.) ― -b2- And The karawaAn [q. v., a name now given to the stone-curlew, or charadrius œdicnemus]. (M, L, TA.)

1 qabuHa * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
qabuHa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ↓ quboHN, (Msb, K,) [or this, accord. to the S, seems to be a simple subst.,] and qaboHN (K) and qabaAHapN (S, K) and qubuwHapN and qubuwHN and qubaAHN, (K,) He, or it, (a form, and an action, L, and anything, T,) was, or became, bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous; contr. of Hasuna. (S, Msb, K, TA, &c.) One says of a man, qabuHa wa$aquHa [app. using the latter v. as an imitative sequent]: and jaA='a biAlqabaAHapi waAl$~aqaAHapi [He did, or said, what was bad or evil &c.]. (K in art. $qH.) And ↓ AuqobuHo A_ino kunota qaAbiHFA Be thou bad or evil &c., if thou be desirous of becoming so: and qawoqa maA qabuHa ↓ maA huwa biqaAbiHK He is not becoming bad &c., or will not become bad &c., above the degree in which he has become so: and in like manner one says in similar cases. (Lh, L.) -A2- laA taqobaHuwA Alwajoha, occurring in a trad., means Say not ye that the face is qabiyH [i. e. unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous]; because God formed it: or the meaning is, say not ye qabaHa A@ll~`hu wajoha fulaAnK [expl. in what follows]. (L.) ― -b2- And qabaHahu A@ll~`hu, (S, A, Msb, K, TA, &c., [in the CK qab~aHahu,]) aor.
qabaHa , (Msb,) inf. n. qaboHN and qubuwHN, (AZ, L, TA,) God removed him, or may God remove him, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) far, (A, TA,) from good, or prosperity, (S, Msb, K,) or from all that is good; (L, TA;) [or from success, or the attainment of that which he deserves or seeks; (see the pass. part. n.;)] like as one does the dog and the pig: (AZ, L, TA:) [or God drove him away, or may God drive him away, like a dog: or God rendered him, or may God render him, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous, in form: (see, again, the pass. part. n.:)] and A@ll~`hu ↓ qab~aHahu has a similar, but intensive, signification. (Msb.) One says, qaboHFA lahu [an elliptical expression, a verb and its agent being understood, i. e., with these supplied, (May God decree) removal far from good, &c., to him; or (cause) removal &c. (to cleave) to him; meaning may removal &c. betide him]; (S;) and ↓ quboHFA (S, A) also, (S,) with damm; (A;) [i. e. foulness,
unseemliness, unsightliness, ugliness, or hideousness;] and lahu wa$uqoHFA ↓ quboHFA; (L, K, TA;) and qaboHFA lahu wa$aqoHFA; in which $qHA is [said to be] an imitative sequent. (L, TA: but see art. $qH.) ― -b3- qabaHotu lahu wajohahu, [thus,] without teshdeed, means I said to him, qabaHa A@ll~`hu wajohaka [i. e. May God remove thee far from good, &c., for wajohaka is here put for nafosaka, the phrase being] from AlqaboHu signifying “ the removing far [from good, &c.]. ” (AA, L. [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. sbH, conj. 2.]) -A3- And qabaHa (IAar, L, K, TA, [accord. to the CK qb~H, and so in one of two copies of the A, but the former is the right, as is shown by the form of the aor. in an ex. in the TA,]) He broke a purulent pustule (in his face, L,) in order that the matter might come forth: (L, K, TA:) or he squeezed a purulent pustule to express its contents before it was ripe: (A, TA:) and [in like manner] he broke an egg, (K,) or anything. (L.)

2 qb~Hhu *
He (i. e. God) rendered him, or it, bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous. (L.) ― -b2- See also the preceding paragraph, near the middle. ― -b3- And He rejected, or reprobated, what he said, as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (L.) ― -b4- And qb~H Ealayohi fiEolahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqobiyHN, (S, K,) He showed, or declared, his deed to be bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly: (K:) said when a deed is such as is blamed. (Msb.)

3 qAbHhu * , (A,) inf. n. muqaAbaHapN, (K, TA,) with which mukaAbaHapN is syn., (TA,) He reviled, or vilified, him, being reviled, or vilified, by him; or he vied, or contended, with him in reviling, or vilifying (A, K. *)

4 AqbH *
He did [or said] what was bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (S, A, K.) -A2- maA A^aqobaHa wajohahu is said in reviling a man [as meaning How foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous, is his face!]. (Ham p. 138.)

10 AstqbHhu *
He regarded him, or it, as bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous; (TA;) contr. of AstHsnhu. (S, * K.)

quboHN * [either an inf. n. or a simple subst.; much used as a simple subst., and ↓ maqaAbiHu, q. v., may be an anomalous pl. thereof, like as maHaAsinu is said to be of its contr. HusonN]: see 1, first sentence; and again, in two places, in the latter half.
AlqabaAHu * : see the next following paragraph.

qabiyHN *
Bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous; contr. of HasanN; (S, L, Msb, K, &c.;) applied to a form, and to an action, (L,) and to anything: (T:) pl. qibaAHN and qabaAHaY and qaboHaY: fem. qabiyHapN; pl. qabaAy^iHu and qibaAHN. (K.) ― -b2- naAqapN qabiyHapN Al$~uxobi A she-camel having wide orifices to her teats. (A, K.) ― -b3- AlqabiyHu [is said to signify] The extremity of the bone of the elbow; (S, TA;) so in the T; and the A_iborap is another small bone, the head of which is large, and the rest of it small, [the former, i. e. the head.] compactly joined to the qabiyH: (TA:) or [it is more correctly expl. as] the extremity of the bone of the upper half of the arm, next the elbow; (K, TA;) the extremity next the shoulderjoint being called AlHasanu, because of the abundance of the flesh that is upon it: (TA:) or the (??) part of the upper half of the arm; the upper part being called AlHasanu: (Fr. TA:) or the qabiyHaAni are the two slender ends that are at the heads of the *iraAEaAni [here meaning the two bones of the fore arm; (TA:) or the qabiyH is the place of junction [of the bones] of the shank and the thigh, (K, TA,) which are termed qabiyHaAni; (TA;) and it is also called ↓ AlqabaAHu: (K, TA:) accord. to A'Obeyd, kisoru qabiyHK, (L, TA,) which is composed of two syn. words, one prefixed to the other, governing it in the gen. case, (L,) signifies the bone of the saAEid [here meaning the upper half of the arm] from the part next the middle to the elbow. (L, TA; and thus it is expl. in the S and K in art. ksr.)

qub~aAHN *
A bear (K, TA) that is extremely aged, or old and weak. (TA.)
qaAbiHN * [as part, n. of qabuHa]: see 1, first quarter, in two places.

maqobuwHN * , of which the pl. occurs in the Kur [xxviii. 42]. (S, L, Msb,) Removed (S, Msb, K, TA) far (TA) from good, or prosperity, (S, K,) or from all that is good: (L, TA;) or from success, or the attainment of that which he desires or seeks; (Msb;) like as are the dog and the pig: (AZ, L, TA:) or driven away like a dog: (ISd, TA:) or rendered foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous, in form. (I'Ab, TA.) [See also ma$oquwHN, in the first paragraph of art. $qH.]

maqaAbiHu *
Bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, qualities or dispositions [&c.]; contr. of [maHaAsinu and] mamaAdiHu. (L. [See quboHN.])

1 qabara * , aor.
qabura and
qabira , inf. n. qaborN (S, Msb, K) and maqobarN, (K,) He buried a corpse; (S, Msb, K:) concealed it in the earth. (TA.)

4 Aqbrhu *
He made him to be buried: so in the Kur, lxxx. 21: (Fr, S:) where it is meant that man is not made by God to be thrown, when dead, to the dogs, (S,) or to the birds and wild beasts. (Fr.) ― -b2- He ordered that he should be buried. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- [He permitted that he should be buried.] The tribe of Temeem said to El-Hejjáj, who had slain Sálih the son of 'Abder-Rahmán, A^aqobironaA SaAliHFA, meaning, Permit us to bury Sálih. (S, * TA.) You say also Aqbr Alqawoma, meaning, He gave them their slain that they might burg him. (K.) ― -b4- He assigned to him, or made for him, a grave (ISk, S, Msb, K) to be buried in it: (S:) he made him to have a grave. (Mgh.) ― -b5- Accord. to some, He ordered him to dig a grave. (TA.)

qaborN *
A grave, tomb, sepulchre, or place of burial, of a human being: (K:) pl. qubuwr. (S, Msb, K.)
qubarN * : see qab~arN.

qub~arN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ qubarN (K) and ↓ qunoburaA='u (S, K) and ↓ funoburN, this last occurring in a Rejez, to be cited below, (S,) The [lark;] a kind of bird, (S, K,) resembling the Hum~arap; (TA;) a kind of small bird; (Msb:) n. un. qub~arapN (S, Msb, K) and qubarapN (K) and qunoburapN, (S, Msb,) which last is the form used by the vulgar, (S,) or it is not allowable, or it is a form of weak authority, (K,) and is also pronounced qunobarapN: (Msb:) pl. of qnbrA', (S, K,) and of qnbrp, (Msb,) qanaAbiru. (S, Msb, K.) AO cites, from a Rejez of Jendel Ibn-El-Muthennà Et- Tahawee,
jaA='a Al$~itaA='u waA@jovaA^al~a Alqunoburu
[The winter came, and the lark plumed himself]. (S.)
qunoburN * : see qub~arN.
qunoburaA='u * : see qub~arN.
maqobarN * and maqoburN: see maqoburapN.

maqoburapN * and maqobarapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and maqobirapN and miqobarapN (K) and ↓ maqobarN, (Lth, S, Mgh,) with fet-h only, (Mgh,) this last occurring in poetry, (S,) but agreeable with analogy, (IB,) and ↓ maqoburN. (MF, and TA voce A^aluwkN, [under which see some remarks on words of this form in the present work,]) A cemetery, burial-place, or place of graves: (Msb, K:) or the place of a grave: (Mgh:) or the last of the above words has this latter signification: (Lth:) pl. (of mqbrp and mqbr, Mgh) maqaAbiru. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
maqobariY~N * and maqoburiY~N applied to a man [A keeper of a cemetery: or of a grave or tomb: or a gravedigger]. (S.)

1 qabasa naArFA * , aor.
qabisa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. qabosN, (T, K,) He took fire, minohu [from him;] (K;) as also ↓ AqtbshA: (S, K:) or he took fire from the main mass thereof; (Msb;) as also ↓ Aqtbs [alone]. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qabasa EilomFA, (and mina AlEilomi, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He acquired knowledge, minohu [from him;] (Ks, K, TA;) as also ↓ Aqtbshu: (Ks, S, K, TA:) or he learned knowledge; as also ↓ Aqtbs. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence also, qabasa Hum~aY (assumed tropical:) He caught a fever from another; as also ↓ AqtbshA.] You say, h`*ihi Hum~aY qabosK (assumed tropical:) This is a fever caught from another; not accidentally inbred: (A, TA:) but Sgh explains it differently, as signifying an accidental fever. (TA.) And AlHum~aY mino gayorihi walamo ↓ Aqtbs taEoriDo lahu mino nafosihi (assumed tropical:) [He caught the fever from
another; and it did not accidentally come to him from himself]. (A, TA.) -A2- qabasa minohu naArFA, aor.
qabisa , inf. n. qabosN, [He sought from him fire; (see its part. n., below;)] (S;) [and so ↓ Aqtbsh, for Aqtbs minohu naArFA; for you say,] AiqotabasonaA fulaAnFA faA^abaY An yuqobisanaA, meaning, [We sought fire from such a one, and he refused] to give us fire. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, qabasa EilomFA (assumed tropical:) He sought knowledge; (see, again, its part. n., below;) and so ↓ Aqtbshu; as appears from an explanation of the part. n. of this latter also; and from the saying,] A^ataAnaA fulaAnN yaqotabisu AlEiloma faA^aqobasonaAhu, meaning, (assumed tropical:) [Such a one came to us seeking knowledge, and] we taught him. (TA.) -A3- Also, qabasa Aln~aAra He lighted, or kindled, the fire. (IKtt.) -A4- See also 4, passim.

4 Aqbshu *
He gave him a qabas [a brand, or burning stick, or burning piece of fire-wood]: (S, K:) or he gave him fire: and ↓ qabasahu he brought him fire: (TA:) and Aqbshu naArFA (Ks, S, Msb) he gave him fire; (S, * Msb, TA;) as also naArFA ↓ qabasahu. (Yz, Ks, IAar, S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Aqbshu (assumed tropical:) He taught him: (K:) and Aqbshu EilomFA, (Yz, Ks, IAar, S, A, Msb,) and xayorFA, (A, TA,) (assumed tropical:) he taught him knowledge, (S, * Msb, TA,) and (assumed tropical:) good; (TA;) as also EilomFA ↓ qabasahu, (Ks, IAar, S, A, Msb, TA,) and xayorFA: (A:) the latter verb is sometimes thus used; (IAar, TA;) or is allowable: (Ks, TA:) or only the former: (A:) [but it seems to be indicated in the TA, that you say. xayorFA ↓ qabasahu as meaning (assumed tropical:) he brought him good:] and you say also maAlFA ↓ qabasahu [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) he gave him property]. (IAar, TA.) -A2- Aqbs fulaAnFA naArFA He sought fire for such a one. (Yz, * S, * K.)
8 A_iqotabasa see 1, passim.

qabasN *
Fire: (TA:) or a live coal: (Bd, xx. 10:) or [more commonly, and more properly, like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN;] a firebrand ($uEolapN mino naArK, T, S, A, Msb, K, * and Bd ubi supra,) taken from the main mass of fire; (T, A, Msb, * K;) as also ↓ muqotabasN and ↓ miqobasN (A) and ↓ miqobaAsN: (S, A, Msb, K:) the last two [properly] signify a thing [such as a stick, or piece of fire-wood,] with which one has taken fire: (TA:) and qabasN is also explained as signifying a live coal, or piece of fire, (ji*owapN mino naArK,) which one takes upon the end of a stick: (TA:) [and ↓ qabosapN also signifies the same; as appears from an application thereof in the K, art. j*w, where Alji*owapu is explained by Alqabosapu mina Aln~aAri; and from the saying,] maA A^anaA A_il~aA qabosapN mino naArika [lit., I am nought but a piece from thy fire; app. meaning, my subsistence, or the like, is derived from thee]. (A, TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, Hat~aY A^aworaY qabasa AlqaAbisi (assumed tropical:) So that he manifested a light of truth to the seeker thereof. (TA.)

qabosapN * [inf. n. of un. of 1; A single act of taking fire; &c. Hence the saying,] maA zurotuka A_il~aA kaqabosapi AlEajolaAni [I did not visit thee save like the hasty person's single act of taking fire]. (TA.) -A2- See also qabasN.

qaAbisN * [act. part. n. of 1; Taking fire; a taker of fire; &c. Hence the saying,] maA A^anota A_il~aA kAlqaAbisi AlEajolaAni [Thou art none other than like the hasty taker of fire]. (A.) ― -b2- [(assumed tropical:) Acquiring, or learning, knowledge; an acquirer, or a learner, of knowledge.] -A2- Seeking, or a seeker of, fire: pl. A^aqobaAsN; its only broken pl. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Seeking, or a seeker of, knowledge; as also ↓ muqotabisN. (TA.) ― -b3- AlqawaAbisu [pl. of AlqaAbisu, like as AlfawaArisu is pl. of AlfaArisu,] (assumed tropical:) Those who teach men what is good. (TA.)

maqobisN * The place of the fire-brand: i. e., firewood that has been lighted: or charcoal that has become hard; opposed to HumamapN, which is [a piece of] charcoal that does not hold together: pl. maqaAbisu. (Msb.)
miqobasN * : see qabasN.
miqobaAsN * : see qabasN.
muqotabasN * : see qabasN.
muqotabisN * : see qaAbisN.

1 qabaSahu * , aor.
qabiSa , (M, A, K,) inf. n. qaboSN, (S, M,) He took it with the ends of his fingers; (S, M, A, K;) the action which it denotes being less than that termed qaboDN; (M;) the latter signifying the “ taking with the whole of the hand; ” (Bd, xx. 96;) as also ↓ qbS~hu, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. taqobiySN. (TA.) Thus, accord. to one reading, [in the Kur, xx. 96,] faqabaSotu qaboSapF mino A^avari Alr~asuwli; (S, M, A, TA;) and, accord. to another, quboSapF; (TA;) [in each] with S [in both instances] instead of D, with which the passage is commonly read; (TA;) meaning, [And I took with the ends of my fingers somewhat] of the dust from the footstep of the horse of the messenger Gabriel. (Jel.) [But see qbD.] You say also, quboSapF ↓ A_iqotabaSotu [I took for myself somewhat with the ends of my fingers]. (A.) And mino A^anowaArika ↓ jiy^otu liA^aqotabisa waA^aqotabiSa mino A=vaArika (tropical:) [I came to acquire of thy lights of knowledge, and pick up somewhat of thy traditions]. (A.)
2 qab~aSa see 1.
8 A_iqotabaSa see 1, in two places.
qaboSN * : see qiboSN, throughout.

qiboSN *
A great number (AO, S, M, K) of men or people; (S, K;) as also ↓ qaboSN: (M, TA:) thus applied it is like a dim. applied to that which is esteemed great. (El-Fáïk, O.) You say, A_in~ahumo lafiY qiboSi AlHaSaY Verily they are numerous as the pebbles. (TA.) And huwa fiY qiboSi AlHaSaY, and ↓ qaboSihaA, He is in, or among, a multitude that cannot be numbered. (O, TA.) [See also a verse of ElKumeyt cited in the first paragraph of art. vrw.] ― -b2- A place where a number is collected together of ants; as also ↓ qaboSN: (M:) and of bees; as also the latter word: (TA:) or where a great number of ants is collected together: (El-'Eyn, TA:) or where a great quantity of sand is collected together; as also the latter word. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

qaboSapN *
What one takes with the ends of his fingers; as also ↓ quboSapN, (K,) and ↓ qabiySapN: (S, Msb:) [in the L, qubayoSapN; but this is the dim. of the first and second of the above words:] or, accord. to some, the first is a noun signifying the act [of so taking]: (M:) and the second, (M,) or this and the first also, (K,) signifies what one's two hands carry, of food, or wheat: (M, K:) the pl. of ↓ quboSapN is qubaSN. (TA.)
quboSapN * : see qaboSapN, throughout.
qabiySN * : see what next follows.
qabiySapN * : see qaboSapN. ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) and ↓ qabiySN, (M, TA,) Dust, or earth, (M, K,) and pebbles, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) collected together. (M, K, TA.)
qaAbiSapN * sing. of qawaAbiSu; which signifies Bodies [of men]; syn. TawaAy^ifu; and a number collected together. (TA.)

1 qabaDahu * , (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) or qabaDahu biyadihi, (O, K,) aor.
qabiDa , (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. qaboDN, (S, Msb,) He took it with his hand, (A, O, K,) by actual touch, or feel: (O:) or the former signifies he closed his hand upon it: (Lth:) [he grasped it; griped it; clutched it; seized it:] or he took it with the whole of his hand: (Bd, xx. 96:) or i. q. A^aja*ahu [he took it in any manner: he took it with his hand: he took possession of it: and he received it]: (S, M, Mgh, Msb:) and qabaDa Ealayohi, and bihi, (M,) or qabaDa Ealayohi biyadahi, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) he grasped it, clutched it, laid hold upon it, or seized it, with his hand; syn. A^amosakahu: (A, K:) or he seized it (A^anoHaY Ealayohi) with the whole of his hand: (M:) or he closed, or contracted, his fingers upon it: (Mgh, Msb:) it is also said, by MF, that some assert qaboDN to signify the “ taking with the ends of the fingers; ” but this is a mistranscription, for qaboDN, with the unpointed S. (TA [in which it is said, in another place in this art., that ↓ taqobiyDN has also this last signification; but this is evidently, in like manner, a mistranscription, for taqobiyDN.]) You say, qabaDa AlmataAEa [He took, or received, the commodity, or the commodities, or goods]. (A.) And qabaDa minohu Ald~ayona [He took, or received, from him the debt]. (M, K, in art. qDY; &c.). And it is said in the Kur, [xx. 96,] faqabaDotu qaboDapF mino A^avari Alr~asuwli, (M,) and, accord. to an extraordinary reading, ↓ qabiyDapF, (B,) meaning [And I took a handful] of the dust from the footstep of the hoof of the horse of the messenger [Gabriel]: (IJ, M:) and ↓ A_iqotabaDa
mino A^atarihi qaboDapF signifies the same as qabaDa: and qabaSa [q. v.] is [said to be] a dial. form thereof. (TA.) And you say, qabaDa AlT~aAy^ira He collected, or comprehended, the bird in his grasp. (A.) And qabaDa EalaY Eurofi Alfarasi [He grasped, or laid hold upon, the mane of the horse]. (A.) ― -b2- It is also used metaphorically, to denote the having an absolute property in a thing, to dispose of it at pleasure, without respect to the hand; as in the phrase qabaDotu AlA^aroDa, and Ald~aAra, (tropical:) I had, or took, or got, possession of the land, and of the house. (TA.) And [in like manner] it is said in a trad., yaqobiDu A@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa, and Als~amaA='a, (assumed tropical:) God will comprehend, or collect together, [within his sole possession, (see quboDapN,)] the earth, and the heaven. (TA.) [In like manner] you say also, qabaDa EalaY gariymihi (tropical:) [He arrested his debtor: used in this sense in the present day]. (A.) And qabaDa A@ll~`hu ruwHahu (tropical:) God took his soul. (TA.) And qabaDahu A@ll~`hu (tropical:) God caused him to die. (Msb.) And qubiDa (tropical:) He (a man, S, M, A) died: (S M, A, * K:) and also (assumed tropical:) he (a sick man) was at the point of death; in the state of having his soul taken; in the agony of death. (L, TA.) And qabaDotuhu Eani AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) I removed him from the thing, or affair. (Msb.) ― -b3- qabaDahu, aor. as above, (M, K,) and so the inf. n., (S, M, Mgh,) also signifies the (assumed tropical:) contr. of basaTahu; (S, * M, Mgh, * K;) and so ↓ qb~Dhu, (IAar, M,) inf. n. taqobiyDN. (TA.) [As such, (assumed tropical:) He contracted it; or drew it together.] You say, qabaDa rijolahu wabasaTahaA (tropical:) [He contracted his leg, and extended it]. (A.) And qabaDa kaf~ahu [He clenched his hand]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, in art. brjm.). And qabaDa yadahu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) [He drew in his hand from it: or] he refrained from laying hold upon it. (K.) Whence the saying in the Kur, [ix. 68,] wayaqobiDuwna A^ayodiyahumo, meaning (assumed tropical:) [And they draw in their hands, or refrain,] from expenditure, or from paying the [poor-rate called] zakaAp. (TA.) You say also, janaAHahu ↓ qb~D (assumed tropical:) He (a bird) contracted his wing: (M:) or qabaDa, or qabaDa janaAHahu, (assumed tropical:) he contracted his wing to fly. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) qabaDa, aor. as above; (S, K;) or qabuDa (M;) [or both;] inf. n. [of the former] qaboDN (S, K,) and [of the latter, as indicated in the M,] qabaADapN (S, M, A, K) and qabaADN; (M;) (tropical:) He (a bird, S, K, and a horse, A, and a man, S, or other [animal], K,) was quick, (S, M, A, K,) in flight, or in going or pace. (K.) yaqobiDona, said of birds, in the Kur, [lxvii. 19,] is [said to be] an ex. of this signification. (S, K. *) You say also, qabaDati AlA_ibilu (tropical:) The camels were quick in their pace; at every spring therein, putting their legs together. (A.) And ↓ A_inoqabaDa (tropical:) He, or it, (a company of men, M,) went, or journeyed, and was quick. (Lth, M, K.) And fiY fulaAnN ↓ A_inoqabaDa HaAjatihi (tropical:) Such a one was quick, and light, or active, in accomplishing his want. (A.) And qaboDN also signifies i. q. nazowN (assumed tropical:) [The act of leaping, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- [Also, as contr. of basaTahu,] (assumed tropical:) He collected it together. (Az.) And hence, (Az,) qabaDa AlA_ibila, (Az, M,) aor.
qabiDa , inf. n. qaboDN (Az, S, M) (assumed tropical:) He drove (Az, S, M) the camels violently, or roughly, (Az, M.) or quickly: (S:) because the driver collects them together, when he desires to drive them; for when they disperse themselves from him, the driving of them is difficult: (Az, TA:) and bihaA ↓ A_inoqabaDa [signifies the same, or, agreeably with an explanation given above, (tropical:) he went quickly with them]. (M.) And AlEayoru yaqobiDu EaAnatahu (assumed tropical:) The he-ass drives away his she-ass. (M.) ― -b5- [As such also,] qabaDahu; (A;) and ↓ qb~Dhu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. taqobiyDN; (S;) (tropical:) He, or it, drew it, collected it, or gathered it, together; contracted it, shrank it, or wrinkled it. (S, M, A, * K.) You say, qabaDa wajohahu (tropical:) He, or it, contracted, or wrinkled, his face]. (A.) And qabaDati Aln~aAru Aljilodapa (tropical:) [The fire contracted, shrank, or shrivelled, the piece of skin]. (A.) And ↓ qab~aDa maA bayoni Eayonayohi (assumed tropical:) He contracted, or wrinkled, the part between his eyes. (M, TA.) And ↓ yawomN yuqab~iDu maA bayona AlEayonayoni (assumed tropical:) [A day that contracts, or wrinkles, the part between the eyes]; a metonymical phrase, denoting vehemence of fear, or of war. (M, TA. *) And in like manner you say, AlHa$aY ↓ yawomN yuqab~iDu (assumed tropical:) [A day that contracts the bowels]. (M.) [And hence qabaDa, aor. and inf. n. as first mentioned, (assumed tropical:) It (a medicine, or food, &c.,) astringed, or constipated. And (assumed tropical:) It (food) was astringent in taste; as also ↓ taqab~aDa.] ― -b6- As such also, qabaDahu, signifies (assumed tropical:) He straitened it; scanted it; made it scanty. (Msb, TA.) You say, qabaDa A@ll~`hu Alrizoqa, aor. and inf. n. as first mentioned, (assumed tropical:) God straitened, scanted, or made scanty, the means of subsistence. (Msb.) And it is said in the Kur, [ii. 246,] waA@ll~`hu yaqobiDu wayabosuTu (assumed tropical:) And God straitens, or scants, or makes scanty, the means of subsistence, to some, (Bd, Msb, * TA, *) or withholds the means of subsistence from whom He will, (Jel,) and amplifies, enlarges, or makes ample or plentiful, the same, (Bd, Msb, Jel, TA,) to some, (Bd, TA,) or to whom He will. (Jel.) ― -b7- [As such also, (assumed tropical:) He abridged his liberty.] You say, fulaAnN yabosuTu gabiydahu vum~a yaqobiDuhumo (tropical:) [Such a one enlarges the liberty of his slaves; then abridges their liberty]. (A.) ― -b8- [As such also, (tropical:) He, or it, contracted his heart; i. e. distressed him; grieved him.] You say, A_in~ahu yaqobiDuniY maA yaqobiDuka wayabosuTuniY maA yabosuTuka (tropical:) Verily what distresses thee, or grieves thee, distresses, or grieves, me; and what rejoices thee rejoices me]. (A.) [And it is related in a trad., that Mohammad said, faATimapu min~iY yaqobiDuniY maA qabaDahaA wayabosuTuniY maA basaTahAa (tropical:) [Fátimeh is as though she were a part of me: what hath distressed her, or grieved her, distresses, or grieves, me; and what hath rejoiced her rejoices me]. (TA.) Or the phrase A_in~ahu layaqobiDuniY maA qabaDaka, mentioned by Lth, means (assumed tropical:) Verily what hath annoyed and angered thee annoys and angers me. (Az, TA.) qaboDN and basoTN are terms applied by the investigators of truth among the Soofees to two contrary states of the heart, from both of which it is seldom or never free: the former being an affection of the heart withholding it from dilatation and joy; whether the cause thereof be known, as the remembrance of a sin or an offence, or of an omission, or be not known; and some of them make other divisions thereof. (TA.) [In like manner] you say also, Ean~aA famaA qabaDaka ↓ AinoqabaDotu (tropical:) [Thou shrankest from us: and what made thee to shrink?]. (A.) ― -b9- [As such also, (tropical:) He, or it, made him close-fisted, tenacious, or niggardly.] You say, Alxayoru yaqobiDuhu waAl$~ar~u yabosuTuhu (tropical:) [Wealth makes him close-fisted, tenacious, or niggardly; and poverty makes him open-handed, liberal, or generous]. (A.)

2 qab~aDa see a remark appended to the first sentence in this art. : ― -b2- see also fabaDahu as contr. of basaTahu, in six places. ― -b3- qab~aDahu AlmaAla, (S, * M, K, *) or AlmataAEa, (A,) inf. n. taqobiyDN, (S, K,) He gave to him, (S, M, K,) in his grasp, or possession, (K,) i. e. to him who should receive it, (S,) the property, (S, M,) or commodity, or commodities, or goods; (A;) i. e. he transferred it to his possession; (TA;) [lit. he made him to take it, to take it with his hand, to grasp it, or to receive it;] as also A_iy~aAhu ↓ A^aqobaDahu. (A.)
3 qAbDhu * , inf. n. muqaAbaDapN (AZ, A) and qibaADN, (Er-Rághib, TA in art. $rY,) He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him. (AZ, in TA, art, xwS.) [See also qaAyaDahu.]
4 AqbDhu AlmataAEa * [or AlmaAla]: see 2. -A2- AlqbDhu He put, or made, a handle to it, (S, M, A, K,) namely a knife, (S, M, A,) and a sword. (S, K.)

5 tqb~D * quasi-pass. of qab~aDahu as contr. of basaTahu; (M;) as also ↓ AinoqabaDa is of qabaDahu in the same sense, (S, * M, K, *) being contr. of AinobasaTa. (S, K.) [As such,] both signify (assumed tropical:) It became drawn, collected, or gathered, together; or it drew, collected, or gathered, itself together; or contracted; or shrank; syn. of the former, tajam~aEa; (TA;) and of the latter, AinoDam~a [which also signifies it became drawn and joined, or adjoined, to another thing; &c.]. (O, K.) So the latter signifies in the phrase fiY HaAjatiY ↓ AnqbD (assumed tropical:) [It became comprised in, or adjoined to, the object of my want]. (O.) ― -b2- [As such also,] the former signifies (tropical:) It (a man's face, A, or the part between the eyes, M,) became contracted, or wrinkled; (M, A; *) and in like manner a piece of skin, in, or upon, a fire; meaning it became contracted, shrunken, or shrivelled; it shrank: (so in different copies of the S:) or it (skin, K, or the skin of a man, TA) became contracted, or shrunken; (K, TA;) and so an old man. (A.) ― -b3- [As such also,] taqb~D Eanohu (tropical:) He shrank, or shrank with aversion, from him, or it; (S, M, A, K;) as also Eanohu ↓ AinoqabaDa: (A:) [see an ex. of the latter near the end of 1.] ↓ AlAinoqibaADu Eani Aln~aAsi also signifies (assumed tropical:) The withdrawing, removing, or retiring, from men. (TA.) And Eani AlA^amori ↓ AinoqabaDa (assumed tropical:) He removed, or became
removed, from the thing, or affair. (Msb.) ― -b4- tqb~D EalaY AlA^amori (tropical:) He paused, or waited, at the thing, or affair; syn. tawaq~afa. (M, A.) ― -b5- tqb~D A_ilayohi (assumed tropical:) He leaped, or sprang, towards him. (Sgh, K.) ― -b6- See also 1; last third of the paragraph.
6 tqAbD AlmutayaAyiEaAni * [The two parties in an affair of traffic bartered, or exchanged commodities, each with the other: see 3]. (A.)

7 AnqbD *
It (a thing) became maqobuwD [meaning taken, taken with the hand, grasped, or received]. (S.) ― -b2- See also 5, in six places. ― -b3- And see 1, in three places, about the middle of the paragraph.

8 AqtbDhu linafosihi * [He took it, took it with his hand, grasped it, clutched it, seized it, took possession of it, or received it, for himself]. (A.) See an ex. in 1, before the first break in the paragraph.

qaboDN * The act of taking, taking with the hand; [grasping; clutching; seizing;] taking possession of; or receiving. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence], Possession; (S, TA;) as also ↓ qaboDapN: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, TA:) or the latter is a n. un. [signifying an act of taking, or taking with the hand; a grasp; a seizure; &c.]. (TA.) You say, SaAra Al$~aYo'u fiY qaboDika, and ↓ qaboDatika, The thing became in thy possession. (S, M. *) And h`*ihi Ald~aAru fiY qaboDiY, (TA,) and ↓ qaboDatiY, (M, TA,) This house is in my possession; (M, TA;) like as you say, fiY yadaY. (TA.)

qabaDN *
i. q. maqobuwDN; (Mgh, K;) like hadamN in the sense of mahoduwmN, and nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN; (TA;) meaning What is taken, of articles of property (S, M) of people: (S:) what is collected, (Lth,) or taken and collected, (Mgh,) of spoils, before they are divided. (Lth, Mgh.) You say, daxala maAlu fulaAnK fiY AlqabaDi The property of such a one entered into what was taken of the articles of property of the people. (S.) And A_iToraHahu fiY AlqabaDi (A, Mgh) Throw thou it among the things that have been taken: (Mgh:) said to Saad Ibn-Abee- Wakkás, when he slew Sa'eed Ibn-El-'Ás, and took his sword: so in a trad. (TA.) And in another trad. it is said, juEila salomaAnu EalaY qabaDK Selmán was set over spoils that were taken and yet undivided, to guard and divide them. (Mgh.)

qaboDapN * : [pl. qabaDaAtN:] see qaboDN, in three places. ― -b2- See also quboDapN, in four places. ― -b3- And see maqobiDN. ― -b4- Also, [The measure of a man's fist, from side to side;] four finger-breadths; (Mgh, Msb, voce jariybN;) the sixth part of the common *iraAE [or cubit: but in the present day, the measure of a man's fist with the thumb erect; which is about six inches and a quarter]: pl. qabaDaAtN. (Mgh, Msb, vocibus *iraAEN and jariybN.)

quboDapN * (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) [A handful;] what one takes with the hand, or grasps; (S, K;) mino ka*aA [of such a thing]; (Mgh;) as, for instance, mino sawiyqK [of meal of parched barley]; (S;) or mino tamorK [of dates]; (S, A, Msb;) i. e. kaf~AF; (S;) as also ↓ qaboDapN; (S, M, A, K;) but the former is the more common; (S, K;) and ↓ qabiyDapN: (B:) or the first is a subst. in the sense of maqobuwDN, and the second is a n. un.: (TA:) the pl. of the first is qubaDN. (TA.) You say also, kaf~iY ↓ h`*aA qaboDapu This is the quantity that my hand grasps. (M.) See two other exs. of the second word, and an ex. of the third, in 1, before the first break in the paragraph. It is also said in the Kur, [xxxix. 67,] waA@loA^aroDu jamiyEFA yawoma AlqiyaAmapi ↓ qaboDatuhu, i. e. quboDatuhu, for qaboDapN is an inf. n. [of un.] used as a subst., or is for *aAtu qaboDapK, (Bd,) and the literal signification is, [And the earth altogether shall be] his handful [on the day of resurrection]; (Bd, Jel;) meaning in his possession (Jel, TA) alone, (TA,) and at his free and absolute disposal: (Jel:) Th says, that this is like the phrase h`*ihi Ald~aAru fiY qaboDatiY, meaning as explained above, voce qaboDN; but this opinion is not valid:) (M:) another reading is ↓ qaboDatahu, in the accus. case, (M, Bd,) as an adv. n.; that which is determinate being thus likened to what is vague; (Bd;) and this is allowed by some of the grammarians; but it is not allowed by any one of the grammarians of El-Basrah. (M.) It is also said, in the trad. of Bilál and the dates, fajaEala yajiYo'u bihi qubaDFA qubaDFA [And he set about bringing them (the pronoun referring to Alt~amor the dates) handfuls by handfuls]. (TA.)

qubaDapN * , (K,) or qubaDapN rufaDapN, (S, M, A, TA,) to this latter, not to the former alone, the following explanation applies, (TA,) A man who lays hold upon a thing, and then leaves it without delay. (S, M, A, K.) And the former, A pastor who draws his sheep or goats together, not going far and wide in pasturing them: (S:) or who manages well (A, K) for his sheep or goats, (K,) or for his beasts, collecting them together, and, when he finds a place of pasture, spreads them abroad: (A:) and the latter, a pastor who manages well, and is gentle with his pasturing beasts, collecting them together and driving them, when their place of pasturage becomes wanting in herbage, and, when they light upon a piece of herbage, leaves them to spread abroad and pasture at pleasure: (Az, TA:) or who collects together his camels, and drives them until he brings them whithersoever he will. (M.) [See also art. rfD.]
qabiyDN * : see qaAbiDN, in three places.
qabiyDapN * : see quboDapN, in two places.
qab~aADN * : see qaAbiD; each in two places.
qab~aADapN * : see qaAbiDN; each in two places.

qaAbiDN *
Taking with the hand: [or in any manner: taking possession of: receiving: (see 1:)] grasping, clutching, or seizing, with the hand: and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense,] ↓ qab~aADN: (K:) or the latter is of the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh, applied to him who [grasps or] collects everything: (Aboo-'Othmán El-Mázinee:) and ↓ qb~aADapN [which is doubly intensive]; (K;) the p in this last not denoting the fem. gender. (TA.) qaAbiDu AlA^arowaAHi [(tropical:) The taker of the souls] is an appellation of [the Angel of Death,] 'Izrá-eel, or 'Azrá-eel. (TA.) And AlqaAbiDu, one of the names of God, signifies (tropical:) The Withholder [or Straitener or Scanter] of the means of subsistence, and of other things, from his servants, by his graciousness and his wisdom: and the Taker of souls, at the time of death. (TA.) ― -b2- A bird (assumed tropical:) contracting his wing to fly. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) qaAbiDN (S, K) and ↓ qabiyDN (S, A, K) A bird, (K,) or horse, (A,) or other [animal], (K,) (tropical:) quick (A, K) in flight, or in going or pace: (K:) or a man (assumed tropical:) light, or active, and quick: (S:) and [hence, app.,] the latter also signifies (assumed tropical:) an intelligent man, who keeps, or adheres, to his art, or work. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And Al$~ad~i ↓ qabiyDu A horse, (S, K, in [some of] the copies of the K “ a man, ” which is a mistake, though it seems to be also applied to a man, TA,) or a beast of carriage, (L,) (assumed tropical:) quick in the shifting of the legs from place to place [in running]. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- A camel-driver (assumed tropical:) driving quickly; a quick driver; and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense,] ↓ qab~aADN, and [in a doubly intensive sense] ↓ qab~aADapN: (S:) or the last signifies (assumed tropical:) driving away vehemently; the p denoting intensiveness; and is applied to an ass driving away his she-ass, and to a camel-driver. (M.) [See an ex. of the first, voce EaAy^iDF, in art. EwD.] ― -b4- [Applied to medicine, food, &c., (assumed tropical:) Astringent, or constipating.]

maqobaDN *
A place of taking, taking with the hand, [grasping, clutching, seizing,] or receiving: extr. [in form, for by rule it should be maqobiDN]. (M.) See also what next follows.

maqobiDN * (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ maqobaDN, (Lth, M, Msb, K,) but the former is the more common and the better known, (Lth,) and ↓ miqobaDN, (M, K,) and with p, (K,) i. e. ↓ maqobiDapN, and ↓ miqobaDapN, (M,) The handle; or part where it is grasped, (S, M, A, * Mgh, * Msb, K,) by the hand, (Msb,) or with the whole hand; (S;) of a sword, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ qaboDapN is said to signify the same; (TA;) or of a knife, (M, A,) and of a bow, (S, A,) and of a whip, (A,) &c., (K,) or of anything: (M:) or ↓ maqobiDapN or ↓ miqobaDapN signifies the place of the hand of a spear or spear-shaft: (ISh:) pl. maqaAbiDu. (A.)
miqobaDN * : see maqobaDN.
maqobiDapN * and miqobaDapN: see maqobiDN, in two places.
maqobuwDN * pass. part. n. of qabaDahu. See qabaDN, and quboDapN. ― -b2- (tropical:) Taken to the mercy of God; (A;) dead. (S.)
mutaqab~iDN * : see what next follows.
munoqab~iDN * , (O, TS,) or ↓ mataqab~iDN, (K,) A lion prepared to spring: (K:) or a lion drawn together: and one prepared to spring: (O, TA:) but the conjunction should rather be omitted. (TA.)

1 qabaTahu * , aor.
qabiTa , so in the margin of a copy of the S, (TA,) inf. n. qaboTN, (TS, O, K,) He collected it together, or comprehended it, with his hand: (TS, O, K:) [like qabaDahu:) in the TS given as on the authority of IDrd: in the O as on that of IF. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He mixed it. (TA.)

2 qab~aTa [qb~T wajohahu He contracted his face much; made it much contracted, or very austere or morose:] taqobiyTu Alwajohi is syn. with taqobiyTuhu; (Yaa- koob, K;) and is formed from the latter by transposition. (TA.)

AlqiboTu * [The Copts; often called by themselves AlquboTu;] a certain people, or nation, in Egypt; (TA;) the original, or genuine, people of Egypt; (S, K, TA;) the Christians of Egypt: (Msb:) n. un. ↓ qiboTiY~N; (S, Msb, K;) fem. with p: (Msb, K:) you say A_imoraA^apN qiboTiy~apN [A Copt woman]: (Msb:) and jamaAEapN qiboTiy~apN and A^aqobaATN [A company of Copts; AqbAT being a pl. of qiboTN]. (TA.) [See quboTiY~N.] Authors differ respecting their pedigree: some say, that AlqiboTu was son of HaAm [or Ham], son of nuwH [or Noah]: the author of the Shejereh, that miSoraAy^iym [or Mizraïm] the son of HAm left issue from luw*iym [or Ludim], and that lw*ym are the qiboT of Egypt, in the Sa'eed: Aboo-Háshim Ahmad Ibn-Jaafar El-'Abbásee, the genealogist, says, that they are the children of qiboT son of miSor son of quwT [a mistranscription for fuwT, the Phut of the English Bible, A. V.,] son of HAm: and this is verified by Ibn-El-Joowánee the genealogist. (TA.)

quboTiY~N *
A kind of thin, or fine, (Mgh, Msb,) white, (Mgh,) cloth, (Mgh, Msb,) of linen, (Msb,) made in Egypt; so called in relation to the qiboT, irregularly, to distinguish between it and the man, who is called qiboTiY~N: (Mgh, Msb:) so says Lth, respecting these two forms: (TA:) you also say, ↓ viyaAbN qiboTiy~apN, with kesr; but when you convert the rel. n. into a subst, you say quboTiy~apN, with damm, to distinguish the subst. from the rel. n. without vyAb; like as you say, rimaAHN xaT~iy~apN, and xiT~iy~apN, with kesr, when you do not mention the rmAH: so says Kh: (Msb in art. xT:) it is said in the K, that AlquboTiy~apu, with damm, signifies a kind of cloths, so called in relation to the qiboT; and sometimes it is with kesr; which is a plain assertion that the form with damm is the more common: but in the S it is said, that AlqiboTiy~ipu signifies certain white, thin, or fine, cloths, of linen, made in Egypt; and sometimes it is with damm, because they make a change in the rel. n., as in suholiY~N and duhoriY~N, which (as SM adds) are from saholN and dahorN; and this indicates that the regular form, with kesr, is the more common: (TA:) the pl. is qabaATiY~N (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and qabaATiY: (K [but the latter, being indeterminate, should be written qabaATK, like mahaArK &c.:]) Sh says, that the qabaATiY~ are a kind of cloths inclining to fineness and thinness and whiteness. (TA.)
qiboTiY~N * and qiboTiy~apN: see AlqiboTu and quboTiY~N.
qubayoTaA='u * : see what next follows.
qub~aATN * : see what next follows.
qub~ayoTN * : see what next follows.

qub~ayoTaY * and ↓ qubayoTaA='u, the former with teshdeed and with a short final alif, and the latter without teshdeed and with a long final alif, (S, Msb, K, *) and ↓ qub~ayoTN and ↓ qub~aATN, (S, K,) i. q. naATifN; (S, Msb, K;) [described by Golius, on the authority of an Arabic and Persian vocabulary, entitled ktAb AlsAmY fY AlAsAmY, as a very white kind of sweetmeat, which consists of juice of grapes, with an addition of other things, cooked so that it becomes white and hard:] derived from qaboTN signifying the act of “ collecting together. ” (TA.)
qun~abiyTN * : see art. qnbT.
See Supplement

1 qat~a * , (M, K, *) or qat~a AlHadiyva or AlA^aHaAdiyva, (S, O, TA,) aor.
qatu3a , (S, M, O,) inf. n. qat~N, (S, M, O, K,) with which ↓ qit~iytaY is syn. [either as an inf. n., app. in an intensive sense, or as a simple subst.]; (O, K;) and so too is taqotiytN [as inf. n. of ↓ qt~t], (K,) or so is taqotiytu AlHadiyvi; (O;) and so is qatoqatapN [as inf. n. of ↓ qatofata], (K,) or so is qatoqatapu AlHadiyvi; (O;) i. q. nam~a, (M,) or nam~a AlHadiyva (S, O, K, * TA) or AlA^aHaAdiyva, (S, O, TA,) i. e. [He uttered calumny; or] he made known, divulged, or told, discourse, or conversation, in a malicious, or mischievous, manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like; (TA;) or qat~a AlHadiyva signifies he falsified and embellished discourse, or conversation: (A:) it is said that Alqat~, which signifies Aln~amiymapu [i. e. the uttering, or utterance, of calumny], (M, L,) [and] so does ↓ Alqit~iytaY, (S,) is from AlHadiyva ↓ tqt~t, meaning he sought time after time to obtain a knowledge of discourse, or conversation, and listened thereto: (M, L:) and ↓ Alqit~iytaY signifies [also] the seeking time after time to obtain a knowledge of namaAy^im [i. e. calumnies, pl. of namiymapN]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And qat~N [app. as an inf. n.] signifies The lying, or uttering of falsehood: (K:) [or] a prepared lying. (M.) ― -b3- And qat~ahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. qat~N, (TA,) signifies qad~ahu [meaning He cut it out, or shaped it, in any manner, whether lengthwise or otherwise]. (K, TA.) One says, huwa Hasanu Alqat~i, meaning Hasanu Alqad~i [i. e. He is goodly, or beautiful, in conformation]: and a poet says,
kaA^an~a vadoyayohaA A_i*aA maA A@boranotaY
Huq~aAni mino EaAjK A^ujiydaA qat~aA
meaning qad~FA and xaroTFA [i. e. As though her two breasts, when they come forth unexpectedly (a meaning of AbrntY expl. in the L, in art. brt, on the authority of Lh, but it is here expl. in the TA as signifying AntSb, so that the phrase may be rendered either when appearing unexpectedly, or when standing out), were two round boxes of ivory, excellently cut out, or shaped, and made smooth in their surfaces]: (O, TA: *) regarding them as one member, he has made the verb singular. (O.) ― -b4- Also He prepared, disposed, or arranged, it; or put it into a right, or good, state. (M, K.) ― -b5- And He collected it together by little and little. (M, K.) ― -b6- And He made it, or made it to appear, to be little; syn. qal~alahu. (M, K.) And qat~a A^avarahu, (M, K,) aor.
qatu3a , inf. n. qat~N, (M,) He followed, or followed after, his track, or footsteps, in pursuit; or endeavoured to track him, or trace him. (M, K.) ― -b7- And qat~N signifies also The following the footsteps of a man secretly, in order to know what he desires [to do]. (O, K.) ― -b8- And A pastor's smelling the odour of a camel (O, K) that is mahoyuwm (K) [i. e.] that is smitten by the [disease termed] huyaAm. (O, TA. [Freytag, supposing mahoyuwm in this explanation in the K to be syn. with haAy^im, renders the verb as meaning He (a pastor) smelt the urine of a straying camel, that he might know its way.]) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

2 qat~a3a see 1, first sentence. -A2- taqotiytN also signifies The collecting of odoriferous substances, or aromatics, (O, K,) of all sorts, in a cooking-pot, (O,) and cooking them: (O, K:) and one does not say qut~ita except of olive-oil when it is thus prepared [i. e. it means it was, or has been, cooked with all sorts of odoriferous substances, or aromatics]: thus says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh: IF adds that Alz~ayoti ↓ qat~u is like taqotiytuhu [in meaning]: and Zj says that Ald~uhona ↓ Aiqotat~u means the same as qat~at~uhu [i. e. I cooked the oil with all sorts of odoriferous substances, &c.]. (O.) [See also muqat~atN, below.]
5 taqat~a3a see 1, first sentence.

8 Aiqotat~ahu *
He, or it, extirpated, or eradicated, him, or it. (M, K.) -A2- See also 2.
R. Q. 1 qatoqata * , inf. n. qatoqatapN: see 1, first sentence.

qat~N * inf. n. of qat~a [q. v.]. (S, M, O, K.) -A2- And i. q. fiSofiSapN, (S, M, O, Msb,) or A_isofisatN, (Mgh, K,) both of which signify the same, i. e. A certain food, or fodder, of beasts, as is said in the Nh; (TA;) [a species of trefoil, or clover;] or (M, K) when dry: (M, Mgh, O, Msb:) accord.
to Sb, a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.], (M,) sing., or n. un., qat~apN, (T, S, M, O,) like as tamorapN is of tamorN. (T, S, O.) ― -b2- And A certain wild grain, not raised by man; which the people of the desert, on the occasion of a year of drought, when they are destitute of milk and dates and the like for their food, bruise and grind; being content therewith notwithstanding its coarseness. (T, Msb, TA.)
qatuwtN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

qat~aAtN * (S, M, A, O, K) and ↓ qatuwtN and ↓ qit~iytaY, (M, K,) this last being used as an inf. n. and as an epithet, (TA,) A man wont to calumniate; or to make known, divulge, or tell, discourse, or conversation, in a malicious, or mischievous, manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like; (S, * M, * A, * O, * K, * TA;) [or wont to falsify and embellish discourse, or conversation: (see 1:)] or who listens to the discourse, or conversation, of others, without their knowing; (M, K, TA;) whether he make it known in the manner explained above, or not: (M, * K, * TA:) or qat~aAtN, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, signifies one who hears the discourses, or conversations, of men, and informs their enemies: or, as some say, one who is with a people, or party, and calumniates them: (TA:) it is said in a trad. (S, O) of the Prophet (O) that the qat~aAt will not enter Paradise: (S, O:) the epithets qat~aAtapN and ↓ fatuwtN are applied to a woman: (M, TA:) and the pl. of qat~aAtN is qut~aAtN, with damm. (TA.)
qit~iytY * : see 1, in three places: ― -b2- and see qat~aAtN.

muqat~atN * Oil, (M, A, Mgh,) or olive-oil, (O, K,) perfumed, or rendered fragrant, (M, A, Mgh, O,) by its being (Mgh, O) cooked with sweet-smelling plants: (M, Mgh, O, K:) or mixed with other oils of fragrant odour: (Th, M, K: *) or olive-oil cooked with sweet-smelling plants, not mixed with perfume: so says IAth: or olive-oil boiled over the fire with odoriferous substances, or aromatics. (TA.) [See also its verb.]

qawolN maqotuwtN *
i. q. mako*uwbN [meaning mako*uwbN fiyhi A saying in which a falsehood, or lie, is told]; (M, TA;) i. e. a false saying, or lie: (TA:) or a saying that is falsified, or embellished with lies: (JK:) or a misreported saying; a reported saying that is misrepresented: (TA:) it occurs in the saying (O, TA) of Ru-beh, (O,)
qulotu waqawoliY Einodahumo maqotuwtu
[I said, and my saying was in their estimation false, or falsified, &c.]. (O, TA.)
1 qatobN * The feeding (O, K) a guest (O) with [the intestines called] A^aqotaAb [pl. of qitobN or of qitobapN] roasted, or broiled: (O, K:) an inf. n. of which the verb is qataba. (TK.)

2 qut~iba kaAhiluhu * , said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, such as is termed A^ajonaA^u. (JK. [See rajulN muqat~abu AlkaAhili, below.] ― -b2- And one says, fiY kaAhili Alfarasi taqotiybN i. e. janaA^N (tropical:) [app. meaning In the withers of the horse is a bending over the breast]. (A.)

4 A^aqotabotu AlbaEiyra * , (S, A,) inf. n. A_iqotaAbN, (S, K,) I bound upon the camel the [saddle called] qatab. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (A,) Aqtbhu yamiynFA, (T, A, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He imposed upon him a hard, or severe, oath; (T, A, O, K; *) as though he put upon him a [saddle of the kind called] qatab: and in like manner, Aqtbhu fiY Alyamiyni: (A:) and Aqtb Ealayohi fiY Alyamiyni. (T, O.) And Aqtbhu Ald~ayonu (tropical:) Debt, or the debt, pressed heavily upon him. (A.)

qitobN * (Ks, S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ qitobapN (As, S, ISd, O, Msb, K) and ↓ qatabN (TA) i. q. miEFY [i. e An intestine of those into which the food passes from the stomach]: (S, O, Msb, K:) or (S, O, K,) as AO says of the first of these words, (S, O,) an intestine of the belly that winds round, or takes a coiled form; (S, O, K;) and such as take this form are [also] called the HawaAyaA; but the A^amoEaA=' are the A^aqoSaAb: (S, O:) qitobN is of the fem. gender: (Ks, S, O:) and its pl. is A^aqotaAbN: (Ks, S, O, Msb:) or the sing. of this pl. is ↓ qitobapN: and the dim. is ↓ qutayobapN. (As, S, O, Msb, K.) -A2- And qitobN signifies also All the apparatus, or furniture, of the saAniyap [i. e. camel, or she-camel, upon which water is drawn] (S, ISd, O, K;) consisting of the A^aEolaAq [pl. of EalaqN q. v.] of the sAnyp, and the ropes thereof. (S, ISd, O.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

qatabN *
A small raHol [or camel's saddle], (S, O,) or a small [camel's saddle such as is called A_ikaAf, (ISd, K,) of a size corresponding to the hump: (S, ISd, O, K:) or [a sort of pack-saddle for a camel; i. e.] the A_ikaAf that is put upon such beasts [or camels] as transport burdens: (A:) or [simply] i. q. A_ikaAfN; as also ↓ qitobN; but the former is the more common: (K:) or the ↓ qitob is only what belongs to the saAniyap [meaning as expl. in the next preceding paragraph], (As, TA,) or to the camel that draws water (lilobaEiyri Als~aAniY); (JK;) and the A_ikaAf belongs to the ass, or is common to the ass and the mule and the camel: (TA:) the qanab belongs to the camel: (Msb:) the word thus applied is sometimes fem., though more commonly masc.: and its dim. is ↓ qutayobapN: (TA:) the pl. is A^aqotaAbN, (Sb, A, Msb, K, TA,) only, (Sb, TA.) It is said in a trad. that the woman on the occasion of her bringing forth used to be seated upon a qatab, in order that her parturition might be more easy. (O.) ― -b2- huwa qanabN yaEaD~u biAlgaAribi (tropical:) [lit. He is a saddle that pinches the fore part of the hump] and qatabN miloHaAHN (tropical:) [a pinching, galling, saddle] are said of an importunate person. (A.) -A2- See also qitobN.
qatibN * [in the O without any vowel-sign] Narrow, or contracted, (O, K, TA,) in disposition, (TA,) quickly excited to anger. (O, K, TA.)
qitobapN * : see qitobN, in two places.
qatuwbN * : see the paragraph here following.

qatuwbapN *
Camels upon which the [kind of saddle called] qatab is bound: (S, A, O, K, TA:) or a camel upon which the qatab may be put: (Lh, TA:) the p is affixed because the word is similar to HaluwbapN and rakuwbapN, (S, O, TA,) having the signification of a pass. part. n.; but one may elide the p, saying ↓ qatuwbN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA Sadaqapa fiY AlA_ibili Alqatuwbapi, meaning There is no poor rate in the case of the working camels, (O, TA,) but only in the case of the pasturing. (O.) And you say, kaA^an~iY lahumo qatuwbapN wakaA^an~a maw^uwnatahumo EalaY~a makotuwbapN (tropical:) [I am as though I were to them a working camel, and as though their food were prescribed as incumbent on me]. (A.)
qutayobapN * a dim. n.: see qitobN: -A2- and qatabN.
muqotabN Ealayohi * (tropical:) One upon whom is imposed a hard, or severe, oath. (T, O, TA.)
rajulN muqat~abu AlkaAhili * (tropical:) i. q. A^ajonaA^u [app. meaning A man having a bending of the upper part of the back over the breast]. (JK, A. *)

1 qatidati AlA_ibilu * , (L, K, TA,) aor.
qatada , (K, TA,) inf. n. qatadN, (TA,) The camels had a complaint (L, K, TA) of their bellies (L, TA) in consequence of eating of the trees called qataAd [q. v.]. (L, K, TA.)

2 Alt~aqotiydu * [or taqotiydu AlqataAdi] signifies The cutting of the trees called qataAd [q. v.], and burning them, (L, K,) i. e. burning [off] their thorns, (L,) and then giving them as fodder to the camels, (L, K,) which fatten upon them on the occasion of drought: (L:) one says, qt~d AlqataAda, inf. n. as above, He (a man) scorched, or slightly burned, the extremities of the qtAd with fire: (O:) the man comes, in the year of drought, and kindles fire among them, so that he burns their thorns, then he feeds his camels therewith: (T, O, TA:) one says of him who does this, qt~d A_ibilahu [i. e. He fed his camels with qtAd thus prepared]: so says Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) and the act [of burning &c.] is called Alt~aqotiydu. (T, TA.)

qatadN * (S, O, L) and ↓ qatidN (Kr, L) The wood of a [camel's saddle that is called] raHol: (S, O, L:) or one of the things that compose the apparatus of a raHol: or the whole apparatus thereof: (L:) pl. [of mult.] qutuwdN and [of pauc.] A^aqotaAdN (S, O, L) and A^aqotudN: (L:) but accord. to the Basrees, qutuwdN, signifying the pieces of wood of a raHol, has no singular. (Ham p. 662.)

qatidN * [part. n. of qatida said of a camel: see 1]. One says A_ibilN qatidapN, and qataAdaY, [the latter being pl. of the former,) Camels having a complaint (Ks, S, O, K) of their bellies (Ks, S, O) in consequence of eating of the trees called qataAd: (Ks, S, O, K:) like as one says ramivapN and ramaAvaY. (Ks, S, O.) -A2- See also qatadN.

qataAdN * [a coll. gen. n., The tragacanth-tree;] a species of thorny tree; this is the larger sort; (S;) a species of thorny and hard tree, which bears a pod, and of which the fruit is like that of the samur [or gum-acacia-tree], growing in Nejd and Tihámeh; n. un. with p; (L;) it is a species of hard tree having thorns like needles; (K;) a species of tree having thorns like needles, and a small dust-coloured leaf, and a fruit growing therewith of the same colour, resembling the date-stone; (AHn, O, * L;) the large qtAd [thus described] produces large wood, and its thorns are curved and short, and it is of the [class termed] EiDaAh; (Aboo-Ziyád, L;) or it is not reckoned among the EiDaAh: (AHn, L: [but this assertion may perhaps be meant to apply to the smaller sort: respecting the larger, see also 1 and 2:]) the smaller sort is a species of tree of which the fruit is a bladder (nuf~aAxap) like that of the Eu$ar [q. v.]; (S, O, L;) accord. to the ancient Arabs of the desert, it is not tall, being of the size of a man sitting; (L;) and this sort grows upwards, no part of it spreading, consisting of twigs, or shoots, in a collected state, every one of which is full of thorns from its top to its bottom. (Aboo-Ziyád, L.) It is said in a prov., mino duwnihi xaroTu AlqataAdi [expl. in art. xrT, first paragraph]. (S, L.)

A_ibil qataAdiy~apN *
Camels that eat the trees called qataAd. (AHn, K.)

qutaAy^idapN * , (S, O, K,) occurring in a verse of 'AbdMenáf Ibn-Riba [cited in art. A*A, p. 40, col. iii.], (S, O,) is the name of a certain Eaqabap [or mountain-road], (S, O, K,) or a vaniy~ap [which is said by some to be syn. with Eaqabap]; (K;) [and if so, it is properly imperfectly decl.;] or any vaniy~ap is called qutaAy^idapN. (K.)

1 qatara * , aor.
qatira (S, Msb, K) and
qatura , (Msb, K,) inf. n. qatorN and qutuwrN; (TK;) and qatira, aor.
qatara ; (S, K;) It (roast meat, S, Msb, K, and a cookingpot, and burnt bone, and a perfume with which one fumigates, K, or aloes-wood, TA) exhaled its scent, smell, or odour; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ qt~r, inf. n. taqotiyrN. (K.) ― -b2- qatarati Aln~aAru The fire smoked. (TA.) -A2- qatara, aor.
qatura and
qatira , inf. n. qatorN and qutuwrN, It (sustenance) was barely sufficient; (K;) as also ↓ A^aqotara. (CK: but this latter is omitted in the TA; and in a MS. copy of the K I find in its place A^qotaru, as a syn. of qaAtirN and qatuwrN.) [This signification is implied in the K, but not expressed, and I think it doubtful.] ― -b2- qatara EalaY EiyaAlihi, aor.
qatura and
qatira inf. n. qatorN and qutuwrN; (S, Msb;) and ↓ qt~r Ealayohimo, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqotiyrN; (S, Msb;) and ↓ Aqtr, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iqotaArN; (S, Msb;) He scanted his household, stinted them, or was niggardly or parsimonious towards them, in expenditure; (S, Msb, K;) like qadara: (S, art. qdr:) as though he took only the qutaAr [or scent] of a thing. (El-Basáïr.) walamo yaqoturuwA in the Kur, xxv. 67, signifies walamo yaqoturuwA Eam~aA yajibu Ealayohimo mina Aln~afaqapi [Nor are sparing of what is incumbent on them, of expenditure]. (Fr.) You say also A@ll~`hu rizoqahu ↓ A^aqotara God made his means of subsistence strait, and scanty. (IAth.) And qutira Ealayohi rizoquhu His means of subsistence were scanted, or straitened, to him, like fudira; (S, art. qdr;) and rizoquhu ↓ taqat~ara [signifies the same]. (TA in art. Hrf, &c.)

2 qt~r * , inf. n. taqotiyrN: see 1. ― -b2- He excited, or raised, the scent termed qutaAr. (S.) ― -b3- qt~r liloA^asadi He put for the lion some flesh-meat (S, K) in the pitfall, (S,) that he might perceive its scent. (S, K.) ― -b4- qt~r lilowaHo$i He (a hunter, TA) fumigated [himself or his clothes] with camels' dung, in order that the wild animals might not perceive his (the hunter's) smell, (K, TA,) and flee from him. (TA.) -A2- qt~r EalaY EiyaAlihi: see 1.

4 Aqtrt *
She (a woman) fumigated herself with aloes-wood. (S, K.) ― -b2- Aqtr Aln~aAra He made the fire to smoke. (TA.) -A2- Aqtr ElY EiyaAlihi: and Aqtr All~`h rizoqahu: see 1. ― -b2- Also Aqtr He was, or became, poor, needy, or indigent: (S, K:) or his property became small, though some of it yet remained to him. (TA.) A poet says,
lakumo qiboSuhu mino bayoni A^avoraY waA^aqotaraA
