See also 1.) -A3- qadorN (A, L, K) and ↓ qadarN (L) A camel's or horse's saddle of middling size; (A, L, K;) and in like manner ↓ qaAdirN, applied to a horse's saddle, between small and large; or this last signifies easy, that does not wound; like qaAtirN: (T, TA:) and ↓ muqotadarN, (JK,) or ↓ muqotadirN, (K, but see 8,) a thing, (JK,) or anything, (M, K,) of middling size, (JK, M, K,) whether in length or tallness or in width or breadth: (JK:) mqtdru Alxaloqi signifying a man, and a mountain-goat, and an antelope, of middling make: (M, TA:) and mqtdru AlTuwli a man of middling stature or tallness; (A, TA;) as also ↓ qudaArN. (K.) And A^u*unN qadoraA='u An ear neither small nor large. (Sgh, K.) -A4- See also qudorapN.
qudorN * : see qadorN.

qidorN *
A cooking-pot; a vessel in which one cooks: (Msb:) [and it very often means the food contained therein; i. e. pottage of any kind: (see, for an ex., 3 in art. glw:)] of the fem. gender (Msb, K, TA) without p: (TA:) or it is made fem. (S, K) as well as masc., accord. to some: but he who asserts it to be made masc. is led into error by a saying of Th: AM observes, as to the saying of the Arabs, related by Th, maA raA^ayotu qidorFA galaY A^asoraEa minohaA [I have not seen a cooking-pot that has boiled quicker than it], qdr is not here meant to be made masc. but the meaning is, mA rA^yt $ayoy^FA glY [I have not seen a thing that has boiled]; and similar to this is the saying in the Kur, [xxxiii. 52,] laA yaHil~u laka Aln~isaA='u, meaning, lA yHl~ lk $aYo'N mina Aln~isaA='i: (TA:) the dim. is qudayorN, without p, contr. to analogy; (S, TA;) or qudayorapN, with p, because qidorN is fem.; (Msb;) or both: (TA:) and the pl. is quduwrN: (Msb, K:) it has no other pl. (TA.) [See a tropical ex. voce HAmK.]

qadarN * : see qadorN, throughout: (where its pl. is A^aqodaArN; K, * TA:) and qudorapN: (in which sense also its pl. is as above; K.) ― -b2- See also jaborN: and see miqodaArN. ― -b3- Also, A time, or a place, of promise; an appointed time, or place; syn. mawoEidN. (TA.) [See Kur, xx. 42.]

qudorapN * and ↓ maqodurapN and ↓ maqodarapN and ↓ maqodirapN (S, K) and ↓ qadorN and ↓ qadarN (Ks, Fr, Akh, K) and ↓ qidoraAnN (S, K) and miqodaArN (K) and ↓ maqodarN (TA) and ↓ qadaArN (Sgh, K) and ↓ qidaArN (Lh, K) and ↓ qadaArapN and ↓ quduwrapN and ↓ quduwrN (K) Power; ability. (K.) See qadarotu EalaY Al$~aYo'i. ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) the first and second and third and fourth (S, * Msb, * TA) and fifth, (K, TA,) or all excepting qadarN and maqodarN, (TK,) [and there seems to be no reason for not adding these two,] Competence, or sufficiency; richness. (S, * Msb, * K.) You say rajulN *uw qudorapK, and ↓ maqoduwrapK, and ↓ maqodarapK, and ↓ maqodirap. A man possessing competence, or riches. (S, Msb, TA.)

qadarapN *
A certain interval, or distance, between every two palm-trees. (JK, Sgh, K.) You say naxolN gurisa EalaY Alqadarapi Palm-trees planted at the fixed distance, one from another. (JK, Sgh, K.) And kamo qadarapu naxolika [What is the fixed distance of thy palm-trees, one from another?] (K.)
A^u*unN qadoraA='u * : see qadorN, last signification. -A2- banuw qadoraA='a Those possessing competence, or sufficiency; the rich. (K.)
qidoraAnN * : see qudorapN.

Alqadariy~apu *
The sect of those who deny Alqadar as proceeding from God, (K, * TA,) and refer it to themselves. (TA.) [Opposed to Aljabariy~apu.]
qadaArN * : see qudorapN.

qudaArN * : see qadorN, last signification. -A2- A cook: or one who slaughters camels or other animals; (S, K;) as being likened to a cook: (TA:) or one who slaughters camels, and cooks their flesh: (TA:) and one who cooks in a cooking-pot (qidor); as also ↓ muqotadirN. (K.)
qidaArN * : see qudorapN.
quduwrN * : see qudorapN.

qadiyrN * : see qaAdirN. -A2- Flesh-meat cooked in a pot, with seeds to season it, such as pepper and cuminseeds and the like: (Lth, JK:) if without such seeds, it is called TabiyxN: (Lth, TA:) or what is cooked in a qidor; (L, K:) as also ↓ qaAdirN: so in the K; but this seems to be a mistake, occasioned by a misunderstanding of the saying of Sgh [and others] that qadiyrN is the same as qaAdirN: or perhaps the right reading of the passage in the K is waAlqadiyru AlqaAdiru wamaA yuTobaxu fiY Alqidori; and it has been corrupted by copyists:) (TA:) [but this is improbable, as the passage, if thus, would be in part a repetition:] also cooked broth; (L;) and so ↓ maqoduwrN. (JK, L.)
qadaArapN * : see qudorapN.
quduwrapN * : see qudorapN.

qaAdirN * , applied to God, i. q. ↓ muqad~irN [Decreeing, appointing, ordaining, deciding]; (S;) and ↓ qadiyrN may signify the same. (TA.) -A2- See also qadorN, last signification. -A3- Possessing power, or ability; as also ↓ qadiyrN, (K,) and ↓ muqotadirN: (TA:) or qadiyrN has an intensive signification, and muqotadirN still more so: (IAth:) or ↓ qadiyrN signifies he who does what he will, according to what wisdom requires, not more nor less; and therefore this epithet is applied to none but God; and muqotadirN signifies nearly the same, but is sometimes applied to a human being, and means one who applies himself, as to a task, to acquire power or ability. (El-Basáïr.) When you say Aall~`hu EalaY kul~i $aYo'K qadiyrN [God is able to do everything; is omnipotent;] you mean, to do everything that is possible. (Msb.) ― -b2- bayona A^aroDika waA^aroDi fulaAnK layolapN qaAdirapN; (Yaakoob, S;) and bayonanaA lylyp qAdrp; (K;) Between thy land and the land of such a one is a gentle night's journey; (Yaakoob, S;) and between us is an easy night's journey, in which is no fatigue. (K.) -A4- See also qadiyrN.
taqodiyrN * : see qadorN, and 2.
maqodarN * : see qudorapN.
muqad~irN * : see qaAdirN.
maqodarapN * and maqodurapN and maqodirapN: for the first, see qadorN: ― -b2- and for all, see qudorapN.

miqodaArN *
A measure; (JK, L;) a thing with which anything is measured; as also ↓ qadarN: (L:) a pattern (mivaAlN) by which a thing is measured, proportioned, or cut out. (T, art. mvl.) ― -b2- See also qadorN, in six places. ― -b3- Death. They say A_i*aA balaga AlEabodu AlmiqodaAra maAta [When man reacheth the term of life, he dieth]. The pl. is maqaAdiyru. (TA.) -A2- See also qudorapN.
maqoduwrN * : see qadiyrN.
muqotadarN * : see qadorN, last signification.
muqotadirN * : see qadorN, last signification. -A2- See also qaAdirN. ― -b2- SaAniEN muqotadirN An artificer gentle in work. (A, TA.) -A3- See also qudaArN.

1 qadasa fiY AlA^aroDi *
He went far away into the land, or country. (Bd, ii. 28.) -A2- qadusa, aor.
qadusa , (TK,) inf. n. qudosN and qudusN, (S, A, K,) said of a thing, (TK,) It was, or became, [holy, accord. to the most common usage, or] pure. (S, * A, * K, * TK.) [It may also be said of God, as meaning, emphatically, He is holy.]

2 qd~shu * , (A,) inf. n. taqodiysN, (S, M, K,) [He hallowed, or sanctified, him or it: he consecrated him or it]. ― -b2- He declared Him (namely God, M, A) to be far removed, or free, from every impurity or imperfection, or from everything derogatory from his glory; (M;) he declared Him to be far removed from evil; [i. e., to be holy;] and so qd~s lahu; from qadasa fiY AlA^aroDi, explained above; (Bd, ii. 28;) the l, in the latter case, being redundant. (Jel, ii. 28.) ― -b3- He purified him or it; (S, M, K, Bd, ubi supra;) because he who purifies a thing removes it far from unclean things. (Bd.) Accord. to Zj, wanuqad~isu laka, in the Kur, ii. 28, means, And we purify ourselves, and those who obey Thee, for, or towards, Thee. (TA.) ― -b4- He blessed him. You say, laA qad~asahu A@ll~`hu May God not bless him. (IAar, M.) ― -b5- taqodiysN also signifies The praying for a blessing. (M.) [You say, app., qad~asa lahu, meaning, He prayed for a blessing for him.] -A2- Also qd~s He came [or went] to bayot Almaqodis [i. e. Jerusalem]; like
kaw~afa [he came or went to El-Koofeh] and baS~ara [he came or went to El-Basrah]. (A.)

5 tqd~s * [He, or it, was, or became, hallowed, or sanctified: he, or it, was, or became, consecrated]. ― -b2- He (God, Msb) was far, or far removed, or free, [or clear,] from every impurity or imperfection, or from everything derogatory from his glory; [i. e., He was holy;] or He removed himself far from every impurity or imperfection, &c.: (Msb, TA:) he, or it, was, or became, purified; or he purified himself. (S, K.)

qudosN * and ↓ qudusN [Holiness, sanctity:] purity: (S, A, Msb, K:) [each] a subst. as well as an inf. n.: (S, A, K:) the former a contraction of the latter. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) HaZiyrapu Alqudosi, or ↓ Alqudusi, [The Enclosure of Holiness or Purity;] i. e., Paradise. (S, A.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] ruwHu ↓ Alqudusi, (S, A, K,) and ruwHu Alqudosi, accord. to the reading of Ibn-Ketheer, (Bd, ii. 81,) [The Spirit of Holiness or Purity; properly applied to The Holy Spirit, The Third Person of the Trinity, in Christian theology; generally, but incorrectly, called by the Eastern Christians among the Arabs Alr~uwHu Alqudusu: but accord. to the Muslims,] Jibreel [i. e. Gabriel, the Archangel]; (S, A, K; and Bd, ubi supra;) as also Alqudosu and Alqudusu: (K, TA:) or the Spirit of Jesus: or the Gospel: or the most great name of God, by which Jesus used to raise to life the dead: (Bd, ubi supra:) or God's protection and direction. (A.) You say, ruwHu Alqudusi maEaka, and muEiynuka, Gabriel, or God's protection and direction, be with thee, and be thine aider. (A.) ― -b4- qudosN or ↓ qudusN also signifies Blessing. (M, TA.) ― -b5- Also, Alqudosu and ↓ Alqudusu i. q. Albayotu Almuqad~asu, q. v. (K,) or bayotu Almaqodisi. (A.) ― -b6- And ↓ A^aroDu Alqudusi [or ArD Alqudosi] i. q. AlArD Almuqad~asapu. (TA.)

qadasN *
A [vessel of the kind called] saTol; (S, A, K;) of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz; so called because one purifies himself in it, (S, TA,) and with it. (TA.)
qudusN * : see qudosN, throughout.
HadiyvN qudosiy~N * [A holy tradition or narration]: see art. Hdv.

Alqud~uwsu * (S, M, A, Msb, K) and Alqad~uwsu, (S, M, K,) applied to God, (S, M, A, &c.,) as also ↓ Almutaqad~isu (M, A) and ↓ Almuqad~asu; (A;) [all of which are nearly syn.;] Alqd~ws signifies [The All-holy, All-pure, or All-perfect;] He who is far removed from every imperfection or impurity, or from everything derogatory from his glory; (M, Msb;) as also Almtqd~s [but not in an intensive degree]; (M;) and Almqd~s signifies the same as this last; (T, TA;) or from faults and defects: (TA:) or the Pure; (S, * K;) [or the Very Pure:] or the Blessed; (Ibn-El-Kelbee, K;) [or the Greatly Blessed:] Sb used to say qad~uwsN and sab~uwHN, with fet-h to the first letter of each: (S:) Th says, (S,) every noun of the measure fE~uwl is with fet-h to the first letter, (S, K, *) like saf~uwdN and kal~uwbN &c., (S,) except sub~uwHN and qud~uwsN (S) and *ur~uwHN, (S, K, but not as from Th,) and in the K is added fur~uwjN; (TA;) [see sub~uwHN] for these are mostly with damm, though sometimes with fet-h: (S, K: *) Lh says, all agree in pronouncing sb~wH and qd~ws with damm, though fet-h is allowable; (M;) but Az denies this agreement: (TA:) and Lh adds, that all other words of the measure fE~uwl are with fet-h. (M.)
bayotu Almaqodisi * : see muqad~asN.

muqad~asN *
Hallowed, or sanctified: consecrated: purified:] blessed. (M.) ― -b2- Almuqad~asu, applied to God: see Alqud~uwsu. ― -b3- Albayotu Almuqad~asu, (K,) and bayotu Almuqad~asi, (S, K,) and [more commonly] bayotu ↓ Almaqodisi, (M, A, K,) which [i. e. Almaqodis] is either formed from muqad~asN by rejecting the augmentative letter, or is a subst. not formed from a verb, like as Sb says of Almanokibu, (M,) [signifying The hallowed, or consecrated, or purified, or blessed, dwelling; or the dwelling of the hallowed, &c.; are appellations of Jerusalem;] also called ↓ Alqudosu [which is the name generally given to it in the present day] and ↓ Alqudusu; (A, K;) because one is purified therein from sins, or because of the blessing that is therein. (TA.) ― -b4- AlA^aroDu Almuqad~asapu The [hallowed, or consecrated, or] purified land; (S, Msb, K;) or the pure land; (Fr;) or the blessed land; (IAar;) is an appellation of Damascus and Palestine and part of the Jordan: (Fr:) or Syria: (M:) and ↓ A^aroDu Alqudusi [or ↓ A^aroDu Alqudosi] signifies the same. (TA.)

muqad~isN * A Christian monk [or any Christian or a Jew] who comes [or goes or performs pilgrimage or has performed pilgrimage] to Alqudos or bayot Almaqodis [i. e. Jerusalem]: (A:) or a Christian monk: (K:) or a [learned Jew or other, such as is called] Habor. (M, TA.) Imra-el-Keys says, describing dogs and a [wild] bull,
faA^adorakonahu yaA^oxu*ona biAls~aAqi waAln~asaA
kamaA $aboraqa AlwilodaAnu vawoba Almuqad~isi
And they (the dogs) overtook him, (namely, the bull,) seizing the shank and the sciatic vein, and tearing his skin, as the children of the Christians tear the garment of the monk that has come from bayot Almaqodis, [or Jerusalem] for the purpose of obtaining a blessing from it: thus the verse is found in the handwriting of Aboo-Sahl; but in all the copies of the S, we find vawoba Almuqad~asiY, with Y. (TA.)
maqodisiY~N * and muqad~asiY~N Of, or relating to, or belonging to, bayot Almaqodis or bayot Almuqad~as [i. e. Jerusalem]: a Jew. (S.)
Almutaqad~isu * : see Alqud~uwsu.

div1.div2:
qdE
qdm qdw and qdY See Supplement

div2.entryFree:
1 qa*~a Alr~iy$a * (S, M, A, L,) [aor.
qa*u3a ,] inf. n. qa*~N, (K,) He cut the edges, or extremities, of the feathers, (S, M, A, L, K,) [for the arrow, or arrows,] with the instrument called miqa*~, (A,) and made them (Ha*~afahu, M, L, [in the K, taHoriyfuhu is put for taHo*iyfuhu]) of the suitable dimensions, (EalaY naHowi AlHa*owi wAlt~aqodiyru, M, [in the L and K, Alt~adowiyr is put for Alt~aqodiyr, and in the K AlH*w and the foll. conjunction are omitted,]) and even. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- And qa*~a, He cut anything in a similar manner. ― -b3- [Hence,] qu*~a, It (anything) was made even, and fine, or delicate, or elegant; (M, L;) [as also ↓ qu*~i*a: see muqa*~a*N, and see 2.] ― -b4- qa*~a Als~ahoma, (S, M, A, L,) aor.
qa*u3a , (M, A, L,) inf. n. qa*~N; (S, M, L, K;) and ↓ Aq*~hu, (M, L,) inf. n. A_iqo*aA*N; (K;) and ↓ q*~*hu; (Deewán El-Hudhaleeyeen, cited by Freytag;) He feathered the arrow; fixed, or stuck, upon it the feathers; (S, M, A, L, K;) whereof an arrow has three, also called its A=*aAn. (L.) -A2- qa*~ahu, aor.
qa*u3a , (L,) inf. n. qa*~N, (K,) He struck him upon the part called the maqa*~; (L, K;) on the back of his neck. (L.) [But see TabaEa qafaAhu in art. TbE.]
2 qu*~i*a * , (inf. n. taqo*iy*N, L,) It (anything) was trimmed, or decorated. (M, L.) See also 1.
4 A^aqo*a3a see 1.
8 Aqt*~ AlHadiyva min~iY * (assumed tropical:) He heard the story from me like as I heard it. (TA, voce A_ikotat~a.)

qu*~apN *
A feather of an arrow: pl. qu*a*N, (S, M, L, K,) and qi*aA*N. (M, L.) [You say,] Ha*owa Alqu*~api bAlqu*~api, Like as one feather of an arrow corresponds to, or matches, another. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] the ear of a man, and of a horse; (M, L, K;) the two ears are called Alqu*~ataAni. (M, L.) ― -b3- And the side of the vulva; (K;) dual, qu*~ataAni, the two sides of the vulva, (S, M, L,) which are called the A_isokataAni. (M, L.) -A2- The flea; (S, M, L, K;) as also ↓ qu*~a*N: (M, L, K:) pl. qi*~aAnN. (S, M, L, K.)
qu*~a*N * see qu*~apN.

qu*aA*apN *
A piece that is cut from the extremity of a feather; (M, L;) and qu*aA*aAtN, [the pl.,] what falls in the cutting of the extremities of feathers, and the like: (S, L, K:) and the sing., what is cut, or clipped, from the extremities of gold, &c.: (K:) the pl. signifies pieces, (M,) or small
pieces, (L,) cut, or clipped, from the extremities of gold: and pieces cut or clipped from silver are called ju*aA*aAtN: or the sing. signifies what is cut, or clipped, from anything. (M, L.)

A^aqa*~u * An arrow without feathers upon it; (T, S, M, A, L, K;) like as A^afowaqu, applied to an arrow, signifies “ having no notch: ” (L:) or of which the feathers have fallen off: (L:) or just pared, before it is feathered: (Lh, M, L:) also, a feathered arrow: or (in the K, and) that is evenly pared, without any deviation from a straight shape: (M, L, K: *) pl. qu*~N: and pl. of qu*~N, qi*aA*N. (S, L. [See an ex. voce A^aHo$anu.]) ― -b2- maA lahu A^aqa*~u walaA mariy$N He has not anything: (M, L, K:) or he has not either property or people. (Lh, M, L, K.) A proverb. (TA.) ― -b3- maA A^aSabotu minohu A^aqa*~a walaA mariy$FA I gained not from him anything: (M, L:) or I obtained not from him good, either little or much. (Meyd, TA.) Ibn-Háni relates this saying, on the authority of Aboo-Málik, differently, saying A^afa*~a, with f, instead of Aq*~, from fa*~N in the sense of farodN. (L.) ― -b4- In another proverb it is said, maA tarakotu lahu A^aqa*~a walaA mariy$FA [I left not to him anything]. (A.)

maqa*~N * The part between the two ears, behind: (M, * L, K:) one says, A_in~ahu lalay^imu Almaqa*~ayoni Verily he is vile in the part between the two ears, behind, and Hasanu Almq*~yn, goodly in that part; though a man has but one maqa*~: also, the base of the ear: (M, L:) and the place where the hair of the head ends, between the two ears, behind: (S:) the part of the back of the head where the growth of the hair ends: (M, L, K:) or the part of the back of the head where the hair is cut with the shears: (M, L:) and the part where the hair ends, behind and before: (L:) or the place where the head is set upon the neck: its proper signification is a place of cutting: and therefore it may mean the place where the hair ends, at the back of the neck: or the place where the head ends; which is the place where it is set upon the neck. (A.)

miqa*~N *
A blade for cutting or clipping; syn. miqoraADN; (S;) an instrument for cutting the extremities of feathers, (M, A, L, K, *) such as a knife and the like; as also miqa*~apN: (M, L:) a knife. (K.)

muqa*~a*N * and ↓ maqo*uw*N, Trimmed, or decorated; (M, K;) applied to a man. (M.) See maqo*uw*N ― -b2- [Hence,] muqa*~a*N (M, K) and ↓ maqo*uw*N (L), A man (M, L) having his hair clipped (M, L, K) round the part where its growth terminates, before and behind: (M, L:) and muqa*~a*N Al$~aEari, (S, L,) and ↓ maqo*uw*uhu, (L,) A man having his hair trimmed. (S, L.) ― -b3- muqa*~a*N Anything made even, and fine, or delicate, or elegant. (K.) ― -b4- [Hence,] A man having a clean garment, one part of it resembling another, every part of it goodly. (L.) And A man of light form, or figure; (Yaakoob, S, M, L, K;) as also muzal~amN: and in like manner muqa*~a*apN, A woman not tall; also muzal~amapN. (Yaakoob, S, M, * L.)

maqo*uw*N * see muqa*~a*N in three places. ― -b2- A^u*unN maqo*uw*apN, (S, M, L, K,) and ↓ muqa*~a*apN, (M, L, K,) an ear of a rounded shape (M, L, K,) as though it were pared. (S, L.) [You say,] lahu A^u*unaAni maqo*uw*ataAni He (a horse) has two ears shaped like the feathers of an arrow. (A.) ― -b3- huwa maqo*uw*u AlqafaA He has his hair clipped at the back of the neck. (L.)

1 qa*ira * , aor.
qa*ira ; (Lth, Mgh, Msb, K;) and qa*ura, aor.
qa*ura ; (Lth, Mgh, K;) and qa*ara, aor.
qa*ura ; (K;) inf. n. qa*arN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of qa*ira; (Msb;) and qa*aArapN, (S, Mgh, K,) of qa*ura; (Lth;) It (a thing, Mgh, Msb) was, or became, unclean, dirty, or filthy. (S, Mgh, Msb.) -A2- qa*irahu. (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
qa*ara ; (Msb, K;) and qa*arahu, aor.
qa*ura ; (K;) inf. n. [of the former] qa*arN, and [of the latter] qa*orN; (K;) and ↓ tq*~rhu; and ↓ Astq*rhu; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [and ↓ q*~rhu; (see qaA*uwrapN;) He held it to be unclean, dirty, or filthy:] he disliked it, or hated it, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness: (Msb:) or (assumed tropical:) he disliked it, or hated it: (S.) or (assumed tropical:) he shunned it, or avoided it, through dislike, or hatred: (Mgh:) qa*irahu and ↓ Astq*rhu and minohu ↓ tqd~r are syn. [in this last, or a similar, sense]: (Lth:) and qa*arahu, aor.
qa*ura , signifies (tropical:) he disliked it, or hated it, and shunned it, or avoided it: (TA:) and ↓ taqa*~arato (tropical:) she (a woman) shunned, avoided, or removed herself far from, unclean things, or foul actions; preserved herself therefrom. (S.) It is said in a trad., qa*irotu lakumo jaw~aAla AlquraY [I dislike, for you, what goes round about the towns, or villages], meaning, I dislike, for you, oxen and cows that eat filth; therefore do not ye eat them. (Mgh.) And El-'Ajjáj says
waqa*ariY maA layosa bimaqo*uwri
(tropical:) [And my disliking what was not disliked], meaning, that he had come to dislike (yaqo*aru) the food which he did not dislike in his youth. (TA.)
2 qa*~ara see 1. ― -b2- [q*~r also signifies He fouled a thing.]

4 Aq*rhu *
He found it to be unclean, dirty, or filthy. (Msb.)
5 taqa*~ara see 1, in three places. -A2- [Also tq*r~ He became unclean, dirty, or filthy. (So used in the L, K, art. nt.)]
10 A_isotaqo*ara see 1, in two places.
qa*orN * : see qa*irN.

qa*arN * : see 1. ― -b2- [As a simple subst., Uncleanness, dirt, or filth: and an unclean, a dirty, or a filthy, thing: pl. A^aqo*aArN:] also, dirt, or filth, which renders one legally impure: (Az, Msb:) ↓ qaA*uwrapN is likewise used in the sense of qa*arN: (Msb:) and [hence] both these words also signify (tropical:) a foul action: (TA, for this meaning of qa*arN, accord. to an explanation of its pl. A^aqo*aArN; and L, Msb, for the same meaning of qaA*uwrapN:) qaA*uwrapN is also explained as signifying adultery, or fornication, (Msb, K,) and the like: (Msb:) or this latter word signifies anything that is deemed foul (yusotafoHa$u), and that ought to be shunned, or avoided: (Mgh:) an offence for which a punishment such as is termed Had~N is inflicted; such as adultery, or fornication, and drinking [wine or the like]: (IAth:) or foul action, and evil speech. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh.) You say huwa yatanaz~ahu Eani Alqa*ari, and ↓ AlqaA*uwraAti, (Msb,) and AlA^aqo*aAri, (S,) [He shuns, avoids, or removes himself far from, that which is unclean, and unclean things, or foul conduct, and foul actions; preserves himself therefrom.] And A@l~atiY nahaY ↓ A_ijotanibuwA AlqaA*uwwaraAti A@ll~`hu EanohaA Shun ye, or avoid ye, the foul actions, such as adultery, or fornication, and the like, which God hath forbidden. (Msb.) -A2- See also qa*irN.
qa*urN * : see qa*irN.

qa*irN * , (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) from qa*ira, (Lth.) and ↓ qa*orN, (Lth, K,) from qa*ura, (Lth,) and ↓ qa*urN and ↓ qa*arN, (K,) [but the last has an intensive signification, as though meaning “ dirt, ” or “ filth, ” itself, (see Eur~apN,)] A thing unclean, dirty, or filthy. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
qu*arapN * A man who shuns, avoids, or removes himself far from, causes of blame; who preserves himself therefrom. (S, K, TA.) See also qa*uwrN and maqo*arN.

qa*uwrN * (tropical:) A woman who shuns, avoids, or removes herself far from, unclean things, or foul actions. (S, K.) See also qu*arapN, and maqo*arN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A woman who shuns, or avoids, men. (K.) See also qaA*uwrapN. ― -b3- (tropical:) A she-camel that lies down apart (A 'Obeyd, S, K) from the other camels, retiring to a distance, (A 'Obeyd, S,) and fleeing from them at the time of milking; (TA;) like kanuwfN, excepting that the knwf does not retire to a distance: (A 'Obeyd, S) or a she-camel that does not come to the watering-trough or tank, to drink, until it is left to her unoccupied; that cuts herself off from the other camels: (L, voce EaDaAdN:) as also ↓ qaA*uwrapN: (K:) and so kanuwfN. (TA voce SaruwmN.)
qaA*uwrN * : see qaA*uwrapN.

qaA*uwrapN * : see qa*arN, throughout. -A2- (assumed tropical:) A man foul in language; (Mgh;) evil in disposition: (Mgh, K:) one who cares not what he does or says. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A very jealous man; syn. gayuwrN. (Lth, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A man who does not mix with
others, (K,) or who does not associate as a friend with others, (S,) because of the evilness of his disposition, (S, K,) nor alight with them; (S;) as also ↓ qa*uwrN and ↓ qaAduwrN (K) and *uw qaA*uwrapK: (S, K:) or a man who shuns, avoids, or removes himself far from, others, not sitting unless alone, nor alighting unless alone. (A, TA.) See also qa*uwrN. ― -b4- Dainty, or squeamish; one who dislikes and avoids a thing, and will not eat it: (AO, M, Mgh, K:) the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification: (TA:) or one who dislikes (yuqa*~iru) everything that is unclean. ('Abd-el-Wahháb El-Kilábee.) It is said of Mohammad, kaAna qaA*uwrapF laA yaA^okulu Ald~ajaAja Hat~aY tuEolafa He was dainty; not eating the domestic fowl until it had been fed with vegetable food. (Mgh, TA.)

maqo*arN * (assumed tropical:) One whom others avoid, or shun: (S, K:) occurring in a Hudhalee poem: (S:) or i. q. ↓ mutaqa*~irN [one who shuns, avoids, or removes himself far from, unclean things, or foul actions; who preserves himself therefrom]. (K.) See also qu*arapN, and qa*uwrN.
muqa*~irN * (assumed tropical:) One who commits foul actions. (TA, from a trad.)
mutaqa*~irN * : see maqo*arN.

div1.div2:
q*E
q*f q*l q*m q*Y See Supplement

div2.entryFree:
1 qar~a biA@lomakaAni * , (M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and fiyhi, (S, M, Mgh,) first pers. qararotu, (S,) aor.
qari3a ; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and first pers. qarirotu, (S, Msb, TA,) aor.
qara3a ; (S, M, Msb, K;) but the former is the more usual, or common; (M, TA;) inf. n. qaraArN, (S, M, Mgh, K,) of both verbs, (S,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and quruwrN, (S, M, K,) of the former verb, (S,) and qar~N (M, Msb, K) and taqir~apN, (M, K,) which last is anomalous, (M,) and taqoraArapN; (TA;) and ↓ Astqr~, (S, M, Msb, K,) bihi, (Msb,) or fiyhi; (S;) and ↓ tqAr~a, (S, M, K,) originally taqaArara, (TA,) fiyhi; (S, TA;) and ↓ tqr~r; (TA;) [and ↓ Aqtr~, as appears from an ex. below;] He, or it, settled; became firm, steady, fixed, settled, or established; became motionless, stationary, standing, quiet, still, or at rest; rested; remained; continued; resided; in the place; syn. vabata wasakana, (K,) and tamak~ana [which, when said of a man, particularly implies being in authority and power]. (Msb.) [See also 4.] In the words of the Kur, [xxxiii. 33,] waqirona fiY buyuwtikun~a, and waqarona, [And remain ye in your houses, or chambers,] qirona and qarona are contractions of Aiqorirona and Aiqorarona like as Zilona and Zalona are contractions of AiZolilona and AiZolalona: (M, Bd, * TA: * [but see Zal~a:]) or qirona is from waqara, aor.
qari3a , inf. n. waqaArN; (Bd, TA; *) and qarona from qaAra, aor. yaqaAru, signifying AijotamaEa. (Bd.) It is said in a proverb, AibodaA^ohumo biAlS~uraAxi yaqir~uwA [Begin thou by crying out to them, and they will become still, or quiet; or] begin thou by complaining of them, and they will be content to be still, or quiet. (TA.) [But see Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 173, where, instead of yaqir~uwA, we find yafir~uwA.] You also say fiY makaAnihi ↓ fulaAnN maA yataqaAr~u, i. e. ↓ maA yasotaqir~u [Such a one does not rest, or remain, in his place]. (S.) And it is said in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, A^ano qumotu ↓ falamo A^ataqaAr~a And I did not delay to rise, or stand up. (TA.) You say also, of a woman, taqir~u limaA yuSonaEu bihaA (K) She suffers quietly what is done to her, such as the being kissed, &c. (K. * TA.) And maA='u AlfaHoli fiY Alr~aHimi ↓ Aiqotar~a The seed of the stallion rested, or remained, in the womb (S, K) of the she-camel; (K;) i. q. ↓ Astqr~. (S, K.) See also qar~N, and qaraArN, below. -A2- qar~a, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) like labisa (Mgh) and taEiba, (Msb,) [so that the second pers. is qarirota,] aor.
qara3a ; (Lh, M, IKtt, Mgh, Msb, K;) and qar~a, like Daraba, (Mgh, Msb,) [so that the second pers. is qararota,] aor.
qari3a ; (M, IKtt, Mgh, Msb, K;) and qar~a, [second pers. qararota or qarurota,] aor.
qaru3a ; (Lh, M, K;) or, accord. to MF, Lh mentions the aors.
qaru3a and
qari3a in his Nawádir; and IKtt, the three forms of aor., and so the author of the Ma'álim; but IKtt says, in his Kitáb el-Abniyeh, yaqar~u and yaqir~u, though he may have mentioned the three forms in another book; and accord. to what is stated [in the M and] in the L, Lh says yaqur~u and yaqar~u, which is a rare form; (TA;) [on which it should be remarked, that ISd, IKtt, and Mtr, mention the form
qara3a first, as though to indicate its being the more, or most, common;] inf. n. qar~N, (Msb,) or qur~N, (IKtt, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) It (the day, Lh, S, M, &c., and in like manner one says of the night, qar~ti All~ayolapu, M) was, or became, cold. (Lh, S, M, &c.) ― -b2- qur~a He (a man) was, or became, affected, or smitten, by the cold. But you do not say qar~ahu A@ll~`hu: instead of this you say ↓ A^aqar~ahu. (M, K.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad. respecting the war of the Moat, falam~aA A^axobarotuhu xabara Alqawomi waqarirotu qararotu, meaning, And when I [acquainted him with the tidings of the people, and] became quiet, I experienced cold. (TA.) [But perhaps the last word should be qurirotu.] ― -b4- qar~ato Eayonuhu, (S, M, IKtt, Msb, K,) of the measure faEilato, (M,) like taEibato, (Msb,) [second pers. qariroti,] aor.
qara3a , (S, M, IKtt, K,) which is the more usual form; (M;) and qar~ito, like Darabato, (Msb,) [second pers. qararoti,] aor.
qari3a ; (S, M, IKtt, K;) inf. n. qur~apN, (Th, M, Msb, K,) said by Th to be an inf. n., (M,) and qar~apN (M, K) and quruwrN; (M, Msb, K;) (tropical:) His eye was, or became, cool, or refrigerated, or refreshed; contr. of saxinato; (S, M;) wherefore some prefer that qar~ato should be of the measure faEilato, to agree in measure with its contr.: (M:) or became cool, &c., by reason of happiness, or joy: (Msb:) or became cool, &c., and ceased to weep, (M, K,) and to feel hot with tears; (M;) for the tear of happiness, or joy, is cool; and that of sorrow, or grief, is hot: (S:) [it may therefore be rendered, his eye was, or became, unheated by tears:] or it is from AlqaraAru, and means, his eye, seeing that for which it longed, became at rest, and slept. (M, K. *) You also say qarirotu bihi EayonFA, and qararotu bihi EayonFA, inf. n., of both forms, qur~apN and quruwrN, (tropical:) I was, or became, cool, or refrigerated, or refreshed, in eye thereby. (S.) See also 4. -A3- qar~ahu, aor.
qaru3a , inf. n. qar~N, He poured it; poured it out, or forth; namely, water: and he poured it, or poured it out or forth, at once. (TA.) You say qar~a Ealayohi AlmaA='a He poured the water upon him. (M, K.) And qararotu EalaY raA^osihi *anuwbFA mino maA='K baAridK I poured upon his head a bucket of cold water. (S.) And qar~a AlmaA='a fiY AlA_inaA='i He poured the water into the vessel. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) qar~a AlkalaAma fiY A^u*unihi, (Sh, M, K,) and AlHadiyva, (S,) aor.
qaru3a , (Sh, S, M,) inf. n. qar~N, (Sh, S, M, K,) (tropical:) He poured forth the speech, or discourse, or narration, into his ear: (M, K:) or he did as though he poured it into his ear: (S:) or he intrusted him with it: (TA:) or he spoke it secretly into his ear: (M, * K, * TA:) or he repeated it in his ear, meaning the ear of a dumb man (A^abokam), that he might understand it: (IAar:) or he put his mouth to his ear and spoke loudly to him, as one does to a deaf man. (Sh.)

2 qar~a3a see 4, in two places. -A2- qar~arahu bihi, inf. n. taqoriyrN, He made him to acknowledge, or confess, it. (S.) You say qar~arahu biA@loHaq~i, (S,) and EalaY AlHq~i, (M, K,) Hat~aY A^aqar~a, (S,) He made him to acknowledge the truth, or right, or due, (S, M, K,) so that he did acknowledge it. (S.)

3 qaAr~ahu * , inf. n. muqaAr~apN, He settled, became fixed or established or motionless or quiet or still or at rest, rested, remained, or continued, with him. (S, K.) You say A^anaA laA A^uqaAr~uka EalaY maA A^anota Ealayohi I will not settle, &c., with thee in the state in which thou art. (TA.) And hence the saying of Ibn-Mes'ood, qaAr~uwA AlS~alaApa, (S, * K,) from AlqaraAru, not from AlwaqaAru, (S,) meaning, Be ye still, without motion, and without play, during prayer. (TA.)

4 Aqr~h * , (S, M, K,) and ↓ qr~rhu, (M, K,) He settled, fixed, established or confirmed, him, or it; rendered him, or it, motionless, quiet, still, or at rest; made him, or it, to rest, remain, or con-
tinue; (S, * M, * K;) fiyhi [in it, namely, a place, or the like], and Ealayohi [in it, namely, a state, an office, or the like]. (M, K.) You say Aqr~hu fY makaAnihi [He settled, fixed, established, or confirmed, &c., him, or it, in his, or its, place]. (S, K.) And maA A^aqar~aniY fiY h`*aA Albaladi A_il~aA makaAnuka [Nothing fixed me in this country, or town, &c., but thy being in it]. (TA.) And Aqr~ AlT~ayora fiY wakorihi He left the birds to rest in their nest. (Msb.) And Aqr~ AlEaAmila EalaY Eamalihi He left the agent to rest, [or settled, fixed, or established, him, or made him to continue, or confirmed him,] in his agency. (Msb.) [And Aqr~hu EalaY qawolihi He left him at rest in his assertion, undisturbed, unopposed, or uncontradicted; he confirmed him in it; he confessed him to be correct respecting it. Thus the verb is used in the phrase Aqr~hu EalaY *`lika in the Expos. of the Jel., xxxviii. 22: and in many other instances.] You say also Al$~aYo'a ↓ qr~r, inf. n. taqoriyrN, meaning, He put the thing in its qaraAr [or resting-place]. (S.) And qar~arotu Einodahu Alxabara Hat~aY ↓ A@sotaqar~a [I established the information in his mind, so that it became established]. (S.) And A^aqorarotu h`*aA AlA^amori, inf. n. taqoraArapN and taqir~apN, [both of which inf. ns. properly belong to the synonymous form qar~arotu, (as Lumsden has remarked, in his Arabic Grammar, page 241,) I settled, fixed, established, &c., this thing, or affair; or I confirmed it.] (S.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Othmán, A^aqir~uwA AlA^anofusa Hat~aY tazohaqa Make ye the souls of the beasts which ye slaughter to become at rest, [and wait ye] that they may depart, and do not hasten to skin the beasts, nor to cut them in pieces. (TA.) And in a trad. of Aboo-Moosà, A^uqir~ato AlS~alaApu biA@lobir~i wAlz~akaApi Prayer is established and connected with br~ and zkAp [i. e., benevolent treatment of others or piety or obedience to God, and the giving of the alms required by the law]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aqorarotu AlkalaAma lifulaAnK I explained the saying, or speech, or language, to such a one, so that he knew it. (TA.) -A2- A^aqar~a He became quiet and submissive. (TA, from a trad.) -A3- Aqr~ bihi, (S, Msb,) inf. n. A_iqoraArN, (M, K,) He acknowledged, or confessed, it, (S, M, Msb, K,) namely, the truth, or a right, or due, (S, M, K,) or a thing. (Msb.) A_iqoraArN signifies The affirming a thing either with the tongue or with the mind, or with both. (ElBasáïr.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] A^aqar~ati Aln~aAqapu, [as though signifying The she-camel acknowledged, or confessed, herself to be pregnant;] the she-camel's pregnancy became apparent: (IKtt, TA;) or became established; became a positive fact: (ISk, S, K:) or the she-camel conceived; became pregnant. (IAar.) -A4- Aqr~ He entered upon a time of cold. (M, K.) ― -b2- Aqr~hu A@ll~`hu, (inf. n. A_iqoraArN, Msb,) God caused him to be affected, or smitten, by the cold. (S, * M, Msb, K.) One does not say qar~ahu (M, K) ― -b3- Aqr~ A@ll~`hu Eayonuhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) and biEayonihi, (M, K,) (tropical:) God made his eye to become cool, or refrigerated, or refreshed, (Msb, TA,) by happiness, or joy, in consequence of his having offspring, or of some other event: (Msb:) or cooled his tears; for the tear of happiness, or joy, is cool: (As:) or gave him to such an extent that his eye became quiet (Hat~aY taqar~a), and was not raised towards him who was above him, (S, TA,) or towards that which was above it: (L:) or caused him to meet with that which contented him, so that his eye became quiet (taqar~a) in looking at other things; an explanation approved and adopted by Abu-l-'Abbás: (L, TA:) or caused his eye to sleep, by making him to meet with happiness, or joy, that dispelled his sleeplessness. (Aboo-Tálib.) You say also yuqir~u biEayoniY A^ano A^araAka [It refreshes my eye, &c., to see thee]. (TA.) See also 1.
5 taqar~a3a and 6: see 1, first signification.
8 A_iqotara3a see 1, first signification. -A2- Aqtr~, (K,) or Aqtr~ biA@loqaruwri, (S,) or biA@lomaA='i AlbaAridi, (M,) He washed himself with cold water. (S, M, K.)

10 A_isotaqora3a see 1, first signification, in three places; and see 4. [― -b2- Astqr~ often signifies It was, or subsisted, or had being: and hence musotaqir~N is frequently used or understood as a copula, often with bi prefixed to the predicate; as is also yasotaqir~u; so that rayodN musotaqir~N Einodaka or yasotaqir~u Endk may mean Zeyd is with thee; as well as Zeyd is residing, &c., with thee. See, on this point, I 'Ak, p. 58.) ― -b3- Also, It obtained, or held.

R. Q. 1 qaroqara * , [inf. n. qaroqarapN,] It (a man's belly) sounded, [or rumbled,] (S, TA,) by reason of hunger, or from some other cause. (TA.) Also said of a cloud, with thunder. (TA.) ― -b2- It (wine, or beverage,) sounded, [or gurgled,] in a man's throat. (M, TA.) ― -b3- He laughed (S, M, K) in a certain manner, (S,) violently, or immoderately, and reiterating his voice in his throat: (M, K:) or he imitated the sounds of laughing: (IKtt:) or qaroqara is similar to qahoqaha. (Sh.) ― -b4- He (a camel) brayed, (S, M, K,) with a clear and reiterated voice: (S, M:) or brayed in the best manner: (IKtt:) said only of a camel advanced in age: (S, in art. nqD:) qaroqarapN is the inf. n., (S, * M, K, *) and the simple subst. is qaroqaArN: (M, K:) and qaraAqiru is pl. of the former of these ns. (S.) ― -b5- qaroqarato It (a pigeon, HamaAmap,) [cooed; or] uttered its cry: (S, K:) or uttered a hind of cry: (M:) the inf. n. is qaroqarapN and qaroqariyrN, (S, M, K,) which latter IJ says is of the measure faEolaliyolN, thus making it a quadriliteralradical word, (M,) and qaroqaArN and qaroqaArN, which last is a simple subst. as well as an inf. n., and so is qaroqrapN. (El-Hasan Ibn-'Abd-Allah El-Kátib El-Isbahánee.) ― -b6- She (a domestic hen) uttered a reiterated cry, or cackling. (Hr, M.)

qar~N * : see 1, throughout. ― -b2- yawomu Alqar~i [The day of resting;] the eleventh day of Dhu-l-Hijjeh; (A 'Obeyd;) the first of the days called A^ay~aAmu Alt~a$oriyqi; (Msb;) the day next after that called yawomu Aln~aHori [or the day of the sacrifice, or of the slaughtering of camels]: (S, M, Mgh, K:) so called because the people on that day rest, or settle, in their abodes: (S, M, Mgh:) or because they rest on that day in [the valley of] Minè, (A 'Obeyd, Kr, M, Msb, K,) after the fatigue of the three days immediately preceding. (A 'Obeyd.) -A2- yawomN qar~N, (S, M, Msb, K,) the inf. n. being thus used as an epithet, (Msb,) and ↓ qaAr~N, (S, Mgh, Msb,) but the latter was disapproved by IAar, (TA,) and ↓ maqoruwrN, (M, K,) and layolapN qar~apN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and ↓ qaAr~apN, (S, Msb,) A cold chill, or cool, day, and night: (S, M, &c.:) and qar~N is applied to anything as signifying cold; (TA;) [and so, app., ↓ qaAr~N, and perhaps ↓ qaruwrN and ↓ qariyrN]. [Hence,] Alqar~ataAni [The two cold times;] the morning and the evening. (S, K.) A man being asked what had caused his teeth to fall out, he answered ↓ A^akolu AlHaAr~i wa$urobu AlqaAr~i [The eating what was hot, and drinking what was cold: but he may have used qaAr~ instead of qr~ for the purpose of assimilation to HAr~; and it seems that, when coupled or connected with HaAr~N, qaAr~N is more chaste than qar~N]. (TA.) Respecting the saying wal~i HaAr~ahaA mano tawal~aY qaAr~ahaA, see art. Hr. -A3- See also qur~N.

qur~N *
i. q. qaraArN [q. v.] (S, M, K) and musotaqar~N (TA) [and maqar~N]. -A2- Also, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ qar~N, (Lh, Kt,) which latter form, it is said, must be used in conjunction with [its contr.] Har~N, for the sake of assimilation, (TA,) and ↓ qir~N, (Kt,) Cold; coldness; chill; chilness; coolness; syn. barodN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ qir~apN: (S:) or qur~N signifies cold; &c., in winter; (M, K;) whereas barodN is in winter and summer: (M:) and ↓ qir~apN, cold, &c., by which a man (M, K) or other creature, (M,) is affected, or smitten. (M, K.) You say daxaluwA fiY Alqur~i They entered upon the [time of] cold. (M.) And laA Har~a walaA qar~a Neither heat nor cold. (TA, from a trad.) And layolapN ↓ *aAtu qir~apK A night of cold. (TA.) And A$d~u ↓ AlEaTa$i Hir~apN EalaY qir~apN (S) The most severe of thirst is thirst in a cold day. (S, art. Hr.) And sometimes the Arabs said ↓ A^ajidu Hir~apN taHota qir~apN (S) [I experience] thirst in a cold day. (ISd, in TA, art. Hr.) [See this and other exs. in art. Hr.) One says also ↓ *ahabato qir~atuhaA, [meaning qir~apN AlEil~api,] The time of its access, or coming, meaning of the access, or coming, of the disease, [app., of the shivering-fit of an ague, (see EurawaA='u,)] departed: the [pronoun] hA refers to [the word] AlEil~ap. (S.)
qir~N * : see qur~N.
lqar~ataAni * : see qar~N.

qur~apu AlEayoni * signifies maA qar~ato bihi AlEayonu (tropical:) [That by which, or in consequence of which, the eye becomes cool, or refrigerated, or refreshed; &c.; or in consequence of which it becomes at rest, and sleeps: see 1]. (M, K.) In the Kur, xxxii. 17, instead of qur~apa A^aEoyunK, Aboo-Hureyreh reads qur~aAti A^aEoyunK, as on the authority of the Prophet. (M.) You say also huwa fiY qur~apK mina AlEayo$i (tropical:) He is in a plentiful and pleasant state of life. (TA.)
qir~apN * : see qur~N, throughout.

qaraArN * : see 1, first signification. ― -b2- A state of settledness, fixedness, stability, establishment, quiet, stillness, rest, permanence, or continuance; (Msb, TA;) and so ↓ musotaqar~N, in the Kur, ii. 34, and vii. 23: (Bd, TA:) or in these two instances the latter is a n. of place. (Bd.) [Hence,] daAru AlqaraAri [Kur, xl. 42, The abode of stability; the permanent abode; i. e.,] the world to come. (TA, art. dwr; &c.) -A2- [A place, and a time, of settledness, fixedness, stability, establishment, quiet, stillness, rest, permanence, or continuance; a restingplace;] i. q. ↓ musotaqar~N (TA) [and ↓ maqar~N] and ↓ qur~N. (S, M, K.) Exs. SaAra AlA^amoru A_ilaY qaraArihi, and ↓ musotaqar~ihi, [The thing, or affair, came to its place, or time, of settledness, &c.; or the meaning may be, to its state of settledness, &c.; the explanation is] came to its end, and became settle, fixed, &c. (M, TA.) And lahaA ↓ waAl$~amosu tajoriY limusotaqar~K [Kur, xxxvi. 38,] And the sun runneth to a place, and time, beyond which it doth not pass: or to a term appointed for it: (TA:) or to a determined limit, where its revolution ends; likened to the mstqr~ of a traveller, when he ends his journey: or to the middle of the sky; for it there seems to pause: or to its state of settledness, &c., according to a special path: or to its appointed end in one of the different places of rising and setting which it has on different days: or to the end of its course, in the desolate part of the world: and accord. to other readings, laA musotaqar~a lahaA, and laA musotaqar~N lahaA, meaning, it has no rest; for it is always in motion. (Bd.) And ↓ likul~i nabaA_K musotaqar~N [Kur, vi. 66,] To every prophecy is a term [for its fulfilment], which ye shall see in the present world and in the world to come. (TA.) And Alr~aHimi ↓ maqar~u The extreme part of the womb; the resting-place (musotaqar~) of the fœtus therein. (M, K.) It is said in the Kur, [vi. 98,] wamusotawodaEN ↓ famusotaqar~N, meaning, And ye have a resting-place in the womb, and a depository [in the spermatic sources] in the back: but some read wamusotawodaEN ↓ famusotaqir~N, meaning, and [there is] such as is yet remaining in the womb, or such as is established in the present world, in existence, and such as is deposited in the back, not yet created: or and there is of you such as remains among the living, and such as is deposited in the earth [among the dead]: (M, TA:) or such as hath been born and hath appeared upon the earth, and such as is in the womb: (Lth, TA:) or such as yet remains in the back, and such as is deposited in the womb. (TA.) You say also, A@lomuqad~asapa ↓ A^a*okaraniY A@lomaqaAr~a [He, or it, reminded me of the consecrated places of abode: maqaAr~u is pl. of ↓ maqar~N]. (TA.) And one says, on the occasion of a calamity befalling, ↓ SaAbato biqur~K, (S, Z, M, *) or ↓ waqaEato biqur~K, (K,) meaning, It (the calamity, Al$~id~apu, S) became [or fell] in its qaraAr [or settled or fixed place, or in the place where it should remain:] (S, K:) or the thing came to its qaraAr: (M:) or it fell in its place: (Z:) or it fell where it ought: (Th:) and sometimes they said ↓ waqaEato biqur~ihaA [it fell in its settled or fixed place, &c.]: (S:) and waqaEa AlA^amoru ↓ biqur~ihi, i. e. ↓ bimusotaqar~ihi [the thing fell in the place where it did, or should, rest, or remain]: (As:) and one says to a man who seeks blood-revenge, when he meets the slayer of his relation, ↓ waqaEota biqur~ika thy heart has met that which it looked for. (TA.) ↓ laqado waqaEotu biqur~ika, and ↓ biquHaAHi qur~ika, also means I have become acquainted with all that thou knowest, nothing thereof being hidden from me. (Ibn-Buzurj, in TA, art. qH.) One says also, [in threatening another,] laA^ulojivan~aka A_ilaY qur~i qaraArika; a prov., meaning, AlY A^aSolika wajahodika [i. e. I will assuredly impel thee, or drive thee, against thy will, to the utmost point to which thou canst go, or be brought or reduced; and, constrain thee to do thine utmost]. (JK. [Or the meaning is, I will assuredly impel thee, or drive thee, against thy will, to the place that thou deservest: or, to the place where thou shalt remain: or, to thy grave: or, to thy worst and lowest state or condition: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 450.]) ― -b2- A region, or place, of fixed abode; i. q. mina ↓ musotaqar~N AlA^aroDi: (S:) a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; syn. HaDarN. (TA.) Hence, A^aholu AlqaraAri [The people residing in such a region]: and hence, qaraAriY~N, q. v. (TA.) [Hence, Almuloki wagayorihi ↓ musotaqar~u The seat of regal power, &c.] ― -b3- I. q. maA qar~a fiyhi, (as in a copy of the M,) or mA qur~a fyh, (as in copies of the K,) i. e., mA qr~ fyh AlmA' (TA, written without any syll. signs,) [app. meaning, A place in which water has remained, or been poured]; as also ↓ qaraArapN: (M, K:) a depressed piece of ground; as also the latter word: (M, K:) or the latter is applied to any depressed piece of ground into which water pours and where it remains; and such ground is fertile, if the soil be soft: (AHn, M:) and to a round tract of level, or level and depressed, ground: (IAar, S:) and to a low meadow: (TA:) and to a small pool of water left by a torrent: (TA, art. vEjr:) and the former of the two words is also explained as signifying a depressed place where water rests: so in the Kur, xxiii. 52: and a place where water rests in a meadow: (TA:) and it is also a pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is ↓ qaraArapN: (As, M:) and qaraArN is applied to low grounds because water rests in them. (ISh.) Ibn-' Abbás, mentioning 'Alee, said, EilomiY A_ilaY Eilomihi kaAlqaraArapi fiY AlmuvoEanojari My knowledge compared to his knowledge is like the small pool of water left by a torrent, placed by the side of the [main deep, or] middle of the sea. (K, * TA, art. vEjr.) ― -b4- [The bottom of the sea, &c.]

qaruwrN * A woman who suffers quietly what is done to her, (M, K,) or who does not prevent the hand of him who feels her, as though she remained quiet to suffer what was done to her, (TA,) not repelling him who kisses her nor him who entices her to gratify his lust, (M, K, TA,) nor shunning that which induces suspicion. (TA.) -A2- Cold water (S, K) with which one washes himself. (S.) (It seems to be an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates.)

rajulN qariyru AlEayoni * (tropical:) A man whose eye is cool, refrigerated, or refreshed: (S:) or whose eye is cool, &c., and ceases to weep: or whose eye sees that for which it has longed [and becomes at rest and sleeps]. (K.) [See 1.] And EayonN qariyrapN, and ↓ qaAr~apN, (tropical:) [An eye that is cool, &c.] (M, K.)
fir~iy~apN * The stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird; syn. HawoSalapN; (S, K;) like jir~iy~apN (S) [and jir~iyoy^apN].
qaraArapN * : see the last division of what is given above under qaraArN.

qaraAriY~N * , from qaraArN, because he who is so called remains in the dwellings, (TA,) An inhabitant of a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land, who does not go in search of pasture: (K:) a tailor: (IAar, S, K:) a butcher: or any workman or artificer. (K.) The vulgar use it in the present day as an intensive epithet; saying xay~aAT qaraAriY, and naj~aAr qaraAriY, (TA,) meaning a clever tailor, and a clever carpenter; and in like manner, qiroqaAriY. (IbrD.)
qaroqarapN * : see R. Q. 1; the first and last in two places.
qaroqariyrN * : see R. Q. 1; the first and last in two places.
qaroqaArN * : see R. Q. 1; the first and last in two places.

quroquwrN *
A long ship or boat: (S, K:) or a great ship or boat: (K:) pl. qaraAqiyru. (TA.)
qaAr~N * [act. part. n. of qar~a, q. v.] You say fulaAnN qaAr~N Such a one is quiet, or still, or at rest. (TA.) -A2- See also qar~N and qariyrN.

qaAruwrapN * [A flask, bottle, or, as it generally signifies in the present day, phial;] the thing in which wine, or beverage, &c., (M,) or in which wine, or beverage, and the like, (K,) rests, or remains: (M, K:) or it is of glass, (S, M, K,) only; (M, K;) a kind of vessel of glass: (Msb:) pl. qawaAriyru. (S, &c.) The dim. is quwayoriyrapN. (TA.) qawaAriyra qawaAriyra mino fiD~apK, in the Kur, [lxxvi. 15 and 16,] is said by some learned men to mean Vessels, [vessels] white as silver and clear as qwAryr.
[See also art. fD.] An A is added by some to the final qwAryr [of verse 15] in order that the ends of the verses may be similar. (M.) ― -b2- A receptacle for fresh, or dried, dates; also called qawoSarapN. (Msb.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The black of the eye; the part, of the eye, that is surrounded by the white: (M, K:) as being likened to qArwrp of glass, because of its clearness, and because the observer sees his image in it. (M, TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. slb.] ― -b4- (tropical:) A woman, or wife; as also qawoSar~apN: (Az, Msb:) called by the former appellation because the child, or the seed, rests in her womb, as a thing rests in a vessel, and as being likened to a vessel of glass because of her weakness. (Msb.) Hence the words [of Mohammad] in a trad., ruwayodaka rifoqFA biA@loqawaAriyri [Go thou leisurely: act gently with the qawaAryr]: women being here likened to qwAryr of glass because of their weakness of purpose, and their fickleness; for such vessels are soon broken and cannot be restored to soundness: meaning, that the man thus addressed, named A^anoja$ap (Anjesheh), [a freedman of Mohammad,] should not raise his voice and sing in driving the camels, for fear of the women's having their desires excited by what they heard; or for fear that the camels, hearing the singing, should go quickly, and jolt and fatigue the riders. (TA.)
maqar~N * : see qaraArN, in three places.

muqir~N * A she-camel whose pregnancy is established: (TA:) or that has condensed and retained the seed of the stallion in her womb, (M, K,) and not ejected it: (M:) or that has conceived, or become pregnant. (IAar.) See 4.

maqoruwrN *
Affected, or smitten, by the cold: (S, M, K:) from A^aqar~ahu A@ll~`hu, contr. to rule; as though formed from qur~a. (S.) [It seems that J was not acquainted with the form qur~a, which is mentioned in the M and K, or that he did not allow it.] ― -b2- See also qar~N.
musotaqar~N * : see qaraArN; the former in several places: ― -b2- and for the latter, see 10.
musotaqir~N * : see qaraArN; the former in several places: ― -b2- and for the latter, see 10.

1 qaraA^a Al$~aYo'a * , [aor.
qaraAa ,] inf. n. quroA=nN, He collected together the thing; put it, or drew it, together; (S, O, K, TA;) part to part, or portion to portion. (S, O, TA.) [This seems to be generally regarded as the primary signification.] ― -b2- Hence the saying of the Arabs, maA qaraA^ato h`*ihi Aln~aAqapu salFY qaT~u and maA qaraA^ato jiniynFA, meaning This she-camel has not contracted her womb upon a young one: (S, O, TA:) but most say that the meaning is, her womb has not comprised, or enclosed, a fœtus: or the former saying means she has not borne a fœtus: accord. to AHeyth, this same saying and maA qaraA^ato maloquwHFA are both said to mean, by some, she has not borne in her womb a young one (??): and by some, she has not let fall a young one, ever; i. e. she has not been pregnant: and accord. to ISh, one says, ↓ Daraba AlfaHolu Aln~aAqapa EalaY gayori qaro'K [which seems to mean The stallion covered the she-camel without her bringing forth, or becoming pregnant; for he adds that qr' AlnAqp means DEthA; app. DaEatuhaA or DiEatuhaA; but I have not found DaEapN nor DiEapN among the inf. ns. of waDaEato meaning “ she brought forth; ” and I rather think that the right reading is DaganuhaA or DigonuhaA, and that the meaning therefore is, without her inclining, or being desirous: see 10, third sentence; and see qaro'u Alfarasi]: and there is another saying; that lamo taqoraA^o janiynFA means She has not, or did not, cast forth a fœtus, or a young one. (TA.) One says also, of the she-camel, (K, TA,) and of the ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) qaraA^ato, alone, meaning She became pregnant: (K, TA:) and likewise, of the pregnant [in general], or of the she-camel, accord. to different copies of the K, (TA,) meaning she brought forth: (K, TA:) ISh says that qaraA^ato is used in relation to a she-camel; and ↓ A^aqoraA^ato, in relation to a woman: [each, app., in the former sense and in the latter:] and that one says ↓ naAqapN qaAriy^N; pl. nuwqN qawaAriy^u. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 4. -A2- qaraA^a AlkitaAbi, (S, O, Msb, * K, *) and bihi, (Msb, * K,) the verb being trans. by itself and by means of b, or this particle is redundant, (Msb,) and sometimes the ' is suppressed, so that one says [qaraY and] qarayotu &c., (TA,) aor.
qaraAa and
qaruAa , (K,) the latter aor. on the authority of Ez-Zejjájee, as is said in the L, but generally ignored, (TA,) inf. n. qiraA='apN and quroA=nN (S, O, Msb, K) and qaro'N, (Msb, K,) this last mentioned by Az; (Msb;) and ↓ AqtrA^hu; (K;) He read [the book, or Scripture], or recited [it]: (K, TA:) or qaraA^otu AlquroA=na means [properly, or etymologically, accord. to some,] I uttered [the words of] the Kur-án in a state of combination [or uninterruptedly]; (O, TA;) as Ktr is related to have said: (O:) [or qaraA^a as used in a case of this kind app. signifies properly he read, or recited, the Scripture chanting; like as A^ano$ada properly signifies “ he recited ” poetry “ chanting with a high voice: ” (for Scripture and poetry are usually chanted:) then, he read, or recited, anything in any manner, without, or from, or in, a book.] It is said in a trad., mano A^araAda A^ano yaqoraA^a AlquroA=na gaD~FA kamaA A^unozila faloyaqoraA^ohu qiraA='apa A^um~i EabodK [He who desires to read, or recite, the Kur-án freshly, like as it was revealed, let him read, or recite, it in the manner of Ibn-Umm-'Abd]; meaning faloyuran~ilo katarotiylihi [properly, let him read, or recite, in a leisurely manner, with distinct utterance, and with moderation; but conventionally, let him chant, in a peculiar, distinct, and leisurely, manner; like as he did]: or yuHaz~ino kataHoziynihi [let him read, or recite, with a slender and plaintive voice, like as he did]: or yaHodurohu kaHadorihi [let him read it, or recite it, quickly, like as he did]. (O.) And in a trad. of I'Ab, it is said, kaAna laA yaqoraA^u fiY AlZ~uhori waAlEaSori, meaning He used not to recite [the Kur- án] aloud in the [prayers of the] noon and the [period of the afternoon called the] EoSr: or he used not to make himself to hear his reciting: as though he heard persons reciting and making themselves and those near them to hear. (TA.) The saying, in the Kur [lxxv. 17 and 18], A_in~a EalayonaA jamoEahu waquroA=nahu faA_i*aA qaraA^onaAhu faA@t~abiE quroA=nahu means Verily on us is the collecting thereof [i. e. of the Kur-án] and the reciting thereof; and when we recite it, then follow thou the reciting thereof: or, accord. to I'Ab, and when we explain it to thee, then do thou according to that which we have explained to thee: (S, O, TA:) or the meaning [signified and implied] is, verily on us is the collecting thereof in thy mind, and the fixing the recitation thereof on thy tongue; and when we recite it to thee by the tongue of Gabriel, then follow thou the reciting thereof, and often recur therein so that it may become firmly rooted in thy understanding: (Bd:) [therefore quroA=nahu in the former instance means the teaching thee to recite it; and thus we may explain the assertion that] qaraA^a and ↓ A^aqoraA^a are syn. in like manner as are EalaA qironahu and AstElAhu. (Sb, TA.) See 4. qaraA^a Ealayohi means He read, or recited, to him the Kur-án, &c., [as a teacher, or an informant; (as is shown by phrases in the Kur xxvi. 199 and lxxxiv. 21;) like talaA Ealayohi: and also, as a conventional and post-classical phrase,] as a pupil, or learner, to his sheykh, or preceptor. (L.) qaraA^a Ealayohi Als~alaAma and Als~alaAma ↓ A^aqoraA^ahu are syn., (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) signifying He conveyed, or delivered, to him the salutation: or the latter phrase is not used unless the salutation is written: (K, TA:) or belongs to a particular dial.; and is used when the salutation is written, meaning he made him to read the salutation: (AHát, TA:) the aor. of the verb in the former phrase is
qaraAa , and the inf. n. is qiraA='apN: As says that the making that verb trans. by itself is a mistake; therefore one should not say AiqoraA^ohu Als~alaAma [meaning Convey thou, or deliver thou, to him, salutation]. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 5. -A3- And see 4, first quarter.

2 qr~A^t jaAriyapF *
She kept at her abode a girl, or young woman, until she should menstruate, in order to find if she were free from pregnancy. (Aboo- 'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, S, O.) And qir~y^ato She was kept in confinement [for the purpose above mentioned, or] in order that the termination of her menstruations might be waited for, or awaited, (K,) or until the termination of her Eid~ap [q. v.]. (TA.)

3 qArA^hu * , (O, K.) inf. n. muqaAraA^apN and qiraA='N, (K,) He read, or studied, with him, each of them teaching the other. (O, K.) ― -b2- It is said of the [ch. of the Kur-án entitled] suwrapu AlA^aHozaAb, as Ibn-Háshim related that trad., A_ino kaAnato latuqaAriy^u suwrapa Albaqarapi hiYa A^aTowalu i. e. [Verily (A_ino being here a contraction of A_in~a as in the Kur xvii. 75 and 78 &c.)] it was equal as to the time required to read it, or to recite it, to [that which is entitled] the swrp of the bqrp [or it was longer]: but most
related it as commencing with the words An kAnt latuwaAziY. (TA.)

4 AqrA^t * , said of a woman: see 1, former half. Said of a she-camel, (K, TA,) and of a ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) She retained the seed of the male in her womb: (K, TA:) and when this is the case, one says that she is fY qirowatihaA, which is anomalous, for ↓ fY qiroA^atihaA; (TA in the present art.;) meaning in the first period of her pregnancy, before its becoming apparent, or manifest. (TA in art. qrw.) [And accord. to Freytag, (app. in the phrase A^aqoraA^ato sam~FA,) the verb is expl. in the Kitáb el-Addád as said of a serpent, meaning It retained poison for the space of a month.] ― -b2- Also, said of a woman, She menstruated: and she became pure from the menstrual discharge: (S, O, * Msb, K, TA:) and so ↓ qaraA^ato, in both of these senses, (Msb, TA,) aor.
qaraAa , inf. n. qaro'N; (Msb;) or in the former sense; (Akh, S, K;) and [accordingly] one says, qaraA^ato HayoDapF A^awo HayoDatayoni [so in copies of the S, agreeably with what immediately precedes, but in one of my copies of the S and in the O and TA, A^aqoraA^at, meaning, she menstruated once or twice]; (S, O, * TA; *) and qaraA^ato signifies she saw the blood [of the menses app. for the first time]: (TA:) and A^aqoraA^ato signifies she became one who had the menstrual discharge. (Akh, S, O, TA.) [Accord. to Zj, as I gather from the TA, the second of the significations in the sentence immediately preceding is from the collection of the blood in the womb: in the opinion of IAth, it and the first signification are from relation to time: but I rather incline to think that the converse of this is the case, and that hence are deduced several other meanings here following.] ― -b3- AqrA^t Alr~iyaAHu (S, K) The winds blew, (K,) or began [to blow], (S,) in their time, or season. (S, K.) ― -b4- AqrA^ (said of a man, O, TA) He reverted, or turned back, (O, K, TA,) from his journey. (O, TA.) And He returned (K, TA) from his journey. (TA.) ― -b5- And He, or it, approached, or drew near. (K.) You say, A^aqoraA^otu mino A^aholiY I approached, or drew near to, my family. (O.) And A^aqoraA^ato HaAjatuka They object of want approached, or drew near; or has approached, &c. (S, O.) ― -b6- And It set, (K, TA,) said of a star: or the time of its setting came, or drew near. (TA.) A^aqoraA^ati Aln~ujuwmu signifies The stars set: (O:) ― -b7- and also (O) The stars delayed [to bring] their rain. (S, O.) ― -b8- And AqrA^ is also syn. with A^ax~ara, (K, TA,) in the phrase AqrA^ HaAjatahu [He postponed, or delayed, the object of his want:] (TA:) and, (K, TA,) as some say, (TA,) syn. with AisotaA^oxara [He, or it, was, or became, behind, backward, late, &c.:] (K, TA:) [but it should be observed that A^ax~ara is often intrans., and syn. with AisotaA^oxara; therefore one signification may possibly in this instance be meant by both: such, however, is not the case accord. to SM, as has been shown above, and as is further shown by his saying,] perhaps the saying of the author of the K, that it is syn. with A^ax~ara, may have been taken from the phrase A^aEat~amota qiraAka A^amo A^aqoraA^otahu i. e. Hast thou withheld thy entertainment for the guest, or guests, or hast thou postponed it? but his explanation is obviously loose and defective. (TA.) ― -b9- A^aqoraA^otu fiY Al$~iEori is from AlA^aqoraA='u [pl. of Alqaro'u or Alquro'u: hence it seems to mean I rhymed, or versified: compare A^arojaza from Alr~ajazu, and A^aromala from Alr~amalu, &c.]. (O. [See also 8.]) -A2- A^aqoraA^hu, (L, K, TA,) inf. n. A_iqoraA='N, (TA,) He (a sheykh, or preceptor, L, TA) made him, or taught him, to read, or recite; (L, K, TA;) [and so ↓ qaraA^ahu, inf. n. quroA=nN, as shown before:] see 1, last quarter. One says, A^aqoraA^ahu AlquroA=na (S, O, L, TA) and AlHadiyva (L, TA) He made him, or taught him, to read, or recite, the Kur-án and the tradition. (L, TA.) Hence A^aqoraA^ahu Als~alaAma: (AHát, TA:) see 1, near the end. ― -b2- See also what next follows.

5 tqr~A^ *
He devoted himself to religious exercises [and particularly to the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án]; (S, K;) as also ↓ qaraA^a; (O, TA;) and ↓ AqrA^: (K, TA:) and i. q. tafaq~aha [i. e. he learned knowledge, or science; or particularly Alfiqoh, meaning the science of the law. (K.)

8 A_iqotaraAa see 1, former half. [After the mention of AqtrA^hu as syn. with qaraA^ahu, it is added in the TA, yqAl AqtrA^t fY Al$Er, in which AqtrA^t is evidently a mistranscription; and not attributable to the copyist, but to the author, of the TA, for the whole sentence is misplaced.]

10 AstqrA^ AlA^a$oyaA='a * , (Msb,) or AstqrY AlA$yA'a, (TA in art. qrw,) [both probably correct, as dial. vars.,] He investigated the A^aqoraA=' [or modes, or manners of being, (pl. of ↓ qaro'N or quro'N, and of qarowN,)] of the things, for acquiring a knowledge of their conditions and properties. (Msb in this art., and TA in art. qrw.) [And one says also, AstqrA^ AlktaAba, meaning He investigated the book to find some particular thing.] ― -b2- And AstqrA^ Aljamalu Aln~aAqapa The he-camel left the she-camel (taArakahaA [in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K bArkhA]) in order that he might see whether she had conceived or not: (S, K:) [or whether she were in her state of desire: for SM adds, after stating that this is from AO,] as long as the wdyq [i. e. wadiyq, an epithet which seems to be properly applied to a female solid-hoofed animal, but here app. applied to a she-camel,] is in her wdyq [a mistranscription for widaAq or a noun cognate there with], one says of her, ↓ hiYa fiY quroy^ihaA and A^aqoraAy^ihaA. (TA. [See also 1, first quarter; and see qaro'u Alfarasi.]) ― -b3- And AstqrA^hu signifies He desired, or demanded, of him that he should read, or recite. (MA, TA.)

qaro'N * (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ quro'N, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or the latter is a simple subst. and the former is an inf. n., (Msb,) A menstruation: and a state of purity from the menstrual discharge: (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, &c.:) thus having two contr. meanings: (S, O, K:) said by IAth to have the latter meaning accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee and the people of El-Hijáz, and the former meaning accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh and the people of El-' Irák: (TA:) and a time; (AA, S, Mgh, O, K;) and so ↓ qaAriy^N; (S, Mgh, O;) as in the sayings, hab~ati Alr~iyHu liqaroy^ihaA and ↓ liqaAriy^ihaA The wind blew at its time; (Kt, Mgh;) and this is the primary signification (IAth, Mgh, O) accord. to AA [and some others]; (Mgh;) whence [accord. to them] the first and second of the meanings mentioned above: (Kt, S, IAth, Mgh, O:) and qaro'N signifies also the termination of a menstruation: and some say, the period between two menstruations: (S:) accord. to Zj, it means the collecting of the blood in the womb; which is only in the case of becoming pure from menstruation: (TA:) the pl. is A^aqoraA='N and quruwo'N and A^aqoruw^N, (S, O, Msb, K,) the last of which [as also properly the first] is a pl. of pauc.; (S, O, Msb;) or when qaro'N or ↓ quro'N has the first of the meanings assigned to it above the pl. is A^aqoraA='N, and when it has the second thereof the pl. is quruwo'N: (K:) respecting the phrase val`vapa quruwo'K in the Kur [ii. 228], As says, it should by rule be val`vapa A^aqoruw^K: (Msb, TA:) the grammarians say that it is for val`vapF mina Alquruwo'i; thus in the L: (TA:) or they say that it is for val`vapa A^aqoruw^K mina Alquruwo'i: but some of them say that it is allowable to use a pl. of mult. in relation to three and more as far as ten [inclusively] without [the necessity of] rendering the phrase otherwise in grammatical analysis. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A rhyme: (Z, K, TA:) A^aqoraA='N (Z, O, TA) and quruwo'N (O) signifying the rhymes of verses; (Z, O, TA;) which terminate like as do the AqrA=' of the states of purity from menstruation; (Z, TA;) [i. e., they are thus called] because they terminate, and limit, the verses: (O:) and A^aqoraA='u Al$~iEori signifies also the several modes, or manners. or species, (IAth, O, K, TA,) and metres, (IAth, TA,) and scopes, (K, * TA,) of verse, or poetry: (IAth, O, K, TA:) the sing. is qaro'N (O, TA) and ↓ quro'N, and some say ↓ qiro'N also, and ↓ qariYo and qariY~N, and some say that it is qarowN [q. v.] with w: and the pl. of qariY~N is [also] A^aqoriyapN [a pl. of pauc.]. (TA.) One says, h`*aA Al$~iEoru EalaY qaro'i h`*aA Al$~iEori i. e. This poetry is according to the mode, or manner, &c., of this poetry. (O.) See also 10, first sentence. ― -b3- Also A periodical festival; syn. EiydN. (TA.) ― -b4- And A fever [app. an intermittent, or a periodically-recurrent, fever]. (TA.) ― -b5- And i. q. gaAy^ibN [app. meaning A thing becoming absent, or unapparent, or setting, like a star: see 4]. (TA.) ― -b6- And quro'u Alfarasi means The days of the mare's desiring the stallion: or, of her being covered: one says hiYa fiY qaroy^ihaA and fiY A^aqoraAy^ihaA [She is in her days of desiring &c.]. (TA.) See also 1, first quarter; and see 10, third sentence.
quro'N * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
qiro'N * : see qaro'N, last quarter: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

qiroA^apN * The wabaA=' [by which is here meant the common, or general, disease] (As, S, O, K) of a country; (S, O;) of which it is said that when a person has come to that country and remained in it fifteen nights [or days, accord. to one of my copies of the S,] the qrA^p thereof quits him; or, as the people of El-Hijáz say, its qirap; meaning that if he be affected with a malady after that, it will not be from the wbA=' [or qrA^p] of the country: (As, S, O;) and it is also termed ↓ qiro'N. (TA. [But I think it not improbable that this last word may have originated in a mistranscription of qirapN.]) -A2- See also 4, second sentence.

AlquroA=nu * is said by some of the erudite to be originally an inf. n. of qaraA^otu Al$~aYo'a meaning “ I collected together the thing, ” or of qaraA^otu AlkitaAba meaning “ I read, or recited, the book, or Scripture; ” and then conventionally applied to signify The Book of God that was revealed to Mo- hammad: (Kull:) it is [also expl. as signifying] the revelation, (K, TA,) meaning that which is termed AlEaziyz [the mighty, or inimitable, &c.], which is read, or recited, and written in books, or volumes: (TA:) used as a subst., and unrestrictedly, it is applied in the language of the law to the substance itself [whereof the Kur-án consists], and lexically to the alphabetical letters [in which it is written] for these are what are read; as when one says, katabotu AlquroA=na [I wrote the Kur-án], and masisotuhu [I touched it]: (Msb:) [and without the article Al, it is applied to any portion of the Kur-án:] accord. to AO, (S,) and Zj, (TA,) it is thus called because it collects and comprises the suwar [or chapters]: (S, O, TA:) and IAth says that the original meaning of the word is the collection; and that the quroA=n is so called because it has collected the histories [of the prophets &c.], and commands and prohibitions, and promises and threats, [and the like is said in the O,] and the A=yaAt [i. e. verses, or signs], and the suwar [or chapters]: but Ismá'eel Ibn-Kustan- teen, to whom, as a disciple to his preceptor, EshSháfi'ee read, or recited, the Kur-án, is related on the latter's authority to have said that AlquraAnu is a subst., and with hemz, and not taken from qaraA^otu, but is a name for the Book of God, like Alt~aworaApu [the Book of the Law revealed to Moses] and AlA_inojiylu [the Gospel]: and it is related that Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà used to pronounce AlqrAn without hemz [like many others, but it is, and always has been, pronounced by most with hemz]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied to The divinely appointed act of prayer (AlS~alaApu) because it comprises recitation [of words of the Kur-án]. (IAth, TA.)
qariYo'N * : see qaro'N, last quarter.

qar~aA'N *
A good reader or reciter [of the Kur-án]: pl. qar~aAw^uwna: it has no broken pl. (K, TA.)

qur~aA='N * , (S, O, K,) an epithet applied to a man and to a woman, (Fr, TA,) and ↓ qaAriy^N and ↓ mutaqar~iy^N, (K,) A devotee; or one who devotes himself [and in the case of the first of these epithets herself] to religious exercises [and particularly to the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án]: (S, O, K:) pl. qur~aAw^uwna (S, K) and qaraAriYo'u, (K, TA,) [in the CK qarAriy^u and] in a MS copy of the K qawaAriy^u, which might be a pl. of qaAriy^N; and in the L qaraAy^iy^u. (TA.) And qur~aA='u is sometimes a pl. of qaAriy^N. (S.)

qaAriy^N * as an epithet applied to a she-camel; pl. qawaAriy^u: see 1, former half. -A2- Also Reading, or reciting, the Kur-án [&c.]; or a reader, or reciter, thereof: (K, TA:) and sometimes the ' is suppressed, so that one says qaArK: (TA:) pl. qaraA^apN and qur~aA='N (S, O, Msb, K) and qaAriy^uwna. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- And syn. with qur~aA='N, q. v. (K.) -A3- See also qaro'N, first quarter, in two places. -A4- h`*aA waqotu qaAriy^i Alr~iyHi means This is the time of the blowing of the wind. (TA.) -A5- It is also said to signify The top, or upper part, of a qaSor [or pavilion, &c.]. (O.)

A^aqoraw^ukumo * , occurring in a trad., may mean He, of you, who reads, or recites, [the Kur-án] most: or it may mean, who is most sound in his knowledge of the Kur-án, and who retains it most in his memory. (Ibn-Ketheer, TA.)

muqoriy^N * [thus withot p] Menstruating: (S, Msb:) and also being pure from the menstrual discharge. (Msb.) -A2- And One who makes, or teaches, another or others to read, or recite, (S, TA,) the Kur-án [&c.). (S.)
muqar~aA^apN * One whose termination of her menstruations is waited for, or awaited (K.) [See the verb.]

SaHiyfapN maqoruwo'apN * , (K, TA,) the only form of the latter word allowed by Ks and Fr, (TA,) and maqoruw~apN and maqoriy~apN, (K, TA,) which are extr., except in the dial. of those who say qarayotu [for qaraA^otu], (TA,) [A writing read.]
mutaqariy^N * : see qur~aA='N.

1 qaruba * , aor.
qaruba , inf. n. qurobN (S, Mgh, O, Msb *) and qurobapN and qaraAbapN and qurobaY (Mgh, Msb) and maqorabapN, (Mgh,) [to which may be added some other syns. mentioned below with qurobN and qaraAbapN,] It, and he, was, or became, near; (S, Mgh, O;) syn. danaA; (S, O;) contr. of baEuda: (Mgh:) or qurobN is in place, and qurobapN is in station, or grade, or rank, and qaraAbapN and qurobaY are in Alr~aHim [meaning relationship, or relationship by the female side]; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) or, accord. to the T, qaraAbapN is in Aln~asab [app. relationship in a general sense], and qurobaY is in Alr~aHim [app. as meaning relationship by the female side]: (TA:) You say, qaruba minohu, (A, MA, Msb, K,) and A_ilayohi; (A;) and qaribahu, (S, MA, O, K,) aor.
qaraba ; (S, K;) inf. n. (of the former verb, Msb) qurobN, (Msb, K,) or qurobN and qurobapN &c. as above, (Msb,) or qurobN and maqorabapN and maqorubapN; (MA;) and (of the latter verb, S, MA, O) qirobaAnN (S, MA, O, K) and qurobaAnN; (K;) he (a man, S, O) was, or became, near to it; (S, A, MA, O, K;) syn. danaA: (S, A, O, K:) or the former verb means thus; but when one says laA taqorabo ka*aA with fet-h to the r, the meaning is, occupy not thyself with doing such a thing: (MF, TA, &c.:) or qaribotu AlA^amora, aor.
qaraba , and qarabotuhu, aor.
qaruba , i. e., like taEiba and like qatala, inf. n. qirobaAnN, signifies I did the thing, or affair; or I was, or became, near, or I approached, to it, or to doing it [or to doing something with it or to it]: an ex. of the former meaning is the saying [in the Kur xvii. 34], laA taqorabuwA A@lz~inaA [Commit not ye fornication, or adultery; or, accord. to some, this is an ex. of the latter meaning]; and hence one says, qaribotu AlmaroA^apa, inf. n. qirobaAnN, a metonymical phrase, meaning I compressed the woman: and an ex. of the latter meaning is the saying, laA taqorabuwA AlHimaY i. e. laA tadonuwA minohu [meaning Approach not ye to doing, or to entering upon, the thing, or place, that is prohibited, or interdicted]. (Msb.) And the Arabs say, of a man, when a thing has disquieted, or disturbed, and grieved, him, A^axa*ahu maA qaruba wamaA baEuda, as though meaning (assumed tropical:) He became, or has become, disquieted by reason of near and remote circumstances of his case: (O:) or recent and old griefs took hold upon him. (Mgh in art. qdm. [See art. bEd.]) danaA min~iY waqaruba is expl. by Zj as meaning He drew near to me and drew nearer. (T in art. dlw: see 5 in that art.) [And several other verbs belonging to this art. are syn., or nearly so, with qaruba or with qariba in senses expl. above. Thus ↓ Aqrb is syn. with qaruba in the first of the senses expl. above, like as A^adonaY is with danaA, for its inf. n.] AlA_iqoraAbu signifies Ald~ubuw~u. (TA.) ↓ Aqtrb, also, is syn. with qaruba in the first of the senses expl. above; (MA;) [i. e.] it is syn. with danaA: (Msb:) or it is syn. with ↓ tqArb, (S, O, K, TA,) signifying he, or it, drew near; (TA;) thus ↓ waA@qotaraba AlwaEodu [in the Kur xxi. 97] signifies tqArb [meaning And the fulfilment of the promise shall draw near]: (S, O, TA:) and you say, Aqtrb min~iY [meaning He drew near to me]: (A:) it is also said that is has a more particular signification than qaruba; for it denotes intensiveness in Alqurob; thus says Ibn-'Arafeh; probably meaning that it denotes labour and difficulty in the accomplishment of the act. (MF, TA.) ↓ tqr~b [likewise] is syn. with [qaruba, i. e.] danaA, in the phrase tqr~b minohu: (O: [see qaruba minohu:]) or it signifies he drew near, or approached, by little and little, (tadan~aY,) to a thing. (TA.) And Al$~aYo'a ↓ qArb, (ISd, TA,) or AlA^amora, (Msb,) [like qaribahu in many instances,] signifies He was, or became, near, or he approached, to the thing, or affair, or to doing
it. (ISd, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- qaruba, aor.
qaruba , inf. n. qurobN signifies also (assumed tropical:) He formed an opinion that was near to certainty. (MF.) ― -b3- In the phrase qarabati Al$~amosu lilomagiybi [meaning The sun was, or became, near to setting], like karabat, the q is asserted by Yaakoob to be a substitute for k. (TA.) -A2- qaraba, aor.
qaruba ; inf. in. qiraAbapN, He (a man) journeyed to water, there being between him and it a night's journey. (S, O.) [See also A^aqoraba Alqawomu. Or,] accord. to Lth, you say, qarabuwA, aor.
qaruba , inf. n. qarabN [q. v.], meaning They, after pasturing their camels in the tract between them and the wateringplace, and journeying on during a part of the time until there remained between them and the water a night, or an evening, hastened in their course. (TA.) And qaraba AlA_ibil [in some copies of the K AlA_ibila and in others AlA_ibilu], aor.
qaruba , inf. n. qiraAbapN; thus in the K; but accord. to Th, qarabati AlA_ibilu, aor.
qaruba , inf. n. qarabN; (TA;) i. e. The camels journeyed by night in order to arrive at the water on the morrow: (K, * TA:) and [a man says, of himself,] qarabotu, aor.
qaruba , inf. n. qiraAbapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And qarabotu AlmaA='a, aor.
qaruba , inf. n. qarabN, so in the Fs [of Th, meaning I journeyed to the water by night in order to reach it on the following morning]. (TA.) [Or] you say, qarabuwA AlmaA='a, meaning They sought, or sought to attain, the water. (A.) ― -b3- And [hence] one says, fulaAnN yaqorubu HaAjatuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one seeks, or seeks to attain, the object of his want; from the seeking, or seeking to attain, the water: and hence the saying, in a trad., waA_ino naqorubu bi*`lika A_il~aA A^ano naHomada A@ll~`ha (assumed tropical:) We not seeking thereby [aught] save our praising God: thus expl. by El-Khattábee. (Az, TA.) [Hence, also,] one says qado qaraba A^amorFA laA A^adoriY maA huwa (tropical:) [He has sought to accomplish an affair, I know not what it is]: (A, O: *) and fulaAnN yaqorubu A^amorFA laA yasohulu lahu (tropical:) [Such a one seeks to accomplish an affair that will not be easy to him]. (A.) fulaAnN yaqorubu A^amorFA means (assumed tropical:) Such a one seeks, desires, or aims at, [the accomplishment of] an affair, when he does a deed, or says a saying, with that object. (T, O, TA.) -A3- qaraba Als~ayofa, (S, O,) inf. n. qarobN; (K;) and ↓ Aqrbhu, (O,) inf. n. A_iqoraAbN; (K;) He put the sword into the qiraAb [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) or the former, (accord. to the K,) or ↓ the latter, (accord. to the S and TA,) he made for the sword a qiraAb: (S, K, TA:) or ↓ the latter has both of these significations: (O:) or the former verb is said of a sword or of a knife in the former sense; and in like manner ↓ the latter verb in the latter sense: or the former phrase signifies he made for the sword a qiraAb; and ↓ the latter phrase, he put the sword into its qiraAb: and one says, qiraAbFA ↓ qr~b and ↓ Aqrbhu, meaning he made a qiraAb. (TA.) -A4- qarobN [as an inf. n. of which the verb is qaraba] also signifies The feeding a guest with the A^aqoraAb (O, K, TA) meaning flanks [of an animal or of animals, pl. of qurobN or qurubN].
