(TA.) -A5- And qariba, (O, K,) with kesr to the r, (O,) like fariH, (K,) [aor.
qaraba , inf. n. app. qarabN,] He (a man, TA) had a complaint (O, K) of his qurob or qurub, (K,) [i. e.] of his flank; (O;) as also ↓ qr~b, (O, * K, [in the former this verb is only indicated by the mention of its inf. n.,]) inf. n. taqoriybN. (O, K.)

2 qr~bhu * , inf. n. taqoriybN, He made, or caused, to be, or become, near, caused to approach, or brought, or drew, near, him, or it. (S, O, Msb. *) [Hence the phrase qar~aba A@ll~`hu daAraka, which see in what follows.] ― -b2- [And hence, He made him to be a near associate; he made him an object of, or took him into, favour: and (agreeably with an explanation of the pass. in the Ham p. 184) he made him, or rendered him, an object of honour.] One says, qar~abahu minohu meaning He (a king, or a governor, or prince, [or any other person who was either a superioror an equal,]) made him to be to him a qurobaAn, i. e. [a near associate, or] a consessor, or a particular, or special, associate or companion [&c.: see qurobaAnN]. (TA.) ― -b3- qar~abahu A_ilayohimo, in the Kur li. 27, means He presented it, or offered it, to them: (Jel:) or he placed it, or put it, before them. (Bd.) And one says also, qr~b xaSomahu A_ilaY Als~uloTaAni [He brought, or placed, his adversary before the Sultán]. (Mgh in art. rfE.) And ↓ qr~b lil~`hi qarobaAnFA [He offered, or presented, to God, an offering, or oblation]. (S, O: in the Msb, A_ilaY A@ll~`hi.) ― -b4- Hay~aA waqar~aba, (A, O,) inf. n. taqoriybN, (K,) signifies (tropical:) He said, Hay~aAka A@ll~`hu waqar~aba daAraka [May God preserve thee alive, or prolong thy life, and make thine abode to be near]: (A, O, K:) one says thus of a host to a visitor. (TA.) ― -b5- And Alt~aqoriybu signifies also The denoting nearness. (Mughnee and K * voce A^awo, and Kull pp. 82 and 83 and 124.) Thus what is termed taSogiyru Alt~aqoriybi [The diminutive denoting nearness] is such as occurs in the saying, daAriY qubayola Almasojidi [“ My house is a little before the mosque ”]. (Kull p. 124.) ― -b6- And The advancing an argument in such a manner as renders the desired conclusion a necessary consequence. (MF.) ― -b7- And A certain sort of Eadow [or running] (S, O, K) of a horse: (S, O:) one says, of a horse, qr~b, inf. n. taqoriybN, (S, A, O,) meaning he raised his fore legs together and put them down together (S, O, K *) in running: (S, O:) or he ran [as though] pelting the ground [with his hoofs]: (AZ, TA:) and it is also said of other animals than the horse: but not of the camel: (MF:) [one sort of] Altqryb is [a rate] less than AlHuDoru; (S, A, O;) and more than Alxababu: (El-Ámidee, MF:) there are two sorts of tqryb, called A^aEolaY [which is a gallop] and A^adonaY [which is a canter]: (S, O:) the former is termed Alv~aEolabiy~apu; and the latter, AlA_iroxaA='u. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, near the end, in two places.

3 qaArabotuhu * , inf. n. muqaArabapN [and qiraAbN], I was, or became, near to him, or it; contr. of baAEadotuhu. (Msb.) See 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- One says of a vessel, (S, O, K,) qArb A^ano yamotaliy^a (S, O) or qArb AlAimotilaA='a (K) [It was, or became, near to being full]: qArb [thus used] is the verb from qarobaAnu [q. v.], and qaruba is not used in its stead. (Sb, TA.) And one says also, qArb miloA^ahu [It was, or became, nearly equal, or it nearly amounted, to what would fill it]. (Msb.), And qArb qadorahu [It was, or became, nearly equal, or equivalent, to its quantity, or amount; or it was, or became, nearly equivalent to it]. (K, TA.) [And hence the term A^afoEaAlu AlmuqaArabapi The verbs of appropinquation; as kaAda &c.] ― -b3- qArb AlxaTowa He made the stepping to be contracted; syn. daAnaAhu; (AZ, K, TA;) [i. e. he made short steps: made his steps to be near together;] said of a horse. (TA.) And qArb kalaAmahu [He made the several portions of his speech, i. e. he made his words, to be near together; so that it means he uttered his speech rapidly]. (K in art. wT; &c.) And qArb byn Alkalimapi waAlkalimapi fiY Alt~asobiyHi [He made the words to follow one another nearly, or to be near together, in the act of praise, or the like.] (M in art. dnw.) And qaArabotu bayona AlA^amorayoni i. q. daAnayotu [I made the two affairs, or events, to be nearly uninterrupted]. (T, S, Msb, all in art. dnw.) ― -b4- qArbhu also signifies He thought him, or it, to be near. (Ham p. 634.) And qArb AlA^amora He thought the thing. (MF.) ― -b5- And He interchanged with him good, or pleasing, speech. (O, K, TA.) ― -b6- And qArb fiY AlA^amori He pursued the right, or just, or middle, course, neither exceeding it nor falling short of it, in the affair. (O, * K, * TA.) ― -b7- And qaArabotuhu fiY AlbayoEi [app. meaning, in like manner, I pursued a middle course with him in selling, or buying, with respect to the price demanded or offered, neither exceeding what was just nor falling short of it], (S, O,) inf. n. muqaArabapN. (S.) ― -b8- muqaArabapN and qiraAbN signify also The raising the leg [or legs, of a woman,] for the purpose of jimaAE. (K.)

4 A^aqoraba see 1, second quarter. ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aqorabat, (S, A, O, K,) said of the pregnant, (A, TA,) or of a woman, and of a mare, and of a ewe or goat, (S, O, TA,) and also of an ass, (Lth, TA,) but [app.] not [properly] of a camel, (Lth, S, * O, * TA,) [though it is sometimes said of a camel, as in the S and O voce gamuws, and in the O and K in art. k,] She was, or became, near to bringing forth. (Lth, S, A, O, K.) ― -b3- And Aqrb said of a colt, and of a young camel, (K, TA,) &c., (TA,) He was, or became, near to the age of shedding his central incisors; (K, TA;) and likewise, to that of shedding other teeth. (TA.) ― -b4- And He nearly filled a vessel. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- laA^uqoriban~akumo SalaApa rasuwli A@ll~`hi occurs in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, meaning I will indeed perform to you the like of, or what will be nearly the same as, the praying of the Apostle of God.
(TA.) ― -b6- Aqrb AlA_ibila He made the camels to journey by night in order to arrive at the water on the morrow: (O, * K, TA:) or AqrbwA A_ibilahumo They, after pasturing them in the tract between them and the watering-place, and journeying on during a part of the time until there remained between them and the water a night, or an evening, hastened their camels. (Lth, TA.) ― -b7- And Aqrb Alqawomu The people, or party, became persons whose camels were performing a journey such as is termed qarabN: the part. n. is [said to be] ↓ qArb, not muqorbN: (As, S, O:) the former of these is said by A'Obeyd to be anomalous: (S, O:) [but see qaraba, which is expl. as having almost exactly the same meaning as that which is in this instance assigned to Aqrb. And it is also mentioned in the TA, app. on the authority of AA, that the same phrase and the same anomalous part. n. are used when the people's camels are mutaqaAribap (which means few, or near together): but I think that this word is a mistake of a copyist, for qawaAribu: see qaAribN.] -A2- See also 1, last quarter, in six places.

5 taqar~aba see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence] one says to his companion, urging him, taqar~abo, meaning (tropical:) Advance thou, or come forward: (A, TA:) or taqar~abo yA rajulu, meaning hasten, O man. (As, O, L, K, TA.) Only the imperative mood in this sense is said to be used. (MF, TA.) ― -b3- And [hence, also,] tqr~b signifies He rendered himself near, or allied himself, [drew near, or ingratiated himself,] by affection and friendship. (TA, voce tanas~aba. [In this sense it is trans. by means of mino.]) And He applied himself with gentleness, or courtesy, to obtain access, or nearness, to a man, by means of some act performed for that purpose, or by right. (TA. [In this sense it is trans. by means of A_ilaY.]) And one says, tqr~b mina A@ll~`hi [He drew near unto God] by prayer or the like, and righteous actions: and tqr~b A@ll~`hu minohu [God drew near unto him] by beneficence towards him. (TA.) And tqr~ib bihi A_ilaY A@ll~`hi, (S, A, O, Msb, K, *) inf. n. taqar~ubN and tiqir~aAbN, (O, K,) the latter [of a rare form] like tiHim~aAlN and tikil~aAmN and timil~aAqN, (O,) He sought thereby nearness, to bring himself near, to draw near, or to approach, unto God; or to advance himself in the favour of God: (S, K, * TA:) and faEalahu taqar~ubFA A_ilayohi [He did it by way of seeking nearness, &c., to Him]. (A.) -A2- tqr~b also signifies He (a man, O) put his hand upon his qurob (O, K, TA) i. e. his flank, (O, TA,) in walking; or, as some say, hastening, or going quickly. (TA.)

6 tqArbwA *
They were, or became, or drew, near, one to another: (S, * A, * Msb:) you say tqArbwA and ↓ AqtrbwA [both app. signifying the same, like txASmwA and AxtSmwA, and txAlTwA and AxtlTwA, and t$ArkwA and A$trkwA, &c.]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 1, second quarter. ― -b3- tqArbt A_ibiluhu means (tropical:) His camels became few, [because drawing near together,] (A, O, K, TA,) and (as is also said of other things, TA) declined, or became reduced to a bad state. (O, * K, * TA.) ― -b4- And [for the like reason, because of its becoming dense,] tqArb is said of seed-produce, or standing corn or the like, meaning (assumed tropical:) It became nearly ripe. (O, K, TA.) ― -b5- And hence [accord. to some], taqaAraba Alz~amaAnu (assumed tropical:) [When the time becomes contracted], occurring in a trad., expl. in art. zmn, q. v. (TA.)
8 A_iqotaraba see 1, second quarter, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 6.
10 Astqrbhu * [contr. of AstbEdhu]. One says, huwa yasotaqoribu AlbaEiyda [He reckons near that which is remote]. (A, Msb.)

qurobN * [mentioned in the first sentence of this art. as an inf. n.] is the contr. of buEodN: (S, O:) [used as a simple subst., it signifies Nearness, and] it is said to be [properly, or primarily,] in respect of place; [i. e. vicinity;] as distinguished from qurobapN &c. (Msb, TA.) You say, A_in~a qurobaka zayodFA [Verily Zeyd is in thy vicinity; i. e., near thee in respect of place]; but not A_in~a buEodaka zayodFA; because qurob is more capable of being used as an adv. n. of place than buEod: in like manner they said also ↓ huwa quraAbataka, meaning [He is in thy vicinity; i. e.,] near thee in respect of place. (Sb, TA. [See also qariybN.]) [And biAlqurobi minohu is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning In the vicinity of, or near in respect of place to, him, or it.] And one says, tanaAwalahu mino qurobK and ↓ mino qariybK [He took it, or took it with his hand, from a near place or spot]. (A, Msb.) And raA^ayotuhu mino qurobK [and ↓ mino qariybK I saw him, or it, from a near place or spot, or from within a short distance]. (S in art. Am; &c.) ― -b2- It is also syn. with ↓ qaraAbN [signifying Nearness in respect of time] as used in the saying AifoEalo *`lika biqaraAbK [i. e. Do thou that soon; like as one says, Eano ↓ qariybK]: (K, TA:) accord. to the K, the word qrAb in this case is like saHaAb: but it is said in a prov., A^akoyasu ↓ AlfiraAru biqiraAbK, thus in the S, or, as some relate it, ↓ biquraAbK; and IB says, J has cited this prov. [next] after the qiraAb of the sword, but should have said that AlqiraAbu is also syn. with Alqurobu, and should then have adduced the prov. as an ex. meaning The fleeing soon in eagerness of desire for safety [is more, or most, shrewd]: (TA:) [this rendering, however, requires consideration; for, accord. to Meyd, who gives only the reading biqiraAbK, the meaning of the prov. is, that he who flees with the ↓ qiraAb (by which is meant the scabbard) when the sword has passed away from his possession is more shrewd than he who causes, or suffers, the qiraAb also to pass away from him: in Freytag's Arab Prov. ii. 210, both of these explanations are given; but qryb is there erroneously put for qurob.] ― -b3- See also qaraAbapN. ― -b4- It is also a pl. of qariybN [q. v.]. (TA in art. zlf.) -A2- qurobN also, and ↓ qurubN, (S, O, K,) the former of which is the original, (TA,) signify The xaASirap [or flank]: (O, K:) or [the part] from the $aAkilap [which is syn., or nearly so, with xaASirap,] to the maraAq~ [or soft parts] of the belly: (S, O, K:) and likewise from the rafog [generally meaning groin] to the armpit, on each side: (TA:) [properly used in relation to a horse:] sometimes metaphorically used in relation to a she-camel, and to an ass [meaning a wild ass, and also to a man: see 5, last sentence]: (TA:) pl. A^aqoraAbN; (T, S, O, K;) which is also used in the place of the dual. (T, TA.)

qarabN * [mentioned in the latter half of the first paragraph of this art. as an inf. n.] is [said to be] a subst., signifying A journey to water when it is a night's journey distant: or, as As said, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, (S, O,) a journey by night in order to arrive at the water on the morrow; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ qiraAbapN [which is also mentioned as an inf. n. in the latter half of the first paragraph of this art.]; (K;) a journey by night in order to arrive at the water on the second following day being called TalaqN: (S, O:) and the seeking water by night: or, when it is not more than a night's journey distant: or the first day in which one journeys to water when it is two days distant; the second day being called TalaqN: (K: [but the converse seems to be the truth, being asserted by several of the highest authorities, and agreeable with the derivation of each of the two words: see TalaqN:]) or the night after which, in the morning, one arrives at the water: (TA:) and layolapu Alqarabi is the night in which people with their camels hasten to the water in a journey such as is termed qarabN baSobaASN; this latter term being applied to signify a people's letting their camels pasture while they are journeying towards water; and when there remains an evening between them and the water, hastening towards it: (S, O:) or, as is said on the authority of As, layolapu Alqarabi is the second night after the pastor has turned the faces of his camels towards the water, and so left them to pasture; this second night being the night of hard driving; and the first night being called layolapu AlT~alaqi: accord. to AA, [the journey called] Alqarabu is [the journey to water] during three days, or more. (TA.) And [hence] Alqaraba is used to signify What is a night's journey distant. (S in art. nwb, in explanation of a verse cited in that art. [Or, accord. to IAar, qarab there signifies near, so as to be visited repeatedly: or, as AA says, at such a distance as to be visited once in three days.]) [See also a saying mentioned voce HawozN.] ― -b2- Also A well of which the water is near [to the mouth]. (O, K.)
qurubN * : see qurobN, last sentence.

qurobapN * an inf. n. of qaruba [q. v.: and used as a simple subst. signifying Nearness]; like qurobN: or the former is in station, or grade, or rank. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, Talabotu minohu Alqurobapa [I sought of him nearness of station, &c.; or admission into favour]. (A.) ― -b2- See also qaraAbapN. ― -b3- Also, (A, O, Msb,) and ↓ qurubapN, (Msb,) A thing [such as prayer, or any righteous deed or work,] whereby one seeks nearness, to bring himself near, to draw near, or to approach, unto God; or to advance himself in the favour of God; (A, * O, Msb;) as also ↓ qurobaAnN: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. of the first and second qurabN and qurobaAtN and qurubaAtN and qurabaAtN. (Msb.)

qirobapN *
A kind of siqaA=' [or skin], (S, * O, * TA,) used for water: (S, O:) or a waTob [or skin] that is used for milk, and sometimes for water: (ISd, K:) or such as is sewed on one side: (K:) [the modern qirobap, which is seldom, if ever, used for anything but water, is (if I may judge from my own observations and the accounts of others) always made of the skin of a goat about one year old or upwards: it consists of nearly the whole skin; only the skin of the head, and a small portion of that of each leg, being cut off: it has a seam extending from the upper part of the throat nearly to the belly, and sometimes a corresponding seam at the hinder part, but more commonly only a patch of leather over the fundament and navel: over the seam, or over each seam, is sewed a narrow strip of leather; and a mouth of leather is added in the place of the head: it is carried on the back, by means of a strap, or cord, &c., one end of which is generally attached to a cord connecting the two fore-legs; and the other, to the right hind leg:] the pl. (of pauc., S, O) is qirobaAtN, and qirabaAtN, and qiribaAtN, and (of mult., S, O) qirabN. (S, O, Msb, K.)
fiyhi qarabapN * and ↓ qiraAbapN are said of a vessel that is nearly filled [meaning In it is a quantity that nearly fills it]. (K, TA.) [See also qiraAbN.]
qurubapN * : see qurobapN: ― -b2- and see also qaraAbapN.
qurobaY * [mentioned in the first sentence of this art. as an inf. n.: and used as a simple subst.]: see qaraAbapN, in five places: and see also qariybN, latter half.

qarobaAnu * A vessel nearly full: fem. qurobaY: (S, O, K:) and pl. qiraAbN: (S, O:) you say qadaHN qarobaAnu maA='F i. e. [A drinking vessel] nearly full of water: and the q in qrbAn is [said to be] sometimes changed into k: (TA:) so accord. to Yaakoob; but ISd denies this. (TA in art. krb.) -A2- See also the paragraph here following.

qurobaAnN * : see qurobapN: [it may often be rendered An offering, or oblation: and hence it sometimes means a sacrifice, as in the Kur iii. 179:] pl. qaraAbiynu. (Msb.) qurobaAnuhumo dimaA=w^uhumo [Their offering to God is their blood, lit. bloods,] occurs in a trad. as cited from the Book of the Law revealed to Moses, and as referring to the Arabs; meaning, they seek to bring themselves near unto God by shedding their blood in fighting in the cause of religion; whereas the qrbAn of preceding peoples consisted in the slaughtering of oxen or cows, and sheep or goats, and camels. (TA.) And it is said in another trad., AlS~alaApu qurobaAnu kul~i taqiY~K [The divinely-appointed act of prayer is the offering to God of every pious person]; meaning, that whereby the pious seek to bring themselves near unto God. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, O, K,) and ↓ qarobaAnN, (K,) but this latter is by some disapproved, (TA,) [A near associate; or] a particular, or special, (A, K,) associate or companion (A) or consessor; (K;) or a consessor; and a particular, or special, associate or companion; (S, ISd, O;) [or a familiar, or favourite;] of a king, (S, ISd, A, O, K,) or of a governor, or prince; (S, O;) [or of any person who is either a superior or an equal;] so called because of his nearness: (TA:) pl. qaraAbiynu: (S, A, O, K:) and one says also, fulaAnN mino qurobaAni AlA^amiyri [Such a one is of the near associates, &c., of the governor, or prince]; (S, O;) [for] qurobaAnN is [said to be originally] an inf. n., and [therefore, as an epithet,] the same as sing. and dual and pl.: (so in a marginal note in one of my copies of the S:) or, in a phrase of this kind, it is a pl. of ↓ qariybN. (A in art. bEd.)
qaraAbN * : see qurobN, former half.
quraAbN * : see qariybN, last quarter, in two places: ― -b2- and qurobN, near the middle: ― -b3- and qiraAbN, former half: ― -b4- and quraAbapN.

qiraAbN * [an inf. n. of 3. And hence qiraAba as an adv. n. of time]. You say, A^atayotuhu qiraAba AlEi$aA='i I came to him near nightfall: and qiraAba All~ayoli near night. (Lth, TA.) And 'Oweyf El-Kawáfee says, describing she-camels, (so in the TA and in one of my copies of the S,) or 'Oweyf El-Fezáree, (so in the O,)
huwa A@bonu munaD~ijaAtK kun~a qidomFA
yazidona EalaY AlEadiydi qiraAba $ahorK
(O, TA) i. e. He is the off spring of [one of the] she-camels that went beyond the usual time of bringing forth, that used formely to exceed the computed [time] near a month: J give a different reading of this verse, yaridona EalaY Algadiyir; but the correct reading is that given above. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- See also qurobN, near the middle. ― -b3- qiraAbu Al$~aYo'i and ↓ quraAbuhu and ↓ quraAbatuhu signify What is nearly the equal in quantity, or amount, or nearly the equivalent, of the thing. (K.) One says, maEahu A^alofu dirohamK A^awo qiraAbuhu He has with him a thousand dirhems, or nearly the equal thereof: and maEahu milo'u qadaHK maA='F A^awo qiraAbuhu He has with him a cupful of water, or nearly the equal thereof. (Lth, TA.) And a poet says, (S,) namely, El- 'Ambar, (so in the O and TA,) or Es-Sinnabr, (so in the Mz, 49th nwE,) Ibn-'Amr, Ibn-Temeem, (O, TA, *)
A_il~aA tajiy^o maloA^aY yajiy^o qiraAbuhaA
[If a full bucket (dalowN being understood, as is indicated in the S and O and TA,) come not, what will be nearly the equal thereof will come]. (S, O, TA.) One says also, lawo A^an~a liY qiraAba h`*aA *ahabFA i. e. [If there belonged to me] the quantity nearly sufficient for the filling of this [of gold]: and lawo jaA='a biqiraAbi AlA^aroDi i. e. [If he brought] that which would be nearly the equal in quantity of the earth. (Msb.) And Alr~ukobatayoni ↓ AlmaA='u quraAbapu [The water is such as is nearly the equal in height of the two knees]. (A.) [See also qarabapN.] -A2- Also The gimod [i. e. scabbard, or sheath,] of a sword, (K, TA,) or of a knife: (TA:) or the jafon [i. e. case, or receptacle,] of the gimod; (K, TA;) the jafon, which is a case, or receptacle, wherein is the sword together with its scabbard (bigimodihi) and its suspensory belt or cord: (S, O, TA:) it is like a jiraAb of leather, into which the rider, or rider upon a camel, puts his sword with its jafon [here meaning scabbard], and his whip, and his staff, or stick, and his utensils: (Az, TA:) or like the jiraAb, into which one puts his sword with its scabbard (bigimodihi), and his whip, and sometimes his travelling-provisions of dates &c.: (IAth, TA:) the pl. of the qiraAb of the sword is qurubN [a pl. of mult.] (Msb, TA) and A^aqoribapN [a pl. of pauc.], like xumurN and A^axomirapN pls. of ximaArN. (Msb.) See also qurobN, latter half.

qariybN *
Near in respect of place: (S, O, Msb, K, * &c.:) in this sense used alike as sing. and pl. (Kh, ISk, T, O, Msb, K *) and dual, (ISk, TA,) and as masc. and fem., (AA, Kh, Fr, ISk, T, S, O, Msb,) as is also baEiydN in the contr. sense: (Kh, ISk, TA:) the Arabs say huwa qariybN min~iY, (ISk, O, * TA,) and humaA qariybN min~iY, and humo qariybN min~iY, (ISk, TA,) and hiYa qariybN min~iY, &c., meaning fiY makaAnK qariybK [in a place near, to me, or little removed from me:] (ISk, O, TA:) or when you say hinodN qariybN minoka, it is as though you said hinodN mawoDiEuhaA qariybN minoka [Hind, her place is near to thee:] (AA, Msb:) hence, [in the Kur vii. 54,] A_in~a raHomapa A@ll~`hi qariybN mina AlmuHosiniyna [Verily the mercy of God is near unto the welldoers]: (AA, ISk, O, Msb:) but it is allowable to say qariybapN, as also baEiydapN: (ISk, O, Msb, TA:) or (accord. to Zj, TA) qryb is here without p because rHmp is not really [but only conventionally] of the fem. gender: (S, O, TA:) [but this reason is not satisfactory, because it does not apply to other cases mentioned above:] and it is also said that it is without p because it is assimilated to an epithet of the measure faEuwlN, which does not receive the fem. affix p. (TA.) [Hence the phrase mino qariybK:] see qurobN, former half, in two places. And [hence also] you say, A_in~a qariybFA
minoka zayodFA [Verily Zeyd is in a place near to thee]; like as you say, A_in~a qurobaka zayodFA. (Sb, TA.) ― -b2- [Also Near in respect of time, whether future, as in the Kur xlii. 16, &c.; or past, as in the Kur lix. 15. And hence qariybFA meaning Shortly after and before. And Nearly, as when one says, A^aqamotu biAlmawoDiEi qariybFA mino sanapK I remained, stayed, or abode, in the place nearly a year. Hence also the phrase Eano qariybK:] see qurobN, near the middle. ― -b3- And Near as meaning related by birth or by marriage: (S, O, Msb, K:) [and generally used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, meaning a relation, or relative:] in this sense it receives the fem. form, by universal consent; so that you say, h`*ihi AlmaroA^apu qariybatiY [This woman is my relation]: (Fr, S, O, Msb: *) and likewise the dual form; so that you say, [humaA qariybaAni and] humaA qariybataAni [They two are relations]: (AA, Msb:) [and it has a pl., namely, A^aqoribaA='u;] you say, humo A^aqoribaAy^iY and A^aqaAribiY (S, A, O, K) [and A^aqorabiY~a, this last originally A^aqorabuwYa; the first signifying They are my relations; and the second and third, properly, being pls. of ↓ A^aqorabu, They are my nearer, or nearest, or very near, relations; though in the T the second is said to be pl. of qariybN; and in most of the copies of the K, but not in all, (for in some the first of these three words is omitted, as it is also in the TA,) it is implied that A^aqoribaA='u and A^aqaAribu and A^aqorabuwna (which are mentioned in the Msb without any distinction of meaning) are all to be understood in the latter sense]: and qurobN [also] is a pl. of qariybN [app. in the sense here assigned to it], like as gurobN is of gariybN; (TA in art. zlf;) and qarobaY is allowable as a pl. of fariybN: (T, TA:) the pl. of qariybapN is qaraAy^ibu. (T, Msb, TA.) And like as you say, huwa qariybiY [meaning He is my relation], as too you say, ↓ huwa *uw qaraAbatiY (S, O, K) and min~iY ↓ *uw qaraAbapK and mn~Y ↓ *uw maqorubapK and min~iY ↓ *uw qurobaY; (TA;) but not ↓ huwa qaraAbatiY; (K;) [for only] the vulgar say this; as also humo qaraAbaAtiY: (S, O:) or, accord. to Z, ↓ huwa qaraAbatiY is allowable, being accounted for as a phrase in which the prefixed n. [*uw] is suppressed; and it has moreover been asserted to be correct and chaste in verse and prose: ↓ qaraAbapN also occurs in the trads. in the sense of A^aqaAribu: it is said in the Nh to be an inf. n. used as an epithet, agreeably with general analogy: and in the Tes-heel it is said to be a quasi-pl. n. of qariybN, like as SaHaAbapN is of SaAHibN: (MF, TA:) [accord. to Mtr,] ↓ qaraAbapN is correctly applicable to one and to a pl. number, as being originally an inf. n.; so that one says, huw qaraAbatiY and humo qaraAbatiY; though the chaste phrase is *uw qaraAbatiY applied to one; and *awaA qaraAbatiY, to two; and *awuw qaraAbatiY, to a pl. number. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And [it is also applied to relationship:] one says, bayonanaA nasabN qariybN and ↓ quraAbN [Between us is a near relationship]. (A.) ― -b5- It signifies also Near, or allied, by affection and friendship. (TA voce tanas~aba.) [You say, fulaAnN qariybN mina Aln~aAsi meaning Such a one is near, &c., or friendly and affectionate, to people, or mankind.] See also qurobaAnN, last sentence. ― -b6- And one says, maA huwa biEaAlimK EaAlimK ↓ walaA quraAbi and EaAlimK ↓ quraAbapi meaning qariybi EaAlimK [i. e. He is not learned nor near learned]. (TA.) And mino *`lika ↓ maA huwa bi$abiyhika walaA biquraAbapK meaning walaA biqariybK mino *`lika [i. e. He is not the like of thee nor near that]; (S, O;) or minoka ↓ walaA biquraAbapK meaning bqariybK [i. e., nor near the like of thee]. (K.) ― -b7- fulaAnN qariybu Alv~araY; and qariybu Alv~araY baEiydu Aln~abaTi: see in arts. vrY and nbT. -A2- Also, (O, K, TA,) but in some of the lexicons written qir~iybN, (TA,) Salted fish, while yet in its recent, moist, state. (O, K, TA.)

qaraAbapN * , (S, O, K,) which is originally an inf. n., (S,) [i. e., of qaruba, as is also, app., every one of its syns. here following,] and ↓ qurobaY and ↓ qurobapN and ↓ qurubapN (S, O, K) and ↓ qurobN (S, O) and ↓ maqorubapN and ↓ maqorabapN (S, O, K) ↓ maqoribapN, (K,) all of them, (S, O, K,) or the first and ↓ qurobaY, (Msb,) signify Relationship, or relationship by the female side; (S, O, * Msb, K, * TA;) or the first has the former of these significations and ↓ qurobaY has the latter of them: (T, TA:) [in the S, AlqaraAbapu is expl. signifying AlqurobaY fiY Alr~aHimi; and in the Mgh and Msb, it and ↓ AlqurobaY are expl. as being fiY Alr~aHimi; but in the T, as cited in the TA, the former is expl. as being fiY Aln~asabi, and ↓ AlqurobaY as being fiY Alr~aHimi: see the first sentence of this art.:] you say, bayoniY wabayonahu qaraAbapN &c. [i. e. Between me and him is a relationship, or a relationship by the female side]. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also qariybN, latter half, in six places.

quraAbapN * : see qurobN, first quarter: ― -b2- and qiraAbN, in two places: and qariybN, near the end, in three places. ― -b3- quraAbapu Almuw^omini and ↓ quraAbuhu signify The believer's firaAsap [i. e. insight, or intuitive perception, &c.]; (Fr, O, K;) and his opinion, which is near to knowledge and assurance: occurring in a trad., in which it is said that one is to beware thereof, because he looks with the light of God. (Fr, O, TA. [See also firaAsapN.])
qiraAbapN * : see qarabapN: -A2- and see also qarabN.
jaAw^uwA quraAbaY * , (IDrd, O, K,) the latter word similar to furaAdaY, (IDrd, O,) They came near together. (IDrd, O, K.)

qurayobaY * [dim. of qurobaY]. duwna kul~i qurayobaY qurobaY [There is a relationship nearer than every relationship small in degree] is a prov. applied to him who asks of thee something wanted which one more nearly related to thee than he has asked of thee. (Meyd. [See another prov., app. similar in meaning and application, voce daniY~N, in art. dnw.])

qar~aAbN *
A maker of [what are called] qrb [app. qurub, pl. of qiraAbN; or perhaps qirab, pl. of qirobapN]. (TA.)
qaronabN * : &c.: see art. qrnb.

qaAribN * [part. n. of qaraba said of a man journeying to water: and accord. to As and A'Obeyd, part. n. of A^aqoraba used in a similar sense; as such anomalous]. One seeking, or seeking to attain, [or journeying to,] water: so says Az, without specifying any time: (TA:) or, accord. to Kh, (S, O, TA,) one doing so by night; (S, O, K, TA;) not applied to one doing so by day. (S, O, TA.) And its pl. qawaAribuwna signifies Persons whose camels are performing a journey such as is termed qarabN: (As, S, O:) see 4, latter half. The epithet applied to camels in this case is qawaAribu; (S, O;) [of which see another explanation voce TalaqN;] and this epithet is also used in relation to birds. (IAar, TA.) maA liY qaAribN walaA haAribN occurs in a trad., meaning I have not any that goes to water nor any that returns from it. (L, TA. [See also haAribN.]) And HimaArN qaAribN means An ass hastening on in the night of arriving at the water. (Lth, TA.) -A2- Also A small safiynap; (A, K;) i. e. (A,) [a skiff;] a ship's boat, used by the seamen as a convenient means af accomplishing their needful affairs; (S, A, O;) also called sunobuwkN [or sunobuwqN]: (A:) pl. qawaAribu: and A^aqorubN occurs in a trad., and is said to be also a pl. of qaAribN; but IAth says that this is not known as a pl. qArb, unless as anomalous; and it is said that A^aforubu Als~afiynapi means the nearest parts of the ship; i. e., the parts near [or next] to the land. (TA.)

qaworabN *
Water over which, or against which, one has not power, or with which one cannot cope, by reason of its copiousness. (O, K.)

A^aqorabu *
Nearer, and nearest, in respect of place, and in respect of time, &c.]: see qariybN, in the middle of the paragraph.

Zaharato taqar~ubaAtu AlmaA='i * (tropical:) The foretokens of water appeared; i. e. small pebbles, from seeing which the well-digger, when he has nearly reached a spring, infers that water is near. (A, TA.)

maqorabN * (A, O, K) and ↓ maqorabapN (O, K) (tropical:) A near, or the nearest, road or way: (A, O, K, TA:) or a small road or way, leading into a great one; said to be from Alqarabu signifying “ the journeying by night, ” or “ the journeying [by night] to water: ” (TA:) or, the former, a conspicuous road or way; so says IAar: (TA voce maTorabN:) and the latter, accord. to AA, a place of alighting or sojourning or abiding; from Alqarabu signifying “ the ” journeying [by night &c.]: the pl. is maqaAribu. (TA.)

muqorabN * A horse that is brought [or kept] near [to the tent, or dwelling], and treated generously, and not left to seek for pasture: fem. with p:] or this is done only with mares, lest a stallion of low race should cover them: (IDrd, S, O, K:) or xayolN muqorabapN signifies horses that are [kept] near at hand, and prepared [for riding]: (El-Ahmar, TA:) or horses that have been prepared by scant food (Dum~irato) for riding: (Sh, TA:) or horses of generous race, that are not confined in the pasturage, but are confined near to the tents, or dwellings, prepared for running. (R, TA.) And A_ibilN muqorabapN Camels girded for riding: (Sh, O, K:) or camels upon which are saddles (riHaAl) cased with leather, whereon kings ride: but this explanation has been disallowed. (Aboo-Sa'eed [i. e. As], TA.) [See also mukorabaAtN.]

muqoribN * A woman, and a mare, and a ewe or goat, (S, O,) and an ass, (Lth, TA,) near to bringing forth: (S, O, K, TA:) [said to be] not used in relation to a camel; (S, O, TA;) the epithet used in this case being mudonK: (TA:) [but see the verb:] the pl. is maqaAriybu; (S, O, K, TA;) as though they had imagined the sing. to be miqoraAbN. (TA.)
maqorabapN * : see qaraAbapN: -A2- and see also maqorabN.
maqorubapN * : see qaraAbapN; and see also qariybN, latter half.
maqoribapN * : see qaraAbapN.
Almuqar~abuwna * : see Alkaruwbiy~uwna. -A2- See also what here follows, in two places.

$aA^owN muqar~ibN * and ↓ muqar~abN, and halo mino muqar~ibapi xabarK and xabarK ↓ muqar~abapi, occur thus written, probably by mistake, the q being thus put in the place of g: see [mugar~ibN in] art. grb. (TA.)
muqaArabN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

$aYo'N muqaAribN * , with kesr to the r (tropical:) A thing of a middling sort, between the good and the bad: (S, O, K: *) and also a cheap thing: (S, O:) and vawobN muqaAribN a garment that is not good: (Msb:) you should not say ↓ muqaArabN, (ISk, S, O, Msb,) with fet-h: (ISk, Msb:) you say also rajulN muqaAribN [a man of a middling sort]: and mataAEN muqaAribN [a commodity, or commodities, &c., of a middling sort, or cheap]: (TA:) or you say diynN muqaAribN with kesr, [meaning a religion of a middling sort], and ↓ mataAEN muqaArabN with fet-h, (K, TA,) meaning [a commodity, &c.,] not precious. (TA.)

mutaqaAribN * A short man: because his extremities are near together. (O.) ― -b2- And AlmutaqaAribu is the name of The fifteenth metre of verse; (O;) the metre composed of faEuwlunN eight times; (O, K; *) and [one species of] faEuwluno faEuwluno faEalN twice: (K:) so called because its A^awotaAd are near together; there being between every two of them one sabab. (O, K. *)

qarabuwsN * , and qarobuwsN, but the latter is only used in poetry, (S,) by poetic license, (K,) because faEoluwlN is not one of the measures of Arabic words, (S,) or, accord. to AZ, is a dial. form, and, as such, is said by MF, to be written qurobuws, with damm to the q and with the r quiescent, but this is a mistake; (TA;) [A thing] pertaining to the saddle of a horse; (S;) each of the two curved pieces of wood of the saddle of a horse, (IDrd, K,) which form its fore part and its hinder part; [one answering to the pommel of our saddle, and the other being the troussequin;] together corresponding to the $aroxaAni of the [camel's saddle called] raHol: in the qrbws are the EaDudaAni, which are its two legs, that lie against, or upon, the daf~ataAni, which are [the two boards that form] the inner sides of the EDdAn: each qrbws has two legs (EDdAn) and what are termed *iy^obataAni: then come the df~tAn, which are the two things against which comes the baAd~ of the horse; and in the df~tAn are the EiraAqaAni, which are the two edges of the d~ftAn, at the fore part of the saddle and its hinder part: (IDrd:) the pl. is qaraAbiysu. (K.) Some of the people of Syria pronounce the word with tesh-deed, [qar~abuws,] which is wrong; and make its pl. qarabaAbiys, which is more wrong. (O.)

1 qariva * , aor.
qarava , (O, K,) inf. n. qaravN, (TA,) He toiled; and gained or earned, or sought gain or sustenance. (O, K.) -A2- qaravahu AlA^amoru i. q. karavahu. (K.) You say, qaravaniY AlA^amoru and karavaniY, meaning The affair, or event, grieved me; and burdened me heavily, or overburdened me. (As, O.)
8 Aiqotaravati AlbusorataAni * , and Alv~alaAvu, The two unripe dates, and the three, grew together, intermingling. ('Eesà Ibn-'Omar, O and TA in art. sxl.)

qarovN *
A small [leathern vessel for water, of the kind called] rakowap: (O, K:) mentioned by Th, on the authority of IAar: (O:) farovN is a dial. var. thereof; (TA;) [or] this latter, mentioned by Az, in art. frv, is a mistranscription. (O.)
qariyvaY * : see qariyvaA='u.
qaraAvaA='u * : see what next follows, in four places.

busorN qariyvaA='u * , (Ks, S, O, K,) with the lengthened alif and without tenween, (Ks, S, O,) and ↓ qaraAvaA='u; (O, K;) and tamorN qariyvaA='u and ↓ qaraAvaA='u: (Lh, K:) and naxolN qariyvaA='u (Ks, S, O, K) and ↓ qaraAvaA='u: (K:) qariyvaA=' is [thus] used as an epithet, and it is also used as the complement of a prefixed noun; [so that one says also busoru qariyvaA='a, and app. ↓ qaraAvaA='a likewise, and each in like manner with tamoru and with naxolu prefixed;] and it is dualized and is pluralized; and there is no word like it in form, except kariyvaA=', in which the k is app. a substitute [for q]; (ISd, L;) and which is said by AZ to be syn. with qariyvaA=' as applied to busor: (L:) [but kaviyraA='u should be added as a word of the same form; and perhaps there are other instances:] and accord. to Abu-l-Jarráh, one says ↓ tamorN qariyvaY, (S, O,) not with the lengthened alif, (S,) i. e. with the shortened alif: (O:) the meaning is, A species of dates, (S, K,) of (K) the sweetest, or best, thereof, in the state in which they are termed busor; (S, O, * K;) a species of dates, which are black, and of which the skin quickly falls off from the liHaA=' [or flesh] thereof when they become ripe; as AHn says, they are the best of dates in the state in which they are termed busor; and he adds, the dried thereof are black: (L, TA:) [and palm trees that produce such dates:] some say that the word [qryvA='] is A^aEojamiY~ [i. e. foreign or Pers.]. (TA.)

qir~iyvN *
A certain species of fish; (S;) a dial. var. of jir~iyvN [q. v.]. (S, K. *)

1 qaraHahu * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, *) aor.
qaraHa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. qaroHN (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb) and quroHN, (A,) or the latter is a simple subst., (L, Msb,) He wounded him; syn. jaraHahu. (S, Mgh, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- qaraHa biy^orFA: see 8. ― -b3- And quriHa said of an arrow: see 8. ― -b4- quriHa said of a camel, He was attacked by the disease termed quroHap [q. v.]; as also ↓ qur~iHa. (L.) ― -b5- qaraHahu biAlHaq~i, (S, A, L, K, [in some copies of the K qr~Hhu,]) inf. n. qaroHN, (S,) (tropical:) He accused him to his face (Aisotaqobalahu) with truth: (S, A, L, K:) or [simply] he accused him (ramaAhu) with truth. (L.) See an ex. voce quroHaAnN. [See also 3.] -A2- qaraHa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
qaraHa , (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. quruwHN; (S, A, K;) and qariHa, aor.
qaraHa , inf. n. qaraHN; and ↓ AqrH; (K;) the last mentioned by Lh, but bad, or of weak authority, and rejected; (TA;) said of a horse, (A, K,) or of a solid-hoofed animal, (S, Msb,) He finished teething, (S, Msb, K,) completing his fifth year: (S, Msb:) or became in the state corresponding to that of the camel that is termed baAzilN: or shed [his corner-nipper, i. e.] the tooth next after the rabaAEiyap: (K:) when a horse's nipper that is next to the central pair of nippers falls out, and a new tooth grows in its place, he is termed rabaAEK: this is when he has completed his fourth year: and when the time of his quruwH comes, [the corner-nipper which is] the tooth next after the rabaAEiyap falls out, and
his naAb grows in its place: [but by the nAb (which more properly means the tusk, and which does protrude at this time,) must be here meant the permanent corner-nipper, corresponding to the nAb of a human being:] this tooth is his ↓ qaAriH: no tooth is shed, nor is any bred, after quruwH: and when the horse has entered his sixth year, you say of him qado qaraHa: (IAar, T:) one says A^ajo*aEa Almuhoru, and A^avonaY, and A^arobaEa, and qaraHa; the last, only, without A: and of every solid-hoofed animal one says yaqoraHu; and of [the camel, or] every animal that has a foot of the kind termed xuf~, yabozulu; and of every animal that has a divided hoof, yaSolagu. (S.) [See also qaAriHN.] ― -b2- And qaraHa naAbuhu His bAb [here meaning permanent cornernipper as above] grew forth. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence] one says also qaraHato sin~u AlS~abiY~i (tropical:) The tooth of the young male child was about, or ready, to grow forth. (A.) ― -b4- qaraHato, (S, K, TA,) aor.
qaraHa , (S, TA,) inf. n. quruwHN (S, K, TA) and qiraAHN, (TA,) said of a she-camel, She was, or became, in a manifest state of pregnancy: (S, K, TA:) or began to be in a state of pregnancy: or began to show a sign of pregnancy by raising her tail: (TA:) or was in a state in which she was not supposed to be pregnant, and did not give a sign of it with her tail, until her pregnancy became evident in the appearance of her belly. (Lth, TA.) [See also qaAriHN.] -A3- qariHa, aor.
qaraHa , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. qaraHN, (S, A, * Msb, K, TA, [accord. to the CK, app. qaroHN, for the v. is there said to be like samiEa, but this is wrong,]) He, (a man, Msb, K, *) or it, (his skin, S, A,) broke out with quruwH [i. e. purulent pustules]; (S, A, Msb, K;) and [in like manner] ↓ tqr~H it (his body) broke out, or became affected, therewith. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, qariHa qalobu Alr~ajuli mina AlHuzoni (assumed tropical:) [The heart of the man became as though it were ulcerated by grief]. (L.) ― -b3- qariHa, aor.
qaraHa , inf. n. qaraHN, said of a horse, He had a white mark in his face, such as is termed quroHap. (IAar, S.)

2 qr~Hhu *
He wounded him much, or in many places. (Msb.) ― -b2- qur~iHa said of a camel: see 1, near the beginning. ― -b3- [qr~Hhu biAlHaq~i in some copies of the K is a mistranscription; the verb in this phrase being without teshdeed.] ― -b4- qr~H Alwa$oma He pricked, or punctured, the w$m [or tattoo] with the needle. (A.) ― -b5- And [the inf. n.] Alt~aqoriyHu signifies Alt~a$owiyku [by which may be meant The pricking with a thorn: or, as seems to be not improbable from what here follows, it may be from $w~k Alz~aroEu, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b6- qr~H, (A,) inf. n. taqoriyHN, (TA,) said of the [plant called] Earofaj, means (tropical:) It put forth its first growth. (A, TA. *) And qr~H Al$~ajaru (tropical:) The trees put forth the heads [or extremities] of their leaves. (A.) Accord. to AHn, Alt~aqoriyHu signifies (assumed tropical:) The first vegetation of herbs, or leguminous plants, that grow from grain, or seed: and the growing of the stalk of herbs, or leguminous plants; i. e. the appearing of the stem thereof: IAar uses the phrase yanobutu SulobFA ↓ Albaqolu muqotariHFA [as though meaning the herbs, or leguminous plants, grow putting forth the stem in a hard, or firm, state]; but it should be ↓ muqar~iHFA, unless ↓ AiqotaraHa be a dial. var. of qar~aHa: or it may be that ↓ muqotariHFA here means standing upright upon the stem thereof. (TA.) taqoriyHu AlA^aroDi signifies The land's beginning to give growth to plants, or herbage. (TA.)
3 qArHhu * , (K,) inf. n. muqaAraHapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He faced him, confronted him, or encountered him. (S, * A, * K.) You say, laqiytuhu muqaAraHapF (tropical:) I met him face to face. (S, A.)

4 AqrHhu A@ll~`hu *
God caused his skin to break out with quruwH [or purulent pustules]. (S.) ― -b2- And maA zilotu A=kulu Alwaraqa Hat~aY A^aqoraHa $afatiY [app. I ceased not to eat the leaves until my lip broke out with purulent pustules, or sores]. (A. [So accord. to two copies: but perhaps correctly A^uqoriHa.]) ― -b3- And AqrHwA They had their cattle attacked by [what is termed] AlqaroH [which may here mean purulent pustules, or sores]: (S, L:) or they had their camels attacked by the severe and destructive mange or scab termed AlqaroH (K) or AlquroH. (L. [But see qaroHN.]) -A2- See also 1, first quarter.

5 taqar~aHa see 1, near the end. -A2- tqr~H lahu (K, TA) biAl$~ar~i (TA) i. q. tahay~aA^a [app. He prepared himself for him, or it, with evil intent]: and so taqa*~aHa and taqad~aHa [if these be not mistranscriptions]. (TA.)

8 AqtrH rakiy~apF * (A) or biy^orFA, (K,) and ↓ qaraHahaA, (A, K,) He dug a well (A, K) in a place in which one had not been dug, (A,) or in a place wherein water was not [as yet] found. (K.) ― -b2- AuqoturiHa and ↓ quriHa, said of an arrow, (assumed tropical:) It was begun to be made. (TA.) ― -b3- AqtrH Aljamala (tropical:) He rode the camel before it had been ridden [by any other person]. (S, A, K. *) ― -b4- And AqtrH (tropical:) He originated, invented, or excogitated, a thing; made it, did it, produced it, or caused it to be or exist, for the first time; (IAar, Msb, K, TA;) spontaneously, without his having heard it; (IAar, TA;) or without there having been any precedent. (Msb.) (assumed tropical:) He elicited a thing, without having heard it. (K.) And (tropical:) He uttered, or composed, a speech, or discourse, or the like, extemporaneously; without premeditation. (S, A, K, TA.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) He chose for himself, took in preference, or selected. (IAar, L, K.) Hence one says, AqtrH Ealayohi Sawota ka*aA waka*aA (assumed tropical:) He desired of him in preference such and such an air, or such and such a tune or song. (IAar, L.) And one says, A^anaA A^aw~alu mani A@qotaraHa mawad~apa fulaAnK (tropical:) I am the first [who has chosen for himself the love, or affection, of such a one, or] who has taken such a one as a friend. (A.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) He exercised his authority, or judgment, (K, TA,) Ealayohi over him: (TA:) or he demanded some particular thing of some particular person by the exercise of his authority, or judgment, (El-Beyhakee, TA, and Har * p. 142,) and with ungentleness, roughness, or severity. (Har ibid.) And AqtrH Ealayohi bika*aA (tropical:) He exercised his authority, or judgment, over him, in such a thing, and asked without consideration. (TA.) And AqtrH Ealayohi $ayoy^FA (tropical:) He asked of him a thing without consideration. (S, A.) -A2- See also 2, last sentence but one.

qaroHN * and ↓ quroHN A wound; (L;) the bite of a weapon, and of a similar thing that wounds the body: (L, K: [but in some copies of the K, for EaD~u Als~ilaAHi wanaHowihi mim~aA yajoraHu Albadana (which is the reading in the CK), we find ED~ AlslAH wanaHowuhu mm~A yaxoruju biAlbadani, and the L and TA combine the two readings, the latter whereof gives a second signification, which will be found below:]) i. q. juroHN [with which jaroHN is held by many to be syn.]: (TA:) they are two dial. vars., (S, Msb,) like DaEofN and DuEofN, (S,) and jahodN and juhodN, (Fr, Msb, TA,) and wajodN and wujodN; (Fr, TA;) the former of the dial. of El-Hijáz: (Msb:) or the former is an inf. n. and the latter is a simple subst.: (L, Msb:) or the former signifies as above; and the latter signifies its pain: (A:) or the latter seems to bear this latter signification; and the former, to signify wounds themselves: (Yaakoob, TA:) [and the like is said in the L and K:]) [and thus used in a pl. sense, the former is a coll. gen. n.;] and its n. un. is ↓ qaroHapN; and pl. quruwHN: (L:) one says, bihi quroHN mino qaroHK In him is pain from a wound; (A;) or from wounds. (L.) ― -b2- qaroHN also signifies Pustules, or small swellings, when they have become corrupt; (L, K;) [i. e. purulent pustules; and imposthumes, ulcers, or sores: and so ↓ quroHN accord. to the L and some copies of the K, as shown above; but this seems to be of doubtful authority: qaroHN in this sense is a coll. gen. n.:] its n. un. is ↓ qaroHapN; and pl. quruwHN. (S.) Imra-el-Keys (the poet, TA) was called *uw AlquruwHi because the King of the Greeks sent to him a poisoned shirt, from the wearing of which his body became affected with purulent pustules, or ulcers, or sores, (taqar~aHa,) and he died: (S, K, * TA:) or, as some say, he was called *uw AlfuruwjK, with f and j; because he left only daughters. (Es-Suyootee, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (accord. to the K,) or ↓ quroHN, (as in the L,) A severe scab or mange, that destroys young weaned camels; (L, K;) or that attacks young weaned camels, and from which they scarcely ever, or never, recover: so says Lth: Az, however, says that this is a mistake; but that quroHapN signifies a certain disease that attacks camels, expl. below. (L.) -A2- See also qariyHN.

quroHN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. -A2- See also qariyHapN in two places. [Hence] one says, huwa fiY quroHi sin~ihi (tropical:) He is in the first part of his age. (TA.) A^anaA fiY quroHi Alv~alaAviyna (tropical:) I am in the beginning of the thirtieth [year] was said by an Arab of the desert to IAar, who had asked him his age. (TA.) And AlquroHu, (K,) by some written AlquraHu [pl. of ↓ AlquroHapu], (MF, TA,) signifies Three nights (K, TA) of the first part (TA) of the month. (K, TA.)
qaraHN * a subst. signifying The state (in a camel) of having never had the mange, or scab: and (in a child) of having never been attacked by the small-pox. (S.)
qariHN * A man, (Msb,) or a man's skin, (S,) breaking out with quruwH [or purulent pustules]. (S, Msb.)
qaroHapN * : see qaroHN (of which it is the n. un.) in two places: -A2- and see also farojapN.

quroHapN *
A disease that attacks camels, consisting in quruwH [or purulent pustules] in the mouth, in consequence of which the lip hangs down; not scab, or mange. (Az, L, TA.) [See also qaroHN, near the end.] -A2- Also A gur~ap [meaning star, or blaze, or white mark,] in the middle of the forehead of a horse: (T, L:) or what is less than a gur~ap in the face of a horse: (S, K:) or it is a whiteness in the forehead of a horse (Mgh) of the size of a dirhem, or smaller than it; (AO, Mgh, TA;) whereas the gur~ap is larger than a dirhem: (AO, TA:) or what is like a small dirhem between a horse's eyes: (En-Nadr, TA:) or any whiteness, in the face of a horse, which stops short of reaching the place of the halter upon the nose; differently distinguished in relation to its form, as being round, or triangular, or four-sided, or elongated, or scanty: (L, TA:) [and it is also applied to a white mark upon the face of the common fly: (see qaduwHN:) the pl. is quraHN, like gurarN.] ― -b2- [Hence] one says, huwa qaroHapu A^aSoHaAbihi i. e. gur~atuhumo [meaning (tropical:) He is the noble, or eminent, one of his companions; or the chief, or lord, of them]. (A.) ― -b3- And [hence, likewise,] quroHapN signifies also (tropical:) The first, or commencement, of the [rain called] wasomiY~; (A;) and of the [season called] rabiyE; or of the $itaA='. (K.) ― -b4- See also quroHN.
qaroHaAnu * : see qaAriHN, last sentence.

quroHaAn * ([i. e. quroHaAnN or quroHaAnu] with or without tenween, as you please, Sh, TA) A camel that has never been attached by the mange, or scab: (S, K:) and a child, (S, K,) or a man, (A,) that has never been attacked by the small-pox, (T, * S, A, K,) nor by the measles, (T, A,) nor by purulent pustules or the like: (T:) applied alike to one (S, K) and to two (S) and to a pl. number, (S, A, K,) and expl. as meaning persons not yet attacked by disease, (S,) and also applied alike to the male and to the female: (TA:) quroHaAnuwna [as a pl. thereof] is of weak authority, (K,) or disused. (S, A, L.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, A^anota bihi ↓ quroHaAnN mim~aA quriHota i. e. (tropical:) Thou art clear [of that whereof thou hast been accused]. (A, TA.) And A^anota quroHaAnN mino h`*aA AlA^amori (tropical:) Thou art quit of this affair; and so ↓ quraAHiY~N. (Az, K, TA.) ― -b3- And quroHaAn signifies also One who has not witnessed war; and so ↓ quraAHiY~N: ― -b4- and One who has been touched by quruwH [here app. meaning wounds, and perhaps also purulent pustules]: thus having contr. significations: (K:) masc. and fem. (TA.) -A2- Also, quroHaAnN, [with tenween,] A species of kamaA^ap [or truffle], (S, K, TA,) white, small, and having heads like those of the fuTor [or toadstool]: (TA:) one of which is called quroHaAnapN, (S, K,) or ↓ A^aqoraHu. (K.) [See also faroHaAnapN.]
qiroHiyaA='u * : see the next paragraph.

qaraAHN *
Clear, pure, or free from admixture; as also ↓ qariyHN. (AHn, K. [And particularly] Water not mixed with anything: (S, A:) or water not mixed with camphor nor with [any of the perfumes called] HanuwT nor with any other thing: (Msb:) or water not mixed (Mgh, K) with aught of sawiyq, (Mgh,) or with dregs of swyq, (K,) nor any other thing: (Mgh, TA:) such as is drunk after food. (TA.) And Water mixed [thus in the L, and hence in the TA, probably a mistake of a copyist for not mixed] with something to give it a sweet taste, as honey, and dates, and raisins. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (or A^aroDN qaraAHN, A,) A place of seed-produce, having no building upon it, nor any trees in it: (S, Msb:) or land (T, K) lying open to view, (T,) containing neither water nor trees, (T, K,) and not intermixed with anything: (T:) or land having in it no herbage nor any places of growth of herbage: (A:) or any piece of land by itself, having in it no trees nor any intermixture of a place exuding water and producing salt: (Mgh:) or any piece of land by itself, in which palm-trees &c. grow: (L:) or land cleared for sowing and planting: (AHn, K:) as also ↓ qirowaAHN and ↓ qiroyaAHN and ↓ qiroHiyaA='u: (K:) or ↓ qirowaAHN signifies land lying open to the sun, not intermixed with anything: (S:) or [a place] exposed to the sky, not concealed from it by anything: (K:) or a wide tract of land: (A:) or a wide, or plain and wide, expanse of land, not having in it any trees, and not intermixed with anything: (IAar:) or a hard and even tract of land, and a plain tract in which the water is not retained, somewhat elevated, but having an even surface, from which the water flows off to the right and left: (ISh:) the pl. of qaraAHN is A^aqoriHapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or, as some say, this is pl. of ↓ qryH. (TA.)

qariyHN *
Wounded; (S, A, * Mgh, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ maqoruwHN; (A, * Mgh, Msb;) and ↓ qaroHN [an inf. n. used as an epithet and therefore by rule applicable to a pl. as well as to a sing.]: (L:) pl. of the first qaroHaY (S, A, L) and qaraAHaY. (L.) El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee says,
laA yusolimuwna qariyHFA Hl~a wasoTahumaA
yawoma All~iqaA='i walaA yu$owwna mano qaraHuwA
(S, IB) i. e. They will not deliver up to the enemy a wounded man who has alighted in the midst of them, on the day of encounter, nor will they hit in a part not vital him whom they wound. (IB.) ― -b2- See also maqoruwHN, in two places. -A2- And see qaraAHN, first sentence; and end of last sentence. ― -b2- Also A cloud when it first rises. (K.) ― -b3- And The water of a cloud (K, TA) when it descends. (TA.)

qariyHapN * The first water that is drawn forth, or produced, of a well, (S, A, K, TA,) when it is dug; (TA;) and ↓ quroHN signifies the same. (K.) ― -b2- And The first of what pours forth, or descends, [for ASAb in my original I read SaAba] of the contents of clouds. (A.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The first of a thing; (A;) and so ↓ quroHN; and the former, the first of anything. (K.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) A faculty whereby intellectual things are elicited, or excogitated. (MF.) One says, lifulaAnK qariyHapN jay~idapN i. e. (tropical:) Such a one has a good, or an excellent, natural faculty for the elicitation of matters of science: (S, A:) from qariyHapN in the first of the senses expl. above. (S.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) The natural, native, or innate, disposition, temper, or other quality, of a person: (K, TA:) and, as some expl. it, the mind, and intellect: (TA:) pl. qaraAy^iHu. (L.)

quraAHiY~N * : see quroHaAn, in two places. ― -b2- Also One who keeps to the town, or village, not going forth into the desert: (K:) or it is a rel. n. from quraAHN, a certain town, or village, on the shore of the sea. (T.)

AlquraAHiy~ataAni *
The two flanks. (K.)

qurayoHaA='u *
A certain thing (hanapN [perhaps a large calculus, which may weigh several pounds,]) that is found in the belly of the horse, like the head of a man: thus in the K, and the like is said in the T and L. (TA.) ― -b2- And, of the camel, [The ventricle into which it conveys whatever it eats of earth and pebbles;] what is called laq~aATapu AlHaSaY [and more commonly laAqiTapu AlHaSaY, q. v.]. (K.)

qirowaAHN * : see qaraAHN, in two places. ― -b2- haDobapN qirowaAHN A [hill, or mountain, such as is termed] hDbp, that is smooth, bare of herbage, and tall, or long. (TA.) ― -b3- And naxolapN qirowaAHN A tall palm-tree: (S, * A:) or a tall and smooth palm-tree, (K, TA,) of which the lower parts of the branches are bare and long: (TA:) pl. qaraAwiyHu, (K,) and (by poetic license, L) qaraAwiHu. (S.) ― -b4- And naAqapN qirowaAHN, (S, K,) or qirowaAHu AlqawaAy^imi, (A,) A long-legged she-camel; (S, A, K;) described by an Arab of the
desert to As as one that walks as though upon spears [i. e. as though her legs were spears]. (S.) ― -b5- And jamalN qirowaAHN A camel that dislikes the drinking with the great, or old, ones, but drinks with the small, or young, ones, when they come. (AA, K.)
qiroyaAHN * : see qaraAHN.

qaAriHN * A solid-hoofed animal finishing teething, completing his fifth year: (S, Msb:) or in the state corresponding to that of the camel that is termed baAzilN: (K:) [or shedding his corner-nipper: (see qaraHa:)] in the first year he is termed HawoliY~N; then, ja*aEN; then, vaniY~N; then, rabaAEK; and then qaAriHN: (S:) or in the second year, faluw~N; and in the third, ja*aEN: (TA:) pl. qar~aHN (S, K) and qawaAriHu (K) and ↓ maqaAriyHu, (S, K,) the last (which occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, S) anomalous, (K, TA,) as though pl. of miqoraAHN: (TA:) fem. qaAriHN and qaAriHapN, (K,) but the former is the more approved, and the latter is by Az disallowed; (TA;) pl. qawaAriHu. (S.) ― -b2- The tooth by [the growing, or shedding, of] which a horse, or other solid-hoofed animal becomes what is termed qaAriHN; (K;) the [permanent, or the deciduous, cornernipper, or] tooth next but one to the central pair of incisors: pl. qawaAriHu: the teeth thus called are four. (S.) [See qaraHa.] ― -b3- Also A she-camel becoming in a manifest state of pregnancy: (S, K:) or in the first stage of pregnancy: or showing a sign of pregnancy by raising her tail: (TA:) or not supposed to be pregnant, and not giving a sign of being so by raising her tail, until her pregnancy becomes evident in the appearance of her belly: (Lth:) or not known to have conceived until her pregnancy has become manifest: or whose pregnancy is complete: (TA:) or a she-camel is so termed in the days when she is covered by the stallion; after which, when her pregnancy has become manifest, she is termed xalifapN, until she enters upon the term called Alt~aEo$iyr: (IAar:) also a mare that has gone forty days from the commencement of her pregnancy, and more, until it has become known: pl. qawaAriHu and qur~aHN. (TA.) -A2- See also maqoruwHN. -A3- Also A bow having a space between it and its string. (K.) -A4- And AlqaAriHu signifies The lion; as also ↓ AlqaroHaAnu. (K.)

A^aqoraHu * A horse having in his face a [star, or blaze, such as is termed] quroHap: [fem. qaroHaA='u:] (S, A, Mgh:) pl. quroHN. (A.) And it is also an epithet applied [in a similar sense] to every common fly. (A, TA. [See qaduwHN.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] rawoDapN qaroHaA='u (tropical:) [A meadow] in which, (S, K,) or in the middle of which, (TA,) is a white nuw~aArap [or flower]; (S, K, TA;) or in the middle of which are white nawor [or flowers]: (A:) and of which the herbage has appeared. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence also] taEar~aY Ald~ujaY Eano wajohK A^aqoraHa (tropical:) [The darkness became stripped] from the dawn, or daybreak. (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also quroHaAn, last signification. ― -b5- [AaqoraHu in the CK voce qasaAmiY~ is a mistake for the verb A^aqoraHa; not an epithet as Freytag has supposed it to be.]

muqar~aHN * : see maqoruwHN, in two places. ― -b2- Almuqar~aHapu also signifies A^aw~alu AlA_iroTaAbi; (so in copies of the K; but in one copy Almuqar~iHapu; [the right explanation, however, is evidently, I think, A^aw~alu AlA^aroTaAbi, and the meaning (assumed tropical:) The first, or earliest, of the ripe dates; Almuqar~aHapu being an epithet applied to them;]) this being the case when there appear [upon them] what are like quruwH [or purulent pustules]. (TA.)
muqar~iHN * : see 2, last quarter.

muqoruwHN * : see qariyHN. ― -b2- Also Having quruwH [or purulent pustules]. (K.) ― -b3- Also A young weaned camel attacked by the disease termed quroH; [see qaroHN;] as also ↓ qaAriHN: or a camel attacked by the disease termed quroHap; as also ↓ qariyHN and ↓ muqar~aHN: (L:) one says ↓ A_ibilN muqar~aHapN, [accord. to some copies of the K muqar~iHapN, but erroneously, for it is from qur~iHa,] meaning camels having quruwH [or purulent pustules] in their mouths, in consequence of which their lips hang down; (K;) and so A_ibilN qaroHaY [in which the epithet is pl. of ↓ qariyHN]. (L.) ― -b4- And TariyqN maqoruwHN (assumed tropical:) A road in which marks, or tracks, have been made [by the feet of men and of beasts], so that it has been rendered conspicuous. (K, TA.)
maqaAriyHu * an anomalous pl. of qaAriHN, q. v.
muqotariHN * : see 2, last quarter, in two places.

1 qarida * , aor.
qarada , (S, L, K,) inf. n. qaradN, (S, L), It (wool) fell off by degrees from the sheep, and became compacted in lumps, or clotted: (S:) or it (wool, L, and hair, L, K) became contracted together, (L, K,) and knotted in its extremities; (L;) as also ↓ tqr~d. (L, K.) ― -b2- It (a tanned skin) became worm-eaten. (S, K.) -A2- (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, silent by reason of impotence of speech; (S, K;) as also ↓ Aqrd and ↓ qr~d: (K:) or he was, or became, abject, and humble, or submissive: or, acc. to IAar ↓ Aqrd signifies he (a man) was, or became, silent by reason of abjectness: [see also xrida:] or, acc. to another, he was, or became, still and abject. (TA.) See Aqrd below. The verbs are used in these senses because, when a raven or crow lights upon a camel and picks off the ticks (qrodaAn), the beast remains still on account of the ease which it occasions him. (TA.) -A3- qarada, (L, K,) aor.
qarida , (K,) inf. n. qarodN, (L,) He collected together, and gained, (L, K,) for his family. (L.) [You say] qarada fiY Als~iqaA='i He collected clarified butter in the skin; (L, K;) as also qarada samonFA fY Als~iqaA='i: (S, L:) or he collected milk in the skin. (L, K.) See also qalada.

2 qr~dhu * , inf. n. taqoriydN, (K,) He plucked off his (a camel's, S, A) qirodaAn [or ticks]: (S, A, K:) it (a raven, or crow) lighted upon him (a camel), and picked off his qirodaAn [or ticks]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) He rendered him (a camel, L,) submissive, or tractable: (L, K:) because a camel, when he is freed from his ticks (qirodaAn), becomes quiet. (L.) [And, of a camel (?) it is said,] qr~d, (tropical:) he became submissive, and tractable. (K.) [And] qr~dhu, (A, L, K,) and ↓ nazaEa quraAdahu, (A,) [signify] (tropical:) He beguiled him (S, A, L, K) and wheedled, or cajoled, him; (L;) because a man, when he desires to take a refractory camel, first plucks off his ticks (yuqar~iduhu). (S, L.) See also qarida.

4 Aqrd *
He (a camel) became still, quiet, or tranquil, in consequence of his having his ticks pulled off. (A.) [And hence] (tropical:) He (a camel) went at a gentle pace, not shaking, or jolting, his rider. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He was, or became, silent, (K,) still, or quiet, (S, K,) and submissive, (K,) and feigned himself dead. (S, K. See qarida in two places.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a man) clave to the ground by reason of abjectness, or submissiveness. (A.) See art. xarida.
5 tqr~d * , see qarida ― -b2- It (flour) became heaped up, one part upon another. (L, from a trad.)

qirodN * [The ape; the monkey; and the baboon;] a certain animal, (TA,) well known: (L, K:) fem. with p: (S, L, Msb:) pl. [of pauc., of the masc.,] A^aqorudN, (L, Msb,) and A^aqoraAdN, (L, K,) and [of mult., of the same,] quruwdN and qiradapN, (S, L, Msb, K,) and [quasi-pl. n.] qaridapN; (K;) and pl. of the fem., (S, L, Msb,) qiradN. (S, L, Msb, K.) Hence the proverb A^azonaY mino qirodK [More incontinent than an ape]; because the qirod is the most incontinent of animals: (K:) such is generally said to be the meaning of this proverb: (TA:) or (accord. to A'Obeyd, S, L) by qrd is here meant a man of the tribe of Hudheyl, named Kird, the son of Mo'áwiyeh. (S, L, K.) -A2- Aibonu Alqirodi The Hawodal. (TA in art. bnY.)

qaradN * [a coll. gen. n.] Refuse of wool; (L, K;) afterwards applied also to soft hair (wabar), and other hair, and flax: (L:) or soft hair and wool that fall off by degrees from the animals, and become compacted in lumps, or clotted: (L, K:) or refuse of wool, and what falls off by degrees from the sheep, and becomes compacted in lumps, or clotted: (S:) or bad wool: (R:) or the worst of wool and soft hair, and what is picked up thereof from the ground: (Nh:) a piece thereof
is termed qaradapN. (S.) It is said in a proverb, Eakarato EalaY Algazoli biA^axarapK falamo tadaEo binajodK qaradapN, Eakarato meaning EaTafato, [She returned to spinning at last, and left not in Nejd a piece of refuse of wool]: (S, L:) in the K, Eavarato is put for Eakarato; and both readings are mentioned by the relaters of proverbs: [Evrt ElY Algzl app. signifies she applied herself by chance to spinning:] the proverb is applied to him who neglects a needful business when it is possible, and seeks to accomplish it when it is beyond his reach: (K:) its origin is the fact, that a woman neglects spinning while she finds that which she may spin, (of cotton or flax &c., L,) until, when it is beyond her reach, she seeks for refuse of wool among sweepings and rubbish. (L, K.) ― -b2- Also, Palmbranches stripped of their leaves: n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- Also, A thing like down, sticking to the [plant called] Turovuwv. (K.) ― -b4- Also, Little things, [i. e., little flocks of clouds,] less than [what are termed] saHaAb [or clouds in the common acceptation of the term] not conjoined; as also ↓ mutaqar~idN; (K;) in some copies of the K ↓ mutaqar~idapN. (TA.) See also qaridN. -A2- Also, A hesitation in speech; (El-Hejeree, L, K;) because a man who hesitates in his speech is silent respecting somewhat of that which he would say. (L.) See also qarida.

qaridN * Wool sticking together, and compacted in a lump or lumps: (A:) wool, and hair, contracted together, and knotted in its extremities. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] a cloud, or collection of clouds, dissundered, in the tracts of the sky, in parts, or portions, one upon another; cirro-cumulus: (S, L:) or of which the several portions are compacted together, (M, K,) one upon another; likened to soft hair such as is thus termed: (M:) or compacted in lumps, not smooth; as also ↓ mutaqar~idN. (AHn.) See also qaridN. ― -b3- qaridu AlxaSiyli A horse [compact in frame;] not lax. (L, K.) -A2- A camel [&c.] abounding with qirodaAn [or ticks]. (K.) -A3- And qaridN [an epithet used as a subst.] Accumulated foam which the camel casts forth from his mouth. (TA in art. twj. See an ex. in that art. voce mataAwiju.)

qarodadN * (in which the second d is not incorporated into the first because the word is quasi-coordinate to the class of those of the measure faEolalN, S, L,) Elevated ground; (L, K;) as also ↓ quroduwdapN: (K:) or elevated and rugged ground; as also ↓ quroduwdN: (L:) or a rugged and elevated place; (S, L;) as also ↓ quroduwdN: (S:) or a tract similar to what is termed quf~: (As:) or a prominent portion of ground by the side of a depressed place, or hollow: (M:) also, even, or plain, ground: (L:) pl. qaraAdidu and qaraAdiydu; (S, L, K;) the latter form being adopted from a dislike to [the concurrence of] the two dáls: (S, L:) Sb says, that qaraAdiydu is a pl. of qarodadN; but as one also says quroduwdN, there is no reason for this assertion: (L:) ISh says, that ↓ quroduwdapN signifies elevated and rugged ground producing little herbage, and all of it gibbous: and Sh, that it signifies an extended strip [of ground], like the qrdwdp of the back. (TA.)
quroduwdN * : see qarodadN, in two places.

quroduwdapN * : see qarodadN. ― -b2- quroduwdapu AlZ~ahori The upper, or highest, part of the back (L, K) of any beast of carriage: (L:) or the withers; syn. siysaA='N: (As, L:) or the elevated portion of the part called the vabaj; (S, L;) also called quroduwdapu Alv~abaji. (L.) ― -b3- quroduwdapu Al$~itaA='i The severity and sharpness of winter: (K:) or its sterility and severity. (Aboo-Málik, L.)

quraAdN * [a coll. gen. n., The tick; or ticks;] a certain insect, (L, K,) well known, (L,) that clings to camels and the like, (Msb,) [and to dogs &c.,] and bites them; (L;) it is, to them, like the louse to man: (Msb:) [see also HalamapN and HamonaAnN:] n. un. with p: (Msb:) pl. (of pauc., TA,) A^aqoridapN, (L,) and (of mult., L,) qirodaAnN (S, L, Msb, K) and qurudN: (L:) qurodN also signifies the same as quraAdN, (K,) or is a contraction of the pl. qurudN. (L.) A^a*al~u mino quraAdK and A^asofalu mn qrAd [Viler than a tick] are proverbial sayings. (TA.) -A2- AlquraAdu, (K,) or quraAdu Alv~adoYi, (L,) or quraAdu AlS~adori, (S, A,) (tropical:) The nipple (Halamap) of the breast: (S, A, L, K:) called quraAdN and HalamapN as being likened. to a large tick: (Mgh in art. Hlm:) the nipple of the dug of a mare. (K.) -A3- A^am~u AlqirodaAni The place between the fetlock and hoof of a horse: (S, L:) also, the part between the phalanges (sulaAmayaAt) of the foot of a camel. (L.) ― -b2- See also 2.
qaruwdN * A camel that does not impatiently avoid having his ticks (qirodaAn,) plucked off. (L, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) a still, or quiet, man. (A.)

qar~aAdN *
A trainer of the qirod [or ape, monkey, or baboon]. (K.)
mutaqar~idN * : see qaradN and qardN.
mutaqar~idapN * : see qaradN.

qurozuHN * , (AA, S, K,) and qurozuwHN, (TA, and so in one copy of the S.) A certain species of tree: (S, K:) n. un. qurozuHapN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also qurozuHapN A certain herb, or leguminous plant. (Kr, K.) ― -b3- And A certain small tree, (AHn, K,) curling and contracting, (jaEodapN,) and having black jab~ [i. e. grains, or berries, or the like]. (AHn.)

1 qarasa * , aor.
qarisa , (S, A, K,) inf, n. qarosN, (S,) It (cold) was, or became, intense, or vehement; (S, A, K;) as also qarisa, aor.
qarasa , (S, K,) inf. n. qarasN. (S.) ― -b2- It (water) became congealed, or frozen. (S, K.) ― -b3- qrs, inf. n. qrs, [so in the TA, without any syll. signs,] He (a man) was, or became, cold. (TA.) [The verb and its inf. n. in this sense are probably the same as in the sense here next following.] ― -b4- qurisa, inf. n. qarosN; (TA;) or qarisa, [inf. n. qarasN;] (JK;) He (a man smitten by cold) became unable to work (JK, TA) with his hands, (JK,) or with his hand, by reason of the intenseness of the cold, or, as in the L, by reason of cold in his extremities. (TA.) -A2- qarasa AlmaA='a: see 4. -A3- qarasa qariysFA, (TA,) or ↓ qr~shu, (accord. to a copy of the A,) He made, or prepared, what is termed qrys, (A, * TA,) i. e., broth with flesh-meat. (A.)
2 qar~asa see 4, in two places: -A2- and see 1, last signification.

4 Aqrs AlEuwud *
The branch, or twig, had its sap congealed in it. In the M, instead of jamasa maAw^uhu fiyhi, we find Habasa fiyhi maAw^uhu [which is probably a mistake of a copyist]. (TA.) -A2- Aqrshu Albarodu [The cold] made him cold; as also ↓ qr~shu, inf. n. taqoriysN: (S, K:) [or,] accord. to some, by Albrd is here meant sleep: (TA:) or the cold made him unable to work with his hand: (JK:) and Aqrs Albarodu A^aSaAbiEahu the cold made his fingers rigid, by chilness of the extremities, so that he was unable to work. (A, L.) ― -b2- Aqrs AlmaA='a fiY Al$~an~i He cooled the water in the old worn-out skin; (A'Obeyd, TA.) as also qyh ↓ qr~shu; (A'Obeyd, S, A;) and ↓ qarasahu fbh, inf. n. qarosN. (A'Obeyd, TA.)

qarosN *
Intense, or vehement, cold; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ qaArisN and ↓ qariysN. (K.) You say, layolapN *aAtu farosK A night of [intense] cold. (S.) ― -b2- The densest and coldest hoar-frost or rime: (Lth, JK, K:) or the coldest and most copious hoarfrost or rime; as also ↓ qarasN. (M, TA.) ― -b3- See also qaArisN.
qarasN * : see qarosN: ― -b2- and qaArisN.

qariysN * : see qaArisN, in three places: ― -b2- and qarosN. -A2- Broth with flesh-meat. (A.) -A3- samakN qariysN Fish that is cooked, and for which a sauce (SibaAg) is then made, in which it is left until it becomes concreted: (S:) or cooked fish in which a sauce is made, wherein it is left until it becomes concreted, (K, * TA,) but neither congealed nor fluid; [being converted into a gelatinous substance;] as also qariySN: the former is of the dial. of Keys. (TA.)

qaArisN *
Intense, or vehement, cold; as also ↓ qariysN: you should not say qaAriSN. (S.) ― -b2- See also qarosN. ― -b3- In a state of congelation, or freezing; as also ↓ qariysN; (S;) and ↓ qarasN: (IAar, ISk, S, K:) the first and second applied to water: (S:) the last, to anything; (IAar;) but this last was unknown to Abu-l-Gheyth. (S.) ― -b4- Cold; chill; as also ↓ qariysN, (TA,) and ↓ qarosN. (K.) You say
yawomN qaArisN [A cold day]. (A, TA.) And layolapN qaArisapN [A cold night]. (TA.)

qiro$ab~N *
Advanced in years: (As, S, K:) applied to a man. (S.) ― -b2- One who is in a bad state, or condition. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- A man of bad disposition. (Kr, K.) ― -b4- Having a capacious belly. (K.) ― -b5- A great eater; voracious. (K.) ― -b6- A man (TA) corpulent, or bulky, and tall. (K.) ― -b7- Alqiro$ab~N The lion. (K.) ― -b8- Pl. (in each of the above senses, TA) qaraA$ibu. (K.) [See also kiro$ab~N.]

1 qaraSahu * , (S, M, A, Msb,) aor.
qaruSa , (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. qaroSN, (S, M, Msb, Mgh, K,) [He pinched him, or it,] with the two fingers: (S:) or it (a person's skin) with his fingers, so as to pain him: (A:) or he took, or took hold of, it (a man's flesh) with his two fingers, so as to pain him: (K:) or he twisted round two fingers upon it, namely, a thing; or the extremities of the fingers, only: (Msb:) or he scratched him, or it, with his nails: and he pressed, or squeezed, or pinched, him, or it, with the fingers, so as to pain: (M:) or he took it with the ends of his fingers: (Mgh, CK: [one of the explanations of AlqaroSu in the latter being AlqaboSu:]) or he seized it (so accord. to a MS. copy of the K, [the inf. n. being there rendered by AlqaboDu; in the place of which I find in the TA, AlqrD; but this I think a mistranscription;]) with the two fingers, (so in some copies of the K, and in the TA,) so as to pain. (TA.) You say also, qaraSahu biZuforayohi He took [or pinched] his skin with his two nails. (Z, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) It (a flea) bit him: (S, K:) also said of a gnat; (A, TA;) and of a serpent. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (tropical:) [as meaning It pinched him, or pained him,] said of the cold. (A, TA.) ― -b4- And qaraSa, aor. and inf. n. as above, [and quruwSapN seems to be another inf. n. of the same,] (tropical:) It (beverage) bit the tongue. (M.) You say also of [the beverage called] nabiy*, fiyhi quruwSapN (tropical:) In it is a biting quality, affecting the tongue. (A, TA.) ― -b5- Also, qaraSahu bilisaAnihi, (M, Msb,) inf n. qaroSN, (Msb,) (tropical:) He hurt him with his tongue, by saying something which gave pain. (M, * Msb.) And laA tazaAlu taqoruSuniY minoka qaAriSapN (tropical:) [A hurtful saying proceeding from thee does not cease to hurt me]. (A.) ― -b6- qaraSahu also signifies He took it, (M, TA,) or cut it in pieces, namely, anything, (TA,) between two things; (M, TA;) as also ↓ qr~Shu: (Msb:) or the former signifies [simply] he cut it: (K:) and the latter, he cut it in pieces. (A.) Hence, (TA,) A^uqoruSiyhi biAlmaA'i, (S, Mgh, * Msb, * TA,) or bAlmA' ↓ qar~iSiyhi, (S, M, TA,) said in a trad., (S, M, Msb,) respecting the menstrual blood, (S, M,) accord. to different relations: (S, TA:) the latter means, Separate thou its particles [so I here render qaT~iEiyhi] with water; (A'Obeyd, S, TA;) and the former has a similar [but less intensive] meaning: (TA:) or the former means, wash it with the ends of thy fingers; (S, Msb;) and remove it with the nail or the like: (Msb:) or take it [off] with the ends of the fingers: (Mgh:) or rub it hard with the ends of the fingers and the nails, and pour upon it water, so as to remove it and the mark of it. (Az, in Msb, art. Ht; and IAth, * in TA, in the present art.) ― -b7- You say also, qaraSa AlEajiyna, (A,) inf. n. qaroSN; (K;) or ↓ qr~Shu; (M;) He cut the dough to spread it out: (M, A:) or the former, [simply,] he spread out the dough: (K:) or qaraSati AlEajiyna, aor.
qaruSa , inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) she cut the dough, (S,) or spread it out and cut it, (TA,) into pieces, each such as is termed quroSap: (S, TA:) and ↓ qur~Sthu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. taqoriySN, (S, K,) she cut it into many pieces, (S, Msb, K,) each such as is termed quroSap, (S,) or quroS. (Msb.) -A2- qariSa, aor.
qaraSa , (K,) inf. n. qaraSN, (TK,) signifies daAma EalaY AlmunaAfarapi waAlgiybapi (tropical:) [He continued in a course of mutual aversion and defamation]. (K, TA.)

2 qar~aSa see 1, latter half, in four places. ― -b2- qr~S AlmaA='a (tropical:) He cooled the water; or made it cold; as also with s: (TA:) or he made the water cold so that its coldness pinched, or pained. (A.) ― -b3- qr~S All~abana (tropical:) He rendered the milk biting to the tongue; or acid.] (TA.) See qaAriSN.

3 qaAoraSa [qArShu, inf. n. muqaAraSapN, originally, He pinched him, being pinched by him. ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) He regarded him with mutual aversion, and mutually defamed him; or exchanged bad words with him; for] AlmuqaAraSapu signifies AlmunaAfarapu waAlgiybapu: (TA:) or the speaking bad words, one to another. (KL.) You say, bayonahumaA muqaAraSaAtN (tropical:) [Between them two are mutual aversions and defamations]. (A, TA.) See also 6.

6 raA^ayotuhumaA yataqaAraZaAni vum~a raA^ayotuhumaA yataqaAraSaAni * (tropical:) [I saw them two eulogizing each other: then I saw them two regarding each other with aversion, and defaming each other, or speaking bad words, each to the other]. (A, TA.) See 3.

quroSN * and ↓ quroSapN A round cake (K, * TA,) of bread; (S, K, TA;) syn. xubozapN (K, TA) and ragiyfN: (TA:) or such as is very small: (TA:) [or, accord. to present usage, small, but thick:] the former word is the more common: (TA:) or a [round] piece of dough: (M, A: *) [and any similar thing, small, and of a round, flattened form:] pl., (of the former, S, Msb,) A^aqoraASN [a pl. of pauc.] and qiraSapN (S, M, Msb, K) and qiraASN, (M, TA,) [both pls. of mult.;] and (of quroSapN, S, TA,) quraSN; (S, K;) and A^aqoriSapN [is a pl. of pauc. of either]. (K, art. bt.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened to the thing above mentioned, (M,) AlquroSu, (M, TA,) or quroSu Al$~amosi, (S, A, TA,) or ↓ AlquroSapu, (K,) The disk (Eayon) of the sun: (S, M, K, TA:) and sometimes the sun, as a common, or general, term: (M:) or the disk (Eyn) of the sun when it is setting: (TA:) you say, gaAba quroSu Al$~amosi [the disk of the sun set, or disappeared]: (A, TA:) or the Eyn of the sun is called ↓ quroSap, with p, at the setting. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- See also muqar~aSN. ― -b4- [quroSu $ahodK or EasalK A honey-comb: or the same, and $ahodK ↓ quroSapu or EasalK, a portion of a honey-comb: pl. qiraSap.]

[
qaroSapN * inf. n. of un. of qaraSahu; A pinch, or a pinching: &c.: pl. qaraSaAtN.] You say, qaraSahumu AlbaEuwDu qaraSaAtK raqaSuwA minohaA raqaSaAtK (tropical:) [The gnats bit them with several bitings, in consequence of which they danced with several dancings.] (A, TA.)
quroSapN * : see quroSN, in four places.
qaruwSN * : see qar~aASN, in two places.

qariySN *
A kind of condiment, or seasoning; (Lth, M, K;) called in the dial. of Keys qariysN, q. v. (TA.)
