qar~aASN * [an intensive epithet from qaraSahu; That pinches much: &c.: as also ↓ qaruwSN. ― -b2- And hence,] lijaAmN qar~aASN and ↓ qaruwSN (tropical:) A bit that hurts the beast of carriage. (A, TA.)

qaAriSN * [act. part. n. of qaraSahu; Pinching: &c. (See an ex. voce mawoquwSN.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Biting; applied to a flea, &c. ― -b3- And hence,] (tropical:) A certain insect, like the baq~ [q. v.,] (K,) that bites. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also, (tropical:) Pinching, or paining;] applied to cold. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And, applied to milk, (As, S, A, K,) and beverage, (M,) or such as is termed nabiy*, (A, TA,) (tropical:) That bites the tongue: (As, S, M, A, K:) or, when applied to milk, it is to camels' milk in particular, and signifies sour: (M, TA:) in the K is added, or sour milk upon which much fresh is milked so that the acidity goes away: but this is a mistake; for it is an explanation, given by Sgh, of the epithet mumaH~alN, occurring in a verse of Abu-n-Nejm, where it is coupled with qaAriSN. (TA.) It is said in a proverb, EadaA AlqaAriSu faHazara (tropical:) What was biting to the tongue attained to an excessive degree, so that it became acid: meaning, the affair, or case, became distressing. (S.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] qaAriSapN [for kalimapN qaAriSapN] (tropical:) A saying that hurts; (S, M, A;) or that pains; (Msb;) or that troubles and pains one (K, * TA) like the pinching of the body: (TA:) pl. qawaAriSu. (S, A, K.)

miqoraSapN *
A receptacle for milk, in which it is rendered biting to the tongue, or acid: (yuqar~aSu fiyhi:) pl. maqaAriSu. (TA.)

muqar~aSN *
Cut in pieces, [by being] taken between two things. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A woman's ornament round like a quroS: (IF, K:) or set, or adorned, with jewels: (IDrd, M:) such is also called ↓ quroS. (TA.) [This latter name is now applied
to A round convex ornament, generally composed of diamonds set in gold; but sometimes of thin embossed gold, usually with a false emerald set in the centre; worn upon the crown of the headdress by women. For further descriptions, and a figured specimen of each kind, see my work on the Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians, Appendix A.]

1 qaraDahu * , aor.
qariDa , (S, M, A, &c.,) inf. n. qaroDN, (S, M, Msb,) He cut it; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely a thing, (S, Msb,) or a garment, or piece of cloth, (A, Mgh,) with the miqoraAD, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and with the miqoraADaAni; (Msb;) and in like manner, [or as signifying he cut it much, or frequently, or repeatedly,] you say, ↓ qr~Dhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. taqoriyDN: (TA:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) said of a rat, or mouse, (A'Obeyd, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, * Msb, TA,) He [cut it with his teeth; gnawed it; or] ate it; (Msb;) namely a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and bread, &c. (TA.) You say also qaraDahu binaAbihi He cut it with his canine tooth, or fang. (A.) And qaraDa AlbaEiyru jar~atahu, (M, TA,) aor. as above, (A, TA,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) The camel chewed his cud: (M, A, TA:) or returned it [to his mouth, to be chewed again, or to his stomach]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] qaraDa ribaATahu, (S, M, A, K,) [lit.] He cut, or severed, his bond, i. e. the bond of his heart; and consequently, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) he died; (IAar, M, K, TA;) as also qaraDa alone, (S, [in which the former is not explained] O, Msb, K,) and qariDa: (IAar, O, K:) or (assumed tropical:) he was at the point of death. (K.) And you say, jaA='a waqado qaraDa ribaATahu (AZ, Az, S, &c.) (assumed tropical:) He came harassed, or distressed, or fatigued, and at the point of death: (AZ, Az:) or (tropical:) harassed, or distressed, by thirst, or by fatigue: (A:) or (assumed tropical:) in a state of intense thirst and hunger: (M:) said of a man: (S:) mentioned in the S in such a manner as [appears] to indicate that the verb has here the first of the significations mentioned in this art.; but this is not the case [as is shown in the S itself in art. rbT]. (TA.) See also 7. -A2- [Hence also,] qaraDotu AlwaAdiY (assumed tropical:) I passed through, or across, the valley. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur, [xviii. 16,] waA_i*aA garabato taqoriDuhumo *aAta Al$~imaAli (assumed tropical:) And when it [the sun] set, to leave them behind on the left; to pass by and beyond them, leaving them on its left: (S, K:) so explained by AO, or by A'Obeyd: (so accord. to different copies of the S,) to leave them and pass by them on the left; not falling upon them at all: (Jel:) or to turn aside, or away, from them, on the left: (Msb:) or to be over against them, on the left: from qaraDotuhu, meaning Ha*awotuhu, i. e. I was over against him, or it; as also ↓ A^aqoraDotuhu. (JK.) And a man says to his companion, Hast thou passed by such and such a place? and the man asked says qaraDotuhu *aAta Alyamiyni layolFA (assumed tropical:) [I passed by it, leaving it behind, on the right, by night]. (S.) The Arabs say, qaraDotuhu *aAta Alyamiyni, and *aAta Al$~imaAli, and qubulFA, and duburFA, (assumed tropical:) I was over against him, or it, on the right, and on the left, and before, and behind. (Fr.) You say also, qaraDa AlmakaAna, (M, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He turned aside, or away, from the place. (M, Msb, K.) And qaraDa fiY AlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) He traversed the land. (Z.) And qaraDa fiY sayorihi, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He turned to the right and left in his going or journeying. (M, K.) And qariDa, like samiEa, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, passed away from a thing to another thing. (IAar, Sgh, L, K.) -A3- Hence also, (TA,) qaraDa Al$~iEora, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S,) (tropical:) He said, spoke, uttered, or recited, poetry; or he poetized, or versified; syn. qaAla Al$~iEora: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or he composed poetry according to rule: (Msb:) because poetry consists of cut feet: or because it is called qariyD as being likened to the cud: (A:) or because it is language cut out: (Msb:) or as being likened to a garment; as though the poet cut it and divided it into portions; although MF denies that this phrase is from qaraDa as signifying “ he cut: ” he has also assigned to qaroDu Al$~iEori a signification which belongs to taqoriyDN, q. v. (TA.) -A4- Hence also, qaraDahu as syn. with qaAraDahu, q. v. (TA.)

2 qar~aDa see 1, first signification. -A2- taqoriyDN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The art of poetry: (M, TA:) or the criticism thereof; the picking out the faults thereof; and the discriminating, by consideration, of what is good thereof from what is bad, both expressed and speculative. (TA.) -A3- Also, like taqoriyZN; (assumed tropical:) The act of praising: or dispraising: (S, TA:) or it has both these contr. significations; (K, TA;) relating to good and to evil; whereas tqryZ relates only to praise and good. (TA.) You say, fulaAn yuqar~iDu SaAHibahu (assumed tropical:) Such a one praises his companion: or dispraises him. (S.)

3 qArDhu * , inf. n. muqaAraDapN and qiraADN, (M,) [He lent to him, and received from him, a loan: or it signifies, or signifies also,] i. q. A^aqoraDahu, q. v. (L, TA.) ― -b2- qiraADN (S, A, Msb, K) and muqaAraDapN, (S, A, K,) with the people of El-Hijáz, (TA,) also signify i. q. muDaArabapN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as though it were a contract for traversing the land [for traffic], (K,) from AlqaroDu fiY Als~ayori, or, as Z says, from AlqaroDu fiY AlA^aroDi, meaning “ the traversing the land, ” like as mDArbp is from AlD~arobu fiY AlA^aroDi; (TA;) and the form of the contract is what is shown by the following explanation. (K.) You say, qaAraDotuhu, (S, A, Mgh,) or qaAraDotuhu mina AlmaAli, (Msb,) I gave to him property (S, A, Mgh, K *) muDaArabapF, (A, Mgh,) [i. e.] that he might traffic with it, on the condition that the gain should be between us, and the loss should fall upon the property. (S, K. [See also DaArabahu.]) ― -b3- qArDhu, (S, K,) inf. n. muqaAraDapN, (TA,) also signifies (tropical:) He requited him; he compensated him; (S, K;) and so ↓ qaraDahu, (S, K,) inf. n. qaroDN. (TA.) Hence the saying of Abu-l-Wardà, (TA,) A_ino qaAraDota Aln~aAsa qaAraDuwka waA_ino tarakotahumo lamo yatorukuwka waA_ino harabota minohumo A^adorakuwka (tropical:) (A, * TA) [If thou requite men their evil deeds, they will requite thee; and if thou leave them, they will not leave thee; and if thou flee from them, they will overtake thee]: meaning if thou do evil to them, they will do the like thereof to thee; and if thou leave them, thou wilt not be safe from them, for they will not let thee alone; and if thou revile them and injure them, they will revile thee and injure thee: he said this intending thereby to censure them: and it is from the signification of “ cutting. ” (TA.) [See also qaroDN, below.] You say also, fulaAnN yuqaAriDu Aln~aAsa, inf. n. muqaAraDapN, (tropical:) Such a one accords, or agrees, with men. (A.) And qaAraDotuhu Alz~iyaArapa (tropical:) [I interchanged visiting with him]. (A.)

4 AqrDhu *
He cut off for him a portion, to be requited, or compensated, for it. (Sgh, K.) [And hence,] He gave him, or granted him, a qaroD [or loan, or the like]; (S, M, A, * Mgh, * K;) and ↓ qaAraDahu signifies the same as AqrDhu. (L, TA.) You say also, AqrDhu AlmaAla, (M, Msb,) wagayorahu, (M,) [He lent him the property, &c.;] he gave him the property, &c., as a qaroD; (M;) he gave him the property, [&c.,] to demand its return. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur, [lxxiii. 20,] waA^aqoriDuwA A@ll~`ha qaroDFA HasanFA [lit. And lend ye to God a good loan; meaning (assumed tropical:) give ye to God good service for which to be requited]: (S, TA:) it is not here said A_iqoraADFA because the simple subst. [as distinguished from the inf. n.] is what is meant. (TA.) And again, in the same, [ii. 246, and lvii. 11,] mano *aA A@l~a*iY yuqoriDu A@ll~`ha qaroDFA HasanFA, meaning, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák the Grammarian, (assumed tropical:) [Who is he who will offer unto God] a good action or gift, or anything for which a requital may be sought? or, as Akh says, (assumed tropical:) Who will do a good action by following and obeying the command of God? (TA.) The Arabs say, qado A^aqoraDotaniY qaroDFA HasanFA (assumed tropical:) Thou hast done to me a good deed [which I am bound to requite]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., A^aqoriDN EiroDaka liyawomi faqorika (assumed tropical:) [Lend thou thine honour for the day of thy poverty]; meaning, when a man defames thee, do not thou requite him, but reserve his recompense undiminished for thee, as a loan for the payment of which he is responsible, that thou mayest receive it from him in the day of thy need thereof: (TA:) [but see EiroDN.] ― -b2- [And hence,] A^aqoraDaniY Al$~aYo'a He gave, or paid, to me the thing. (M.) -A2- maA Ealayohi maA yuqoriDu Eanohu AlEuyuwna fayasoturuhu (assumed tropical:) [There is not upon him what will turn aside, or away, from him the eyes, and cover him]. (Ibn- 'Abbád, Sgh.) -A3- See alse 1, latter half.

6 taqaAoraDa [taqaAraDaA They lent and received loans, each to and from the other.] -A2- [And hence,] humaA yataqaAraDaAni Alxayora waAl$~ar~a (assumed tropical:) [They two interchanged good and evil, each with the other]; (IKh, S, K;) as also ytqArZAn: (IKh:) [but see the latter in its proper place.] And humaA yataqaAraDaAni AlmadoHa, (AZ,) or Alv~anaA='a, (A, Msb,) or Alv~anaA='a bayonahumo, (TA,) [or bayonahumaA, (in the M, humo yataqaAraDuwna Alv~anaA='a bayonahumo,)] (tropical:) They praise each other; (AZ, Msb;) as also ytqArZAn: (AZ:) or they requite, or compensate, each other with praise. (TA.) And AlqironaAni yataqaAraDaAni Aln~aZara (assumed tropical:) The two opponents, or adversaries, look askance, with anger, each at the other: (S, K:) and yataqaAraDuwna naZarFA (assumed tropical:) They look with enmity and vehement hatred, one at another. (TA.) And humo yataqaAraDuwna Alz~iyaArapa (tropical:) [They interchange visiting]. (A.) El-Kumeyt, says,
yataqaAraDu AlHasana Aljamiyla mina Alt~aA^al~ufi waAlt~azaAwuro
meaning, Interchanging what is good and comely, of sociable conduct and mutual visiting. (O.) ― -b2- El-Hasan El-Basree, being asked whether the companions of the Apostle of God used to jest, or joke, answered, (TA,) naEamo wayataqaAraDuwna, (K, * TA,) i. e. Yes, and they used to recite poetry [one to another]: (TA:) from qariyDN as signifying “ poetry. ” (K.)

7 AnqrDwA * (assumed tropical:) They passed away, or perished, [as though cut off,] (S, K,) all of them, (K,) not one of them remaining; (S;) as also ↓ quriDuwA [perhaps a mistake for qariDuwA: see 1]. (TA.)

8 AqtrD *
He received what is termed qaroD [a loan, or the like], (S, Msb, K,) i. q. Aisotalafa; (A;) minohu from him. (S, A, K.) -A2- AqtrD EiroDahu (assumed tropical:) He defamed him, or spoke evil of him, behind his back or in his absence, or otherwise; syn. AigotaAbahu: (K:) as though he cut off [somewhat] from his honour. (TA.)

10 AstqrD mino fulaAnK * , (S, Msb, *) or AstqrDhu, (A, Mgh,) He sought, or demanded, of such a one what is termed qaroD [a loan, or the like]. (S, A, * Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] AisotaqoraDotuhu Al$~aYo'a I sought, or demanded, of him the gift, or payment [in advance], of the thing. (M.)

qaroDN * (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ qiroDN; (Ks, S, M, K;) or, accord. to Th, the former is an inf. n., and the latter a simple subst., but this [says ISd] does not please me; (M;) or the former is an inf. n. used as a subst.; (Mgh;) or a subst. from A^aqoraDotuhu AlmaAla; (Msb;) [A loan: and the like:] a piece of property which a man cuts off from his [other] articles of property, and which, itself, he receives back; [in rendering the explanation in the Mgh, for the words fayuEoTiyh EynFA in my copy of that work; I read fayuqoDaAhu EayonFA, which makes this agreeable with explanations given in other works;] but what is due to the one from the other as a debt is not so called; (Mgh, [see dayonN;]) what one gives, (S, Msb, K,) to another, (Msb,) of property, (S, Msb,) to receive it back, (S, K,) or to demand it back: (Msb:) or a thing that one gives to be requited for it, or to receive it back: (TA in art. frD:) or a thing of which men demand the payment [or restitution], one of another: (M, L:) or a thing which a man gives, or (assumed tropical:) does, to be requited for it: (Aboo-Is-hák the Grammarian, and TA:) pl. quruwDN. (M, Msb.) You say, Ealayohi qaroDN [He owes a loan], and quruwDN [loans]. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, TA,) (tropical:) What one does, in order to be requited it, of good, and of evil. (S, K, TA.) See three exs. above, under 4. The Arabs also say, qado A^aHosanota qaroDiY, meaning (assumed tropical:) Thou hast done to me a good deed [which I am bound to requite]. (TA.) And laka EinodiY qaroDN HasanN, and qaroDN say~iy^N (assumed tropical:) I owe thee a good deed, and an evil deed. (Aboo-Is-hák the Grammarian, and TA.)
qiroDN * : see qaroDN.

qariyDN * The cud: (Lth, A:) or what the camel returns [to his mouth, to be chewed again, or to his stomach,] of his cud; (S, K;) as also ↓ maqoruwDN: (S:) or it is applied to the cud (jir~ap) of the camel, and signifies chewed: or, accord. to Kr, this is fariyDN, with f. (M.) And hence, accord. to some, the saying HaAla AljariyDu duwna AlqariyDi [explained in art. jrD]: but accord. to others, the last word in this saying has the signification next but one following. (S.) -A2- The sound, or voice, of a man in dying. (Er-Riyáshee, in TA, art. jrD.) -A3- (tropical:) Poetry: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) so called for one or another of the reasons mentioned under 1, last sentence but one; (A, Msb, TA;) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) El-Aghlab El-'Ijlee distinguishes between it and rajaz. (IB.)

quraADapN * [Cuttings; clippings; and the like;] what falls by the action termed AlqaroD; (S, A, * Mgh, * K;) as, for instance, of gold, (S, TA,) and of silver; and of a garment, or piece of cloth, which a tailor cuts with his shears; (TA;) and of this last, and of bread, (JK, TA,) &c., (TA,) by the gnawing (qaroD) of a rat, or mouse: (JK, A, Mgh, TA:) pl. quraADaAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^axa*a AlA^amora biquraADatihi (assumed tropical:) He took the thing, or affair, in its fresh state. (M, L.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] quraADapu AlmaAli (assumed tropical:) [The refuse, or] what is bad, vile, paltry, or of no account, of property. (TA.) ― -b4- quraADapN also relates to an evil action, and an evil saying, which one man directs against another. (TA.) [What is meant by this is not clear to me.]

qar~aADapN *
A certain creeping insect (duwayob~ap) that eats wool. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) A man who defames others, or speaks evil of them, behind their backs, or otherwise; syn. mugotaAbN liln~aAsi. (TA.)

Aibonu miqoraDK * , (S, M, A, Msb,) [in one copy of the S, Abn muqoriDK, and in another, Abn muqar~aDK,] like miqowad, (Msb,) [A species of weasel;] a certain small beast (duwayob~ap), (S, M, Msb,) called in Persian dalahN, (S, Msb,) or dal~ahN, (as in one copy of the S,) whence the arabicized word dalaqN, (Msb,) which kills pigeons, (S, M, A,) seizing upon their throats, and it is a species of rat; (A;) the longbacked quadruped that kills pigeons: (Lth, O, Msb:) this last explanation is given by the author of the Bári', after saying that it is a small beast (dwyb~p), like the cat, which is in houses, and, when angry, gnaws clothes: (Msb:) accord. to some, i. q. Aln~imosu [q. v.]: (Msb:) pl. banaAtu miqoraDK. (A, (Msb.)

muqar~iDaAtu AlA^asaAqiY *
A [kind of] small creeping thing (duwayob~ap), which makes holes in, and cuts, skins used for water or milk. (M.)

miqoraADN * is the sing. of maqaAriyDu; (S, Msb, K;) and a pair thereof is called miqoraADaAni: (Msb, K:) the miqoraAD is [A single blade of a pair of shears or scissors;] a thing with which one [shears, or clips, or] cuts; and when you speak of the two together, you do not say miqoraADN, as the vulgar say, but miqoraADaAni; (Msb;) which last is syn. with jalamaAni [a pair of shears]; a word, accord. to the lexicologists having no sing.; but Sb mentions miqoraADN, thus using the sing. form: (M:) or miqoraADN and miqoraADaAni signify the same; [a pair of shears;] like jlamN and jalamaAni, and qalamN and qalamaAni: (Msb in art. jlm:) or miqoraADN signifies jalamN SagiyrN [a small pair of shears; i. e. a pair of scissors]: (JK:) 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd uses the expression $aforataA miqoraADK [the two blades of a pair of shears or scissors] in a poem; (IB;) and other poets use the sing., mqrAD: (TA:) and miforaASN, with f and S, signifies the same. (IB.) Hence the saying, lisaAnu fulaAni miqoraADu AlA^aEoraADi (tropical:) [The tongue of such a one is the detractor of reputations]. (TA.)
maqoruwDN * pass. part. n. of qaraDahu. ― -b2- See qariyDN.

qiroDiy^N *
One of the strange species of trees of the desert; (AA, O, K, TA;) a certain plant that attaches itself to trees, and wraps itself about them; (TA;) a species of plant (AHn, O, TA) the flower of which is yellower than the waros, (AHn, O, K, TA,) and which grows at the base, or on the stem, of the salam and samur and EurofuT (O, TA) and the like: (O:) n. un. with p. (O, K, TA.)

Q. 1 qaroDabahu *
He cut it; (S, K;) and so qaroSabahu; (K in art. qrSb;) but the former is the more approved: (TA in that art.:) and [the inf. n.] qaroDabapN signifies the cutting vehemently. (TA in the present art.) [See also qiroDaAbN, below; first
sentence.] ― -b2- And He separated it; or separated it into several, or many parts; or dispersed it; i. e., a thing. (K.) ― -b3- And He collected it together; namely, flesh-meat in a cooking-pot: thus it has two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b4- And He ate it entirely; namely, flesh-meat: (K:) and in like manner, qaroDaba Al$~aApa, said of the wolf, he ate entirely the sheep, or goat. (TA.) And [the inf. n.] qaroDabapN is said to signify The [eating indiscriminately,] not clearing, or freeing, the moist, or tender, from the dry, or tough, by reason of vehement voracity. (TA.) ― -b5- And qrDb said of a man, He ate a dry, or tough, thing. (S, O, K.) ― -b6- And He (a man) ran in the manner termed EadowN: (K:) or qaroDabapN signifies [a running] such as falls short of what is termed EadowN. (O.)
qiroDibN * The refuse remaining in the sieve, that is thrown away. (O, K, TA.)

qiroDaAbN * A sharp sword; as also ↓ quroDuwbN: (O:) or both signify a very sharp sword; (K;) as also ↓ quraADibN: (TA in art. qrTb:) or the first signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (O,) a sharp sword, that cuts bones. (S, O.) Both the first and second of these words are compounded from qaraDa and qaDaba, which signify “ he cut. ” (O.) ― -b2- And One who eats much: (TA:) or, as also ↓ quroDuwbN and ↓ qiroDaAbapN and ↓ quraADibN and ↓ muqaroDibN, one who leaves nothing uneaten by him. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And A man who eats what is dry, or tough. (Th, S, O, K.) ― -b4- And AlqiroDaAbu signifies The lion. (O, K.) ― -b5- And qiroDaAbN and ↓ quroDuwbN signify A thief, or robber: pl. qaraADibapN. (S, O, K.) And both words, (the latter, S, O, K, and the former also, K, TA,) sometimes, (S,) A poor man; (S, O, K, TA;) a pauper: (TA:) pl. as above. (K, TA.) ― -b6- maA razaA^otuhu qiroDaAbFA means I did not get, or obtain, or take, from him, or it, anything. (O, K.)
quroDuwbN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
qiroDaAbapN * : see qiroDaAbN; the second in two places.
quraADibN * : see qiroDaAbN; the second in two places.
muqaroDibN * : see qiroDaAbN; the second in two places.

2 qr~T AljaAriyapa * , (S, K,) inf. n. taqoriyTN, (TA,) He adorned the girl, or young woman with the [ornament called] quroT. (S, * K.) A rájiz says, addressing his wife, (S, TA,) who had asked him to adorn her with a pair of ornaments of the kind so called, (TA,)
qar~aTaki A@ll~`hu EalaY AlEayonayoni
EaqaAribFA suwdFA waA^aroqamayoni
(assumed tropical:) [May God suspend to thee, upon the two eyes, black scorpions, and two black and white serpents]. (S, TA.) [See also another tropical usage of the verb voce $an~afa.] ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) qr~T Alfarasa (tropical:) He put, or threw, the bridle (lijaAm) upon the horse's head; (S, TA;) this is what is meant by the explanation A^alojamahaA in the K: (TA:) or he placed the horse's reins behind his ears, in putting the bridle on his head: (Sgh, K: *) or it has the former of the meanings explained above, and also signifies, he (the rider) stretched forth his hand so as to put it upon the back of the horse's head, upon the place where the Ei*aAr is tied, while the horse was running: (IDrd:) or he incited the horse to the most vehement running; (TA, and so in the CK, excepting that Alxayola is there put in this instance in the place of Alfrs;) because, when his running is vehement, the rein is extended upon the ear, and so becomes like the quroT: accord. to the A, qr~T Alfarasa EinaAnahu means (tropical:) he slackened the horse's rein so that it fell upon, or against, the part behind the ear, the place of the quroT, in urging him to run. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (A,) qar~aTotu A_ilayohi rasuwlFA (tropical:) I hastened to him a messenger: (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA:) or I dismissed (lit. flung) in haste to him a messenger: a phrase doubly tropical. (A, TA.) And hence taqoriyTN is used by the vulgar to signify the act of (tropical:) notifying: and (tropical:) desiring to hasten: and (tropical:) straitening: and (tropical:) confirming, or corroborating, in an affair or a command: in all which senses it is trebly tropical. (TA.) -A2- qr~T Ealayohi (tropical:) He gave him little; (K, TA;) or by little and little. (TA.) [This is said in the TA to be from AlqiraATu; app. meaning from AlqiraATu as a dial. var. of AlqiyraATu: but IDrd says, that from this phrase is derived AlqyrAT.] -A3- [He cut, or clipped, money.]

5 tqr~Tt AljaAriyapu *
The girl adorned herself with the [ornament called] quroT. (S, * TA.)

quroTN * [An ear-ring, or ear-drop;] i. q. $anofN: (K:) or the thing that is suspended to the lobe of the ear; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) such as a silver bead fashioned like a pearl, or a pendant of gold; the $nf being that which is in the upper part of the ear: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aqoriTapN (Mgh, Msb) and A^aqoraATN, (K,) and [of mult.] qiraTapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and qiraATN (S, K) and quruwTN. (K.) It is said in a proverb, xu*ohu walawo biquroTaY maAriyapa [Take thou it, although by means of giving for it the two earrings of Máriyeh]; (TA, S, K, in art. mrY;) i. e., take thou it at all events: (K in art. mrY:) this Máriyeh, respecting whom authors differ, was the first Arab woman who wore ear-rings, and her ear-rings are said to have been of great value. (TA.) ― -b2- AlquroTu (tropical:) The Pleiades (Alv~uray~aA): so called by way of comparison. (TA.) -A2- A certain plant, like the ruTubap [or raTobap, a species of trefoil, or clover], except that it is superior in size, or quality, to the latter, (AHn, K,) and larger in the leaves, fed upon by horses and the like; (AHn, TA;) in Persian $abo*ar [or $abodar]. (AHn, K.) [See birosiymN.]
qiraATN * : see what next follows.
qir~aATN * : see what next follows.

qiyraATN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ qirATN, (K, TA,) like kitaAbN, (TA,) or ↓ qir~aATN; (as in some copies of the K) which last is the original form, as is shown by its pl., qaraAriyTu, (S, Msb,) and by its dim., qurayoriyTN, (Msb,) the same change being made in this instance as is made in diynaArN; (S, Msb;) in the ancient Greek language, [ κεράτιον,] said to signify A grain of the xuronuwb [or carob-tree]: (Msb:) [and hence, the weight thereof; a carat; i. e. four grains;] the half of a daAniq, (S, Msb,) accord. to the ancient Greeks: (Msb voce dAnq, q. v.) or it is a weight differing in different countries; in Mekkeh being the twenty-fourth part of a deenár; and in El-'Irák, the twentieth part thereof: (K:) or the twentieth part of a deenár in most countries; but accord. to the people of Syria, the twenty-fourth part thereof. (IAth.) As occurring in a trad., (S, TA,) in which it is said, that he who attends a corpse until it is prayed over shall have a qiyraAT, and he who attends it until it is buried shall have qiyraATaAni, (TA,) qyrAT is explained as meaning, The like of Mount Ohod; (S, TA;) [i. e. a very great reward;] and qyrATAn as meaning the like of two great mountains. (TA.) ― -b2- qiyraATN is also applied by accountants to The twenty-fourth part of a thing; because twenty-four is the first number that has an eighth and a sixth and a fourth and a third and a half without a fraction. (Msb.)
qurayoriyTN * dim. of qiyraATN. (Msb.)

jaAriyapN muqar~aTapN *
A girl having [or being adorned with] the [ornament called] quroT. (K.)

Q. 1 qaroTasa * , (Msb, K,) inf. n. qaroTasapN, (Msb,) He (an archer) [and it (an arrow)] hit the qiroTaAs [or target]. (Msb, K.) It is also allowable to say, qaroTasati Alr~amoyapu The shot went right to the qiroTaAs. (Msb.)

Q. 2 taqaroTasa *
He perished. (Sgh, K.)
qaroTasN * and qiroTasN: see qiroTaAsN.

qiroTaAsN *
Paper; syn. kaAgadN: (K:) or such as is made of the barodiY~ [or papyrus], found in Egypt: (TA:) [and particularly a roll, or scroll, thereof: see also TuwmaArN, and surofapN:] what one writes upon: (S, Msb:) also written quroTaAsN; (S, Msb, K;) but the former is the better known, (Msb), or the former only is of established authority, for El-Járabardee says the contrary of the latter; (MF;) and qaroTaAsN; (Lh, ISd, K;) but this is not mentioned by most of the lexicographers; (MF;) and ↓ qaroTasN signifies the same; (AZ, S, Msb, K;) and so does ↓ qiroTasN. (K [app. on the authority of El-Fárábee and Aboo-'Alyà; but the
names are imperfectly written in the TA.]) ― -b2- qiroTaAsN also signifies A writing, or book, (SaHiyfapN,) of whatever thing it be: (K:) pl. qaraATiysu. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, A butt, or target, to shoot at; (S;) a piece of skin, (Msb,) or any skin, (K,) set up for persons contending in shooting. (Msb, K.) ― -b4- And A kind of burod [q. v.] of the fabric of Egypt. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And A white, or fair, girl, of tall stature. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- And A camel such as is termed A=dam. (Sgh, K.) ― -b7- And A young she-camel. (IAar, K.)

daAb~apN qiroTaAsiy~apN *
A beast of carriage in whose whiteness is no mixture of any other colour. (K.)
muqaroTisN * An archer [and in like manner an arrow] hitting the qiroTaAs. (Msb.) And ramoyapN muqaroTisapN A shot going right to the qiroTaAs. (TA.)

1 qaraZahu * , aor.
qariZa , inf. n. qaroZN, He tanned it, (Msb, TA,) namely, a skin, or hide, (Msb,) or a skin for water or milk, (TA,) with qaraZ, q. v. infra: (Msb, TA:) or he dyed it therewith. (TA.) ― -b2- He plucked it, or gathered it, from the tree; namely, what is called qaraZ. (Msb.) -A2- qaraZotuhu a dial. var. of qaraDotuhu, in the phrase qaraZotuhu *aAta Al$~imaAli, q. v. (Fr, K.) ― -b2- And [in like manner as a dial. var. of qaraDotuhu,] I cut it, or made it and cut it according to a measure and pattern. (Fr.) -A3- qariZa, aor.
qaraZa , He was, or became, a lord, master, chief, or man of rank or quality, after being in a base or abject state. (IAar, O, K; and T in art. qrD.)

2 qr~Zhu * , inf. n. taqoriyZN, He took extraordinary pains, or exceeded the usual degree, in tanning it, namely, a skin, or hide, with qaraZ. (Z.) ― -b2- [And hence, (see 6,)] (tropical:) He praised, or eulogized, him, he, the latter, being living; (S, K, TA;) taA^obiynN signifying the “ doing so when the man is dead; ” (S;) the former signifies he did so truly or falsely. (K.) And fulaAnN yuqar~iZu SaAHibahu, and yuqar~iDuhu, (tropical:) Such a one praises his companion, falsely or truly. (AZ, S, TA.) And yuqar~iZuniY bimaA layosa fiY~a (tropical:) [He praises me for that which is not in me]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- And He praised him immoderately: like fr~Thu. (O in art. frT.) ― -b4- Also, [like qr~Dhu,] (assumed tropical:) He dispraised him: (Kitáb el-Addád, cited by Freytag:) or it relates only to praise and good; but taqoriyDN relates to good and to evil. (TA in art. qrD.)

6 humaA yataqaAraZaAni AlmadoHa * (tropical:) They two praise each other; (S, K, TA;) from 2 in the first of the senses assigned to it above; each embellishing the other like as the qaAriZ embellishes the skin, or hide; (Z, TA;) and ytqArDAn is like it: (TA;) and you say also, humaA yataqaAraZaAni Alxayora wAl$~ar~a [They two interchange good and evil, each with the other]; as also ytqArDAn: (IKh, in TA, art. qrD:) or taqaAruZN relates only to praise and good; but taqaAruDN, to good and evil. (TA.)

qaraZN * , accord. to some, (Msb,) The leaves of the salam [mimosa flava], (Lth, S, Mgh, K,) with which they tan; (Lth, S, Mgh;) but this assertion is [said to be] inaccurate; for the leaves are called xabaT, and camels are fed with them, and they are not used for tanning: some say, that it is a kind of tree; but this also is inaccurate; for one says, “ I plucked, or gathered, qaraZ; ” and trees are not plucked, or gathered: (Msb:) AHn [contradicts this, however, for he applies this word to a kind of tree, and] says, it is the best of things with which hides are tanned in the land of the Arabs; and these are tanned with its leaves and its fruit: [the pods of the sanoT, which is also called qaraZ, are used for tanning;] and in one place he says, it is a large kind of trees, having thick stems (swq [app. a mistranscription for $awok, thorns,]) resembling the walnut-tree, [in the Mgh, evidently from the same source, “ or, as some say, a large kind of trees, having thick thorns ($wok), resembling the walnut-tree, ”] the leaves of which are smaller than those of the apple-tree, and it has grains which are put into balances [for weights, like as are those of the carob-tree]: it grows in the low plains: (TA:) or a kind of tree, whereof the sanoT [mimosa Nilotica, also called acacia Nilotica,] is a species: (M, K, in art. snT:) [or,] correctly speaking, it is [the fruit, or seed with its pericarp, of that tree;] a well-known grain, which comes forth in envelopes, like lentils, from the trees called EiDaAh; (Msb;) or, [to speak more precisely,] the fruit of the sanoT, whence is expressed A^aqaAqiyaA [acacia, i. e. succus acaciæ]; (K;) which is termed EuSaArapu AlqaraZi, [and when inspissated, rub~u AlqaraZi,] and has an acrid property; the best thereof is that which is sweet in odour, heavy, hard, and green; and it strengthens relaxed members, when cooked in water, and poured upon them: (Ibn-Jezleh, TA:) [the last application is that which commonly obtains in the present day: see also 'Abd-el-Lateef, pp. 48-52 of the Arabic text, and De Sacy's translation and notes:] the n. un. is qaraZapN: (AHn, Mgh, Msb:) and the dim. of this is qurayoZapN. (AHn, Msb.) Hence bilaAdu AlqaraZi, applied to El-Yemen, because the qaraZ grows there [most plentifully]. (S.) See also SamoEN.

qaraZiY~N * The dye (Sibog [a mistranscription for diboE i. e. tan]) of the qaraZ. (TA.) ― -b2- See also maqoruwZN. ― -b3- A_ibilN qaraZiy~apN Camels that eat qaraZ. (TA.) ― -b4- kb$ qaraZiY~N and quraZiY~N A ram of El-Yemen; because the qaraZ grows there [most plentifully]. (S, K.)

qar~aAZN *
A seller of qaraZ. (Msb, K.)

qaAriZN *
A plucker, or gatherer, of qaraZ. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in a proverb, (S,) laA A=tiyka A^awo yaw^uwbu AlqaAriZu AlEanaziY~u [I will not come to thee unless the gatherer of qrZ, of the tribe of 'Anazeh, return]: (S, K, but in the latter AlEnzY is omitted:) and Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
waHat~aY yaw^uwba AlqaAriZaAni kilaAhumaA
[And until the two gatherers of qrZ return, each of them]: (S:) the qaAriZaAni were two men of the tribe of 'Anazeh, who went forth in search of qaraZ, and did not return. (S, K.) We also find in the M, laA A=tiyka AlqaAriZa AlEanaziY~a, i. e. I will not come to thee as long as the gatherer of qrZ, of the tribe of 'Anazeh, is absent: AlqArZ AlEnzY being made to occupy the place of Ald~ahora, and being put in the accus. case as an adverbial expression, by an extension of the signification, of which there are parallel instances. (TA.)
taqoriyZ * : see 2. [Used as a subst., (tropical:) An encomium, or eulogy, on a living person: pl. taqaAriyZu and taqoriyZaAtN.]
muqoraZN * : see what next follows.

maqoruwZN * A skin, or hide, tanned with qaraZ; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ qaraZiY~N; and AHn mentions, on the authority of Aboo-Mis-hal, ↓ muqoraZN, as though from A^aqoraZahu, which, he says, we have not heard: (TA:) or dyed therewith. (K.)
See Supplement

Q. 1 qarofaSa [qarofaSa: see qurofuSaA='u, below.] -A2- qarofaSahu, (JK, TA,) inf. n. qarofaSapN (JK, S, K) and qirofaASN, (TA,) He bound his arms beneath his legs: (JK, K:) or he drew him together, (namely, a man,) binding his legs and arms. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qarofaSapN also signifies A certain mode of coitus, in which the woman's extremities are drawn together, so that the man makes fast here arms beneath her legs: (JK, K:) transmitted by Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

Q. 2 taqarofaSato *
She (an old woman) wrapped herself up in her clothes. (JK, K.)
qurofuSaY * and its variations: see what follows.

qurofuSaA='u * , with damm, (K,) [in a copy of the S written without any vowel-sign to the f,] or qurofaSaA='u, (so in a copy of the S) or both, (El-Ashmoonee, in his Expos. of the Alfeeyeh of Ibn- 'Akeel,) and qurufoSaA='u, with damm to the q and r, (IJ, K,) and qurofuSaY, (S, * K,) and qirofiSaY, (Fr, K,) and qaroqaSaY, (K,) of all which the first is the most chaste, (TA,) [all inf. ns., of which the verb, accord. to analogy, is qarofaSa, but I have met with no instance of its occurrence,] A certain mode of sitting; (S;) the sitting upon the buttocks, making the thighs cleave to the belly, and putting the arms round the shanks, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) like as a man binds himself with a piece of cloth round his back and shanks; his arms being in the place of the piece of cloth: (A'Obeyd, S:) or the sitting upon the knees, bending down, (munokab~FA, [in the L mut~akiy^FA, which is a mistranscription,]) making the belly cleave to the thighs, and putting the hands under the arm-pits; (Abu-l-Mahdee, S, K;) a mode of
sitting of the Arabs of the desert: (S:) or the sitting upon the legs, putting the knees together, and contracting the arms to the breast. (IAar, TA.) You say, qaEada AlqrfSA='a He sat in the manner above described. (IAar, S.)
See Supplement

Q. 1 qaromada *
He plastered a pool, (S, L,) or a tank, or cistern, (L,) with the burnt stones called qaromadN: (S, L:) or he plastered thickly. (TA, art. kls.) ― -b2- He constructed a building with such stones. (L.) ― -b3- [He smeared a garment with saffron, or perfume. See muqaromadN.]

qaromadN *
A kind of stones, (S, L, K,) which have holes, (L, K,) and upon which a fire is lighted and kept up until they are thoroughly burnt, (S, L, K, *) when they are used for plastering pools, (S, L,) and tanks, or cisterns, (L,) and for building; (L, K;) as also ↓ qiromiydN: (L:) or a thing [or substance] like gypsum, with which one plasters: (TA:) and qaromadN (L, K) or ↓ qiromiydN (Msb) signifies anything (L) with which one plasters, or smears, (L, Msb, K,) for the purpose of ornament, (Az, L, Msb,) as gypsum, and saffron, (L, Msb, K,) and perfume, &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- Rocks, or masses of stone. (L.) ― -b3- Baked pottery. (L, K.) ― -b4- Also qaromadN (L, K) and ↓ qiromiydN (IAar, As, S, L, Msb, K) [coll. gen. ns.: the n. un. of the latter, qiromiydapN, occurs in the M and TA, voce A_irodab~apN:] Baked bricks: (S, L, Msb, K:) or the baked bricks of baths; in the dial. of Syria: (As, L:) or large baked bricks: (S, voce A_irodab~apN:) or the large baked bricks of houses: (IAar, L:) or a thing resembling baked brick: (TA:) originally Greek, [kerami/s,] (L, Msb,) used by the Arabs in ancient times: (L:) pl. of the latter, qirAmiydu: (IAar, As, S, L:) which is the word in common use. (TA.) ― -b5- Also ↓ qiromiydN i. q. A_irodab~apN, (K,) i. e., A [cover for a] wide sink-hole (baAluwEap) made of baked clay: (TA:) [but see A_irodab~apN].

quromuwdN * The male mountain-goat: (L, K:) or a mountain-kid: pl. qaraAmiydu, (AO, Az, S, L,) with which qaraAhiydu is syn. (Az, L) ― -b2- The fruit of the gaDaAp: (L, K:) or a species thereof; as also quromuwTN. (T, L.)
qiromiydN * : see qiromadN, in four places. -A2- The female mountain-goat, A^urowiy~apN: or this word is corruptly written [for A_irodab~apN]. (K.)

muqaromadN * : see the verb, of which it is the pass. part. n. ― -b2- A building constructed with baked bricks (A=jur~ [or qiromiyd]) or (in the K, and) with stones: (S, L, Msb, K:) or lofty, or high. (K.) ― -b3- A building thickly plastered. (TA, art. kls.) ― -b4- Narrow: (TA:) or made narrow. (L.) ― -b5- A garment smeared with saffron and perfume: (L, Msb:) or smeared with the like of saffron. (K. [in the CK, for bi$ibohi AlzEfrAni is put yu$obihu AlzEfrAna.])

qiromizN * , a Persian word, arabicized; (TA;) [The insect called coccus: and particularly the coccus baphica, or coccus ilicis; commonly called by us, from the Persian and Arabic, kermes: and also applied to that species which is the true cochineal:] a certain Armenian dye, (Lth, K,) of a red colour, (Lth, TA,) obtained from the expressed fluid of a kind of worm found in the woods of Armenia: (Lth, K:) such is said to be the case: and in some of the correct copies of the K we find the following addition: it is said to be red like the lentil, in the form of grains: it falls upon a species of bal~awT, [or oak,] in the month of A=*aAr, [or March, O. S.,] and if not gathered, it becomes a flying thing, and flies: it is used as a dye for animal substances, such as wool and skill, but not cotton. (TA.)

qiromiziY~N *
Dyed with qiromiz: or resembling the colour of that dye: (the book entitled mA lA ysE AlTbyb jhlh, by Ibn-El-Kutbee; cited by Golius:) [in the present day, crimson; or of a deep red colour.]

Q. 1 qaromaTa * , (TA,) [or, as is implied in the S, qaromaTa fiY AlxaT~i, or fY xaT~ihi,] inf. n. qaromaTapN, (S, K,) He made the lines near together in writing: (S:) or he made the characters fine, or slender, or minute, (K, TA,) and the letters and lines near together. (TA.) ― -b2- qrmT fiY xaTowihi, (TA,) [or, as implied in the S, fY Alma$oYi, or fY ma$oyihi,] inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He (a man, TA) contracted his steps in walking or going: (S, K, TA:) and in the same sense qrmT is said of a camel. (TA.)

Q. 3 A_iqoranomaTa * , (S,) or A_iqoram~aTa, (K,) [the former being the original form,] It (skin, S, TA) became contracted, or shrivelled: (K, TA:) or became drawn together, one part to another. (S, TA.) ― -b2- He (a man, AA) became angry. (AA, K.)

qaromaT~iY~N *
One of the ↓ qaraAmiTap [or Karmathians]; (S, K;) i. e. of the people [or sect] thus called. (K.) [See De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., ii. 97.]
qaromaTiyTN * One who contracts his steps in walking or going. (K, * TA.)
AlqaraAmiTapu * : see qaromaTiY~N.
See Supplement

qaronabN * The jerboa; or a rat, or mouse; syn. qaA^orapN: or the young one generated between it and a jerboa: (K:) and frnb [i. e. fironibN, with kesr,] is a dial. var. thereof. (So in the TA. [But I incline to think that qaronabN is a mistranscription for fironibN.])
quronubN * The flank: (IAar, O, K:) or a flabby flank. (TA.)

qaranobaY *
An insect resembling the [beetle called] xunofasaA=', or somewhat larger than the latter, with long hind-legs: (As, T, TA:) or an insect with long hind-legs, resembling the xnfsA=', (S, O, Meyd,) but somewhat larger, (S, O,) having a speckled back. (Meyd.) It is said in prov., AlqaranobaY fiY Eayoni A^um~ihaA HasanapN [The karembà in the eye of its mother is beautiful]. (S, O, Meyd. [Mentioned in the S and O, in art. qrb.]) [See Aibonu AlfaAsiyaA='i, in art. fsw.]
qaronabiyTN * : see qun~abiyTN, in art. qnbT.
qaronasa * : see qrnS.

Q. 1 qaronaSa AlbaAziYa *
He acquired for himself, permanently, for the chase, the hawk, or falcon, (S, K, TA,) by tying it up in order that its feathers might drop off. (TA.) -A2- qaronaSa AlbaAziY The hawk, or falcon, became a permanent acquisition for the chase: the verb being intrans. as well as trans. (K.) Lth mentions it as being written with s [i. e. qaronasa]. (TA.)

baAzN muqaronaSN *
A hawk, or falcon, permanently acquired for the chase, (S, TA,) by the means mentioned above. (TA.)

div2.head: qrw and qrY
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 qaz~a * , [sec. pers., app., qazuzota,] aor.
qazu3a , inf. n. qazaAzapN, He felt, or had a sense of, or was moved with, shame, or pudency; his soul shrank from foul things: (M:) and [in like manner] ↓ tqz~z he was scrupulous in shunning, or avoiding, unclean things, or impurities; (S, M;) he removed himself far from such things; (S, Mgh, K;) and quz~N [an inf. n. of qaz~a] signifies the same as taqaz~uzN. (K, TA.) You say also, qaz~a mina Ald~anasi, inf. n. quz~N, He removed himself far from what was unclean. (TK.) And qaz~ato nafosiY Eani Al$~aYo'i, and qaz~atohu, with and without a prep., (M, TA,) inf. n. qaz~N, (M, K,) My soul, or mind, refused the thing, or rejected it; (M, K, * TA;) a meaning said by IKtt to be of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) and it loathed the thing; which latter is the more common signification: (M, TA:) and [in like manner] Eani Al$~aYo'i ↓ tqz~z he did not eat the thing, nor drink it, willingly: (M, TA:) end mino ↓ tqz~z A^akoli AlD~ab~i wagayorihi [he loathed, or shunned, or
avoided, the eating of the lizard called Db~ &c.]. (S, Mgh, TA.)
5 taqaz~a3a see 1, in three places.

qaz~N *
A quality, or thing, that is to be loathed, or shunned, or avoided, for its uncleanness, in food; as also ↓ quz~u and ↓ qazaAzapN. (M, TA.) See also 1. -A2- A man who feels, or has a sense of, or is moved with, shame, or pudency; whose soul shrinks from foul things: (M, TA:) and, as also ↓ quz~N and ↓ qiz~N, a man scrupulous in shunning, or avoiding, unclean things, or impurities; (S;) who removes himself far from such things; (S, K;) who does not eat nor drink a thing willingly: (M:) and the same three epithets, (TA,) and ↓ qazazN (K) and ↓ quz~aAzN, (IAar, K,) a man well-bred, or polite, (ZariyfN,) who guards against vices or faults, and shuns acts of disobedience and afflictions, not through pride: (K, TA;) fem. qaz~apN and quz~apN and qiz~apN: (M, K: *) the pl. of qaz~N is A^aqiz~aA='u, which is anomalous. (M, TA.) -A3- I. q. A_iboriysamN [Silk: or raw silk:] (K:) or a kind thereof: (S:) or that whereof Abrysm is made; (Lth, Az, Msb, TA;) wherefore some say, that qz~ and Abrysm are like wheat and flour: (Msb:) a Persian word, [originally qazo,] (M, TA,) arabicized: (S, M, Msb:) pl. quzuwzN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, duwdu Alqaz~i The silk-worm.]
quz~N * : see qaz~N; the first in three places, and the second in two.
qiz~N * : see qaz~N; the first in three places, and the second in two.
qazazN * : see qaz~N; the first in three places, and the second in two.
qazaAzapN * : see qaz~N, and see also 1.

qaz~aAzN *
A seller of qaz~, q. v. (K.)
quz~aAzN * : see qaz~N.

1 qazaHa Alqidora * : see 2. -A2- qazaHati Alqidoru, [aor.
qazaHa ,] inf. n. qazoHN and qazaHaAnN, The cooking-pot made what came forth [or overflowed] from it to drip, or fall in drops. (AZ, K, TA.) ― -b2- And qazaHa bibawolihi, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and qaziHa bihi, (A, Mgh, K,) aor. of each
qazaHa , (K,) inf. n. qazoHN (S, K) and quzuwHN; (K;) and bh ↓ qz~H, inf. n. taqoziyHN; (A;) said of a dog, (S, A, Mgh, K,) He ejected his urine, (S, Mgh, TA,) and sprinkled it: (S:) or raised his hind leg, and emitted his urine: (TA:) or ejected his urine with an impetus, or in several discharges. (K, accord. to different copies; as is said in the TA.) ― -b3- qazaHa A^aSola Al$~ajarapi: see 2. -A3- qazaHa also signifies It (a thing, TA) was or became, high, or elevated. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And qazaHato, said of a plant or tree [nabotapN or $aHarapN], It had, or produced, what is termed a taqoziyH [q. v.]. (TA.)

2 qz~H Alqidora * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoziyHN; (S;) and ↓ qazaHahaA, (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
qazaHa , (K,) [inf. n. qazoHN, as indicated in the K;] [He put into the cooking-pot seeds for seasoning, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) called qizoH. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qz~H kalaAmahu (tropical:) He seasoned [meaning he embellished] his speech, or language; syn. tawobalahu. (TA in art. tbl.) taqoziyHu AlHadiyvi mans (tropical:) The embellishing of discourse (K, TA) without lying therein. (TA.) ― -b3- qz~H A^aSola Al$~ajarap, in copies of the K incorrectly ↓ qazaHa, without tesh-deed, (TA,) He made water upon (baw~ala) the root, or stem, of the tree: (K, TA:) or he put urine at the root of the tree to render its fruit abundant. (JK.) ― -b4- See also 1.
5 tqz~H Aln~abaAtu * , (K, TA,) and Al$~ajaru, (TA,) The herbage, and the trees, branched forth into many branches. (K, TA.)
qazoHN * : see qizoHN. ― -b2- Also The urine of the dog. (K.)

qizoHN * (IAar, S, Msb, K) and ↓ qazoHN (IAar, K) Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; syn. taAbalN; (S, K;) or A^abozaArN; (Msb;) that are put into the cooking-pot; such as cuminsees and coriander-seeds: pl. A^aqozaAHN: (TA:) and ↓ taqaAziyHu (a pl. that has no sing., TA) signifies the same as [A^aqozaAHN, i. e.] A^abaAziyru. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And the former (qizoHN) signifies also Onion-seed: (K, TA:) so in the dial. of Syria. (TA.) ― -b3- And The dung of the serpent: (K, TA:) pl. A^aqozaAHN, as above. (TA.)

qawosu quzaHa * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) which is [an appellation applied to The rainbow] in the sky, (S,) i. e. certain streaks of an arched form appearing in the sky in the days of the [season called] rabiyE, after rain, red and yellow and green, (TA,) is imperfectly decl. [accord. to general usage], (S,) [that is to say,] it is a compound of two words whereof the latter is inseparable from the former, so that one may not say taA^am~alo quzaHa famaA A^aboyana qawosahu [Consider thou Kuzah, for how plain is his bow!], (TA,) and the latter word is said to be the name of a certain devil, as such, imperfectly decl., (TA, Msb,) assigned to the same class as zuHal, which, as Mbr says, is imperfectly decl. as being a proper name and deviating from its original form: (TA:) it is said in a trad., Say not ye qawosu quzaHa, for quzaHu is the name of a devil, but say qawosu A@ll~`hi: (Msb, TA:) or quzaHu is the name of a certain angel who is charged with the management of the clouds: or the name of a certain king of the 'Ajam [i. e. Persians or foreigners]: (K: [but SM remarks upon this last saying as being very strange, deemed improbable by his sheykh (MF), and not found by himself in any book except the K:]) or quzaHu is the name of a mountain in El-Muzdelifeh, and the word qawos was prefixed to it because this was the first place over which the qws thus called appeared in the Time of Ignorance: (TA:) or quzaH thus used is from quzoHapN, (Msb, K, TA,) of which quzaHN is pl., (Msb,) and which signifies a streak of yellow and of red and of green, (Msb, K, TA,) which are the colours that are in the [said] qws; (TA;) and if so, it is perfectly decl. [i. e. one says qawosu quzaHK]: (Msb:) or it is from qazaHa signifying it was, or became, high, or elevated: (K, TA:) Dmr strangely asserts that qws qzH is a mistake, and that it is correctly qawosu qazaEK, from qazaEN signifying “ clouds. ” (MF, TA.)

quzoHapN *
A streak of yellow and of red and of green: (Msb, K:) pl. quzaHN. (Msb.)

quzaAHN *
A certain disease that attacks sheep or goats. (K.)

maliyHN qaziyHN * [Seasoned with salt and with the seeds called qizoH;] two epithets applied to food: (A:) accord. to the K, the latter is an imitative sequent: but, correctly, each has its own proper meaning: as is said in the L, the former is from AlmiloHu; and the latter, from AlqizoH. (TA.)

qaz~aAHN *
One who sells the seeds called qizoH, that are used in cooking, for seasoning food. (K.)

qaAziHN *
A hard penis: (K, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) ― -b2- siEorN qaAziHN (tropical:) A dear [or high] current price. (K. [For siEorN, Freytag appears to have read $aEiyrN.])

qawaAziHu AlmaA='i *
The bubbles of water, (K, TA,) that become inflated, and pass away. (TA.)

taqoziyHN *
A thing upon the head of a plant or tree, (K, TA,) that divides into several divisions, (K, * TA,) like the paw of the dog: (K, TA:) a subst. like tamotiynN and tanobiytN. (TA.)
taqaAziyHu * (a pl. that has no sing., TA): see qizoH.

miqozaHapN * , (S, K,) and accord. to some maqozaHapN also is allowable, (MF,) [A vessel, or other receptacle, for the kind of seeds called qizoH, that are used in cooking, for seasoning food;] a thing like a mimolaHap. (S, K.)

muqaz~aHN *
A species of trees ($ajarN) resembling the fig, (K, TA,) of the strange trees of the desert, having short branches, (Mgh, TA,) at the heads of which are what resemble the paw of the dog: so says IAar. (Mgh.) Al$~ajarahu Almuqaz~aHapu, behind which it is forbidden, in a trad., to perform prayer, (TA,) or the performing of prayer towards which is said in a trad. to be disapproved, is said to be A tree of the sort abovementioned: so says Az: (Mgh:) or, as some
say, a tree that branches forth into many branches: (TA: [see 5:]) or a tree at which the dogs and the beasts of prey have emitted their urine may be meant thereby. (Mgh, TA.)
See Supplement

1 qas~ahu * , aor.
qasu3a , (M,) inf. n. qas~N (S, M, A, K) and qus~N and qis~N (A, K) and qasasN, (M, [in which this and the first only are mentioned, accord. to a copy of a portion in my possession,]) He sought after, or pursued, it: and he did so repeatedly, or by degrees, and leisurely, or repeatedly and by degrees and leisurely: (S, M, A, K:) as also ↓ tqs~shu. (A, * K.) [See also qaS~ahu, which, accord. to the TA, is a dial. form of qas~ahu.] You say, AlA^axobaAra ↓ tqs~s [He sought after, or sought after repeatedly, &c., news, or tidings]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] qas~N signifies Calumniation; or malicious and mischievous misrepresentation; (S, M, K;) as also qus~N and qis~N; (K;) and the spreading, or publishing, of discourse, and speaking evil of men behind their backs, or in their absence: (TA:) [probably inf. ns., of which the verb is qas~a; perhaps a trans. verb; for] qas~ahumo signifies He hurt them, or annoyed them, by foul speech; (K;) as though he sought, or sought repeatedly, or by degrees and leisurely, or repeatedly and by degrees and leisurely, after that which would hurt them, or annoy them. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] qas~a maA EalaY AlEaZomi, (A, K,) mina All~aHomi, (A,) aor.
qasu3a , inf. n. qas~N; (TA;) and ↓ qasoqasahu; (K;) or qasoqasa AlEaZoma; of the dial. of El-Yemen; (M;) He sought, or sought repeatedly, or by degrees and leisurely, or repeatedly and by degrees and leisurely, after the meat that was upon the bone, so as not to leave any of it: (A:) or he ate the flesh that was upon the bone, and extracted its marrow: (M, K:) and maA EalaY AlmaAy^idapi ↓ qasoqasa he ate what was upon the table. (M.) -A2- qas~a, [of which the sec. pers. is app. qasusota, and the aor.
qasu3a ,] (TK,) inf. n. ↓ qusuwsapN and ↓ qisiysapN, accord. to all the copies of the K, [so says SM, in the TA, but in the CK ↓ qus~uwsap and ↓ qis~iysap, and in a MS copy of the K I find the latter written ↓ qasiysap,] but correctly ↓ qis~iys~apN, as written by Lth, (TA,) He became a qas~ [or qis~iys]: (K, * TK:) or ↓ qasuwsapN and ↓ qisiys~apN [so in a copy of the M, but in a copy of the A ↓ qusuwsiy~apN and ↓ qis~iysiy~apN, which I hold to be the correct forms of these two words, the former from the pl. of qas~N and the latter from qis~iysN,] are simple substs., (M,) and you say, [using them as such,] lahu Alqusuwsiy~apu and Alqis~iys~apu To him belongs the rank, or office, of qas~ or qis~iys. (A.)

5 taqas~a3a see qas~ahu, in two places. ― -b2- tqs~s A^aSowaAtihumo (S, M, A *) biAll~ayoli, (S, A,) or AlS~awota ↓ taqasoqasa, (K,) He listened to, or endeavoured to hear, (S, M, A, K,) their voices, (S, M, A, *) or the voice, (K,) by night, or in the night. (S, M, A.)

8 Aqs *
He (a lion) sought what he might eat. (M.)
R. Q. 1 qasoqasa * , inf. n. qasoqasapN, He asked, or inquired, respecting the affairs of others. (M: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places.

R. Q. 2
see 5.

qas~N * and ↓ qis~iysN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and sometimes the latter is without teshdeed in the sing., [i. e., ↓ qisiysN, vulgo ↓ qasiysN,] though the pl. is with teshdeed, like as the Arabs sometimes make A^ataAtiynu pl. of A^atuwnN, (Fr,) [Syr. 165, a consenuit, (Golius,)] The head, or chief, of the Christians, in knowledge, or science: (A, K:) or one of the heads, or chiefs, of the Christians, (S, M,) in religion and knowledge or science: (S:) or the learned man of the Christians: (Msb:) or an intelligent, an ingenious, or a clever, and a learned, man: (M:) [in the present day applied to a Christian presbyter, or priest: see jaAvaliyqN:] pl. (of the first, Msb) qusuwsN, (Msb, K,) and (of the second, M, Msb) qis~iysuwna (Fr, M, Msb, K) and qasaAqisapN, (Fr, and so in some copies of the K,) contr. to rule, (TA,) or qasaAwisapN, (M, Sgh, and so in some copies of the K,) contr. to rule, (M,) one of the seens [in the original form, which is qasaAsisapN,] being changed into wáw. (CK [but in the copies of the K which have qasaAqisapN, we find added “ and the seens being many, ” meaning, in the original form qasaAsisapN, or in qis~iysN, “ they change one of them into wáw. ”]) -A2- qas~N also signifies Hoar-frost, or rime. (A, K.) See qas~iY~N.
qasiysN * and qisiys: see qas~N.
qasuwsapN * and qusuwsapN: see qas~a.
qasiysapN * and qisiysapN: see qas~a.
qusuwsiy~apN * : see qas~a.
qisiysiy~apN * : see qas~a.

qas~iY~N * , (S, A, Mgh,) coll. n. qas~iy~apN, (M, Mgh, K,) also pronounced with kesr to the q, [qis~iY~N and qis~iy~apN,] (K,) in the latter manner by the relaters of traditions, but by the people of Egypt with fet-h, (A'Obeyd, S,) A kind of cloths, or garments, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) of flax (A, TA) mixed with silk, brought from Egypt, (S, M, A,) and forbidden to be worn [by the Muslims]: (S, M, Mgh:) so called in relation to a district, (A' Obeyd, S,) or place, (M, K,) or town or village, upon the shore of the sea, (A,) called Alqas~u, (A'Obeyd, S, M, K,) or qas~N, (M, A, Mgh,) between El-'Areesh and El-Faramà, (K,) in Egypt, (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh,) seen by A'Obeyd, but not known to As: (S:) or so called in relation to ↓ qas~N, meaning “ hear-frost, ” or “ rime; ” because of the pure whiteness thereof: (A:) or [originally] qaz~iY~N, (A.) and qaz~iy~apN, (Sh, K,) from qaz~N, meaning “ a kind of silk; ” (TA;) the z being changed into s: (Sh, K:) it was said to 'Alee, What are qas~iy~ap? and he answered, Cloths, or garments, that come to us from Syria, or from Egypt, ribbed, that is, figured after the form of ribs, and having in them what resemble citrons. (Mgh.)

qas~aAsN *
A calumniator; a slanderer: (M:) or one who inquires respecting news, and then makes it known, divulges it, or tells it, in a malicious or mischievous manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like, (TA, voce qat~aAtN.)
qis~iysN * : see qas~N.
qus~uwsapN * : see qas~a.
qis~iysapN * : see qas~a.
qis~iysiy~apN * : see qas~a.
qasoqasN * : see qasoqaAsN.

qasoqaAsN *
A seeker, or one who seeks repeatedly or leisurely, without inadvertence; as also ↓ qasoqasN. (TA.) ― -b2- One who inquires respecting the affairs of others. (M.)

1 qasaba * , aor.
qasiba , It (water) ran, or flowed: (S, O, K:) or it ran, or flowed, with a sound, beneath trees or leaves. (So accord. to different copies of the A.) ― -b2- And qasabati Al$~amosu The sun began to set. (K.) -A2- qasubN, aor.
qasuba , inf. n. qusuwbapN (A, O, K) and qusuwbN, (K,) It was, or became, hard: (O, K:) or hard, and dry, or tough: you say, qasuba Alt~amoru The dates were, or became, hard, and dry, or tough. (A, TA.)

qasobN *
Hard. (S, O, K.) You say, A_in~ahu laqasobu AlEilobaA='i [Verily he is hard in respect of the tendon, or sinew, of the neck.] (TA.) ― -b2- And Hard, and dry, or tough; (TA;) and so ↓ qasiybN. (A, TA.) tamorN qasobN signifies Hard, and dry, or tough, dates, (S, Mgh, * O, K,) that crumble in the mouth and have hard stones: (S, Mgh, O:) [see an ex. in a verse cited in art. rmY, conj. 4:] or [simply] dry, or tough, dates: n. un. with p: (Msb:) or bad dates, (A,) or so ↓ qusaAbapN. (K.) ― -b3- See also qisoyab~N.

qasuwbN *
A xuf~ [or boot]; (IAar, O, K;) accord. to IAar, i. q. qafo$N [expl. by him as meaning a short boot] and nixaAfN [expl. by him as syn. with xuf~N]. (TA.) [See also qas~uwbN.]

qasiybN *
A current, or flow, of water: (ISk, S, O:) or its current, or flow, with a sound: (K:) or its current, or flow, beneath trees: (A, TA:) or its sound beneath leaves (T, A) or rubbish. (T, TA.) -A2- See also qasobN.
qusaAbapN * : see qasobN.

qisoyab~N *
Long, and hard, or strong; (S, O, K, TA;) as applied to anything; and so ↓ qasobN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A tall man. (TA.)

qas~uwbN *
Boots: a word having no [proper] singular. (ISd, K.) [The word used in the sing. sense is qasuwbN, without teshdeed.]
qaAsibN * [or *akarN qaAsibN?] i. q. guromuwlN mutomahil~N, (O, K, [Almutamah~ilu in the CK is a mistake for Almutomahil~,] i. e. *akarN SulobN [Penis durus]. (TA.)

qayosabN *
A species of $ajar [meaning plants]; (IDrd, O, K; *) of the [kind termed] HamoD; (K;) said by AHn to be the ASl [app. A^aSol, and, if not a mistranscription, meaning best sort,] of the HamoD; (TA;) or, as he says, (O, TA,) in one place, (TA,) on the authority of certain of the Arabs of the desert, of 'Omán, (O,) the qayosabap is a plant ($ujayorap, O, or $ajarap, TA) which grows in the manner of slender stalks, from one root or stem, and rises to the measure of a cubit, (O, TA,) having a leaf intensely green, round, and somewhat long, (O,) the flower of which is like that of the violet, (O, TA,) exactly; (O;) and it serves as fuel in its fresh, or moist, state, like as does the dry. (TA.)
*akarN qayosabaAnN * [in the CK qayosabaAnu] Penis durus et crassus. (K.)

[
muqas~abN * said by Freytag to occur in the Deewán of Jereer as an epithet applied to poison, signifying Having things whereby its potency is augmented mixed with it, is evidently a mistranscription for muqa$~abN.]

1 qasaHa * , aor.
qasaHa , inf. n. qasaAHapN and qusuwHapN, It was, or became, hard, firm, or tough. (S, [in two copies belonging to me, but omitted in a third,] K.) ― -b2- And qasaHa He twisted a rope. (K.) -A2- Also, aor. as above, inf. n. qusuwHN, (TA,) and ↓ A^aqsH (in some copies of the K ↓ AqtsH, TA,) He (a man) was much, or frequently, excited by vehement lust: (S, [in two copies belonging to me, but omitted in a third,] K:) or was excited by vehement lust. (TA.)

3 qAsaHahu *
He treated him with dryness and hardness, or niggardliness; syn. yaAbasahu. (L, K.)
4 A^aqosaHa see 1.
8 A_iqotasaHa see 1.
qasaHN * , (K,) and ↓ qusuwHN, and ↓ qasaAHN, (TA,) Dryness, syn. yubosN; ― -b2- or the remains of vehement lust, (K,) or its continuance, or its intenseness. (L.)

qaAsiHN *
A hard and strong spear. (TA.) ― -b2- A thick or coarse garment, syn. galiyZN. (K.) -A2- Also, and ↓ qusaAHN, and ↓ maqosuwHN, A man in a state of excitement, or frequently in a state of excitement, by vehement lust. ISd knows no way of accounting for the last of these epithets but by supposing it to be used for the act. part. n., like maA^otiy~FA in the Kur, xix, 62, for A=tiyFA. (TA.)
qasaAHN * : see qasaHN.
qusaAHN * : see qaAsiHN ― -b2- [You say also] A_in~ahu laqusaAHN ↓ maqosuwH (T, K) Verily he is dry or hard. (TA.)
qusuwHN * : see qasaHN.
maqosuwHN * : see qaAsiHN and qusaAHN.

1 qasarahu EalaY AlA^amori * , (S, K,) aor.
qasira , (M, S, TA,) inf. n. qasorN; (S, TA;) and Ealayohi ↓ Aqtsrhu; (S, K;) He made him to do the thing against his will; (S;) he forced him to do the thing: (S, K:) or qasarahu ElY AlAmr has the former of these two significations; (TA;) and qasarahu and ↓ Aqtsrhu signify he overcame him; he overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, him; (M, TA;) and ↓ tqs~rhu signifies the same as Aqtsrhu. (TA.)
5 taqas~ara and 8: see 1.

qasowarN * (S, TA) and qasowarapN, (K, TA,) the former a coll. gen. n., and the latter the n. un., (M,) A certain plant, (S, M, K,) which grows in plain, or soft, land; (M, K;) a sour plant, of the kind called najiyl, which is like the jum~ap [or full and long hair of the head] of a man, and becomes tall and large, of which camels are greedily fond, (AHn, M,) and which fattens them, and makes them plentiful in milk. (Az, TA.) Lth is in error in saying that the former signifies a huntsman, or hunter; for it signifies a plant, as IAar and AHn and others have said. -A2- See also qasowarapN, in two places.

qasowarapN *
Mighty; (M, K;) that overpowers, or subdues, others: (M, TA:) also strong; applied to a man: and courageous: (TA:) pl. qasaAwiru. (M.) ― -b2- A lion; as also ↓ qasowarN: (S, M, K:) because he overcomes and overpowers. (TA.) So in the Kur, [lxxiv. 51,] kaA^at~ahumo HumurN musotanofirapN far~ato mino qasowarapK [As though they were asses taking fright and running away at random that have fled from a lion]. (S, M.) Or it has here the signification next following. (S.) ― -b3- Hunters that shoot, or cast: (S, K:) sing. ↓ qasowarN; (K;) accord. to Lth.; [and in the M it is said that ↓ qasowarN signifies a shooter, or caster: or, accord. to some, a hunter:] but this is a mistake; for qswrp is a coll. n., having no sing.; and Fr says, that in the verse of the Kur cited above, it means shooters, or casters of missile weapons: it is also related of 'Ikrimeh, that it was said to him that qswrp signifies, in the Abyssinian language, a lion; but he said that is signification is that given above on the authority of Fr, and that the lion in the Abyssinian language is called Eanobasap: and Ibn-'Arafeh says qswrp is of the measure faEowalapN from Alqasoru; and that the meaning [in the Kur] is, as though they were asses made to take fright and run away by shooting or hunting &c. (TA.) Or, accord. to I'Ab, in the passage above cited, it has the signification here next following. (IKt, TA.) -A2- The sound of men, (IKt, K, TA,) and their voices, or cries. (IKt, TA.)
qawosarapN * and qawosar~apN dial. forms of qawoSarapN and qawoSar~apN, which see. (M, K.)

1 qasaTa * , (S, M, &c.,) aor.
qasiTa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. qusuwTN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and qasoTN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) He declined, or deviated, from the right course; acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically. (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) -A2- See also 4, in two places: -A3- and see 2.

2 qs~Thu * , (IAar, M, TA,) inf. n. taqosiyTN, (IAar, TA,) He distributed it; or dispersed it. (IAar, M, TA.) It is implied in the K that the verb in this sense is ↓ qasaTa, of three letters [only, without teshdeed]. (TA.) You say, qs~T AlmaAla biyonahumo He distributed the property among them. (TA.) And qs~T AlxaraAja Ealayohimo He assigned the several portions which each one of them should pay of the [tax called] xrAj: (TA:) or qs~T AlxaraAja, inf. n. as above, signifies he assessed, or apportioned, the xrAj (Mgh, Msb) with equity and equality, (Mgh,) to be paid at certain times. (Msb.) ― -b2- qs~T EalaY EiyaAlihi Aln~afaqapa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He was niggardly, or parsimonious, towards his household in expenditure. (K, * TA.)

4 AqsT * , (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. A_iqosaATN, (Mgh, K,) He acted equitably, or justly, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in his judgment or the like; (M, TA;) as also, (Msb, K,) accord. to IKtt, (Msb,) ↓ qasaTa, aor.
qasiTa (Msb, K) and
qasuTa , (K,) but the former of these aors., as well as the former verb, is the more known, (TA,) inf. n. qasoTN, (Msb, TA,) or qisoTN [q. v. infra]; (M, K;) or A_iqosaATN is only in division: (TA:) thus the latter of these two verbs is made to have two contr. significations: (Msb, TA:) in the former of them, accord. to some, the A^ has a privative effect, [so that the verb properly signifies he did away with, or put away, injustice, or the like,] as [it has in A$kAh] in the phrase $akaY A_ilyasohi faA^a$okaAhu [he complained to him and he made his complaint to cease]. (TA.) It is said in the Kur,
[iv. 3,] waA_ino xifotumo A^al~aA tuqosiTuwA fiY AlyataAmaY [And if ye fear lest ye should not act equitably with respect to the orphans]: (Mgh:) or, accord. to one reading, ↓ taqosuTuwA, with damm to the s. (TA.) And you say also, A^aqosaTotu bayonahumo [I acted equitably between them], and A_ilayohimo [towards them]. (TA.)

5 taqas~aTuwA Al$~aYo'i bayonahumo *
They divided the thing among themselves (Lth, S, * M [in which last bynhm is omitted] and O, L, K) equitably, (M, O,) or equitably and equally, (L,) or with equality. (Lth, K.) You say also, AlmaAla bayonahumo ↓ A_iqotasaTuwA They divided the property among themselves; (TK;) A_iqotisaATN being syn. with A_iqotisaAmN. (K.)
8 A_iqotasaTa see 5.

qusoTN * a dial. var. of kusoTN, or, accord. to Yaakoob, the q is a substitute [for k]; (M;) said by IF to be Arabic; (Msb;) [Costus; so in the present day;] a certain substance, (AA, Msb,) or perfume, (Mgh,) or wood, (M,) or a certain Indian wood, and also Arabian, (K,) with which one fumigates; (AA, M, Mgh, Msb;) well known; (Msb;) also called kusoTN and ku$oTN (AA) and qu$oTN: (TA in art. q$T:) or a wood which is brought from India, and which is put into the substances used for fumigating, and into medicine: (Lth:) or a certain drug of the sea: (S:) [it is said in the S and TA, voce HinozaAbN, that the carrot of the (jazaru AlbaHori) is called qusoTN:] in a trad., AlqusoTu AlbaHoriY~u [or qusoT of the sea] is mentioned as one of the best of remedies: and in another trad., qusoT is coupled by the conjunction w with A^aZofaAr, or, accord. to one relation thereof, is prefixed to the latter word, governing it in the gen. case: and IAth says, that it is a sort of perfume: but some say that it is aloes-wood (Euwd, q. v.): [see also ZafaAriY~N:] and others, a well-known drug, of sweet odour, with which women and infants are fumigated: (TA:) it is diuretic, beneficial to the liver in a high degree, and for the colic, and for worms, and the quartan fever, as a beverage; and for rheum, and defluxions, and pestilence, when the patient is fumigated therewith; and for the [leprous-like disorder called] bahaq, and the [discolouration of the face termed] kalaf, when applied as a liniment; (K;) and it confines the bowels, expels wind, strengthens the stomach and heart, occasions pleasurable sensation, is an ingredient in many sorts of perfume, and is the best of perfumes in odour when one fumigates therewith. (TA.)

qisoTN *
Equity; justice: (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K: *) [an inf. n. having no proper verb, or] a subst. from A^aqosaTa. (Mgh, Msb.) -A2- Equitable; just: (S, * M, K:) an inf. n. used as an epithet, like its syn. EadolN; (M, K;) and [therefore] applied alike to a sing. n. [and to a dual] and to a pl.: (K:) you say miyzaAnN qisoTN an equitable, or a just, balance; and miyzaAnaAni qisoTN; and, agreeably with the usage of the Kur, xxi. 48, mawaAziynu qisoTN. (M.) -A3- A portion, share, or lot; (S, M, Msb, K;) of a thing; (K;) and pertaining to a person: (TA:) pl. A^aqosaATN. (Msb.) You say, waf~aAhu qisoTahu He gave him in full his portion, share, or lot. (TA.) And A^axa*a kul~N mina Al$~urakaA='i qisoTahu Every one of the partners took his portion, or share. (TA.) ― -b2- A portion, or piece. (So accord. to an explanation of the pl., A^aqosaATN, in the TA.) ― -b3- The means of subsistence: (K:) or the portion thereof which is the share of every created being. (TA.) yaxofiDu AlqisoTa wayarofaEuhu, said of God, in a trad., has been explained as meaning He maketh the portion of the means of subsistence which is the share of any created being little, and maketh it much. (TA.) [See, below, another meaning which is assigned to it in this instance; and see also art. xfD.] ― -b4- A quantity, (K, TA,) of water only; or any quantity, of water and of other things. (TA.) ― -b5- A measure with which corn is measured, (S, Mgh, K,) which holds (K) half of a SaAE; (S, Mgh, K;) six thereof making a faroqa: (S:) accord. to Mbr, four hundred and eighty-one dirhems. (TA.) Sometimes it is used for performing the ablution termed wuDuwo': and hence it is said in a trad., A_in~a Aln~isaA='a mino A^asofahi Als~ufahaA='i A_il~aA SaAHibapa AlqisoTi waAls~iraAji; (K;) the qisoT being here the vessel in which the wDw' is performed; (TA;) the meaning app. being, [Women are of the most lightwitted of the lightwitted,] except she who serves her husband, and assists him to perform the wDw', [so I render tuwaD~iy^uhu,] and takes care of the vessel which he uses for that purpose, and stands at his head with the lamp: (K:) or who performs his affairs with respect to his wDw' and his lamp. (Nh.) ― -b6- A [mug of the kind called] kuwz; (M, K;) so called by the people of the great towns: (M:) now applied to one with which olive-oil is measured. (TA.) ― -b7- A balance, or weighing-instrument. (K.) Some say that this is its meaning in the phrase mentioned above, yaxofiDu AlqisoTa wayarofaEuhu He depresseth the balance, and raiseth it: alluding to the means of subsistence which He decrees. (TA.)

qaAsiTN *
Declining, or deviating, from the right course; acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically: pl. qaAsiTuwna (S, M, Mgh, TA) and qus~aATN. (TA.) You say, huwa qaAsiTN gayoru muqosiTK He is declining, or deviating, from the right course; &c.: not acting equitably, or justly. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [lxxii. 15,] A^am~aA A@loqaAsiTuwna fakaAnuwA lijahan~ama HaTabFA [As for the deviators from the right course, they shall be fuel for hell]. (S, M, Mgh.) [See also EaAdilN.] ― -b2- AlqaAsiTuwna is also specially applied to The party of Mo'áwiyeh; (Mgh;) the people of Siffeen. (TA.) ― -b3- [And it has the contr. meaning, i. e. Acting equitably, or justly. See, again, EaAdilN.]

A^aqosaTu *
More [and most] equitable, just, or right: occurring in the Kur, ii. 282, and xxxiii. 5: (TA:) formed from the triliteral verb [qasaTa], not from the quadriliteral [A^aqosaTa], as some assert it to be, holding it anomalous. (MF.)
taqosiyTN * The register in which is written a man's portion, or share, (qisoT,) of property &c: a subst., like tamotiynN. (TA.)

muqosiTN *
Acting equitably, or justly. (S, M.) It is said in the Kur, [v. 46, and xlix. 9, and lx. 8,] A_in~a A@ll~`ha yuHib~u AlmuqosiTiyna [God loveth those who act equitably, or justly]. (S, M.) ― -b2- AlmuqosiTu is one of the names of God, meaning The Equitable. (TA.)

qusoTaAsN * and qisoTaAsN A balance, or instrument for weighing: (S, Msb, K; and Bd in xvii. 37:) or the most even and most just kind thereof: or such as is just, of whatever kind it be: (K:) or i. q. qab~aAnN [a steelyard]: or, as Lth thinks, the iron of the qb~An: or i. q. $aAhiynN [the beam of a balance]: (TA:) or i. q. farasoTuwnN [an arabicized Persian word, signifying a public standard of weights or measures]: (Zj, TA:) also written qSTAs: (K:) said to be Arabic, from AlqisoTu, meaning “ justice: ” (Msb:) or a Greek word arabicized; (IDrd, Msb, K;) and its being so does not impugn the truth of the Kur-án's being [altogether] Arabic; for when a foreign word is used by the Arabs, and made by them conformable with their language in respect of desinential syntax and determinateness and indeterminateness and the like, it becomes Arabic: (Bd, ubi supra:) pl. qasaATiysu. (Msb.)
See Supplement

1 qa$obN * signifies The act of mixing. (S, Mgh, O, K.) You say, qa$aba, aor.
qa$iba , inf. n. qa$obN, He mixed. (K.) And qu$iba, said of anything, It was mixed. (M.) ― -b2- And qa$abahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He corrupted, or vitiated, it: (K, TA:) or he mixed it (i. e. anything) with a thing that corrupted, or vitiated, it. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] qa$aba AlT~aEaAma, (S, M,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He poisoned the food; (S;) he mixed the food with poison; as also ↓ q$~bhu: (M, TA:) or qa$aba signifies he mixed poison, and so prepared it that it should take effect upon the body. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And qa$abahu, (S, O, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., He gave him poison to drink; (S, O, K;) and (TA) so lahu ↓ q$~b. (M, TA.) And qa$aba Aln~asora He put poison on flesh-
meat for the vulture, that he might eat it and die, and he might take his feathers. (AA, TA.) ― -b5- And [hence] qa$abaniY riyHuhu; (K, TA;) and (TA) ryHh ↓ qa$~abaniY, inf. n. taqo$iybN; (S, TA;) His, or its, odour annoyed me: (S, K, TA:) as though meaning it poisoned me. (S, TA.) qa$abahu and ↓ q$~bhu both signify He, or it, annoyed him. (Mgh.) And qa$abahu Ald~uxaAnu means The smoke annoyed him by its odour; and oppressed, or overpowered, him. (O.) qa$obN [in a case of this kind], (O, K,) as inf. n. of qa$aba, aor.
qa$iba , (K,) means The affecting [a person] with what is displeasing, or hateful, and with what is deemed unclean, or filthy: (O, K: [in the former Alqa$obu is expl. by the words AlASAbpu bmA yukorahu wyusotaqo*aru; which, as well as what here follows, shows that an assertion in the TK (copied from the TA, and adopted by Freytag) respecting the explanation in the K, is erroneous:]) and hence the saying of 'Omar, when he perceived the odour of perfume from Mo'áwiyeh when the latter was a pilgrim, mano qa$abanaA [i. e. Who has affected us with what is displeasing &c.?]; likening the odour of perfume in this case to a stink. (O.) ― -b6- qa$obN also signifies The depriving [one] of reason; (K, TA;) from the same word as signifying the act of “ corrupting, ” or “ vitiating: ” (TA:) and its verb is qa$aba, aor.
qa$iba . (K, TA.) 'Omar said to one of his sons, qa$abaka AlmaAlu (M, O, TA) i. e. Wealth has deprived thee of thy reason: (M:) or has corrupted, or vitiated, thee, and deprived thee of thy reason. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And qa$abahu, (S, M, O, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) He spoke evil of him: (S, O:) (tropical:) he aspersed him, or upbraided him, (M, K, TA,) bi$aYo'K with a thing; (K, TA;) and so ↓ q$~bhu, inf. n. taqo$iybN: (accord. to some copies of the K, and said in the TA to be agreeable with usage:) and (tropical:) he reproached him with disgraceful conduct. (M, K, TA.) You say, qa$abahu biqabiyHK (tropical:) He charged, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul. (S, O, TA.) And qa$abahu bi$ar~K (assumed tropical:) He cast upon him an evil imputation that was a mark whereby he should, or would, be known. (M, TA.) And qa$abahu biEayobi nafosihi (assumed tropical:) He imputed to him, or charged him with, his own vice, or fault. (IAar, TA.) And qa$abanaA (assumed tropical:) He reproached, or upbraided, us with, or accused us of, a thing that was not in us: (O:) [or] he commanded us to forbear from a thing that was not in us. (TA.) And qa$aba, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He forged, or fabricated, a lie, or falsehood. (K, TA.) -A2- qa$aba Ails~ayofa, (O, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) He polished the sword; (O, K;) removed its qi$ob [i. e. rust]. (O.) -A3- And qa$aba, (S, M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (M, K;) or qa$iba, with kesr; (O, as on the authority of Fr;) He (a man, S, M, O) gained, or acquired, praise or blame; (Fr, S, M, O, K;) as also ↓ Aqt$b. (S, M, K.) -A4- qa$uba, (Th, M, K,) aor.
qa$uba , inf. n. qa$aAabpN, (K,) It (a garment, Th, M, TA) was new and clean: (Th, M, TA:) or it was white and clean. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And qa$uba, (thus written in my copy of the TA,) or qa$iba, (thus in a copy of the M,) It (a thing) was, or became, unclean, dirty, or filthy. (M, TA.)
2 q$~b * : see the preceding paragraph, in five places. ― -b2- Also, He rendered a thing unclean, dirty, or filthy. (M, TA.)

4 maA A^aqo$aba bayotahumo *
How unclean, dirty, or filthy, is their tent or house! (O,) or, what surrounds their tent or house, by reason of the human excrement, or ordure! (TA.)
8 A_iqota$aba see 1, last sentence but two.

10 Astq$bhu *
He deemed it (i. e. a thing) unclean, dirty, or filthy. (M, TA.)

qa$obN * inf. n. of qa$aba [q. v.] ― -b2- [The explanations of this word by Golius and Freytag, by the former as an epithet applied in two contr. senses to a sword, and by the latter as a subst. (from a misstatement in the TK mentioned above), are erroneous.]

qi$obN *
Poison; (S, M, Mgh, O, K;) because consisting of things mixed together; (Mgh;) as also ↓ qa$abN: (M, K:) pl. of the former A^aqo$aAbN. (S, M.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] A certain plant, (M, O, K,) resembling the maqir, (M, [which is generally said to mean the aloe, and by AHn to be a certain plant consisting of leaves without branches, agreeably with what follows, in the O and K resembling the mafod,]) from the middle whereof there rises a stalk, which, when it grows tall, bends down its top by reason of its succulence, or suppleness; having upon its head a fruit (vamarapN, M, O, [in the TA Eqdp,]) with which birds of prey are killed, (M, O,) being poisoned therewith by its being put into flesh and thrown where they alight: he who prepares it stops up his nose; if he do not, it injures him; and people fear to pasture their cattle near to the places of its growth lest the animals should come in contact with it and should break it or bruise it and it should exhale its odour upon them and kill them: thus says AHn, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, of the Saráh (Als~araAp). (O.) ― -b3- And Anything unclean, dirty, or filthy; as also ↓ qa$abN: (M, TA:) or anything that is deemed unclean, dirty, or filthy. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Rust (K, TA) upon iron: (TA:) or dirt upon a sword. (A, TA.) ― -b5- The refuse, that is thrown away, as being of no good, of TaEaAm [i. e. wheat, or other food]. (M, TA.) ― -b6- See also [the pl.] A^aqo$aAbN, voce qaA$ibN. ― -b7- Also, i. e. qi$obN A man in whom is no good; (K, TA;) and (TA) so qi$obN xi$obN; (S, M, O, TA;) or this means with whom is no good: the latter word is an imitative sequent.
