(TA in art. x$b.) [See also qi$obapN.] ― -b8- And Dry, or tough, and hard. (M, TA. [Like qasobN.]) -A2- And Alqi$obu signifies The nafos [here meaning jasad, i. e. body, as is shown below, voce qaA$ibN]. (O, K.)
qa$abN * : see qi$obN, in two places.
qa$ibN * : see qa$iybN.

qi$obapN *
A low, vile, ignoble, or mean, man, (IDrd, M, O, K, TA,) possessing no good: (TA:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, M, O, TA.) [See also qi$obN, last quarter.] ― -b2- And The young one of the ape, or of the monkey: (M, O, K:) so, IDrd says, some assert; (O;) but he doubted its correctness; (M, O, TA;) and the right word is qi$~apN. (M, TA.)

qa$iybN * Food mixed with poison: (M, TA:) and anything poisoned; as also ↓ muqa$~abN. (Nh, TA.) [Hence,] nasorN qa$iybN A vulture for which poison is mixed in flesh-meat, which he eats, and which kills him; and then his feathers are taken: (S, O:) a vulture killed by means of galovaY [q. v.]. (M, TA.) -A2- And White, (O, K,) and clean. (K.) ― -b2- And, (S, M, O, K,) as also ↓ qa$ibN, (M,) New: (S, M, O, K:) ― -b3- and Old, and worn-out: (M, O, K:) thus having two contr. meanings: (O, K:) the former used alike as masc. and fem.; applied to a garment; and its pl. is qu$ubN [and by contraction qu$obN, mentioned by Golius on the authority of Meyd]. (M.) ― -b4- And the former, applied to a sword, (S, O, K,) Polished: (K:) or recently polished: (S, O:] ― -b5- and, (O, K,) so applied, (A, O, K,) Rusty: (O, K:) or dirty: (A:) thus, again, having two contr. meanings. (O, K)

qu$obaAniy~ataAni * (occurring in a trad., O) Two old and worn-out [garments of the kind called] burdehs (burodataAni): (O, K, TA:) or, as some say, new: (Nh, TA:) the assertion that qu$obaAnN is a pl. of qa$iybN, and that qu$obaAniy~apN is a rel. n. from this pl., is one upon which no reliance is to be placed, (O, K,) for a rel. n. is not formed from a pl. [unless from a pl. of the class of A^anoSaArN]: it is an innovated form of rel. n. (O.)

qaA$ibN * [act. part. n. of qa$aba; Mixing: &c.]. ― -b2- One who imputes to others, or charges them with, vices, or faults, that are in himself. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And A tailor (O, K) who ejects his ↓ A^aqo$aAb, i. e. the knots of the threads, [meaning who spits them out,] when he ejects them. (O.) -A2- And [A man] weak in respect of the body (DaEiyfu Aln~afosi); (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) one whose qi$ob [meaning body] is weak, or emaciated; (O, TA;) by his fi$ob being meant his nafos [as syn. with jasad]. (O.)

muqa$~abN * Poison with which medicaments [or drugs] are mixed to render it potent. (Ham p. 331.) See also qa$iybN, first sentence. ― -b2- And, (M, K,) or muqa$~abu AlHasabi, (S,) (tropical:) A man whose grounds of pretension to respect are mixed (S, M, K, * TA) with ignobleness. (M, TA.)

1 qa$adahu *
i. q. ka$aTahu. (K.)

8 Aqt$d *
He collected clarified butter. (L.)

qi$odapN * The dregs, or sediment, remaining at the bottom of fresh butter when it is cooked with meal of parched barley or wheat (sawiyq) to be made into clarified butter: (S, M, L:) or the dregs, or sediment, remaining at the bottom of fresh butter when it is cooked with meal of parched barley or wheat (swyq) and with dates; as also ↓ qu$aAdapN: (K:) or the dregs, or sediment, of clarified butter: (Ks, L:) or (in the K, and) thin fresh butter: (L, K:) it is also called qilodapN, and kudaAdapN, (Ks, L,) and A_ivorN, and A^ulaAqapN, and xulaASapN; and remains at the bottom of the cooking-pot, after the butter has been clarified, mixed with hairs and pieces of wood &c. (AHeyth, L.) ― -b2- Also, A certain herb, abounding with milk (L, K) and grease. (L.)
qu$aAdapN * : see qi$odapN.

1 qa$arahu * , aor.
qa$ira and
qa$ura , inf. n. qa$orN; and ↓ q$~rhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqo$iyrN; (S;) He divested or stripped it of, or stripped off or removed from it, namely a branch, (S, Msb,) or other thing, (S,) its qi$or [i. e. peel, rind, bark, coat, covering, husk, shale or shell, crust, scab, skin, or outer integument, or superficial part; he, or it, pared, peeled, rinded, barked, decorticated, husked, shelled, scaled, flayed, skinned, or excoriated, it; he, or it, stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed, its outer covering or integument, or superficial part]; (S, Msb;) but the ↓ latter verb has an intensive signification; (Msb;) [or denotes frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects, as well as muchness;] he pared off, or removed, its peel, rind, bark, or the like, (liHaA='ahu,) or its skin: (M, K:) [and he pared, peeled, stripped, scraped, or rubbed, it off; namely, anything superficial, and generally a thing adhering to the surface of another thing, as, for instance, peel and the like, and a scab, and skin, and mud. One says of a fruit, or the like, yuqo$aru Eano Hab~apK, Its covering, being removed, shells off from a grain or the like.] ― -b2- qa$arahu biAls~awoTi [He excoriated him with the whip]. (TA, art. Hmr.) ― -b3- qa$arahu biAll~isaAni (assumed tropical:) [He galled him, as though he flayed him, with the tongue; i. e., with reproof, &c.] (TA, ibid.) -A2- qa$ira, aor.
qa$ara , It (a date) had a thick skin. (TA.) -A3- qa$ira, (TA,) [aor.
qa$ara ,] inf. n. qa$arN, (S, TA,) He had his nose excoriated by intense heat: or (tropical:) he was intensely red, as though he were flayed, (M,) or as though his scarf-skin were peeled off. (TA.)
2 qa$~ara see 1.
5 taqa$~ara see 7.

7 Anq$r * and ↓ tq$~r quasi-passives of qa$arahu and qa$~arahu, respectively; [It became divested, or stripped, of its peel, rind, bark, coat, covering, husk, shale or shell, crust, scab, skin, or superficial part; it became pared, peeled, rinded, barked, decorticated, husked, shelled, scaled, flayed, skinned, or excoriated; its superficial part became stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed: and it peeled off; it scaled off, or exfoliated:] (S, M, K:) both signify the same: (S:) [or the latter, as quasipass. of q$~rh, has an intensive signification; or denotes frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many subjects, as well as muchness: and the same also signifies it became divested, or stripped, of its peel, &c. part after part: and it peeled off, or scaled off, part after part.]
qu$orN * . ― -b2- Alqu$oraAni [dual], with damm, (K,) or ↓ Alqi$oraAni, (so written in a copy of the M,) The two wings, (K,) or the two thin wings, (M,) of the locust. (M, K.)

qi$orN * The covering of a thing, whether natural or accidental; (M, K;) i. e., of anything; (M;) [the exterior part, peel, rind, bark, coat, crust, integument, skin, or covering, of a branch, plant, fruit, or the like; a coat such as one of those of an onion or other bulbous root, as is shown in the K, voce muS~aAxN; a case, husk, shale, shard, or shell, such as covers a seed or seeds or an egg; a crust, a scab, a substance consisting of scales or laminæ and any similar thing, that peels off from the skin &c.; the skin of fruits &c.;] of a branch [and the like], the part which is like the skin of a human being; and hence the qi$or of a melon and the like: (Msb:) pl. qu$uwrN. (S, M, Msb, K.) ↓ qi$orapN is a more particular term [signifying A piece, or particle, of peel, rind, bark, &c.]: (S:) and likewise signifies the skin of a haborap [or piece of flesh-meat] which remains when its liquor has been sucked; as also ↓ qu$orapN. (M.) ↓ qu$aArN also signifies the same as qi$orN: and likewise the skin [or slough] of a serpent. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qitorN also signifies (tropical:) The dress, or apparel, of a man; (S;) any dress, or apparel: (M, K:) and a garment; (TA;) as also ↓ qi$orapN: (M, TA:) and the pl. is qu$uwrN. (M, K.) You say, Ealayohi qi$orN HasanN (tropical:) [Upon him is goodly apparel]. And xaraja bayona qi$oratayoni naZiyfatayoni (tropical:) He went forth in two clean garments. (TA.) And in a trad. of Keyleh it is said, kunotu A_i*aA raA^ayotu rajulFA *aA ruwaA='K wa*aA qi$orK TamaHa baSariY A_ilayohi (tropical:) [I used, when I saw a man of goodly aspect, and of apparel, to raise my eyes towards him]. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] ↓ qu$aArN signifies (assumed tropical:) The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people. (IAar, in TA, arts. b$r and x$r.) See also qu$aArahN. ― -b4- And see qu$orN.

tamorN qa$irN *
Dates, or dried dates, having much qi$or [or skin]; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ qa$iyrN. (TA.) See qa$ira.
qu$orapN * : see qi$orN: ― -b2- and see qaA$irapN.
qi$orapN * : see qi$orN, in two places.
qu$arapN * : see qaA$irapN.
qu$aArN * : see qi$orN, in two places.

qa$uwrN *
A medicine with which the face is peeled, in order that it may become clear (M, K) in complexion. (M.) See qaA$irapN.
qa$iyrN * : see qa$irN.

qu$aArapN *
Peel, rind, bark, or the like, (liHaA=',) or skin, pared off, or removed, from a thing; (M, K;) [parings, or bits, or particles, of a thing, that fall off, or are pared off.]

qaA$irapN * [A $aj~ap (or wound upon the head) which merely peels off the external skin; also termed HaAriSapN; (see $aj~apN;)] the first $aj~ap, (S, K,) because it peels off the skin, (S,) or which peels off the skin. (K.) ― -b2- A woman who peels her face, (K,) i. e., the external skin of her face, with medicine [called qa$uwrN], in order that her complexion may become clear; (K, TA;) and who rubs her face, or the face of another, with [the kind of liniment called] gumorap; (TA;) as also ↓ maqo$uwrapN: (K:) which latter [also] signifies a woman to whom this is done. (TA.) The qaA$irap and the maqo$uwrapN are cursed in a trad. (M, K.) ― -b3- maTorapN qaA$irapN, (S,) and ↓ qu$orapN, and ↓ qu$arapN, (M, K, TA,) A rain that pares, or strips, the surface of the earth, (S, M, K, TA, [in the K, maTarN yaqo$iru is put in the place of maTorapN taqo$iru, in the M]) and removes the pebbles from the ground, being a rain that falls with vehemence. (TA.) ― -b4- sanapN qaA$irapN, (TA,) and ↓ qaA$uwrapN, (S, M, K,) and ↓ qaA$uwrN, (M, K,) (tropical:) A year that strips, or strips off, everything: (M, K:) or that strips, or strips off, men; and camels or the like: (M:) a year of sterility, drought, or dearth. (S.) See also A^aqo$aru.
qaA$uwrN * and qaA$uwrapN: see qaA$irapN.

A^aqo$aru * A thing having its peel, rind, bark, or the like, pared off. (M, K.) ― -b2- One whose nose is excoriated by intense heat: (M, K: *) or (so accord. to the M; but in the K, and) (tropical:) one intensely red, (S, M, K,) as though he were flayed, (M,) or as though his scarf-skin were peeled off. (TA.) ― -b3- Ground partly bare of herbage and partly producing herbage: and ground bare of herbage. (TA.) ― -b4- $ajarapN qa$oraA='u A tree peeled, or barked: (M:) or as though part of it were peeled, or barked, (M, K,) and part not. (M.) ― -b5- Hay~apN qa$orA='u A serpent casting off its slough, or having its slough cast off; syn. saAlixN: (M, K:) or as though having part of its slough cast off, and part not. (TA.) ― -b6- EaAmN A^aqo$aru A severe year. (TA.) See also qaA$irapN.

muqa$~arN * A thing having its peel, rind, bark, or the like, pared off, or removed; peeled, rinded, barked, &c. (TA.) See 1. ― -b2- fusotuqN muqav~arN Shelled pistachio-nuts; (S, TA;) and so muqas~arN alone, by predominant usage. (Z, TA.)
maqo$uwrapN * : see qaA$irapN.
muqota$irN * (tropical:) Naked. (K, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) An aged man: because he finds his garments heavy to him, and throws them from him. (TA.)

1 qa$aTa * , (M, Msb, TA,) aor,
qa$iTa , (Msb,) inf. n. qa$oTN, (M, Msb, K,) i. q. ka$aTa, (M, K, *) said (M, Msb,) by Yaakoob, (M,) to be a dial. var. of the latter; (M, Msb;) of the dial. of Temeem and Asad; the latter being of the dial. of Keys; the q not being a substitute for the k; (M;) He removed, put off, took off, or stripped off, (M, Msb, * K,) a thing; (M, Msb;) as, for instance, the housing, or covering, from (Eano) a horse; (M;) and a roof [from a chamber or the like]. (TA.) And qi$aATN, [inf. n. of the pass. form qu$iTa, It was, or became, removed, &c.,] is syn. with, (K,) being a dial. var. of, (M,) ki$aATN, (M, K,) in the sense of A_inoki$aAfN. (TA.) It is said in the Kur, [lxxxi. 11,] accord. to the reading of 'AbdAllah Ibn-Mes'ood, waA_i*aA Als~amaA='u qu$iTato, with q, (M,) meaning the same as ku$iTato, i. e. And when the heaven shall be removed from its place, like as a roof is removed from its place. (Zj.) You say also, qa$aTa Ald~aAb~apa [He removed the housing, or covering, from the beast of carriage]; the verb thus used, also, being a dial. var. of ka$aTa; and ↓ q$~ThA, inf. n. taqo$iTN, signifies the same. (TA.) And Alr~ajulu ↓ qu$~iTa The man was spoiled, despoiled, or plundered. (TA.) ― -b2- qa$oTN also signifies The act of beating, [app. so as to excoriate,] with a staff, or stick. (Yaakoob, K.)
2 qa$~aTa see 1, in two places.
5 taqa$~aTa see 7.
7 Anq$Tt Als~amaA='u * , and ↓ tq$~Tt, (tropical:) The sky became clear; became free from clouds or mists. (K, * TA.)
qu$oTN * a dial. var. of qusoTN, q. v. (TA.)
qi$oTapN * a dial. var. of qanodapN [app. meaning Sugarcandy]. (TA.) ― -b2- [In the present day, applied to Cream.]

qa$~aATN *
A great spoiler, despoiler, or plunderer; one who spoils, despoils, or plunders, much, or frequently; syn. sal~aAbN. (TA.)
muqa$~aTN * : see maqo$uwTN, in two places.

daAb~apN maqo$uwTN EanohaA * [for maqo$uwT EanohaA Aljul~u] and ↓ muqa$~aTN [A beast of carriage having its housing, or covering, removed from it]. (TA.) You say also, ↓ rajulN muqa$~aTN, meaning A man spoiled, despoiled, or plundered. (TA.)

Q. 4 A_iqo$aEar~a * , said of the skin, (S, K,) It quaked; shuddered; was, or became, affected by a tremor, quaking, or quivering. (K.) [And in like manner said of a man, (see the part. n., below,) i. e. He quaked, or shuddered.] ― -b2- It (the skin) dried up (qaf~a) by reason of mange, or scab. (TA.) ― -b3- A_iqo$aEar~ati AlA^aroDu The earth became of a colour inclining to that of dust, or ashes, (A_irobad~at,) and contracted, by reason of drought. (TA.) ― -b4- Aq$Er~t Als~anapu (tropical:) The year became one of drought. (K, * TA:)
A^axa*atohu qu$aEoriyrapN * (S, K) A tremor, quaking, or quivering, of the skin seized him. (K.)
muqo$aEir~N * , applied to a man, [Having a quaking or shuddering of the skin,] has for its pl. qa$aAEiru, without the m because it is augmentative. (S.)
See Supplement

1 qaS~ahu * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
qaSu3a , inf. n. qaS~N, (M, Msb,) He cut it; (S, Msb;) or he clipped it, or shore it, or cut off from it; (A, K;) namely, hair, (S, M, A, K,) and wool, (M,) and plumage, (A,) and a nail of a finger or toe; (M, K;) with the miqaS~, q. v.: (A, K:) as also ↓ qS~Shu, (M, A,) and, by permutation, qaS~aAhu: (M:) or these two forms have an intensive signification: or you say, AlZ~ufora wanaHowahu ↓ qaS~ayotu, meaning, I pared the nail and the like. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, He (a weaver) cut off from it, namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, its unwoven end, or extremity, consisting of warp without woof. (M.) ― -b3- And He cut off the extremities of his ears. (IAar, M.) quS~iyhi occurs in a trad., as meaning, Take thou from the extremities of his ears. (TA.) [But this may be from the root qSw, q. v.] ― -b4- And [hence,] qaS~a A@ll~`hu xaTaAyaAhu (assumed tropical:) God diminished, or took or deducted from, [the account of] his sins. (TA, from a trad.) -A2- qaS~a A^avarahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
qaSu3a , (M, TA,) inf. n. qaSaSN, (S, M, A, O, L, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K qaSiySN, but the former is the right, (TA,) and qaS~N, (T, M, K,) He followed, or followed after, his track, or footsteps, in pursuit; endeavoured to trace him, or track him; (S, M, A, Msb, K, &c.;) or he did so by degrees: (TA:) or by night: or at any time: (M, TA:) which last is the correct explanation: (TA:) and qaS~ahu signifies the same, (A, TA,) and so Avrh ↓ AqtS~, (S, K,) and Avrh ↓ tqS~S: (S, M, K:) and qas~a is a dial. form of the same. (TA.) You say, xaraja fulaAnN qaSaSFA fiY A^avari fulaAnK Such a one went forth following, or following after, the footsteps of such a one, in pursuit. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xviii. 63,] (S,) faA@rotad~aA EalaY A=vaArihimaA qaSaSFA (S, K) And they both returned by the way by which they had come, retracing their footsteps. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] qaS~a Ealayohi Alxabara, (S, M, Msb, * K, *) and AlHadiyva, and Alr~uw^oyaA, (A,) aor.
qaSu3a , (M, TA,) inf. n. qaSaSN, (M, TA,) or this is a subst. put in the place of the inf. n. so that it has become predominant over it, (S,) and qaS~N, (M, TA,) or the latter only is the inf. n., and the former is [only] a subst., (Msb,) He related to him the piece of news, or information, (S, M, Msb,) and the tradition, or story, and the dream, (A,) in its proper manner (EalaY wajohihi): (S, Msb:) or he made it known [to him]: (K:) and AlHadiyva ↓ AqtS~ he related the tradition, or story, in its proper manner (EalaY wajohihi); (S, K, TA;) as though he followed its traces, in pursuit, and related it accordingly: (TA:) [i. e., he pursued the course of the tradition, or story:] and Alxabara ↓ tqS~S he pursued, or sought after, the particulars of the news, or information, gradually, and deliberately. (M.) qaS~a is also said to signify He recited, or delivered, a [discourse such as is termed] xuTobap. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xii. 3,] naHonu naquS~u Ealayoka A^aHosana AlqaSaSi We explain unto thee with the best explanation: (K, TA:) or, as some say, qaS~N is the inf. n. of the verb used in this sense, and qaSaSN is a subst. [syn. with qiS~apN, q. v.]. (TA.) And in a trad. respecting the Children of Israel it is said, lam~aA qaS~uwA halakuwA: or lam~aA halakuwA qaS~uwA: accord. to different relations: meaning, When they relied upon words, and neglected works, they perished: or when they perished, by neglecting works, they inclined to, and relied upon, stories. (TA.) -A3- qaS~ahu Almawotu, and qaS~ahu EalaY Almawoti, or mina Almawoti: see 4.

2 qS~Shu * and qaS~aAhu : see I, first signification. -A2- qS~S, (S,) inf. n. taqoSiySN, (A, K,) He plastered, or built, (TA,) a house, (S, K, TA,) and a tomb, which it is forbidden to do, (A, TA,) with gypsum; (TA;) syn. jaS~aSa: (S, K:) of the dial. of El-Hijáz. (TA, art. jS.)

3 qAS~hu * , (Msb,) inf. n. muqaAS~apN (A, Mgh, Msb) and qiSaASN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) [which latter is the more common,] He (the relation of a slain man, A, Mgh, TA, or one who has been wounded, Mgh, [or mutilated,]) retaliated upon him by slaying him, or wounding him, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) or mutilating him, (S, * Msb, K, *) so as to make him quit, or even, with him. (Mgh.) See also 8. ― -b2- Hence, (A, Mgh,) (tropical:) He made him quit, or even, with himself: used in a general way. (Mgh.) You say, qAS~ SaAHibahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, * K,) inf. ns. as above, (Msb,) (tropical:) He made his fellow quit, or even, with him, (Mgh,) in a reckoning, (S, Mgh, K,) or other thing, (S, K,) by withholding from him the like of what the latter owed to him; (Mgh;) he made a debt which his fellow owed him to be as a requital of a like debt which he owed his fellow: [but Fei adds,] this is taken from A_iqotiSaASu AlA^avari: and hence the former signification, relating to retaliation of slaughter and
wounding and mutilation, which, however, is the predominant signification. (Msb.) You say also, qaASaSotuhu bimaA kaAna liY qabolahu, [or, more probably, qibalahu, or perhaps Ealayohi,] (tropical:) I withheld from him the like of what he owed me. (A, TA.) ISd says, (TA,) The phrase quwS~a zayodN maA Ealayohi has been mentioned; and means, in my opinion, (assumed tropical:) Zeyd was reckoned with for what he owed: though made trans. without a particle, as implying the meaning of A^ugorima and the like. (M, TA.)

4 AqS~hu * , inf. n. A_iqoSaASN, He retaliated for him; (M;) as also ↓ AqtS~hu; (A; [so in a copy of that work; but I think it is a mistake for AqS~hu, or for AqtS~ lahu, q. v.]) or AqtS~ minohu. (TA [but this seems to be a mistake for AqtS~ lahu.]) You say, AqS~ fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK He (a governor, or prince,) retaliated for such a one upon such a one, (S, K,) by wounding the latter like as he had wounded the former, (S, Msb, K,) or by slaying the latter for the slaughter of the former; (S, K;) and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- AqS~ Alr~ajulu minu nafosihi The man gave power, or authority, to retaliate upon himself, (K, TA,) by doing to him the like of that which he had done, whether it be slaughter or mutilation or beating or wounding. (TA.) [Whence the saying,] A^aqoSaSotuka AljuroHapa (tropical:) I authorize thee to adduce anything whereby to invalidate the testimony. (A, * TA, art. jrH.) -A2- Darabahu Hat~aY A^aqaS~ahu mina Almawoti, (S, K,) and EalaY Almawoti ↓ qaS~ahu, (K,) He beat him until he made him to be near to death: (S, K:) and Fr used to say, Drbh Ht~Y A^aqaS~ahu Almawota [meaning as above]. (S.) You say [also], A^aqoSaSotuhu EalaY Almawoti [I made him to be near to death]. (M.) And a poet says,
faqado A^aqoSaSota A^um~aka biAlohuzaAli
meaning, Thou hast made thy mother to be near to death. (TA.) ― -b2- Fr also said, (S,) Almawotu ↓ qaS~ahu and A^aqaS~ahu Almawotu [in the L and TA qaS~ahu mina Almawoti and A^aqaS~ahu minohu, which seems to be a mistranscription,] both signifying Death became near to him: (S, K:) or he became at the point of death, and then escaped; (TA;) and so A^aqaS~atohu $aEuwbu: (M:) and A^aqaS~a ElY Almawoti he became at the point of death. (M.)

5 tqS~S * and taqaS~aY : see 8. -A2- tqS~S A^avarahu: see qaS~a Avrh. ― -b2- tqS~S Alxabara: see qaS~a Ealayohi Alxabara. ― -b3- tqS~S kalaAmahu He preserved in his memory his speech, or discourse. (AZ, M, K.)

6 tqAS~wA *
They made themselves quits, or even, one with another, by retaliation, (M, TA,) slaying for slaying, or wounding for wounding. (M.) A poet says,
farumonaA AlqiSaASa wakaAna Alt~aqaAS
Su HukomFA waEadolFA EalaY AlomusolimiynaA
[And we sought retaliation so as to make a party quit, or even, with us; for people's making themselves quits, or even, one with another, by retaliation, is a statute, and an act of justice, appointed to the Muslims]: in which Alt~aqaAS~u is an instance of a deviation from a general rule, as it presents two quiescent letters together in poetry; wherefore some relate it differently, saying, AlqiSaASu: and there is no other instance of the kind excepting one verse cited by Akh:
walawolaA xidaA$N A^axadotu dawaAb
ba saEodK walamo A^aEoTihi maA EalayohaA
but Aboo-Is-hák thinks, that, if this verse be genuine, the right reading is dawaAbiba saEodK, as the making the duplication of a letter distinct is allowable in poetry; or rawaAHila saEodK. (M, TA.) This is the primary signification of the verb. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (A, * Mgh, * TA,) [or, accord. to Fei, the reverse is the case, (see 3,)] (tropical:) They made themselves quits, or even, one with another, in a reckoning, (S, A, Mgh, K,) or other thing (S, A, K) one withholding from another the like of what the latter owed him. (Mgh.)

8 AqtS~ *
It (hair [or the like]) was, or became, cut, or clipped, or shorn, (M, TA,) with the miqaS~; (TA;) as also ↓ tqS~S and taqaS~aY. (M, TA.) -A2- AqtS~ A^avarahu: see qaS~a Avrh. ― -b2- AqtS~ AlHadiyva: see qaS~a Ealayohi Alxabara. -A3- He retaliated, slaying for slaying, or wounding for wounding. (M.) You say, AqtS~ lifulaAnK mino fulaAnK (S, A, K) He retaliated for such a one upon such a one, by wounding the latter like as he had wounded the former, or by slaying the latter for the slaughter of the former, (S, K, TA,) and the like; (TA;) as also minohu ↓ A^aqaS~ahu. (S, K.) [See the latter verb, first signification.] And ↓ A^afaS~ahu, inf. n. A_iqoSaASN, signifies [also] He (the Sultán) slew him in retaliation. (Msb.) ― -b2- AiqotiSaASN, as a subst., [i. e., having no verb corresponding to the signification here following, though I do not see how this can be asserted, for one may certainly say AuqotuS~a minohu,] also signifies The being done to like as one has done, whether it be slaughter or mutilation or beating or wounding. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 10.

10 AstqS~ *
He sought, or demanded, retaliation, i. e., slaying for slaying, or wounding for wounding. (M.) ― -b2- AstqS~hu He asked of him to retaliate for him: (S, A, Msb, K:) and ↓ AqtS~hu signifies the same accord. to the K; but the author has been misled into saying this by misunderstanding the following passage in the O; tqS~S Avrh mvl qaS~ahu wAqtS~hu wAstqS~hu saA^alahu A^ano yuqiS~ahu, in which wAqtS~h terminates a clause. (TA.)

qaS~N * (M, K) and ↓ qaSaSN (M, TA) What is cut, or clipped, or shorn, of the wool of a sheep. (M, K, TA.) See also quSaASapN. -A2- Also, both words, (S, M, A, K,) and ↓ qaSoqaSN (M, TA) The breast (M, A, K) of anything: (M:) or the head thereof, (S, K,) called in Persian sr synh [i. e. sarosiynaho, applied to the pit at the head of the breast]; and such is the qaSaS of the sheep or goat, &c.: (S:) or the middle thereof: (M, K:) or the bone thereof, (M, K,) of a man or other animal; (TA;) [i. e. the sternum;] the soft bone into which are set the cartilaginous ends of the [seven upper pairs of the] ribs, in the middle of the breast: (Lth, TA:) pl. qiSaASN [a reg. pl. of the first]. (K.) Hence the saying, huwa A^alozamu laka mino $uEayoraAti qaS~ika, (S,) or huwa A^alozamu bika mino $aEaraAti qaS~ika, and ↓ qaSaSika, (M, TA,) [He is more closely adherent to thee than the little hairs, or the hairs, of thy breast, &c.:] because as often as they are cut they grow [afresh]: (As, TA:) meaning, he will not separate himself from thee, nor canst thou cast him from thee: applied to him who denies his relation: and also to him who denies a due that is incumbent on him. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b2- Also, the same three words, (the first and ↓ second accord. to the TA, and the ↓ third accord. to the K) and ↓ qaSiySN, (K,) The place of growth of the hair of the breast. (K, TA.) -A3- qaS~N, (JK, and so in one place in a copy of the M, and in the TA,) or ↓ qiS~N, (so in one place in a copy of the M) and ↓ qaS~apN and ↓ qiS~apN, (M,) i. q. jaS~N, (JK,) or jiS~N, (M,) [i. e. Gypsum;] qaS~apN is syn. with jS~ (S, Msb) in the dial. of El-Hijáz: (S:) or ↓ qaS~apN and ↓ qiS~apN, (K,) the latter on the authority of IDrd, (TA,) and said by Aboo-Bekr to be with kesr, but by others said to be with fet-h, (Seer, TA,) are syn. with jaS~apN [and jiS~apN, ns. un. of jaS~N and jiS~N]: (K:) or signify stones of jS~ [or gypsum]: (TA:) pl. qiSaASN [reg. as pl. of qaS~apN]: (K:) and ↓ qaS~aASN is a dial. form of qaS~N [app. as syn. with jaS~N and jiS~N], a subst., like jay~aArN [which is nearly, if not exactly, syn. with jiyrN and jiaS~N]. (M, L.) In a trad. of Zeyneb, occurs this expression: EalaY maloHuwdapK ↓ yaAqaS~apF [O gypsum upon buried corpses!] by which she likens the bodies of the persons addressed to tombs made of jS~, and their souls to the corpses contained in the tombs. (TA.)
qiS~N * : see qaS~N, last signification; the latter in three places.
qaS~apN * : see qaS~N, last signification; the latter in three places.

quS~apN * The hair over the forehead; syn. naASiyapN, (M, A,) or $aEaru Aln~aASiyapi; (S, K;) accord. to some, (TA,) of a horse: (M, TA:) or what comes forward, thereof, over the face: (M, TA:) and the nASyp of a woman: (M:) or the Tur~ap, i. e., the nASyp, [or front hair of the head,] which is cut over (lit. over against, Hi*aA='a,) the forehead: (Mgh, Msb:) or what a woman makes, in the fore part of her head, by cutting the hair of that part, excepting over her temples: (TA:) or it signifies, as some say, (Mgh,) or signifies also, (M, A,) any lock of hair: (M, A, Mgh:) pl. quSaSN (M, Msb, K) and qiSaASN. (M, K) See also quSaASN.

qiS~apN *
A story; a narrative: (S, M, TA:) and what is written: (S, K:) and an affair; or a case: (S, Msb, K:) and ↓ qaSaSN is syn. therewith, in the first of the above senses; (S, * M, A, * Msb, * TA;) and signifies a story, or narrative, related: (M, TA:) and ↓ qaSiySapN also is syn. with qiS~apN [in the first of the above senses], (A, K,) and so is ↓ qaSiySN: (A:) the pl. of qiS~apN is qiSaSN, (S, Msb, K,) and A^aqaA SiySu is a pl. pl.: (A, * TA:) and the pl. of ↓ qaSiySapN is qaSaAy^iSu. (A, * TA.) You say, lahu qiS~apN EajiybapN and qaSaSN &c. [He has, or to him, or it, relates, a wonderful story]. (A.) And fiY raA^osihi qiS~apN (tropical:) In his head is a speech; or the like. (TA.) And maA qiS~atuka What is thine affair? or thy case? (Msb.) And rafaEa qiS~apF A_ilaY Als~uloTaAni [He referred an affair, or a case, to the Sultán]. (A.) -A2- See also qaS~N, last signification.
qaSaSN * : see qaS~N, first signification. -A2- See also qiS~apN. -A3- See also qS~N, again, second and third significations.
qaSaASN * : see quSaAS.

quSaASu Al$~aEari * and ↓ qiSaASuhu and ↓ qaSaASuhu, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) of which three forms the first is the most common, (S,) The part where the growth of the hair terminates, (As, S, M, A, * Mgh, K,) in the fore part and the hind part (As, S, M) of the head; (M;) or in the fore part or the hind part; (K;) or in the fore part of the head and around it; (A;) or in the fore part of the head or around it; (Mgh;) or in the middle of the head: (TA:) or the extremity of the back of the neck: (M, TA:) or the whole circuit [of the hair], behind and before and around; and one says also Al$~aEari ↓ quSaASapu: (TA:) and Al$~aEari ↓ maqaS~u, of which the pl. is maqaAS~u, signifies the same as quSaASuhu; (As, TA;) or the part where it is taken with the scissors: (TA:) AlquSaASu also signifies the place along which the scissors run in the middle of the head: (M, K:) or the extremity of the back of the neck: (K:) or the part where the growth of the hair terminates (K, TA) in the fore part of the head; or in the fore part and the hind part thereof; as before explained. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, EaD~a biquSaASi kaf~ayhohi, meaning, (tropical:) He bit the extremities of his two hands, where they meet together. (A, TA.)

qiSaASN * : see quSaAS. -A2- Also, (S, M, Msb, K,) and ↓ qaSaASaA='u, (so in a copy of the M, and in the CK, and in a MS copy of the K [in the TA ↓ quSaASaA='u, which I think a mistake,]) and ↓ qiSaASaA='u, (M, K,) [the first an inf. n. of 3, q. v.,] i. q. qawadN; (S, K;) Retaliation, by slaying for slaying, and wounding for wounding, (M, Msb, TA,) and mutilating for mutilating. (Msb.)
qaSiySN * : see maqoSuwSN: -A2- and qiS~apN: -A3- and qaS~N, third signification.

quSaASapN *
Cuttings, or what is cut off (M, A) with the miqaS~, (A,) of hair, (Lh, M, A,) and of the unwoven end, or extremity, of a garment, or piece of cloth. (M.) ― -b2- See also quSaAS.

qaSiySapN *
A camel, (M, K,) or horse, or the like, (M,) with which one follows, or follows after, (M, K,) footsteps, (M,) or the footsteps of travellingcamels: (K:) pl. qaSaAy^iSu. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) -A2- See also qiS~apN, in two places.
qaSaASaA='u * , or quSaASaA='u, and qiSaASaA='u: see qiSaASN.
qaS~aASN * : see qaS~N, last signification.
qaSoqaSN * : see qaS~N, second and third significations.

qaAS~N *
A relater of a story or narrative (K, TA) in its proper course; as though he followed its meanings and expressions; or of stories, or narratives; as some say, because he pursues story after story: (TA:) pl. quS~aASN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And One who recites, or delivers, the kind of discourse termed xuTobap. (TA.)
A^aqaASiySu * : see qiS~apu.
maqaS~u Al$~aEari * : see quSaAS.

miqaS~N *
A miqoraAD [or single blade of scissors or shears], (S, A, K,) with which one cuts, or clips, or shears; (TA;) one of the things whereof a pair is called miqaS~aAni: (S, K:) or miqaS~aAni signifies the thing with which one cuts hair [&c.]; and has no sing., accord. to the lexicologists, though Sb assigns to it a sing.: (M:) some say, that the use of the sing. is a mistake of the vulgar: (MF:) the pl. is maqaAS~u. (A, TA.)
muqaS~aSN * : see maqoSuwSN, in two places. -A2- A tomb plastered with qaS~ [or gypsum]: and in like manner muqaS~aSapN applied to a city (madiynap). (M, TA.)

maqoSuwSN *
Cut, clipped, or shorn; applied to hair [&c.]; as also ↓ qaSiySN: (M, TA:) and to a wing; as also ↓ muqaS~aSN. (A.) maqoSuwSu AlxanaAHi A bird having the wing clipped. (S.) And ↓ muqaS~aSN Having the forelocks clipped, or shorn. (Meyd, in Golius.)

1 qaSabahu * , aor.
qaSiba , (M, K,) inf. n. qaSobN, (S, M, O,) He cut it, (S, * M, O, * K,) namely, a thing; (M;) as also ↓ AqtSbhu. (M, K.) And qaSaba Al$~aApa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (M, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, M, O, Msb,) said of the butcher, (O,) He cut up the sheep, or goat, into joints, or separate limbs: (S, O, Msb:) or he separated the [bones called] qaSab of the sheep, or goat. (M, K.) ― -b2- fulaAnN lamo yuqoSabN meaning (tropical:) Such a one has not been circumcised, is from AlqaSobu signifying “ the act of cutting. ” (A.) ― -b3- And qaSabahu, (S, M, A, O, K,) aor.
qaSiba , inf. n. qaSobF; (M;) and ↓ qS~bhu, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoSibN, (K,) (tropical:) He attributed, or imputed, to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault, or the like; (S, M, A, O, K;) and reviled, or vilified, him; (M, A, K;) meaning he cut him with censure. (A.) -A2- And qaSabahu, (S, M, O, K,) namely, a camel, and [any] other [animal], (S, O,) or a man, (M, K,) and a beast, (M,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He stopped, or cut short, (S, O,) or prevented, (M, K,) his drinking, before he had satisfied his thirst. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- And qaSaba $urobahu He (a camel) abstained from his drinking before he had satisfied his thirst: (ISk, S, O:) or qaSaba [alone], said of a camel, (As, M, K, TA,) aor. as above, inf. n. qaSobN and quSuwbN, (M, K,) he refused to drink: (As, TA:) or he abstained from drinking the water, raising his head from it, (M, K, TA,) before he had satisfied his thirst: (TA:) or, as some say, quSuwbN signifies the satisfying of thirst by coming to the water &c. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And qaSaba AlmaA='a, aor.
qaSiba , inf. n. qaSobN, He (a camel) sucked up, or sucked in, the water. (M, TA.) -A3- It seems to be applied in the S that qaSaba, aor. as above, also signifies He played upon a musical reed, or pipe. (MF.)

2 qaS~aba see the preceding paragraph. -A2- qS~b Alz~aroEu, (S, M, O,) inf. n. taqoSiybN; (S;) and ↓ AqSb; (M;) The zrE [i. e. seed-produce, or wheat or the like,] produced its qaSab [or jointed stalks, or culms:] (M:) this is the case after the taforiyx. (S, O. [See 2 in art. frx.]) [Hence the saying,] A_in~iY A^araY Al$~ar~a qaS~aba (assumed tropical:) [Verily I see evil, or the evil, to have grown, like corn producing its culms]. (TA voce nab~aba.) ― -b2- And qS~b Al$~aEara, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoSiybN, (O, K,) (assumed tropical:) He twisted the locks of the hair [in a spiral form so that they became like hollow canes]: (M, K:) or qaS~abato $aEarahaA (tropical:) she (a woman) twisted the locks of her hair so that they became like qaSab [i. e. hollow canes]: (A:) and (K) (assumed tropical:) he curled the hair; syn. jaE~adahu. (O, K.) ― -b3- And qS~bhu, (ISh, TA,) inf. n. as above, (O, K,) He bound his hands to his neck, (ISh, O, K, TA,) namely, a man's: (ISh, TA:) [and app., in like manner, his fore-legs, namely, a sheep's or a goat's: sea qaS~aAbN, last sentence.]

4 AqSbhu EiroDahu * (assumed tropical:) He empowered him to revile, or vilify, him. (M.) [Agreeably with an explanation of qaSabahu in the A, mentioned above, it may rather be rendered (tropical:) He caused him to cut, with censure, or to wound, his honour, or reputation.] -A2- AqSb said of a pastor, (ISk, S, M, O, K,) [He performed his service ill, so that] his camels disliked, and refused to drink, the water; (ISk, M, K;) or, [so that] his camels abstained from drinking before they had satisfied their thirst. (S, O.) raEaY faA^aqoSaba [He pastured, and performed his service ill, &c.,] is a prov., (S, M, O, K,) applied to a [bad] pastor; because, if he
pasture the camels ill, they will not drink; (S, O, K;) for they drink only when they are satiated with the herbage: (S, O:) or, as Meyd says, it is applied to him who will not act sincerely, or honestly, and with energy, or vigour, in an affair which he has undertaken, so that he mars, or vitiates, it. (TA.) -A3- AqSb said of a place, It produced reeds, or canes. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also 2.
8 A_iqotaSaba see 1, first sentence.

quSobN *
A gut; syn. miEFY: (S, M, Mgh, O, K:) or all the A^amoEaA=' [or guts]: or the guts [AmEA='] that are in the lower part of the belly: TA:) pl. A^aqoSaAbN. (S. M, Mgh, O, K.) One says, huwa yajur~u quSobahu [expl. by what here follows]. (S, O.) The Prophet said, respecting 'Amr Ibn- 'Ámir El-Khurá'ee, who first set at liberty sawaAy^ib [pl. of saAy^ibapN, q. v.], (O,) or respecting 'Amr Ibn-Kamee-ah, who first changed the religion of Ishmael, (TA,) raA^ayotuhu yajur~u quSobahu fiY Aln~uAri [I saw him dragging his guts in the fire of Hell]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- El-Aashà in his saying
wa$aAhidunaA Aljul~a waAlyaAsamiY
nu waAlmusomiEaAtu biA^aqoSaAbihaA
means [The rose being present with us, and the jasmine, and the songstresses] with their chords of gut: or, as some relate it, (and as it is cited in the M,) he said ↓ biquS~aAbihaA, meaning with their musical reeds, or pipes. (S, O.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The middle of the body; metaphorically applied thereto: so in the saying of Imra-el-Keys, (S, O, L,) or, accord. to the people of El-Koofeh and ElBasrah, it is falsely ascribed to him, (O,)
wAlquSobu muDoTamirN waAlmatonu maloHuwbu
[And the middle of the body slender and lean, and the portion next the back-bone, on either side, smooth, and sloping downwards]. (S, O, L.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The back. (O, K. [SM, not having found this in any lexicon but the K, supposed that AlZ~ahoru might be substituted in it for AlxaSoru, which is not therein mentioned as a meaning of AlquSobu.])

qaSabN * [a coll. gen. n., signifying Reeds, or canes; and the like, as the culms of corn, &c.; and sometimes signifying a reed, or cane, and the like, as meaning a species thereof;] any plant having (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) its stem composed of (Mgh, Msb) A^anaAbiyb [or internodial portions] (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and [their] kuEuwb [or connecting knots, or joints]; (Mgh, Msb;) [i. e. any kind, or species, of plant having a jointed stem;] i. q. A^abaA='N [a word comparatively little known]; (S; [in the O AanA', a mistranscription;]) and [it is said that] ↓ qaSobaA='u signifies the same: (S, O: [but see what follows:]) the n. un. of the former is ↓ qaSabapN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ qaSobaApN or ↓ qaSabaApN: (K accord. to different copies; the former accord. to the TA: [but each of these I believe to be a mistake for ↓ qaSuboA='apN, which is said to be a n. un. of qaSobaA='u, and therefore held by some to be syn. with qaSabapN:]) ↓ qaSobaA='u [appears, however, to differ somewhat from qaSab, for it is said that it] signifies an assemblage of qaSab; (M, K;) and its n. un. is ↓ qaSabapN and ↓ qaSobaA='apN [like HalafapN and HalofaA='apN which are both said to be ns. un. of HalofaA='N; and TarafapN and TarofaA='apN, said to be ns. un. of TarofaA='N; the former in each case anomalous]: (M: [see also Ham p. 201:]) or, accord. to Sb, ↓ qaSobaA='u is sing. and pl., (S, M, Mgh, O,) and so TarofaA='u, (S, M, O,) and HalofaA='u; (S, O;) as pl. and as sing. also having the sign of the fem. gender; therefore, when they mean to express the sing. signification, they add the epithet waAHidapN; thus, and thus only, distinguishing the sing. meaning from the pl., and making a difference between a word of this class and a noun that denotes a pl. meaning and has not the sign of the fem. gender such as tamorN and busorN, and such as A^aroTFY and EaloqFY of which the ns. un. are A^aroTaApN and EaloqaApN: (M:) or, as some say, ↓ qaSobaA='u signifies many qaSab growing in a place: (Mgh:) and it signifies also a place in which qaSab grow: (M, K:) [or] ↓ maqoSabapN has this last meaning; (Mgh, Msb;) or signifies, like ↓ A^aroDN qaSibapN, a land having qaSab. (M, K. *) ― -b2- A^aHoraza qaSaba Als~aboqi, (Msb,) or Als~aboqi ↓ qaSabapa, (TA,) [meaning (assumed tropical:) He won, or acquired, the canes, or cane, of victory in racing,] is said of the winner in horseracing: they used to set up, in the horse-course, a cane (qaSabap,) and he who outstripped plucked it up and took it, in order that he might be known to be the one who outstripped, without contention: this was the origin of the phrase: then, in consequence of frequency of usage, it was applied also to the expeditious, quick, and light, or active: (Msb, * TA:) [accord. to the TA, it is a tropical phrase, but perhaps it is so only when used in the latter way:] it is said in a trad. of Sa'eed Ibn-El-Ás, that he measured the horse-course with the cane, making it to be a hundred canes in length, and the cane was stuck upright in the ground at the goal, and he who was first in arriving at it took it, and was entitled to the stake. (O, TA. [See also muqaS~ibN.]) ― -b3- [The ↓ qaSabap here mentioned as A certain measure of length, used in measuring race-courses, was also used in other cases, in measuring land, and differed in different countries and in different times: accord. to some, it was ten cubits; thus nearly agreeing with our “ rod: ” (see jariybN:) accord. to others, six cubits and a third of a cubit: (see fad~aAnN:) the modern Egyptian qaSabap, until it was reduced some years ago, was about twelve English feet and a half; its twentyfourth part, called qaboDapN, being the measure of a man's fist with the thumb erect, or about six inches and a quarter.] ― -b4- AlqaSabu AlfaArisiY~u [The Persian reed] is a kind whereof writing-reeds are made: (Mgh, Msb:) and another kind thereof is hard and thick; and of this kind are made musical reeds, or pipes; and with it houses, or chambers, are roofed. (Msb) One says, qaSabu AlxT~i A^anofa*u mino qaSabi AlxaT~i [meaning Writingreeds are more penetrating, or effective, than the canes of El-Khatt (which are spears); i. e., words wound more than spears]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- qaSabu Als~uk~ari is well-known [as meaning The sugar-cane]: (Msb:) this is of three kinds; white and yellow and black: of the first and second, but not of the third, the juice [of which sugar is made] is expressed; and this expressed juice is called Easalu AlqaSabi. (Mgh.) ― -b6- qaSabu Al*~ariyrapi [is Calamus aromaticus; also called qaSabu AlT~iybi]: a species thereof has the joints near together, and breaks into many fragments, or splinters, and the internodial portions thereof are filled with a substance like spiders' webs: when chewed, it has an acrid taste, and it is aromatic (Mgh, Msb) when brayed, or powdered; (Mgh;) and inclines to yellowness and whiteness. (Mgh, Msb. [See also *ariyrapN, in art. *r.]) ― -b7- qaSabN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Any round and hollow bone [or rather bones]; (S, O;) it is pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which ↓ qaSabapN is the sing. [or n. un,], this latter signifying any bone containing marrow; (M, K;) thus called by way of comparison [to the reed, or cane]. (M.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) The bones of the yadaAni and rijolaAni [i. e. arms and legs, or hands and feet, but here app. meaning the latter], (A, Msb,) and the like: (Msb:) [or] (assumed tropical:) the [phalanges, or] bones of the fingers and toes; (M, K, * TA;) (tropical:) the bones whereof there are three in each finger and two in the thumb [and the like in the feet]; (A, TA;) and Zj says, the bones of the A^aSaAbiE [or fingers and toes] which are also called sulaAmaY: (Msb in art. slm:) or, as some say, the portions between every two joints of the A^aSaAbiE: (M, TA:) and AlA^aSaAbiEi ↓ qaSabapu [or qaSabupu AlA_iSobaEi] signifies the A^anomalap [here perhaps meaning the ungual phalanx] of the finger or toe. (Msb, TA.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) The bones and veins of a wing. (MF.) ― -b10- [And (assumed tropical:) Quills: thus in the phrase SaAra Alr~iy$u qaSabFA, in the K, voce A^anuwqN, meaning The feathers became quills: n. un. ↓ qaSabapN: see SanamapN.] ― -b11- And (tropical:) [The bronchi;] the branches of the windpipe; (M, K;) and outlets of the breath; (K;) [i. e.] AlqaSabu, (S, M, O,) or faSabu Alr~iy^api, (A, Msb,) signifies the ducts (Euruwq) of the lungs; (S, A, O, Msb;) through which the breath passes forth. (S, M, A, O, Msb.) [See HaloqN.] ― -b12- And (assumed tropical:) Any things made of silver, and of other material, resembling [in form] the kind of round and hollow bone [or bones] thus called: n. un. ↓ qaSabapN. (S, O.) And (assumed tropical:) Jewels (S, M, K) having the form of tubes (A^anaAbiyb), (S,) or oblong, (M, K,) and hollow. (M.) ― -b13- And (assumed tropical:) Brilliant pearls, and brilliant chrysolites, interset with jacinths. (IAar, O, K.) So in the saying, in a trad., (O, K,) related as uttered by Gabriel, (O,) [cited in the S app. as an ex. of the meaning next preceding
this last,] ba$~iro xadiyjapa bibayoti fiY Aljan~api mino qaSabK (IAar, O, K) i. e. [Rejoice thou Khadeejeh by the announcement of] a pavilion [in Paradise] of brilliant pearls, &c.: (IAar, O:) or the meaning is, of hollow pearls [or pearl], spacious, like the lofty palace: (IAth, TA:) or of emerald: (TA voce bayotN:) and it is said by some to convey an allusion to Khadeejeh's acquiring what is termed qaSabu Als~aboqi [expl. above], because she was the first person, or the first of women, who embraced El-Islám. (MF, TA.) ― -b14- And (tropical:) Fine, thin, or delicate, (S, O,) or soft, (M, Msb, K,) garments, or cloths, of linen: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) a single one thereof is called ↓ qaSabiY~N. (M, O, Msb, K.) One says, maEa fulaAnK qaSabu SanoEaA='a waqaSabu miSora (tropical:) [In the possession of such a one are] qaSab [meaning the cylindrical, or oblong, hollow pieces] of carnelian [of San'à], and qaSab [meaning the fine, or soft, garments, or cloths,] of linen [of Egypt]. (A.) ― -b15- Also (tropical:) The channels by which water flows from the springs, or sources: (S, M, A, O, K:) or the channels by which the water of a well flows from the springs, or sources: (As, T, TA:) n. un. ↓ qaSabapN. (M.) And qaSabu AlbaToHaA='i (assumed tropical:) The waters [of the kind of water-course called bTHA=' (q. v.)] that run to the springs, or sources, of the wells. (As, S, O.) Aboo-Dhueyb says,
A^aqaAmato bihi faA@botanato xayomapF
EalaY qaSabK wafuraAtK naharo
(As, S, M, O,) meaning She remained [in it, and constructed for herself a booth, or a tent,] amid wells and sweet water that flowed copiously. (As, S, O.) ― -b16- See also qaSabapN below, in the next paragraph. -A2- AlqaSabu is also a name for The ewe. (O.) ― -b2- And qaSabo qaSabo is A call to the ewe (O, K) to be milked. (O.)

qaSabapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in nine places. ― -b2- [It also, app., signifies The caneroll of a loom: see niyrN. ― -b3- And, app., (assumed tropical:) The mouth, which has the form of a short cylinder, in the middle of the upper part, of the kind of leathern water-bag called mazaAdap: see xurotapN.] ― -b4- (tropical:) The bone of the nose; qaSabapu AlA^anofi signifying the nasal bone. (S, A.) ― -b5- [And (assumed tropical:) The shaft of a well.] You say biy^orN musotaqiymapu AlqaSabapi (assumed tropical:) [A well of which the shaft is straight]. (TA.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) A well recently dug. (M, K, TA.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) The interior part of a country or town; (A;) and of a qaSor [i. e. pavilion, or palace]; (M, A, K;) and of a fortress; (A:) or of a fortress containing a building or buildings; or the middle of such a fortress, (TA,) and of a town or village: (S, L, Msb, TA: [Golius, reading qiroyap qaroyap, assigns to it also the signification of the “ middle of a water-skin: ”]) or a qaSor [i. e. pavilion, or palace,] itself; (M, K;) and [a fortress itself, or] a fortified castle such as is occupied by a commander and his forces: (TA in art. xwj:) and a town or village [itself]: (M, K:) and the Hariym [as meaning interior, or middle,] of a house. (T and TA in art. Hrm.) Also A city: (K:) or the [chief] city (S, M, Msb) of the Sawád, (S,) or, [by a general application,] of a country: (M, Msb:) or the chief, or main, part (M, K) of a city (M) or of cities. (K: but in the TA this last meaning is given as the explanation of AlA^amoSaAri ↓ qaSabu.) ― -b8- See also qaSiybapN, in two places: ― -b9- and see qiSaAbN.
A^aroDN qaSibapN * : see qaSabN, first quarter.
qaSobaA='u * : see qaSabN, first quarter, in four places.
qaSobaApN * or qaSabaApN: see qaSabN, first sentence.
qaSobaA='apN * : see qaSabN, first sentence, in two places.
qaSabiY~N * : see qaSabN, last quarter.

qiSaAbN * , (so in the K, there said to be like kitaAbN,) or ↓ qiSaAbapN, (so in the M and L,) A dam that is constructed in the place that has been eaten away by water, [for lajof in the CK, and liHof in other copies of the K, (in the place of which I find luhoj in a copy of the M, app. a mistranscription,) I read, and thus render lajaf, supposing it to mean such a place in the side of a rivulet for irrigation,] lest the torrent should collect itself together from every place, and consequently the border of the rivulet for irrigation of the garden of palm-trees [thus I render EiraAqu AlHaAy^iTi (see art. Erq)] should become demolished. (M, K.) ― -b2- And qiSaAbN signifies dibaArN: (so accord. to a copy of the M:) or diyaArN: (so in copies of the K:) [the former I think to be the preferable reading; but its meaning is doubtful: accord. to the K it signifies Small channels for irrigation between tracts of seed-produce; and ISd says the like: accord. to AHn, patches of sown ground: see more voce daborN: it is a pl.,] and the sing. is ↓ qaSabapN. (M, K.)
qaSuwbN * A sheep or goat that one shears. (O, K.)

qaSiybN * , applied to a he-camel, (M, TA,) and likewise to a she-camel, (TA, [but this I think doubtful, as it has the meaning of an act. (not pass.) part. n.,]) That sucks up, or sucks in, the water. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also qaASibN.
qiSaAbapN * The art of playing upon the musical reed, or pipe. (S, O.) ― -b2- [And] The craft, or occupation, of the butcher. (M, Msb.) -A2- See also qiSaAbN.

qaSiybapN * : see quS~aAbapN. ― -b2- Also, and ↓ quS~aAbapN, (S, M, O, K,) and ↓ qaSabapN, (Lth, M, K,) and ↓ taqoSiybapN, (M, O, K,) and ↓ taqoSibapN, (M, K,) (tropical:) A lock of hair having a [spiral] twisted form [so as to be like a hollow cane]: (Lth, M, K:) or a pendent lock of hair that is twisted so as to curl [in a spiral form]; not plaited: (S, O:) or qaSiybapN signifies a lock of hair that curls naturally so as to be like a hollow cane; (A;) and its pl. is qaSaAy^ibN: (S, A:) [and,] accord. to Lth, such is termed ↓ qaSabapN (TA) [and app. ↓ quS~aAbapN also]: and ↓ taqoSiybapN, (Lth, A, TA,) of which the pl. is taqaASiybu, (Lth, A, O, TA,) signifies such as is twisted and made to curl by a woman; (Lth, * A, TA;) [and so, app., ↓ taqoSibapN;] i. e., such as, being [naturally] lank, is curled by means of canes and thread. (A.)

qaS~aAbN *
A blower in reeds or canes (naAfixN fiY AlqaSabi); as also ↓ qaASibN. (M, K. [In the former, this explanation is given in such a manner as plainly shows that it is meant to be understood as being distinct from that which next follows: but I incline to think that the two explanations are taken from different sources and have one and the same application.]) And (M, K) A player on the musical reed, or pipe; (AA, S, M, O, K;) and so ↓ qaASibN. (S, O.) Ru-beh says, (S, M, O, TA,) describing an ass, (S, O, TA,) braying, (TA,)
fiY jawofihi waHoYN kawaHoYi AlqaS~aAbo
[In his chest is, or was, a sound like the sound of the player on the musical reed]. (S, M, O, TA.) ― -b2- And A butcher; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ qaASibN: (M, K:) so called from qaSaba in the first of the senses expl. in this art.; (M, O, Msb, TA;) or because he takes the sheep or goat by its qaSabap, i. e. its shank-bone; (M, TA;) or because he cleanses the A^afoSaAb, or guts, of the belly; or from qaS~abahu signifying as expl. in the last sentence of the second paragraph of this article. (O, TA.)
quS~aAbN * : see quS~aAbahN, in two places.

qaS~aAbapN * (O, K, accord. to my MS. copy of the K quS~aAbapN [which is wrong]) liln~aAsi (O) (tropical:) One who reviles men, vilifies them, or defames them, much: (O, K:) [or, very much; for] the p is added to render the epithet [doubly] intensive. (O.) [See 1, third sentence.]

quS~aAbapN * , (S, O, and so accord. to my MS copy of the K, accord. to other copies of the K qaS~aAbapN [which is wrong,]) with damm and teshdeed, (S,) An internodial portion of a reed or cane; such a portion thereof as intervenes between two joints, or knots; syn. A^anobuwbapN; (S, O, K;) [a n. un. of the coll. gen. n. ↓ quS~aAbN;] and ↓ qaSiybapN, (O, K,) of which the pl. is qaSaAy^ibu, (TA,) signifies the same. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A musical reed, or pipe; syn. mizomaArN: (S, M, K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ quS~aAbN. (S, M, O.) See an ex. of the latter in a verse of El-Aashà (accord. to one relation thereof) cited voce quSobN. (S, M, O.) ― -b3- See also qaSiybapN, in two places.

qaASbN * , applied to a he-camel and a she-camel,
(ISk, S, M, O, K,) Abstaining from drinking before having satisfied thirst: (ISk, S, O:) or abstaining from drinking the water, and raising the head from it; (M, K;) and so ↓ qaSybN, likewise applied to the he-camel and the she-camel: (K: [but this latter I think doubtful:]) or a camel (baEiyrN) refusing to drink: (As, TA:) and ↓ muqotaSibapN is also said to be applied to a she-camel. (TA.) -A2- And A raiser, or grower, of qaSab [i. e. reeds, or canes]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also qaS~aAbN, in two places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Sounding thunder: (M:) and a cloud in which is thunder and lightning: (As, TA:) or, accord. to As, a cloud in which is thunder; (O;) [and] so says Az; (TA;) likened to a player on a musical reed, or pipe. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And dir~apN qaASibapN (assumed tropical:) A stream of milk coming forth easily (M, O) from the teat of the udder (O) as though it were a rod of silver. (M, O.) ― -b5- See, again, qaS~aAbN, last sentence.
taqoSibapN * and taqoSiybapN: see qaSiybapN; each in two places.
maqoSabapN * : see qaSabN, first quarter.
muqaS~abN * (tropical:) Hair curled in the manner expl. above, voce qaSiybapN. (S, A, O.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, folded. (Msb.)

muqaS~ibN * (tropical:) One who wins, or acquires, the canes of the contest for victory (in racing yuHorizu qaSaba Als~ibaAqi, A, O, K, TA, in the CK qaSabaAti Als~ibAqi) [i. e. in horse-racing]: and (tropical:) a fleet horse, that outstrips others. (A.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Milk upon which the froth is thick. (O, K.)
miqoSaAbN * may mean A place abounding with qaSab [i. e. reeds, or canes]; like as miEo$aAbN means “ a place abounding with [herbage of the kind termed] Eu$ob. ” (Ham p. 490.)
muqotaSibahN * : see qaASibN.

1 qaSadahu * , and qaSadalahu, and A_layohi, (S, M, A, L, Msb, K,) and naHowahu, (A in art. smt, &c.,) aor.
qaSida , (M, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. qaSodN, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) from which the pl. quSuwdN is formed by some of the professors of practical law; [and maqoSadN, q. v., is also an inf. n.;] (Msb;) He tended, repaired, or betook himself, or went, to, or towards, him, or it; (originally and properly, either in a direct course, in which sense it is in some places specially used, or indirectly; IJ, M, L;) he directed himself, or his course or aim, to, or towards, him, or it; he made for, or towards, him, or it; he made him, or it, his object; he aimed at him, or it: he sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain, or obtain, him, or it: he desired it, or wished for it: he intended it; purposed it; or meant it: syn. tawaj~aha wanahada wanahaDa naHowahu, (IJ, M, L,) and naHaAhu, (S, L,) and A^ataAhu, (S, A, L,) and Talabahu biEayonihi, (Msb,) and A^am~ahu, and AiEotamadahu, (M, L, K,) and AiEotazamahu. (IJ, M, L.) ― -b2- qaSadotu qaSodahu: see qaSodahu, below. ― -b3- qaSadotuhu bika*aA and qaSadotuhu lahu bihi [I brought to him such a thing: lit. I directed, or betook, myself to him with such a thing: see an ex. in the first para. of art. bY] (Ham. p. 41.) A_ilayoka qaSodiY, and ↓ maqoSadiY, (the latter with fet-h to the S, Msb), To thee is my tending, or repairing, &c. (A.) ― -b4- qaSada fiY AlA^amori, [aor.
qaSida ,] (A, Msb,) inf. n. qaSodN; (S. M, L, Msb, K) and fiyhi ↓ AqtSd; (M, L, K;) (tropical:) He pursued a right, or direct, course in the affair: (L:) or he followed the middle and most just way in the affair; and did not exceed the due bounds therein: (Msb:) or he acted in a moderate manner, in a manner between that of prodigality and that of parsimoniousness, in the affair: (S, L:) or he acted in a manner the contrary of that of extravagance in the affair: (M, L, K:) or he kept within the due bounds in the affair, and was content with a middle course: (A:) and in like manner, fY Aln~afaqapi in expense: (L:) and fiY maEiy$atihi with respect to his means of subsistence. (A, L.) See also 8. ― -b5- qaSada fiY ma$oyihi He (a man) walked at an equable, or a moderate, pace; syn. ma$aY musotuwiyFA. (L.) waA@qoSido fiY ma$oyika [in the Kur xxxi. 18,] (S) means And go thou at a moderate pace in thy walking; neither slowly nor quickly. (Beyd, Jel.) ― -b6- AiqoSido bi*aroEika Deal thou gently with thyself; moderate thyself; restrain thyself; i. q. AirobaEo EalaY nafosika. (S.) ― -b7- AlqaSoda AlqaSoda taboluguwA Keep ye to the middle way: keep ye to the middle way in affairs; in sayings and actions: so shall ye attain [to that which ye should desire]: AlqSd being in the accus. case as a corroborative inf. n.; and it is repeated also for the sake of corroboration. (L, from a trad.) ― -b8- qaSada, aor.
qaSida , (L,) inf. n. qaSodN, (M, L, K,) (tropical:) It (a road, or way,) was direct, or right; had a direct, or right, tendency. (M, L, K.) EalaY A@ll~`hi qaSodu Als~abiyli [Kur xvi. 9,] Upon God it rests to show the direct, or right way, (M, Beyd, L,) [or the right direction of the way] which leads to the truth, (Beyd,) and to invite to it by evident proofs: (M, L:) or upon God it rests to make the way direct, or right, in mercy and favour: or upon God depends one's directing his course to the [right] way. (Beyd.) ― -b9- qaSada, aor.
qaSida , (S, L,) inf. n. qaSodN, (S, L, K,) (tropical:) He acted with justice, or equity. (S, L, K.) Abu-l-Lahhám Eth-Thaalebee says,
EalaY AlHakami AlmaA^otiY~i yawomFA A_i*aA qaDaY
qaDiy~atahu A^an l~aA yajuwra wayaqoSidu
(S, L) meaning, It is encumbent on the judge who is come to, any day, when he decides his case, that he do not deviate from what is right, but (balo) act with justice, or equity. (IB, L.) Akh says, He means wayanobagiY A^ano yaqoSida; but as he makes an ellipsis, and puts yqSd in the place, syntactically, of ynbgY, he makes it marfooa, because it has the place of that which is [virtually] marfooa: and Fr says, he makes it marfooa because of the disagreement; for as its meaning disagrees with that of the preceding verb, it is made to disagree therefore in desinential syntax. (S, L.) -A2- qaSada, (S, L,) aor.
qaSida , (L,) inf. n. qaSodN, (S, L, K,) [and qaSida, see 7] He broke a stick: (S, L:) he broke in any way or manner: or he broke in halves: as also ↓ qS~d, inf. n. taqoSiydN: (L, K:) [or the latter signifies he broke many things; or broke in many pieces: see 7.] -A3- quSida lahu He was given a little. (S, O, K, art. qSd.) -A4- qaSuda, aor.
qaSuda , inf. n. qaSaAdapN, He (a camel, TA) became fat. (K.) -A5- See also 4.
2 qaS~ada see 1 last sentence but one. -A2- And see 4.

4 A^aqoSadaniY A_ilayohi AlA^amuro *
The affair caused me to tend, repair, betake myself, or direct my course, to, or towards, him, or it; to aim at him, or it; to seek, endeavour after, pursue, or endeavour to reach, attain, or obtain, him, or it; to desire it, or wish for it; to intend it, or purpose it. (M, L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (an arrow) hit its object, and killed on the spot. (S, K.) ― -b3- He pierced a man with a spear, (K,) or shot him with an arrow, (TA,) and did not miss him: (K:) he struck, or shot, a thing so that it died on the spot: (As:) he killed on the spot: (Lth:) it (a serpent) killed a person (Lth, S) on the spot: (Lth:) or bit him so as to kill him. (K, * TA.) A^aqoSadatohu Almaniy~apu Destiny killed him on the spot. (A.) -A2- AqSd, (inf. n. A_iqoSaAdN, TA,) He composed [odes, or] poems of the kind termed qaSiyd; a verb similar to A^aromala and A^ahozaja and A^arojaza: (Ibn-Buzurj, L:) also, (L, TA,) or ↓ AqtSd, inf. n. A_iqotiSaAdN, accord. to the K, but the former is the correct form, (TA,) [or the latter is probably correct, as being similar to A_irotajaza, as well as the former, of which the act. part. n. occurs in a verse,] and ↓ qaSada, inf. n. qaSodN; (K;) or ↓ qaS~ada; (as in the M and L;) he continued uninterruptedly, (L, K,) and prolonged, (L,) the composition of [odes, or] poems of the kind termed qaSaAy^id. (L, K.) See muqoSdN.

5 tqS~d *
He (a dog &c.) died. (S.) ― -b2- And see 7, in three places.

7 AnqSd * and ↓ tqS~d; (L, K;) and ↓ qaSida, aor.
qaSada , inf. n. qaSadN; but this form of the verb is seldom used; (L;) It broke, or became broken, in any way or manner: or it broke, or became broken, in halves: (L, K:) [but they are differently used: you say,] AnqSd Alr~umoHu [the spear broke: or] (S, L) the spear broke in halves: (L:) and Alr~imaAHu ↓ tqS~dti the spears broke in many pieces. (S, A, L.) -A2- AnqSd and ↓ tqS~d It (marrow) became detached, or came forth, from its place. (TA.)
8 AqtSd * : see 1. ― -b2- He aimed at that which was right and just. (A, art. Syd. See 1 in that art.) -A2- And see 4.

qaSodN * , [inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Used as a subst., The tending, self-direction, aim, or course of a
person ― -b3- Hence, An object of aim, of endeavour or pursuit, of desire or wish, or of intention or purpose; one's intention, intent, or meaning; as also ↓ maqoSuwdN. See maqoSidN] ― -b4- A thing that is right, of what is said and of what is done; syn. sadaAdN and SawaAbN. (S, voce tasodiydN, &c.) huwa EaAaY qaSodK, He is following a right way, or course. (Msb.) See also qaASidN. ― -b5- Conforming, or conformable, to the just mean. (M in art. Am.) See also muqaS~adN. -A2- A little that is given. (S, O, K, art. qSd.) -A3- See also qaSiydN.

qaSodahu *
In the direction of, or towards, him, or it. Ex. qaSadotu qaSodahu I tended, repaired, betook myself, or directed my course, towards him, or it: (S, Msb:) [like Samadotu Samodahu, and Haradotu Harodahu, and $adaA $adowahu, &c.:] also signifying, [I purposed his purpose, or] I pursued his (another's) way, or course, doing [and thinking] as he did. (L, in art. wkd.) A^axa*a qaSoda AlwaAdiY, and ↓ qaSiydahu, [He went towards the valley]. (A.) ― -b2- huwa qaSodaka, and qaSoduka, He is before thee, before thy face. It is more commonly used as a subst. (M, L.)

rumoHN qaSidN * , and ↓ qaSiydN, (M, L, K,) and ↓ A^aqoSaAdN, (S, L,) which is one of the words [used as a sing. epithet] having a pl. form, (Akh, S,) A spear broken: (M, L:) [or, broken in halves:] or broken in many pieces. (K.)

qiSodapN *
A fragment; a piece of a thing that is broken: (S, K:) and any piece [of a thing]: (TA:) pl. qiSadN. (S, K.) Ex. AlqanaA qiSadN [The spears are broken into fragments]. (S.) ― -b2- qiSodapN mino EaZomK A piece of a bone; meaning, a third, or a quarter, of the thigh, or arm, or skin, or shoulder; (M, L;) less than the half; as much as the third, or quarter. (IKtt.)
qaSuwdN * A camel having compact marrow. (ISh, L.) See also qaSiydN.

qaSiydN * and ↓ maqoSuwdN Aimed at, sought, desired, intended, or purposed. (L.) -A2- Fat marrow: (K:) or thick and fat marrow, that breaks in pieces (yataqaS~adu) by reason of its fatness: a piece thereof is termed qaSiydapN: (L:) or the former word and ↓ qaSuwdN signify marrow inferior to that which is fat (A, O, K) but superior to that which is lean: (A, O:) and qaSiydapN, a piece of marrow that has come forth from the bone. (L.) ― -b2- And (L, K), or *uw qaSiydK, (L,) A bone containing marrow. (L, K.) ― -b3- Dry, or tough, (yaAsis,) fleshmeat; (Lth, S, L, K;) as also ↓ qaSodN; and, as some say, fat fleshmeat. (L.) ― -b4- A fat she-camel, (L, K,) plump and corpulent, (L,) and having marrow in her bones; as also qaSiydapN. (L, K.) ― -b5- A fat camel's hump. (K.) -A3- A staff; (L, K;) as also qaSiydap; (K;) or the latter has not been heard: (TA:) pl. qaSaAy^idu. (L.) -A4- Poetry, or a poem, trimmed, pruned, or free from faults, well executed, (K,) and composed with premeditation; (TA;) as also qaSiydapN: (TA:) [but the latter is used as a subst.] ― -b2- qaSiydN, a gen. n., applied properly to poetry, and, by extension of the signification, to a single poem, for qaSiydapN; (IJ, L;). or it is pl. of qaSiydapN, like as safiynN is of safiynapN; (S, L;) and so is qaSaAy^idu; (L;) [but properly, qaSiydN is a coll. gen. n., and qaSiydapN is its n. un., and qaSaAy^idu is pl. of the latter;] Poetry, or a poem, [or an ode, (for it was always designed to be chanted or sung,)] of which the bipartition ($aTor) of the verses is complete; (M, L, K;) [i. e., of which the hemistichs are complete, not curtailed; (see Alr~amalu;)] consisting of three verses or more; (Akh, M, L, K;) or of sixteen or more; (M, L, K;) for it is usual to call that which consists of three verses, or ten, or fifteen, qiToEapN, and what consists of more than fifteen the Arabs call qSydp: (IJ, M, L:) or, as Akh has once said, what is of the metre called AlT~awiyl, and AlbasiyT that is complete, and AlkaAmil that is complete, and Almadiyd that is complete, by which he means the first species thereof, which is the most complete that is in use, and AlwaAfir that is complete, by which, in like manner, he means the first species thereof, and Alr~ajaz that is complete, and Alxafiyf that is complete, and [any ode, or] any poem that is sung by persons riding; but, he adds, we have not heard them sing what is of the metre called Alxfyf: (M, L:) such poetry is thus termed because composed with purpose and consideration, and earnest endeavour to make it excellent; from qaSodN as syn. with A^am~N: or because composed with care, and trimmed with excellent expressions and choice meanings, from qaSiydN signifying “ thick and fat marrow; ” for the Arabs tropically apply to chaste, or eloquent, or excellent, language the epithet samiyn, or “ fat: ” (L:) or because of its completeness, and the soundness of its measure. (M, L.) For the meanings of bayotu AlqaSiydapi, see bayotN; last sentence. -A5- See also qaSidN.
qaSiydapN * : see qaSiydN throughout.

Tryq qaASidN * , (M, L,) and qaASidapN, (A,) and ↓ qaSodN, (A, Msb,) (tropical:) A direct, or right road, or way; a road, or way, having a direct, or right, tendency: (A, L:) an even, and a direct, or right, road, or way: (M, L:) an even road, or way. (Msb.) ― -b2- sahomN qaASidN (tropical:) An arrow rightly directed towards the animal at which it is shot: pl. sihaAmN qawaASidu. (A.) ― -b3- qaASidN Near. (S, K.) ― -b4- safarN qaASidN An easy, short journey: (TA:) [a moderately easy and short journey:] a journey not difficult, nor extremely far. (Ibn-'Arafeh.) ― -b5- bayonanaA wabayona AlmaA='i layolapN qaASidapN (tropical:) Between us and the water is an easy night's journey (S, K) without fatigue or tardiness: (S:) pl. layaAlK qawaASidu. (TA.) ― -b6- maA='N qaASidN Water of which the herbage, or pasture, is near. (IAar, TA, voce muTolibN.)
A^aqSadu * [A more, or most, direct road]. (S, voce A^aro$adu.) ― -b2- Ealayoka bimaA huwa A^aqoSadu waA^aqosaTu (tropical:) Keep thou to that which is most right and most just. (A.)
A^aqoSaAdN * : see qaSidN.

[
maqoSadu AlkalaAmi * means the intended sense of the saying; the meaning thereof: (see maEonFY in art. EnY:) maqoSadN being an inf. n. used as in the sense of the pass. part. n. of its verb, i. e. in the sense of ↓ maqoSuwdN; like as is generally said of its syn. maEonFY, of which maqoSuwdN is one of the explanations: hence it has a pl. maqaASidu: in the CK in art. gzw it is erroneously written maqoSid, which is the n. of place and of time from qaSada. ― -b2- And in like manner maqoSadN signifies also A thing aimed at, intended, or purposed; an object of aim or pursuit: see 1: and ↓ maqoSidN, tropically used, has the same meaning.]

maqoSidN * , with kesr to the S, A place to, or towards, which one tends, repairs, or betakes himself; to which one directs his course; at which one aims; which one seeks, pursues, endeavours to reach, desires, or wishes for; [pl. maqaASidu.] Ex. lahu maqoSidN maEay~anN He has a specified place to which, or towards which, he tends, or repairs, &c. (Msb.) baAbuka maqoSidiY Thy door, or gate, is the place to which, or towards which, I tend, or repair, &c. (A.) ― -b2- maqaASidu AlT~aruqi [The right places to which roads tend]; i. q. maraA$iduhaA. (S, L, K, art. r$d.) See also maqoSadN.
muqoSadN * One who falls sick and quickly dies. (K.)

muqoSidN * [One who composes poems of the kind termed qaSaAy^id: see 4: also,] and ↓ muqaS~idN, one who continues uninterruptedly, and prolongs, the composition of poems of the kind termed qSAy^d. (M, L.)

maqoSadapN * [lit., A thing that causes people to repair to, or seek, or endeavour after, or desire, it]. ― -b2- A woman great, and perfect, or complete, who pleases every one (K) that beholds her. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (or, as some write it, ↓ muqaS~adapN, TA,) A woman inclining to shortness. (K.)
maqoSuwdN * : see qaSodN, qaSiydN, and maqoSadN.

muqaS~adN * (tropical:) A man neither corpulent nor thin; as also ↓ muqotaSidN and ↓ qaSodN: (L, K:) or a man of moderate, or middle, stature; (ISh, L;) neither tall nor short, nor corpulent; (IAth, L;) as also qaSodN: (ISh:) or a man &c. neither corpulent nor short. (Lth, L.) See maqoSadapN.
muqaS~idN * : see muqoSidN.

fulaAnN muqotaSidN fiY Aln~afaqapi * (tropical:) Such a one acts in a moderate manner, in a manner between that of prodigality and that of parsimoniousness, in expense. (S, L.) See 1. And see muqaS~adN.

1 qaSura * , aor.
qaSura , inf. n. qiSarN (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and qaSorN (IAar, M, K) and qaSaArapN, (Lh, M, K,) It (a thing, S, Msb, i. e. anything, M) was, or became, short; contr. of TaAla. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [And It was, or became, too short. And qaSura Eanohu It was, or became, too short for him, or
it. ― -b3- Hence, qaSurato yaduhu, and qaSura baAEuhu, (tropical:) He had little, or no, power: and he was, or became, niggardly.] -A2- And qaSara Als~ahomu Eani Alhadafi, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura , (Msb,) inf. n. quSuwrN, (M, Msb,) The arrow fell short of the butt; did not reach it; (S, Msb;) fell upon the ground without reaching the butt: (M:) and qaSara Eano manozilihi [he fell short of his place of alighting or abode; did not reach it]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qaSara Eani AlA^amori, (S, Msb, K,) [and qaSara duwnahu,] aor.
qaSura , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. quSuwrN; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ AqSr, (K,) inf. n. A_iqaSaArN; (TA;) and ↓ qS~r, (K,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (TA;) and ↓ tqASr; (K;) [He fell, or stopped, or came, short of doing the thing, or affair; he failed of doing, or accomplishing, it;] he lacked power, or ability, to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair; (S, Msb, K;) he could not attain to it: (S:) or the first has this signification; (ISk, S, Msb;) and [in like manner] Eanohu ↓ qS~r, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN, (TA,) he left or relinquished it, or abstained from it, being unable to do or accomplish it: (M, K:) but Eanohu ↓ AqSr, he desisted or abstained from it, being able to do or accomplish it: (ISk, S, M, Msb:) such, at least, is generally the case, though both sometimes occur in one and the same sense, that which AqSr Enh generally bears: (TA:) and fiY AlA^amori ↓ qS~r [he fell, or stopped, or came, short in the affair: it signifies nearly the same as AqSr Enh, i. e., he fell short of accomplishing the affair; he fell short of doing what was requisite, or due, or what he ought to have done, (Eam~aA kaAna yanobagiY, or the like, being understood,) in, or with respect to, the affair: a meaning very common, and implied, though not expressed, in the M: and] he flagged, or was remiss, in the affair; syn. tawaAnaY: (S, TA:) or ↓ qS~r signifies he left, desisted from, neglected, or left undone, a thing, or part thereof, from inability: but ↓ AqSr, he left it, &c., or part thereof, with ability to do it. (Kull p. 128.) [And ↓ qS~r duwnahu He fell short of reaching, or attaining, it: see an ex. voce yaEoquwbN.] [Hence also,] qaSarato binaA Aln~afaqapu The money for expenses [fell short of what we required;] did not enable us to attain our object; (Msb;) meaning, that they were unable to pay the expenses: (Mgh:) and bihi ↓ qaS~ara A^amaluhu [his hope fell short of what he required]: 'Antarah says,
faA@loyawoma qaS~ara Eano tiloqaAy^ika AlA^amalu
[but to-day, hope hath fallen short of extending to the meeting with thee]. (TA.) [And hence, app.,] bika*aA nafosuka ↓ qaS~arato [Thy mind, or wish, fell short of what was requisite with respect to such a thing], said to him who has sought, or desired, little, and a mean share or lot. (TA.) And, bifulaAnK ↓ qaS~ara [He fell short of what was required by such a one, or due to him; or] he acted meanly, and sparingly, with such a one, in a gift. [&c.] (JK [see muqaS~irN: and see two exs. of qaS~ara bihi voce A^azoraY in art. zrY.] ― -b3- [Also, qaSara Eani AlA^amori, (M, K,) aor.
qaSura , (M,) inf. n. quSuwrN; and ↓ AqSr; and ↓ qS~r and ↓ tqASr; (M, K;) He refrained, abstained, or desisted, from the thing, or affair. (M, K.) A poet says,
A_i*aA gam~a xiro$aA='u Alv~umaAlapi A^anofahu
minohaA lilS~ariyHi faA^aqonaEaA ↓ taqaASara
[When the froth of the water remaining in the drinking-trough covers his nose, he refrains from it, turning to the clear, and raises his head]: or mnhA ↓ tqASr here signifies he contracts his neck from it: and it is said that Enh ↓ qS~r signifies as explained above, he left or relinquished it, &c. (M.) qaSara Ean~iY AlwajaEu, and AlgaDabu, (M, K,) aor.
qaSura , inf. n. quSuwrN, (M,) The pain, and anger, ceased from me; quitted me; (M, K;) as also qaSira; (M, TA;) which latter is erroneously written in the copies of the K, qaS~ara: (TA:) and qaSarotu A^anaA Eanohu [I ceased from it]. (M.) And A@lomaTaru ↓ A^aqoSara The rain left off. (TA.) -A3- qado qaSara AlEa$iY~u, aor.
qaSura , inf. n. quSuwrN, [The afternoon, or evening, has come,] is said when you enter upon the masaA=' [i. e. afternoon, or evening]: (S:) or it means has almost drawn near to night. (TA.) [See also qaSorN, below.] ― -b2- Hence, (S,) qaSaronaA and ↓ A^aqoSaronaA We entered upon the Ea$iY~ [i. e. afternoon, or evening]; (M, K;) the former signifies A^amosayonaA; and the latter, daxalonaA fiY qaSori AlEa$iY~i, like as you say A^amosayonaA from AlmasaA='u: (S:) or the former, we came to be in the last part of the day; and the latter, we entered upon the last part of the day. (IKtt.) -A4- qaSarahu, (Msb, K,) aor.
qaSura , (Msb,) or
qaSira , (K,) inf. n. qaSorN; (TA;) and ↓ qS~rhu, (M, Msb, TA;) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (TA;) and ↓ AqSrhu; (Msb;) He made it short; (M, K, TA;) he shortened it; took from its length. (Msb.) You say qaSara Al$~aEara, (M, Msb, K,) and qaSara mina Al$~aEari, (S,) aor.
qaSura , (Msb,) or
qaSira ; (K;) and ↓ qS~rh, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and minohu ↓ qS~r; (S;) and ↓ AqSrhu; (Msb;) He shortened the hair; (M, K, * TA;) took from its length; (Msb;) cut its ends; (Mgh;) clipped, or shore, it. (TA.) And qaSara AlS~alaApa, (M, Msb, TA,) and qaSara mina AlS~alaApi, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura , inf. n. qaSorN; (S, M, Msb, TA;) and ↓ qS~rhA, (M, Msb, TA,) and ↓ qS~r mnhA, (S, M,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (S;) and ↓ AqSrhA, (Msb, TA,) and ↓ AqSr mnhA; (S;) but AqSrhA is extr.; (TA;) He curtailed [or contracted] the prayer; (M;) he performed a prayer of four rek'ahs (rakaEaAt) making it of two; (Mgh;) in a journey. (Mgh, TA.) And AlxuTobapa ↓ AqSr He made the [form of words called] xTbp [delivered from the pulpit] short, or concise: (Mgh, TA: *) the doing so being commanded. (Mgh.) qaSorN also signifies the contr. of mad~N; (M, K;) and the verb is qaSara [He contracted, or straitened]. (M.) You say qaSarotu qayoda AlbaEiyri; (Msb;) and qaSarotu lahu mino qayodihi; (M;) aor.
qaSura , inf. n. qaSorN; (M, Msb;) I contracted the shackles of the camel; syn. Say~aqutuhu; (Msb;) and I contracted his shackles; syn. qaArabotu. (M.) [And in like manner, AlEaTiy~apa ↓ qaS~ara, inf. n. taqoSiyrN, He made the gift scanty, or mean: or, accord. to the TK, qS~r fiY AlEaTiy~api, which properly signifies he fell short of what he ought to have done with respect to the gift: but, though each of these phrases is doubtless correct, the former expression I hold to be that which is indicated when it is said that] Alt~aqoSiyru signifies A_ixosaAsu AlEaTiy~api. (M, K.) -A5- qaSarahu, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura , (S, M,) inf. n. qaSorN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He confined, restricted, limited, kept within certain bounds or limits, restrained, withheld, hindered or prevented, him, or it; syn. Habasahu. (S, M, Msb, K. *) It is said in a trad. of Mo'ádh, lahu maA qaSara fiY bayotihi To him belongeth what he hath held confined in, or kept within, his house or tent: (TA:) or what he hath held in possession &c. (Az, TA in art. xmr: see 10 in that art.) You say also qaSarotu Ald~aAra, inf. n. as above, I [confined and so] defended the house by walls. (TA.) And qaSara AljaAriyapa biA@loHijaAbi He [confined and so] kept safe the girl by means of the veil, or covering, or the like: and in like manner you say of a horse. (TA.) And in a trad. of 'Omar it is said, qaSara bihimu All~ayolu, (TA,) or ↓ qaS~ara, (L,) The night withheld them; namely a company of riders upon camels on other beasts. (L, TA.) You also say qaSara Alr~ajula Eani AlA^amori [and qaSara bihi and bh ↓ qS~r] He withheld the man from the thing, or affair, that he desired to do. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce Tal~aAE.] And qaSarotu nafasiY Eano $aYo'K I withheld, or restrained, myself from a thing: (JK, TA: *) and I restrained myself from inordinate desire of a thing. (TA.) Lebeed says
falasotu waA_ino A^aqoSarotu Eanohu bimuqoSiri
meaning, But although thou blame in order that I may be restrained, I do not refrain from that which I desire to do. (El-Mázinee, L.) Also, qaSarotu TarofiY [I restrained my eye, or eyes;] I did not raise my eye, or eyes, towards that at which I ought not to look. (TA.) And qaSara AlbaSara He turned away the eye. (TA.) It is also said in a trad. of I'Ab, quSira Alr~ijaAlu EalaY A^arobaEK mino A^ajoli A^amowaAli AlyataAmaY Men were restricted to marrying no more than four [because of the property of the orphans which they might leave]. (TA.) And one says qaSarotu nafosiY EalaY Al$~aYo'i I confined, or restricted, myself to the thing, and obliged myself to do it. (TA.) [See also 8.] Hence what is said of Thumámeh, in a trad., fA^abaY A^ano yusolima qaSorFA But he refused to become a Muslim by constraint and compulsion: or by force, as some say, from Alqasuru; the s being changed into S, as is done in many other cases. (TA.) You say also
qaSarotu Al$~aYo'a EalaY ka*aA I restricted the thing to such a thing. (S, TA.) And qaSarahu EalaY AlA^amori, meaning, rad~ahu A_ilayohi, (M, K,) i. e., [He reduced him, to the thing, or affair; or] he appropriated him [or it, restrictively,] to the thing, or affair. (TK.) [Hence,] qaSarotu All~iqoHapa EalaY farasiY I appropriated the milk of the milch-camel [restrictively] to my horse. (S, TA.) [And hence,] qaSarotu EalaY nafosiY naAqapF I retained for myself [restrictively] a she-camel, that I might drink her milk. (Msb.) Aboo-Du-ád says, describing a horse,
faquSirona Al$~itaA='a baEodu Ealayohi
wahuwa lil*~awodi A^ano yuqas~amona jaArN
