meaning, So they were restricted to him, that he might drink their milk, during the severity of the winter, afterwards; and he is a protector to the few she-camels from their being suddenly attacked and divided in shares; mino being understood before A^ano. (M.) -A6- qaSara Alv~awoba, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura , (S,) inf. n. qaSorN (S, Mgh, Msb) and qiSaArapN; (Sb, M, TA;) and ↓ qS~rhu, (S, M,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (S;) He beat, (S, TA,) washed, (Mgh,) and whitened, (M, Msb, TA,) the cloth, or garment. (S, M, &c.)
2 qaS~ara see 1, throughout.

4 A^aqoSara see 1, throughout. -A2- A^aqoSarato She brought forth short children: hence the saying, A_in~a AlT~awiylapa qado tuqoSiru waA_in~a AlqaSiyrapa qado tuTiylu [Verily the tall woman sometimes brings forth short children, and verily the short woman sometimes brings forth tall children]. (S, K. *) J is in error in saying that this is in a trad. (Sgh, K.) But IAth also asserts it to be a trad. (MF in art. Twl.)

6 tqASr *
He feigned, or pretended, (A^aZohara,) shortness; (M, Sgh, K;) as also ↓ taqawoSara: (Sgh, K:) or, accord. to some, these two verbs have different significations: see the latter below. (TA.) ― -b2- [And He contracted himself, or drew himself together. (See R. Q. 1 in art. f*.)] ― -b3- tqASrt nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) He (lit. his spirit, or soul,) became abject, mean, contemptible, or despicable; syn. taDaA='alato. (M.) ― -b4- tqASr AlZ~il~u (tropical:) The shade became contracted. (M, TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, in two places.

8 AqtSr EalaY AlA^amori *
He confined, restricted, or limited, himself to the thing, or affair; did not exceed it. (M, K. *) ― -b2- AqtSr EalaY Al$~aYo'i, (S,) or ElY ka*aA, (Msb,) [and bika*aA,] He was satisfied, or content, (S, Msb,) with the thing, (S,) or with such a thing. (Msb.) ― -b3- AqtSr EalaY A^amoriY He obeyed my command. (JK.)

10 AstqSrhu *
He reckoned, or held, him, or it, to be short. (S.) ― -b2- He reckoned him, or held him, to fall short of doing what he ought to do: or to flagg, or be remiss: Ead~ahu muqaS~irFA. (S.)

Q. Q. 2 taqawoSara * , said of a man, (M,) He became contracted; lit., one part of him entered into another part; (M, K;) as though he became like a qawoSar~ap, from which word the verb is derived. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- See also 6.

qaSorN * and ↓ qaSarN and ↓ quSorapN [like the inf. n. quSuwrN] The falling, or stopping, or coming, short of accomplishing an affair; or of doing what one ought, or is commanded, to do; or flagging, or remissness: you say to a man whom you have sent to accomplish some needful affair, and who has fallen short of doing what you commanded him to do, on account of heat or some other cause, maA manaEaka A^ano taboluga AlmakaAna Al~a*iY A^amarotuka bihi A_il~aA A^an~aka A^aHobabota AlqaSora, and AlqaSara, and AlquSorapa, i. e. A^ano tuqaS~ira [Nothing prevented thy reaching the place to which I commanded thee to go but thy loving to fall short &c.; or to flag, or be remiss]. (M, K *.) And ↓ qaSarapN, (K,) or ↓ qaSarN, without p, accord. to the Nawádir of IAar, as cited in the L, and so in the handwriting of Sgh, (TA,) and ↓ qaSaArN, (K,) signify Laziness; slothfulness. (IAar, Sgh, K.) An Arab of the desert is related to have said ↓ A^aradotu A^ano A=tiyaka famanaEaniY AlqaSaAru [I desired to come to thee, but laziness prevented me]. (TA.) -A2- qaSoruka A^ano tafoEala ka*aA and ↓ qaSaAruka, (S, M, K,) and ↓ quSaAruka, (M, K,) and ↓ quSaAraAka, (S, M, K,) and ↓ quSayoraAka, (M, K,) Thine utmost, or the utmost of thy power or of thine ability or of thy deed, (juhoduka, M, K, [or app., jahoduka, (see art. jhd,)] and gaAyatuka, S, M, K,) and the end of thy case, and that to which thou hast confined or restricted or limited thyself, (S, TA,) [or that to which thou art confined or restricted or limited,] is, or will be, thy doing such a thing. (S, M, K.) It is from qaSorN signifying the “ act of confining, restricting, limiting, ” &c. (TA.) And ↓ quSoraY also signifies the end of an affair. (Sgh, TA.) A poet says
A_in~amaA A^anofusunaA EaAriy~apN
waA@loEawaAriY~u qaSaArN A^ano turado
[Our souls are only a loan: and the end of loans is their being given back; turado being for turad~a]. (S, TA.) You also say, kul~i balaA='K wa$id~apK ↓ Almawotu quSaAriY [Death is the end of every trial and distress]. (TA, art. HmA^.) -A3- qaSorN (S, M) and ↓ maqoSarN (K) and ↓ maqoSarapN and ↓ maqoSirN (M, K) The afternoon: or evening: syn. Ea$iY~N: (S, M, K:) or the first signifies the last part of the day: (IKtt:) or the time before the sun becomes yellow: (JK:) or the first and second signify the time of the approach of the Ea$iY~, a little before the EaSor: (A, TA:) and the first (S, K) and second (A'Obeyd, TA) and third, (A'Obeyd, S, TA,) [the time of] the mixing of the darkness: (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA:) pl. of the second (TA) and third (S, M) and fourth, (M,) maqaASiru (S, M) and maqaASiyru, which latter is extr.; (M;) in the first sense, as signifying Ea$aAyaA; (M;) or in the last sense; (S;) not signifying, as it is said to do in the K, AlEi$aA='u AlA=xirapu; for this is a great mistake, app. occasioned by F's seeing the passage [in the T] of Az, [or in the M, in which I find it,] waAlmaqaASiru waAlmaqaASiyru AlEa$aAyaA AlA^axiyrapu naAdirapN, and not properly considering it. (TA.) Sb says, that qaSorN has no dim.; the Arabs being content to use in its stead the dim. of masaA='N. (M.) You say A^atayotuhu qaSorFA I came to him in the afternoon, or evening; syn. Ea$iy~FA. (S.) And jiy^otu qaSorFA, and ↓ maqoSarFA, I came at the approach of the Ea$iY~, a little before the EaSor. (A, TA.) And AlEi$aA='i ↓ A^aqobalato maqaASiyru [The times of the mixing of the darkness of nightfall came, or advanced]. (A, TA.) -A4- qaSorN [A palace: a pavilion, or kind of building wholly or for the most part isolated, sometimes on the top of a larger building, i. e., a belvedere, and sometimes projecting from a larger building, and generally consisting of one room if forming a part of a larger building or connected with another building; the same as the Turkish kw$k: to such buildings we find the appellation to have been applied from very early times to the present day:] a well-known kind of edifice: (M:) a mansion, or house; syn. manozilN: (Lh, M, K:) or any house or chamber (bayot) of stone; (M, K;) of the dial. of Kureysh: (M:) so called because a man's wives and the like are confined in it: (M:) pl. quSuwrN. (S, M, Msb.) qaSoru A@lomaliki [The palace, or pavilion, of the king]. (Msb.) -A5- Also qaSorN Large and dry, or large and thick, or dry, fire-wood; HaTabN jazolN. (M, K.) So in the Kur, lxxvii. 32, accord. to El-Hasan, as related by Lh. (M.)

qaSarN * : see qaSorN, in two places. -A2- The necks of men, and of camels: (M, K:) a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.], of which the sing. [or n. un.] is qaSarapN: (M:) [see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. sndr:] or [so accord. to the M, but in the K and] ↓ qaSarapN signifies the base of the neck; (S, M, K;) the base of the neck at the place where it is set upon the upper part of the back: (Nuseyr, TA:) or the base of the neck when thick; not otherwise: (Lh, M:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] qaSarN, and pl. pl. [or pl. of qaSarN] A^aqoSaArN: (M:) or this latter is pl. of qaSarapN, (M, K,) accord. to Kr, but this is extr., unless the augmentative letter in the sing. be disregarded in its formation. (M.) I'Ab reads kaA@loqaSari, in the Kur, lxxvii. 32, (S, M, * TA,) and explains it as meaning Like the thick bases of necks, (M, * TA,) or as meaning kaqaSari Aln~axoli, i. e. AlA^aEonaAq. (S.) [See the next signification.] You say *al~ato qaSaratuhu [His neck or] the base of his neck became in a state of subjection. (TA.) And A_in~ahu lanaAm~u AlqaSarapi Verily he has a large, or thick, neck. (Aboo-Mo'ádh the Grammarian.) ― -b2- And hence, (Aboo-Mo'ádh,) (tropical:) The trunks, or lower-parts, (A^uSuwl, M, K, or A^aEonaAq,
I'Ab, S,) of palm-trees: (S, M, K:) so explained in the Kur, ubi supra, (S, M,) by I'Ab: (S:) sing. [or n. un.] ↓ qaSarapN: the palm-tree is cut into pieces of the length of a cubit, to make fires therewith in the winter: (Aboo-Mo'ádh:) and [in the TA or] so of other trees: (M, K:) or of large trees: (Ed-Dahhák:) or [accord. to the M, but in the K and] the remains of trees. (M, K.)
qaSorapN * : see quSorapN.

quSorapN * : see qaSorN. -A2- huwa A@bonu Eam~ihi quSorapF, (S, M, K,) and ↓ qaSorapF, (K,) and ↓ maqoSuwrapF, (S, M, K,) and ↓ qaSiyrapF, (K,) [He is his cousin on the father's side,] nearly related; (S, M, K;) i. q. dinoyFA (S, TA) and dunoyFA: (TA:) and in like manner you say of the Abn AlEam~ap and Abn AlxaAlap and Abn AlxaAl. (Lh, M.)

quSoraY * : see qaSorN. -A2- AlquSoraY (Az, S) and ↓ AlquSayoraY (A'Obeyd, Az, S) The rib that is next to the $aAkilap [or flank], (A'Obeyd, Az, S,) also called AlwaAhinapu, (S,) and DilaEu Alxilofi, (A'Obeyd,) at the bottom of the ribs, (S,) between the side and the belly: (Az:) or the former is the lowest of the ribs, and the latter is the highest of the ribs: (AHeyth:) or the latter is the lowest of the ribs: or the last rib in the side: or the quSorayaAni and ↓ quSayorayaAni are the two ribs that are next to the TafoTafap [or flank]: or that are next to the two collar-bones. (M, K.)
qaSarapN * : see qaSorN: -A2- and qaSarN, in two places: -A3- and miqoSarapN.
qaSaArN * : and qaSaAruka and quSaAruka: see qaSorN.

qiSaArN * , a subst., The shortening [or clipping] of the hair. (Th, M, K. *) Fr says, An Arab of the desert said to me in Minè, AlqiSaAru A^aHab~u A_ilayoka A^ami AlHaloqu, meaning, Is the shortening [or clipping] more pleasing to thee, or the shaving of the head? (M.)

qaSiyrN *
Short; and low, i. e. having little height; contr. of TawiylN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and so ↓ qaASirN, app. a kind of rel. or possessive n., not a verbal epithet: (M:) fem. of the former [and of the latter] with p: (M, K:) pl. of the former, masc., (S, M, Msb, K,) and fem., (M, K,) qiSaArN, (S, M, &c.,) and pl. masc. [applied to rational beings,] quSaraA='u, (M, K,) and pl. fem. qiSaArapN; (K;) p being added by the Arabs to any pl. of the measure fiEaAlN, as in jimaAlapN and HibaAlapN and *ikaArapN and HijaArapN; (Fr;) or qiSaArapN is syn. with qaSiyrapN, and is extr. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- qaSiyrapN mino TawiylapK [lit. A short thing from a tall thing; meaning,] a date from a palm-tree: a proverb; alluding to the abridgment of speech or language. (K.) ― -b3- huwa qaSiyru Alyadi, [and AlbaAEK, (tropical:) He has little, or no, power: or is niggardly:] and lahumo A^ayodK qiSaArN [they have little, or no, power: or are niggardly]. (TA.) ― -b4- qaSiyru Alhim~api [Having little ambition]. (O in art. bjl.) ― -b5- A_in~ahu laqaSiyru AlEilomi (tropical:) [Verily he has little knowledge]. (M.) ― -b6- qaSiyru Aln~asabi [Having a short pedigree;] whose father is well known, so that when the son mentions him it is sufficient for him, without his extending his lineage to his grandfather. (K.) [See also a verse below, in this paragraph.] ― -b7- HadiyvN qaSiyrN, and ↓ muqotaSarN, A [concise, or] comprehensive, and profitable, story, or narration. (TA.) -A2- [I. q. ↓ maqoSuwrN and ↓ maqoSuwrapN, Shortened; contracted: and confined; restricted; limited; &c.] ― -b2- A_imoraA^apN qaSiyru AlxuTaY, and AlxaTowi ↓ maqoSuwrapu, [A woman whose steps are shortened, or contracted;] likened to one who is shackled, whose steps are shortened, or contracted, by the shackles. (Fr.) ― -b3- farasN qaSiyrN A mare that is brought near [to the tent or dwelling], and treated generously, and not left to seek for pasture, because she is precious: (S, K:) and a mare that is kept confined. (TA.) ― -b4- qaSiyrapN, [which is extr., for by rule it should be without p,] and ↓ qaSuwrapN, (Az, S, M, K,) and ↓ maqoSuwrapN, (K,) A woman confined in the house, or tent, not suffered to go forth: (S, M, K:) a woman kept behind, or within, the curtain: (TA, in explanation of the last of these three epithets:) a girl kept with care, that does not go out: (Az:) the pl. of qSwrp is qaSaAy^iru:] [and so, app., of qSyrp:] when you mean short in stature, you say qaSiyrapN [only], and the pl. is qiSaArN. (TA.) Kutheiyir says
waA^anoti Al~atiY Hab~aboti kul~a qaSiyrapK
A_ilaY~a wamaA tadoriY bi*aAka AlqaSaAy^iru
Eanayotu qaSiyraAti AlHijaAli walamo A^urido
qiSaAra AlxuTaY $ar~u Aln~isaA='i AlbaHaAtiru
(S, M) or, as Fr relates it, kul~a qaSuwrapF (S) [And thou art the person who hath made every female confined within the house to be an object of love to me, while the females confined within the house know not that: I mean those confined within the curtained canopies: I do not mean the short in step: the worst of women are the short and compressed]. And a poet says
waA^ahowaY mina Aln~iswaAni kul~a qaSiyrapK
lahaA nasabN fiY AlS~aAliHiyna qaSiyru
[And I love, of women, every one that is confined within the house, that has a short pedigree, among the good]; i. e., every ↓ maqoSuwrap, of whom it suffices to mention her descent from her father, because of his being well known. (M.) Hence, in the Kur, [lv. 72,] HuwrN maqoSuwraAtN fiY AlxiyaAmi [Damsels having eyes whereof the white is intensely white and the black intensely black,] confined in the pavilions, (Az, Msb,) which are of pearls, for their husbands; (Az;) concealed by curtains: (Az, Bd:) or confined to their husbands, and not raising their eyes to others: (Fr:) or having their eyes restricted to their husbands. (Bd.) And ↓ naAqapN maqoSuwrapN, (TA,) or maqoSuwrapN EalaY AlEiyaAli, (Msb,) A she-camel retained [restrictively] for the household, that they [alone] may drink her milk. (Msb, TA. *) ― -b5- See also quSorapN.
quSaArapN * : see maqoSuwrapN.
qiSaArapN * The art of [beating and] washing (Mgh) and whitening (M, Msb) clothes. (M, Mgh, Msb.)
qaSuwrapN * : see maqoSuwrapN: and qaSiyrN.
quSaAraY * . ― -b2- quSaAraAka: see qaSorN.
quSayoraY * . ― -b2- quSayoraAka: see qaSorN. -A2- See also quSoraY.

qaS~aArN *
One who beats (S) and washes (Mgh) and whitens (M, Msb, K) clothes; (S, M, &c.;) as also ↓ muqaS~irN. (M, K.)

qaASirN * : see qaSiyrN, first signification. -A2- A_imorA^apN qaASirapu AlT~arofi A woman restraining her eyes from looking at any but her husband. (S, K.) ― -b2- Zil~N qaASirN (tropical:) Contracting shade. (TA.)

qawoSar~apN * , and (sometimes, S,) qawoSarapN, without teshdeed, A receptacle for dates, or for dried dates, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in which they are stored, made of mats, (S,) of reeds: (M, Mgh, Msb, K:) in common conventional language only so called as long as it contains dates: otherwise it is called zabiylN: (Mgh:) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic; (M;) and he doubts respecting the authenticity of a verse in which it is mentioned, ascribed to 'Alee: (TA:) pl. qawaASiru: (K, art. knz; &c.:) the dim. is quwayoSir~apN and quwayoSirapN. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A woman, or wife; (IAar, K;) as also qaAruwrapN [q. v.]. (IAar, TA.)

A^aqoSuru *
More, and most, short: fem. quSoraY: (Mgh:) the pl. of A^aqoSaru is A^aqaASiru. (S, K.)

tiqoSaArN * (S, M, K) and tiqoSaArapN (S, K) A necklace, or collar, or the like, syn. qilaAdapN, (S, M, K,) resembling a mixonaqap: (S:) so called because it cleaves to the qaSarap [or base] of the neck: (M:) or a mixonaqap proportioned to the qaSarap [or base of the neck]: (A, TA:) pl. taqaASiyru. (S, K.)

raDiYa bimaqoSarK mina AlA^amori * , and minohu ↓ bimaqoSirK, He was content with less than he was seeking, of the thing. (TA.) And mim~aA kaAna yuHaAwilu ↓ raDiYa bimuqoSirK with kesr to the S, (S,) or bimaqoSarK minohu, (as in a copy of the M,) He was content with less than he was seeking. (S, M.) And raDiytu mino fulaAnK bimaqoSarK, and ↓ bimaqoSirK, I was content with an inferior thing from such a one. (M.) -A2- See also qaSorN.
maqoSirN * : see maqoSarN: -A2- and qaSorN.

jaA='a fulaAnN muqoSirFA *
Such a one came when the
afternoon, or evening, was almost drawing near to night. (TA.)
maqoSarapN * : see qaSorN.

miqoSarapN * (M, K) and ↓ qaSarapN (M, TA) The wooden implement of the qaS~aAr, (M, K,) with which he beats clothes: (M:) and the ↓ latter, a piece of wood, (M, K,) of any kind; or of the jujube-tree, specially. (TA.)

muqaS~irN * act. part. n. of 2, q. v. and see qaS~aArN. ― -b2- [Deficient in liberality or bounty:] one who makes a gift scanty, or mean. (TA.) A poet says
faqulotu lahu qado kunota fiyhaA muqaS~irFA
[And I said to him Thou hast been deficient in liberality with respect to them; app. meaning she-camels or the like;] i. e., thou hast not given of them nor given to drink from them [of their milk]. (M.)

maqoSuwrN * and maqoSuwrapN: see qaSiyrN, in five places. ― -b2- See also quSorapN. ― -b3- maqoSuwrapN An ample or a spacious [house or mansion such as is called a] dAr, which is defended by walls: (M, * K, * TA:) or it is less than a dAr; (M, K;) as also ↓ quSaArapN; and is not entered by any but the owner: (K:) such a part of a house is called the mqSwrp of a dAr, and the qSArp thereof: (Useyd, TA:) any apartment (naAHiyapN), by itself, of a dAr, when the latter is ample, or spacious, and defended by walls: (Lth, TA:) a [chamber such as is called a] Hujorap, of a house: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. maqaASiyru and maqaASiru. See an ex. voce muSomatN. (Lth, TA.) And AlmaqoSuwrapN, (Lth,) and maqoSuwrapu masojidK, (Mgh, Msb,) and maqoSuwrapu jAmiEK, (S,) The part which is the station of the Imám [or Khaleefeh] in a mosque: (Lth, Mgh:) so called because confined [by a railing or screen]: (S:) or, accord. to some, mqSwrp, thus applied, is changed from its original form, which is qaASirapN, an act. part. n.: (Msb:) [and, as used in the present day, that part of a mosque which is the principal place of prayer, when it is partitioned off from the rest of the building: and the railing, or screen, which surrounds the oblong monument of stone or brick or wood over a grave in a mosque; sometimes enclosing a kind of baldachin over the monument. maqoSuwrapN also signifies The chancel of a church: see ma*obaHN.] And maqoSuwrapN and ↓ qaSuwrapN A Hajalap [or kind of curtained canopy or baldachin, such as is prepared for a bride]. (Lh, M, K.) And the former word, A piece of ground which none but the owner thereof is allowed to tread. (TA.)
maqoSuwrapN * : see maqoSuwrN.
HadiyvN muqotaSarN * : see qaSiyrN.
quSoTaAsN * and qiSoTaAsN dial. forms of qusoTaAsN and qsoTaAsN. [q. v.] (K.)
See Supplement

1 qa`D~a * , (S, M, A, &c.,) aor. yaquD~u, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. qaD~N, (M, Msb,) He bored, or perforated, a pearl, (S, M, A, K,) or a piece of wood. (Msb.) qaD~a dur~apF is also used as signifying qaD~a EanohaA SadafahaA faA@sotaxorajahaA [app. meaning He broke through the shell of the pearl so as to disclose it, and extracted it.] (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (M, A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He broke a thing: (M:) or he broke a stone with the miqaD~, q. v.: (A:) or he broke, brayed, crushed, or broke in pieces by beating, a thing; syn. daq~; (K;) as also ↓ qaDoqaDa: (TA:) which latter also signifies he broke a thing in pieces [in any manner]. (M, TA.) You say also, qaD~a AlHaAy^iTa, (A,) or AljidaAra, (TA,) meaning He threw down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, demolished, or destroyed, with violence, the wall. (A, TA.) And ↓ AlA^asadu yuqaDoqiDu fariysatahu (S, A) The lion breaks the limbs and bones of his prey. (A.) And janobahu mino Sulobihi ↓ qaDoqaDotu I severed his side from his back-bone. (Sh.) ― -b3- [Hence,] qaD~a Ealayohimu Alxayola, (S, M, A [in the first and last qaDaDonaA]) aor. as above, (M, A,) and so the inf. n., (M,) (tropical:) He sent, or sent forth, (M, TA,) or impelled, (TA,) [or dispersed, (see 7,)] the horses, or horsemen, against them, or upon them. (M, TA.) ― -b4- qaD~a Alwatida, (JK, O, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He pulled out (qalaEa, in some copies of the K qaTaEa,) the wooden pin or peg or stake. (JK, O, K, TA.) -A2- qaD~a Als~awiyqa, (Zj, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Zj,) (tropical:) He put into the swyq [i. e. meal of parched barley, or gruel made thereof,] something dry, or hard, such as sugar, or qanod [i. e. sugar-candy]; (Zj, K;) as also ↓ A^aqaD~ahu: (A, Sgh, K:) and ↓ qaDoqaDa signifies (tropical:) he put much sugar into his swyq. (IAar.) -A3- qaDiDotu AlT~aEaAma, (TA,) and qaDiDotu minohu, (S, M, K,) [aor. A^aqaD~u,] inf. n. qaDaDN, (M, TA,) I found pebbles, (S, M, K,) or dust, (M, K,) between my teeth in eating the food. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- qaD~ AlT~aEaAmu, aor. yaqaD~u, (S, A, K,) inf. n. qaDaDN, (A, TA,) The food had in it pebbles, (S, * A, * K, * TA,) or dust, (K, * TA,) which got between the teeth of the eater: (S, * K, * TA:) from qaDaDN [q. v.]: (S:) the verb is like Ealima, in this sense as well as in that next preceding; intrans. as well as trans.: (TA:) and ↓ A^aqaD~a signifies [in like manner] it (food) had in it pebbles and dust. (TA.) And qaD~a All~aHomu, (IAar, M,) second pers. qaDiDota, [aor. yaqaD~u,] inf. n. qaDaDN, (M,) The flesh-meat had in it qaDaD [q. v.], which got between the teeth of its eater, like small pebbles: (IAar:) or fell upon pebbles, or dust, which one consequently found in the eating of it. (M.) And qaD~ati AlbaDoEapu biAlt~uraAbi The piece of flesh-meat had some dust upon it; as also ↓ A^aqaD~at. (M, K.) An Arab of the desert, describing the effect of rains, said, lawo A^aloqayota baDoEapF maA qaD~ato, i. e. [If thou wert to throw down a piece of flesh-meat,] it would not become dusty; meaning, by reason of the abundance of the herbage. (M.) You say also, qaD~a AlmakaAnu, aor. yaqaD~u, inf. n. qaDaDN, The place had in it, or upon it, qaDaD [or small pebbles, or dust]; as also ↓ A^aqaD~a; (M, K;) and ↓ AstqD~. (K.) And qaD~a AlfiraA$u, aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding instance, The bed became overspread with dust. (M.) And Ealayohi AlmaDojaEu ↓ A^aqaD~a (S, M, A, K *) The bed, or place where he lay upon his side, was, or became, rough to him, and dusty: (S, K: *) or had qaDaD, or small pebbles, upon it: (TA:) or was, or became, uneasy to him; as also qaD~a Elyh: (M, TA:) or both signify he did not sleep: or his sleep was uneasy. (TA.) And [hence] Ealayohi Alham~u ↓ A^aqaD~a (assumed tropical:) [Grief, or anxiety, disquieted him]. (A, TA.)

4 A^aqoDa3a see 1, in six places; from qaD~a Als~awiyqa to the end of the paragraph. -A2- AqD~ A@ll~`hu Ealayohi AlmaDojaEa God rendered the bed, or the place where he lay upon his side, rough to him, and dusty: thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (S, K. *) And AqD~ Al$~aYo'a He left the thing [consisting of, or overspread with,] small pebbles. (K, * TA.)
5 taqaD~aDa * and taqaD~aY : see 7.

8 AqtD~hA * (tropical:) He devirginated her; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely a girl, (S, A, Mgh,) or a woman; (M;) or either, i. e. before and after puberty; whereas AbtkrhA and AbtsrhA and AxtDrhA are only used as meaning before puberty: (Msb:) and AftD~hA, with f, signifies the same as AqtD~hA. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AqtD~ AlA_idaAwapa (assumed tropical:) He opened the head [or mouth] of the AdAwp [or water-skin]. (TA.)

10 A_isotaqoDa3a see 1, near the end. -A2- AstqD~ maDojaEahu He found his bed, or the place where he lay upon his side, to be rough. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And hence,] AstqD~ Alham~a (assumed tropical:) [He found grief, or anxiety, to be disquieting to him]. (A, TA.)
R. Q. 1 qaDoqaDa * : see 1, first half, in four places: and see qaDoqaDapN, below.

R. Q. 2 taqaDoqaDa *
It broke, or became broken, into pieces: (M:) it separated, or dispersed; or became separated, or dispersed; (K, TA;) said of a company of men, in a trad. (TA.)

qaD~N * A place in which are qaDaD, (M, K,) meaning small pebbles, or dust; (M;) as also ↓ qaDiDN. (M, K.) And A^aroDN qaD~apN, (M,) or ↓ qaD~apN [alone, as though a subst.], (K,) and ↓ qiD~apN, (S, K,) Land in which are pebbles: (S, M, K:) and land abounding with stones: (M:) or low, or depressed, land, the ground of which is sand, and by the side of which is plain, or hard, and elevated land: (Lth in explanation of the last of these words, and K:) pl. of the last, qiDaDN. (Lth.) Also, Food in which are pebbles and dust: (TA:) and flesh-meat that has fallen upon pebbles, or dust, (M,) or upon stones, or pebbles, (TA,) which one consequently finds in eating it: (M, TA:) and anything having dust in it, or upon it; as food, or a garment, &c.: (M, TA:) and [in like manner] ↓ qaDiDN, (S,) or ↓ qaDaDN, (K,) but when applied to a place, the author of the K writes it qaDiDN, (TA,) food containing pebbles, (S, K,) or dust, (K,) getting between the teeth of the eater. (S, K.) -A2- See also qaDaDN, in two places.

qaD~apN * : see qiD~apN, in four places. -A2- Also, of a star, or an asterism, (tropical:) i. q. nawo'N [here signifying The dawn-setting thereof; for it is] from A_inoqaD~a said of a star, or asterism. (TA.) So in the saying (TA) A^atayonaA Einoda qaD~api Aln~ajomi (tropical:) [We came at the dawnsetting of the asterism, meaning the Pleiades]. (A, * TA.) And muTironaA biqaD~api AlA^asadi (tropical:) [We were rained upon, or we had rain at, lit. by means of, the dawn-setting of the Lion]. (A, TA.) -A3- See also qaDaDN, in three places. -A4- And see qaD~N.

qiD~apN * , (M, K,) or ↓ qaD~apN, (A,) (tropical:) [Devirgination]; a subst. from A_iqotaD~ in the former of the two senses assigned to it above. (M, K.) You say, layolapa EurosihaA ↓ kaAna *`lika Einoda qaD~atihaA (tropical:) [That was on the occasion of her devirgination, on the night of her being conducted to her husband]. (A, TA.) -A2- Also the former, (S, M, Msb,) or ↓ latter, (A, Mgh,) or both, (K,) (tropical:) The virginity, or maidenhead, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of a girl, (S, Mgh, K,) or of a woman, (M,) or of both. (Msb.) You say, A^axa*a qiD~atahaA, (Lh, M,) and ↓ *ahaba biqaD~atihaA, (A, Mgh,) (tropical:) He took her virginity. (Lh, M, Mgh.) -A3- See also qaDaDN. -A4- And see qaD~u.

qaDaDN *
A thing broken, brayed, crushed, or broken in pieces by beating: (TA:) pebbles broken in pieces and crushed: (TA:) or, as also ↓ qaD~apN, pebbles broken into small pieces: (K:) or small pebbles broken in pieces: (A:) or, accord. to some, the former is pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of the latter: (TA:) or both signify pebbles, and dust: (TA:) or the former signifies small pebbles; (S, M;) as also ↓ qiD~apN, (S, K,) and ↓ qaD~apN, (K,) and ↓ qaDiyDN, accord. to IAar, as is said by IAth and Sgh and the author of the L, not ↓ qaD~N, as is said in the K, for this signifies large pebbles, accord. to IAar, as is said by the three authors mentioned above as citing him, and the author of the K has erred in assigning this last meaning to ↓ qaDiyDN: (TA:) or ↓ qaD~N signifies pebbles; and ↓ qaDiyDN is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] thereof: (AHeyth, L:) and qaDaDN also signifies dust that overspreads a bed. (M, K.) You say, A_it~aqi AlqaDaDa fiY TaEaAmika, and ↓ AlqaD~apa, Beware thou of the pebbles and dust in thy food. (TA.) -A2- See also qaD~N.
qaDiDN * : see qaD~N, in two places.
qaDiyDN * : see qaDaDN, in three places. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) Small pieces of food; as being likened to small pebbles. (Kt.)
qaDoqaDapN * The sound of the breaking of bones. (S.) ― -b2- [See also R. Q. 1., of which it is the inf. n.]

miqaD~N *
An instrument with which stones are broken, (JK, A, TA,) resembling a qaduwm, q. v. (JK.)

1 qaDiy^a Als~iqaA='u * , (K,) or qaDiy^ati Alqirobapu, aor.
qaDaAa , inf. n. qaDaA^N, (AZ, S, O, K,) The water-skin became rotten, and fell in pieces, (AZ, S, O, K, TA,) as is the case when it has been folded while damp. (TA.) You say ↓ siqaA='N qaDiy^N (TA) and ↓ qirobapN qaDiy^apN. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b2- And qaDiy^a said of a garment, (S, O, TA,) or of a rope, (K, TA,) It became old and worn out, and dissundered, (K, TA,) and rotten, (S, * O, * TA,) when said of a garment, (S, O,) from being long moist and folded: (S, O, TA:) or, said of a rope, it broke in pieces in consequence of its having been long buried in the earth. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And qaDiy^ati AlEayonu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) The eye became red, and flaccid in its inner angle, and in an unsound, or a corrupt, state, (K, TA,) ulcerated, or sore. (TA.) You say ↓ EayonN qaDiy^apN. (TA.) And fiY ↓ Eayonihi quDoA^apN (S, O, TA) meaning In his eye is unsoundness, or corruptness [&c.]. (S, O.) ― -b4- And qaDiy^a Hasabuhu, inf. n. qaDaA^N (K, TA) and qaDaA^apN or qaDaA='apN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) in the L the latter of these, and quDuwo'N also, (TA,) His Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour] were unsound, (K, TA,) and faulty. (TA.) -A2- qaDiy^a, (El-Umawee, S, O, K,) aor.
qaDaAa , inf. n. qaDo'N, (El-Umawee, S, O, [and the same is indicated in the K,]) He ate (El-Umawee, S, O, K) a thing; said of a man. (El-Umawee, S, O.)

4 AqDA^hu *
He gave him to eat; (S, O, K;) namely, a man: (S, O:) some say that it is with f: (TA in this art.:) but Sh says that it is with q, after mentioning AfDA=h as transmitted from A 'Obeyd from As (TA in art. fDA.)

5 taqaD~aw^uwA minohu A^ano yuzaw~ijuwhu *
They accounted his grounds of pretension to respect or honour [too] low [for them to marry him], or [too] mean, (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA,) and [too] faulty. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) ― -b2- See also tafas~aA^a.
qaDiy^N * part. n. of qaDiy^a; and its fem, with p: see 1, in three places.
qaDoA^apN * : see the following paragraph.

fiY Eayonihi quDoA^apN * : see 1. ― -b2- One says also, maA Ealayoka fiY h`*aA AlA^amori quDoA^apN i. e. [There is not] any disgrace [to be imputed to thee in, or in respect of, this affair]. (S, O.) And fiY Hasabihi quDoA^apN (S, O, K) and ↓ qaDoA^apN (K) [In his grounds of pretension to respect or honour is] faultiness, (S, O, K,) and unsoundness. (K.) And nakaHa fiY quDoA^apK (S, O, TA) He married in a disparaging manner. (TA.)

1 qaDabahu * , (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
qaDiba , (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. qaDobN, (M, Mgh, O, Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AqtDbhu; (M, Msb, K;) and ↓ qD~bhu; (M, K;) [or this last is used in an intensive sense, or in relation to a number of objects:] you say, qaDaba AlguSona [He cut off the branch]; and guSonFA mino $ajarapK ↓ AqtDb [He cut off a branch from a tree]; and fuDuwla A^agoSaAni Al$~ajari ↓ qD~b [He cut off the redundant portions of the branches of the trees], inf. n. taqoDiybN. (A.) -A2- See also 8, in
two places. -A3- And qDabahu, (S, O, K, JM,) aor. in this case
qaDuba , (JM,) inf. n. qaDobN, (S, TA,) He struck him, or beat him, (i. e. a man, K,) with a qDyb, (S, O, K, JM,) i. e. a rod, or stick, or the like. (TA.)

2 qaD~aba see the preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] qD~b Alkaroma, (S, M,) inf. n. taqoDiybN, (S,) He cut (S, M) the branches, (S,) or some of the branches, (M,) of the grape-vine, [i. e. he pruned it,] in the days of the rabiyE [or spring]. (S, M.) -A2- And qD~bt Al$~amosu, (M, O, K,) inf. n. as above; (O, K;) The sun extended its rays, or beams, (M, O, K,) like quDobaAn [or rods]; (M;) as also ↓ tqD~bt: (M, O, K:) used by a rájiz in describing the sun when it had risen appearing like a shield, without rays, or beams. (IAar, M.)

4 AqDbt AlA^aroDu * (M, K, * TA) The land produced, (M, TA,) or produced abundantly, (K, [but SM states that he had not found it thus expl. in any lexicon except the K,]) the plant called qaDob which is eaten when freshly cut. (M, K, TA.)
5 taqaD~aba see 7: ― -b2- and see also 2.

7 AnqDb *
It was, or became, cut, or cut off; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) and so ↓ tqD~b [but app. in an intensive sense or said of a number of things]. (M, K.) ― -b2- And [hence] (tropical:) He became cut off, or separated, from his companions. (A.) ― -b3- And, said of a star, (tropical:) It darted down (TA) from its place. (S, A, O.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (S, A, O,) describing a wild bull [i. e. a bovine antelope], (O,)
kaA^an~ahu kawokabN fiY A_ivori EiforiyapK
↓ musaw~amN fiY sawaAdi All~ayoli munoqaDibu
[As though he were a star launched forth in the darkness of night, darting down after an evil demon]. (S, A, O.)

8 A_iqotaDaba see 1, in two places. You say, AiqotaDabotuhu, meaning I cut it off from the thing. (S, O.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, kaAna yuHad~ivunaA fulaAnN fajaA='a zayodN faA@qotaDaba Hadiyvahu, meaning AiqotaTaEahu and AinotazaEahu [i. e. Such a one was talking to us, and Zeyd came, and broke off his talk, and turned it to what was wholly different in subject, or to what had but little connection with the subject of the former discourse: an ex. of a common conventional usage of AqtDb, mentioned in rhetorical treatises &c.; as when a poet breaks off his nasiyb to enter upon the main subject of his ode]. (A.) ― -b3- And AqtDb (tropical:) He extemporized, or uttered without having prepared it, (S, M, A, O,) speech, (S, A, O,) or a narrative, and poetry, or verses. (M.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He rode (S, A, K) a beast, (S,) or a she-camel, (A,) before it, or she, was trained, or broken-in; (S, A, K;) and (S, K) so ↓ qaDaba, (S, O, K,) aor. qaDaba. (K.) And (TA) (assumed tropical:) He took from the camels, and trained, one in an untrained state; (M, K;) as also ↓ AqtDbhu. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He rode a young camel for a night, before it was trained. (TA.) ― -b5- And qaDobN (assumed tropical:) He tasked him to do a deed, or work, before he was able to do it well. (M.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) He slaughtered him, namely, a camel, in a state of freedom from disease and in a fat and youthful condition. (A.)

qaDobapN *
Such as are cut, and eaten in their fresh state, of plants, (M, Msb, K,) of any kind; as is said in the Bári'; (Msb;) a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is ↓ qaDobapN: (K:) or it signifies, (S, O, Msb,) or signifies also, (K,) [a species of trefoil, or clover; i. e.] i. q. raTobapN, (S, O, Msb,) which is the same as fiSofiSap, (Msb,) or qat~N, [which is also the same,] (K,) the name by which the people of Mekkeh call qat~, (Fr, TA,) and (K) called in Pers. (S, O) A_isofisot, (S, Mgh, K,) or A_isobisot; (O;) as also ↓ qaDobapN; (S;) or this is the sing. [or rather n. un.] of qaDobN, which signifies faSaAfiSu [pl. of fiSofiSapN]; (M;) called qaDobN because it is cut. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And Any tree of which the branches grow long and lank: (K, * TA:) basaTato in the K is a mistranscription for sabiTato. (TA.) ― -b3- And Certain trees from which bows are made; (En-Nadr, O, K;) said to be of the kind called naboEN. (O.) AHn says that qDb [accord. to the L and TA app. qaDobN, but accord. to a copy of the M ↓ qaDabN, which I think a mistranscription,] is the name of Certain trees of the plains, or soft tracts, growing among collections of [other] trees; having leaves like those of the pear-tree, except that they are thinner, and more soft; and as trees [in general] resembling pear-trees: the camels feed upon its leaves and the extremities of its branches; but when the camel has become satiated therewith, he forsakes it for a time, for it sets his teeth on edge, and irritates his chest, and occasions him cough. (M, L, TA.) And ↓ qaDobapN [as n. un. of qaDobN] signifies A tree from which arrows are made: one says sahomu qaDobK [An arrow made from the species of tree called qDb]; like as one says sahomu naboEK &c. (ISh, TA. [See also qaDobapN below.]) ― -b4- It is also a name applied to Portions that one has cut from branches to make thereof arrows or bows. (O, K. *) ― -b5- See also qaDiybN.
qaDabN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

qaDobapN * : see qaDobN, in three places. ― -b2- Also i. q. qaDiybN (K, TA) as meaning The bow thus called: (TA:) see the latter word: or an arrow-shaft from a tree of the species called naboE, whereof (minohu [for which the CK has fyhi]) an arrow [in the complete state] is made: pl. qaDabaAtu. (M, K. [In the TA, the pl. is said to be qaDobaAtN, with fet-h and sukoon; but this, as pl. of a subst. of the class of qaboDapN, is anomalous.])

qiDobapN *
A portion of a herd of camels; and of a flock, or herd, of sheep or goats. (O, K.) -A2- And Such as is slender, and light, or active; as an epithet applied to a she-camel, and in like manner to a man. (O, K. *)

qaDiybN * , as an epithet applied to a branch, i. q. maqoDuwbN [i. e. Cut off]. (M voce fananN, and Msb. *) ― -b2- And [as a subst., A rod, stick, wand, branch, twig, switch, shoot, or stalk;] a guSon [i. e. branch from the stem or from another branch, of a tree], (S, M, O, Msb, K,) [and particularly] that is cut off: (M, Msb:) pl. quDobaAnN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and qiDobaAnN (M, O, Msb, K, but this is less approved, TA) and quDubN, and ↓ qaDobN is a quasi-pl. n. (M, TA.) [Hence] one says, malaka Alburodapa waAlqaDiyba (tropical:) [lit. He became possessor of the burdeh and the rod], meaning Ausotuxolifa [i. e. he became a successor]. (A.) ― -b3- And A bow made of a rod, or branch, (AHn, M, K) in its complete state: (AHn, M:) or one made of a rod, or branch, not split: (M, K:) also called ↓ qaDobapN. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The quill of a feather. (TA voce baTonN.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) The virga, nervus, or yard, (AHát, T, K, TA,) of a bull, (AHát, TA,) or of a man, and of an animal other than man, (T, TA,) or of an ass, &c. (S, * TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A slender arrow: pl. quDubN. (As, TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) A slender sword; contr. of SafiyHapN: pl. qawaADibu and quDubN: (IAth, TA:) or (tropical:) slender as an epithet applied to a sword; (M, A, K; *) likened to the qaDiyb of the tree. (A.) ― -b8- See also qaADibN. -A2- Also (tropical:) A she-camel that has not been trained, or broken-in: (S, K:) or that has been ridden (A, M) before she has been trained, (A,) or before she has been rendered gentle: (M:) or that has not acquired expertness in being trained: and applied also to the male. (M.)

qaDaAbapu $ajarK * , (S, M, * A, O,) and karomK, (A,) What falls in consecutive portions, of the extremities of the branches of trees, when they are lopped, or pruned, (S, M, * A, * O,) and of a grape-vine: (A:) or you say quDaAbapu $aYo'K, meaning what is [or are] cut off, of a thing. (M, K.)
qaD~aAbN * : see qaADibN. ― -b2- Also One whose habitual work or occupation is that of cutting [app. in a general sense]. (Ham p. 490.)

quD~aAbN *
A certain plant. (Kr, M.)

qaD~aAbapN * : see qaADibN. ― -b2- One says also, maA fiY famiY qaD~aAbapN There is not in my mouth a tooth that will cut a thing so as to separate one half of it from the other half. (TA.) ― -b3- And rajulN qaD~aAbapN (tropical:) A man who often exercises the faculty of deciding affairs; (qaT~aAEN liloA^amuwri; S, M, A, K;) possessing ability to execute, or perform, them. (S, A.)

qaADibN * and ↓ qaDiybN (S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ qaD~aAbN and ↓ qaD~aAbapN and ↓ miqoDabN, (M, K,) as epithets applied to a sword, Very sharp, or sharply-cutting: (S, M, Msb, K:) or the first signifies [simply] cutting, or sharp: (O:) [and the last but one is doubly intensive, signifying very sharply-cutting:] the pl. (of the first, O) is qawaADibu (S, O) and [of the second] quDubN. (S.)
miqoDabN * and ↓ miqoDaAbN i. q. minojalN [as meaning A reaping-hook and also a pruning-hook]. (O, K.) ― -b2- For the former, see also qaADibN.

maqoDabapN *
A place in which grows [the species of trefoil, or clover, called] qaDob, (T, S, M, * O, * K, *) i. e. (S, K) raTobap, which is called in Pers. (S) A_isofisot: (S, K; and the like is said in the M:) pl. maqaADibu, and by poetic license maqaADiybu. (O.) And A place in which grow the trees called qaDob from which bows are made. (K.)

miqoDaAbN * One whose craft, or occupation, is that of cutting [app. herbage &c.]. (Ham p. 490.) ― -b2- See also miqoDabN. -A2- And Land that produces (M, K) abundantly (K) the herbage called qaDob which is eaten when freshly cut, (M, * K, TA,) i. e. [the species of trefoil, or clover, called] fiSofiSap. (TA.)
maqoDuwbN * [pass. part. n. of 1, q. v.; and see qaDiybN].

AlmuqotaDabu *
A certain metre of verse, (M, O,) the thirteenth, (O,) consisting of faAEilaAtu mufotaEiluno, (M, O,) twice; (M;) originally mafoEuwlaAtu musotafoEiluno: so called as though it were the munosariH with a foot, namely, mstfEln, cut off. (O.) ― -b2- muqotaDabN applied to verse, or poetry, and a writing, means (tropical:) Extemporized. (S, O.) ― -b3- And muqotaDabN fiY EamalK means (tropical:) Untrained in a work; (A;) or tasked to do it before he can do it well. (IDrd, S.)
munoqaDibN * : see its verb, 7.
See Supplement

1 qaT~ahu * , aor.
qaTu3a , (S, M,) inf. n. qaT~N, (M, K,) He cut it, in a general sense: (M, K:) or he cut it, meaning a hard thing, such as a Huq~p [or box], (Lth, M, K,) and the like, (M,) in a good form, or fashion, like as a man cuts a reed upon a bone; (Lth;) and ↓ taqoTiyTN, also, [inf. n. of qT~Thu,] signifies the cutting a Huq~ap, (K, TA,) and making it even: (TA:) or qaT~ahu signifies he cut it breadthwise, across, or crosswise; (S, M, O, K;) he so separated it; (Kh, S;) opposed to qad~ahu, (S, TA,) which signifies he cut it in halves lengthwise, like as one cuts a strap or thong: (TA:) and ↓ AqtT~hu signifies the same. (M, K. *) You say, qaT~a Alqalama, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) He nibbed the reed for writing; cut off its head breadthwise, across, or crosswise. (S, * Msb.) And qaT~a AlbayoTaAru HaAfira Ald~aAb~api The farrier pared, and made even, the hoof of the beast of carriage. (TA.) -A2- qaTTa Al$~aEaru, (S, M, K,) with the reduplication made manifest, (S, M,) and qaT~a, aor. yaqaT~u, (M, Msb, K,) and, of the latter, yaquT~u also, [contr. to the general rule,] (Msb,) inf. n., of the former, qaT~N, (M, TA,) which is extr., (M,) and of the latter, (M, TA,) qaTaTN and qaTaATapN, (M, K,) The hair was, or became, [frizzled, or] very crisp, very curly, or much twisted, and contracted: (S, * Msb:) or like that of the zanojiY~: (Msb:) or crisp, curly, or twisted, and contracted, and short. (M, K.) -A3- qaT~a Als~iEoru, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaqiT~u, (S, K,) with kesr, (S, TA,) or yaquT~u, (M, Msb,) the verb being co-ordinate to qatala, [contr. to the general rule,] (Msb) inf. n. qaT~N (S, M, Msb, K) and quTuwTN; (M, K;) as also quT~a, with damm; (Fr, K;) The price was, or became, dear, (S, M, Msb, K,) and high: (Msb:) Sh thought this explanation to be wrong, and the meaning to be the price flagged; but Az says, that in this he was mistaken. (TA.) ― -b2- qaT~a A@ll~`hu Als~iEora God made the price to be, or become, dear. (Fr. TA.)
2 qaT~a3a see 1, first sentence.
7 AnqT~ * quasi-pass. of qaT~ahu as explained in the first sentence of this art.; It was, or became, cut; &c.; and so ↓ AqtT~. (M, TA.)
8 A_iqotaTa3a see 1, first sentence: and see also 7.

R. Q. 1 qaToqaTati Als~amaA='u *
The sky let fall rain, (AZ, S, M,) or hail, (M,) such as is termed qiToqiTN: (AZ, S, M:) or the sky rained. (K.)

qaTo * , signifying Hasobu, [explained in exs. here following,] (Lth, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) i. e., (S,) denoting the being satisfied, or content, (Sb, S, M, Msb,) with a thing, (Msb,) is thus written, with fet-h to the q, and with the T quiescent, (Sb, S, M, Msb, * Mughnee,) like Eano; (K;) and also, (Sb, M, K,) sometimes, (Sb, M,) ↓ qaTK, (Sb, M, K,) with tenween, mejroor; (K;) and ↓ qaTiY [distinguished from qaTiY in the next sentence]; (Sb, M, K;) but the term “ mejroor ” is here used contr. to the rules of grammar, as it denotes that qT is decl., whereas it is not. (MF.) It is used as a prefixed noun: you say, qaToka h`*aA Al$~aYo'u Thy sufficiency [meaning sufficient for thee] is this thing; syn. Hasobuka; (Lth, S, Mughnee; *) and like it is qado: (Lth:) and you also say, using it as a prefixed n., qaToniY My sufficiency; syn. HasobiY; (Lth, S, * Mughnee;) like qadoniY; introducing n, (Lth, S, TA,) as in Ean~iY and min~iY and ladun~iY, contr. to rule, for the reason which has been explained in treating of qado, (S, TA,) to preserve the original quiescence of the T; (Mughnee;) and qaTiY; (S, Msb, Mughnee;) and ↓ qaTi; (S;) and ↓ qaTaATi, (S, M, K,) like qaTaAmi, (S, K,) indecl.; (M;) as signifying HasobiY: (S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K:) and, as is said in the Moo'ab, qaTo Eabodi All~`hi dirohamN The sufficiency of 'Abd-Allah is a dirhem; [and the like is said by Lth and in the Mughnee;] pausing upon the T, and making qT to govern a gen. case [as it does virtually in the preceding instances]; and the Basrees say, that this is the right mode, as meaning the like of Hasobu zayodK dirohamN and kafoYa zayodK dirohamN: (K:) or some say qaTo, with jezm; and some say ↓ qaTu, making it inded. with damm for its termination; each governing what follows it in the gen. case. (M.) ― -b2- It is also a verbal noun, signifying yakofiY [It suffices, or will suffice; or it is, or will be, sufficient]; and when this is the case, you say, qaToniY, (Mughnee, K,) like as you say, yakofiyniY [It suffices me, or will suffice me]; (Mughnee;) or kafaAniY [which means, emphatically, it suffices me], accord. to the Koofees; (Lth;) which is also allowable when qaTo is equivalent to Hasobu [as we have observed above]: (Mughnee:) and you say also, qaToka, meaning kafaAka [emphatically It suffices thee]: and qaTiY, meaning kafaAniY [emphatically It suffices me]: (K:) so in the copies of the K; [in the CK, erroneously, qaT~aniY;] but [it seems that it should be qaToniY; for] it is said in the Mughnee and its Expositions, that in this last case the addition of the n is indispensable: (MF:) and some say, qaTo Eaboda All~`hi dirohamN [A dirhem suffices, or will suffice, 'Abd-Allah (in the CK, erroneously, qaT~u)]; making it to govern the accus. case [as it does virtually in preceding instances]: and some add n, saying, Eaboda All~`hi dirohamN ↓ qaTonu [meaning the same]: (Lth, K:) [hence,] some say, that [qaTon in] qaToniY is a word originally thus formed without any augmentation, like [Hasob in] HasobiY; (M;) [but J says,] if the n in qaToniY belonged to the root of the word, they had said qaTonuka, which is not known. (S.) ― -b3- It is also syn. with Hasobu in the phrase maA raA^ayotuhu A_il~aA mar~apF waAHidapF faqaTN [I have not seen him, or it, save once, and that was a thing sufficient or that was enough]: (S, Msb: *) or, as is said in the Mutowwel, qaTo in faqaTo is a verbal noun, meaning abstain thou [from further questioning, or the like], as though it were the complement of a condition suppressed [such as “ the case being so ”]: or, as is said in the Mesáïl of Ibn-Es-Seed, the f is properly prefixed because the meaning is and I was satisfied, or content, therewith; so that the f is a conjunction: (from a marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee:) [it therefore virtually signifies and no more; or only; and thus it may often be rendered: and this explains what here follows:] when qaT is used to denote paucity, (M, K,) which is said by El-Hareeree, in the Durrah, to be only in negative phrases, (MF,) it is [written qaTo,] with jezm, (M, K,) and without teshdeed: (M:) you say, maA Einodaka A_il~aA h`*aA qaTo [which may be rendered Thou hast not save this only]: but when it is followed by a conjunctive A, it is with kesr; [as in the saying,] maA Ealimotu A_il~aA h`*aA qaTi Alyawoma [virtually mean-
ing I knew not, or, emphatically, know not, save this only, to-day]: (K:) and also, (K,) when thus using it, (M,) you say, maA lahu A_il~aA Ea$arapN qaTo yaAfataY [likewise virtually meaning He has not save ten only, O young man], without teshdeed, and with jezm; and ↓ qaT~i, with teshdeed and khafd; (Lh, M, K;) the kesreh of the latter, in a case of this kind, being to distinguish the qaT~ which denotes [paucity of] number from qaT~u, which denotes time. (Lth.) -A2- See also qaT~u, first sentence.
quTo * : see qaT~u.
qaTu * : see qaTo: -A2- and see also qaT~u.
qaTi * : see qaTo.
quTu * : see qaT~u.
qaTK * : see qaTo.
qaT~a * : see qaT~u.

qaT~u * is an adv. noun, (Mughnee,) [generally] denoting time, (S, M, Mughnee,) or past time, (Msb, K,) used to include all past time; (Lth, Mughnee;) as also ↓ quT~u, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) the former vowel being assimilated to the latter; (S, Mughnee;) and ↓ qaTu, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) and ↓ quTu; (S, Mughnee, * K;) and some say ↓ qaTo, (S, Mughnee,) whence qaTu is formed, by making its termination similar to that of the primary form qaT~u, to show its origin; (S, M;) or this would be better than qaTu; (M;) and ↓ quTo, (S, M, Mughnee, *) like mu*o, which is rare: (S, M:) of all these, the first is the most chaste: (Mughnee:) when time is meant by it, it is always with refa, without tenween: (K:) or one says also ↓ qaT~i, (M, Mughnee, K,) with kesr and teshdeed to the T, (M, K,) accord. to IAar; (M;) and ↓ qaT~a, with fet-h and teshdeed to the T; (M, * K;) as well as with damm to the T without teshdeed. (K [in some copies of which is here added, “ and with refa to the T; ” to which is further added in the CK, “ without teshdeed: ” but I find two copies without any addition of this redundant kind: for by “ refa ” is here meant, as in a former instance, “ damm; ” though improperly, as the word is indecl.]) You say, maA raA^ayotuhu qaT~u &c. [I have not seen him, or it, ever, or hitherto]; (S, M, K;) and maA faEalotuhu qaT~a [I have not done it ever, or hitherto]; (Msb, Mughnee;) i. e., in the time that is past; (Msb, K;) or in what has been cut off of my life; (Mughnee, K;) its derivation being from qaTaTotu meaning “ I cut; ” for the past is cut off from the present and the future; and it is indecl. because it implies the meaning of mu*o and A_ilaY; its meaning being mu*o A^ano xuliqotu A_ilaY AlA=na [since my being created until now]; and with a vowel for its termination to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; (Mughnee;) and it is with refa [meaning damm for its termination] because it is like qabolu and baEodu: (Lth:) accord. to Ks, (S,) qaT~u is a contraction of qaTaTu: (S, M:) Sb says, that it denotes AlA_inotihaA='; [app. meaning that it signifies abstain thou from further questioning, or the like; for El-Hareeree says, in the Durrah, that qaT~u and qaTo both signify the same as Hasobu;] and that it is indecl., with damm for its termination, like Hasobu. (M.) You say also, maA faEalotu h`*aA qaTo walaA qaT~u [app. meaning I have not done this alone, nor ever]: (K, TA: [in the CK qaT~u wlA quTu, but]) the former qT is with jezm to the T, and the latter is with teshdeed and damm to the T. (TA.) And yaA fataY ↓ maA zaAla EalaY h`*aA mu*o quT~a [He, or it, has not ceased to be after this manner during all past time, O young man]; with damm to the q, and with teshdeed. (Lh, M.) It is used only in negative phrases relating to past time; the saying of the vulgar laA A^afoEaluhu qaT~u [meaning I will not do it ever] being incorrect; (Mughnee, K; [in the CK qaTu]) for with respect to the future you say EawoDu (TA) [or A^abadFA]: or it is mostly so used, accord. to Ibn-Málik: (MF:) but it occurs after an affirmative phrase in places in El-Bukháree, (K,) in his Saheeh; (TA;) for ex., A^aTowalu SalaApK Sal~ayotuhaA qaT~u [The longest prayer which I have prayed ever]: and in the Sunan of Aboo-Dawood; tawaD~aA^a valaAvFA qaT~u [He performed the wuDuwo' three times ever]: and Ibn-Málik asserts it to be right, and says that it is one of the things which have been unperceived by many of the grammarians: (K:) El-Karmánee, however, interprets these instances as though they were negative. (TA.)
qaT~i * : see qaTo, near the end of the paragraph: -A2- and see also qaT~u, in the first sentence.
quT~u * : see qaT~u, in two places.

$aEarN qaT~N * , and ↓ qaTaTN, (M, Msb, K,) and ↓ qaTiTN, (TA,) Crisp, curly, or twisted and contracted, and short, hair: (M, K:) or hair that is very crisp, very curly, or much twisted and contracted: or, accord. to the T, ↓ qaTaTN means hair of the zanojiY~: (Msb:) or you say, ↓ jaEodN qaTaTN, meaning very crisp, very curly, or much twisted and contracted. (S.) ― -b2- rajulN qaT~N, and ↓ qaTaTN, (Msb,) or rajulN qaT~u Al$~aEari, and ↓ qaTaTu Al$~aEari, (S, M, K,) A man whose hair is crisp, curly, or twisted and contracted, and short: (M, K:) or whose hair is very crisp, very curly, or much twisted and contracted; (S, * Msb;) as also ↓ qiTaATN: (K: accord. to some copies; but accord. to other copies, as a pl. in this sense: [the reading of the latter is more probably correct, and is that of the TA:]) or beautifully crisp or curly or twisted and contracted: (TA:) the pl. [of qaT~N] is A^aqoTaATN [a pl. of pauc.] and qaT~uwna and qiTaATN; and [of ↓ qaTaTN] qaTaTuwna: (M, K:) the epithet applied to a woman is qaT~apN, and ↓ qaTaTN without p. (M, Msb.) -A2- See also ↓ qaAT~N.

qiT~N *
A slice cut off ($aqiyqapN), of a melon or other thing. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A portion, share, or lot, (M, A, Msb, K,) of gifts, (A, TA,) &c. (TA.) Hence the saying in the Kur, [xxxviii. 15,] rab~anaA Eaj~ilo lanaA qiT~anaA qabola yawomi AlHisaAbi (tropical:) [O our Lord, hasten to us our portion before the day of reckoning]: accord. to some, our portion of punishment: but accord. to Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, it means, of Paradise. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A writing; (Fr, S, Msb;) [such as that of a man's works;] and hence, accord. to Fr, the words of the Kur cited above; those words being said in derision: (TA:) or a writing of reckoning: (M, K:) or a written obligation: (M:) or it signifies also a written obligation binding one to give a gift or present; (S, K, TA;) and hence the saying in the Kur cited above: (S:) pl. quTuwTN: (S, M, Msb, K:) which Az explains as meaning gifts, and stipends; so called because they were issued written in the form of notes and statements of obligation upon cut pieces of paper or the like. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) An hour, or a portion, (saAEap,) of the night. (M, K.) You say maDaY qiT~N mina All~ayoli (assumed tropical:) [An hour, or a portion, of the night passed]. (Th, M.) -A2- A male cat: (S, M, Msb, K:) the female is called qiT~apN: (Lth, S, M, Msb:) Kr disallowed this latter; and IDrd says, I do not think it to be genuine Arabic; (M;) but to this it is objected that it occurs in traditions: (MF:) the pl. is qiTaATN (S, M, Msb, K) and qiTaTapN, (M, K,) or qiTaTN. (Msb.)
qaTaTN * : see qaT~N, throughout.
qaTiTN * : see qaT~N.
qiT~apN * [A mode, or manner, of cutting a thing, such as the extremity of the nib of a writingreed]: see an ex. voce sin~N (near the end of the paragraph).
qaTonu * : see qaTo.
qaTiY * : see qaTo.
qaTaATi * : see qaTo.
qiTaATN * : see qaT~N.

qaT~aATN *
A xar~aAT [q. v.] who makes [the small boxes of wood or the like called] Huqaq [pl. of Huq~ap]. (S, O, K.) [See 1, first sentence.]

qiToqiTN *
Small rain; (M, K;) resembling $a*or [q. v.]: (M:) or the smallest of rain; the next above which is termed ra*aAdN; the next above this, Ta$~N; [but see this last term;] the next above this, bago$N; and the next above this, gaboyapN: (AZ, S:) or rain falling continuously, in large drops: (Lth, K:) or hail: (K:) or small hail, (M, O, K,) which is imagined to be hail or rain. (O.)

sEorN qaAT~N *
A dear price; as also ↓ maqoTuwTN, (M, K,) and ↓ qaT~N, (K,) and ↓ qaATiTN. (IAar, K.)
You say, waradonaA A^aroDFA qaAT~FA siEoruhaA We arrived at a land of dear prices. (S, TA.)
qaATiTN * : see qaAT~N.

maqaT~N * [in the CK erroneously miqaT~] The place of ending of the extremities of the ribs of a horse: (M, K:) or the extremity of the rib, projecting over the belly: (K in art. $rsf:) or the place of ending of the ribs of a horse: (TA:) maqaAT~u [is the pl., signifying, as explained in the S, in art. $rsf, the extremities of the ribs, projecting over the belly: or it] signifies the two extremities of the belly of a horse, whereof one is at the sternum (AlqaS~), and the other at the pubes. (En-Nadr.)

miqaT~apN * The thing upon which the reed for writing is nibbed; (S;) [generally made of bone or ivory;] a small bone upon which the writer nibs his reeds for writing; (K;) a small bone which is found with the sellers of paper, upon which they cut the extremities of the reeds for writing. (Lth.)
maqoTuwTN * : see qaAT~.

samaA='N muqaToqiTapN *
A sky letting fall rain such as is called qiToqiTN. (AZ, S.)

1 qaTaba * , (K, TA,) aor.
qaTiba , inf. n. qaTobN, (TA,) He collected a thing, brought it, gathered it, or drew it, together: (K, TA:) this is the primary signification. (O.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, qaTaba AlHimaAru EaAnatahu i. e. (tropical:) [The wild ass] collected [his herd of wild she-asses]. (A: there distinguished as tropical.) ― -b3- And qaTaba Alqawomu, [A^anofusahumo being app. understood,] and ↓ AqTb, (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, assembled themselves together, or congregated, (O, K, TA,) and were guests, and mixed together. (TA.) ― -b4- And qaTaba, (A, K,) aor.
qaTiba , inf. n. qaTobN and quTuwbN; (K, TA;) and ↓ qT~b, (K,) inf. n. taqoTiybN; (TA;) He contracted the part between his eyes; (A, K;) and grinned, or displayed his teeth, frowning, or contracting his face, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely; (K, TA;) by reason of drink, &c.: (TA:) or qaTaba bayona Eayonayohi, (S, O, Msb,) aor.
qaTiba , inf. n. qaTobN, (Msb,) he contracted the part between his eyes: (S, O, Msb:) and wajohahu ↓ qT~b, inf. n. taqoTiybN, he contracted his face; (S, O;) or did so much. (So accord. to a copy of the S.) ― -b5- And qaTaba Al$~araAba, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) aor.
qaTiba , inf. n. qaTobN, (Msb,) He mixed the wine, or beverage; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AqTbhu; (S, O, K;) and ↓ qT~bhu, (O, K, TA,) inf. n. taqoTiybN. (TA.) ― -b6- And qaTaba AlA_inaA='a He filled the vessel. (K.) ― -b7- qaTaba AljuwaAliqa, (K, TA,) inf. n. qaTobN, (S, O,) He inserted one of the two loops of the [sack called] jwAlq into the other, (S, O, K, TA,) on the occasion of making up a load, (TA,) then bent it (S, O, K *) again, (S, O,) [this time, app., back and down,] and put them together [in order, it seems, to insert a stick, so that the middle of one loop should be above the stick and the middle of the other should be beneath it]: (K, TA:) when he does not bend the loop, [app. meaning through the other and then a second time as described above,] the action is termed saloqN. (S, O, [See salaqa AljuwaAliqa, in art. slq.]) -A2- qaTabahu signifies also He angered him; (O, K;) aor. as above [and so, app., the inf. n.]. (O.) -A3- And also, (K, TA,) aor.
qaTiba , (TA,) inf. n. qaTobN, (S, O,) He cut it, or cut it off: (S, O, K:) but in this instance the T is substituted for D. (O.)
2 qaT~aba see above, in three places.
4 A^aqoTaba see the first paragraph, in two places.
qaTobN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

quTobN * (S, A, O, Msb, K) and ↓ qaTobN and ↓ qiTobN (S, A, O, K, but some reject the second and third of these, TA) and ↓ quTubN (A, K) and ↓ quTobapN, (so in some copies of the K,) or ↓ qaTobapN, (so in other copies of the K, and thus accord. to the TA, as on the authority of Th,) The axis, or pivot, (T, A, Msb, K,) of iron, (A, K,) of a mill; (T, S, A, O, Msb, K;) the iron thing that is fixed in the middle of the nether stone of a mill; (IAth, TA;) the iron in the nether stone, around which revolves the upper stone, of a mill: (Ham p. 54:) pl. A^aqoTaAbN (A, IAth, O, TA) and quTuwbN (IAth, TA) and qiTabapN. (O.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlquTobu, (S, O, Msb, K,) and accord. to some ↓ AlqaTobu and ↓ AlqiTobu, (MF,) (tropical:) [The pole-star: or the pole of the celestial sphere:] a certain star, (K,) a small star, (ISd, TA,) according to which the kibleh is constructed: (ISd, K, TA:) a star between the jadoY and the faroqadaAni, around which the celestial sphere, or firmament, revolves, (S, O, TA,) small and white, and never moving from its place: [but it seems that nebula should be here substituted for star:] Aboo-'Adnán says that the qZb is a small star always in the midst of the four [stars] of banaAtu naEo$K, [which is evidently a mistake,] never quitting its place, around which revolve the jdY and the frqdAn: but accord. to Ibn-Es-Saláh El-Mohaddith, it is not a star, but a buqoEap [meaning a spot, or a nebula,] in the sky, near the jdY, which latter is the [pole-] star whereby the kibleh is known in the northern countries. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence likewise,] AlquTobu signifies also (tropical:) The cause, or means, of the subsistence of a thing: and (tropical:) the thing, or point, [or person,] upon which [or upon whom] a thing [such as an affair, and a question,] turns: pl. [as above, i. e.] A^aqoTaAbN and quTuwbN and qiTabapN. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The chief, or lord, of a people or tribe; (S, A, O, K;) quTobu baniY fulaAnK meaning (tropical:) the chief, or lord, of the sons of such a one, upon whom their state of affairs turns [i. e. depends, and by whose government their affairs are regulated]. (S, O, TA.) And quTobu raHaY AlHarobi [lit. The axis, or pivot, of the mill of war, or of the mill of the war,] means (tropical:) the commander of the army. (S, O, TA.) ― -b5- [In the conventional language of the mystics, it is applied to (assumed tropical:) The hierarch of the saints of his generation, who is also called Algawovu, and is supposed to be pre-eminently endued with sanctity, and with thaumaturgic faculties, and to be known as the quTob to none but his agents unless he make himself known: at his death, his place is believed to be filled by another.] -A2- [quTobN also signifies A species of plant:] accord. to AHn, the quTob [is a species of plant that] extends upon the ground like ropes, and has a yellow, thorny, or prickly, blossom; when fit to be reaped, and dry, it hurts men to tread upon it; and is round like a pebble: n. un. ↓ quTobapN: (O:) [it is said in the K that ↓ AlquTobapu is said to signify a certain plant: and the pl. is quTobN or quTabN: (thus accord. to different copies: in my MS. copy, the former; and in the CK, the latter, and there said to be like SuradN: if the former be right, it is a coll. gen. n.:)] or quTobN and ↓ quTobapN signify two species of plants: and the latter is said to be a certain herb, having a fruit, or produce, and berries (Hab~) like those of the haraAs [a tree that bears a kind of drupe]: Lh says that it [app. the quTob, the pronoun being masc.,] is a species of thorn, from which diverge three thorns, resembling a Hasak [here meaning caltrop: the leaves of its stem resemble those of the [species of trefoil called] nafal and *urq, and qTb is the name of the fruit: and A^aroDN qTbp [i. e., accord. to general analogy, ↓ qaTibapN, like qaSibapN &c.,] signifies Land in which this kind of plant grows. (TA.) -A3- See also quTobapN.
qiTobN * : see quTobN, first and second sentences.

qaTabN * , [app. an inf. n. of which the verb is not mentioned, (in the CK qaTob, but, as is said in the TA, it is muHar~akap,)] which is forbidden, is One's taking a thing [by measure or weight], and then taking the rest of the commodity by comparing it with the former portion, without measure or weight. (Kr, K, * TA.)
qaTibN * : see qaTuwbN: -A2- and A^aroDN qaTibapN: see quTobN, last sentence but one.
quTubN * : see quTobN, first sentence.
qaTobapN * : see quTobN, first sentence.

quTobapN * : see quTobN, first sentence: -A2- and again, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in three places. -A3- Also An arrow-head (S, O, K) of small size (O) with which one shoots at a butt: (S, O, K:) accord. to ISd, a small, short, foursided head at the end of an arrow with which one shoots, to the utmost possible distance, at the butts: accord. to Th, the end of an arrow with which one shoots at the butt: accord. to AHn, it is of what are called AlmaraAmiY [pl. of miromaApN, q. v.]: (TA:) or an arrow with which one contends for superiority in shooting: (A:) [but] accord. to En-Nadr, it is not accounted an arrow: and ↓ quTobN signifies an arrow-head; occurring in a trad. in this sense. (TA.)

quTobaAnN *
A certain plant. (K.)

qiTib~aY *
A certain plant, of which is made rope of twisted strands, or well-twisted rope, (K, TA,) resembling that of the cocoa-nut, the price of which mounts to a hundred deenárs of ready money, (TA,) and which is better than that made of the fibres of the cocoa-nut. (K, TA.)

qiTaAbN *
An admixture (Lth, S, * O, K, TA) in what is drunk and what is not drunk. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- And qiTaAbu Aljayobi, (S, A, O, K, *) from AlqaTobu meaning “ the act of cutting, ” (S, TA,) or from the same as meaning “ the act of bringing, or drawing, together ” two things, (TA,) The opening that is cut out at the neck and bosom of a shirt or the like, for the head to enter into it: (O:) or (tropical:) the part where the two sides of that opening unite: (A, * K, * TA:) or, as AAF says, the lower, or lowest, part of that opening. (TA.)

qaTuwbN * (S, O, K) and ↓ qaATibN (K) [and ↓ qaTibN (occurring in the A in art. dEb, as opposed to daEibN and laEibN, to which it seems to be therefore assimilated in form,)] Who contracts the part between his eyes; (S, O, K;) and grins, or displays his teeth, frowning, or contracting his face, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely; (K;) [or rather the first signifies one who does so much;] applied to a man. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlqaTuwbu and ↓ AlqaATibu signify The lion. (O, K, TA.)

qaTiybN *
Mixed wine or beverage [&c.]; as also ↓ maqoTuwbN. (K.)

quTaAbapN *
A piece of flesh: (Kr, K:) from qaTaba signifying “ he cut ” a thing. (TA.)

qaTiybapN *
Anything mixed. (TA.) And [particularly] (TA) Camels' milk and sheeps' or goats' milk mixed together: (IAar, S, O, K:) or goats' milk and sheeps' milk mixed together; (K;) which is also called naxiysapN: (TA:) or fresh milk, or milk such as is termed Haqiyn [q. v.], mixed with A_ihaAlap [or melted fat, &c.]: and i. q. raviyy^apN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also qaATibap.
qaATibN * : see qaTuwbN, in two places.

jaAw^uwA qaATibapF * (tropical:) They came all together: (S, A, * O, Msb, K:) qATbp being a noun denoting generality, (Sb, S, O,) not used but as a word descriptive of state, in the accus. case: (Sb, S, O, K:) its use otherwise is a vulgar corruption, though allowed by El-Khafájee: (MF:) or it may be regarded in a phrase such as that above as being in the accus. case as an inf. n.: (IAth, TA:) it is expl. in the T as meaning all together; mixed, one with another. (TA.) And ↓ jaAw^uwA biqaTiybatihim means (assumed tropical:) They came with their [whole] company. (K.)
AlmuqaT~abu * and AlmuqaT~ibu and AlmaqoTibu The part between the eyebrows. (TA.)
maqoTuw``bN * : see qaTiybN. ― -b2- qirobapN maqoTuwbapN A water-skin filled. (Lh, O, TA.)
wajohN mutaqaT~ibN * [A contracted face]. (K in art. bsr.)

1 qaTara * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
qaTura , (S, Msb,) inf. n. qaTorN and qaTaraAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and quTuwrN; (K;) [and in an intensive sense, taqoTaArN (see a verse cited voce gusolN);] and ↓ AqTr; (AHn, TA;) and ↓ tqATr; (Msb, TA;) said of water, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of tears, (K,) or other fluid, (S, * TA,) [It dropped, dripped, or fell in drops;] it flowed (Mgh, Msb, TA) drop by drop. (Msb.) ― -b2- It occurs in a trad. as signifying qaTara EaraqFA, or bawolFA, [He let fall sweat, or urine, in drops,] in which each subst, is in the accus. case as a specificative: said of a person in intense awe or fear. (Mgh.) ― -b3- qaTara AlS~amogu minaY Al$~ajarapi The gum [exuded in drops or] came forth from the tree. (TA.) ― -b4- qaTarati A@sotuhu i. q. maSalat [His anus voided excrement in drops]. (K.) -A2- qaTara fiY AlA^aroDi inf. n. quTuwrN, (tropical:) He went away into the country, or in the land; (S, K; *) and hastened; (K, * TA;) as also maTara, inf. n. muTuwrN. (TA.) -A3- qaTarahu, (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [aor.
qaTura ,] inf. n. qaTorN; (Mgh;) and ↓ AqTrhu, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iqoTaArN; (Msb;) or the latter but not the former accord. to AZ; (Msb;) and ↓ qT~rhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoTiyrN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) He (God, K, or a man, S, Msb) made it (namely water &c.) [to drop, drip, dribble, or fall in drops;] to flow (S, Msb, TA) drop by drop: (S, Msb:) he poured it out, or forth. (Mgh.) You say qaTarotu AlmaA='a fiY AlHaloqi, and A^aqoTarotuhu, and qaT~arotuhu, [He made the water to fall drop by drop into the throat.] (Msb.) ― -b2- maA qaTaraka EalayonaA (tropical:) What hath poured thee (maA Sab~aka) upon us? (TA.) ― -b3- qaTara fulaAnFA, (Lth, K,) inf. n. qaTorN, (Lth,) (assumed tropical:) He prostrated such a one with vehemence. (Lth, K.) [Perhaps this is from quTorN, signifying the “ side; ” and if so it is not tropical. See also 2.] ― -b4- qaTara Alv~awoba (tropical:) He sewed the garment, or piece of cloth. (IAar, K.) -A4- qaTara AlA_ibila, (Msb, K,) aor.
qaTura , (Msb,) inf. n. qaTorN; (Msb, K;) and ↓ qT~rhA, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoTiyrN; (S;) but this has an intensive signification; (Msb;) and ↓ AqTrhA; (K;) but this [says SM] I do not find in the [other] lexicons; Az and ISd mention only the first and second; (TA;) He disposed the camels in a file, string, or series; (S, * Msb;) he placed the camels near, one to another, in a file, string, or series; (K;) [and tied the halter of each, except the first, to the tail of the next before it.] It is said in a proverb, Aljalaba ↓ Aln~ufaADu yaqaT~iru The failure of provisions causes the camels, driven or brought from one place to another, to be disposed in files for sale. (S.) -A5- qaTara AlbaEiyra He smeared the camel with qaTiraAn [or tar]. (S, Msb.)

2 qT~rhu * : see 1. ― -b2- bihi taqoTiyrN [He has a dribbling of his urine] is said of a man who cannot retain his urine, (Mgh, K, *) by reason of cold affecting the bladder. (TA.) -A2- qT~r AlA_ibila: see 1. -A3- TaEanahu faqaT~arahu (inf. n. taqoTiyrN, S) He pierced him [with his spear] and threw him down on one of his sides. (S, Msb.) And qT~rhu farasuhu; in the copies of the K qT~rhu EalaY farasihi, but this is a mistake; (TA;) and ↓ AqTrhu; and bih ↓ tqT~r; (K;) vulgarly taqanoTara bihi; (TA;) His horse threw him down on one of his sides. (K, * TA.) See quTorN: see also 1. -A4- qT~r vawobahu, inf. n. as above, He fumigated his garment with quTor, i. e., aloes-wood. (K.)

4 AqTr * : see 1. ― -b2- It was time for it to drop, drip, or fall in drops; it was ready, or near, to drop, &c.; expl. by HaAna lahu A^ano yaqoTura, (S,) and HaAna A^ano yaqoTura. (K.) -A2- AqTrhu: see 1. -A3- AqTr AlA_ibila: see 1. -A4- AqTrhu farasuhu: see 2.

5 tqT~r * , quasi-pass. of 2, [It was made to drop, drip, or fall in drops; &c. See an ex. in a verse cited voce tasaq~aY. ― -b2- ] He fell [upon his side]. (S.) ― -b3- tqT~r bihi farasuhu: see 2. -A2- tqT~rt She fumigated herself with quTor, i. e., aloes-wood. (K.)

6 taqaAoTara see 1. -A2- tqATr Alqawomu (tropical:) The people came in consecutive companies; from qiTaAru AlA_ibili. (S, TA.) And hence also, tqATrt kutubu fulaAnK (tropical:) [The books, or letters, of such a one followed one another in a regular series]. (TA.)

10 AstqTrhu *
He sought, or desired, its dropping, or dripping, or flowing; [endeavoured to make it drop, or drip;] expl. by raAma qaTaraAnahu, (K, TA,) i. e., sayalaAnahu. (TA.) ― -b2- AstqTr maEoruwfFA [He sought, or demanded, bounty, as it were drop by drop]. (K in art. nD.)
Q. Q. 1 qanoTara * : see art. qnTr.
Q. Q. 2 taqanoTara * : see art. qnTr.

qaTorN * [Drops;] pl. of qaTorapN: (S:) [or rather a coll. gen. n., having this signification; or] what drops, (K,) of water &c.: (TA:) n. un. qaTorapN; (K;) which signifies a drop: (Msb:) pl. of the former, qiTaArN: (K:) and of the latter, qaTaraAtN. (Msb.) [See also quTaArapN.] You say saAla qaTorapF qaTorapF It flowed drop by drop. (Msb.) ― -b2- Rain: (S, Msb:) n. un. qaTorapN [signifying a rain; a shower of rain]: (Msb:) pl. of the former, qiTaArN. (S.)

quTorN *
A side, part, portion, quarter, tract, or region, (S, Msb, K,) of the heavens, and of the earth; (TA;) as also qutorN (S, K, art. qtr,) and quturN: (K, ibid.) either side of a man: pl. A^aqoTaArN. (S, Msb, K.) You say A^aloqaAhu ElY AHd quTorayohi He threw him down on one of his sides. (S, * Msb, * K, * TA.) And laA A^adoriY EalaY A^aY~i quTorayohi yaqaEu [I know not on which of his two sides he will fall; i. e., what will be his final state]. (JK.) And the pl. signifies The outer parts or regions (nawaAHK)
of a horse, and of a camel: the prominent parts of a horse, such as the withers (AlkaAvibap) and the rump: the prominent parts of the upper portions of a camel, and of a mountain. (TA.) ― -b2- fuToru daAy^irapK [The diameter of a circle;] a straight line extending from one side of a circle to the other side so that its middle falls upon the centre (KT.) [But this is app. post-classical.] -A2- quTorN (S, K) and ↓ quTurN (S) Aloes-wood with which one fumigates. (S, K.)

qiTorN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ qaTirN (ISk, TA) Copper, or brass: (S, Mgh, Msb:) so in the Kur [xiv. 51, accord. to one reading,] mino qiTorK A=nK (S,) or mino qaTirK A=nK, accord. to the reading of I'Ab, meaning, of copper, or brass, in the utmost state of heat: (TA:) [but the common reading is mino qaTiraAnK:] or copper, or brass, in a state of fusion: (K:) so in the Kur, xxxiv. 11 (TA) [and xviii. 95]: or a certain kind thereof: (K:) or molten iron: (Mgh, Msb:) and anything that drops or flows (yaqoTuru) by fusion or melting, like water. (Mgh.)
qaTirN * : see qiTorN.
quTurN * : see quTorN.
qaTorapN * : see qaTorN, in two places.

qaTiraAnN * (S, Msb, K) and qiToraAnN (Msb, K) and qaToraAnN (K) [Tar, or liquid pitch;] what exudes from the tree called A^abohal, [or juniper, or the species of juniper called savin, both of which have this name in the present day,] (Msb, K, * TA,) and from the A^aroz [or pine-tree], and the like, (K, TA,) when subjected to the action of fire; (lit. when cooked;) used for smearing [mangy] camels, (Msb, TA,) &c.; (Msb;) i. q. hinaA='N. (S.) [See also zifotN.]
quTaArN * A cloud, (K,) or rain, (TA,) having large drops. (K, TA.)

qiTaArN *
A file, string, or series, of camels; a number of camels disposed in one series; (JK, Msb, K; *) one behind another; (JK;) [the halter of each, except the first, being tied to the tail of the next before it:] and the poet Abu-n-Nejm speaks of a qiTaAr of ants: (S:) of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) pl. quTurN (S, Msb) and, (S,) or pl. pl., (Msb,) quTuraAtN; (S, Msb;) vulg. qiTaAraAtN. (TA.)
qaTuwrN * and miqoTaArN A cloud having many drops, or much rain. (Th, AAF, K.)

quTaArapN *
What drops, or drips, (maA qaTara,) from a jar (Hub~) and the like: (Lh, S:) or from a thing. (K.) See also qaTorN. ― -b2- A small quantity of water. (Lh, K. *) Ex. fiY AlA_inaA='i quTaArapN mino maA='K In the vessel is a little water. (Lh.)

qaATirN * Any gum that exudes in drops, or comes forth, (yaqoTuru,) from trees. (IDrd, K. *) ― -b2- Alq~ATiru Almak~iY~u: see damN in art. dmw. ― -b3- A camel whose urine continually dribbles. (S, K.)
qanoTarapN * and qinoTaArN &c.: see art. qnTr.
miqoTarapN * [A kind of stocks]: see EilobapN and falaqN.

maqoTuwrN * . ― -b2- A^aroDN maqoTuwrapN Land rained upon. (K, TA.) -A2- baEiyrN maqoTuwrN, and ↓ muqaToranN, (S, K,) the latter after the form of the original [qaTiraAnN], (S, TA.) A camel smeared with qaTiraAn [or tar]. (S, K.)
muqaToranN * : see maqoTuwrN.
Q. 1 qaToraba * , (K,) inf. n. qaTorabapN, (O,) He hastened, sped, or went quickly. (O, K.) -A2- And qaTorabahu He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground: (O, K: *) and so qaroTabahu. (O.)

Q. 2 taqaToraba *
He (a man, TA) moved about his head: and made himself to resemble the quTorub: (K:) or became like the quTorub in some one of the senses assigned to it in what follows. (TA.)

quTorubN *
A certain bird; (S, O, K;) [app. a species of owl; accord. to Dmr, as cited by Freytag, a bird that roves about by night and does not sleep; and hence rendered by him, and by Golius, strix. No other meaning of the word, as an appellative, is mentioned in the S.] ― -b2- And A certain insect that rests not all the day, going about, or going about quickly, (O, K, TA,) or, as they used to assert in the Time of Ignorance, that never rests, (TA,) moving about on the surface of water. (KL.) Mohammad Ibn-El-Mustaneer, (K, TA,) the grammarian, (TA,) was surnamed quTorub because he used to go early in the morning to Seebaweyh; so that the latter, whenever he opened his door, found him there; wherefore he said to him, maA A^anota A_il~aA quTorubu layolK [Thou art none other than a kutrub of night]. (K, * TA.) It is also expl. in the K as meaning Light, or active; and Th mentions that it signifies thus; and adds that one says, A_in~ahu laquTorubu layolK [Verily he is a kutrub of night]; but this shows that it means an insect [described above], and is not [properly speaking] an epithet. (TA.) To this insect is likened a man who labours during the day in accomplishing worldly wants and in the evening is fatigued so that he sleeps during the night until he enters upon the time of morning to betake himself to the like thereof, h`*aA jiyfapu layoli quTorubu nahaArK [lit. This is a corpse of the night, a kutrub of the day]. (O, from an explanation of a trad.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 329 and 643.] ― -b3- And [hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) A thief who is skilful, or active, in thievishness: (O, M, TA:) for All~iS~u AlfaArihu fiY All~uSuwSiy~api, an explanation of AlquTorubu given [in the O and] by IM and others, the copies of the K erroneously substitute All~iSu waAlfaA^orapu [as though quTorubN had the significations of a thief and a rat or mouse]. (TA.) ― -b4- And The male (Lth, O, K, TA) of the [kind of demon called] siEolaAp (Lth, TA) or of the guwl [which is said to signify the same as sElAp]; as also ↓ quToruwbN. (O, K, TA.) ― -b5- And [app. A young, or little, jinnee: thus quroTubN is expl. in the L: or] the young ones, or little ones, of the jinn. (K.) ― -b6- And A young, or little, dog: (O:) or the young ones, or little ones, of dogs. (K.) ― -b7- And A wolf such as is termed A^amoEaT [i. e. whose hair has fallen off, part after part, or has become scanty; or mischievous, or malignant]. (O, K.) ― -b8- And An ignorant person, (O, K, TA,) who boasts by reason of his ignorance (yaZoharu bijaholihi). (O, TA.) ― -b9- And Cowardly, or a coward, (O, K, TA,) even if intelligent. (O, TA.) ― -b10- And Lightwitted; syn. safiyhN; (O, K, TA;) as also ↓ quToruwbN: and IAar has mentioned as a pl. in this sense, used by a poet, qaTaAriybu, which, ISd says, may be pl. of quToruwbN or of a sing. of some other form requiring such a form of pl., or it may be used as a pl. of quTorubN by poetic license. (TA.) ― -b11- And Thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground, syn. maSoruwEN, (O, K, TA,) by reason of diabolical possession or wrestling. (O, * TA.) -A2- Also A species of melancholia; (O, K, TA;) a well-known disease, arising from the black bile; (TA;) mostly originating in the month of $ubaAT [February, O. S.]; vitiating, or disordering, the intellect, contracting the face, occasioning continual unhappiness, causing to wander about in the night, and rendering the face A^axoDar [here app. meaning of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour], the eyes sunken, and the body emaciated. (O.) [A more ample discription is given by Avicenna (Ibn-Seenà). in book iii. pp. 315, et seq. SM states that he had not found this in any other lexicon than the K. Golius explains the word as signifying Lycanthropia, on the authority of Rhazes (Er-Rázee).]
quToruwbN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
See Supplement

qiTomiyrN * (S, K) and qiTomaArN (K) The cleft ($aq~) of a date-stone: (M, K:) or the integument (qi$orap) that is upon it (fiyhaA): (K:) the thin skin (S, K) called fuwfap, which is upon a date-stone, (S,) between the stone and the date itself: (K:) or the white point [i. e. the embryo] in the back of the date-stone, (S, K,) from which [when it is sown] the palm-tree grows forth. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A small, mean, paltry, contemptible, thing. So the former signifies in the Kur, xxxv. 14. One says also maA A^aSabotu minohu qiTomiyrFA, meaning, (assumed tropical:) I obtained not of him, or it, anything. (TA.)
See Supplement
