2 taqoEiybN * [as inf. n. of the pass. v. quE~iba], used in relation to a solid hoof, means (tropical:) The being muqab~ab [i. e. round, or hemispherical,] like the [drinking-cup, or bowl, called] qaEob. (K, TA. [See also muqaE~abN.]) ― -b2- And Alt~aqoEiybu signifies taqoEiyru AlkalaAmi; (K;) or taqoEiybu AlkalaAmi signifies taqoEiyruhu; (S, O;) [or Alt~aqoEiybu fiY AlkalaAmi signifies Alt~aqoEiyru fiyhi, i. e. (tropical:) The speaking with a guttural voice, or from the furthest part of the fauces; or the doing thus, with a twisting of the sides of the mouth; and opening the mouth so that it becomes as though it were a cup such as is called qaEob: (see muqaE~ibN:)] you say, qaE~aba fiY kalaAmihi and qaE~ara; both meaning the same. (L, TA.)

Q. Q. 3 AiqoEanobaY *
He put his hands upon the ground, and sat in such a posture as to be ready to rise. (TA in art. qEnb, from a trad.)

qaEobN *
A deep wooden drinking-cup or bowl: (S, O:) or a large vessel like the [bowl called] qaSoEap: (Msb:) or a large, rude, drinking-cup or bowl: (A, K:) or one inclining more nearly to be small: (A, K: *) to which a solid hoof is likened: (TA:) or such as satisfies the thirst of a man: (A, K:) accord. to IAar, the first [or smallest] of drinkingcups or bowls is that called the gumar, which does not hold enough to satisfy [a man's] thirst: next is the qaEob, which is [a cup] large enough to satisfy the thirst of a man; and sometimes it satisfies the thirst of two men, and three: and then, the Eus~: (TA:) the pl. is qiEabapN (S, O, K) and (K) qiEaAbN and A^aqoEubN, (Msb, K,) the last a pl. of paucity. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Depth of speech, or language. (O, K, TA.) One says, h`*aA kalaAmN lahu qaEobN (assumed tropical:) This is speech, or language, having depth. (TA.) ― -b3- And in the T, in art. qnE, the phrase qiEaAbu AlA^aworaAqi is expl. as meaning A^aqotaA='N biyDu AlA^asonaAni [app. for AlbiyDu AlA^asonaAni mina AlA^afotaA='i i. e. The white in respect of the teeth, of the young; for AlAwrAq seems to be here used in a sense assigned to its sing., Alwaraqu, namely, AlA^aHodaAvu, pl. of AlHadavu, which is syn. with AlfatiY~u, of which AlA^afotaA='u is pl.: but for this usage of qiEaAb I am unable to account: I incline to think it a mistranscription, though I do not know any word resembling it for which it may have been substituted]. (TA.)

qaEobapN * (assumed tropical:) A thing resembling [the kind of receptacle called] a Huq~ap, pertaining to a woman: or a covered Huq~ap for sawiyq [i. e. meal of parched barley or the like]: (K:) or a thing resembling a covered Huq~ap in which is a woman's swyq. (O.)
quEobapN * (assumed tropical:) A [hollow, or cavity, such as is termed] nuqorap, in a mountain. (O, K.)

qaEiybN *
A large number: (K:) or a number: and a large number or quantity. (O.)

qaAEibN *
A wolf that howls much. (O, K.)

EuqaAbN qaEonabaApN *
i. q. EqAb EaqanobaApN, (O, K,) formed by transposition, meaning [An eagle] having sharp talons. (O. [See more in art. Eqb.])

HaAfirN muqaE~abN * (tropical:) A solid hoof likened to a qaEob; (S, O;) round like the qaEob. (A.) ― -b2- And sur~apN muqaE~abapN (tropical:) A navel resembling a qaEob, (A, O, K,) sunk in the belly, and elevated in the part around it. (O.) ― -b3- And HajarN muqaE~abN (tropical:) A stone in which is a hollow, or cavity, resembling the qaEob. (A.)

fulaAnN muqaE~ibo muqaE~irN * (tropical:) Such a one is a person who twists the sides of his mouth, and who speaks [with a guttural voice, or] with [or from] the furthest part of his fauces, and opens his mouth [making it to be] as though it were a [cup such as is called] qaEob. (A, TA.)

1 qaEavotu lahu qaEovapF * , (S, O, K, * TA, *) [accord. to which last, ↓ qaEovapN is an inf. n., as also qaEovN, but, if an inf. n., it is app. an inf. n. un.,] aor.
qaEuva , (accord. to the TK, [but I think it is more probably
qaEava , agreeably with a general rule, like the aor. of the same verb in the next sentence,]) means Hafanotu lahu HafunapN, (S, O,) i. e. I gave to him a small quantity, (S, O, K, *) mina Al$~aYo'i [of the thing]. (TA.) -A2- qaEava Al$~aYo'a, aor.
qaEava , inf. n. qaEovN, He (a man) eradicated, or uprooted, the thing; (IDrd, O, L;) and (O) so ↓ qE~vhu, inf. n. taqoEiyvN. (O, K.)
2 qaE~ava see what immediately precedes.

4 AqEv fiY maAlihi *
He acted extravagantly in respect of his property. (ISk, S, O, K. *) ― -b2- And AqEv lahu AlEaTiy~apa He made the gift to him large; (S, O, K, TA;) and so ↓ AiqotaEavahaA, and AqEvhu [i. e. AqEvhu AlEaTiy~apa]. (TA. See the verse cited voce muqoEavN; and the remark of As respecting it.)

7 AnqEv *
It was, or became, pulled out, or up, (As, S, O, TA,) from the foundation, or utterly; (As, S, TA;) it was, or became, eradicated, or uprooted. (K.) One says, Darabahu faA@noqaEava He struck it, and it became pulled out, or up, (As, S, O, TA,) from the foundation, or utterly. (As, S, TA.) ― -b2- And It (a wall) fell down from its foundation: like AnqEf. (As, S, O.)

8 AqtEv *
He (a digger) took forth much earth from a well. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also 4.

qaEavN *
Muchness, or abundance. (TA. [See qaEiyvN.])
qaEovapN * : see the first sentence of this art.

quEaAvN *
A certain disorder in the noses of sheep, or goats: (O, K:) thus expl. by Aboo-Turáb. (O.)

qaEiyvN * , (O, K,) as expl. by As, (O,) Paltry, or little in quantity; syn. hay~inN and yasiyrN. (O, K. [See also muqoEavN.]) ― -b2- And Abundant, or copious; applied to rain: (S, O, K:) and to a benefit, or benefaction, &c.: (TA:) and to a gift (sayob): (O, TA:) and, (S, K, TA,) or as some say, (O,) to a torrent (sayol), (S, O, K,) as meaning thus, (S, O,) or as meaning great: (K:) whence, in a verse of Ru-beh,
↓ maA $aA='a mino A^abowaAbi kasobK miqoEavi
[What he will of the means of the attainment of abundant gain]; miqoEavN being of the measure mifoEalN from qaEiyvN as applied to rain &c. (O. [The word ksb, of which the right reading is certainly as above, is there imperfectly written, more like kusob than kasob.])

muqoEavN * [pass. part. n. of 4]. Ru-beh says,
A^aqoEavaniY minohu bisayobK muqoEavi
layosa bimanozuwrK walaA biray~ivi
[He gave me liberally thereof, or from him, a large gift, (lit., accord. to the explanation of the verb, a gift made large,) not such as was small, or not such as was obtained by importunity, nor such as was slow in coming]: (S, * TA:) but As says that Ru-beh has done ill in using the phrase bsyb mqEv; for muqoEav, he says, means paltry, or little in quantity; syn. hay~inN and yasiyrN [like qaEiyvN, which is said to have this meaning and also the contr. thereof]. (TA. [Perhaps the right reading in the verse cited above is ↓ miqoEav.]
miqoEavN * : see qaEiyvN. [See also what here immediately precedes.]

1 qaEada * , (S, K, &c.,) aor.
qaEuda , (A, L,) inf. n. quEuwdN and maqoEadN (S, L, K) and qaEodN, (L,) He sat; i. q. jalasa [when the latter is used in its largest sense]; (S, A, L, K;) so accord. to 'Orweh Ibn-Zubeyr, a high authority; contr. of qaAma: (L:) or it signifies he sat down; or sat after standing: and jls, he sat after lying on his side or prostrating himself: (Kh, IKh, El-Hareeree, K:) or, as some say, qEd signifies he sat for some length of time. (MF.) See also jalasa. ― -b2- [And hence, He remained.] ― -b3- qaAma waqaEada (tropical:) He experienced griefs which disquieted him so that he could not remain at rest, but stood up and sat down. (Mgh, art. qdm.) [See an ex. voce sud~apN.] h`*aA $aYo'N yaqoEudu bihi Ealayoka AlEaduw~u wayaquwmu (tropical:) [This is a thing for which the enemy will be restless in his attempts against thee]. (A.) Darabahu Darobapa A@bonapi A@qoEudiY waquwmiY He beat him with a beating of a female slave: (IAar, L, K: *) who is thus called because she sits and stands in the service of her masters, being ordered to do so. (IAar, L.) ― -b4- [qaEada lahu, properly, He sat for him, often means He lay in wait for him, in the road, or way: see an ex. in a verse cited voce sad~N.] ― -b5- qaEadati Alr~axamapu (tropical:) The
aquiline vulture lay upon its breast on the ground; syn. javamat. (S, A, K.) See also jalasa. ― -b6- [Hence, from the notion of sitting down over against any one,] qaEada biqironihi (assumed tropical:) He was able to contend with his adversary. (L, K.) ― -b7- banuw fulaAnK libaniY fulaAnK yaqoEuduwna (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one are able to contend with the sons of such a one, and come to them with their numbers. (L.) ― -b8- qaEaduwA Ean~aA (assumed tropical:) They were able to contend for us, with their warriors, and to suffice us in war. (L.) ― -b9- qaEada liloHarobi (tropical:) He prepared for war those who should contend therein. (L, K.) ― -b10- qaEada liloA^amori He performed the affair; syn. A_ihotam~a bihi. (Msb.) ― -b11- qaEada ya$otimuniY (tropical:) He set about, fell to, or commenced, reviling me. (Fr, A, L.) ― -b12- [And from the notion of sitting down in refusal or unwillingness,] qaEada Eani AlA^amori (tropical:) He abstained from, omitted, neglected, left, relinquished, or forsook, the thing or affair; (A, Mgh;) he hung back, or held back, from it. (IKtt.) qaEada Eano HaAjatihi (tropical:) He hung, back, or held back, from accomplishing his want. (Msb.) qaEada Eani Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) He remained behind, or after, the people, or party, not going with them. (Msb, art. xlf.) And qaEadotu baEodahu [(assumed tropical:) I remained behind, or after, him;] as also qEdt xilaAfahu: (Msb, ibid.:) and qaEada xilaAfa A^aSoHaAbihi, He remained behind, or after, his companions; he did not go forth with them (TA, in art. xlf) ― -b13- [qaEada maEahu and qaEada A_ilayohi are like jalasa maEahu and jalasa A_ilayohi, q. v.] ― -b14- qaEada bihi, see 4 in three places, and 5. ― -b15- qaEadato, inf. n. quEuwdN; (K;) or qaEadato Eani Alwaladi, (Mgh, K,) and AlHayoDi, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Alz~awoji; (A, Msb, K;) (tropical:) She (a woman) ceased from bearing children, (A, Mgh, K,) and from having the menstrual discharge, and from having a husband. (A, K.) [And hence,] (tropical:) She (a woman) had no husband: (K, * TA:) said of her who is, and of her who is not, a virgin. (TA.) ― -b16- qaEadati Aln~axolapu (tropical:) The palm-tree bore fruit one year and not another. (L, K.) ― -b17- qaEada maqaAEida riqaAqFA (assumed tropical:) [He had thin evacuations of the bowels: see sad~a] (TA, in art. sk.) ― -b18- qaEadN Laxness (S, K) and depression (S) in the shank (waZiyf) of a camel. (S, K.) [App. an inf. n., of which the verb is qaEida. But see 1 in art. Sdf.] -A2- qaEada It [or he] became; syn. SaAra. Ex. Had~ada $aforatahu Hat~aY qaEadato kaA^an~ahaA HarobapN He sharpened his large knife so that it became as though it were a javelin. And vawobaka laA taqoEudu taTiyru bihi Alr~iyHu [in the CK, vawobuka and yaqoEudu] Take care of thy garment, that the wind do not become flying away with it. (IAar, L, K. *) vwbk is here in the acc. case because the verb AiHofaZo is understood before it. (L.) ― -b2- qaEadati A=lfasiylapu (tropical:) The young palm-tree came to have a trunk. (S, A, K.) -A3- qaEada He (a man, AZ) stood. Thus it bears two contr. significations. (AZ, L, K.)

2 qaE~adotuka A@ll~`ha *
I beg God to perserve, keep, guard, or watch, thee. See qaEiydaka A@ll~`ha. (Aboo- 'Alee, IB, L.) See also 4 in two places, and 5.

3 qAEdhu *
He sat with him. (L.) [See also an ex. in art. sfh, conj. 3.]

4 AqEdhu * , (S, L, K,) and bihi ↓ qaEada, (L, K,) He caused him to sit, or sit down; he seated him. (S, L.) ― -b2- A^uqoEida (tropical:) He was affected by a disease in his body which deprived him of the power to walk: (Msb:) he was unable to rise: (L:) [as though constrained to remain sitting: see muqoEadN, and quEaAdN.] ― -b3- A^aqoEadahu Alharamu (tropical:) [Decrepitude crippled him, or deprived him of the power of motion]. (A.) ― -b4- A^uqoEida He (a man) was, or became, lame. (S, L.) ― -b5- A_iqoEaAdN in the hind leg of a horse is Its being much expanded (An tufora$a jid~FA), so that it is not erect. (S, L.) ― -b6- A^uqoEida He (a camel) had the disease called quEaAd. (IKtt, L.) ― -b7- A^aqaAmahu waA^aqoEadahu, and ↓ qaAma bihi waqaEada, (tropical:) He, or it, caused him to experience griefs which disquieted him so that he could not remain at rest, making him to stand up and sit down. (See 1, and muqoEidN. And see an ex. in a verse cited in art. fnY, conj. 3.] ― -b8- AqEd Albiy^ora He dug the well to the depth of a man sitting: or he left it upon the surface of the ground, and did not dig it so as to reach water. (L, K.) See also muqoEadapN. ― -b9- AqEd (Ibn-Buzurj, L) and ↓ A_iqoEanodada (K) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place. (Ibn-Buzurj, L, K.) -A2- AqEdhu and ↓ qE~dhu (inf. n. of the latter taqoEiydN) He sufficed him (namely his father [but in the CK, instead of A^abaAhu, we read A_iy~aAhu,]) for gaining, or earning; (K, TA;) and aided, or assisted, him. (TA.) ― -b2- AqEdhu and ↓ qE~dhu (inf. n. of the latter taqoEiydN, K) He served him. (IAar, L, K.) [Ex.] maA lifulaAnK A@moraA^apN tuqoEiduhu, and tuqaE~iduhu, [Such a one has no wife to serve him]. (A.) -A3- AqEdhu A=baAw^uhu, and ↓ tqE~dhu, (tropical:) His ancestors withheld him from eminence, or nobility; (L;) [as also bihi ↓ qaEada, and ↓ AqtEdhu. You say also,] bihi Eano nayoli ↓ maA qaEada AlmasaAEiY A_il~aA luw^omu EunoSurihi, and ↓ mA tqE~dhu, and mA ↓ AqtEdhu, (tropical:) [Nothing withheld him from attaining to the means of honour and elevation but the baseness of his origin]. (A.) See also 5. ― -b2- wirovuhu biAlA_iqoEaAdi (assumed tropical:) [His inheritance is by reason of nearness of relationship]. You do not say biAlquEuwdi (L.) ― -b3- A_iqoEaAdN (tropical:) The having few ancestors. (IAar, L.)

5 tqE~dhu * (tropical:) He, or it, withheld, restrained, debarred, or prevented, him from attaining the thing that he wanted. (S, L, K.) Ex. maA taqaE~adaniY Eanoka A_il~aA $ugolN Nothing but business withheld me from thee. (ISk, S.) See also 4. You say also biY Eanoka $ugolN ↓ qaEada Business withheld me from thee. (TA.) [And so,] ↓ maA qaE~adaka, and ↓ maA A@qotaEadaka, what hath withheld, restrained, debarred, or prevented, thee? (L.) ― -b2- tqE~d Eani AlA^amori, (S, A, L, K,) and ↓ tqAEd, (A,) (tropical:) He did not seek, seek for or after, or desire, the thing. (S, A, L, K.) See also 1. ― -b3- tqE~d signifies He held back, or refrained. (KL.) ― -b4- And also He held back, or restrained. (KL.) ― -b5- tqE~dhu He performed his affair. (IAar, Th, L, K.)
6 tqAEd bihi fulaAnN * (assumed tropical:) Such a one did not pay him his due. (S, L.) -A2- See also 5.

8 AqtEd *
He rode a camel: (L, Msb:) he took, or used, a camel as a quEodap q. v. (L, K.) ― -b2- AqtEd qaEiydapF [He took a seat of the kind called qEydp to sit upon]. (L.)
R. Q. 3 A_iqoEanodada * : see 4.
qaEodaka A=ll~`ha * and qiEodaka, see qaEiydaka A=ll~`ha throughout.

qaEadN *
Human dung. (L, K.) -A2- See also qaAEidN in two places.

qaEodapN *
A single sitting. (S, L, Msb.) Ex. qaEada qaEodapF waAHidapF He sat a single sitting. (L.) ― -b2- qaEodapu rajulK, see qiEodapN in three places. -A2- And see qaAEidN. -A3- *uw AlqaEodapi, and *uw AlqiEodapi, A certain month; (S, L, K;) [the eleventh month of the Arabian year;] next after $aw~aAl: (L:) so called because the Arabs [when their year was solar] used to abstain (yaqoEuduwna) therein from journeys (L, K, * TA) and warring and plundering expeditions and laying in stores of corn and seeking pasturage, before performing the pilgrimage in the next month; (L, TA;) or because in that month they broke in the young camels (AlqiEodaAn) for riding: (Msb, voce jumaAdaY:) pl. *awaAtu AlqaEodapi (S, L, Msb, K) and *awaAtu AlqaEadaAti; (Yoo, Msb;) but the former is the regular pl., (Yoo,) because the two words are considered as one, (Msb,) and it is the more common: (TA:) dual *awaAtaA AlqaEodapi and *awaAtaA AlqaEodatayoni. (Msb.)

quEodapN * , (K,) or ↓ quEadapN, (L,) An ass: (L, K:) pl. quEodaAtN, (K,) with the E quiescent, (TA,) [in the CK, quEodaAnN,] or quEadaAtN. (L.) -A2- [The former,] A horse's, and a camel's saddle: (L, K:) pl. quEudaAtN, (IDrd, L,) with which is syn. quEayodaAtN [the dim.]. (S, L.) ― -b2- See qaEuwdN.

qiEodapN *
A mode, or manner, of sitting. (S, L, Msb, K.) Ex. huwa Hasanu AlqiEodapi He has a good manner of sitting: (A, L:) and qaEada qiEodapa Ald~ub~i He sat in the manner of sitting of the bear. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- qiEodapu rajulK, and rajulK ↓ qaEodapu, (L, K, *) The space occupied by a man sitting: (L, K:) and the height, or depth, of a man sitting. (L.) Ex. $ajarapN qiEodapu rajulK A tree of the height of a man sitting: (AHn, in L and TA, passim:) and biy^orN qiEodapN A well of the depth of a man sitting: (As:) and Eumoqu biy^orinaA qiEodapN, and ↓ qaEodapN, The depth of our well is that of a man sitting: (L:) and
maA Hafarotu fiY AlA^aroDi A_il~aA qiEodapF, and ↓ qaEodapF, I dug not in the ground save to the depth of a man sitting: (Lh, L:) and mararotu bimaA='K qiEodapi rajulK I passed by water of the depth of a man sitting. (Sb, L.) -A2- qiEodapN One's last child, male or female; and one's last children. (K.)

qaEadapN *
A vehicle, or beast of carriage, (marokabN,) for women: so in the copies of the K in our hands; (S, M;) but accord. to the L, &c., of a man: and it is ↓ qaEiydapN that bears the former signification. (TA.) ― -b2- The [kind of carpet called] Tanofasap [q. v.] (L, K) upon which a man sits; and the like. (L.)
quEadapN * see quEodapN and quEodiY~N.
quEodadN * : see the next paragraph.

quEodudN * (tropical:) Nearness of relationship. (L.) ― -b2- *uw quEodudK A man nearly related to [the father of] the tribe. (Lh.) [And] quEodudN and ↓ quEodadN (S, K) and ↓ quEoduwdN and ↓ A^aqoEadu and Aln~asabi ↓ qaEiydu, (L, K,) (tropical:) A man near in lineage to the chief, or oldest, ancestor [of his family or tribe]; (S, L, K;) contr. of TarifN and TariyfN: (S, M, K in art. Trf:) and the first, The next of kin to the chief, or oldest, ancestor [of his family]; (Msb;) and contr., remote in lineage therefrom: (L, K:) [in the former sense, an epithet of praise:] in the latter sense, an epithet of dispraise: or, as some say, of praise: (TA:) or, in the first sense, it is an epithet of praise in one point of view, because dominion, or power, or authority, belong to the elder; and of dispraise in another point of view, because the person so termed is of the sons of the very old, and weakness is attributed to him. (S.) ― -b3- AlmiyraAvu AlquEodudu (tropical:) The inheritance of him who is nearest of kin to the deceased. (L.) ― -b4- quEodudN (assumed tropical:) A cowardly and ignoble man, who holds back, or abstains, from war and from generous actions; (L, K; *) as also ↓ quEodadN. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A man withheld from eminence, or nobility, by his lineage; as also ↓ muqoEadN. (Az, L.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) An obscure man; (L, K;) ignoble; of low rank; as also ↓ quEodadN. (Az, L.)
quEodaY * [A nearer degree in lineage to the chief, or oldest, ancestor, than TurofaY, q. v.]

quEodiY~N * and qiEodiY~N, and both with p, and DujoEiY~N and DijoEiY~N, (K,) and DujaEapN ↓ quEadapN, (S, K,) A man (S) who sits much and lies much upon his side: (S, K:) or the last, an impotent man, who does not earn that whereby he may subsist; (A;) [and the first two] (assumed tropical:) A man impotent; or lacking power, or ability; (L, K;) as though preferring sitting: (L:) or loving to sit in his house. (A.)

qaEadiY~N * (tropical:) A man belonging to the sect called AlqaEadu, (L,) or AlqaEadapu; (A [see qaAEidN];) who holds the opinions of that sect. (L, K.) ― -b2- Also applied by a post-classical poet to (tropical:) A man who refuses to drink wine while he approves of others' drinking it. (L.)

quEaAdN *
Lameness in a man. You say mataY A^aSaAbaka h`*aA AlquEaAdu When did this lameness befall thee? (S, L;) [and] bihi quEaAdN, (L, K,) and ↓ A_iqEAd, (K,) and ↓ A^aqoEaAdN, (CK,) (tropical:) He has a disease which constrains him to remain sitting. (L, K.) See A^uqoEida, and muqoEadN. ― -b2- quEaAdN also signifies, (S, L, K,) and so ↓ A_iqoEaAdN, (S, L,) or ↓ A^aqoEaAdN, with fet-h, (accord. to the K,) A certain disease which affects camels in their haunches, and makes them to incline (or as though their rumps inclined, IAar) towards the ground: (S, K:) or a laxness of the haunches. (IKtt.)
qiEaAdN * : see qaEiydN.

qaEuwdN *
A young weaned camel: (L, K:) and a young she-camel; i. q. qaluwSN: (K:) or this latter epithet is applied to a female and the former to a male young camel: (ISh, L, Msb:) so called because he is ridden: (Msb:) and a young male camel, until he enters his-sixth year: (K:) or a young male camel when it may be ridden, which is at the earliest when he is two years old, after which he is thus called until he enters his sixth year, when he is called jamalN: the young she-camel is not called thus, but is termed qaluwSN: (S, L:) Ks heard the term qaEuwdapN applied to the female; but this is rare. (Az, L.) ― -b2- A camel which the pastor rides, or uses, in every case of need; (A'Obeyd, S, L, K;) called in Persian raxoto; (A'Obeyd, S, L;) as also ↓ qaEuwdapN, (K,) accord. to Lth, the only authority for it known to Az; but Kh says that this signifies a camel which the pastor uses for carrying his utensils &c., and that the p is added to give intensiveness to the epithet; (TA;) or the former is masc. and the latter fem.; (Ks, L;) and ↓ quEodapN: (S, K:) you say niEoma AlquEodapu h`*aA, i. e. AlmuqotaEadu, [an excellent camel for the pastor's ordinary riding, or use, is this]: (S, L:) or each of these words signifies a camel which the pastor uses for riding and for carrying his provisions and utensils &c.: and quEodapN, a camel which a man rides whenever and wherever he will: (L:) the pl. of qaEuwdN is A^aqoEidapN [a pl. of pauc.] and quEudN and qiEodaAnN and qaEaAy^idu; (L, K;) and pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of qiEodaAnN] qaEaAdiynu. (TA.) The dim of qaEuwdN is quEay~idN. It is said in a proverb, A_it~axa*uwhu quEay~ida AlHaAjaAti They made him an ordinary servant for the performance of needful affairs. (S, L.)

qaEiydN *
A companion in sitting: (S, AHeyth, L, K:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEilN. (L.) ― -b2- A preserver; a keeper; a guardian; a watcher. (L, K.) [In some copies of the K, by the omission of wa, this meaning is assigned to muqaAEidN.] It is used alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem. (L, K) and dual also. (L.) It is said in the Kur, [l. 16,] Eani Alyamiyni waEani Al$imaAli qaEiydN [On the right and on the left a sitter, or guardian, or watcher]: respecting which it is observed, that faEiylN and faEuwlN are of the measures used alike as sing. and dual and pl.; as in A_in~aA rasuwlu rab~ika, [Kur xi. 83, accord. to one reading,] and waAlmalaAy^ikapu baEoda *`lika ZahiyrN, [Kur lxvi. 4:] (S, L:) or, as the grammarians say, qaEiydN is understood after Alymyn. (L.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A father; (A'Obeyd, K;) and ↓ qaEiydapN A man's wife; (S, L, K; *) as also ↓ qiEaAdN: (S, L:) and qaEiydapu bayoti rajulK a man's wife: pl. qaEaAy^idu. (L.) ― -b4- qaEiydaka A@ll~`ha, and A@ll~`ha ↓ qaEodaka, and A@ll~`ha ↓ qiEodaka, (K,) but the last was unknown to AHeyth, (L,) [By thy Watcher, or Keeper, God: qEyd and ↓ qEd being epithets, put in the acc. case because of the prep. bi understood: or] I conjure thee by God; syn. na$adotuka A@ll~`ha: some say, the meaning is, as though God were sitting with thee, watching over thee, or keeping thee: [in some copies of the K, for biHifoZihi Ealayoka, the reading in the TA, we find yaHofaZuhu Ealayoka:] or by thy Companion, who is the Companion of every secret, [namely God] ! qaEiydaka laA A=tiyka, and lA Atyk ↓ qiEodaka; and qaEiydaka A@ll~`ha lA Atyk, and A@ll~`ha lA Atyk ↓ qiEodaka; are forms of swearing used by the Arabs, in which qEyd and ↓ qEd are inf. us. put in the acc. case because of a verb understood; [or rather, as it appears to me, and as I have said above, they are epithets, put in the acc. case because of the prep. bi understood;] and the meaning is, By thy Companion, who is the Companion of every secret, [I will not come to thee; and by thy Companion, &c., or by thy Watcher, or Keeper, God, I will not come to thee;] like as one says na$adotuka A@ll~`ha: (S, L:) some say, that qEyd and ↓ qEd signify here a watcher, or an observer, and a preserver, a keeper, or a guardian, that God is meant by them, and that they are in the acc. case because A^uqosimu followed by the prep. bi is understood; [the meaning being I swear by thy Watcher, or Keeper, &c., God, &c.; and this opinion is the more agreeable with the explanation given above, “ By thy Companion &c. ”:] others say, that they are inf. ns., and that the meaning is, I swear by thy regard, or fear, of God, bimuraAqabatika A@ll~`ha: El-Mázinee and others, however, assert that qEyd has no verb. (MF.) ― -b5- Ks says that A@ll~`hu ↓ qiEodaka [All~`h being in the nom. case] signifies God be with thee! (L.) [or God be thy Companion, or Watcher, or Keeper!]; and so does qaEiydaka All~`hu. (AHeyth, L.) [Or] qaEiydaka A@ll~`ha, (IB, L, K,) and qiEodaka A@ll~`ha, (K,) and qaEodaka A@ll~`ha, (IB, L, TA,) [are] expressions of conciliation, not oaths, as they have not the complement of an oath: the former word in each is an inf. n. occupying the place of a verb, and therefore is put in the acc. case, as in Eamoraka A@ll~`ha, which means Eam~arotuka A@ll~`ha, i. e., I beg God to prolong thy life: in like manner, qaE~adotuka A@ll~`ha [in the K, qiEodaka,] signifies, [and so the three first phrases above, of which it is the original form,] I beg God to preserve, keep, guard, or watch, thee; from the saying in the Kur, [l. 16,] Eani Alyamiyni waEani Al$~imaAli qaEiydN, i. e. HafiyZN. (Aboo-'Alee, IB, L, K. *) qaEiyda kumaA A@ll~`ha is used in interrogative phrases and in phrases conveying an oath, [and so is
qaEiydaka A@ll~`ha]. You say, interrogatively, qaEibdakumaA A@ll~`ha A^alamo yakuno ka*aA waka*aA [I beg God to preserve, keep, guard, or watch, thee. Was it not so and so?]: and in the other case, qaEiydaka A@ll~`ha laA^ukoriman~aka [By thy Watcher, or Keeper, God, I will assuredly pay thee honour!] (Th, L.) ― -b6- [And from the signification of ' father ' is derived] the phrase qaEiydaka latafoEalan~a, By thy father, thou shalt assuredly do such a thing. (K, TA.) -A2- What comes to thee from behind thee, (S, L, K,) of gazelles or birds (L, K) or wild animals: contr. of naTyHN: (S, L:) of evil omen. (L.) -A3- The locust of which the wings are not yet perfectly formed. (S, K.)

qaEiydapN *
A thing like the [kind of receptacle called] Eayobap, (L, K,) woven by women, (L,) upon which one sits: (L, K:) pl. qaEaAy^idu. (L.) ― -b2- See qaEadapN -A2- A [sack of the kind called] giraArap: (S, K:) or the like thereof, in which are put qadiyd [or pieces of flesh-meat, q. v.] and kaEok: (L, K:) pl. qaEaAy^idu. (S, L.) -A3- A sand that is not of an oblong form: (S, L, K:) or a long tract of sand like a rope, cleaving to the ground: (L, K:) or a heap of sand collected together. (L.) -A4- See also qaEiydN.

qaE~aAdapN *
A [seat, or couch, of the kind called] sariyr: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

qaAEidN * [act. part. n. of qaEada] Sitting; sitting down; pl. quEuwdN (Msb) and quE~aAdN and qaAEiduwna: (TA:) fem. qaAEidapN; pl. qawaAEidu and qaAEidaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A sack full of grain; (IAar, K;) as though by reason of its fulness it were sitting. (IAar.) ― -b3- [And from qaEada in the third meaning,] qaAEidN Eani Algazowi (tropical:) A man holding back, or abstaining, from warring and plundering: pl. quE~aAdN and qaAEiduwna; and quasi-pl. n. qaEadN: (L:) which last is also explained as signifying those who have no diywaAn [or register in which they are enrolled as soldiers and stipendiaries], (S, A, L, K,) and (as some say, L) who do not go forth to fight. (L, K.) ― -b4- [And hence, the pl.] qaEadN, [which is, properly speaking, a quasi-pl. n.,] like HaArisN and HarasN, (S,) and xaAdimN and xadamN: (TA:) [The Abstainers, or Separatists:] the qaEad (so in the S, L, K: in the A, and some copies of the K, ↓ qaEadap:) are (tropical:) The [schismatics called] xawaArij: (K:) or certain of the xwArj; (S;) a people of the xwArj who held back (qaEaduwA) from aiding 'Alee, and from fighting against him; (A;) certain of the Haruwriy~ap; (L;) the [schismatics called] $uraAp, who hold the doctrine that government belongs only to God, but do not war; (IAar, L;) who hold the doctrine that government belongs only to God, but do not go forth to war against a people. (L.) ― -b5- [And the sing.,] qaAEidN (tropical:) A woman who has ceased to bear children, (S, K,) and to have the menstrual discharge, (ISk, S, K,) and to have a husband: (Zj, K:) or an old woman, advanced in years: (IAth:) pl. qawaAEidu: (ISk, S:) when you mean “ sitting, ” you say qaAEidapN. (ISk, IAth.) ― -b6- naxolapN qaAEidapN (tropical:) A palm-tree bearing fruit one year and not another: (A, TA:) or, that has not borne fruit in its year. (IKtt.) ― -b7- Also, qaAEidN, A palm-tree: or a young palm-tree: pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] qaEadN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN. (L.) ― -b8- qaAEidN (tropical:) A young palm-tree having a trunk: (A, K:) or, [of] which [the branches] may be reached by the hand. (S, K.) Ex. fiY A^aroDihimo ka*aA mina AlqaAEidi In their land are so many young palm-trees having trunks. (A.) Thus it is used us a gen. n. (TA.) -A2- raHFY qaAEidapN A mill which one turns by the handle with the hand. (L.) -A3- Halabota qaAEidFA: see art. Hlb.

qaAEidapN *
A foundation, or basis, of a house: (Msb:) pl. qawaAEidu: (S, Msb:) which signifies, accord. to Zj, the columns, or poles, (A^asaATiyn) of a structure, which support it. (L.) [Hence,] qaAEidataA AlbaAbi [The two side-posts of the door]. (K, in art. swm.) ― -b2- banaY A^amorahu EalaY qaAEidapK, and ElY qawaAEida, (tropical:) [He built his affair upon a firm foundation, and, upon firm foundations]. And qaAEidapu A^amorika waAhiyapN (tropical:) [The foundation of thine affair is unsound]. (A.) ― -b3- qawaAEidu Als~aHaAbi (tropical:) The lower parts of clouds extending across the view in the horizon, likened to the foundations of a building: (A'Obeyd, L:) or clouds extending across the view, and lying low. (IAth, L.) ― -b4- [Hence] qawaAEidu Alhawodaji The four pieces of wood, (S, K,) placed transversely, [two across the other two, so as to form a square frame,] beneath the hwdj (S, K,) which is fixed upon them. (K.) [See 1 in art. f$l.] -A2- As a conventional term, i. q. DaAbiTN, i. e. (assumed tropical:) A universal, or general, rule, or canon. (Msb.) [See DaAbiT.]

A^aqoEadu * A camel having a laxness and depression in the shank. See qaEadN. (TA.) But see A^aSodafa -A2- fulaAnN A^aqoEadu mino fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one is more nearly related to his chief, or oldest, ancestor than such a one. (IAar, IAth, L.) See also quEodudN.

maqoEadN *
A place of sitting; a sitting-place; (L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ maqoEadapN: (L, K:) pl. of the former maqaAEidu, (Msb,) signifying sittingplaces of people in the markets &c. (S.) huwa min~iY maqoEada AlqaAbilapi [He is, with respect to me, as though in the sitting-place of the midwife;] i. e., in nearness; meaning he is sticking close to me, before me: (Sb, S:) denoting nearness of station. (Sb, L.) See also maEoqidN. ― -b2- [Hence, (tropical:) a place of abode,] tarakuwA maqaAEidahumo, (tropical:) They left their places of abode. (A.) ― -b3- A time of sitting. (MF.) ― -b4- ↓ AlmaqoEadapu The anus [as is shown in the S and Msb, voce baAsuwr &c., and so in modern Arabic; and app. also the posteriors, upon which one sits]: syn. Als~aAflapu. (S, Msb.)

muqoEadN * (tropical:) Having a disease which constrains him to remain sitting: (K:) or crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, by a disease in his body; (Mgh, L;) as though the disease constrained him to remain sitting: (Mgh:) or deprived of the power to stand, by protracted disease; as though constrained to remain sitting: (L:) or affected by a disease in his body depriving him of the power to walk: (Msb:) a lame man (S, L:) also, i. q. zaminN: (Msb:) accord. to the physicians, muqoEadN and zaminN are syn.; [see the second explanation above, which is that here indicated;] but some make a distinction, and say that the former signifies having the limbs contracted, and the latter, having a protracted disease; (Mgh;) [which is app. one of the two significations assigned to the former word in the Msb:] accord. to some, it is from quEaAdN signifying a disease which affects camels in their haunches: (L:) [and] muqoEadN [is applied to] a camel having this disease. (L.) ― -b2- muqoEadu Aln~asabi, and mqEd AlA^asobaAbi, (assumed tropical:) A man of short lineage. (L.) ― -b3- muqoEadu AlHasabi (assumed tropical:) A man without eminence, or nobility. (L.) See also quEodudN. -A2- muqoEadu AlA^anofi (tropical:) A man having wide nostrils: (K:) or having wide and short nostrils. (A, L.) vadoYN muqoEadN (tropical:) A breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant, (S, A, L, K,) that fills the hand, (A,) and has not yet become folding. (S, L, K.) -A3- biy^orN muqoEadapN A well that is partly dug, and then left before the water has come into it; (K;) i. q. musohabapN. (TA.) -A4- muqoEadaAtN (tropical:) Young birds of the kind called qaTFA, before they rise (L, K) to fly. (L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Frogs. (A, L, K.)

A^axa*ahu Almuqiymu AlmuqoEidu * (tropical:) (A) Griefs took hold upon him, disquieting him so that he could not remain at rest, and making him to stand up and sit down: a phrase similar to A^axa*ahu maA qaduma wamaA Haduva, and maA qaruba wamaA baEuda. (Mgh, art. qdm.) -A2- muqoEidN and ↓ muqaE~idN A servant. (IAar, L.)
maqoEadahN * and AlmaqoEadapu: see maqoEadu.
muqoEadapu * and muqoEadaAtN: see muqoEadN.
muqaE~idN * : see muqoEidN.

1 qaEurati Albiy^oru * , aor.
qaEura , inf. n. qaEaArapN, The well was deep; had a deep bottom. (S, K. *) -A2- qaEara Albiy^ora, (S, K,) aor.
qaEara , inf. n. qaEorN, (TA,) He reached the bottom of the well; (K;) he descended the well until he reached the bottom of it: (S:) or the same verb; (IAar, K;) or ↓ qaE~arahaA, (A,) inf. n.
taqoEiyrN; (S;) and ↓ A^aqoEarahaA; (A;) he made the well deep. (IAar, S, * A, K.) ― -b2- qaEara AlA_inaA='a, (S, K,) or ↓ tqE~rhu, (A,) (tropical:) He drank what was in the vessel, (S, A. K,) or all that was in the vessel, (TA,) until he came to the bottom of it. (S, A, TA.) And in like manner, qaEara Alv~ariydapa (tropical:) He ate the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth] from the bottom of it. (K.) ― -b3- qaEara Al$~ajarapa, (S, A,) inf. n. qaEorN, (S,) (tropical:) He pulled out the tree from its root; uprooted it. (S, A.) And qaEara Aln~axolapa, aor.
qaEara , (tropical:) He cut down the palm-tree from its root. (K.) And qaEarahu (assumed tropical:) He threw him down prostrate. (K.)

2 qaE~ara see 1. ― -b2- qaE~ara fiY kalaAmihi He twisted the sides of his mouth in his speaking, and spoke with the furthest part of his mouth; as also ↓ tqE~r: (K:) or both signify, he spoke [gutturally, or] with the furthest part of his fauces: (TA:) [he was guttural in his speech, or spoke with a guttural voice.] See qE~b.

4 AqEr Albiy^ora *
He made a bottom to the well. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 tqE~r *
He went deep; syn. taEam~aqa. (S.) See Eajorafiy~ap. ― -b2- (tropical:) He, or it, became prostrated, and overturned. (TA.) [See also 7.] -A2- tqE~r AlA_inaA='a: see 1.

7 AnqErt Al$~ajarapu * , (S, A,) or Aln~axolapu, (K,) (tropical:) The tree, (S, A,) or palm-tree, (K,) became uprooted, (S, A, K,) and fell prostrate; (TA;) it fell down: (K:) or, as some say, it went into the bottom [or depth] of the earth [and disappeared, leaving no mark nor trace: see the part. n., below]: (TA:) and, accord. to some, AnqEr, said of anything, signifies it became prostrated. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- AnqEr Eano maAlK lahu (assumed tropical:) He died, leaving property that belonged to him: (TA, from a trad.:) and AnqEr [simply] he died. (TA.)

qaEorN * The bottom, lowest depth, or extremity of the lower part, [of the interior,] of a thing; (Msb;) i. q. EumoqN, of a well &c.; (S;) the remotest part of anything; (A, K;) [as, for instance,] of a river, (TA,) and of a vessel; (S, A;) pl. quEuwrN. (Msb, K.) You say jalasa fiY qaEori bayotihi, [lit., He sat in the innermost part of his house,] meaning (assumed tropical:) he kept in his house. (Msb.) And laA A^adoxulu Ealayohi qaEora Albayoti, and ↓ qaEiyratahu, and ↓ qaEoratahu, all signify the same [I will not go in to him in the innermost part of the house; or (assumed tropical:) I will not be an intimate in his house]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Depth, properly and tropically. You say] *ahaba fY qaEori AlA^aroDi [It (a tree or the like) went into the depth of the earth]. (TA.) And fulaAnN baEiydu AlqaEori (A, TA) (tropical:) Such a one is deep and excellent in judgment; one who examines deeply. (TA.) And layosa likalaAmihi qaEorN (tropical:) [His speech, or language, has not depth]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- The root, or lower or lowest part, of a palm-tree [or the like]. (TA.) ― -b4- A hollow in the ground, such as is called a jawobap, (K, TA,) the descent into which and the ascent from which are difficult; (TA;) as also ↓ qaEorapN. ― -b5- A city, or town; syn. baladN; (K;) such as El-Basrah or ElKoofeh. (AZ.) You say maA fiY h`*aA AlqaEori mivoluhu There is not in this city, or town, the like of him. (K.) And maA xaraja mino A^aholi h`*aA AlqaEori A^aHadN mivoluhu, like as you say mino A^aholi h`*aA AlgaAy^iTi, There came not forth, of the people of this city, or town, any one like him. (AZ.) ― -b6- A [bowl, such as is called] jafonap. (Fr, IAar, K.)

qaEarN *
Intellect, or intelligence: (K:) or full, or perfect, [or profound,] intellect or intelligence. (IAar, TA.) [See also qaEorN.]
qaEorapN * : see qaEorN, in two places. ― -b2- What covers the bottom of a bowl; as also ↓ quEorapN. (K.) See qaEoraAnu.
quEorapN * : see qaEorapN.
qaSoEapN qaEirapN * : see qaEoraAnu. ― -b2- See also $afirapN.

qaEoraAnu * A drinking-cup or bowl (qadaHN) made deep; i. q. muqaE~arN. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A vessel nearly full: (A:) or a vessel having something in its bottom: (K:) fem. qaEoraY: (TA:) and qaSoEapN qaEoraY, and ↓ qaEarpN, (tropical:) a bowl having in it what covers its bottom. (K, TA.)
qaEuwrN * : see qaEiyrN, in two places.

qaEiyrN *
Deep; having a remote bottom; (A, K;) applied to a river; as also ↓ qaEuwrN, accord. to the K; but this is not mentioned by any one before the author of the K, and is a mistake for ↓ qaE~uwrN, which occurs afterwards in the K. (TA.) You say biy^orN qaEiyrapN, (A,) and ↓ qaE~uwrN, (K, TA,) A deep well; (K, TA;) a well having a remote bottom. (TA.) And qaSoEapN qaEiyrapN (S, A) (tropical:) A deep bowl. (TA.) ↓ qaEuwrN is also applied as an epithet to a woman's vulva: (Ibn-Habeeb, TA in art. xjY:) and, accord. to the K, to a woman. (TA in that art.)
qaEiyrapN * : see qaEorN: ― -b2- and qaEiyrN. ― -b3- See also $afiyrapN.
qaE~uwrN * : see qaEiyrN.

[
A^aqoEaru *
Deeper.]

miqoEarN * , (so in a copy of the A,) or ↓ muqaE~arN, like muEaZ~amN [in measure], (so in the TA,) [but the former I think the correct form, being agreeable with analogy,] A man who reaches the bottoms, or utmost points, of things, or affairs. (A, TA.)
muqaE~arN * : see qaEoraAnu: ― -b2- and miqoEarN.
muqaE~irN * : see muqaE~bN in art. qEb.
miqoEaArN * , applied to a [cup of the kind called] qaEob, Wide and deep. (K.)

munoqaEirN *
Uprooted. So in the Kur, [liv. 20,] kaA^an~ahumo A^aEojaAzu naxolK munoqaEirK As though they were the lower parts of palm-trees uprooted: (TA:) or the meaning is, extirpated, by going into the bottom [or depth] of the earth, so as to leave no mark nor trace. (El-Basáïr, TA.)

1 qaEisa * , aor.
qaEasa , (TK,) inf. n. qaEasN, (S, A, K,) He (a man, TK) had a protruding, or protuberant, breast, or chest, and a hollow, or receding, back; qaEasN being the contr. of HadabN. (S, A, K, TK.) [And in like manner,] qaEasN in a bow is A bending outwards of its inner side, in its middle, and a bending inwards of its outer side. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6, in two places. -A2- qaEasa Al$~aYo'a, [aor.
qaEasa ,] inf. n. qaEosN, He bent the thing; as also ↓ qE~shu. (TA.)
2 qaE~asa see 1, last signification.
5 taqaE~asa see 6, in two places.

6 tqAEs *
He made his [meaning his own] breast, or chest, to stick out. (A.) ― -b2- He drew back, and became refractory, and made himself like him who has a hollow, or receding, back, and a protruding, or protuberant, breast, or chest. (Har, p. 17.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He drew back; held back; or hung back. (S, K.) You say, tqAEs Eani AlA^amori (tropical:) He drew back, held back, or hung back, from the thing, or affair, and would not go forward in it; (S, TA;) as also ↓ qaEisa, inf. n. qaEasN; and ↓ tqE~s: (TA:) in some copies of the S, instead of tqAEs, in this phrase, we find ↓ taqaEowasa. (TA.) And [in like manner,] ↓ AiqoEanosasa (assumed tropical:) He drew back; he receded, or went backwards. (S, K.) When a man draws water without a pulley, pulling the rope at the head of the well, his back pains him, and it is said to him, waA@jo*ibi Ald~alowa ↓ AiqoEanosiso (assumed tropical:) [Go thou backwards, and pull the bucket]. This verb is without idghám because it is quasi-coördinate to AiHoranojama. (S.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He (a horse, S, K) drew back, or held back, and would not go forward: (S:) or would not submit to his leader; (K;) [as also ↓ AqEnss; as appears from an explanation of its part. n., below.] You say also, Ald~aAb~apu ↓ tqE~st, meaning (assumed tropical:) The beast of carriage stood still, and would not move from its place. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) [He (a man) and] it (might or strength) was, or became, firm, or steady, and resisted; [as also ↓ AqEnss; as appears from an explanation of its part. n., below:] and ↓ AqEnss (assumed tropical:) he was, or became, firm, and did not bow his head: and qaEisa, inf. n. qaEasN, (assumed tropical:) he (a man) was, or became, inaccessible, or unapproachable, and mighty, or strong, and firm, or steady. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) It (the night) was, or became, long, or protracted; as though it did not quit its place; like baraka. (A, TA.) See A^aqoEasu.
Q. Q. 2 taqaEowasa * : see 6.
R. Q. 3 A_iqoEanosasa * : see 6, in five places.
qaEisN * : see A^aqoEasu.
quEayosN * : see muqoEanosisN.
quEayosisN * : see muqoEanosisN.
quEayosiysN * : see muqoEanosisN.
quEayonisN * : see muqoEanosisN.

A^aqoEasu *
Having a protruding, or protuberant, breast, or chest, and a hollow, or receding, back; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ qaEisN (S, K) and ↓ mutaqaAEisN: (S:) [or the last rather signifies making his breast, or chest, to stick out: see its verb:] fem. of the first, qaEosaA='u; (K;) applied to a woman [&c.]: and pl. quEosN: the dim. of the first is A^uqayoEisu. (TA.) [See A^ajonaA^u and A^afozaru.] ― -b2- Applied to a horse, Having the Sahowap [or place of the saddle], (K,) or the spine in that part, (S,) depressed, and the qaTaAp [or part next behind] elevated; (S, K;) [i. e., saddle-backed.] ― -b3- Applied to a camel, Having the head and neck and back inclining: (K:) or having the head and neck inclining towards the back: (S:) the latter is the right explanation. (TA.) Hence the saying, Aibonu xamosK Ea$aA='u xalifaAtK quEosK, meaning, The tarrying of the moon five nights old until it sets is like the tarrying during the evening feed of pregnant camels having their heads and necks inclining towards their backs. (S, TA.) [See EatamapN.] The same epithet applied to a camel also signifies Having a shortness in the hind legs, and a sloping in the withers. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, the fem., qaEosaA='u, applied to an ant (namolap), Raising its breast and its tail: (K:) pl. quEosN and qaEosaAwaAtN. (TA.) ― -b5- And applied to a bow (qawos,) Having a bending outwards of its inner side, in its middle, and a bending inwards of its outer side. (TA.) ― -b6- Also A^aqoEasu, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Inaccessible, or unapproachable, (S, K, TA,) and mighty, or strong, and firm, or steady. (TA.) You say also, Eiz~N A^aqoEasu (A) and Eiz~apN qaEosaA='u (S, A) (tropical:) Firm might or strength. (S.) [See also muqoEanosisN.] ― -b7- layolN A^aqoEasu (tropical:) A long, or protracted, night; (A, K;) as though it did not quit its place. (S, A.) And sinuwna quEosN (assumed tropical:) Years lasting long. (TA.)

muqoEanosisN * (assumed tropical:) Drawing back; holding back; or hanging back: [see its verb:] (TA:) or strong; powerful; mighty: (S, K, TA:) also anything drawing in his head upon his neck, like him who refrains, or defends himself, from a thing: a camel that resists being led: anything that resists, or withstands: might, or power, that resists, or withstands, injury. (TA.) [See also A^aqoEasu.] The pl. is maqaAEisu and maqaAEiysu; (S, K;) the addition of the Y being in this case optional. (S.) The dim. is muqayoEisN, or muqayoEiysN, (Sb, S, K,) or quEayosisN and quEayosiysN, (TA,) or quEayonisN, (S, TA,) or quEayosN: (TA: and so in some copies of the K:) Mbr objected to the first and second of these, as not agreeable with analogy; and preferred the third and fourth, or, accord. to the S, the fifth, or, as some say, the last. (TA.)
mutaqaAEisN * : see A^aqoEasu.
1 qaEaSahu * : see 4, throughout. -A2- quEiSati Alganamu The sheep, or goats, were seized, or affected, with the disease called quEaAS, q. v. (S, K.)

4 AqEShu *
He slew him on the spot; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ qaEaSahu, (A, K,) aor.
qaEaSa , (K,) inf. n. qaEoSN: (TK:) or both signify he slew him quickly: or the former signifies he struck, or shot at, it, (a thing, or an object of the chase,) and it died on the spot, before it was [struck or] shot: and he hastened and completed, or made sure or certain, his (a man's) slaughter: and ↓ qiEoSapN is a subst. derived from it [app. signifying the act]. (L, TA.) You say also, AqEShu biAlr~umoHi, and ↓ qaEaSahu, He thrust him, or pierced him, with the spear, quickly: or from behind. (TA.)

7 AnqES *
He died. (K.)

qaEoSN *
A quick death: (S, A, K:) and a quick slaughter; as also ↓ qaEaSN. (TA.) You say, maAta qaEoSFA He (a man, S, A) died on the spot, from a blow or a shot. (S, A, K.) And it is said in a trad., mano xaraja mujaAhidFA fiY sabiyli A@ll~`hi faqutila qaEoSFA faqadi A@sotawojaba AlmaA=ba [Whoso goeth forth as a warrior in the cause of God, and is slain quickly, or suddenly, has a just claim to the permanent abode of happiness in the other world]: (S, * TA:) alluding to the mA=b mentioned in the Kur xxxviii. 24 and 39. (Az, TA.)
qaEaSN * : see qaEoSN.
qiEoSapN * : see 4.

TaEonapN qaEoSaA='u *
A thrust, or wound, with a spear or the like, that kills quickly. (TA.)

quEaASN *
A certain disease which attacks sheep or goats, (S, A, K,) in consequence of which something flows from their noses, (TA,) killing them immediately, (S, A, K,) on the spot: (A:) and which kills men on the spot: (A:) and a certain disease in the breast, or chest, which is as though it broke the neck. (Lth, K.) It is said in a trad., wamuwtaAnN yakuwnu fiY Aln~aAsi kaquEaASi Alganami [And a mortality which shall be among men, like the qEAS of sheep or goats]. (S.)
qaE~aASN * : see what next follows.
miqoEaSN * : see what next follows.
miqoEaASN * A lion that kills quickly; as also ↓ miqoEaSN and ↓ qaE~aASN. (K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

ganamN maqoEuwSapN *
Sheep, or goats, seized, or affected, with the disease called quEaAS: (S, K:) accord. to IAar, ↓ $aApN miqoEaASN signifies a sheep, or goat, having the mortal disease so called. (TA.)

div2.n: qET qEf qEqE qEl qEm qEn qEw qf

head.foreign: qET qEf qEqE qEl qEm qEn qEw qf

div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 qafiy^ati AlA^aroDu * , aor.
qafaAa , inf. n. qafo'N, The land was rained upon, and its herbage became altered and spoiled thereby: (K:) or qafo'N [the inf. n.] signifies the falling of dust upon the herbs, or leguminous plants, (AHn, K, TA,) in consequence of which they are spoiled if the dust be not washed off. (AHn, TA.) [See faqaA^at as said of the buhomaY.]

8 AqtfA^ Alxaroza * is said in the K to be syn. with AftqA^hu, [q. v.,] and is expl. by Lh as meaning He repeated the [kind of sewing termed] xaroz [i. e. the sewing of skins and the like by means of an awl], and added, between the two kulbehs, another kulbeh, as is done with reed-mats when they are re-sewed. (TA.) [The kulbeh (kulobap, q. v.) is here described as a thong, or a strand (TaAqap) of [the membranous fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree and are called] liyf, used in the same manner as the shoemaker's awl, &c., as in art. klb, q. v.; but what is here meant by this word is evidently, I think, a thong, or the like, with which a skin is sewed, agreeably with another explanation of it in art. klb.]

1 qafaxahu * , (S, L,) aor.
qafaxa , (L,) inf. n. qafoxN and qifaAxN, (S, L, K,) He struck him, or it: but the striking termed qfx is only on the head, or on something hollow, (S, L, K,) or on something hard [evidently a mistake for moist, or soft]; (L;) i. q. faqaxahu, (K,) and used by the people of ElYemen in the sense of SaqaEahu: (L:) he struck a person's head with a staff: (L:) he struck a person on the head with a staff. (As.) He broke a person's head: he broke a thing across: he broke the substance called EaromaD upon the surface of water. (L.)

1 qafida * , aor.
qafada , inf. n. qafadN, He was, or became, A^aqofad, or characterized by what is termed qafadN, as explained below, [app. in all the senses of these two words]. (S, L, K, &c.) See Sadifa -A2- qafida, (IKtt,) inf. n. qafadN (S, L, K) and qafodaA='u, (K,)
He wound his turban in a particular manner, not making the end to hang down: (S, IKtt, L, K:) you say also, in this sense, taEam~ama AlqafodaA='a, (IKtt,) and A_iEotam~a AlqfdA': (S:) accord. to Th, he wound his turban upon the qafod of his head: but he does not explain the word qafodN. (L.) ― -b2- qafada, aor.
qafida , (inf. n. qafodN, L,) He struck a person on the back of his neck, (L, K,) or, on his head, (IKtt,) or, on his head at the part next the back of the neck, (L,) with the inside of his hand. (IKtt, L, K.) -A3- qafada, (inf. n. qafodN, TA) He did a deed, or work. (K.)
qafodN * : see qafida.

qafadN * [in the CK, incorrectly, qafodN] The quality denoted by the epithet A^aqofadu, as explained below, [app. in all the senses of this latter word]. (S, L.) ― -b2- An inclining of the foot of a man so that the fore part is seen [distinct] from the hinder part from behind. (L, K.) ― -b3- An erectness of the pastern, and its advancing upon the hoof of a horse: (S, L, K: *) it is only in the hind leg: (A, O, S, L:) is like quwaAmN in the fore legs: (IKtt:) and is a fault: (S, L:) or an elevation of [the tendon called] the EujaAyap, and of the hinder part of the hoof: (L:) or a rigidness in the pastern, as though the animal trod upon the fore part of his hoof. (ISh.) ― -b4- An inclining of a camel's foot (of the fore leg or hind leg, As, S) towards the inner side: (As, S, K:) and in like manner, of a solid hoof: (S, K, voce SadafN:) the verb is qafida; and the epithet, A^aqofadu: (As, S:) an inclining towards the outer side is termed SadafN; (TA;) and the epithet in this case is A^aSodafu: (As, S:) or, as some say, a natural inclining of the fore part of the fore and hind leg of a beast towards the outer side. (L, TA.) ― -b5- A natural rigidness in the hind legs of camels. (L.)
qafadaAnN * (S, L) and ↓ qafadaAnapN (L, K) A xariyTap of leather, for perfumes &c.; (L, K;) the xryTp of a dealer in perfumes: (IDrd, S:) a Persian word [originally qafodaAnu] arabicized. (S, L.)

qafadaAnapN * : see qafadaAnN. ― -b2- Also, The cover (gilaAf) of a vessel in which collyrium (kuHol) is kept; (L, K;) it is made of m$Awr; [a word of which I find no appropriate meaning;] and sometimes, of leather. (L.)

A^aqofadu *
Having the quality termed qafadN, as explained above, [app. in all the senses of this latter word]. (S, L.) See A^aSodafu. ― -b2- A man (S, L) who walks upon the fore parts of his feet, next the toes, his heels not reaching the ground: (S, L, K.) the verb is qafida. (K.) ― -b3- A slave (L) having rigid and contracted arms and legs, with short fingers and toes: (L, K:) the verb is qafida. (K.) ― -b4- A man having a laxness in the heels: fem. qafodaA='u: and in like manner, an ostrich. (Lth, L.) ― -b5- A man weak, and with lax joints. The verb, applied to a member, is qafida, inf. n. qafadN. (L.) ― -b6- A man, and an ostrich, (L,) lax in the neck: (L, K:) the verb, applied to anything that has a neck, is qafida, aor.
qafada , inf. n. qafadN: (IKtt:) or having a thick neck. (L, K.) ― -b7- A horse (S, L) having the pastern erect and advancing upon the hoof (S, L, K) of the hind foot. (AO, S, L.) See qafadN. ― -b8- A camel having his fore or hind foot inclining towards the inner side. (As, S, L.) See qafadN. ― -b9- Eim~apN qafodaA='u A well-known mode of winding the turban, different from the mayolaA='. (T.) See qafida.

1 qafira * , aor.
qafara , (K,) inf. n. qafarN, (TA,) It (food) was without seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (K, TA.) -A2- qafara A^avarahu, (S, K,) aor.
qafura ; (S;) and ↓ Aqtfrhu; and ↓ tqf~rhu; (S, A, K;) (tropical:) He followed his footsteps; tracked him: (S, A, K:) or he followed his footsteps by degrees, and leisurely; syn. tatab~aEahu: (TA:) accord. to Z, from A_iqotafara AlEaZoma. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlEiloma ↓ Zahara qabolanaA naAsN yataqaf~aruwna There appeared before us men searching after knowledge time after time. (TA.) [See also 5 in art. fqr.]

4 Aqfr AlmakaAnu *
The place became vacant, or void; (K;) destitute of herbage or pasturage, [and of water,] and of human beings. (TA.) Aqfrt AlA^aroDu The land became destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water. (A.) Aqfrt Ald~aAru The house became vacant. (S.) Aqfr Alr~ajulu, (K,) or Aqfr mino A^aholihi, (A,) (tropical:) The man became apart from his family, (A, K,) and remained alone. (TA.) ― -b2- Aqfr He came, (S, Msb,) or went, or his course brought him, (S,) to the desert, where was no herbage or vegetable produce, nor water. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He became destitute of food, and hungry. (K, TA.) -A2- Aqfr Albalada He found the country, or town, to be what is termed qafor, (TS, K,) i. e., destitute [of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water, or] of people. (TA.) -A3- Aqfr (tropical:) He ate bread, (A,) or his food, (TA,) without seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He had no seasoning, or condiment, to render his food pleasant, or savoury, remaining with him, or in his abode. (S.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., maA A^aqofara bayotN fiyhi xal~N (S, A) (tropical:) A house in which is vinegar is not destitute of seasoning, or condiment, to render food pleasant, or savoury; its inhabitants are not in want thereof: regarded by 'AObeyd as being from qaforN, meaning a country, or town, “ wherein is nothing. ” (TA.)
5 taqaf~ara see 1, in two places.

8 Aqtfr AlEaZoma *
He ate all the meat that was upon the bone, (K, * TA,) leaving nothing upon it. (TA.) -A2- See also 1.

A^aroDN qaforN * , (S, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ qaforapN, (A, K,) and ↓ miqofaArN, (K,) and ↓ muqofirapN, (A,) Vacant, or void, land, (A, K,) destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water: (S, A, Msb:) and mafaAzapN qaforN, (S, Msb,) and ↓ qaforapN, and ↓ miqofaArN, (S,) a desert destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water: (S, Msb:) or qaqorN signifies a place destitute of human beings, or desert, but sometimes containing a little herbage or pasturage: (Lth, TA:) or baladN qaforN a country, or town, wherein is nothing: (AZ, A'Obeyd:) and daArN qaforN a house destitute of inhabitants; deserted; or desolate: (Msb:) the pl. (of qaforN, S, Msb) is qifaArN (S, Msb, K) and qufuwrN: (K:) and you say also A^aroDN qifaArN, (A, Msb, TA,) imagining it as comprising places; and in like manner, daArN qifaArN: (Msb, TA:) and [in a contrary manner,] A^araDuwna qafurN, and bilaAdN qaforN; as well as qifaArN: (A:) but when you make qafurN a subst., [not meaning A^aroDN or the like to be understood,] (Msb,) or use a single term, (TA,) or apply it as an appellative to a land, (L, TA,) you add p, and say ↓ qaforapN, (Msb,) and A_inotahayonaA A_ilaY qaforapK mina AlA^aroDi [We came at last to a land destitute of herbage and of water]. (L, TA.) ― -b2- nazalonaA bibaniY fulaAnK fabitonaA Alqafora (tropical:) [We alighted at the abode of the sons of such a one, and passed the night] without being entertained by them as guests. (S.) ― -b3- nabotu Alqafori is a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) The stone, and the rock. (TA.) -A2- See also qafaArN.
qaforapa * : see qaforN, in three places.

xubozN qafaArN * , (S, A, K,) and ↓ qaforN, (K,) and TaEaAm qafaArN, (TA,) and ↓ qafiyrN, (K,) (tropical:) [Bread, and food,] without any seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (S, A, K.) You say A^akala xubozahu qafaArFA (tropical:) [He ate his bread without any seasoning, &c.]. (S.) And sawiyqN qafaArN (tropical:) [Meal of parched barley or wheat] not moistened with any seasoning, or condiment, &c. (K, * TA.)
qafiyrN * : see qafaArN.
muqofiyrN * : see qaforN. ― -b2- Also, Destitute of food. (TA.)
miqofaArN * : see qaforN, in two places.

1 qafaza * , aor.
qafiza , inf. n. qafozN (S, A, Msb, K) and qafazaAnN (S, Msb, K) and qufuwzN and qifaAzN, (Msb, and so in a copy of the K,) the last with kesr, (Msb,) or qufaAzN, (K accord. to the TA,) with damm, (TA,) or qafaAzN, (so in the CK,) He leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded: (S, A, Msb, K:) he (an antelope) did so and alighted with his legs together. (TA, art. nfz.) ― -b2- qafaza AlHaAy^iTa [He leaped the wall]. (O and K in art. zyf.) -A2- See also 5. -A3- qafiza, aor.
qafaza , inf. n. qafaza, (tropical:) He (a horse) had fore legs white as high as his mirofaqaAni [properly signifying the elbows; but here, probably meaning, as it seems to do in some other instances, the knees], but not the kind legs. (IKtt, TA. [And ↓ quf~iza app. has a similar meaning: see its inf. n. tqfyz below; and its part. n. muqaf~azN, voce A^aqofazu.]) But see A^aqofazu, and quf~aAzN.
2 qaf~aza see what next precedes.

5 tqf~z * [He put on, or wore, a pair of gloves; as also ↓ qafaza, aor.
qafiza , as appears from a quotation in the L, from Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, viz. Alquf~aAzaAni taqofizuhumaA AlmaroA^apu:] he (a sportsman [or falconer]) put on, or wore, hawking-gloves (quf~aAzaAni): (A:) or took or prepared for himself the reticulated iron thing upon which the falcon sits. (TA, as from Z.) See quf~aAz. ― -b2- taqf~zt biA@loHin~aA='i, said of a woman, (S, A,) (tropical:) She dyed her hands (A, K) to the wrists, (A,) and her feet, (K,) with Hn~A='. (A, K.)
6 tqAfzwA * [They contended together, or vied, one with another, in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding]. You say so of children playing at the game called quf~ayozaY. (A, K.)

[
qufozapN *
A leap, jump, spring, or bound.]

qafazaY *
A leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding. (K.) You say, jaA='ati Alxayolu taEoduw AlqafazaY [The horses came running with a leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding, motion]; from Alqafozu [inf. n. of qafaza]. (S, TA.)
qafuwzN * : see qaf~aAzN.

qafiyzN *
A certain measure of capacity, consisting of ten makaAkiyk [pl. of mak~uwko]; (S, Msb, K;) accord. to the people of El-'Irák: (TA:) or twelve times what is termed man~: (Mgh in art. rbE:) [see also jariybN, in three places: and see SaAEN:] pl. [of pauc.] A^aqofizapN, and [of mult.] qufozaAnN (S, Msb, K) and qifozaAnN. (Fr, Sgh.) [See kur~N, throughout.] qafiyzu AlT~aH~aAni [The qfyz of the grinder] is when one says, “ I will grind for so much and a qfyz of the flour itself: ” so says Ibn-El-Mubárak: or when one hires a man to grind for him a certain quantity of wheat for a qfyz of its flour, (TA,) or when one says, “ I hire thee to grind this wheat for a pound of its flour, ” for instance; whether there be something else therewith or not: (Msb:) what is thus termed is forbidden. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Also, A certain measure of land; (T, Msb, K;) namely, the tenth of a jariyb, q. v.: (Msb:) or a hundred and fortyfour cubits. (K.)

qaf~aAzN *
That leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, much, or often; (A, * Msb;) [and so ↓ qafuwzN, occurring in art. rfA^ in the M and K, applied as an epithet to a gazelle.] ― -b2- Hence, qaf~aAzapN A female slave: because she seldom remains still. You say, yaA A@bona Alqaf~aAzapi O son of the female slave. (A.)

quf~aAzN *
A kind of glove; a thing which is made for the two hands, or hands and arms, stuffed with cotton, (S, L, K,) and having buttons which are buttoned upon the fore arms, (S, L,) worn by a woman as a protection from the cold; (S, L, K;) they are made of skins, and of felt; are worn by the women of the Arabs of the desert; and extend to the bones of the elbow: (L, TA:) a pair of them is called quf~aAzaAni: (S, L:) or a thing which the women of the Arabs of the desert make for themselves, stuffed with cotton, covering a woman's two hands, with her fingers, and, some add, having buttons upon the fore arm; like what the carrier of the falcon wears: (Msb:) or a thing which those women make for themselves, covering the fingers and hand and arm: and a thing which the sportsman [meaning the falconer] wears upon each hand, or hand and arm, of skin, or of felt, or wool: (Mgh:) or a kind of women's ornament for the hands and feet, or the hands and arms and the feet and legs: and a reticulated iron thing (HadiydapN mu$ab~akapN, accord. to the TA, as from the K, but in the CK mu$otabikapN,) upon which the falcon sits. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] Whiteness in the A^a$aAEir [or hairs next the hoof] of a horse. (K. [See also qafiza, and quf~aza, and A^aqofazu.])

quf~ayozaY *
A certain game of children, who set up pieces of wood, or a piece of wood, (the former accord. to the A, and the latter accord. to the K) and leap over them, or it. (A, K, TA.)

qaAfizN *
Leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding. (Msb.) ― -b2- x`ayolN qaAfizapN, and qawaAfizu, Swift horses, that leap, jump, spring, or bound, in their running. (K.) ― -b3- AlqawaAfizu The frogs. (Sgh, K.)

A^aqofazu * (S, K) and ↓ muqaf~azN (S, A, K) (tropical:) A horse whose whiteness of the lower parts of his fore legs extends as far as his mirofaqaAni [properly signifying the elbows; but here, probably meaning, as it seems to do in some other instances, the knees], without his having the like in the hind legs; (S, K;) as though he had gloves (quf~aAzaAni) put upon him: (S:) or whose whiteness of the lower parts of the legs does not extend beyond the A^a$aAEir [or hairs next the hoof]; as also munaE~alN. (A, TA.)

taqofiyzN *
A scattered whiteness intermingling in the shanks, as far as the knees, of a daAb~ap [meaning, horse]: a signification wrongly assigned by Lth to taqofiyr. (TA in art. fqr.)
muqaf~azN * : see A^aqofazu.

1 qafaSahu * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
qafuSa , (TK,) inf. n. qafoSN, (M, TA,) He collected it, gathered it, or put it, together; namely, a thing: (M, Msb:) or he put, or brought, one part, or parts, thereof near to another, or others: (K:) or he collected it, gathered it, or put it, together, and connected, or conjoined, one part, or parts, thereof with another, or others. (Jm, TA.) ― -b2- He collected, or put, together his legs; namely, those of a beast of carriage: (Msb:) or he tied, or bound, his legs, and collected, or put, them together; namely, those of an antelope; (AA, A 'Obeyd, M, A, K;) and those of a beast of carriage; as also ↓ qf~Shu. (L.) ― -b3- He tied it, (namely, the yaEosuwb, K, i. e., the male bee, TA,) in the hive, with a thread, that it might not go forth. (K.)
2 qaf~aSa see 1.

4 AqfS *
He (a man, TA) had a cage, or coop, (qafaS,) of birds. (K.)
5 taqaf~aSa see 6.

6 tqAfS *
It (a thing, M, A, meaning anything, TA) was, or became, complicated, or confused; [either properly, as when said of a cage or the like; or tropically, as when said of an affair of the mind;] (M, A, K, TA;) as also ↓ tqf~S: (TA:) or the latter signifies it was, or became, collected, gathered, or put, together. (IF, K, TA.)
qafoSN * : see what next follows.
qufoSN * : see what next follows.

qafaSN *
A cage, coop, or place of confinement, (A, K,) or thing made of canes or reeds, or of wood, (M, TA,) [or of palm-sticks, &c.,] for a bird or birds: (S, M, A, K:) said by some to be an arabicized word [from the Persian qafasN]: by others, to be Arabic, from qafaSahu in the first of the senses explained above: (Msb:) pl. A^aqofaASN. (S, A, Msb.) ― -b2- [It is also applied to The cageformed structure of the bones of the thorax: (see ZaribaAnN:) and is used in this sense in the present day.] ― -b3- Also, A certain implement for seedproduce; (K;) or a thing composed of two curved pieces of wood between which is a net; (M, L;) upon which wheat is conveyed to the heap where it is trodden out. (M, L, K.) ― -b4- fiY qafaSK mina AlmalaAy^ikapi, (M, Msb,) or qafaDK mina Aln~uwri, (M,) or mn AlmlAy^kp ↓ fY qufoSK, or qufoSK mn Alnwr, [so in several copies of the K, but accord. to the TA, mn Alnwr ↓ qafoSK, being there said to be in the former case with damm, and in the latter with fet-h,] and qafaSK, (K,) occurring in a trad., (M, Msb, K,) means, (assumed tropical:) In an assemblage of angels: (Msb:) or in a confused assemblage of angels: and in a confused mixture of light. (M, Sgh, K.)

qaf~aASN *
A maker of cages or coops. (TA.)

rjulN muqofiSN TayorFA *
A man having a cage, or coop, of birds. (TA, from a trad.)

muqaf~aSN * [in the L, and TA without any syll. signs: but in the latter said to be like mkrm, by which is generally meant mukoramN: in the L, however, it is mentioned after qaf~aSa AlZ~aboYa as meaning “ he tied, or bound, the legs of the antelope: ” and this indicates that it is as I have written it:] Having his arms and legs, or fore legs and hind legs, tied, or bound. (L, TA.) ― -b2- vawobN muqaf~aSN A
garment, or piece of cloth, marked with lines in the form of a qafaS. (K.)
See Supplement

qayoqabN * and ↓ qayoqabaAnN A certain wood of which horses' saddles are made; (IDrd, S, O, K;) called in Pers. A=zaAd diraxot. (IDrd, S, O.) [See also qaboqabN, in art. qb.] ― -b2- And, both words, A horse's saddle itself. (IDrd, O, K.) [See, again, qaboqabN.] ― -b3- And the former word signifies A strap, or thong, that surrounds the pommel and troussequin of a horse's saddle: (O, K:) or, as used by post-classical authors, a strap, or thong, that is put across behind the troussequin of a saddle. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b4- And [The bit-mouth, or mouth-piece of a bit; also called the $akiymap; i. e.] the part of a bit in the middle of which is the faA^os. (O, K.)
qayoqaAbN * The xarazap [app. a polished stone, or a shell,] with which cloths are glazed. (O, K.) [See also qaboqaAbN, last sentence, in art. qb.]
qayoqabaAnN * : see the first paragraph, above.
See Supplement

1 qalabahu * , (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
qaliba , (Msb, K.) inf. n. qalobN, (Msb,) He altered, or changed, its, or his, mode, or manner, of being; (A, Mgh, Msb, * K;) and ↓ ql~bhu signifies the same, (K,) or is like qalabahu in the sense expl. above and in other senses but denotes intensiveness and muchness; (Msb;) and ↓ Aqlbhu also signifies the same as qalabahu in the sense expl. above, (K,) on the authority of Lh, but is of weak authority. (TA.) Hence, (Mgh,) He inverted it; turned it upside-down; turned it so as to make its upper most part its undermost; (S, * A, * Mgh, Msb;) namely, a thing; (S;) for instance, a [garment of the kind called] ridaA=': (A, * Mgh:) and ↓ ql~bhu has a similar meaning, but [properly] denotes intensiveness and muchness. (Msb. See two exs. of the latter verb voce qalabapN.) And, (A, K,) like ↓ ql~bhu, [except that the latter properly denotes intensiveness and muchness,] (K,) it signifies Haw~alahu ZahorFA libaTonK (A, K) [He turned it over, or upsidedown as meaning so that the upper side became the under side; lit. back for belly; accord. to the TA, meaning back upon belly (ZahorFA EalaY baTonK); but this is hardly conceivable; whereas the former explanation is obviously right in another case: (see 5:) and another meaning of qalabahu and ↓ qulbhu, i. e. he turned it inside-out, is indicated in the TA by its being added, so that he knew what was in it]. ― -b2- See an ex. voce qalaAbi. One says, qalaba kalaAmFA [meaning He altered, or changed, the order of the words of a sentence or the like, by inversion, or by any transposition]. (TA.) [And in like manner, qalaba kalimapF He altered, or changed, the order of the letters of a word, by inversion, or by any transposition.] Es-Sakháwee says, in the Expos. of the Mufassal, that when they transpose [the letters of a word], they do not assign to the [transformed] derivative an inf. n., lest it should be confounded with the original, using only the inf. n. of the original that it may be an evidence of the originality [of the application of the latter to denote the signification common to both]: thus they say yay^isa, inf. n. yaA^osN; and A^ayisa is minohu ↓ maqoluwbN [i. e. formed by transposition, or metathesis, from it], and has no inf. n.: when the two inf. ns. exist, the grammarians decide that each of the two verbs is [to be regarded as] an original, and that neither is mqlwb from the other, as in the case of ja*aba and jaba*a: but the lexicologists [in general] assert that all such are [of the class termed] mqlwb. (Mz, close of the 33rd nwE.) [And qalaba likewise signifies He changed, or converted, a letter into another letter; the verb in this sense being doubly trans.: for ex., one says, qalaba AlwaAwa yaA='F He changed, or converted, the w into Y.] ― -b3- And [hence] one says, qalabahu Eano wajohihi (assumed tropical:) He turned him [from his manner, way, or course, of acting, or proceeding, &c.]: and Lh has mentioned ↓ Aqlbhu [in the same sense], but as being disapproved. (TA.) And qalaba AlS~iboyaAna (tropical:) He (the teacher) turned away [or dismissed] the boys to their dwellings: (Th, A, TA:) or sent them [away], and returned them, to their abodes: and Lh has mentioned ↓ Aqlbhm as a dial. var. of weak authority, saying that the former verb is that which is used by the Arabs in this and other [similar] cases. (TA.) And qalabotu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) I turned away [or dismissed] the people, or party; (Th, S, O;) like as you say Sarafotu AlS~iboyaAna. (Th, S.) And qalaba A@ll~`hu fulaAnFA A_ilayohi (assumed tropical:) [God translated such a one unto Himself, by death: meaning God took his soul]; as also ↓ Aqlbh; (K, TA;) whence the saying of Anooshirwán, A@ll~`hu muqolaba A^awoliyaAy^ihi ↓ A^aqolabakumu (assumed tropical:) [May God translate you with the translating of his favourites (mqlb being here an inf. n.), meaning, as He translates his favourites]. (TA.) ― -b4- And qalaba Eayonahu, and HimolaAqahu, (TA,) or HimolaAqa Eayonihi, (A,) [He turned about, or rolled, his eye, and therefore the parts of his eye that are occasionally covered by the eyelids,] on the occasion of anger, (A, TA,) and of threatening. (TA.) ― -b5- qalaba, aor.
qaliba , inf. n. qalobN; and ↓ Aqlb likewise, but this is of weak authority, mentioned by Lh; signify also He turned over bread, and the like, when the upper part thereof was thoroughly baked, in order that the under side might become so. (TA.) And you say, qalabotu AlA_inaA='a EalaY raA^osihi [I turned over the vessel upon its head]. (Msb, in explanation of kababotu AlA_inaA='a.) And qalabotu AlA^aroDa lilz~iraAEapi [I turned over the earth for sowing]: and ↓ qal~abotuhaA, also, I did so much.] (Msb.) And yuqolabu Alt~uraAbu biAlHafori [The earth is turned over in digging]: whence qalabotu qaliybFA means I dug a well. (A.) ― -b6- And [hence also] one says, qalabotu Al$~aYo'a liloAibotiyaAEi I turned over the thing, or (assumed tropical:) I examined the several parts, or portions, of the thing, (taSaf~aHotuhu,) [or I turned over the thing for the purpose of examining it,] with a view to purchasing, and saw its outer part or side, and its inner part or side: and ↓ qal~abotuhu, also, I did so much. (Msb.) And qalaba Als~iloEapa (tropical:) He (a trafficker) examined the commodity, and scrutinized its condition: and ↓ qal~abahaA, also, he did so [much]. (A.) And qalaba Ald~aAb~apa and AlgulaAma (tropical:) [He examined, &c., the beast, or horse, or the like, and the youth, or young man, or male slave]: (A:) and qalaba Almamoluwka, aor.
qaliba , inf. n. qalobN, (tropical:) he uncovered and examined the male slave, to look at [or to see] his defects, on the occasion of purchasing. (O, TA.) And qalabotu AlA^amora ZahorFA libaTonK (assumed tropical:) I considered [or turned over in my mind] what might be the issues, or results, of the affair, or case: and ↓ qal~abotuhu, also, I did so much. (Msb.) -A2- qalabN signifies AinoqilAbN, (S, A, O, K, TA,) meaning A turning outward, (TK,) and being flabby, (TA,) of the lip, (S, A, O, K,) or of the upper lip, (TA,) of a man: (S, A, O, K, TA:) it is the inf. n. of qalibat said of the lip (Al$~afapu); (TA;) [and also, accord. to the TK, of qaliba said of a man as meaning His lip had what is termed qalabN:] and hence ↓ A^aqolabu as an epithet applied to a man; and [its fem.] ↓ qalobaA=' as an epithet applied to a lip. (S, A, O, K, TA.) -A3- qalabahu, (S, A, O, K,) aor.
qaluba (Lh, K) and
qaliba , (K,) He (a man, S, O) hit his heart. (S, A, O, K.) And It (a disease) affected, or attacked, his heart. (A.) And quliba He (a man) was affected, or attacked, by a pain in his heart, (Fr, A, * TA,) from which one hardly, or nowise, becomes free. (Fr, TA.) And quliba said of a camel, (As, S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. qulaAbN, (As, S, TA,) He was attacked by the disease called qulaAb expl. below: (As, S, O, K, TA:) or he was attacked suddenly by the [pestilence termed] gud~ap, and died in consequence. (As, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qalaba Aln~axolapa (tropical:) He plucked out the qalob, or qulob, meaning heart, of the palm-tree. (S, A, O, K.) ― -b3- And qalabati Albusorapu (assumed tropical:) The unripe date became red. (S, O, K.)

2 qal~aba see 1, first quarter, in four places. You say, qal~abotuhu biyadiY [I turned it over and over with my hand], inf. n. taqoliybN. (S.) [And hence several other significations mentioned above.] See, again, 1, latter half, in four places. ― -b2- faA^aSobaHa yuqal~ibu kaf~ayohi, (A, O,) in the Kur [xviii. 40],
(O,) means fASbH yql~b kf~yh ZahorFA libaTonK [And he began to turn his hands upside-down, or to do so repeatedly,] in grief, or regret: (Bd:) or (tropical:) he became in the state, or condition, of repenting, or grieving: (Ksh, A, O:) for taqoliybu Alkaf~ayoni is an action of him who is repenting, or grieving; (Ksh, O:) and therefore metonymically denotes repentance, or grief, like EaD~u Alkaf~i and Als~uquwTu fiY Alyadi. (Ksh.) ― -b3- [taqoliybu AlmaAli ligaraDi Alr~iboHi occurs in the A, in art. tjr, as an explanation of Alt~ijaArapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) The employing of property, or turning it to use, in various ways, for the purpose of gain.] And you say, qal~abotuhu fiY AlA^amori, meaning Sar~afotuhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) I employed him to act in whatever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or I made him a free agent, in the affair: or I made him, or employed him, to practise versatility, or to use art or artifice or cunning, in the affair: and simply, I employed him in the managing of the affair]. (K in art. Srf.) [And qal~aba Alfikara fiY A^m~rK (assumed tropical:) He turned over and over, or revolved repeatedly, in his mind, thoughts, considerations, or ideas, with a view to the attainment of some object, in relation to an affair.] And ql~b AlA^umuwra, (TA,) inf. n. taqoliybN, (S, K, TA,) (tropical:) He investigated, scrutinized, or examined, affairs, [or turned them over and over in his mind, meditating what he should do,] and considered what would be their results. (TA.) waqal~abuwA laka AlA^umuwra is a phrase occurring in the Kur-án [ix. 48,] (Msb,) and is tropical, (A,) meaning (tropical:) [And they turned over and over in their minds affairs, meditating what they should do to thee: or] they turned over [repeatedly in their minds] thoughts, or considerations, concerning the beguiling, or circumventing, thee, and the rendering thy religion ineffectual]: (Jel:) or they meditated, or devised, in relation to thee, wiles, artifices, plots, or stratagems; and [more agreeably with the primary import of the verb] they revolved ideas, or opinions, respecting the frustrating of thy affair. (Ksh, Bd.)

4 A^aqolaba see 1, in six places. [Aqlbhu, said of God, also signifies (assumed tropical:) He made him to return from a journey: see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. SHb. (In the phrase A^aqobilonaA bi*im~apK, expl. in the TA in art. dm as meaning Restore us to our family in safety, A^aqobilonaA is a mistranscription for A^aqolibonaA.)] -A2- Aqlb as intrans., said of bread [and the like], It became fit to be turned over [in order that the other side might become thoroughly baked]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And Aqlb AlEinabu The grapes became dry, or tough, externally, (K, TA,) and were therefore turned over, or shifted. (TA.) -A3- Also He had his camels attacked by the disease called qulaAb. (S, O, K.)

5 tql~b Al$~aYo'u ZahorFA lbiTonK * [The thing turned over and over, or upside-down as meaning so that the upper side became the under side, (lit. back for belly,) doing so much, or repeatedly], like as does the serpent upon the ground vehemently heated by the sun. (S, O, TA.) tql~b said of a man's face [&c.] signifies tSr~f [i. e. It turned about, properly meaning much, or in various ways or directions; or it was, or became, turned about, &c.]. (Jel in ii. 139.) And tataqal~abu fiyhi A@loquluwbu waA@loA^aboSaAru, in the Kur [xxiv. 37], means In which the hearts and the eyes shall be in a state of commotion, or agitation, by reason of fear, (Zj, Jel, TA,) and impatience; (Zj, TA;) the hearts between safety and perdition, and the eyes between the right side and the left. (Jel.) And fiY taqal~ubihimo, in the Kur xvi. 48, means (assumed tropical:) In their journeyings for traffic. (Jel. [See also the Kur iii. 196, and xl. 4.]) You say, tql~b fiY AlbilaAdi, (TA,) and fY AlA^umuwri, (K, TA,) meaning taSar~afa fiyhaA kayofa $aA='a [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He acted in whatsoever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or as a free agent, in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, in the country, and in the disposal, or management, of affairs: and simply, he employed himself in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, in the country, and in the disposal, or management, of affairs: or tql~b fY AlAmwr means he practised versatility, or used art or artifice or cunning, in the disposal, or management, of affairs]. (K, * TA.) And huwa yataqal~abu fiY A^aEomaAli Als~uloTaAni (tropical:) He acts as he pleases, &c., or simply he employs himself, in the offices of administration, or in the provinces, of the Sultán]. (A.)

7 Anqlb * , of which munoqalabN is an inf. n., (S, O, K, TA,) syn. with AinqilaAbN, (TA,) and also a n. of place, (S, O, K, TA,) like munoSarafN, (S, O, TA,) is quasi-pass. of qalabotuhu: (S, O:) it signifies It, or he, was, or became, altered, or changed, from its, or his, mode, or manner, of being: (TA:) [and hence,] it (a thing) became inverted, or turned upside-down [&c.: see 1]. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence] AlAinoqilaAbu A_ilaY A@ll~`hi means (assumed tropical:) The transition, and the being translated, or removed, to God, by death: and [in like manner] Almunoqalabu means the transition [&c.], of men, to the final abode. (TA.
