[See an ex. in p. 132, sec. col., from the Kur xxvi. last verse.]) ― -b3- And AlAinoqilaAbu means also (assumed tropical:) The returning, in an absolute sense: and, as also Almunoqalabu, particularly, from a journey, and to one's home: thus, in a trad., in the prayer relating to journeying, A^uEuw*u bika mino kaA=bapi Almunoqalabi (assumed tropical:) [I seek protection by Thee from the being in an evil state in respect of the returning from my journeying to my home]; i. e., from my returning to my dwelling and seeing what may grieve me. (TA.) The saying in the Kur xxii. 11 waA_ino A^aSaAbatohu fitonapN A@noqalaba EalaY wajohihi means (assumed tropical:) And if trial befall him, and [particularly such as] disease in himself and his cattle, he returns [to his former way, i. e., in this case,] to infidelity. (Jel. [See also other exs. in the Kur in ii. 138 and iii. 138.]) And one says, Anqlb Eani AlEahodi [meaning (assumed tropical:) He withdrew, or receded, from the covenant, compact, agreement, or engagement]. (S in art. Hwl.) [See also an ex. from the Kur-án (lxvii. 4) voce xaAsiy^N.]

qalobN * The heart; syn. fuw^aAdN: (Lh, T, S, M, O, Msb, K, &c.:) or [accord. to some] it has a more special signification than the latter word: (O, K:) [for] some say that fw^Ad signifies the “ appendages of the mariYo' [or œsophagus], consisting of the liver and lungs and qalob [or heart]: ” (K in art. fA^d:) [and, agreeably with this assertion,] it is said that the qlb is a lump of flesh, pertaining to the fw^Ad, suspended to the niyaAT [q. v.]: Az says, I have observed that some of the Arabs call the whole flesh of the qlb, its fat, and its HijaAb [or septum?], qalob and fuw^aAd; and I have not observed them to distinguish between the two [words]; but I do not deny that the [word] qlb may be [applied by some to] the black clot of blood in its interior: MF mentions that fw^Ad is said to signify the “ receptacle, ” or “ covering, ” of the heart, (wiEaA='u Alqalobi, or gi$aAw^uhu, [i. e. the pericardium,]) or, accord. to some, its “ interior: ” the qalob is said to be so called from its taqal~ub: [see 5:] the word is of the masc. gender: and the pl. is quluwbN. (TA.) banaAtu Alqalobi means (assumed tropical:) The several parts, or portions, [or, perhaps, appertenances,] of the heart. (TA in art. bnY.) [And qalobN is also used as meaning The stomach, which is often thus termed in the present day: so, for ex., in an explanation of Tanix, q. v.] ― -b2- qalobu AlEaqorabi (also called simply, Alqalobu, Kzw) is (assumed tropical:) A certain bright star, [the star a in Scorpio,] between two other stars, which is one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O,) namely, the Eighteenth Mansion; so called because it is in the heart of Scorpio: (MF:) [it rose aurorally, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, in Central Arabia, together with Aln~asoru AlwaqiEu (a of Libra) on the 25th of November, O. S.: (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:)] the commencement of the period when the cattle breed in the desert is at the time of its [auroral] rising and the [auroral] rising of Alnsr AlwAqE; these two stars rising together, in the cold season: the Arabs say, Alqalbo jaA='a Al$~itaA='u kaA@lokalobo [When the heart of the Scorpion rises, the winter comes like the dog]: and they regard its nawo' [q. v.] as unlucky; and dislike journeying when the moon is in Scorpio: at its nawo' [meaning auroral rising], the cold becomes vehement, cold winds blow, and the sap becomes stagnant in the trees: its raqiyb is Ald~abaraAnu [q. v.] (Kzw.) There are also three similar appellations of other stars: these are qalobu AlA^asadi (assumed tropical:) [Cor Leonis, or Regulus, the star a of Leo]: qalobu Alv~awori, an [improper] appellation of Ald~abaraAnu: and qalobu AlHuwti, a name of Alr~i$aA='u [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Alqalobu is syn. with
AlD~amiyru [signifying (assumed tropical:) The heart as meaning the mind or the secret thoughts]. (Msb in art. Dmr.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The soul. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The mind, meaning the intellect, or intelligence. (Fr, S, O, Msb, K.) So in the Kur l. 36: (Fr, S, O, TA:) or it means there endeavour to understand, and consideration. (TA.) Accord. to Fr, you may say, maA laka qalobN (assumed tropical:) Thou hast no intellect, or intelligence: (TA:) and maA qalobuka maEaka (assumed tropical:) Thine intellect is not present with thee: (O, TA:) and A^ayona *ahaba qalobuka (assumed tropical:) Whither has thine intellect gone? (TA.) [And hence, A^afoEaAlu Alquluwbi (assumed tropical:) The verbs significant of operations of the mind; as Zan~a, and the like.] ― -b6- See also qulobN. ― -b7- [qalobu Aljayo$i means (assumed tropical:) The main body of the army; as distinguished from the van and the rear and the two wings: mentioned in the S and K in art. xms; &c.] ― -b8- And qalobN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The pure, or choice, or best, part of anything. (L, K, * TA.) It is said in a trad. A_in~a likul~i $aYo'K qalobFA waqalobu AlquroA=ni y`s= (tropical:) [as though meaning, Verily to everything there is a choice, or best, part; and the choice, or best, part of the Kur-án is Yá-Seen (the Thirty-sixth Chapter)]: (A, O, L, TA:) it is a saying of the Prophet; [and may (perhaps better) be rendered, verily to everything there is a pith; and the pith &c.; from qalobN, as meaning, like qulobN, the “ pith ” of the palm-tree; but,] accord. to Lth, it is from what here immediately follows. (O.) One says, jiy^otuka bih`*aA AlA^amori qalobFA, meaning (tropical:) I have come to thee with this affair unmixed with any other thing. (A, * O, L, TA.) ― -b9- Also (tropical:) A man genuine, or pure, in respect of origin, or lineage; (S, A, O, K;) holding a middle place among his people; (A;) and ↓ qulobN signifies the same: (O, K:) the former is used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and dual and pl.; but it is allowable to form the fem. and dual and pl. from it: (S, O:) one says EarabiY~N qalobN (S, A, * O) and ↓ qulobN (O) (tropical:) a genuine Arabian man, (S, A, * O,) and AimoraA^apN qalobN (S, * A, O *) and qalobapN (S, A, O) and ↓ qulobapN (K) a woman genuine, or pure, in respect of origin, or lineage: (S, A, * O, K:) Sb says, they said h`*aA EarabiY~N qalobN and qalobFA (assumed tropical:) [This is an Arabian genuine, or pure, &c., and being genuine, or pure, &c.]; using the same word as an epithet and as an inf. n.: and it is said in a trad., kaAna EalY~N qura$iy~FA qalobFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) 'Alee was a Kurashee genuine, or pure, in respect of race: or, as some say, the meaning is, an intelligent manager of affairs; from qalobN as used in the Kur l. 36. (L, TA.)

qulobN * (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and ↓ qalobN (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ qilobN (S, O, K) (tropical:) The lub~, (S, O,) or $aHomap, (A, K,) or jum~aAr, (Mgh, Msb,) [i. e. heart, or pith,] of the palm-tree; (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) which is a soft, white substance, that is eaten; it is in the midst of its uppermost part, and of a pleasant, or sweet, taste: (TA: [see also jum~aArN:]) or the best of the leaves of the palm-tree, (AHn, K [in which this explanation relates to all the three forms of the word, but app. accord. to AHn it relates only to the first of them], and TA,) and the whitest; which are the leaves next to the uppermost part thereof; and one of these is termed ↓ qulobapN, with damm and sukoon: (AHn, TA:) or qulobN, with damm, signifies the branches of the palm-tree (saEaf [in my copy of the Msb sEfp]) that grow forth from the qlb [meaning heart]: (T, TA: [see AlEawaAhinu and AlxawaAfiY, pls. of EaAhinN, or EaAhinapN, and xaAfiyapN:]) the pl. is qilabapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is of the second, (Msb,) [or of all,] and quluwbN, (Msb, K,) a pl. of the second, (Msb,) and A^aqolaAbN, (Msb, K,) a pl. [of pauc.] of the first. (Msb.) ― -b2- And qulobN signifies also (tropical:) A bracelet (S, O, K, TA) that is worn by a woman, (K, TA,) such as is one qulob, (S, O, TA, but in the O, one qalob,) [as though meaning such as is single, not double,] or such as is one qilod, ('Eyn, T, MS, [and this is evidently the right reading, as will be shown by what follows,]) meaning such as is formed by twisting [or rather bending round] one TaAq [i. e. one wire (more or less thick), likened to a yarn, or strand], not of a double TaAq; (MS;) and they say siwaArN qulobN; (TA;) and qulobu fiD~apK i. e. a [woman's] bracelet [of silver], (A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) such as is not twisted [like a cord, or rope, of two or more strands, as are many of the bracelets worn by Arab women]: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) so called as being likened to the qulob of the palm-tree because of its whiteness; (A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) or, as some say, the converse is the case. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A serpent: (S, O:) or a white serpent: (A, K:) likened to the bracelet so called. (S, O.) -A2- qulobN as an epithet, and its fem. qulobapN: see qalobN, last sentence, in three places.
qilobN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
qulobapN * , as a subst.: see qulobN, former half. -A2- Also Redness. (IAar, O, K.)

maA bihi qalabapN *
There is not in him any disease, (S, A, Mgh,) thus says IAar, adding, for which he should be turned over (↓ yuqal~ab) and examined, (S,) and in this sense it is said of a camel [and the like], (TA,) or on account of which he should turn over upon his bed: (A:) or there is not in him anything to disquiet him, so that he should turn over upon his bed: (Et-Tá-ee, TA:) or thers is not in him any disease, and any fatigue, (K, TA,) and any pain: (TA:) or there is not in him anything; said of one who is sick; and the word is not used otherwise than in negative phrases: accord. to IAar, originally used in relation to a horse or the like, meaning there is not in him any disease for which his hoof should be turned upsidedown (↓ yuqal~ab) [to be examined]: (TA:) or it is from AlqulaAbu, (Fr, S, A, TA,) the disease, so termed, that attacks camels; (TA;) or from quliba [q. v.] as said of a man, and means there is not in him any disease on account of which one should fear for him. (Fr, TA.)
A^awodaY Al$~abaAbu waHub~u AlxaAlapi AlxalibahN
waqado bariy^otu famaA biAlqalobi mino qalabahN
[Youthfulness has perished, and the love of the proud and self-conceited, the very deceitful, woman, (thus the two epithets are expl. in art. xlb in the S,) and I have recovered so that there is not in the heart any disease, &c.]; meaning I have recovered from the disease of love. (S, TA.)

qalaAbi * [as used in the following instance is an attributive proper name like fajaAri &c.]. Aiqolibo qalaAbi [Alter, O alterer,] is a prov. applied to him who turns his speech, or tongue, and applies it as he pleases: accord. to IAth, to him who has made a slip of the tongue, and repairs it by turning it to another meaning: yaA, he says, is suppressed before qlAb. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 247.])

qulaAbN *
A certain disease of the heart. (Lh, K.) And (K) A disease that attacks the camel, (As, S, O, K,) occasioning complaint of the heart, (As, S, O,) and that kills him on the day of its befalling him: (As, S, O, K:) or a disease that attacks camels in the head, and turns it up. (Fr, TA.) [It is also mentioned as an inf. n. of quliba, q. v.] Accord. to Kr, it is the only known word, signifying a disease, derived from the name of the member affected, except kubaAdN and nukaAfN. (TA in art. kbd.)
qilaAbN * : see qil~iybN.

qaluwbN * , (O, K,) as an epithet applied to a man, (O, TA,) i. q. mutaqal~ibN kaviyru Alt~aqal~ubi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Who employs himself much in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, or in the disposal, or management, of affairs: or who practises much versatility, &c.: see 5, last sentence but one]. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also qil~iybN. -A2- qaluwbu Al$~ajari means What are soft, or tender, of succulent herbs: these, and locusts, [it is said,] were eaten by John the son of Zachariah. (O.)

qaliybN *
Earth turned over (turaAbN maqoluwbN): [app. an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] this is the primary signification. (A.) ― -b2- And hence, (A,) a masc. n., (A, * Msb,) or masc. and fem., (S, O, K,) A well, (Msb, K, TA,) of whatever kind it be: (TA:) or a well before its interior is cased [with stones or bricks]: (S, A, Mgh, O:) or an ancient well, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K, TA,) of which neither the owner nor the digger is known, situate in a desert: (TA:) or an old well, whether cased within or not: (TA:) or a well, whether cased within or not, containing water or not, of the kind termed jafor [q. v.] or not: (ISh, TA:) or a well, whether of recent formation or ancient: (Sh, TA:) so called because its earth is turned over (Sh, A, TA) in the digging: (A:) or a well in which is a spring; otherwise a well is not thus called: (IAar, TA:)
the pl. (of pauc., S, O) A^aqolibapN (S, O, K) and (of mult., S, O) qulubN (S, Mgh, O, K) and qulobN, (O, K,) the first and last of which are said to be pls. in the dial. of such as make the sing. to be masc., and the second the pl. in the dial. of such as make the sing. to be fem., but the last, as MF has pointed out, is a contraction of the second like as rusolN is of rusulN, (TA,) and qulobaAnN also is mentioned as a pl. of qaliybN on the authority of AO. (TA voce badiYo'N.) ― -b3- El-'Ajjáj has applied the pl. qulub to (tropical:) Wounds, by way of comparison. (S, O.)
qulayobN * [dim. of qalobN: and hence, perhaps,] (assumed tropical:) A xarazap [i. e. bead, or gem,] for captivating, fascinating, or restraining, by a kind of enchantment. (Lh, K.)

rajulN qul~abN * (assumed tropical:) A man who employs himself as he pleases in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, or in the disposal, or management, of affairs: or in practising versatility, or using art or artifice or cunning, in the disposal, or management, of affairs. (TA.) And Huw~aliY~N qul~abN (S, O, K) and Huw~alN qul~abN and Huw~aliY~N qul~abiY~N (O, K) or qul~abN Huw~alN (A) (tropical:) One who exercises art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, and excellence of consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free will, with subtilty; knowing, skilful, or intelligent, in investigating, scrutinizing, or examining, affairs, [or turning them over and over in his mind,] and considering what will be their results. (S, A, * O, K, TA. [See also art. Hwl.])
qil~aAbN * : see qil~iybN.
qil~awobN * and qal~uwbN: see what next follows.

qil~iybN * and ↓ qil~awobN The wolf; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ qal~uwbN and ↓ qaluwbN and ↓ qilaAbN, the last like kitaAbN, (K,) or ↓ qil~aAbN. (O: thus there written.) ― -b2- And The lion. (O, in explanation of the first and second.)

qaAlabN * , with fet-h to the l, (S, MA, O, Msb, K, KL,) and ↓ qaAlibN, (MA, O, Msb, K,) but the former is the more common, (Msb, K,) A model according to which the like thereof is made, or proportioned: (T in art. mvl, MA, KL, MF:) the model [or last] (KL,) of a boot, (S, O, Msb, KL,) and of a shoe, (KL,) &c.: (O, Msb, KL:) and a mould into which metals are poured: (K:) qaAlabN is an arabicized word, as is shown by its form, which is not that of an Arabic word; though Esh-Shiháb, in his Expos. of the Shifè, denies this: its original is [the Pers. word] kaAlabN: (MF:) the pl. is qawaAlibu, (MA,) and qawaAliyb is used by El-Hareeree to assimilate it to A^asaAliyb. (Har p. 23.) [A fanciful and false derivation of qaAlibN used in relation to a boot &c., as though it were of Arabic origin, is given in the O, and in Har p. 23.] ― -b2- AlkalaAmi ↓ qado rad~a qaAliaba waqado Tab~aqa AlmafoSila wawaDaEa AlhinaA='a mawaADiEa Aln~uqobi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) He has returned in reply the model, or pattern, of speech; and has hit the joint so as to sever the limb; (that is to say, has hit aright, or hit upon, the argument, proof, or evidence, agreeably with an explanation in art. Tbq;) and has put the tar upon the places of the scabs;] is mentioned by AZ as said of an eloquent man. (O, TA. * [The TA, in this art. and in art. Tbq, has wrd (to which I cannot assign in this case any apposite meaning) instead of rad~a, the reading in the O.]) ― -b3- And ↓ qaAliabN, (O, L, TA,) with fet-h and with kesr to the l, (L, TA,) signifies also A [clog, or] wooden sandal, (O, L, TA,) like the qaboqaAb [q. v.]: in this sense likewise said to be an arabicized word: and qawaAliybu is its pl., [properly qawaAlibu,] occurring in a trad., in which it is said that the women of the Children of Israel used to wear the wooden sandals thus called: (L, TA:) it is related in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood that the woman used to wear a pair of the kind of sandals thus called in order thereby to elevate herself (O, L, TA) when the men and the women of that people used to pray together. (O.)

qaAlibN *
Red unripe dates: (S, O, Msb, K:) so in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab: (El-Umawee, TA:) [app. an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; for busorN qaAlibN:] or an unripe date when it has become wholly altered [in colour] is termed qaAlibN. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- And $aApN qaAlibu lawonK A ewe, or she-goat, of a colour different from that of her mother: (O, * K, TA:) occurring in a trad. (O, TA.) -A2- See also qaAlabN, in three places.
A^aqolabu * as an epithet applied to a man: and qalobaA='u as an epithet applied to a lip ($afapN): see 1, near the end.
A_iqlAbyp * [app. A_iqolAbiy~apN] A sort of wind, from which sailors on the sea suffer injury, and fear for their vessels. (TA.)

[
taqal~ubaAtN * (assumed tropical:) Vicissitudes of fortune or of time.]
miqolabN * The iron implement with which the earth is turned over for sowing. (S, O, K.)
muqal~ibu Alquluwbi * (assumed tropical:) [The Turner of hearts: an epithet applied to God]. (TA in art. Hrk, from a trad.)

maqoluwbN * pass. part. n. of qalaba Al$~aYo'a. (A, O.) You say HajarN maqoluwbN [generally meaning A stone turned upside-down]. (A.) And sariyrN maqoluwbN i. e. [A couch-frame] of which the legs are turned upwards. (Mgh.) And kalaAmN maqoluwbN [A sentence, or the like, altered, or changed, in the order of its words, by inversion, or by any transposition]. (A.) And in like manner mqlwb is applied to a word: see 1, former half. -A2- Also a man attacked by a disease of the heart. (A.) And A camel attacked by the disease termed qulaAb [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) fem. with p. (S.)
Almaqoluwbapu * [A subst., rendered such by the affix p,] The ear. (O, K.)

mutaqal~abN *
i. q. mutaSar~afN (assumed tropical:) [Place, or room, or scope, for free action, &c.: see srb: and see an ex. voce sabaHa]. (Jel. in xlvii. 21.) ― -b2- See also the following paragraph, in two places.

munoqalabN * An inf. n. of 7 [q. v.]. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And also a n. of place from the same [for which Freytag seems to have found in a copy of the S muqal~abN, a mistranscription], (S, O, K, TA,) like munoSarafN. (TA.) [As a n. of place it signifies A place in which a thing, or person, is, or becomes, altered, or changed, from its, or his, mode, or manner, of being: and hence, a place in which a thing becomes inverted, or turned upside-down, &c. ― -b3- Hence, also, (assumed tropical:) The final place to which one is translated, or removed, by death; and so ↓ mutaqal~abN.] One says, kul~u A^aHad yaSiyru A_ilaY munoqalabihi and ↓ mutaqal~abihi (tropical:) [Every one reaches, or will reach, his final place to which he is to be translated, or removed]. (A.) ― -b4- [And A place to which one returns from a journey &c.]

1 qalita * , aor.
qalata , inf. n. qalatN, (S, * Mgh, O, * Msb, K,) He, or it, perished, or died. (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) One says, maA A@nofalatuwA wal`kino qulituwA [They did not escape, but they perished, or died]. (S, O. [Golius and Freytag appear to have read AnqltwA; for they have said, as on the authority of J, that the seventh form of the verb is not to be used for the first form.])

4 Aqlthu *
He, or it, destroyed him; (K, TA;) said of God, and of a long journey: (TA:) or he (i. e. a man, O) exposed him to destruction; (O, K, TA;) and made him to be on the brink thereof. (TA.) -A2- And Aqltt She was, or became, such as is termed miqolaAtN [q. v.]. (S, O, K, TA.)

qalotN *
A [hollow, or cavity, such as is termed] nuqorap, [generally meaning such as is small, or not large, or such as is round,] in a mountain, (T, S, O, Msb, K,) in which water stagnates, (T, S, O, Msb,) i. e. the water of the rain, (Msb,) when a torrent pours down; (TA;) similar to what is termed waqob: (T, TA:) in some instances so large as to be capable of containing a hundred times as much as the contents of the [leathern water-bag called] mazaAdap: (Msb:) or a nuqorap in a rock: (A:) and any nuqorap in the ground, or in the body: of the fem. gender: (T, O, TA:) and [therefore] its dim. is ↓ qulayotapN: (O:) pl. qilaAtN. (T, S, O, Msb.) Hence the saying, A^asowadu mino maA='i Alqaloti [Blacker than the water of the qalot]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also A round hollow, or cavity, which water dropping from the roof of a cavern forms in the course of ages in soft stone or in hard ground. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] qalotu Alv~ariydapi (tropical:) The hollow, or depression, of the mess of crumbled bread moistened with gravy, in which the gravy collects. (S, A, O, TA.) ― -b4- And qalotN signifies (tropical:) Any small hollow, or depression, in a member. (A.) ― -b5- And Alqalotu [alone], (TA,) or qalotu Alt~aroquwapi, (A,)
(tropical:) The hollow, or depression, that is between the collar-bone and the neck. (A, * TA.) And qalotu AlEayoni (tropical:) The cavity of the eye. (S, A, O.) And qalotu AlS~udogi (tropical:) [The depression of the temple.]. (S, O, TA.) And qalotu AlA_ibohaAmi (tropical:) The hollow that is in the lower part of the thumb. (S, O, TA.) And qlt Alkaf~i [app. signifies the same;] (tropical:) The part that is between the tendon of the thumb [i. e. of the flexor longus pollicis] and the fore finger; which is the middle part between these two [or between the thumb and the fore finger]. (TA.) And qalotu AlxaASirapi (tropical:) The depressed part of the flank: (AZ, TA:) or what is termed Huq~u Alwariki [app. meaning the socket, or turning-place, of the head of the thigh-bone]. (A, TA.) And qalotu Alr~ukobapi (tropical:) The Eayon of the knee. (A, TA. [This, I should have thought, might mean the popliteal space, which is slightly depressed between the two hamstrings: but see EayonN.]) And the qalot (JK, TA) of the mouth (JK) of the horse (TA) is (tropical:) What is between the lahawaAt [app. meaning the furthest, or innermost, parts of the mouth], extending to the muHan~ak [or place where the palate, or soft palate, is rubbed, or pierced, to make it bleed]. (JK, TA.) -A2- Also A man having little flesh: and so ↓ qalitN. (Lh, O, K.) ― -b2- And qalotapN (JK, K, TA, in the CK qalitapN, in the O qaltapN,) A ewe or she-goat whose milk is not sweet. (JK, O, K.)

qalatN * [inf. n. of 1: used as a simple subst.,] Perdition; a state of destruction; or death. (S, O, K.) An Arab of the desert said, A_in~a AlmusaAfira wamataAEahu laEalaY qalatK A_il~aA maA waqaY A@ll~`hu [Verily the traveller and his goods are in danger of destruction, except what God protects]. (S, O.) And one says, A^aSobaHa EalaY qalatK i. e. [He became] on the brink of destruction: or in fear of a thing that beguiled him to venture upon an evil undertaking. (TA.) And A^amosaY EalaY qalatK i. e. [He became] in a state of fear. (TA.) -A2- Also The state, or condition, of such as is termed miqolaAtN. (O, TA.)
qalitN * : see qalotN, last sentence but one.
qalotapN * The channel [or oblong depression] between the two mustaches, against the partition between the two nostrils: also called the xunoEubap and nuwtap and vuwmap and hazomap and wahodap. (TA.)
qulayotapN * dim. of qalotN: see the latter, first sentence.
maqolatN * : see maqolatapN.
muqolitN * : see miqolaAtN.

maqolanapN *
A place of perdition or destruction or death; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ maqolatN. (MF.) And hence, A desert, or waterless desert. (Msb.) And A place that is feared. (TA.)

miqolaAtN * (Lth, S, A, O, K) and ↓ muqolitN (TA) A she-camel that brings forth one only, and does not conceive after: (Lth, S, O, K:) or whose young one has died; as also nakodaA='u:) (L in art. nkd:) and a woman of whom no child lives: (S, A, O, K:) or, accord. to Lth, a woman who has only one child; but Az disallowed this explanation: (O:) or a woman who brings forth one child, and does not bring forth any after that: (TA:) or any female to which there has remained no offspring: (Lh, TA:) pl. of the former maqaAliytu. (S, A, O.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph or art. $xb.] Bishr Ibn-Abee-Kházim says, (S, * O,) mentioning the slaughter of Makhzoom Ibn-Dabbà ElAsadee, (O,)
taZal~u maqaAliytu Aln~isaA='i yaTaA^onahu
yaqulona A^alaA yuloqaY EalaY Almaro'i miy^ozaru
[The women of whom no offspring lived, &c., passing the day treading upon him, saying, Shall not a waist-wrapper be thrown upon the man? for it seems that his body was indecently exposed]: in explanation of which it is said, the Arabs used to assert that when the mqlAt trod upon a noble, or generous, man, who had been slain perfidiously, her child lived. (S, O.)

1 qaliHato A^asonaAnuhu * , (A, Msb, K, *) aor.
qalaHa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. qalaHN, (A, * Msb, K, *) His (a man's, or- other creature's, TA) teeth became yellow: (A, K:) or became altered by yellowness or xuDorap [here meaning a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour; and in like manner are to be rendered similar words (primarily denoting “ greenness ”) in this art.]: (Msb:) or became discoloured by much yellowness, which thickened, and then became black, or of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour: (L:) HiborN signifies yellowness in the teeth; and when this become much in quantity, and thick, and black, and of a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour, it is termed qalaHN: (Sh:) or his teeth became yellow, and incrusted with dirt, from long disuse of the tooth-stick which is employed for cleaning them: (A'Obeyd:) or, as some say, his (a man's) teeth became yellow; and his (a camel's) teeth became of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour. (MF. [But this is said in the TA to be strange.]) ― -b2- And qaliHa Alr~ajulu The man had yellowness [&c.] in his teeth. (S.)

2 qal~aHotu A^asonaAnahu *
I removed the qalaH, i. e. yellowness [&c.] of his teeth. (A.) ― -b2- And ql~Hhu He [cleansed and] cured of their qalaH [or yellowness &c.] his (a man's, and a camel's,) teeth: (TA:) a verb of the same class as qar~adotu in the phrase qar~adotu AlbaEiyra (S, K,) meaning “ I plucked off the ticks from the camel. ” (S.) EawodN yuqal~aju An aged camel whose teeth are cleansed (S, K) and cured of their yellowness [&c.] (S, A, K) is a prov.; (S, A;) applied to the aged that is disciplined and trained; (Meyd, A; *) or to one advanced in age with whom is done what is done with youths, or who does what do young men. (Ham p. 820.)
4 AqlH A^asonaAnahu * , said of time, It rendered his teeth yellow [&c.: see 1]. (A.)

5 AlmaroA^apu A_i*aA gaAba zawojuhaA taqal~aHato * i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The woman when her husband is absent] becomes dirty in her clothes; does not pay frequent attention to the cleansing of her person and her clothes: a saying in a trad., which some relate otherwise, saying tfl~Ht, with f: (TA in this art.:) but El-Khattábee holds the former to be the right, and to be from the yellowness that comes upon the teeth. (TA in art. flH.) -A2- And tql~H AlbilaAda He applied himself to the earning, or gaining, of sustenance, or wealth, in the towns, or districts, in the case of drought, or barrenness of the earth. (K.)

qaloHN * An ass [app. a wild ass] advanced in age: (K:) and so qaloxN. (Lth and K in art. qlx.) [See art. qlx for two other significations mentioned in this art. (one of them inexactly) by Golius and Freytag.]
qiloHN * A dirty garment. (K.)

qalaHN * (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ qulaAHN, (Msb, K,) the former being the inf. n. of qaliHa, and the latter a simple subst., (Msb,) Yellowness in, or of, the teeth: (S, A, K:) or alteration of the teeth by yellowness or xuDorap [here meaning, as expl. before, a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]. (Mgh, * Msb.) [See also 1.]
qaliHN * : see A^aqolaHu. ― -b2- Also Clad with, or wearing, a dirty garment, which is termed qiloHN. (Sh, TA.)
qulaAHN * : see qalaHN.

A^aqolaHu * (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb) and ↓ qaliHN, (A,) applied to a man, (S, A, L, Msb,) and to other than man, (L,) Having, in his teeth, what is termed qalaH [expl. above as a yellowness, &c.]: (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb:) fem. of the former qaloHaA='u: and pl. quloHN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And AlA^aqolaHu signifies The juEal [or species of black beetle called cantharus]; (A, K, TA;) because of the filthiness of its mouth: (A, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.)
muqal~aHN * (tropical:) Experienced, or expert, in affairs; whose qualities have been tried, or proved; (A, TA;) and rendered tractable, or submissive: applied to a man. (TA.)

1 qalaxa * , (S, L, K,) aor.
qalaxa , (K,) inf. n. qaloxN (S, K) and qulaAxN (L) and qaliyxN, (Sb, S, K,) He (a stallion-camel) brayed: (S, L, K:) or began to bray: or brayed vehemently, as though he pulled out the sound from his chest. (L.) ― -b2- And qalaxa Al$~ajarapa He pulled out, or up, the tree: (K, TA:) the x being substituted for E. (TA.) -A2- And qalaxa He struck a dry thing upon, or against, a dry thing. (K.)
2 ql~xhu biAls~awoTi * , inf. n. taqoliyxN, He struck him a most vehement stroke with the whip. (K.) -A2- And ql~x Aln~abotu The plant, or herbage, became strong. (K.)

qaloxN * A stallion-camel excited by lust, (K, TA,) when he is [braying vehemently, as though] pulling out the sound of braying [from his chest: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b2- And An ass [app. a wild ass] advanced in age: (K, TA:) and so qaloHN; with H as well as with x. (TA; and K in art. qlH.) ― -b3- Also, [or perhaps qaSabN qaloxN,] Hollow reeds or canes. (K.)
qalaxo qalaxo * , (K, TA,) with the final letter quiescent, (TA,) An expression uttered to the stallion-camel on the occasion of covering. (K.)

qulaAxN * : see qal~aAxN. ― -b2- Also Large in the haAmap [or head; or crown, or upper part, of the head]: and hence used as a proper name, with the article Al, of the poet El-'Amberee, and of others. (TA.)
qal~aAxN * and ↓ qulaAxN A braying stallion-camel: or one that brays vehemently. (L.)

1 qalada * , (aor.
qalida , inf. n. qalodN, L.) He twisted, wound, or wreathed, a thing (or anything, L,) upon (ElY) another thing; (L, K;) as a qulob (the ornament so called) upon another qulob. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] aor. and inf. n. as above (S, L) He twisted a rope. (S, L, K.) qulida Haboluhu (tropical:) His rope was twisted: said of an old man who has become weak in judgment by reason of age, and whose opinion is not regarded. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] He made a piece of iron slender, and twisted, wound, or wreathed, it (K) upon a similar piece, (TA,) or upon another thing. (K.) ― -b4- qaladatohu AlHum~aY, (aor.
qalida , inf. n. qalodN, L,) (assumed tropical:) The fever seized him every day. (L, K.) See qilodN. -A2- qalada, (aor.
qalida , inf. n. qalodN, L,) He irrigated growing corn. (L, K.) -A3- qalada, aor.
qalida , (inf. n. qalodN, L,) He collected water in a tank or cistern, (L, K,) and milk in a skin, (IAar, L, K,) ladling each out with a bowl, and pouring it into the tank or the skin, (AZ,) and clarified butter in a skin, (L,) and beverage, or wine, in his belly. (L, K.) See also qrd. ― -b2- qalada mina Al$~araAb fiY jawofihi He drank of the beverage, or wine. (IKtt.)

2 qal~adahaA * , inf. n. taqoliydN; (S;) and ql~dhA qilaAdapF; (Msb, K;) He put a qlAdp [or necklace] upon her (a woman's, S, Msb) neck; (S, * K;) attired her therewith. (Msb.) [And so,] qaladotuhu Als~ayofa, I hung upon him the sword, putting its suspensory belt or cord upon his neck or shoulder. (A.) [And] ql~d Albadanapa, inf. n. taqoliydN, He hung upon the neck of the camel or cow or bull brought as an offering to Mekkeh for sacrifice something to show that it was such an offering; (T, S, A, L, K, &c.;) namely, an old worn-out sandal, (JK,) or a piece of a skin, (Msb,) or of a sandal, (T, Mgh,) or of a mizaAdap, (Mgh,) or the loop of a mzAdp. (T.) The pagan Arabs used also to hang upon the necks of their camels pieces of the bark (lisHaA=') of the trees of the sacred territory of Mekkeh, as a means of protection against their enemies. (Zj, on verse 2 of ch. v. of the Kur.) ― -b2- Hence, taqoliydu AlwulaApi AlA^aEomaAla (tropical:) [The investing of prefects, or the like, with offices of administration]. (S, L, K.) You say, ql~dhu EamalFA (tropical:) [He invested him with an office of administration]. (A, L.) qal~dhu niEamahu (tropical:) [He conferred upon him permanent badges of his favours]. (A.) [See qilaAdapN: and see also TawoqN and Tw~q.] ― -b3- Hence, also, Alt~aqoliydu fiY Ald~iyni (tropical:) [The investing with authority in matters of religion]: (S, L:) Altqlyd means a man's following another in that which he says or does, firmly believing him to be right therein, without regard or consideration of the proof, or evidence; as though the former made the saying or deed of the other a qilaAdap upon his neck. (KT.) -A2- ql~dhu AlA^amora (tropical:) He obliged him, or constrained him, to do the thing, or affair; he imposed upon him the thing, or affair. (L.) -A3- qul~ida fulaAnN qilaAdapa sawo'K (tropical:) Such a one was satirized with that which left upon him a lasting stigma. (A.)

4 Aqld AlbaHoru Ealayohimo * (tropical:) The sea drowned them. (K.) Aqld AlbHr ElY xaloqK kaviyrK (tropical:) The sea drowned a great number of people; as though it closed upon them: (S, L:) or, closed upon them, and covered them, when they were drowned therein. (A.)

5 tql~d * , (K,) and tql~dt, (S,) and tql~d qilaAdapF, (L,) and tql~dthA, (Msb,) He put on his neck, or attired himself with, a qlAdp [or necklace], and she did the same. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- tql~d Als~ayofa (S, A, L) He hung upon himself the sword, putting its suspensory belt or cord upon his neck [or shoulder]. (A.) A poet says,
yaA layota zawojaki qado gadaA
mutaqal~idFA sayofFA warumoHFA
[Would that thy husband had gone hanging upon him a sword and bearing a spear]: he means, waHaAmilFA rumoHFA. (S, L.) [See a similar saying voce jadaEa.] ― -b3- tql~d AlEamala (tropical:) [He became invested with an office of administration, or a prefecture]. (A.) ― -b4- tql~d AlA^amora (tropical:) He took, or imposed, upon himself, or undertook, the thing, or affair; (L;) syn. Ailotazamahu. (JK.) See Ham. p. 127.
qalodN * : see maqoluwdN.

qilodN *
A single strand, or twist, of a rope; (AHn, ISd;) and the like of a bracelet: (see qulobN:) pl. A^aqolaAdN and quluwdN. (AHn, ISd.) See maqoluwdN. ― -b2- The day on which a fever comes: (L, K:) or, on which a regular intermittent fever returns, seldom failing to do so at a particular time: (L:) or, on which a quartan fever comes: (S, L, K: *) pl. A^aqolaAdN. (L.) ― -b3- Hence, (S, L.) The caravans from Mekkeh to Juddeh. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- Accord. to As, A man attacked by a quartan fever on the day of its attack. (L.) -A2- Irrigation of growing corn: (Az, L:) as also ↓ qaliydN. (L.) ― -b2- [And] qilodN signifies The day of irrigation. (L.) A^aqaAma qilodahu mina AlmaA='i He performed the work of irrigating his land on the day appointed for his doing so. (L, from a trad.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Irrigation by rain every week. (K.) You say, saqatonaA Als~amaA='u qilodFA fiY kul~i A^usobuwEK (assumed tropical:) The heaven rained upon us at a particular time every week: (S, L:) from the qilod of a fever. (L.) ― -b4- saqaY A_ibilahu qilodFA (assumed tropical:) He watered his camels every day at noon. (Fr, L.) ― -b5- kayofa qilodu naxoli baniY fulaAnK [How is the watering of the palm-trees of the sons of such a one?] a question to which one may answer, They are watered (lit. they drink) once in every ten [nights]. (L.) ― -b6- A portion of water: (L, K:) [pl. A^aqolaAdN, occurring in the A.]: and ↓ qilodapN a draught of water. (A.) -A3- A^aEoTayotuhu qiloda A^amoriY (tropical:) I committed to him [the management of] my affair. (A, K.)

qilodapN *
i. q. qi$odapN; (S, L, K;) i. e., The dregs, or sediment, of clarified butter; also called kudaAdapN. (L.) ― -b2- Also, Dates, and meal of parched barley or wheat (sawiyq), with which butter is clarified. (L, K.) -A2- And see qildN.

qalodapN * [as also qalotapN] i. q. xunoEubapN and nuwnapN and tuwmapN and hazomapN and wahodapN and harovamapN and EarotamapN and Hbrmp [?]: so says IAar.; and Lth says, that the xnEbp is The part where the mustaches divide, against the partition between the two nostrils. (L.)
qaliydN * and ↓ maqoluwdN A twisted rope. (S, K.) -A2- and see qilodN -A3- and A^aqoliydN.

qilaAdapN * [A necklace; a collar; and the like;] that which is upon the neck; (S;) what is put upon the neck (L, K) of a human being, and a horse, and a dog, and a camel or cow or bull that is brought as an offering to Mekkeh for sacrifice, [see 2,] and the like: (L:) Esh-Shiháb observes, in the 'Ináyeh, that the measure fiEaAlapN, in the case
of a word not an inf. n., denotes a thing that envelops, or that surrounds, another thing; as in the instances of lifaAfapN and EimaAmapN and qilaAdapN: (TA:) pl. qalaAy^idu: (Msb:) qilaAdN also occurs, either as a pl. of qilaAdapN, in which case the kesreh and A in the pl. are different from the kesreh and A in the sing., [being the proper characteristics of the pl.,] or as a coll. gen. n., of which qilaAdapN is the n. un. (ISd, L.) ― -b2- Hasobuka mina AlqilaAdapi maA A^aHaATa biAlEunuqi (assumed tropical:) [Sufficient for thee is the necklace that surrounds the neck]. A proverb. (TA.) Said by 'Okeyl Ibn-'Ullufeh, on his being asked why he did not censure his enemies in a longer satire. (Z.) ― -b3- niEomatuka qilaAdapN fiY EunuqiY laA yafuk~uhaA AlmalawaAni (tropical:) [Thy beneficence is a permanent badge upon my neck which day and night will not loose]. (A.) ― -b4- liY fiY A^aEonaAqihimo qalaAy^idu niEamK raAhinapN (tropical:) [To me are owing acknowledgments required by permanent badges of favours firmly fastened upon their necks: see 2]. (A.) [This use of qlAdp in a good sense is more common than the meaning (tropical:) A disgrace attaching constantly or a permanent badge of infamy: see Ham. p. 127.] -A2- qalaAy^idu Al$~iEori, (K,) and ↓ muqal~adaAtuhu, (L, K,) (assumed tropical:) Verses, or poems, that last throughout time. (L, K.) See 2. -A3- AlqilaAdapu A certain asterism. (See Albalodapu.)
qil~iydN * : see miqolaAdN.
A_iqolaAdN * : see A_iqoliydN.

A^aqoliydN * : see A_iqoliydN -A2- A^aqamotu A^aqoliydiY, or AqlydatiY, [as in different copies of the A: perhaps mistakes for ↓ qaliydiY:] I irrigated my land with my qilod [or portion of water]. (A, TA.)

A_iqoliydN * , (S, L, K,) or ↓ A^aqoliydN, with fet-h to the ', (A,) said to be of the dial. of El-Yemen, and said to be arabicized, (Msb, TA,) originally klyd [i. e., kaliydo or kiliydo, which is Persian,] (TA) or originally Aqlyds, (Msb, MF,) which is Greek, [i. e., kleido\s, gen. of klei\s,] (MF,) A key; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ miqoladN (L, K) and ↓ miqolaAdN (K) and ↓ miqoliydN (A Heyth, L) and ↓ A_iqolaAdN: (L:) pl. A^aqaAliydu (L, Msb, El-Basáïr) and maqaAliydu, (Msb, El-Basáïr,) the latter a pl. similar to malaAmiHu and maHaAsinu and ma$aAbihu and ma*aAkiyru, (El-Basáïr,) or [rather] a [reg.] pl. of miqolaAdN or miqoliydN or miqoladN, (Esh-Shiháb, in the 'Ináyeh,) or it has no [proper] sing.; (As;) [and pl. of miqoladN, maqaAlidu of which see an ex. below]. [You say] ↓ fataHa AlbaAba biAlA^aqoliydi, [or bAlA_iqoliydi,] He opened the door with the key. (A.) ― -b2- lahu maqaAliydu A@ls~amawaAti waA@loA^aroDi [Kur xxxix. 63, and xlii. 10,] may signify (assumed tropical:) To Him belong the keys of the heavens and of the earth: (L, Msb:) Zj says, that the meaning is, God is the Creator, and the Opener of the door, of everything in the heavens and in the earth: (L:) some say that it may signify to Him belong the treasuries of the heavens and of the earth. (Es-Suddee, L, Msb.) ― -b3- A^aloqayotu A_ilayohi maqaAliyda AlA^umuwri (tropical:) [lit., I threw to him the keys of the affairs; meaning, I committed to him the disposal, or management, of the affairs]. (A.) ― -b4- DaAqato maqaAliyduhu, and maqaAliduhu, (K,) and DaAqato Ealayohi AlmaqaAliydu, (A,) (tropical:) [His means, likened to keys, became straitened: or] his affairs became straitened, or difficult, to him: (A, K:) accord. to Esh-Shiháb, from miqoladN, signifying a twisted rope: this he says considering maqaAliydu as syn. with qalaAy^idu; but its use in this sense is not established. (TA.)

miqoladN *
A kind of key, like a reaping-hook, (S, L, K,) with which, sometimes, herbage is twisted, (yuqoladu, i. e., yufotalu,) like as [the kind of trefoil, or clover, called] qat~ is twisted when it is made into ropes; pl. maqaAliydu: (S:) a stick with a crooked head, (L, K,) which is used for that purpose: (L:) also, a reaping-hook with which qat~ is cut. (L.) See also A_iqoliydN.

miqolaAdN *
A repository, magazine, store-room, or treasury; (L, K;) as also ↓ qil~iydN: (K:) pl. maqaAliydu. (L.) -A2- And see A_iqoliydN.

maqoluwdN * : see qaliydN. ― -b2- A bracelet formed of two bracelets of the kind called qulob twisted together: (L:) a twisted bracelet; as also ↓ qalodN: (L, K [the latter said in the K to be with fet-h, but in the L written qilodN:]) and the latter, [in the S written qalodN,] a bracelet made of twisted silver. (S, L.)

muqal~adN * The place of the qilaAdap [or necklace, or collar, upon the neck]; (K;) [the neck of a woman, and of a horse, &c.]. ― -b2- The place of the suspensory belt or cord of the sword, upon the shoulders. (S, K.) ― -b3- [Having a qilaAdap or the like put upon his neck]. ― -b4- A horse which outstrips others, (S, L, K,) which has something put upon his neck in order that it may be known that he has outstripped. (S, L.) ― -b5- A chief upon whom are imposed the affairs of his people. (Ham p. 127.)

1 qalasa * , aor.
qalisa , inf. n. qalosN, He belched up, (S, * A, * Msb, K,) from his throat, (S, A, K,) or from his belly, to his mouth, (Msb,) as much as filled his mouth, or less, (S, A, Msb, K,) of [acid and undigested] food or drink, whether he cast it forth or returned it to his belly: when it overcomes [or is repeated (accord. to an explanation of qalosN or qalasN below,)] it [the action] is termed qaYo'N: (Msb:) or he vomited (qaA='a) as much as filled his mouth: (Mgh:) or he, or it, vomited, or cast forth; syn. qa*afa. (S.) The act termed qalosN is an impurity which necessitates the performance of the ablution termed wuDuwo': (A, Mgh:) so in a trad. (A.) ― -b2- qalasato nafosuhu, (A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) His soul, or stomach, heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit: (A, K:) [like laqisato.] ― -b3- [Hence,] qalasati AlT~aEonapu biAld~ami (tropical:) [The wound made with a spear or the like belched forth blood]. (A.) ― -b4- And qalasati Als~aHaAbapu biAln~adaY (tropical:) The cloud cast forth moisture, or fine rain; not vehement rain. (A, * TA.) ― -b5- And qalasati AlkaA^osu, (S, K, *) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) The cup of wine cast forth [or overflowed with] the beverage, in consequence of its being very full. (S, K. *) ― -b6- And qalasa AlbaHoru, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The sea, or great river, cast forth [or overflowed with] water, in consequence of its being very full. (K, * TA.)
2 qal~asa see Q. Q. 1.
5 taqal~asa see Q. Q. 2.
Q. Q. 1 qalosaAhu * (S, K) and qalonasahu (K) He attired him with a qalanosuwap; (S, K;) as also ↓ qal~asahu, (A,) inf. n. taqoliysN. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2 taqalosaY * and taqalonasa He attired himself with, or wore, a qalanosuwap; (S, K;) as also ↓ taqal~asa. (S, A.) [The last of these verbs is used by ElHemedhánee transitively, as meaning, He attired himself with a cap of the kind called dan~iy~ap as a qlnswp: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., T. iii., p. 90 of the Arabic text:) but perhaps this usage is only post-classical.]

qalosN * , (A, K, and so in a copy of the S,) or ↓ qalasN, (A, Mgh, Msb, TA, and so in a copy of the S,) the former being the inf. n., (Mgh, Msb,) and ↓ qalasaAnN, (TA,) [but this last is more like an inf. n.,] What comes forth, (Kh [accord. to the S], or Lth, AZ [accord. to the TA], S, A, Msb, K,) from the throat, (Kh or Lth, S, A, K,) or from the belly, to the mouth, (AZ, Msb,) as much as fills the mouth, or less, (Kh or Lth, S, A, Msb, K,) of [undigested] food or drink, (AZ, Msb,) peculiarly, with acidity, and that acid humour itself, (Meyd, as cited by Golius,) whether the person cast it forth or return it to his belly: (AZ, Msb:) when it is repeated, (Kh, S, A, K,) or overcomes, (Lth, TA,) it is termed qaYo'N: (Kh or Lth, S, A, K:) or what comes forth, of vomit, being as much as fills the mouth: (Mgh:) pl. A^aqolaAsN. (TA.)
qalasN * : see qalosN.
qalosaApN * : see qalanosuwapN.
qalosuwapN * : see qalanosuwapN.
qalasaAnN * : see qalosN.

qalanosuwapN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ qulanosiyapN (S, K) and ↓ qalosuwapN and ↓ qalosaApN (TA) A certain thing that is worn upon the head, (K, TA,) well known; (TA;) [a cap, generally high and pointed, but sometimes close-fitting, which was worn by the Arabs, sometimes alone, and sometimes beneath the turban: there was also one kind which was round, like a melon: (see A^uroSuwSapN:) and a cowl, or hood, of a pointed form: see TuroTuwrN, and buronusN, and Earaqiy~apN: 'Abd-El-Lateef applies the term qalanosuwap nuHaAs to the cap of copper which covered the head of the
obelisk standing on the site of Heliopolis, now called El-Matareeyeh:] the kind worn by the Companions [of the Prophet] was such as fitted close to the head, [not pointed, or] not going away into the air: (K in art. bTH:) pl. qalaAnisu and qalaAsK (S, Msb, K) and qalaAniysu and qalaAsiY~N and qalanosK, which last is [properly a coll. gen. n. of which qalanosuwapN is the n. un., being] originally qalanosuwN, for there is no noun ending with an infirm letter preceded by a dammeh, wherefore the w is changed into Y, and the dammeh into a kesreh, and then the word becomes like qaADK [for qaADiYN]. (S, K.) The dim. is ↓ qulayonisapN and ↓ qulayosiyapN and ↓ qulayoniysapN and ↓ qulayosiy~apN: (S, K:) but not qulayoniysiyapN; for the Arabs form no dim. of a word of five [or more] letters so as to preserve all the letters, unless the fourth be a letter of prolongation. (TA.)
qulanosiyapN * see qalanosuwapN.
qulayosiyapN * and qulayosiy~apN: see qalanosuwapN.
qulayonisapN * and qulayoniysapN: see qalanosuwapN.
qalaAnisiY~N * : see qal~aAsN.

qal~aAsN * : see qaAlisN, in two places. -A2- A maker [or seller] of what is called qalanosuwap [or rather of qalaAnis, the pl.; and so ↓ qalaAnisiY~N; or this latter is perhaps post-classical]. (TA.)

qaAlisN * act. part. n. of 1, in the first and subsequent senses. (S, A.) ― -b2- You say, TaEonapN qaAlisapN and ↓ qal~aAsapN (tropical:) [A wound made with a spear or the like belching forth blood, and belching forth much blood]. (A.) And [in like manner], ↓ baHorN qal~aAsN (assumed tropical:) A sea, or great river, casting forth [much water (see 1)] or froth or foam: (S:) or flowing with a very copious and high tide of water. (K.)

1 qalaSa * , (S, M, A, &c.) aor.
qaliSa , inf. n. quluwSN, (S, M, Msb, K,) [has, among its significations, three which I mention together because two of them are assigned to it in one of the phrases here following, and all of them in another:] It contracted, or shrank; or became contracted or shrunk; (S, M, Mgh, L, Msb, K; *) as also ↓ ql~S, (S, Mgh, K, *) inf. n. taqoliySN; (K;) and ↓ tql~S: (S, M, * Mgh, Msb, * K:) and i. q. AirotafaEa; [which has two significations: it rose, or became raised: and it went away:] (S, M, * A, Mgh, Msb, * K; *) as also ↓ ql~S, and ↓ tql~S. (A, Mgh.) You say, qalaSa AlZ~il~u, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ql~S (TA) and tql~S (Mgh) and ↓ AqlS, (Fr, TA,) The shade contracted, or shrank, (M, K, TA,) Ean~iY from me: (M, K:) or decreased: (TA:) or went away; syn. AirotafaEa: (S, Msb, TA:) all of which explanations are correct. (TA.) And qalaSato $afatuhu His lip became contracted; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tql~St: (Msb:) or became contracted upwards. (A, TA.) And qalaSa AlD~aroEu The udder became drawn together. (TA.) And qalaSa Alv~awobu baEoda Algasoli The garment, or piece of cloth, contracted, or shrank, after the washing. (S, Msb, K.) And AlqamiySu ↓ ql~S, inf. n. taqoliySN; (K, TA;) or ↓ tql~S; (M, TA;) The shirt became contracted, or raised, or tucked up: (M, K, TA:) and in like manner, Ald~iroEu ↓ ql~St, and ↓ tql~St, [the coat of mail became contracted,] most frequently meaning upwards. (TA.) ― -b2- It (water) collected in a well, and became abundant: (IKtt, TA:) or rose (S, M, K) in a well; (S;) syn. AirotafaEa: (S, M, K:) or, when said of the water of a well, it signifies AirotafaEa as meaning it went away: and also as meaning it rose by its becoming copious: (A, TA:) thus it has two contr. significations: and it is also said that qalaSati Albiy^oru signifies the water of the well rose to its upper part: and the well became nearly, or entirely, exhausted: (TA:) and qalaSa Algadiyru the water of the pool left by a torrent went away. (M.) ― -b3- qalaSato nafosuhu, (M, K,) aor.
qaliSa , inf. n. qaloSN, (M,) and qaliSato, (M, K,) with kesr; (K;) His soul heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato: (M, K:) and a dial. form thereof is with s [i. e. qalasato, and also laqisato]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also qalaSa, aor.
qaliSa , inf. n. quluwSN, He leaped, sprang, or bounded. (AA, K.) ― -b5- qalaSati AlA_ibilu; (so in a copy of the A;) and ↓ ql~St, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoliySN; (K;) [probably signify the same: or] the former signifies The camels rose in their pace, or going: (A:) and the latter, they (the camels) were light, or active, and quick, or were vigorous, ($am~arato,) in their pace, or going: (M:) or went on in one regular, uniform, or constant, course. (K.) ― -b6- qalaSa, inf. n. quluwSN, also signifies He went away; (IB, TA;) and so ↓ ql~S, inf. n. taqoliySN: (TA:) each likewise signifies the same, but the latter in an intensive sense, said of tears; and so the latter when said of anything: (TA:) and so ↓ tql~S said of an animal's milk. (Mgh.) ― -b7- Also, qalaSa Alqawomu, inf. n. quluwSN, The company of men took up their luggage, (O, TS, K,) or collected themselves together, (L,) and went, or departed: (O, TS, L, K:) or they became distant, or remote: (TA:) or removed, or migrated, quickly from the dwelling. (A, TA.) ― -b8- And qalaSa AlgulaAmu, inf. n. as above, The boy grew up and walked. (TA.) See qaluwSN.

2 qal~aSa see 1, passim: ― -b2- see also 4. -A2- ql~S qamiySahu He contracted his shirt; he raised it, or tucked it up. (M, K, * TA.) Thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (K.) ― -b2- ql~S biyona Alr~ajulayoni He separated the two men, each from the other, in a case of reviling or fighting; syn. xal~aSa. (M.)

4 AqlS * : see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- It (a camel's hump) began to come forth: (IKtt, TA:) and, said of a camel, his hump appeared in some degree, (ISk, S, K, TA,) and rose: (TA:) and in like manner AqlSt said of a she-camel: (TA:) or the latter signifies she (a camel) became fat in her hump; as also ↓ ql~St; and in like manner one says of a he-camel [AqlS and ↓ ql~S]: (M:) or she became fat in the [season called] Sayof: (S, M, * K:) or i. q. gaArato; [so in the copies of the K, evidently a mistake for gaAr~ato, q. v.;] and her milk went away, or became drawn up; (K;) [a signification nearly agreeing with explanations of gAr~t;] opposed to A^anozalato. (TA.) See also qalaSN.
5 taqal~aSa see 1, passim.

qaloSN *
Abundance of water: and, contr., paucity thereof: (TA:) and ↓ qalaSapN and ↓ qaloSapN have the former of these significations: (M:) or ↓ qalaSapN signifies water of a well collecting therein and rising: (S, K:) and so ↓ qaloSapN, accord. to some lexicologists, as mentioned by Ibn-El-Ajdábee: (IB:) the pl. of qalaSapN is qalaSaAtN: (S, K:) and the pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of qaloSapN is ↓ qalaSN. (IB.) An Arab of the desert is related to have said, mina AlmaA'i ↓ famaA wajadotu fiyhaA A_il~aA qaloSapF, meaning, And I found not in it [i. e. the well] save a little quantity of water. (TA.)
qalaSN * : see qaloSN. -A2- The beginning of a she-camel's becoming fat; as also ↓ quluwSN. (M.) See 4.
qaloSapN * and qalaSapN: see qaloSN, throughout.

qaluwSN *
A young, or youthful, she-camel; (S, M, Msb, K;) i. e. among camels (Mgh, Msb) the like of a jaAriyap among women: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or such as endures journeying; (Lth, K;) so called until her tush grows forth, [in her ninth year,] when she ceases to be so called: (Lth:) or a young, or youthful, Arabian camel: (TA:) or a she-camel from the time when first ridden, until she sheds the central incisor, [in her sixth year,] when she is called naAqapN; (El-'Adawee, S, Sgh, K;) the he-camel during that period being called qaEuwdN, and then jamalN: (El-'Adawee, S, Sgh:) or any sh-camel from the time when she is ridden, whether she be a binotu labuwnK or a Hiq~ap, until she becomes a bakorap, or until her tush grows forth: (M:) or a she-camel in her sixth year: or in her second year: (M:) and sometimes a she-camel just born is thus called: (M:) the qlwS is so called because of the length of her legs, and her not being yet bulky in the body: (T, TA:) and a long-legged she-camel is so called, (S, K,) sometimes: (S:) the term is only applied to a female: (IDrd, K:) [dim. qulay~iSapN, of the pl. of which (qulay~iSaAtN) see an ex. in a verse cited in art. dh:] pl. qalaAy^iSu and quluSN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and quloSaAnN (M, L) and (pl. pl., K, i. e. pl. of quluSN, S) qilaASN. (S, M, Msb, K.) [Hence,] qilaASu Alv~aloji (tropical:) The clouds that bring snow. (A, TA.) [Hence also,] qilaASu Aln~ajomi [also called AlqilaASu and AlqalaAy^iSu] (assumed tropical:) Twenty stars, which, as the Arabs assert, Ald~abaraAn drove before him in demanding in marriage Alv~uray~aA; (TA;) some small stars before AldbrAn, following Alvry~A: (Mir-át ez-
Zemán:) [by some applied in the present day to the Hyades:] or the qilaAS are the stars around Ald~abaraAn. (Kzw.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A young, or youthful, female of the ostrich-kind; like the qlwS of the camel-kind; (M, TA;) the female of riy^aAl [or young ostriches, or young ostriches a year old]; i. e. a raA^olap; (TA;) a female of the ostrich-kind, of such as are termed ry^Al: (S:) or a female of the ostrich-kind: (A, O, K:) and of such as are termed ry^Al: (K:) or quluSu Aln~aEaAmi signifies the ry^Al of the ostrich: (IDrd, TA:) or qlwS [so in the TA, app. a mistake for quluS,] signifies the offspring of the ostrich; its Haf~aAn and its ry^Al: so says IKh, on the authority of El-Azdee. (IB, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (assumed tropical:) The young of the [species of bustard called] HubaAraY: (K:) or the female of the HbArY: or a little female HbArY. (M.) ― -b4- quluSN is also metonymically applied to signify (tropical:) Young women; (K;) as also qalaAy^iSu: (TA:) and the latter, to signify women [in a general sense]. (TA.) -A2- biy^orN qaluwSN A well having abundance of water: pl. qalaAy^iSu. (M.)
quluwSN * : see 1, (of which it is an inf. n.,) throughout: ― -b2- and see qalaSN.
qaliySN * : see qaAliSN.
qal~aASN * : see qaAliSN.

Zil~N qaAliSN *
Shade [contracting, or shrinking, from one: (see 1:) or] decreasing: (S, TA:) [or going away.] $afapN qaAliSapN A contracting lip: (S:) and rajulN qaAliSu Al$~afapi a man having a contracting lip. (Msb.) vawobN qaAliSN A garment contracted and short: (Sh, TA:) and ↓ qmyS muqal~iSN a short shirt: (A:) or a shirt contracted, or raised, or tucked up: and ↓ diroEN muqal~iSapN [a coat of mail contracted]: most frequently meaning upwards. (TA.) ― -b2- maA='N qaAliSN and ↓ qaliySN and ↓ qal~aASN Water collecting and becoming abundant in a well: (TA:) or rising, or high, (S, M, K,) in a well: (S:) the pl. of qaliySN is quluSN. (TA.) See also 1.

muqal~iSN * : see qaAliSN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a horse, Long in the legs, and contracted in the belly: (M, TA:) or light, or active, and quick, (mu$am~irN,) tall, and long in the legs: (S, K:) or tall. (A.)

miqolaASN * A she-camel fat in the hump; and in like manner, a he-camel: (M:) or a she-camel that becomes fat in the [season called] Sayof: (S, M:) and also, a she-camel that becomes fat and lean in the winter. (Ks, TA.)
See Supplement

quloqaAsN * [The colocasia; or arum. colocasia of Linnæus: or its root:] the root of a certain plant, which is eaten cooked, (AHn, K,) and used medicinally: (AHn:) the decoction thereof increases the venereal faculty, and fattens; but the taking it constantly engenders black bile. (AHn, K.) [See De Sacy's “ Relation de l'Egypte par Abd-allatif, ” pp. 94 — 98.]
See Supplement

1 qamaA^ati AlmaA$iyapu * , aor.
qamaAa ; (AZ, S, O, K;) and qamuw^at, (O, K,) aor.
qamuAa ; (K;) inf. n. qumuwo'N and qumuw'apN, (AZ, S, O, K) both of the former verb, (AZ, S, O,) and qamo'N (K) and qamaA='apN, (O, K,) which is of the latter verb, (O, TA,) and qamaA='N, (K,) also of the latter verb; (TA;) The cattle became fat, or plump; (AZ, S, O, K;) as also ↓ AqmA^t: (K:) the first is expl. in the T as meaning the cattle became full with fatness: and the epithet applied to them is there said to be ↓ qaAmiy^apN. (TA.) ― -b2- And qamaA^ati AlA_ibilu biAlmakaAni, (K, TA,) and qamuw^at, (K,) The camels abode in the place, (K, TA,) and were pleased with it, (TA,) because of its abundant pasture, and became fat, or plump, (K, TA,) in it. (TA.) And qamaA^ati AlmaA$iyapu makaAna ka*aA Hat~aY saminato [The cattle abode in such a place until they became fat, or plump]. (TA.) See also 5. ― -b3- And qamaA^otu biAlmakaAni, (O, TA,) inf. n. qamo'N, (TA,) I abode in the place: (O:) or I entered the place and abode in it. (TA.) And qamaA^a A_ilaY manozilK He went into an abode. (TA.) -A2- qamaA^ahu is also syn. with qamaEahu [q. v.]: (K:) the latter is affirmed to be the original word: (MF:) you say qamaA^otu Alr~ajula, meaning qamaEotuhu. (O.) -A3- qamuw^a, (S, O, K,) aor.
qamuAa ; and qamaA^a, aor.
qamaAa ; (K;) inf. n. qamaA='apN (S, O, K) and qamaA='N, both of the former verb, (S, O,) and qumo'N and qimo'N, (so in copies of the K,) or qumoA^apN and qimoA^apN, (so in the TK,) and qamoA^apN, (K,) which last is not an inf. n. un., (L, TA,) said of a man, (S, O, TA,) and of other than a man, (TA,) He was, or became, little and despicable (S, O, K, TA) in the eyes [of others]: (TA:) the former verb is the better known in this sense. (MF, TA.)

3 maA qaAmaA^ahu *
It (a thing, TA) did not suit him: (K, TA:) and so mA qaAnaA^ahu. (TA.)

4 AqmA^t AlmaA$iyapu * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AqmA^ Alqawomu The people, or party, had their camels in a fat, or plump, state. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- AqmA^ AlmaroEaY AlA_ibila The pasture, or place of pasture, suited the camels, (K, TA,) and rendered them fat, or plump. (TA, as from the K.) And AqmA^hu It (a thing, S, O, or a place, or pasture or a place of pasture, TA) pleased him. (S, O, K, TA.) -A2- And AqmA^hu He rendered him little and despicable. (S, O, K.)

5 tqm~A^a AlmakaAna * (in the CK AlmkAnu) [He found that] the place suited him, and consequently he abode in it. (O, K.) ― -b2- tqm~A^ Al$~aYo'i He took the best of the thing. (Th, K.) ― -b3- And He collected the thing little by little: (S, O:) and accord. to Z, Al$~aYo'i ↓ AqtmA^ signifies He collected the thing. (TA.)
8 A_iqotamaAa see what immediately precedes.

qamo'N *
A place in which a she-camel, and a hecamel, and a woman, and a man, abides until she, or he, becomes fat, or plump. (TA.)

qamoA^apN *
Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, and comforts, of life; and ease, repose, or freedom from trouble or inconvenience or from toil or fatigue; as also ↓ qumoA^apN. (K.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ maqomaA^apN and ↓ maqomuw^apN, (like mqnA^ [a mistranscription for mqnA^p] and mqnw^p, TA,) A place on which the sun does not come: (O, K:) pl. of the first word qimaA='N. (TA.)
qumoA^apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

qamiYo'N *
Little and despicable (S, O, K, TA) in the eyes [of others]; fem. qamiyy^apN: (TA:) pl. qimaA='N and qumaA='N; (K;) the latter of a [very] rare form. (TA.)
qaAmiy^apN * , fem. of qaAmiy^N: see 1, first sentence.
maqomaA^pN * and maqomuw^apN: see qamoA^apN.

1 qamiHahu * , (S, A, L, K,) aor.
qamaHa , (K,) inf. n. qamoHN; (S;) and ↓ AqtmHhu; (S, A, L, K;) He ate it, or took it into his mouth, (S, K,) namely, meal of parched barley or wheat, &c., (S, A, L,) not bread nor dates nor the like, but only what is eaten in the manner termed saf~N, (L,) without moistening it, or kneading it with water &c.; syn. Aisotaf~ahu; (S, K;) he took it in the palm of his hand (A, L) [and conveyed it] to his mouth (A) or licked it up. (L.) And qumoHapF minohu ↓ AiqotamaHotu [I so ate a mouthful thereof, i. e. of what is eaten in the manner described above]. (A.) ― -b2- And ↓ AqtmHhu likewise signifies, (L, K,) as also qamiHahu, (L,) He drank it, namely, what is called nabiy*, (L, K,) and $araAb [app. as meaning wine], and water, and milk. (L.) -A2- And, from qamiHahu signifying as expl. above, you say, qamaHa Eani AlmaA='i, (A,) or [simply] qamaHa, (S, L, K,) with fet-h, (S,) aor.
qamaHa , (L,) inf. n. qumuwHN; (S, L, K;) as also qamaha, aor.
qamaHa , inf. n. qumuwhN; (L;) and ↓ qAmH, (A, L,) inf. n. muqaAmaHapN and qimaAHN; (A;) and ↓ tqm~H, and
↓ AnqmH; (S, L, K;) He (a camel) raised his head (S, A, K) from the water (A) or at the watering-trough, and refused to drink, (S, K,) his thirst being satisfied, (S, A,) or by reason of loathing, or of the coldness of the water, or of some disease. (A.) And AlA_ibilu ↓ qaAmaHati The camels came to the water and did not drink, (S, K,) but raised their heads, (S,) by reason of disease, or of cold, (S, K,) or of the coldness of the water, or because their thirst was satisfied. (TA.) And ↓ $ariba fataqam~aHa and ↓ A@noqamaHa [He drank] and raised his head and left drinking by reason of his thirst's being satisfied. (S.) And fulaAnN mina AlmaA='i ↓ tqm~H Such a one drank water, or the water, with dislike, or loathing. (AZ.) ↓ A^a$orabu faA^ataqam~aHu, said by Umm-Zara, means (tropical:) [I drink] and I satisfy my thirst until I am not able to drink more, so I raise my head like the [camel that is said to be] muqaAmiH: (A, TA: *) Az says that Alt~aqam~uHu primarily relates to water, but is metaphorically used by her in relation to milk: she means that she satisfied her thirst with milk until she raised her head from drinking it like as does the camel when he dislikes drinking water: (TA:) or, as some relate her words, she said, faA^ataqan~aHu, (A, TA, *) which [likewise] means, “ and I raise my head in consequence of the being satisfied with drinking. ” (A.) [See also art. qnH.] ― -b2- qamaHa, aor.
qamaHa , inf. n. qumuwHN, is also expl. by Lth as signifying He (a camel) became very languid by reason of vehement thirst: but accord. to Az, this is wrong. (L.)

2 qm~Hhu * , (A, K,) inf. n. taqomiyHN, (K,) (tropical:) He repelled him (i. e. his companion, A) with a small and paltry thing, in lieu of much that was due to him; (A, K; *) like as the wronging commander does to him who engages with him in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition, by doling to him the least, or meanest, thing, and choosing for himself in preference to him in the partition of the spoil. (A, TA.)

3 qaAomaHa see 1, near the middle, in two places. ― -b2- Hence, (S, A,) $ahoraA qimaAHK, (S, A, K,) also called ↓ $ahoraA qumaAHK, (K,) The two coldest, (S, K,) or two of the coldest, (A,) months (S, A, K) of winter; (A;) said by Sh to be $iybaAnu and miloHaAnu; (TA; [in which it is also here said that they are the two months whereof each is called kaAnuwn: if so, corresponding to December and January O. S.: but see $iybaAnu, in art. $yb:]) so called because the camels, when they come therein to water, find its coldness hurtful to them, and therefore raise their heads from it. (S.)

4 A^uqomiHa * , (MA,) [in my MS. copy of the K indefinitely written AqmH, and in the CK A=qomaHa, but it is correctly A^uqomiHa, as is shown by its being added, after the explanation, in the TA, “ whence ↓ muqomaHuwna in the Kur ” (xxxvi. 7,] and by explanations of this epithet in several of the expositions of the Kur-án, and the like is also indicated in the S,] inf. n. A_iqomaAHN, (S,) said of a camel, (MA,) or of a man, and [in this case, but not when said of a camel,] tropical, (TA,) He raised his head, and contracted his eyes: (S, MA, K, TA:) [or he was made to raise his head and to contract his eyes:] it is expl. by Z as in the K. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, (S,) A^aqomaHahu Algul~u (tropical:) The gul~ [i. e. the ring, or collar, of iron, for the neck, or the shackle for the neck and hands, consisting of two rings, one for the neck and the other for the hands, connected by a bar of iron,] caused his (i. e. a captive's K) head to be raised, by reason of the straitness thereof; (S, K, TA;) meaning that the bar of the gul~, which [by its projecting above the ring around the neck] pricked his chin, did not let him lower his head; as is said in the A. (TA.) ― -b3- AlA_iqomaAHu [as inf. n. of A^uqomiHa, like A^ukomiHa (with k and H) in form and in meaning,] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The elevating of the head by reason of pride: and so AlA_ikomaAxu. (L and TA in art. kmx: but in the CK, in that art, AlAiqomAxu, with x.) And AqmH biA^anofihi [i. e. A^uqomiHa] signifies $amaxa [i. e. $amaxa biA^anofihi, (assumed tropical:) He magnified, or exalted, himself; was proud; behaved proudly, or disdainfully; or elevated his nose, from pride]; (K, TA;) and raised his head, scarcely ever, or never, lowering it: as though the verb had two contr. significations. (TA.) ― -b4- AqmH said of thirst is expl. by Lth as signifying It rendered a camel very languid: but accord. to Az, this is wrong. (L.) -A2- AqmH Als~unobulu The ears [of wheat] became pervaded by the farinaceous substance. (K.) ― -b2- And AqmH Albur~u, so in the T and L and other lexicons, but in all the copies of the K Albur~u ↓ AiqotamaHa, The wheat becomes mature qamoH. (TA.)
5 taqam~aHa see 1, near the middle, in four places.
7 A_inoqamaHa see 1, near the middle, in two places.
8 A_iqotamaHa see 1, first quarter, in three places: -A2- and see also 4, last sentence.

qamoHN *
Wheat, syn. bur~N, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) and HinoTapN, and TaEaAmN, (Msb,) when the farinaceous substance pervades the ears, or from the time when it has attained its full growth to the time when it has become compact: (L:) [and the grain of wheat; as also bur~N and HinoTapN and TaEaAmN:] a word of the dial. of Syria. and sometimes used by the people of El-Hijáz; or, as some say, a Coptic word; but the former assertion is the more correct: (TA:) the word bur~N is more chaste: (S in art. br:) ↓ qamoHapN signifies a single grain thereof. (Msb.) ― -b2- jaraY AlqamoHu fiY Als~unobuli means The farinaceous substance pervaded the ears [of wheat]. (L.)
qamoHapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

qumoHapN *
A mouthful of qamiyHap [q. v.]: (S, K:) or, as more than one have said of water. (TA.) -A2- See also Alqum~aHaAnu.
AlqimoHaY * and AlqimoHaApu The qayo$ap [q. v.. generally meaning the glans of the penis]. (K.)

AlqimoHaAnapu *
The part between the qamaHoduwap [or occiput] and what is termed nuqorapu AlqafaA [which is the small hollow in the back of the neck]. (K.)

Alqum~aHaAnu * , thus accord. to the Basrees, (TA,) and Alqum~aHaAnu, and ↓ AlqumoHapu, (K,) The [plant called] waros [q. v.]: (S, K, TA:) or [the kind of perfume called] Al*~ariyrapu: (TA:) or (so accord. to the K and TA, but in the S “ also, ”) a substance that comes upon the surface of wine, like Al*~ariyrap: (S, K, TA:) it is the froth, or scum, thereof: (L, TA:) or, as some say, (TA, but in the K “ and, ”) saffron: (K, TA:) or a certain perfume: or a white substance that overspreads wine resembling Al*~ariyrap: this last is said to be what is meant in the following verse by En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee], the only poet known by AHn to have mentioned Alqm~HAn:
A_i*aA fuD~ato xawaAtimuhu EalaAhu
yabiysu Alqum~aHaAni mina AlmudaAmi
[When its seals are broken, what is exsiccated of the white substance resembling particles of calamus aromaticus of the wine comes, or appears, upon its surface]. (L, TA.)

qumaAHN * , a subst. from qamaHa or qaAmaHa, Aversion of a camel from drinking, by reason of the thirst's being satisfied, or of loathing, or of the coldness of the water, or of some disease. (L. [See also HumaAmN.]) Hence $ahoraA qumaAHK, also called $ahoraA qimaAHK: see 3.

A_in~ahu laqamuwHN liln~abiy*i *
Verily he is a great drinker of the beverage called nebeedh. (ISh.)

qamiyHapN * a subst. signifying What is eaten in the manner termed AiqotimaAH, [see qamiHa,] (S, L,) of the meal of parched barley or wheat, &c., (L,) or such as a digestive stomachic (juwaAri$ [often written jawaAri$], &c.: (S:) expl. in the K by the word juwaAri$ [only], in some copies with the addition of a final n [evidently a mistake for t, since its original in the Pers. GuwaAri$o or GuwaAri$ot]: (TA:) app. from AlqamoHu meaning Albur~u. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, maA A^aSaAbati AlA_ibilu A_il~aA qamiyHapF mino kalaA^K (tropical:) The camels obtained not [aught] save somewhat of dry herbage which they took into the mouth unmoistened, or licked up. (A, TA.)

qaAmiHN * A camel raising his head (S, A, K) from the water (A) or at the watering-trough, and refusing to drink, (S, K,) his thirst being satisfied, (S, A,) or by reason of loathing, or of the coldness
of the water, or of some disease: (A:) and disliking water from any cause: (K:) and ↓ muqaAmiHN signifies the same, applied to a he-camel, (As, S, A,) and to a she-camel: (As, S, K:) pl. of the former qum~aHN; (S, K;) and of ↓ the latter qimaAHN, which is anomalous, (S,) or this is pl. of qaAmiHN, or it is [an inf. n.] syn. with muqaAmaHapN, used as an epithet; you say A_ibilN qimaAHN; (A;) and A_ibilN ↓ muqaAmiHapN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) as expl. by Lth, and so ↓ muqaAmiHN, but, accord. to Az, wrongly, (L,) A camel very languid by reason of vehement thirst. (L, K.)
muqomaHuwna * : see 4, first sentence.
muqaAmiHN * , and its fem.: see qaAmiHN, in three places.

AlqamaHoduwapu *
What is behind the head; (S, in art. qHd; and Msb;) that is to say, (Msb,) the [occiput or] hinder part of the back of the head; (T, Msb, K;) i. e., the surface between the *uw^aAbap [here app. meaning the hair that surrounds the round part of the head] and what is termed faA^osu AlqafaA [or the small protuberance above the back of the neck]: (T:) also, the protuberance above the back of the neck, (L, K,) between the *uw^aAbap [see above] and the back of the neck, sloping down from the haAmap [or middle, or crown, or top, of the head]; it is the part of the head which touches the ground when a man lies on his back: (L:) also, the upper part of the back of the head: (L, K:) or that part of the bone of the head which projects over the back of the neck; the hAmp being above it; and the qa*aAl, below it, next the part of the back of the neck that is between the ears: (AZ, L:) pl. qamaAHidu (S, L, K, &c.) and qamaAHiydu and qamaHoduwaAtN. (L.) Accord. to J and AHei, the m is an augmentative letter; but others hold it to be a radical; and F says, that J's mentioning this word in art. qHd requires consideration. (TA.)

1 qamida * , aor.
qamada , (TA,) inf. n. qamadN, (K,) He, or it, was, or became, tall, or long: or he was, or became, large and long in the neck. (K, TA.)
Q. Q. 4 A_iqomahad~a * [in which the h is an augmentative letter accord. to J, is said by F to be improperly assigned by J to this art.] see art. qmhd.

qumud~N * (Lth, S, L, K) and qumudN (K) or qumodN (L) and qumodudN (Lth, L) and qumoduwdN and qumaAdN and qumaAdiY~N (K) and qumud~aAnN and qumud~aAniY~N (L, K) Strong: (Lth, S, K:) or strong and hard or hardy: (L:) or gross, thick, coarse, or rude, (K,) and hard, or hardy: (TA:) applied to a man: (L, K:) fem. qumud~apN (S) and qumud~aAnapN and qumud~aAniy~apN. (L.) ― -b2- A_in~ahu laqumud~N qumodudN Verily he is very strong. (Lth, L.) ― -b3- *akarN qumud~N Penis vehementer se erigens, (L, K,) or Alqumud~u is a name of the penis. (L.) ― -b4- See also A^aqomadu.

A^aqomadu * , fem. qamodaA='u, (L, K,) and ↓ qumud~N and [fem.? see qumud~u above] qumud~apN and qumud~aAniy~apN, (K,) Large and long in the neck: or tall, (L, K,) in a general sense: applied to a human being. (L.) ― -b2- naHonu qumodu AlA^aqomaAdi We are thick-necked. (L.) ― -b3- See also qumud~N.

1 qamira * , aor.
qamara , (S, A, K,) inf. n. qamarN, (S,) He, (a man, S, A, K, and an antelope, and a bird, TA,) and it, (a man's sight, A,) became dazzled (S, A, K) in the moonlight, (A,) or by snow, (S, A, K,) so that he could not see: (S, A:) he (an antelope) became deprived of his sight by the light of the moon, so that he was perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (IKtt.) ― -b2- qamira, aor.
qamara , (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man, TA,) was, or became, sleepless in the moonlight. (K.) -A2- See also 3, throughout.

3 qAmrhu * , inf. n. qimaArN (S, A, Msb, K) and muqaAmarapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He contended with him for stakes, or wagers, laid by both of them to be taken by the winner; syn. raAhanahu; (K;) [he contended with him in a game of hazard, such as that called Almayosir, or the like: (see Bd and Jel, ii. 216:)] in common modern conventional language, he played with him at a game in which it is generally made a condition that the winner shall receive something of the loser: (so accord. to an explanation which I find in several copies of the KT:) from taqamiarahu signifying “ he deceived him; ” because qimaAr is [often] deception. (A.) You say qaAmarahu ↓ faqamarahu, aor. of the latter
qamura (JK, S, A, Msb, K) and
qamira , (JK,) inf. n. qamorN, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) He contended with him for stakes, or wagers, &c., (S, * K,) and overcame him therein; (S, A, Msb, K;) and ↓ qaAmarahu fataqam~arahu signifies the same: (K:) or ↓ tqm~r signifies he overcame him who contended with him in the contest termed qimaAr: and ↓ qamarahu, aor.
qamira , inf. n. qamorN, he played with him in the manner termed qimaAr and overcame him: (S:) or ↓ qamarahu, inf. n. qamorN, he overcame him in play; and so ↓ A^aqomarahu: (IKtt:) or ↓ qamara, aor.
qamira , (K,) inf. n. qamorN, (TA,) i. q. qAmr, (K, * TK,) and is transitive: (TA:) you say qamara biAlqidaAHi, and biAln~arodi, [he contended for stakes, or wagers, &c., with the gaming-arrows, and with the apparatus for trictrac or backgammon]: (A:) and ↓ qamarahu [as syn. with qaAmarahu]: (TA:) and AlmaAla ↓ qamarotuhu, aor.
qamira , [so in a copy of the A, doubly trans., app. meaning I contended with him in a game of hazard for the property: or I so contended with him for the property and overcame him.]

4 Aqmr AlhilaAlu *
The new moon became what is termed qamar, in the third night. (A.) ― -b2- Aqmrt layolatunaA Our night became bright [with light of the moon]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- A^aqomaronaA [We entered upon the time of moonlight;] the moon rose upon us. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Aqmr He (a man, TA) watched, or waited, for the rising of the moon. (K.) -A2- See also 3.

5 tqm~rhu *
He came to him in the moonlight. (S.) ― -b2- tqm~r AlZ~ibaA='a, (A, TA,) and AlT~ayora, (TA,) He hunted, or pursued, the antelopes, (A, TA,) and the birds, (TA,) in the moonlight, so that their sight was dazzled. (A, TA.) ― -b3- tqm~r AlA^asadu The lion went forth in the moonlight in quest of prey. (S, K. *) -A2- tqm~rhu He deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him; desired to do him some evil action without his knowing whence it proceeded. (A.) -A3- See also 3, in two places.

6 tqAmrwA *
They played [together] in the manner termed qimaAr: (S:) they contended together for stakes, or wagers, &c.; (K;) [they contended together in a game of hazard, such as that called Almayosir, or the like: see 3.]

Alqamaru *
The moon in its third night [and after]: (ISd, A, K:) or the moon during the interval between the first two and last two nights: (AHeyth:) or after three nights until the end of the month: (S:) [and the moon, absolutely, in many instances:] so called because of its whiteness, (S, Msb, TA,) from Alqumorapu: (TA:) of the masc. gender: pl. A^aqomaArN. (TA.) The dim., qumayorN, is found to occur: (S:) and is applied to The moon at the time called muHaAq [which is generally said to be applied to the last three nights of the month]: you say gaAba qamayorN [The moon at the time called muHaAq set, or disappeared]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- AisotaroEayotu maAliYa Alqamara (tropical:) I left my cattle to pasture without a pastor to take care of them in the night: and [in like manner,] AstrEyth Al$~amos, in the day. (TA.) ― -b3- AlqamaraAni The sun and the moon: one of them [namely the latter] being made predominant. (TA.)
qamirN * : fem. with p: see A^aqomaru.

qumorapN *
A colour inclining to greenness: (A, K:) or whiteness inclining to dinginess or duskiness: (A:) or whiteness in which is a dinginess or duskiness: (K:) or clear, or pure, whiteness. (TA.) See also A^aqomaru.
qamariY~N * [Of, or relating to, the moon; lunar]. Ex. Als~anapu Alqamariy~apu The lunar year. (Mgh, art. $ms.)

qumoriY~N * is a rel. n. from TayorN qumorN: and qumorN is either pl. of A^aqomaru, like as HumorN is of A^aHomaru, or pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of qumoriY~N, like as ruwmN is of ruwmiY~N: (S, Msb:) or qumoriY~N is a rel. n. from the name of a mountain, or of a place, or some other thing, accord. to different authors: or its Y is
added to give intensiveness to its signification: (TA:) the qumoriY~ is [A bird] of the [species called] fawaAxit; [pl. of faAxitapN;] (Msb;) a certain species of bird; so called because A^aqomar [q. v.] in colour, like the faAxitap in El-Hijáz; (JK;) [a species of collared turtle-dove, of a dull white colour marked with a black collar: such I have see in Egypt, caged; but they are rare there; and, I believe, are brought from Arabia:] the qumoriy~ap is a species of HamaAm, (K,) HamaAy^im [i. e. pigeons]: (M, TA:) or qumoriy~apN is applied to the female; and the male is called saAqu Hur~K: (S, Msb, K: see saAqu Hur~K in art. swq): and the pl. is qumaAriY~u, (S, Msb, K,) imperf. decl.; (S;) and accord. to some, qamaAraY; (TA;) and qumorN. (K.)
qimaArN * : see 3. [It is often used as a subst., signifying (tropical:) A game of hazard, such as that called Almayosir, and the like.]
qamiyrN * (tropical:) An antagonist in the contention termed qimaArN: (IJ, K:) pl. A^aqomaArN, (IJ, K,) which is anomalous, like A^anoSaArN, pl. of naSiyrN. (TA.)

A^aqomaru *
Of a colour inclining to xuDorap: or of a dull or dingy or dusky white: (K:) and white: (S, Msb, K:) or intensely white: (IKtt:) fem. qamoraA='u: (S, K:) pl. qumorN. (S, Msb.) You say HimaArN A^aqomaru (S, A, Msb, K) An ass of the colour termed qumorap: (K:) or a white ass: (S, A, Msb:) and A^ataAnN qamoraA='u a she-ass of the colour termed qumorap: (K:) or a white she-ass. (S.) The Arabs say, that when the sky appears of the hue of the belly of a she-ass of this colour, it is most abundant in rain. (TA.) Also farasN A^aqomaru A moon-coloured horse. (Mgh.) And saHaAbN A^aqomaru A cloud, or clouds, of a white colour: (S:) or intensely bright, by reason of the abundance of water therein: and [hence] full [of water]. (TA.) ― -b2- layolapN qamoraA='u, (S, A, K,) and muqomirapN, (A, Msb, K,) and ↓ muqomirN, (K) and ↓ qamirapN, (IAar, K,) which last is held by ISd, to be a kind of rel. n., or possessive epithet, (TA,) A moon-lit night; a night in which the moon shines: (A, K:) or a light, or bright, night: (S:) or a white night.
