(Msb.) IAar, mentions layolN qamoraA='u; but ISd, says this is strange, and I think, he adds, that by lyl he means lylp, or that he makes lyl fem. as a pl. (TA.) You also say layolapu AlqamoraA='i, meaning The night of moonlight: (Lth, A, Mgh:) for AlqamoraA='u also signifies the moonlight. (Lth, A, Mgh, K.) And qaEadNnaA fiY AlqamoraA='i We sat in the moonlight. (A.) And A^atoyotuhu fiY AlqamoraA='i [I came to him in the moonlight]. (S.) ― -b3- wajohN A^aqamaru A face likened to the moon (K, * TA) in respect of whiteness. (TA.)

muqomirN * : see A^aqomaru. ― -b2- A_in~a All~ayola TawiylN waA^anota muqomirN [Verily the night is long, and thou hast the light of the moon: a proverb:] meaning, Wait thou patiently for the accomplishment of thy want. (JK.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 45.]

1 qamasa * , (S, K,) aor.
qamisa and
qamusa , (K,) inf. n. qamosN (S, A, K) and qumuwsN, (TA,) He, or it, (i. e. anything, TA,) dived, or plunged, (S, A, K,) in water: (TA:) he, or it, dived, or plunged, or became immersed, therein, and then rose: (TA:) he (a man) disappeared in water: (Sh:) and ↓ Anqms [signifies the same as qamasa: or] he, or it, became immersed, in water: (S:) and this latter, he leaped into a well. (Sh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] It (a child, or fœtus,) was, or became, in a state of commotion in the belly (S, K) of its mother: (S:) or in the membrane which enclosed it in the belly. (TA.) -A2- qamasahu, (S, A,) [aor., app., as above,] inf. n. qamosN, (K,) He immersed, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, (S, A, K, [in the CK Alqamosu is put by mistake for Algamosu,]) in water; (S, A;) as also ↓ A^aqomasahu, (S,) inf. n. A_iqomaAsN. (K.) See also gamasahu. You say also, qamasotu bihi fiY Albiy^ori I cast him into the well. (Sh.) ― -b2- qaAmasotuhu faqamasotuhu: see 3.

3 qAmshu * , (K,) inf. n. muqaAmasapN, (TA,) He vied, or contended, with him in diving. (K, * TA.) You say, ↓ qaAmasatuhu qaqamasotuhu, (S,) [aor. of the latter, accord. to rule,
qamusa only,] inf. n. qamosN, (K,) I vied, or contended, with him in diving, (TA,) and I overcame him therein. (K, TA.) You say of him who contends, disputes, or litigates, with an adversary, (A,) or who disputes with one more knowing than himself, (S, K,) fulaAnN yuqaAmisu HuwtFA (tropical:) [Such a one vies, or contends, in diving with a fish]. (S, A, K.) You say also, fulaAnN yuqaAmisu fiY sir~ihi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) Such a one hides himself at one time and appears at another. (TA.)
4 Aqms * : see 7. -A2- Aqmshu: see qamasahu.

6 AlS~iboyaAnu yataqaAmasuwna fiY AlbaHori *
The children vie, or contend, one with another, in diving in the sea, or great river; syn. yatagaAT~uwna. (A.)
7 Anqms * : see qamasa, in two places. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It (a star) set, or descended in the west; (S, K;) as also ↓ Aqms. (TA.)
qamiysN * : see qaAmuwsN.
qam~aAsN * : see qaAmisN.
qaAmisN * (TA) and ↓ qam~aAsN, (S, TA,) [but the former is a simple epithet, and the latter intensive,] A diver: (S, TA:) a diver for pearls. (TA.)
qawomasN * : see qaAmuwsN.

qaAmuwsN * The sea; syn. baHorN; (IDrd, K;) as also ↓ qamiysN: (O:) or the deepest part thereof: (A 'Obeyd, A, K:) or the main body of the water thereof; as also ↓ qawomasN: (K, A, TA:) or the middle, and main body, thereof. (S.)
munoqamasN * The time of a star's setting at dawn. (S, * TA.)

1 qama$a * , aor.
fami$a , (M, TA,) inf. n. qamo$N, (S, M, K,) He collected (S, M, K) a thing, (S,) or qumaA$, (M, K,) meaning small rubbish, or broken particles of things, on the surface of the ground, (K,) hence and thence; (S, TA:) as also ↓ qm~$, inf. n. taqomiy$N. (S, TA.) Hence, qamo$u Alr~iyHi Alt~uraAba [The wind's collecting the dust]. (TA.)
2 fam~a$a see 1.

5 tqm~$ * , (K,) or tqm~$ AlqumaA$a, and ↓ Aqtm$hu, (M, TA,) He ate what he found, (K, TA,) hence and thence, (TA,) even though it might be vile: (K, TA:) or he ate what is termed qmA$, hence and thence. (M.)
8 A_ifotama$a see 5.

qamo$N * The bad [or refuse] of anything: pl. qumaA$N; like as EuraAqN is pl. of EaroqN; (Yaakoob, ISk, M;) and ↓ qumaA$apN is like it: (TA:) and ↓ qamoA$N is also a sing., like qamo$N. (M, TA.) qumaA$N also signifies What is collected hence and thence: (S:) or small particles, or fragments, of anything; as also ↓ qumaA$apN; (M, IKtt;) and so qu$aAmapN: (IKtt, TA:) or small rubbish, or broken particles of things, on the surface of the ground. (K.) You say, maA A^aEoTaAniY A_il~aA qumaA$FA He gave me not aught save the worst of what he found. (K.) [Hence,] qumaA$N Albayoti Household goods, or utensils and furniture. (S.) [Hence also,] qumaA$u Aln~aAsi The refuse, or meanest sort, of the people, or of mankind. (K, * TA.) [The application of qumaA$N to Any kind of woven stuff, whether linen, cotton, or silk, &c., is post-classical. Its pl. is A^aqomi$apN.]
qumaA$N * : see qamo$N, throughout.
qumaA$apN * : see qamo$N, in two places.

qam~aA$N *
One who sells household goods, or furniture and utensils. (TA.)

1 qamaSa * , aor.
qamuSa (S, M, A, Msb, K) and
qamiSa , (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. qamoSN (S, Msb, K) and qimaASN, (S, M, A, K, or this is a simple subst., Msb,) and qumaASN, (M, K, or this last is not allowable, S,) He (a horse or other animal, S, A, K, or a camel, Msb) raised his fore legs together and put them down together, (S, A, Msb, K,) on being mounted or ridden, (Msb,) and beat the ground (Eajana) with his hind feet; (S, K;) like Aisotan~a; (S;) as also ↓ qm~S: (A:) or qumaASN, with damm,
is the inf. n. when it signifies he did so usually: (K:) and, inf. n. qimaASN and qumaASN, he pranced, leaped, sprang, or bounded: (M, K:) and, inf. n. qimaASN, (tropical:) he was, or became, restless, unquiet, or unsteady, (K, TA,) and took fright, and ran away at random, or shied: (TA:) and, inf. n. qumaASN, (assumed tropical:) it (a bird of the kind called nugar) remained not steadily in a place, but leaped from its place impatiently: and, inf. n. qamoSN, (assumed tropical:) he took fright, and ran away at random, or shied, and turned aside or away. (TA.) You say, h`*ihi Ald~aAb~apu fiyhaA qimaASN; you should not say qumaASN; (S;) or you say qumaASN also; (TA;) and qamaASN, which last is the most chaste; (L, TA;) This beast has in her a property of raising and putting down her fore legs together, and beating the ground with her hind legs. (S.) And it is said in a proverb, (S,) maA biAlEayori mino qimaASK, (S, A, K,) and qumaASK; (Sgh, TA; and so, as well as qimaASK, in two copies of the S;) i. e. AlHimaAr; (S;) [There is not in the ass any power of raising and putting down his fore legs together, &c.;] applied to him who has become low, or mean, after being high, in rank, or condition; (S, A, K;) and to a weak man, in whom is no activity: (A, K:) or, as the proverb is related by Sb, A^afalaA qumaASa biAlEayori [Is there not, then, any power &c. in the ass?] (M, TA.) And in a trad., faqamaSato bihi faSaraEatohu And it leaped, or sprang, or bounded, and took fright, and ran away at random, or shied, with him, and threw him down. (TA.) You also say, Aln~aAqapu biAlr~adiyfi ↓ qam~aSati (tropical:) The she-camel went briskly with the rider upon the hinder part. (A.) And qamaSa AlbaHoru biAls~afiynapi, (S, K,) or bihaA ↓ qam~aSa, (A,) (tropical:) The sea put the ship in a state of commotion (S, A, K) by the waves (S, A) thereof. (A.) And it is said in a trad., lataqomiSan~a bikumu AlA^aroDu qumaASa Aln~ugari (assumed tropical:) Verily the earth shall be in a state of commotion with you [like the commotion of the kind of bird called ngr]. (TA.) You say also, A^axa*ahu AlqimaASu (tropical:) Restlessness, or inquietude, or unsteadiness, seized him. (A, TA.) And, of a horse whose sciatic vein or nerve is contracted, ($anija, [not $bH as in Freytag's Lexicon,]) qamaSato rijolupu [app. meaning, His hind leg became twitched up, as in springhalt]: in which case you also say of him, AlEuroquwbi ↓ A_in~ahu laqaAmiSu [as though meaning, verily he has a twitching up of the hock]. (S, TA.) [See also EusaAfN.]

2 qam~aSa see 1, in three places. -A2- qm~Shu qamiySFA He clad him with a qmyS [or shirt]: (S, Msb, K:) and qm~Shu vawobFA [he clad him with a garment as a shirt]. (A.) [Hence] you say, qm~Shu A@ll~`hu wa$oYa AlxilaAfapi (tropical:) [God invested him with the variegated robe of the office of Khaleefeh]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., (K, TA,) that Mohammad said to 'Othmán, (TA,) A_in~a A@ll~`ha sayuqam~iSuka qamiySFA, meaning (tropical:) Verily God will invest thee with the apparel of the office of Khaleefeh, (K, TA,) and will ennoble and adorn thee like as he is ennobled and adorned who has a robe of honour conferred upon him. (TA.) ― -b2- qm~S Alv~awoba, (inf. n. taqomiySN, TA,) He cut out a qamiyS [or shirt] from the piece of cloth. (Lh, M, A, TA.)

5 tqm~S fiY Aln~ahori *
He turned over, and became immersed, in the river. (TA.) -A2- tqm~S, (K,) or tqm~S qamiySFA, (S, M, A, Msb,) He clad himself with a qmyS [or shirt]. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) [Hence] you say, tqm~S AlA_imaArapa and AlwilaAyapa (tropical:) [He became invested with the office of commander, prefect, or the like]. (TA.) And tqm~S libaAsa AlEiz~i (tropical:) [He became invested with might, or nobility. (A, TA.)

6 tqAmS AlS~iboyaAnu * [app., The boys contended in leaping, springing, or bounding, raising both the legs together and putting them down together]: and bayonahumo muqaAmaSapN [between them is a contending in leaping, &c.]. (A, TA.)
A_in~ahu laHasanu AlqimoSapi * [Verily he has a good mode of attiring himself with the shirt]. (Lh, M.)

qimiS~aY *
i. q. quimaASN, i. e. A leaping, springing, or bounding: (Kr, M:) or i. q. qibiS~aY, (K,) i. e. a quick run. (Fr, TA.)
qamaASN * and qumaASN and qimaASN: see 1, passim.

qamuwSN * A beast of carriage that leaps, springs, or bounds, (taqomiSu, K, i. e. tavibu, TA,) with its master; as also ↓ qamiySN; (K;) likewise signifying a hackney (biro*awon) that leaps, &c., much. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Restless; unquiet; that does not remain steadily in a place. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The lion: (IKh, L:) because he goes about in search of his prey. (TA.) ― -b4- A_in~ahu laqamuwSu AlHanojarapi (tropical:) Verily he is a liar; (Kr, M, A;) as also gmwS. (TA.)

qamiySN * : see qamuwSN. -A2- [A shirt; a shift;] a certain thing that is worn, (S,) well known; (M, K;) accord. to El-Keiyim Ibn-El-Jezeree, and others, a sewed garment with two sleeves, not opened [down the front], worn beneath the [other] clothes; (TA;) accord. to El-Hulwánee, that of which the slit is towards, or to, the shoulder-joint; thus differing from a woman's diroE, of which the opening for the head to pass through extends towards, or to, the bosom; but this [says Mtr] I find not in the lexicons: (Mgh, art. drE:) “ or, ” as in some copies of the K, but in others “ and, ” (TA,) only of cotton, (K,) or of linen; (TA;) not of wool: (Sgh, K:) or by this is app. meant that such is generally the case: (Ibn-El-Hajar El-Mekkee, TA:) accord. to some, it may be from the skin [so called] which is the pericardium; [but accord. to Z, the reverse is the case;] or from taqay~aSa signifying “ he turned himself over: ” (TA:) sometimes fem.: (K:) or masc.; but sometimes meaning a coat of mail (diroEN), and then it is fem.: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aqomiSapN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] qumoSaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and qumuSN. (M, Msb, K.) In a trad. mentioned above, (see 2,) it is used tropically. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The membrane that encloses a child in the womb. (Sgh, K.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or qamiySu Alqalobi, (A,) (tropical:) The pericardium: (IAar, K:) or the latter signifies the fat of the heart; app. as being likened to the garment above mentioned: (M:) [and, by a synecdoche, the heart itself, with its appertenances: see an ex. in a verse cited in art. swd, conj. 9.] You say, hataka Alxawofu qamiySa qalobihi (tropical:) [Fear rent open his pericardium, or the fat of his heart]. (A, TA.)

qam~aASN *
A seller of qumoSaAn [or shirts]. (TA.)
qaAmiSN * : see 1, of which it is the act. part. n.: and see an ex. voce mawoquwSN. ― -b2- Kicking; striking with the foot. (TA.) ― -b3- qaAmiSu AlEuroquwbi: see 1, last signification.

1 qamaTa * , aor.
qamuTa (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and
qamiTa , (M, K,) inf. n. qamoTN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) He bound a child (S, Msb) in the cradle, and a sheep or goat on the occasion of slaughtering it, (S,) with the qimaAT [q. v.]: (S, Msb:) or qamaTahu signifies he bound his arms and legs, or hands and feet, together, like as is done with a child in the cradle, (K, TA,) and elsewhere, putting his limbs [or arms] next to the body, and then winding upon him the qimaAT: (TA:) and he bound his (a captive's, Mgh, Msb, K, or others', Mgh) arms and legs, or hands and feet, together, (Mgh, Msb, K, *) with a rope; (Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ qm~Thu, (M, K,) inf. n. taqomiyTN: (M, TA:) and qumiTa he (a captive) was thus bound. (S, TA.) ― -b2- qamaTa AlA_ibila, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He disposed the camels in a file, string, or series. (K, TA.)
2 qam~aTa see 1.
qimoTN * : see qimaATN, in two places.

qimaATN * The thing, (S,) or wide piece of rag, (Msb,) with which a child is bound (S, Msb) in the cradle: (S:) or the piece of rag, (Mgh, K,) or wide piece of rag, (TA,) which is wound upon a child (M, K, TA) when he is bound in the cradle: (Mgh, TA: *) pl. qumuTN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- A rope with which the legs of a sheep or goat are bound (S, Mgh, K) on the occasion of the slaughtering; (S, K;) as also ↓ qimoTN: (K:) or a rope with which the arms and legs, or hands and feet, of a captive are bound together: (Msb, K:) pl. as above; (Mgh;) and the pl. of qumuTN [probably a mistranscription for qimoTN] is A^aqomaATN. (TA.) ― -b3- qumuTN also signifies The $uruT, (Mgh, Msb,) meaning wide woven ropes, (Mgh,) of fibres or leaves of the palm-tree, by which a booth of reeds
or canes is bound: or, as some say, the pieces of wood that are upon the outside of a booth of reeds or canes, or in its inside, to which are bound the bundles of reeds or canes that form the roof: (Mgh, Msb:) or the heads [or extremities] thereof: (Msb:) or qmT, with damm, [app. meaning qumuTN, with damm to the second letter as well as the first, or qumoTN as a contraction of qumuTN, like as kutobN, accord. to some, is a contraction of kutubN,] as IAth says, on the authority of Hr, (TA,) or ↓ qimoTN, with kesr, (S, K,) signifies the thing, (S,) or rope, (K, TA,) of fibres or leaves of the palmtree, (TA,) with which booths of reeds or canes are bound: (S, K, TA:) and hence maEaAqidu AlqimoTi [the places where such ropes are tied]. (S.) ― -b4- Also qimaATN (assumed tropical:) The snares by which one snares men: and [its pl.] qumuTN, accord. to the A, (tropical:) the cords of stratagems or tricks. (TA.) [Hence,] waqaEotu EalaY qimaATihi (assumed tropical:) I became acquainted with his stratagems, or tricks, (Lth, K,) or his snares by which he snares men. (TA.) [The explanation of this phrase by Lth is wqEt EalY bunuwdihi: that in the K, faTinotu bunuwdahu: another explanation is given in the TA, which is, faTinotu lahu fY tuw^adapK: in the JK, faTanotu bituw^awdapK: the right reading in the K and JK seems to be faTinotu bibunuwdihi: and that of the explanation in the TA mentioned in this sentence is most probably, I think, faTinotu lahu fiY bunuwdihi I understood him in his stratagems, &c.]

qam~aATN *
A maker of qumuT [pl. of qimaAT] for children. (TA.) ― -b2- A rope-maker. (TA.)

Q. 4 A_iqomaTar~a *
It (a day, S) was, or became, distressful, or calamitous. (S, K.)
qamoTarN * : see qamoTariyrN.

qimaTorN * and qimaTorapN (S, Msb, K) and with tesh-deed, [i. e. qim~aTorN and qim~aTorapN,] but this pronunciation is extr., (K,) or, accord. to Yaakoob, (S,) or ISk, (TA,) not allowable, (S, TA,) A repository for books or writings, (S, Msb, K, TA,) resembling a safaT, [q. v., (in the TA, sqT, which is evidently a mistake,)] made of reeds woven together: (TA:) the first word is fem., like the second, as well as masc.: (Msb:) pl. qamaATiru. (S, Msb.)

yawomN qamoTariyrN * , and ↓ qumaATirN, (S, K,) and ↓ muqomaTir~N, (TA,) A distressful, or calamitous, day: (S, K:) or a day that makes one knit the brow, or contract the skin between the eyes: so the first is explained by some as occurring in the Kur lxxvi. 10. (TA.) ― -b2- $ar~N qamoTariyrN, (TA,) and ↓ qumaATirN, and ↓ qamoTarN, (Lth, TA,) and ↓ muqomaTir~N, (TA,) Intense evil. (Lth, TA.)
qumaATirN * : see qamoTariyrN, in two places.
muqomaTir~N * : see qamoTariyrN, in two places.
See Supplement

Q. 4 A_iqomahad~a *
He (a man, L, and a camel, S, L,) raised his head. (S, L, K.) Mentioned by J in art. qmd, q. v.
See Supplement

1 qanaA^a * , aor.
qanaAa , inf. n. qunuwo'N, It (a thing, TA) was, or became, intensely red: (K:) and qanaA, without ', is a dial. var. thereof, (TA in this art.,) aor. yaqonuw, inf. n. qunuw~N. (TA in art. qnw.) You say, qanaA^ato liHoyatuhu, aor. and inf. n. as above, His beard was, or became, intensely red from the dye: (S, O:) or, was, or became, black with the dye. (TA.) And qanaA^ato A^aToraAfu AljaAriyapi biAlHin~aA='i The extremities of the girl, or young woman, were, or became, black, or, accord. to the T, intensely red, with the hinnà (TA.) And qanaA^ati Albusorapu The full-grown unripe date began to have its redness intermixed with blackness. (M in art. nvr.) ― -b2- See also 2. -A2- qanaA^ahu He mixed it, i. e. milk (O, K, TA) with water. (TA.) -A3- And, (O, K, TA,) aor.
qanaAa , (TA,) inf. n. qano'N, (O, TA,) He killed him: (O, K, TA:) or he incited him, or induced him, to kill him; as also ↓ AqnA^hu, (K, TA,) inf. n. A_iqonaA='N: (TA:) [but this is a strange rendering of a verb with a single objective complement; and it appears that AqnA^hu should be followed by Ealayohi, to give this sense; and so should qanaA^ahu, if used in the same sense; for, accord. to Sgh,] Ealayohi ↓ A^aqonaA^otuhu signifies I incited him, or induced him, to kill him. (O.) -A4- qanaA^a Aljilodu, (AHn, K, TA,) [if not a mistranscription, for quniy^a, as seems to be probably the case from what follows,] inf. n. qunuwo'N, (AHn, TA,) The skin was thrown into the tan, (AHn, K, TA,) after the removal of its hair and dirt: and qanaA^ahu SaAHibuhu [Its owner threw it into the tan, &c.]. (AHn, TA.) -A5- qaniy^a, (O, K, TA,) aor.
qanaAa , inf. n. qunuwo'N, (TA,) He died. (O, K.) One says, Darabotuhu Hat~aY qaniy^a I beat him until he died. (TA.) ― -b2- And qaniy^a said of a hide, It became spoiled, or rendered unsound. (O, K.)

2 qn~A^ * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. taqoniy^apN, (S, O,) or taqoniYo'N, (K,) He rendered (S, O, K) a thing, (K,) or his beard, (S, O,) intensely red (S, O, * K) with dye. (S, O.) And He dyed his beard black; as also ↓ qanaA^a. (K.)

3 maA qaAnaA^ahu *
It (a thing) did not suit him; i. q. mA qaAmaA^ahu. (TA in art. qmA^.) [See also qaAnaY, in art. qnY.]

4 AqnA^ *
He spoiled a hide, or rendered it unsound. (O, K.) -A2- A^aqonaA^aniY Al$~aYo'u The thing became possible to me, or within my power, (K, TA,) and near to me. (TA.) -A3- See also 1, in two places.
qunoA^apN * [or qanoA^apN]: see maqonaA^apN.

$aYo'N A^aHomaru qaAniy^N *
A thing intensely red. (S, O.) See an ex. of the fem. qaAniy^apN, applied to the sun, by a poet who was drinking, or watering, with a party, and was prevented by them from taking his share of the water until the sun became red. (TA.)

maqonaA^apN * and maqonuw^apN (S, K) i. q. maqomaA^apN [and maqomuw^apN], (K,) A place on which the sun does not come; (AA, S, TA;) as also ↓ qunoA^apN [perhaps a mistranscription for qanoA^apN like its syn. qamoA^apN]: (TA:) some say that maqonaApN and maqonuwapN, [thus] without ', signify the contr. of maDoHaApN [which means a place from which the sun is hardly ever, or never, absent]. (S, TA.)

1 qanaba fiyhi * , (JK, A, O, K,) aor.
qanuba , (JK, O,) inf. n. qunuwbN, (JK,) (tropical:) He entered into it, (JK, A, O, K,) namely, his house, or tent; as also ↓ tqn~b. (JK, A.) ― -b2- And qanabati Al$~amosu, (A, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (K,) (tropical:) The sun set, (A, K, TA,) so that nothing thereof remained. (TA.) ― -b3- qanaba bimixolabihi, aor.
qaniba , inf. n. qanobN, He (a lion) withdrew his claw into its receptacle. (O.) -A2- qanaba Alkaroma, (A,) or AlEinaba, (JK, K,) inf. n. qanobN, (JK,) He cut off from the grape-vine what would be injurious (A, K) to its produce; (K;) as also ↓ qn~bhu: (A:) or he cut off from its upper part what would not bear and what would perhaps injure its produce: (En-Nadr, TA:) or he cut off some of the shoots thereof in order to thin it and that others might receive the whole of its strength. (AHn, TA.) -A3- qanaba Alz~ahoru The flowers, or blossoms, came forth from their calyxes. (K.)

2 qn~b Alz~aroEu * , (IDrd, S, O, K,) inf. n. taqoniybN, (IDrd, S, K,) The seed-produce put forth the qun~aAbap [or quinaAb i. e. the leaves enclosing the ears of corn]; (K;) i. q. A^aEoSafa [i. e. put forth its EaSof, here meaning the leaves of the ears of corn]. (IDrd, S, O.) -A2- qan~abuwA, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) They became a [troop such as is termed] miqonab; as also ↓ A^aqonabuwA; (O, K;) and so ↓ taqan~abuwA. (A, O, K.) ― -b2- And qn~bwA is said to mean They journeyed, or travelled, far: (O:) [or] so ↓ AqnbwA: (T, TA:) and nHowa qawomK ↓ tqn~bwA They journeyed towards a people, or party. (JK.) -A3- See also 1.

4 A^aqonaba see 2, in two places. -A2- Aqnb also signifies (tropical:) He hid himself from a creditor, or from a Sultán. (O, K.) -A3- And It (a plant) put forth the calyxes of its flowers, or blossoms. (AHn, O, * TA.)
5 taqan~aba see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see 2, in two places.

qunobN * The sheath of the penis (S, A, O, K) of a beast, or of a solid-hoofed animal, (K,) [i. e.] of the horse, (S, A, O,) and of other than the horse (S, O) among the solid-hoofed; (S;) or originally, of the solid-hoofed, and afterwards used in relation to others, as of the camel. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qunobu AlA^asadi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) The sheath of the penis of the Lion, is a name by which the Arabs call the star [b] upon the hinder part of the tail of Leo: [this, is should be observed, is the place of the star in the figure of Leo commonly known; but the ancient Arabs, or many of them, extended the figure of that constellation (as they did also that of Scorpio) far beyond the limits which we assign to it: (see Al*~iraAEu:) another meaning of qunob in relation to a lion, which will be found below, may perhaps be intended in this case, but I think it unlikely:] the Arabs also called the same star AlS~arofapu [q. v.]. (Kzw.) ― -b3- [Hence, likewise,] qunobN signifies also (tropical:) The baZor of a woman; (K;) [meaning the prepuce of the clitoris; as being likened to a qunob properly so called; i. e.] it is metonymically [thus] applied to the part that is circumcised, of a woman. (JK, A.) ― -b4- See also qinaAbN, in two places. -A2- Also A large sail, (O, K,) one of the greatest of the sails of a ship. (O.)
qunaAbN * : see qun~aAbapN.

qinaAbN * The claw of the lion; as also ↓ qunobN and ↓ miqonabN and ↓ miqonaAbN: (K:) or the claw of the lion in its covering; (O, TA;) as also ↓ miqonabN: or this last signifies the fore paw of the lion: and ↓ qunobN, of which the pl. is qunuwbN, signifies the part of the fore paw of the lion into which the claws enter [or are withdrawn]; as also ↓ miqonaAbN; and in like manner this word [or app. each of these words] is used in relation to the hawk and falcon. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (i. e.qinaAbN) The string of a bow. (K.) ― -b3- And i. q. qun~aAbapN, q. v. (K.) ― -b4- See also qin~abN.
qunuwbN * [mentioned in the next preceding paragraph as pl. of qunobN] signifies [also] The calyxes of the flowers of a plant. (AHn, O, K. *)

qaniybN *
Companies of men. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) (tropical:) Clouds (O, K, TA) such as are dense, or compact. (TA.)
qunaAbapN * : see qun~aAbapN.

qin~abN * (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and qun~abN (K) [Cannabis, or hemp;] i. q. A^abaqN [a less-known word]; a genuine Arabic word; (S, O;) or, accord. to AHn, a Pers. word [kanabN] which has become current in the language of the Arabs; (Mgh;) vulgarly pronounced qin~ib; (TA;) [loosely expl. as] a sort of kat~aAn [or flax], (K, TA,) i. e. the coarse [sort], of which are made ropes and the like; (TA;) a plant of which the skin, or rind, is twisted into ropes; (Msb;) its stems are bruised until the culms becomes strewn in fragments and the rind thereof becomes detached; and one says HibaAlu Alqin~abi [the ropes of hemp]: (AHn, Mgh:) it has a grain called $ahodaAnaj [q.v.]: (Mgh, Msb:) ↓ qinaAb, [thus without teshdeed,] occurring in a verse of Aboo-Heiyeh En-Numeyree, is said to signify the same as qin~ab; but whether it be a dial. var. or altered therefrom [by poetic license] is doubtful. (L, TA.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 269.]

qun~aAbapN * , (O, K,) like rum~aAnapN, (K,) or ↓ qunaAbapN, (S, [thus in my copies, without teshdeed,]) The combined leaves in which are the ears of corn; (S, O, K;) also called EaSiyfapN: (S, O:) so says IDrd: (S:) and [it is said that] ↓ qunaAbN, with damm, (O, K,) as also ↓ qinaAbN, with kesr, (K,) signifies the leaves surrounding the heads of growing corn, (O, K, TA,) i. e. the ears, (TA,) in the beginning of its fruit-bearing: (O, K, TA:) by which explanation is meant the same that is meant by the explanation immediately preceding. (TA.)

qaAnibN * The howling wolf. (O, K.) See also maqaAnibu. ― -b2- And A quick, or brisk, fayoj [i. e. foot-messenger, or courier who journeys on foot]; as also ↓ qayonaAbN. (O, K. [In the CK, AlfayoHu is put for Alfayoju.]) ― -b3- And waAdK qaAnibN [A valley, or water-course,] of which the torrent comes from afar. (O.)
qayonaAbN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

miqonabN *
A thing that the sportsman has with him, (S,) his bag, (xariyTap, O, or wiEaA=', K,) or a thing resembling a mixolaAp or a xariyTap, (TA,) in which he puts the game that he takes. (S, O, TA.) ― -b2- See also qinaAbN, in two places. ― -b3- Also A ring of gold. (JK.) -A2- And A troop of horses or horsemen, (S, O, K,) or of both, (TA,) from thirty to forty, (S, O, K, TA,) or less than a hundred, (TA,) or as many as three hundred: (Lth, O, K, TA:) or a troop of horses or horsemen that assemble for a hostile, or predatory, incursion: pl. maqaAnibu. (Kf, TA.)
miqonaAbN * : see qinaAbN, in two places.

maqaAnibu *
Rapacious, or ravening, wolves: (O, K, TA:) a pl. without a sing.; or it is an irreg. pl. of ↓ qaAnibN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also pl. of miqonabN [q. v.]. (Kf, TA.)

qunoburN * and qunoburaA='u A species of the [kind of bird called] Hum~ar: (TA:) [or resembling the Hum~ar:] i. q. qub~arN [i. e., the lark]: (S, K, art. qbr:) n. un. qunoburapN, (S, Msb, art. qbr:) also pronounced qunobarapN: (Msb, ibid.:) pl. qanaAbiru. (TA.) See qub~arN.

qun~abiyTN * [Cauliflower;] the thickest species of kurunob; (K;) called in the dial. of Egypt qaronabiyTN; mentioned in the S in art. qbT; [but only as a thing well known;] the author of the S regarding the n as augmentative: (TA:) it renders the breath stinking; and causes a thickness, or grossness, [app. of the humours;] and she who uses its seed in the manner of a suppository in the vagina will not become pregnant: (K:) so say the physicians. (TA.)

1 qunuwtN * is the inf. n. of qanata, (MA, Msb,) aor.
qanuta , (Msb,) and signifies The being obedient: (S, M, MA, Mgh, K, TA:) or the being constantly obedient: (IAmb, O, TA:) the former is the primary meaning: and hence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 35], ↓ waA@loqaAnitaAti ↓ waA@loqaAnitiyna [And the obedient men and the obedient women]. (S, M, TA.) One says, qanata lil~`hi, (MA,) and qanata A@ll~`ha, (TA,) [but this latter is unusual, the former only being authorized by the Kur-án (in iii. 38 and xxxiii. 31),] meaning He was obedient to God. (MA, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [ii. 110 and xxx. 25], ↓ kul~N lahu qaAnituwna i. e. All are obedient unto Him: but the meaning here is, that the beings in heaven [and earth] are created by the will of God, and that none of them can alter the form in which it is created; the obedience here spoken of being obedience to the will [of God], not the obedience of religious service; some of them being obedient [in this sense], and others being disobedient. (L, TA.) [It is said that] the proper signification of ↓ AlqaAnitu [or the signification that implies all the meanings of the word] is The performer of the command of God. (L, TA.) ― -b2- It signifies also The act of standing; (Mgh, TA;) mentioned by Th, and asserted by him to be the primary meaning. (TA.) And (TA) The standing long. (IAmb, O, TA.) And (TA) The standing in the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer. (S, Msb, K, TA.) [See also 4.] Hence, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) it is said in a trad. (S, TA) of the Prophet, as a reply given by him to the question A^aY~u AlS~alaApi A^afoDalu, (TA,) A^afoDalu AlS~alaApi Tuwlu Alqunuwti (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) i. e. [The most excellent characteristic of the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer is] the long continuance of the standing. (Mgh, * Msb, * TA.) And hence, qunuwtu Alwitori; (S; [see art. wtr;]) or [as it is also termed] duEaA='u Alqunuwti, which means The supplication of the standing; (Msb;) for one utters the supplication standing: (TA:) and what is thus termed (duEaA='u Alqunuwti) is as follows: Aall~ahum~a A_in~aA nasotaEiynuka wanasotagofiruka wanuw^ominu bika wanatawak~alu Ealayoka wanuvoniY Ealayoka Alxayora walaA nakofuruka wanaxolaEu wanatoruku mano yafojuruka Aall~`hum~a A_iy~aAka naEobudu walaka nuSal~iY wanasojudu waA_ilayoka nasoEaY wanaHofidu narojuw raHomataka wanaxo$aY Ea*aAbaka A_in~a Ea*aAbaka biAlkuf~aAri muloHiqN i. e. O God, verily we beg of Thee aid to be obedient and to forsake disobedience, and we beg of Thee forgiveness of sins, [and we believe in Thee, and we rely
upon Thee,] and we laud Thee well, and we will not be unthankful to Thee for Thy favour, and we cast off and forsake him who disobeys Thee: [O God, Thee we worship, and to Thee we perform the divinely-appointed act of prayer, and prostrate ourselves;] and we are quick in working for Thee and in serving Thee: we hope for Thy mercy, and we dread Thy punishment: verily Thy punishment overtakes the unbelievers; thus this clause is expl. on the authority of Ks: or, as some say, it means, causes others to overtake, or become associated with, the unbelievers. (Mgh. [See also art. lHq.]) It is said of the Prophet, qanata $ahorFA fiY SalaApi AlS~uboHi baEoda Alr~ukuwEi yadoEuw EalaY riEolK wa*akuwaAna [He stood during a month, in the prayer of daybreak, after (the prayers of) the rukuwE (pl. of rakaEa, q. v.), cursing (the tribes of) Rial and Dhekwán]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The act of supplicating [God]: (Zj, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA:) this is the signification [most] commonly known. (Zj, Mgh, O, TA.) And [particularly, accord. to general usage,] The supplicating God [by addressing Him with the form of words mentioned above as used in what is termed duEaA='u Alqunuwti], doing so standing. (TA.) ― -b4- And The divinely-appointed act of prayer; syn. SalaApN. (IAmb, O, TA.) ― -b5- And The being silent; (O, Msb, K, TA;) by which is meant (O, * TA) the withholding oneself from talking; (O, * K, TA;) in, or during, [the prayer called] AlS~alaAp. (O, * Msb, TA.) Hence, (O, Msb, TA,) accord. to a trad., (O, TA,) the saying in the Kur [ii. 239], waquwmuwA ↓ lil~`hi qaAnitiyna [And stand ye unto God, in the divinely-appointed act of prayer, refraining from talking]. (O, Msb, TA.) ― -b6- And The serving of God. (TA.) ― -b7- And The continuing of the performance of the pilgrimage. (TA.) One says, [qanata and] ↓ Aqnt, meaning He continued the performance of the pilgrimage. (IAar, O, K, TA.) ― -b8- And The prolonging of engaging in warring, or warring and plundering. (TA.) One says, [qanata and] ↓ Aqnt, meaning He prolonged the engaging in warring, or warring and plundering. (IAar, O, K, TA.) ― -b9- And The confessing, or acknowledging, one's being in the condition of a servant [to God]. (TA.) ― -b10- And The being lowly, humble, or submissive: (A, TA:) or the keeping to obedience [to God], with lowliness, humility, or submissiveness. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, qanata lahu He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, to him. (TA.) And qanatati AlmrAp lizawojihaA, (A,) or libaEolihaA, (TA,) The woman was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, and obedient, to her husband: (A:) or was, or became, quiet and submissive; syn. A^aqar~at. (TA.) [See also 4, and 8.] -A2- qanaAtapN [is an inf. n., of which the verb is qanuta, like qatuna, and] signifies The eating little [like qataAnapN]. (K.)

4 Aqnt *
He stood long in the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer. (O, K.) [And qanata has the same, or nearly the same, meaning; as is shown above.] ― -b2- Also, [like qanata EalaY Eaduw~ihi,] He cursed his enemy. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last quarter, in two places. ― -b4- Also He lowered, humbled, or submitted, himself to God. (IAar, O, K.)

8 Aqtnt *
He was, or became, tractable, or submissive. (TA.) [And Aktnt has a similar meaning.]
qanuwtN * A woman lowly, humble, or submissive, and obedient [to her husband]. (A.)

qaniytN * A woman who eats little: (O, K:) as also qatiynN. (O.) ― -b2- siqaA='N qaniytN i. q. mis~iykN, so in a copy of the K, meaning [A skin] that retains the water; and this is the right explanation: (TA:) but accord. to AZ and Z, the word msyk thus used is like A^amiyrN; and siqaA='N masiykN is expl. by Z as meaning [a skin] that does not exude, and by AZ as meaning [a skin] that retains the water so that it does not exude: (TA in art. msk:) in the present art., in some of the copies of the K, musiylN, the act. part. n. from A^asaAla AlmaA='a; and thus in a copy of the Tekmileh. (TA in the present art.: in the O, in this art., it is masiylN.)

qaAnitN * [part. n. of qanata in all its senses]: see three exs. in the first quarter of the first paragraph, and another ex. in the last quarter; its [broken] pl., in all its senses is qan~atN. (ISd, TA.)

1 qanaHahu * , (S, K, TA,) aor.
qanaHa , (K, TA,) inf. n. qanoHN, (S, TA,) He bent it, or curved it, (S, K, TA,) i. e. a thing, (S,) or a stick, or branch, (TA,) [at the end,] like a miHojan, (S, K, TA,) or SawolajaAn. (TA.) ― -b2- And qanaHa AlbaAba He hewed, or cut out, a wooden implement, (called a qun~aAHap [q. v.], L,) and with it raised [and opened] the door; as also ↓ AqnHhu: (T, L, K, TA:) or [simply] he raised [and opened] the door with the wooden implement called a qun~aAHap; and so ↓ qn~Hhu: (A:) [or] AlbAlba ↓ qn~H, (S, K,) inf. n. taqoniyHN, (K,) He adjusted (A^aSolaHa) a qun~aAHap to the door. (S, K.) -A2- And qanaHa, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) said of one drinking, He satisfied his thirst, and, by reason thereof, raised his head; and showed, or expressed, dislike of drinking (takaAraha EalaY Al$~urobi); like ↓ tqn~H; (K, TA;) which is the more approved [and to which, as well as to the former verb, both of the clauses of the explanation above relate, as will be shown by what follows]: in some of the copies [of the K] like ↓ qn~H: accord. to AHn, one says, qanaHa mina Al$~araAbi, aor. and inf. n. as above, meaning he sipped [of the wine or beverage]; and accord. to Az, ↓ taqan~aHotu mina Al$~araAbi, which, he says, is the prevailing expression: hence the saying of Umm-Zara, A^a$orabu ↓ faA^ataqan~aHu, i. e. I [drink, and] stop, or interrupt, drinking, and proceed leisurely therein: or, I drink after the satisfying of thirst: which latter explanation, mentioned on the authority of AZ, is that which is approved by Sh and Az, in opposition to Aboo-'Abd-Allah Et-Tuwál, who thought it to mean I drink by little and little. (TA. [See also this saying of Umm-Zara, with another reading of it, in the last sentence but one of art. qmH.])
2 qan~aHa see above, second sentence, in two places: -A2- and see also the third sentence.
4 A^aqonaHa see 1, second sentence.
5 taqan~aHa see 1, third sentence, in three places.

qinoHN * [thus accord. to the L] is expl. in the 'Eyn as meaning Thy making a qun~aAHap with which thou wilt fasten (ta$ud~u) the side-post of thy door and the like; termed by the Persians qAnh [app. a mistranscription for faAnahN, a wooden peg, which, dropping into the bolt of a lock, or the like, prevents its being opened until the said peg is pulled up]; but ISd says, I know not how this is, for the explanation is not good; and I think qinoHN here is a dial. var. of qun~aAHN [q. v.]. (L.)
qan~aAHN * and ↓ qan~aAHapN [thus in the L, but app. the q should be with damm in both words,] A stick, or branch, bent, or curved, [at the end,] like a SawolajaAn [q. v.]. (L.)

qun~aAHN *
A bar (mitoras [or mataros]) of a door. (IAar, L.)
qan~aAHapN * : see qan~aAHN.

qun~aAHapN *
A crooked, or curved, long mifotaAH [or instrument for opening a door]: (S, L, K:) [from what here follows, it seems to be a kind of wooden lever, with a crooked, or curved, end, with which a door is raised and opened: (see also 1:)] a wooden implement with which a door is raised [and opened, app. by lifting the lower pivot (which serves as a hinge) out of its socket]: (A, L:) and any piece of wood that is inserted beneath another [as a lever] in order to move it. (L.)

4 Aqnd Als~awiyqa *
He put qanod into the swyq [or meal of parched barley or wheat]. (IKtt.)

qanodN * (S, A, L, Msb, K) and ↓ qanodapN and ↓ qinodiydN (L, K) The honey (or expressed juice, TA) of the sugar-cane, (S, A, L, K,) when it has become concrete, (L, K,) or when it has been rendered concrete; (as in some copies of the K;) [or sugar-candy;] see also TabarozadN; with which faAniyd is made: (L:) or that of which sugar is made; so that sugar is to qnd like clarified butter to fresh butter: the pl. of qnd is qunuwdN: (Msb:) it is (as some say, Msb) an arabicized word, (Msb, K,) from [the Pers.] kanodN [or qanodo]. (TA.)
qanodapN * : see qanodN.
qinodidN * : see qinodiydN.

qinodiydN * : see qanodN. ― -b2- Wine: (AA, IAar, S, L, K:) or it is not wine, (As, S, IJ,) but like A_isofinoTN, i. e., (As, S,) expressed juice (As, T, S, L, K) of grapes, (T, L,) boiled, (As, T, S, L,) with aromatics put in it, (As, T, S, L, K,) and then rendered more fragrant by an admixture of other perfumes: [so I render yufotaqu:] (T, L, K:) or beverage, or wine, ($araAbN,) made of qanod: (A:) pl. qanaAdiydu. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- Ambergris. (Kr, L, K.) ― -b4- Camphor. (K.) ― -b5- Musk. (K.) ― -b6- A perfume made with saffron, (K,) or with [the plant called] waros. (TA.) ― -b7- [The plant called] waros: (K:) or excellent waros. (L.) ― -b8- The state, or condition, of a man, whether good or bad; as also ↓ qinodidN: (K:) pl. of the former qanaAdiydu. (IAar.) ― -b9- jaA='a biAlA^amori EalaY qanaAdiydihi [He did the thing] in its [proper] manner. (K.)

qinodaA^owN * is mentioned among the words whose last radical letter is E. (K.) Aboo-Málik says, that rajulN qinodaAwapN, of the measure fiEolaAwapN, signifies A light, or active, man: and naAqapN qinodaAwapN a swift she-camel: (S:) and a bold she-camel: (Fr, S:) and the epithet is with and without E: (Fr:) and jamalN qinodaAwN a swift he-camel: and qaduwmN qinodaA^owapN a sharp adz: but others say finodaA^owapN, with f. (S.)
muqanodFY * : see the next paragraph.

sawiyqN maqonuwdN * , and ↓ muqan~adN, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and ↓ muqanodFY, (K,) [Meal of parched barley or wheat] prepared [or sweetened] with qanod. (L, Msb.) [See an ex. in art. Hlq.] ― -b2- kalaAmN maqonuwdN, and ↓ muqan~adN, (tropical:) [Sugared speech]. (A.)
muqan~adN * : see the preceding paragraph in two places.

1 qanaSahu * , (S, M, A, K,) aor.
qaniSa , (M, A, K,) inf. n. qanoSN (S, M,) and qanaSN; (M;) and ↓ AqtnShu; and ↓ tqn~Shu; (S, M, A, K;) He took, captured, or caught, it; made it his prey; snared, insnared, or entrapped, it; hunted, or chased, it; or sought to take, capture, or catch, it; syns. SaAdahu, (S, M, A, K,) and AiSoTaAdahu, (S, K,) and taSay~adahu; (S;) namely, a wild animal, or a number of wild animals. (M, A.) [Hence] you say, huwa yaqoniSu AlfurosaAna, and ↓ yaqotaniSuhumo, (tropical:) He captures the horsemen. (TA.)
5 taqan~aSa see 1.

8 A_iqotanaSa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- As being likened to “ the taking ” of the object of the chase, AlAiqotinaASu signifies (tropical:) The taking anything quickly. (Kull.) ― -b3- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) The apprehending quickly.]
qanaSN * [originally an inf. n.] What is taken, captured, caught, insnared, entrapped, hunted, or chased, of wild animals or the like; as also ↓ qaniySN. (S, M, A, K.)
qaniySN * : see qanaSN: -A2- and qaAniSN, in two places.
qan~aASN * : see qaAniSN.

qaAniSN *
One who takes, captures, catches, insnares, entraps, hunts, or chases, wild animals or the like; as also ↓ qaniySN (S, M, A, K) and ↓ qan~aASN: (S, M, K:) or ↓ qaniySN signifies persons who do so, collectively; and is [a quasi-pl. n.] similar to kaliybN and maEiyzN and HamiyrN: (IJ, TA:) the pl. of qaAniSN is qun~aASN: (A, TA:) and ↓ qaAniSapN signifies the same as the pl.: and also low, vile; or mean, persons. (TA. [See also TumoruwrN, in an explanation of which the sing. qaAniSN is app. used in like manner.]) You say, jaA='a AlqaniySu biAloqaniySi The sportsman came with the game taken. (A.) And it is said in a trad., fatuxoriju Aln~aAru Ealayohimo qawaAniSa (assumed tropical:) [And the fire of hell shall send forth against them snatchers]; meaning, it shall snatch them in pieces like as the beast or bird of prey snatches its prey: the sing. is ↓ qaAniSapN: (K, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, sparks like the qawaAniS of birds, i. e., their HawaASil. (TA.) See what follows.

qaAniSapN * : see qaAniSN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, sing. of qawaAniSN, which signifies [The intestines, or bowels, of a bird, into which the food passes from the stomach;] in a bird, what the maSaAriyn are in other creatures: (S, K:) or the pl. [or sing. (K, art. jrA^,)] signifies i. q. jir~iy^apN: (L, TA:) or the qaAniSap is, in a bird, like the HawoSalap [or lower part of the belly] in a man: (M, TA:) or [the stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird;] in a bird, like the kari$ [in other creatures]: (TA:) [see Aljir~iy^ahN:] or a thing like a little burrow in the belly of a bird: (T, A, L:) [in the present day it is applied to the gizzard, or true stomach, which is perhaps meant by the last of the preceding explanations; and is also pronounced qawoniSap:] or the pl., in relation to a bird, signifies i. q. HawaASil [pl. of HawoSalap]: (TA:) the word is also written with s; but is better with S. (TA.)

1 qanaTa * , aor.
qaniTa ; and qanaTa, aor.
qanuTa ; and qaniTa, aor.
qanaTa ; (S, Msb, K;) and qanuTa, aor.
qanuTa ; (K;) and qanaTa, aor.
qanaTa ; and qaniTa, aor.
qaniTa ; each of the last two being a mixture of two dialects; (Akh, S, K;) inf. n. qunuwTN, (S, Msb, K,) which is of the first and second, (S, K, TA,) and of the fourth and sixth also; (K; [but this is doubtful;]) and qanaTN, which is of the third; (S, K;) and qanaATapN, which is also of the third, (S, K,) or [more probably, agreeably with analogy,] of the fourth; (TK;) He despaired (S, Msb, K) of (mino) the mercy of God, (Msb,) or, as in the T, of good: or, as some say, he despaired most vehemently of a thing. (TA.) It is said in the Kur, [xv. 56,] accord. to different readings, wamano yaqoniTu mino raHomapi rab~ihi A_il~aA AlD~aAl~uwna and yaqonuTu (Bd, TA) and yaqonaTu (Bd) [And who despaireth of the mercy of his Lord except those who are in error?] -A2- qanoTN is also syn. with manoEN. (K.) You say, qanaTa maA='ahu Ean~aA He withheld, kept, or debarred, his water from us. (Sgh on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád.)

2 qn~Thu * , (Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoniyTN, (K,) He made him to despair; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ AqnThu. (Msb.) You say, $ar~u Aln~aAsi Al~a*iyna yuqan~iTuwna Aln~aAsa mino raHomapi All~`hi The worst of men are those who make men to despair of the mercy of God. (TA.)
4 A^aqonaTa see 2.
qaniTN * : see what follows.
qanuwTN * : see what follows.

qaAniTN * (S, Msb) and ↓ qaniTN (S, TA) and ↓ qanuwTN, (Msb, TA,) but the last has an intensive signification, (Bd, xli. 49,) Despairing: (S, Msb, TA:) pl. of the first with wn; (Kur xv. 55, accord. to the prevailing reading;) and so of the second. (S, TA.)

Q. 1 qanoTara Al$~Yo'i *
i. q. Eaqadahu waA^aHokamahu [He tied, or knit, the thing; or, agreeably with modern usage, he arched, or vaulted, it; and made it firm, or strong]. (Zj.) Hence what is called a qanoTarap is thus called because of its being firmly, or strongly, knit together, or arched, or vaulted, liA_iHokaAmi EaqodihaA. (MF.) [It seems to signify He compacted the thing. ― -b2- Also, He collected the thing together into one aggregate; he aggregated it. See the pass. part. n., below.] -A2- qanoTara He (a man, TA) possessed property by the qinoTaAr: (K:) or became possessed of a qnTAr of property: (TA:) or possessed large property, as though it were weighed by the qnTAr. (ISd, TA.)
2 taqanoTara bihi farasuhu * , for taqaT~ara bh: see qaT~arahu.

qanoTarapN * [accord. to the Msb, of the measure fanoEalapN, belonging to art. qTr, the n being augmentative; and the same is perhaps meant to be indicated by the place in which it is mentioned in the S and some other lexicons; but accord. to the K, the n is a radical letter; A bridge;] what is built over water, for crossing or passing over (Mgh, Msb) upon it; (Msb;) an A^azaj [or oblong arched or vaulted structure], built with backed bricks or with stones, over water, upon which to cross or pass over: (Az, TA:) or i. q. jisorN: (S, K:) or this latter is a more common term; (Mgh, * Msb;) for it signifies that which is built and that which is not built: (Msb:) a lofty structure: (K:) [pl. qanaATiru.] See 1.

qinoTaArN * [accord. to the Msb, of the measure finoEaAlN, belonging to art. qTr, the n being augmentative; and the same is perhaps meant to be indicated by the place in which it is
mentioned in the S and some other lexicons; but accord. to the K, the n is a radical letter;] A certain miEoyaAr [or standard of weight or measure]: (S, TA:) or, accord. to some, a quantity of no determinate weight: (Msb:) or a large unknown quantity or aggregate, of property: (TA:) or much property heaped up: (Msb:) or four thousand deenárs: (Th, Msb:) this is what most of the Arabs hold to be the truth: (Th:) or four thousand dirhems: (Th:) or one thousand two hundred ookeeyehs: (A 'Obeyd, S, K:) so accord. to Mo'ádh Ibn-Jebel: (S:) or [which is the same] a hundred ritls: (Msb:) [this is its weight in the present day; i. e., a hundredweight, or a hundred pounds:] or a hundred ritls of gold or of silver: (Es-Suddee, K:) or a hundred and twenty ritls: (S, L:) or a thousand ookeeyehs of gold: or of silver: (Th:) or twelve thousand ookeeyehs, accord. to Aboo-Hureyreh, on the authority of the Prophet: (TA:) or a hundred ookeeyehs of gold: or of silver: (Th:) or a hundred mithkáls; (I 'Ab, Msb, TA;) the mith- kál being twenty keeráts: (I 'Ab, TA:) or forty ookeeyehs of gold: (K:) or one thousand two hundred deenárs: (K:) or one thousand one hundred deenárs: (L:) or seventy thousand deenárs: (K:) or, in the language of Barbar, a thousand mithkáls of gold or of silver: (TA:) or eighty thousand dirhems: (I 'Ab, K:) or a hundred dirhems: (Msb:) or a hundred menns: (Msb:) or a quantity of gold, (S, K,) or of silver, (K,) sufficient to fill a bull's hide: (S, K:) so in the Syriac language, accord. to Es-Suddee: (TA:) and there are other definitions of the word: (S:) pl. qanaATiyru. (S.)

muqanoTarN *
Collected together into one aggregate; aggregated; made up; or completed; syn. mukam~alN. (K.) You say qanaATiyru muqanoTarapN, (S,) meaning, Much riches collected together: (Jel. in iii. 12:) the latter word is a corroborative. (Bd. ibid.)
See Supplement

qunofudN *
i. q. qunofu*N. (Ktr, Kr, K.)

div2.n: qnf*, or, accord. to some, qf*
div2.head: qnf*, or, accord. to some, qf*
div2.entryFree: qunofu*N * and qunofa*N [The male hedge-hog;] (S, L, Msb, K;) i. q. $ayohamN: (M, L, K:) or the male and female: (Msb:) or the fem. is with p, (S, L, Msb, K,) sometimes; and the male is called $ayohamN and dulodulN: (Msb:) pl. qanaAfi*u. (S.) Some hold that the n is an augmentative letter: others, that it is a radical. (TA.)
See Supplement

1 qahiba * , aor.
qahaba , (K, TA,) inf. n. qahabN, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, of the colour termed quhobapN [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

4 Aqhb Eani AlT~aEaAmi *
He abstained from food, or the food, and did not desire it. (O, K.)

qahobN * [and ↓ A^aqohabu] White overspread with duskiness: (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K:) fem. [of the former] qahobapN and [of the latter] ↓ qahobaA='u, (S,) [and] ↓ qahibapN is a fem. epithet having the same meaning: (K, TA:) or white; (TA;) and so ↓ quhaAbN and ↓ quhaAbiY~N; (Lth, O, K, TA;) or all signify thus in respect of skin, or hide: (Az, TA:) or qahobN signifies thus as an epithet applied to the young of goats and oxen, (Lth, O, TA,) and the like thereof, and in respect of skin, or hide: (Lth, O:) and ↓ A^aqohabu signifies dust-coloured with an inclining to blackness: (As, S, O:) or red with an intermixture of dust-colour: (IAar, S, O:) or a dusky white: (S, O:) or having a colour inclining to duskiness, with whiteness or blackness (mE AlbyAD llswAd [which I suppose to be a mistake for mE AlbyAD Aw AlswAd]). (TA.) -A2- Also [or app. jabalN qahobN] A great mountain; (S, K;) accord. to AA: (S:) or, accord. to him, a long mountain: (O:) pl. qihaAbN: or this [or jibaAlN qihaAbN?] signifies mountains of a black colour intermixed with redness. (TA.) ― -b2- And Advanced in age; (O, TA;) applied to an elder; like qaHobN and qaHorN: (TA:) and old in respect of origin; used in this sense by Ru-beh: (O, TA:) or [jamalN qahobN signifies] a camel advanced in age (K, TA) beyond such as is termed baAzilN: (TA:) or a great camel. (AA, TA.)

quhobapN * The colour of that which is termed qahobN; i. e. whiteness overspread with duskiness: (K:) or the colour of that which is termed A^aqohabu; i. e. a dusky whiteness: or, accord. to As, dust-colour inclining to blackness: or, accord. to IAar, redness with an intermixture of dust-colour: (S, O:) or, accord. to IAar, blackness inclining to xuDorap [by which word is here app. meant a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]. (TA voce HusobapN.)
qahibapN * : see qahobN, first sentence.
qahobiY~N * The yaEoquwb; (Lth, O, K;) i. e. the male partridge. (Lth, O.)
quhaAbN * : see qahobN, first sentence.
quhayobN * : see quhayobapN.

qahawobapN * , (K accord. to the TA,) or qahuwbapN, (O, and so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) like rakuwbapN, (O,) and qahawobaApN, (O, K, TA, [in the O, in which it is restricted to the last of the following meanings, carelessly written qahuwobaA', but there said to be with fet-h to the h, and with h, by which is meant p,]) accord. to MF with damm to the f, but this is a mistake, (TA,) An arrow-head (O, K *) having three $uEab [i. e. barbs]: (O, K:) and in some instances having two pieces, or two small pieces of iron, (HadiydataAni, O, or Hdy~dtAn, TA,) which sometimes contract, and sometimes diverge, or open: (O, TA:) or a small arrow, that hits the butt: (K:) or qahuwbaAtN, which is the pl., signifies short arrows, that hit the butt: this is said by Az to be the right explanation: and IDrd has mentioned qahawobaApN as signifying broad heads of arrows or the like: (O:) accord. to Sb, (TA,) there is no other instance [than qahowobaApN] of a word of which the [primitive] measure is faEawolaY. (K, TA. [$ajawojFY and similar words are of the measure faEawoEalN.])

quhayobapN * , (thus accord. to SM's copy of the K,) in the form of a dim.; accord. to another copy of the K, quhobiy~apN; [accord. to another copy, quhabiy~apN; accord. to the CK, qahiybapN;] and accord. to the L, ↓ quhayobN [app. a coll. gen. n. of which quhayobapN is the n. un.]; (TA;) A certain bird, (K, TA,) found in Tihámeh, in which are whiteness and xaDorap [here app. meaning, as in an instance mentioned above, a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]; a species of partridge. (TA.)
quhaAbiY~N * : see qahobN, first sentence.

A^aqohabu * , and its fem. qahobaA='u: see qahobN, first sentence, in three places. ― -b2- AlA^aqohabaAni means The elephant and the buffalo: (S, A, O, K:) each of them is termed A^aqohabu because of his colour, (O, TA,) or because of his greatness. (A, TA.)

qahodN *
Clear in colour. (L, K.) ― -b2- White; as also qahobN: (A 'Obeyd, L:) by some specially applied to the young of antelopes and cows: (L:) or of a dingy, or dusky, white; as also qahobN. (S, L.)

1 qaharahu * . (aor.
qahara , A, K,) inf. n. qahorN, He overcame, conquered, subdued, subjected, subjugated, overbore, overpowered, mastered, or prevailed or predominated over, him, or it; he was, or became, superior in power or force, to him, or it. (S, A, Msb, K, TA.) ― -b2- [He abased him. (See 4.) ― -b3- He oppressed him. So in the Kur., xciii. 9, faA^am~aA Alyatiyma falaA taqoharu [Therefore, happen what may, the orphan thou shalt not oppress; i. e., as explained in the Expos. of the Jel., by taking his property, or otherwise.] ― -b4- He forced, compelled, or constrained, him. (??) in the following ex.] qaharahu EalaY AlA^amori [He forced, compelled, or constrained, him to do the thing]. (S, K, art. qsr.) ― -b5- [He coerced him.] ― -b6- He took him [by force;] against his will, or approval; and so A^axa*ahu qahorFA. (A, TA.) -A2- quhira All~aHomu (tropical:) The flesh-meat became, (S,) or
began to be, (A, TA,) affected, or acted upon, (lit. taken,) by the fire, so that its juice flowed. (S, A, TA.)

4 Aqhr *
He became in a state in which to be overcome, conquered, subdued, subjected, subjugated, overborne, overpowered, mastered, or prevailed over: (Msb:) his case became that of one overcome, &c. (S, TA.) ― -b2- His companions became overcome, conquered, subdued, &c., (K, TA,) and abased. (TA.) -A2- Aqhrhu He found him to be overcome, conquered, subdued, overpowered, mastered, or prevailed over. (S, Msb, K.)
7 Anqhr * [quasi-pass. of qaharahu; He was, or became, overcome, &c.]. (TA in art. DgT.)
quhorFA wabuhorFA * , with damm to each, [a form of imprecation, meaning, May he, or they, be overcome and subdued]. (TA.)

fulaAnN quhorapN llin~aAsi *
Such a one is a person to be overcome, conquered, subdued, &c., by everyone. (A.) ― -b2- A^axa*otu qulaAnFA quhorapF I took such a one by constraint, or compulsion. (S.)
quharapN * A woman abounding in evil, injustice, or corruptness; very evil or bad, unjust, or corrupt: (K, TA:) pl. quharaAtN. (TA.)
qah~aArN * : see qaAhirN.

qaAhrN * One who overcomes, conquers, subdues, &c.: and ↓ qah~aArN signifies the same in an intensive sense. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlqaAhiru (TA) and ↓ Alqah~aAru (K, TA) epithets applied to God, (K, TA,) meaning, The Subduer of his creatures by his sovereign authority and power, and the Disposer of them as He pleaseth, with and against their will: (TA:) or the former, the Overcomer, or Subduer, of all created beings. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- [AlqaAhiru The planet Mars.] ― -b4- jibaAlN qawaAhiru (tropical:) Lofty mountains. (A.)
A^aqoharu * [More, and most, subduing, &c.: and, abasing]. (K voce A^axonaEu, q. v.)

Q. 1 qahoqara * , (K, TA,) inf. n. qahoqarapN, (TA,) He (a man) returned by the way by which he had come: (TA:) or i. q. rajaEa AlqahoqarY, (K,) i. e., [he returned backwards; or] he retired, going backwards, without turning his face towards the direction in which he went; (TA;) as also ↓ taqahoqara. (K, TA.) Some hold, [contr. to the general opinion,] that this verb belongs to art. qhr. (TA.)
Q. 2 taqahoqara see 1.

qahoqaraY *
A returning backwards; (S, K;) a retiring, going backwards, without turning the face towards the direction in which one goes: (TA:) the dual is qahoqaraAni; (IAmb, K;) like as the dual of xawozalaY is xawozalaAni; (TA;) without Y, (K,) because this letter is deemed difficult to pronounce with the A and the Y of the dual. (TA.) When you say rajaEotu AlqahoqaraY [I returned backwards; &c.], it is as though you said I returned with the returning which is known by this name; for AlqhqrY is a mode of returning. (S.) ― -b2- ma$aY AlqahoqaraY He reverted from the state in which he was, or from the course which he was following; revolted; apostatized. (Az, from a trad.)
See Supplement

1 qaAba AlA^aroDa * , aor. yaquwbuhaA, (S, O,) inf. n. qawobN; (K;) and ↓ qw~bhA, (S, O,) inf. n. taqowiybN; (S, O, K;) He dug, or made a hollow in, the ground: (K:) or he dug a round hollow in the ground; (S, O, TA;) thus both phrases are expl. by ISd. (TA.) ― -b2- And qAb bayoDahu, (S, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) It (a bird) broke asunder its eggs. (S, O, K.) -A2- qAb is also intrans., signifying jiloduhu ↓ tqw~b [app. His skin became pitted, or marked with small hollows: see an explanation of 2, of which tqw~b is quasi-pass.]. (O.) ― -b2- qAbt AlbayoDapu: see 7. -A3- Also (qAb) He was, or became, near; drew near; or approached: and He fled: (O, K, TA:) inf. n. qawobN: (TA:) thus it has two contr. significations. (K, TA.)

2 qaw~aba see above, first sentence. ― -b2- One says also, qaw~abotu AlA^aroDa meaning I made impressions, marks, or traces, upon the ground, (O, K, TA,) by treading; and made indications [thereby, or thereof,] at its drinking-places. (TA.) And qaw~abwA AlA^aroDa, (A, TA,) or fiY AlA^aroDi, (O,) They (i. e. persons alighting, A, TA) made impressions, marks, or traces, upon the ground, (A, O, TA,) by their treading and their alighting. (O.) ― -b3- And qw~b Aljarabu jiloda AlbaEiyri The mange, or scab, made pits, or small hollows, bare of fur, in the skin of the camel. (Lth, TA.) See also 5. ― -b4- quw~iba mina AlgubaAri means Aigobar~a [i. e., app., He, or it, became sullied with dust]. (Th, TA.) ― -b5- And qw~bhu, inf. n. taqowiybN, He pulled it out or up, by the root; eradicated, or uprooted, it. (K, * TA.)

5 tqw~bt AlA^aroDu * : see 7. ― -b2- tqw~b jiloduhu: see 1. ― -b3- tqw~b also signifies It became peeled, or excoriated, or became so in several, or many, places. (TA.) One says, tqw~b mino raA^osihi mawaADiEu Some places in his head became excoriated. (S.) In the saying of Dhn-r-Rummeh,
taqaw~aba Eano girobaAni A^aworaAkihaA AlxaToru
taqaw~aba may be for ↓ qaw~aba [q. v.]: or the phrase may be inverted, for taqaw~abato girobaAnuhaA Eani AlxaTori. (S in art. xTr. [See guraAbN, in art. grb.]) ― -b4- It is also said of a place as meaning It became, in parts, stripped of trees and herbage; and so ↓ AnqAb. (TA.) ― -b5- And it signifies also It was pulled out or up, by the root; was eradicated, or uprooted. (S, O, K. *) ― -b6- tqw~bt AlbayoDapu: see the next paragraph.

7 AsqAbt AlA^aroDu *
The ground was hollowed out in a round form; (S, ISd, O, TA;) as also ↓ tqw~bt. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- AnqAbt AlbayoDapu, and ↓ tqw~bt, (S, A, O, K, TA,) and ↓ qaAbat, (TA,) The egg broke asunder, (S, A, O, K, TA,) and disclosed the young bird within it. (TA.) [Hence] one says AinoqaAbato biyoDapu baniY fulaAnK Eano A^amorihimo [lit. The egg of the sons of such a one broke asunder, and disclosed their affair, case, or state]: meaning (tropical:) the sons of such a one revealed, or manifested, their affair, case, or state; a phrase like A^aforaxato bayoDatuhumo. (A, TA.)

8 AqtAbhu *
He chose, made choice of, selected, elected, or preferred, him, or it. (O, K.)

qaAbN * The portion, of a bow, that is between the part that is grasped by the hand and the curved extremity: to every bow there are qaAbaAni: (S, O, Msb, K:) or, accord. to El-Khafájee, it is [the space] between the string and the part that is grasped by the hand, of the bow; as also ↓ qiybN: (TA:) in the Kur [liii. 9], fakaAna qaAba qawosayoni accord. to some, is an inverted phrase, meaning fkAn qaAbaYo qawosK [i. e. And he was at the distance of the measure of the two portions between the part that is grasped by the hand and each of the curved extremities of a bow]: (S, O:) [but] qaAbN signifies also a measure, or space; and so ↓ qiybN: (S, O, K:) one says, bayonahumaA qaAbu qawosK and qawosK ↓ qiybu, [Between them two is the measure of a bow], and likewise qaAdu quwosK and qiydu qawosK: (S, O: *) and it is said that qaAba qawosayoni [in the case mentioned above] means at [the distance of] the length of two bows: or as Fr says, at [the distance of] the measure of two Arabian bows. (TA.) [qAbu qawosK is also a term often used in astronomy to denote the distance between two stars; and seems to be syn. with *iraAEN (q. v.) as so used, thus meaning A cubit; which is the measure of each qAb of a bow, or nearly so.]

quwbN *
A young bird; (S, A, O, K;) as also ↓ qaAy^ibapN and ↓ qaAbapN: (K:) or ↓ qaAy^ibapN signifies, (S, A, O,) or signifies also, (K,) an egg; (S, A, O, K;) and so does ↓ qaAbapN: (K;) ↓ qaAy^ibapN is used in the latter sense as meaning *aAtu quwbK, i. e. *aAtu faroxK: (Az, * O, TA: *) or it is like raADiyapN in the phrase Eiy$apN raADiyapN [meaning maroDiy~apN]: (A:) [or as being originally the part. n. of qaAbat in the phrase qaAbati AlbayoDapu: and it may be used in the former sense as being originally the act. part. n. of qaAbat in the phrase qaAbati AlbayoDapa said of a hen-bird:] and ↓ qaAwibapN signifies an egg from which the young bird has come forth: (Az, TA:) or quwbN signifies an egg: and ↓ qaAbapN, a young bird: (AHeyth, TA:) the pl. of quwbN is A^aqowaAbN. (K.)
It is said in a prov., mino quwbK ↓ bariy^ato qaAy^ibapN, (S, A, O,) or mino quwbK ↓ taxal~aSato qaAy^abipN, (K,) or mino quwbK ↓ qaAbapN, (tropical:) An egg became or has become, freed from a young bird [that was in it]: (S, A, O, K:) or a young bird, from an egg: (AHeyth, TA:) applied to him who has become separated from his companion. (A, * K.) An Arab of the desert, of the tribe of Asad, (S,) or Asd, (O,) said to a merchant who asked him to be his safeguard, mino ↓ A_i*aA balagotu bika makaAna ka*aA bariy^ato qaAy^ibapN quwbK, meaning (assumed tropical:) [When I shall have reached with thee such a place,] I shall be clear of obligation to protect thee. (S, O.) El-Kumeyt says
lahun~a waliloma$iybi wamano EalaAhu
waquwbu ↓ mina AlA^amovaAli qaAy^ibapN
[To them (i. e. women), and to hoariness and him upon whom it has come, relates, among the proverbs, “ An egg and a young bird ”]: he likens the fleeing of women from old men to the fleeing of the quwb, or young bird, from the qaAy^ibap, or egg; and [virtually] says that the beautiful woman will not return to the old man, like as the young bird will not return to the egg. (TA.) And Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee mentions the saying, mino quwbK ↓ laA waAl~a*iY A^axoraja qaAy^ibapF, as meaning [No, by Him who has produced] a young bird from an egg: but Aboo-'Obeyd El-Bekree says that this is inverted. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- A^um~u quwbK [in the TA said to be bAlftH, a mistranscription for biAlD~am~i,] Calamity, or misfortune. (O, K.)

quwabN * [in the two phrases here following is probably pl. of ↓ quwbapN]. You say, fiY AlA^aroDi quwabN In the ground are hollows [app. meaning round hollows: see 1, first sentence]. (A.) And fiY raA^osihi wajilodihi quwabN In his head and his skin are pits. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And hence ↓ AlquwabaA='u. (A.) See quwabaA='u, in two places. ― -b3- It signifies [also] Egg-shells. (O, K.)
qiybN * : see qaAbN, in three places.
quAbapN * : see quwbN: in four places.
quwbapN * : see quwabN: ― -b2- and see also quwabaA='u, in three places.

quwabapN * : see quwabaA='u, in three places. -A2- Also, (K,) applied to a man such as is termed maliYo'N [app. as meaning “ rich, ” or “ wealthy ”], One who remains constantly in his abode, (S, K,) not quitting it. (S.)

quwabaA='u * , (S, O, Msb, K,) fem., and imperfectly decl., (S, O,) and quwobaA='N, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is masc., and perfectly decl., as quasi-coordinate to quroTaAsN, said by ISk to be the only word of the measure fuEolaA='N except xu$~aA='N, (S, O,) both originally of the measure fuEalaA='u, (O,) but to these may be added muz~aA='N, (S, O,) [and perhaps some other instances,] and ↓ quwabapN and ↓ quwobapN, (O, K,) both of which are said by Fr to signify the same as quwayaA='u, (O,) [Ringworm, or tetter; so called in the present day;] a well-known disease, (S, O, Msb,) characterized by excoriation and spreading, and cured by spittle, (S, O, TA,) or by the spittle of one who is fasting or hungry; (TA; [see an ex. in a verse cited voce filoqN;]) a cutaneous eruption, in which scabs peel off from the skin, and the hair comes off: (K, TA:) see quwabN, above: ↓ quwabN is [also] pl. of tuwabaA='u [like as nufasN is of nufasaA='u], (S,) [and] so is qawaAbiY~u: (KL:) ISd says, accord. to IAar, quwabaA='u is sing. of ↓ quwobapN and ↓ quwabapN; but I know not how this can be: and he [i. e. IAar] also says that ↓ quwabN is pl. of ↓ quwobapN and ↓ quwabapN; and this is clear. (TA.) The dim. of quwabaA='u is ↓ quwayobaA='u; and that of quwobaA='N is ↓ quwayobiY~N. (S, O.)

quwbiY~N *
Fond of, or addicted to, the eating of young birds, (O, K, TA,) which are termed A^aqowaAb [pl. of quwbN]. (TA.)
quwayobaA='u * and quwayobiY~N: see quwabaA='u, concluding sentence.

qaAy^ibapN * and qaAwibapN: see quwbN; the former in eight places, and the latter in one place. qaAy^ibapu quwbK means An empty egg: to such, in a trad., Mekkeh is likened when devoid of pilgrims. (O.)

A^aroDN mqwbpN * [i. e. maquwbapN or muqaw~abapN, being written without any syll. signs,] Land upon which rain has fallen, and in consequence thereof, in some places, trees that were in it formerly have been carried away: mentioned by AHn. (TA.)

mutaqaw~ibN *
Peeled, or excoriated; or so in several, or many, places. (K.) ― -b2- And One from whose skin scabs have peeled off, (A, K, TA,) leaving upon it marks, (A,) and whose hair has come off [at those places]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And A serpent (S, O, K) of the species termed A^asowadu (S, O) that has cast off its skin. (S, O, K.)

1 qaAta * , (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. yaquwtu, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. qawotN (S, O, Msb, K) and quwtN (Sb, K) and qiyaAtapN, (S, O, K,) the last originally qiwaAtapN, (O,) He fed, nourished, or sustained, (S, Msb, TA,) or fed with what would sustain the body, (S, O, K, * TA,) [or with food sufficient to sustain life,] or with a small supply of the means of subsistence, (TA,) him, (Msb, TA,) or them, (K, TA,) or his family; (S, O;) he gave him [or them] what is termed quwt [q. v.]: (Msb:) and ↓ AqAthu signifies [in like manner] he gave him his quwt. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kafaY biAlmaro'i A_ivomFA A^ano yuDay~iEa mano yaquwtu i. e. [It suffices the man as a sin, or crime, that he destroy] him whom he is bound to sustain, of his family and household and slaves: or, as some relate it, ↓ mano yuqiytuhu; using a dial. var. [of yqwt]. (TA.) [And lahu ↓ AqtAt app. signifies, primarily, He supplied to him food. (See this verb below, near the end of the paragraph.)] -A2- And qaAta and ↓ qw~t and ↓ AqAt and ↓ A^aqowata [sometimes] signify He straitened his household, by reason of niggardliness or poverty. (TA in art. znq.) -A3- quwtuwA TaEaAmakumo yubaAriko lakumo fiyhi, a trad., thus related by some, by others ↓ quw~ituwA, [loosely expl. in the TA,] means, accord. to some, Measure ye your corn, [and] He will bless you in it: or, accord. to others, make ye small round cakes (A^aqoraAS) of your corn, &c. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer, and scholia thereon.) -A4- See also 8, in the middle of the paragraph.
2 qaw~ata see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 AqAthu * : see 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- Also He kept, preserved, guarded, or protected, him. (TA.) -A2- And AqAt EalaY Al$~aYo'i, (S, O, K, *) and AqAth, (K,) He had power, or ability, to do, effect, accomplish, attain, or compass, the thing. (S, O, K.) -A3- See, again, 1, latter half, in two places.

5 fulaAnN yataqaw~atu bika*aA * [Such a one feeds, nourishes, or sustains, himself with such a thing], (S, O,) or biAlqaliyli [with that which is little]: (Msb:) or tq~wt biAl$~aYo'i he made the thing his quwt [or food]; and bihi ↓ AqtAt and ↓ AqtAthu signify thus likewise: (TA:) or bihi ↓ AqtAt signifies he ate it; (Msb;) and so does ↓ AqtAthu. (TA.)

8 AqtAt * signifies He was, or became, fed, nourished, or sustained; being quasi-pass. of qaAta signifying as expl. in the beginning of this art. (S, A, Mgh, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And it is trans. by means of bi, and by itself: see 5, in four places. One says, humo yaqotaAtuwna AlHab~a [They feed upon, or eat, grain]. (A.) ― -b3- The saying, of Tufeyl,
yaqotaAtu faDola sanaAmihaA Alr~aHolu
is held by ISd to mean, (assumed tropical:) The saddle [as it were] eats the remainder of her hump, [as though] making it to be food for itself: accord. to IAar, he says, the meaning is, takes it away thing after thing [or piecemeal]; but I have not heard this [meaning] in any other instance: hence, says IAar, the oath sworn one day by El-'Okeylee, [said in the A to be an oath of the Arabs of the desert,] nafosiY AlbaSiyri maA faEalotu ↓ laA waqaAy^iti, for, he says, AlAiqotiyaAtu [the inf. n. of AqtAt] and Alqawotu [inf. n. of ↓ qaAta] are one [in signification]; and AM says that the meaning of this is, [No, by] Him who takes my spirit, breath after breath, until He has taken it wholly, [the All-seeing, I did not that thing:] and the saying of Tufeyl means the saddle, while I am riding upon it, takes by little and little the fat of her hump until there remains not of it aught. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, AlHarobu taqotaAtu AlA_ibila (tropical:) [War makes the camels to be food]; meaning that [in consequence of war] the camels are given in payment of bloodwits. (A.) ― -b5- And fulaAnN yaqotaAtu AlkalaAma (tropical:) Such a one retrenches, or curtails, speech, or talk; [said of one who speaks, or talks, little;] syn. yuqil~uhu. (A.) -A2- See also 1, latter half. [Hence,] one says, ↓ Aiqotato linaArika qiytapF (assumed tropical:) [Supply to thy fire ali-
ment;] feed thy fire with fuel. (S, O, K.) And ↓ Aiqotato liln~aAri nafoxaka qiytapF, and Aunofuxo fiY Aln~aAri nafoxFA ↓ quwtFA, (assumed tropical:) Blow thou the fire with thy blowing, and with a blowing, gently and little [as an aliment]. (L.)

10 AstqAthu *
He asked of him quwt [i. e. food, or victuals]. (S, A, O, K.)

[
qaAtN *
A species of tree, of the class Pentandria, order Monogynia, of the Linnæan system; belonging to the natural order of Celastraceæ; mentioned in botanical works under the name of Catha edulis; and fully described by Forskål in his Flora Ægypt. Arab., pp. 63, 64; in the latter page of which he says: “ In Yemen colitur iisdem hortis cum Coffea. Stipitibus plantatur. Arabes folia viridia avide edunt, multum eorum vires venditantes, qui copiosius comederit, vel totam vigilet noctem: asseverant quoque pestem ea loca non intrare ubi hæc colitur arbor: ” &c. ― -b2- And in the same work, p. cxviii., Forskål mentions qAt AlrEyAn (by which is meant qaAtu Alr~uEoyaAni) as the name of A species of lettuce, lactuca inermis. ― -b3- Respecting the former plant, see also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 462, 463.]

quwt *
Food, aliment, nutriment, victuals, or provisions, by means of which the body of man is sustained; (S, A, * O, K; *) as also ↓ qiytN and ↓ qiytapN, (S, O, K,) as used in phrases here following, (S, O,) with kesr to the q, and the w changed into Y, (S,) and ↓ qaAy^itN and ↓ quwaAtN, (K,) the last mentioned, but not expl., by Lh, and thought by ISd to be from quwtN: (TA:) what is eaten for the purpose of retaining the remains of life; (A, * O, * Msb, TA; *) thus expl. by Az and IF: (Msb:) or food sufficient to sustain life: (TA:) pl. A^aqowaAtN. (Msb, TA.) One says, maA Einodahu quwtu layolapK and layolapK ↓ qiytu and layolapK ↓ qiytapu (S, O, TA) He has not a night's food sufficient to sustain life. (TA.) And ↓ jad~u A@moriy^K fiY qaAy^itihi, a prov., meaning A man's lot in life is manifest in his food. (Meyd.) ― -b2- See also 8, last sentence.
qiytN * : see quwtN, in two places.
qiytapN * : see quwtN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 8, last two sentences.
quwaAtN * : see quwtN, first sentence.

qaAy^itN * [act. part. n. of qaAta; Feeding, &c. ― -b2- And hence, Sufficing]. AlqaAy^itu mina AlEayo$i means What is sufficient [of the means of subsistence]. (K.) And one says, huwa fiY qaAy^itK mina AlEayo$i He is in a state of sufficiency [in respect of the means of subsistence]. (S. O.) ― -b3- See also quwtN, in two places. -A2- See also 8, former half. ― -b2- AlqaAy^itu is an appellation of The lion. (O, K.)

muqiytN * [Giving, or a giver of, food, nourishment, or sustenance. (See 1, first sentence.) ― -b2- And hence,] Keeping, preserving, guarding, or protecting; or a keeper, &c.; syn. HaAfiZN [as signifying thus; and app. as signifying also watching; or a watcher]: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) and witnessing; or a witness; syn. $aAhidN; (S, O, Msb, K;) or $ahiydN: (A:) and AO says that it signifies, with the Arabs, one acquainted (mawoquwfN) with a thing (EalaY $aYo'K). (TA.) Th cites the following verses (of Es-Semow'al Ibn-Ádiyà, O):
layota $iEoriY waA^a$oEuran~a A_i*aA maA
qar~abuwhaA mano$uwrapF waduEiytu
A^aliYa AlfaDolu A^amo EalaY~a A_i*aA Huw
sibotu A_in~iY EalaY AlHisaAbi muqiytu
[meaning Would that I knew, but I shall assuredly know when they shall have set it (namely, the SaHiyfap, or record, of my actions,) near, unfolded, and I am summoned, whether superiority be for me or against me when I am reckoned with: verily I shall be a watcher, or a witness, of the reckoning, or, accord. to some, as is said in the TA, acquainted with the reckoning]: i. e. I shall know what evil I have done; for [as is said in the Kur lxxv. 14] man shall be a witness against himself: (S, O, TA:) IB says that, accord. to Seer, the correct reading is, rab~iY ElY AlHsAb mqyt [meaning my Lord is able to make the reckoning] because he who is submissive to his Lord does not describe himself by this epithet: but IB adds that Seer has founded this remark upon the assumption that mqyt is here used as meaning muqotadirN; and that if it be understood as syn. with HaAfiZN and $aAhidN, the former reading is not objectionable. (TA.) ― -b3- Almuqiytu is one of the best names of God: (TA:) and [as such] signifies The Possessor of power; (Fr, Zj, S, O, Msb, K, TA;) as He who gives to every man his quwt [or food], (F, S, O, K, TA,) and likewise to everything: (TA:) or (as one of those names, TA) the Preserver, or Protector, (Zj, TA,) who gives to everything such preservation, or protection, as is needful. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 87], wakaAna A@ll~`hu EalaY kul~i $aYo'K muqiytFA, (S, O,) meaning [For God is] a possessor of power [over everything, or is omnipotent], (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) so He will requite everyone for what he has done: (Jel:) or a witness, [and] a preserver, or protector, or watcher. (Ksh, Bd.)

1 qaAHa * , aor. yaquwHu, said of a wound, i. q. qaAHa, inf. n. qyH, q. v.; as also ↓ tq~wH. (K.) -A2- And qAH, (K, TA,) inf. n. qawoHN, (TA,) He swept a house, or chamber; (K, TA;) a dial. var. of HaAqa; mentioned by Kr; (TA;) as also ↓ qw~H. (K, TA.)
2 qaw~aHa see what next precedes.

4 AqAH *
He (a man, TA) kept constantly, or perseveringly, to refusing, after the act of asking, or begging; (K, TA;) mentioned by IAar, but in art. qyH. (TA.)
5 taqaw~aHa see 1, first sentence.

qaAHapN * The court of a house; a spacious vacant part, or portion, thereof, in which is no building; syn. saAHapN; (S in art. qyH, and L, K, in the present art.;) and baAHapN, q and b being interchangeable in this case, as in TiynN laAzibN and laAziqN, and in nabiyvapu Albiy^ori and naqiyvatuhaA: and the middle of a house: (TA:) pl. quwHN; (K, TA;) like [its syn.] suwHN pl. of saAHapN. (TA.) It is related of 'Omar that he said, mano malaA^a Eayonahu mino qaAHapi bayotK qabola A^ano yuw^o*ana lahu faqado fajara [He who satisfies his eye by the sight of what is in the court of a house before permission is given to him to enter verily transgresses]. (TA.) And [the pl.] signifies Lands giving growth to nothing. (TA.)

1 qaAdahu * , aor. yaquwdu, inf. n. qawodN (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and qiyaAdN (Mgh, Msb) and qiyaAdapN (Msb, K) and maqaAdapN and qayoduwdapN (S, L, K) [originally qayowaduwdapN, of the measure fayoEaluwlapN, like dayomuwmapN &c.,] and taqowaAdN, (K,) [an intensive form; or, accord. to some, inf. n. of qaw~ada;] He led him; (namely, a horse &c., L;) contr. of saAqahu; Alqawodu being from before, and Als~awoqu from behind; (Kh, L, Msb, K;) he drew him (a camel) after him; (L;) as also ↓ AqtAdhu; (S, L, K;) and ↓ qw~dhu, inf. n. taqowiydN; (K;) or AqtAdh signifies he led him for himself: (Msb:) and qw~dh, he led him much: (S, A, L:) you say qw~d farasahu he led his horse much. (A.) [One says also qaAda bihi; app. by poetic license: see a verse of Jereer cited in the first paragraph of art. rDE.] ― -b2- A^aSobaHotu yuqaAdu biYa AlbaEiyru (tropical:) [lit., I have become in such a state that the camel is led with me; i. e.,] I have become old and decrepit. (A.) ― -b3- qaAdati Alr~iyHu Als~aHaAba (tropical:) The wind led on the cloud, or clouds. (L.) ― -b4- qaAda, inf. n. qiyaAdapN (Mgh, Msb) and qawodN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) He led an army. (Mgh, L, Msb.) ― -b5- Aln~abotu Alv~awora ↓ AqtAd (tropical:) [The herbage attracted the bull by its odour;] he perceived its odour and rushed upon it. (A.) ― -b6- qaAda, aor. yaquwdu, inf. n. qiyaAdapN, (tropical:) He acted the part, or performed the office, of a pimp, or bawd; or, of a pimp to his own wife, or of a contented cuckold. (Msb.) Ex. qaAda EalaY AlfaAjirapi, inf. n. as above, [He acted the part, or performed the office, of a pimp to the adulteress, or fornicatress]. (A. [Not given there as tropical.]) -A2- qaAda, aor. yaquwdu, inf. n. qiyaAdapN, (tropical:) It extended along the surface of the ground; said of a mountain, and of a dyke [&c.]: (T, L:) and so ↓ AnqAd; said of a mountain, (the Lexicons passim,) and of a tract of land, (L,) and of sand; (TA;) and ↓ tqAwd and ↓ AqtAd. (L.) You say, ZahorN mina AlA^aroDi yaquwdu ka*aA waka*aA miylFA, and yanoqaAdu, and yataqaAwadu, A rugged and elevated tract of
land that extends such and such a number of miles. And h`*aA makaAnN yaquwdu mina AlA^aroDi ka*aA waka*aA This is a place which stretches along (yjAdb) such and such measures of ground. (L.) -A3- qawida, [aor. yaqowadu,] (L,) inf. n. qawadN, (S, L, K,) (assumed tropical:) He (a camel, and a horse, S, L, or other beast of carriage, and a man, L) had a long back and neck. (S, L, K.) See A^aqowadu. -A4- qiyda It (flour) became compacted together in a mass; syn. tak~atla and takab~aba. (K.) [See also art. qyd, to which it probably belongs.]
2 qaw~ada see 1.
3 mar~a wafulaAnN yuqaAwiduhu wayusaAwiquhu * [He passed by, or along, such a one vying, or contending, with him in leading on and in driving on]. (A.) [See also 6 in art. swq.]

4 AqAdhu xayolFA *
He gave him horses to lead: (S, L, K:) and in like manner, maAlFA [camels]. (TA.) ― -b2- AqAd Algayovu (tropical:) The rain spread wide: (L, K:) or, had a cloud, or clouds, leading it on. (L.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a man) advanced; went forward: (L, K:) as though he gave the means of leading him to the ground and it attained thereby its want. (L.) -A2- A^aqaAdaniY, (L,) and AqAdnY mina AlqaAtili, (Msb,) He retaliated for me upon the slayer. (L, Msb.) AqAdhu Als~uloTaAnu mino A^axiyhi [The Sultán retaliated for him upon his brother]. (S.) ― -b2- AqAd AlqaAtila biAlqatiyli, (inf. n. A_iqaAdapN, TA,) He slew the slayer for the slain. (S, L, K.)
6 tqAwdA * (assumed tropical:) They two went away quickly: as though each of them led the other. (L.) [See also 6 in art. swq] -A2- tqAwd (tropical:) It (a place) became even. (A.) See also 1.

7 AnqAd * , [inf. n. AinoqiyaAdN,] He (a beast) suffered himself to be led; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ AqtAd (K) and ↓ AstqAd. (A, TA.)
