You say AnqAd liY, and AstqAd lY, He was, or became, tractable to me; gave me the means of leading him. (S, L.) ― -b2- AnqAd, (A, K,) inf. n. A_inqiyaAdN, (S, L,) (tropical:) He was, or became, submissive, resigned, manageable, easy, humble, or lowly; (S, L, A, K;) as also ↓ AstqAd. (TA.) ― -b3- AnqAd Als~aHaAbu, and lil~iryHi ↓ AstqAd, (tropical:) The cloud, or clouds, became led on by the wind. (A.) ― -b4- AnqAd (tropical:) It (a road) was easy and direct. (TA.) ― -b5- AnqAd liYa AlT~ariyqu A_ilayohi (tropical:) The road to him, or it, was, or became, plain, or obvious, or manifest, to me. (L, K.) ― -b6- AnqAdt A_ilayohi AlmawaAridu (tropical:) The roads, or ways, continued uninterruptedly to it. (As, AM; from a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh.) See also 1.
8 A_iqotawada see 1 in three places. ― -b2- And see 7.

10 A_isotaqowada see 7 in three places -A2- AstqAd AlA^amora minohu He retaliated the thing upon him. (Lth, L.) ― -b2- AstqAdhu He asked him (namely a judge, or governor,) to retaliate upon a slayer; to slay the slayer for the slain. (S, L, Msb.)
qaAdN * : see qiydN.

qawodN *
Horses: (S, L, K:) or a number of horses together: (A:) or led horses; horses led by their leading-ropes, not ridden, (Az, L, Msb, K,) but prepared for the time of want. (L.) You say, mar~a binaA qawodN [A number of horses together, or of led horses, passed by us]. (S, L.)
qayodN * , contr. from qay~idN, see munoqaAdN.

qiydN * [originally qiwodN, if belonging to this art.,] and ↓ qaAdN, Measure; syn. qadorN. (L, art. qyd; and K in the present art.) Ex. huwa min~iY qiyda rumoHK, and rmH ↓ qaAda, He is [distant] from me the measure of a spear. (L, art. qyd.)

qawadN * The slaying of the slayer for the slain: (Lth, L:) or i. q. qiSaASN [which signifies the retaliation of slaughter, and of wounding, and of mutilation;] (S, L, Msb, K;) or slaughter for slaughter, and wounding for wounding. (TA, art. qS.) Ex. Talaba Alqawada mina AlqaAtili [He sought retaliation upon the slayer]. (A.)
qawadN * ― -b2- qatalahu bihi qawadFA He slew him for him (i. e. for the slain) in retaliation. (Msb.)
qiyaAdN * see miqowadN in three places.
qaw^uwdN * and qawuwdN see munoqaAdN.

qiyaAdapN *
Tractableness; (tropical:) submissiveness; easiness; in a horse or camel. (L.)
qiy~idN * : see munoqaAdN.

qaw~aAdN * (tropical:) A pimp; a bawd: fem. with p: (Msb:) a pimp to his own wife; or a contented cuckold; syn. day~awvN. (Msb, * TA.) -A2- Alqaw~aAdu The nose; in the dial. of Himyer. (K.) ― -b2- In the following words of Ru-beh,
A^atolaEu yasomuw bitaliylK qaw~aAdo
[Long-necked, elevating himself, with advancing neck], qw~Ad is explained as signifying mutaqad~imN. (L.)

qay~idapN *
A camel whereby a man conceals himself from the animal that he would shoot, previously to his shooting at it; (ISd;) i. q. dariyoy^apN; (A, L;) as also say~iqapN. (A.)

qaAy^idN *
A leader of horses: (L:) and (assumed tropical:) of an army: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. quw~aAdN and qaAdapN (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and quw~adN; (K;) and pl. of qaAdapN, qaAdaAtN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- qaAy^idapN [A she-camel] that precedes the other camels [or leads them on,] and with which the young ones keep company. (L.) ― -b3- saHaAbN qaAy^idN (tropical:) A cloud, or clouds, leading on rain. (L.) ― -b4- qaAy^idapN (tropical:) A wind [riyHN] leading on a cloud, or clouds. (A.) -A2- qaAy^idN (tropical:) Extending along the surface of the ground; applied to a mountain, and a dyke, (T, L,) and a tract of land [&c.]: (K:) and so ↓ munoqaAdN, applied to a mountain, (the Lexicons passim,) and a tract of land, and of sand. (L.) ― -b2- A prominent part of a mountain (JK, L, K) extending upon the surface of the ground. (JK.) ― -b3- qaAy^idapN A hill of the kind termed A^akamap extending upon the surface of the ground: (L, K:) or a hill cleaving to the ground. (IAar, in TA, art. x$E.) -A3- qaAy^idN The largest of the channels for irrigation (fulojaAn) of a land ploughed for sowing. (L, K.) [In the CK, AlHaAriv is put for AlHarov.] ISd says, that he assigns it to this art. only because w is more common than Y. (L.) [Pl. qawaAy^idu, occuring in the L and TA, voce A^aEoraAfN.] -A4- AlqaAy^idu The last star [ η] in the tail of Ursa Major, banaAti naEo$K AlkuboraY: in the K, AlS~ugoraY, but this is a mistake. (TA.) [The star (z) which is the middle one of the three in the tail of that constellation is called AlEanaAqN, and by the side of it is the obscure star called Als~uhaY, and also called AlS~ayodaqu, and, as is said in the TA, nuEayo$N; and the third of those three, next the body, is called AlHawaru In the K, a strange description is given of these stars: it is there said, AlA^aw~alu mino banaAti naEo$K AlS~ugoraY Al*Y hw [AlqaAy^idu] w A=xiruhaA qaAy^idN waAlv~aAniY EanaAqN waA_ilaY jaAnibihi qaAy^idN SagiyrN w vaAniyhi EanaAqN waA_ilaY jaAnibihi AlS~ayodaqu whw Als~uhaY wAlv~aAlivu AlHawaru.] ― -b2- The qawaAy^idu, among the northern stars, are, it is said, four stars forming an irregular quadrilateral figure, distant one from another, [as though ε, ζ, η π of Hercules,] in the midst of which is an obscure star, resembling a soil, and called Alr~ubaEu, they being likened to she-camels with a young one such as is called rubaEN: they are on the left of Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu [a Lyræ], between it and banaAtu naEo$K. (TA.) [But qawaAy^idu, here, is evidently a mistake for EawaAy^i*u.]

qayoduwdN * , originally qayowaduwdN because from qaAda, aor. yaquwdu accord. to the Basrees; or, accord. to the Koofees, it is of the measure faEoluwlapN, and the Y is substituted for w; A mare easy to be led. (IKtt, MF.) -A2- qayoduwdN (assumed tropical:) A long, or tall, she-ass, (S, L, K,) &c.: (K:) pl. qayaAdiydu. (S, L, K.) See also art. qd. ― -b2- qayoduwdN (assumed tropical:) A mare having a long and curved neck: (L:) not applied to a male. (ISd, L.)

A^aqowadu * A man (S, L) strong-necked: (S, L, K:) so called because he seldom turns his face aside. (S, L.) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) One who is niggardly, or tenacious, of his travelling-provision: (S, L, K:) because he does not turn aside his face in eating, lest he should see a man and be obliged to invite him. (S, L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A man who does not turn aside his face. (L.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A tall, or high, mountain; (S, L, K; *) as also ↓ muqaw~adN. (K.) ― -b5- qawodaA='u (tropical:) A road of a difficult place of ascent of a mountain (vaniy~apN) extending to a great length upwards, (S, L,) or, reaching high. (K.) ― -b6- qul~apN qawodaA='u (tropical:) A tall
mountain-top. (A.) ― -b7- A^aqowadu (assumed tropical:) A man who, when he applies himself to a thing, can hardly turn his face away from it. (T, L, A, K. *) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A camel, and a horse, (S, L,) or other beast of carriage, and a man, (L,) having a long back and neck: (S, L:) or a long-necked horse, (A,) or camel: (R:) or long, or tall, absolutely, applied to a camel: (R, TA:) fem. qawodaA='u; and pl. quwdN: (S, L:) or a horse having a long and large neck. (ISh.) See $agaba. -A2- See also munoqaAdN. ― -b2- (tropical:) More, or most, addicted to the conduct of a pimp, or bawd; or, of a pimp to his own wife, or a contented cuckold. (Msb.)
jaEalotuhu maqaAda Almuhori * (assumed tropical:) I placed him on the right hand: (L, K:) because the colt (mhr) is in most instances led (yuqaAdu) on the right hand. (L.)

miqowadN *
A leading-rope; (L, Msb;) that with which one leads [a horse &c.]; (K;) a rope or the like with which one leads [a horse &c.]; (Mgh;) a rope upon the neck, for leading [a horse &c.]: (A:) as also ↓ qiyaAdN; (L, Mgh, Msb, K;) a rope that is tied to the cord of the nose-ring of a camel, or to the bit of a horse or the like, by which a beast is led; (S, L;) a cord, or a thong or strap, attached to the neck of a beast or of a dog, by which the animal is led: (L:) pl. maqaAwidu. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- ↓ A^aEoTaY AlqiyaAda (tropical:) [lit., He gave the leading-rope; i. e.,] he was, or became, submissive, or obedient, willingly or unwillingly. (Msb.) ― -b3- fulaAnN ↓ salisu AlqiyaAdi (tropical:) [lit., Such a one has an easy leading-rope; i. e.,] such a one will follow thee agreeably with thy desire; (A;) [is submissive, obsequious, or obedient]: and ↓ SaEobu AlqiyaAdi (tropical:) [signifying having a difficult leading-rope; i. e., refractory]. (L.)
maquwdN * and ↓ maqowuwdN (the latter extr. [with respect to form], and of the dial. of Temeem, TA,) A beast of carriage led. (K.)
gayovN muqiydN * (tropical:) Wide-spreading rain: or rain having a cloud, or clouds, leading it on. (L.)
muqaw~adN * : see A^aqowadu.

A^aEoTaAhu maqaAdatapN *
He gave him the means of leading him; he was, or became, tractable to him. (S, * L, * K.)
maqowuwdN * : see maquwdN.

munoqaAdN * and ↓ qaw^uwdN (S, L, K) and ↓ qawuwdN, without ', (Ks,) and ↓ qay~idN and ↓ qayodN, [the last but one originally qayowidN, and the last contracted from it,] like may~itN and mayotN, and ↓ A^aqowadu, (L, K,) A horse, (Ks, S, L, K,) and a camel, (Ks, L,) tractable; (tropical:) submissive; easy. (Ks, S, L, K.) Ex. AijoEalo fiY A^aw~ali qiTaArika baEiyrFA qay~idFA [Place thou at the head of thy string of camels a camel that is tractable]. (A.) -A2- munoqaAdN: see qaAy^idN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A direct road. (A.)

1 qawra * , aor. yaqowaru, inf. n. qawarN, It (a thing) was, or became, wide: whence daArN qawraA'u, q. v. (JK.) -A2- qaArahu, (A, K,) aor. yaquwru, inf. n. qaworN; (TA;) and ↓ qw~rhu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqowiyrN; (Mgh, Msb;) and ↓ A_iqotawarahu; and ↓ AqtArhu; (S, K;) [of all which the second is the most common;] He cut a round hole in the middle of it; (A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as one cuts a jayob [or the opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt], (TA,) and a melon: (Mgh, Msb:) [he hollowed it out; he scooped it out; he cut out a piece of it, generally meaning in a round form:] he cut it in a round form. (S.) You say Aljayoba ↓ qw~r [He cut out, or hollowed out, the opening at the neck and bosom of the shirt]. (TA.) And qurotu AlbiT~iyxapa, and ↓ qaw~arotuhaA, [I cut a round hole in the melon]. (TA.) And qurotu xuf~a AlbaEiyri, and ↓ qaw~arotuhu, and ↓ A_iqotarotuhu, [I cut a round hollow in the foot of the camel]. (TA.) ― -b2- qurotuhu, and qurotu Eayonahu, I put out, or pulled out, [or scooped out,] his eye; syn. faqaA^otu Eayonahu. (TA.) ― -b3- qaAra AlmaroA^apa He circumcised the woman. (L, K.)

2 qw~r *
He widened a house; made it wide. (A, * TA.) -A2- See also 1, in four places.

5 tqw~r *
It (a cloud) became dissundered, and separated into round portions. (TA, from a trad.) See also 7.

7 AnqAr *
It (the side of a cloud) became as though a portion fell from it, by reason of much water pouring [from it]. (TA.) See also 5.
8 A_iqotawarahu * and AqtArhu : see 1, in two places.

qaArN *
i. q. qiyrN [Tar: or pitch]. (S, K.) See muqaw~arN.

qaArapN *
A small mountain separate from other mountains: (K:) or a small mountain upon another mountain: such [or a knoll of a mountain] seems to be meant by qaArapu jabalK:) (TA:) or the smallest of mountains: (A:) or a small, black, isolated mountain, resembling an A^akamapN: or a black A^akamap: (TA:) or i. q. A^akamapN [i. e. a hill, or mound, &c.]: (S:) or the smallest of mountains and the largest of A=kaAm; scattered, rough, and abounding with stones: (Lth:) or a small mountain, slender, compact, and lofty, not extending along the surface of the ground, as though it were a collection of stones, and [sometimes] great, and round: (ISh:) or a great rock, (K,) smaller than a mountain: (TA:) or a black rock: (K:) or a tract of ground containing black stones; (K, TA;) i. e., a Har~ap: (TA:) pl. qaArN, (S, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and qaAraAtN (K) and quwrN (Lth, S, A, K) and qiyraAnN. (Lth, K.)

quwaArapN *
What is cut in a round form (maA quw~ira) from a garment or piece of cloth, &c.; (K;) as the qwArp of a shirt, (S, A, Msb,) and of a jayob [or the opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt], (TA, [but there written, by mistake, jnb,]) and of a melon: (S, A:) or particularly from a hide, or tanned hide; (Lh, K;) what is cut in a round form (maA quw~ira) from the middle of a hide, or tanned hide, for a target to shoot at, like the qwArp of a jayob. (JK.) ― -b2- Also, What one cuts from the sides of a thing (K, TA) that is muqaw~ar [or cut in a round form]. (TA.) ― -b3- And, contr., A thing of which the sides have been cut. (K.)

[
A^aqowaru * : fem. qaworaA='u: Wide in the inside; capacious.] daArN qaworaA='u A house that is wide (S, K, TA) in the inside. (TA.)
muqaw~arN * [Having a round hole cut in its middle: hollowed out; scooped out: cut in a round form. See 1.] -A2- A camel smeared with qaTiraAn [or tar]. (Sgh, K.) See qaArN.
muqaw~irN * A youth who hollows out the cakes of bread, eating the middle parts and leaving the edges. (A, TA.)

1 qaAsa Al$~aYo'a bigayorhi * , and EalaY gayorihi, aor. yaquwsuhu, inf. n. qawosN (S, K *) and qiyaAsN, (S,) i. q. qaAsahu, aor. yaqiysuhu, inf. n. qayosN (S, K *) and qiyaAsN; (S;) i. e., He measured the thing by another thing like it; [both in the proper sense and mentally; but the latter verb is the more common, though the former, accord. to the JK, is the original;] (S, TA;) and so Al$~aYo'a bigayorihi ↓ AqtAs: (S, K: *) but you should not say ↓ A^aqasotuhu for qusotuhu or qisotuhu. (S.) -A2- qawisa: see 5.
2 qaw~asa see 5, in two places. -A2- qw~shu, inf. n. taqowiysN, He made it bowed, or bent. (KL.)
4 A^aqowasa see 1: -A2- and see 5.

5 tqw~s *
It (a thing) became bowed, or bent; as also ↓ Astqws: (TA:) the ↓ latter is also said, tropically, of the moon when near the change [&c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (an old man, S, A) became bowed, or bent; (A, * K;) as also ↓ qaw~asa, inf. n. taqowiysN; (S, A, * Msb, K;) and ↓ Astqws; (S;) and ↓ Aqws: (A:) or he became bowed, or bent, in the back; as also ↓ qaw~asa; and ↓ Astqws; (TA;) and so ↓ qawisa, aor.
qawasa , inf. n. qawasN. (K.) -A2- tqw~s qawosahu He put his bow upon his back. (TA.)
8 A_iqotawasa see 1. ― -b2- yaqotaAsu biA^abiyhi, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iqotiyaAsN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He follows the way of his father, and imitates him. (S, K.)
10 A_isotaqowasa see 5, in four places.
qaAsu rumoHK * : see qiysu rumoHK.

qawosN * [A bow;] a certain thing, well known, (A, K,) with which one shoots: (M, TA:) of the fem. gender: (IAmb, M, Msb:) or masc. and
fem.: (S, Msb:) or sometimes masc.: (A, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aqowaAsN (IAmb, S, A, Msb, K) and A^aqoyaAsN, (TA, and so in some copies of the K, in the place of the former,) the Y being interchangeable with the w, (TA,) and [of mult.] qisiY~N, (S, A, Msb, K,) originally quwuwsN, (S, TA,) which is not used, (TA,) of the neasure fuEuwlN, (S, Msb,) first changed to qusuw~N, of he measure fuluwEN, and then to qisiY~N, of the measure filiyEN, like EiSiY~N, (S,) and qusiY~N, (Fr, Sgh, K,) from the same original, (TA,) [like EuSiY~N,] and qiyaAsN, (IAmb, S, A, Msb, K,) which is more agreeable with analogy than qsY~. (TA.) The dim. is quwayosN, (IAmb, M, Msb, K,) without p, contr. to rule, as the word is fem., (M, TA,) and quwayosapN, (IAmb, Msb, K,) sometimes: (IAmb, Msb:) or the former accord. to those who make qws to be masc., (S,) and the latter accord. to those who make it to be fem. (S, Msb.) It is prefixed to another word to give it a special signification. Thus you say, qawosu nabolK An Arabian bow. And qawosu nu$~aAbK A Persian bow. And qawosu HusobaAnK [A bow for shooting a certain kind of short arrows]. And qawosu julaAhiqK [A cross-bow]. And qawosu nadofK [A bow for loosening and separating cotton]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] fulaAnN laA yamud~u qawosahu A^aHadN [Such a one, no one will pull his bow;] i. e., (tropical:) no one will vie with him, or compete with him. (A, TA.) And ramawonaA Eano qawosK waAHidK, (A, TA,) or waAHidapK, (Mgh,) [lit., They shot at us from one bow: meaning, (tropical:) they were unanimous against us;] a proverb denoting agreement. (Mgh.) [In the Msb, ramawohumo and waAHidapK.] And huwa mino xayori quwayosK sahomFA; (S, L, K; except that in the L and K, for qwys, we find qawosK;) (tropical:) [He is of the best of a little bow, as an arrow; i. e., he is one of the best arrows of a little bow;] or SaAra xayora quwayosK sahomFA (A, K) (tropical:) [He became the best of a little bow, as an arrow; i. e., he became the best arrow of a little bow:] a proverb [See Arab. Prov. i. 718] applied to him who has become mighty after being of mean condition: (A:) or to him who opposeth thee and then returns to doing what thou likest. (A, K.) [Hence also the phrase in the Kur, liii. 9,] fakaAna qaAba qawosayoni And he was at the distance of two Arabian bows: or two cubits [this is app. an explanation by one who holds qaAba qawosayoni to be for qaAbaYa qawosK:] (K:) or the meaning is, qaAbaYo qawosK, i. e., [at the distance of the measure of] the two portions between the part of a bow that is grasped by the hand and each of the curved extremities. (TA.) See also art. qwb. ― -b3- Alqawosu (assumed tropical:) [The Sign of Sagittarius; also called Alr~aAmiY;] one of the signs of the zodiac; (S, K;) namely, the ninth thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- qawosu quzaHa The rainbow: the two words are inseparable. (TA.) See qzH. ― -b5- qawosu Alr~ajuli (assumed tropical:) The bowed, or bent, part of the back of a man. (IAar.) ― -b6- A^aqowaAsu AlbaEiyir (tropical:) The anterior ribs of the camel. (A.) ― -b7- Also qawosN (tropical:) What remains, of dates, (S, A, * K,) in the [receptacle called] jul~ap, (S,) or in the bottom thereof, (K,) or in the sides thereof, like a bow: (A:) or, accord. to Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, the fourth part of the jul~ap, of dates; like rizomapN: (TA in art. rzm:) in this sense, also, it is fem.: or a number of dates collected together: pl. as above. (TA in the present art.) -A2- Also, A cubit: (S, K:) sometimes used in this sense: (S:) because a thing is measured (yuqaAsu) with it. (K.)
qiysu rumoHK * and qaAsu rumoHK The measure of a spear. (Msb, in this art.; and S, K, in art. qys.)

qaw~aAsN *
A hewer, or fashioner, of bows; and so, perhaps, qay~aAsN. (TA.)
qusawiY~N * is the rel. n. from qisiY~N, [pl. of qawosN,] because it is [before its last change] of the measure fuluwEN changed from the measure fuEuwlN. (S.)

A^aqowasu *
Having a bowed, or bent, back. (S, K.) ― -b2- Sand that is elevated (K, TA) like a hoop or ring. (TA.)

miqowasN *
A bow-case. (S, K.) -A2- A horse-course; a race-ground: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) a place whence horses run (K) for a race; (TA;) i. e., (so in the K accord. to the TA,) a rope at which the horses are placed in a row (S, A, K) on the occasion of racing, (S, K,) in the place whence they run: (A:) or the extended rope from which the horses are started: (JK:) also called mqyS: the pl. is maqaAwisu. (TA.) Hence the saying, EuriDa fulaAnN EalaY Almiqowasi [Such a one has been put to the starting-rope]; meaning, (tropical:) such a one has been tried, or proved, by use, practice, or experience. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN EalaY miqowasK, i. e., EalaY HifaAZK [app. meaning, (assumed tropical:) Such a one is intent upon defending his honour or the like]. (Lth, L.)
muqaw~asN * and muqaw~isN: see mutaqaw~isN.

mutaqaw~isN * (assumed tropical:) An eyebrow [or other thing] likened to a bow; as also ↓ musotaqowisN (K) and ↓ muqaw~asN: (TA:) ↓ the second of these epithets is also applied, in the same sense, or like a bow, to a gutter round a tent, and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, A man bowed, or bent; and so ↓ muqaw~isN. (TA.) -A2- Also, (K,) or mutaqaw~isN qawosahu, (S,) A man having with him his bow. (S, K. *)
musotaqowisN * : see mutaqaw~isu, in two places.
1 qawVDa see 2: and see also 1 in art. qyD.

2 qw~Dhu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqowiyDN, (Msb, K,) He demolished it; destroyed it; threw it down; namely a building; as also ↓ qaADahu, (K,) aor. yaquwDu, inf. n. qawoDN: (TA:) or he took it to pieces, without demolishing or destroying or throwing down; (S, A, Msb, K;) namely a building, (S, A, Msb,) and a tent. (A:) or he pulled up, or out, its poles, or pieces of wood, and its tentropes: (IDrd, K:) or he pulled it up, and removed it; namely a tent. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qw~D AlS~ufuwfa, and AlmajaAlisa, (A, TA,) (tropical:) He separated, or dispersed, the ranks, and the assemblies. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] banaY fulaAnN vum~a qaw~aDa [lit. Such a one built, then demolished, or took to pieces]; i. e. (tropical:) did well, then did ill. (A, TA.)

5 tqw~D *
It (a house, and a tent, TA) became demolished, destroyed, or thrown down; (S * in art. qyD; and K;) and in like manner tqw~z; (TA;) as also ↓ AnqAD [which see also in art. qyD]: (K; and in a copy of the S in art. qyD:) or it was, or became, taken to pieces, without being demolished or destroyed or thrown down: (A, TA:) and ↓ AnqADt, said of a well (by^or), it fell; fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed. (Msb: see also art. qyD.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tqw~D Almajolisu, (A,) and tqw~Dt AlHilaqu, (S, TA,) and AlS~afuwfu, (S, Msb, TA,) (tropical:) [The assembly, and] the rings of men, (S, TA,) and the ranks, became separated, or dispersed. (S, Msb, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, (assumed tropical:) He (a man, K, and a bird, Az, TA) came and went, (Az, K, TA,) and would not be still, or remain at rest. (Az, TA.)
7 A_inoqawaDa see 5, in two places.

h`*aA bi*aA qawoDFA biqawoDK *
This is for that, as a substitute for a substitute. (K.) And humaA qawoDaAni [They two are substitutes, each for the other]: mentioned by Sgh: but Z says, hmA qayoDaAni [q. v. in art. qyD]: (TA:) or both signify they are exchangers, each with the other. (JK.)
muqaw~aDN * Anything demolished, destroyed, or thrown down: [&c.: see 2.] (TA.)
See Supplement

quwolanojN * , (Msb, * K,) with fet-h to the l, (Msb,) and sometimes qawolinojN, with kesr to the l, or thus and quwlinojN, i. e. with kesr to the l and with fet-h and damm to the q, (K,) a foreign word, (TA,) [from the Greek kwliko\s The colic;] a certain painful intestinal disease, in which the egress of the feces and wind is attended with difficulty; (K;) a violent griping in the intestine called the colon. (Msb.)

1 qaA='a * , aor. yaqiYo'u, inf. n. qaYo'N, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,
K, &c.,) He vomited (Mgh, TA) what he had eaten. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence one says,] qaA='a nafosahu [lit. He vomited his soul], meaning (assumed tropical:) he died: like lafaZa nafosahu. (A, TA.) And qaA='ati AlT~aEonapu Ald~ama (assumed tropical:) [The wound made with a spear or the like spouted forth the blood]. (A, TA.) And vawobN yaqiYo'u AlSiboga (assumed tropical:) A garment that is saturated with the dye. (S, A, O, K.) And taqiYo'u AlA^aroDu A^afolaA*a kabidihaA [lit. The earth will vomit the pieces of her liver], meaning (tropical:) the earth will cast forth upon her surface her treasures. (TA, from a trad.) And qaA='ati AlA^aroDu A^ukulahaA [lit. the earth vomited her food], meaning (tropical:) the earth disclosed her herbage and her treasures. (TA, from a saying of 'Áïsheh.) And AlA^aroDu taqiYo'u Aln~adaY (tropical:) [The earth exudes the moisture]. (TA.)

2 qy~A^hu *
He, (a man, S, Mgh, O, Msb,) or it, (medicine, K,) caused him to vomit; (S, * Mgh, O, * Msb, K; *) and ↓ AqA='hu signifies the same. (S, O, K.)
4 A^aqoyaAa see what immediately precedes.

5 tqy~A^ *
He constrained himself to vomit; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) and he vomited intentionally. (TA.) See also 10, in two places. -A2- And taqay~aA^ato She addressed, or presented, herself to her husband, and threw herself upon him: (K:) or, accord. to Lth, she affected languor, or languidness, to her husband, and threw herself upon him: but in the opinion of Az, the verb with q in this sense is a mistranscription, and is correctly tfy~A^t, [q. v.,] with f. (TA.)

10 AstqA=' * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) or AstqyaA^a, (thus in the O, in which the former is not mentioned, [and it seems from an ex. in a verse there cited that this may be a dial. var.,]) and ↓ tqy~A^, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) He constrained himself to vomit: (S, Mgh, O, Msb: [see the latter verb above: in the K neither is expl.:]) or the former is an instance of AisotafoEala from AlqaYo'u [i. e. it signifies he desired to vomit]: and ↓ the latter signifies more than the former, i. e. he made what was in the jawof [here meaning stomach] to come forth, intentionally. (TA.) It is said in a trad., lawo yaEolamu Al$~aAribu qaAy^imFA maA *aA Ealayohi laA@sotaqaA='a maA $ariba [If the person drinking in a standing posture knew what would be the effect upon him, he would desire to vomit what he had drunk: for the drinking and the eating in that posture are forbidden in more than one trad.]. (TA.)

qaYo'N * originally an inf. n.: then applied to signify Vomit; i. e. vomited food. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., Alr~aAjiEu fiY hibatihi kaAlr~aAjiEi fiY qayoy^ihi [He who takes back his gift is like him who swallows back his vomit]. (S.)

quyaA='N * a subst. (K, TA) similar to EuTaAsN and duwaArN [and many other words of the same form applied to maladies; indicating that it signifies A complaint that causes much, or frequent, vomiting]. (TA.) One says, bihi quyaA='N, meaning [In him is a complaint in consequence of which] he is vomiting much, or frequently. (ISk, S, O.)

qayuwo'N * One (a man, IAar) who vomits much, or frequently; as also qayuw~N; (IAar, K, TA;) the latter formed from the former, like maqoruw~N from maqoruwo'N. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also, [dawaA='N qayuwo'N,] Medicine that is taken to cause vomiting; (ISk, S, O;) and so ↓ dawaA='N muqay~iy^N (K, TA) and ↓ muqiYo'N. (TA.)
muqiYo'N * and muqay~iy^N: see what immediately precedes.

1 qaAHa * , said of a wound, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yaqiyHu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. qayoHN; (Msb, K;) like qaAHa, aor. yaquwHu; (K;) and ↓ qy~H, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoyiyHN; (A;) and ↓ AqAH; (A, Msb, K;) and ↓ tqy~H; (S, A, Msb, K;) and tq~wH; (Msb, K;) [It suppurated;] it became in the state of containing [or generating] matter, such as is termed qayoH [meaning as expl. below]: (S, * A, * K in art. qwEH, and Msb in explanation of qay~aHa:) or its qayoH ran, or flowed: or became in a state of readiness [to do so]. (Msb in explanation of qaAHa and AqAH and tqw~H.)
2 qay~aHa and 4 and 5: see the preceding paragraph.

qayoHN *
Thick purulent matter (mid~apN) unmixed with blood; (S, A, L, K;) white, thick [matter], unmixed with blood: (Msb:) or, as some say, [contr. to the generality of the lexicographers,] thin matter (Sadiyd) like water, in which is a $ukolap [ or small admixture, or tinge of the red and white hue,] of blood. (L.)
qaAHapN * , mentioned in this art. in the S, see in art. qwH.
1 qiyda * : see 2.

2 qy~dhu * , inf. n. taqoyiydN, He put a qayod [or pair of shackles] upon his (a horse's) [fore-] legs; he shackled his [fore-] legs. (Msb.) qay~adotu Ald~aAb~apa [I shackled the fore-legs of the beast; hobbled him: and, in a general sense, bound him.] (S.) ↓ qiyda (inf. n. qayodN, TA) and quy~ida signify the same, [He had shackles put upon his fore-legs; he had his fore-legs shackled]. (K.) See also 5. ― -b2- qay~idohu biAloA^aloti (assumed tropical:) [Bind thou him by oath]: said when one has not given thee thy right or due. (TA in art. Alt.) ― -b3- A^uqay~idu jamaliY, (inf. n. taqoyiydN, K.) [lit., I shackle the fore-legs of my camel; meaning,] (tropical:) I fascinate my husband so as to prevent him from going to other women; as though I shackled his legs. (IAth, L, K, * from a trad.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (fatigue) kept a she-camel from action. (A.) ― -b5- (tropical:) It (beneficence) shackled, or restrained, a person. (A.) ― -b6- qy~d AlA_iymaAnu Alfatoka (tropical:) [The giving assurance of safety] inhibits assassinating, or assaulting, the muw^oman [i. e. the person to whom assurance of safety has been given (bAlmuw^mini in the CK is a mistranscription for biAlmuw^omani)]; like as shackles inhibit the mischievous animal from doing mischief. (L, K, * from a trad. [See also 1 in art. ftk; where this trad. is cited in full.]) ― -b7- qy~d, (inf. n. taqoyiydN K,) (tropical:) He pointed a writing with the syllabical signs, or signs which point out the pronunciation and division of syllables: (S, A, L, K:) he pointed a letter: (L:) he restricted a word or phrase [in its signification or application] by that which prevented equivocation and removed ambiguity. (Msb.) -A2- (tropical:) He registered, or recorded, a matter of science [&c.] in a book or the like; i. q. DabaTa. (L.)
5 tqy~d * quasi-pass. of qy~d [He had shackles put upon his legs; he had his legs shackled: see also 2]. (A.)
qaAdN * : see qiydN,

qayodN * [A shackle; or fetter: or, generally, a pair of shackles for the fore-legs of a beast, and generally made of rope, but some are of iron; a pair of hobbles; a pair of fetters]: (S, K, &c.:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aqoyaAdN (L, Msb, K) and [of mult.] quyuwdN. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- A_in~ quyuwda AlA^ayaAdo A^awovaqu AlA^aqoyaAdo (tropical:) [Verily the shackles of benefactions are the firmest of shackles]. (A.) [AlA^ayaAdo is for AlA^ayaAdiY.] ― -b3- What binds together [the two pieces of wood in a camel's saddle which are called] the EaDudaAni of [the two broad pieces of wood called] the muw^ax~arataAni, (L, K [in the former of which, however, instead of mA Dm~ AlEDdyn mn Almwx~rtyn, the reading in the K, is put mA Dm~ AlEDdtyn Almw^x~rtyn, which I suppose to be a mistake]) at their upper part, being a thong. (L.) ― -b4- A plaited thong between [the two pieces of wood called] the HinowaAni of a camel's saddle of the kind called raHol, at the upper part; and sometimes, of a horse's saddle. (L.) ― -b5- The thong that binds together [the two pieces of wood called] the EaroquwataAni of a camel's saddle of the kind called qatab. (S, L, K.) ― -b6- Anything that binds one part of a thing to another part. (L.) ― -b7- The extended thing at the lower extremities of the suspensory cords or strings of a sword, which is held by [the rings called] the bakaraAt. (L, K.) ― -b8- qayodaA AlbaAziY The jesses of the hawk or falcon; syn. sibaAqaAhu (S, O, K, all in art. sbq.) ― -b9- qayodu AlA^asonaAni The gum wherein the teeth are set: (K:) quyuwdu AlAsnAn the gums: (L:) or the portions of the flesh of the gums that rise between the teeth; likened to the red quyuwd which are marks upon camels, made with a hot iron. (ISd, L.) ― -b10- qayodu Alfarasi A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the neck of a camel, (S, ISd, L, K,) and upon its face, and thigh, of an oblong shape, (ISd, L,) in the form of a qayod [for the legs], (S, L,) or of two rings with a line extending between them. (Nh, L.) ― -b11-
qayodu AlA^awaAbidi (tropical:) [lit. Shackles upon the legs of the wild animals which shun, and take fright at, mankind &c.; or, accord. to the L, of the wild asses]: indeterminate in signification, though determinate in its grammatical form: (Sb, L:) an appellation given to a horse, (K,) or to a fleet, or swift, and excellent horse, because, by its swiftness, it overtakes the wild beasts, (T, K,) and prevents their escaping. (T, S.) qyd is here a proper subst. used as an epithet because it imports the attribute of a verb; or it is for taqoyid. (IJ, L.) [See also art. Abd and Ham, p. 455.] ― -b12- (tropical:) A wife: as also gul~N. (TA.) ― -b13- maA EalaY h`*aA AlHarofi qyado (tropical:) There is not upon this letter a syllabical sign, or sign which points out the pronunciation, or the division of syllables. (A.) ― -b14- Alqayodu waAlr~atoEapu, a prov.: see art. rtE. -A2- See also qiydN.

qiydN *
A whip made of skin. (MF.) -A2- qiydN and ↓ qaAdN (S, L, K) and ↓ qayodN (K) Measure. (S, L, K.) Ex. bayonahumaA qiydu rumoHK, and qaAdu rmH, Between them two is the measure of a spear. (S.) See also art. qwd.

qiyaAdN *
A leading-rope (S, K) for a beast of carriage. (S, K.) [But this belongs to art. qwd, q. v.]

qay~idN *
Tractable; easy to be led. (S, K.) [But this belongs to art. qwd, q. v.]
qay~idapN * : see art. qwd.
maqiydN * : see muqay~adN.

muqay~adN * The place of the qayod in the leg of a horse; (S, K;) [i. e., the pastern]. Ex. farasN Eabolu Almuqay~adi Tawiylu Almuqal~adi [A horse large in the place of the shackle, or pastern; long in the place of the collar, or neck]. (A.) ― -b2- The place of the anklet in [the leg of] a woman; (S, K;) [i. e., the ankle]. ― -b3- muqay~adN [and ↓ maqiydN] A camel, or the like, having his legs shackled; having shackles upon his legs: pl. [of the latter] maqaAyiydu. (K.) You say h`w^ulaA='i A^ajomaAlN maqaAyiydN, i. e., muqay~adaAtN` [These are camels having their legs shackled]. (S.) ― -b4- naAqapN muqay~adapN (tropical:) A jaded she-camel that will not be roused to action. (A.) ― -b5- And muqay~adN A place in which a camel is left with his legs shackled. (L, K.) Hence applied to a place abounding with herbage, or pasture. (L.)

muqay~idapu AlHimaAri * (L) [in the CK, muqay~adapu AlHimaAri, and in most copies of the K, accord. to the TA, AlximaAri,] (assumed tropical:) A stony tract, of which the stones are black and worn and crumbling, as though burned with fire; syn. Har~apN: (L, K: [in a copy of the K, Hur~apN] so called because it impedes the ass, [in the TA, art. Hmr, the wild ass,] as though it shackled him. (L.) ― -b2- Hence, (L,) banuw muqay~idapi AlHimaAri, (L,) in the K, banuw maqay~adapa [with fet-h to the Y, and without AlHmAr] (TA,) [and in the CK, banuw muqay~adK,] (assumed tropical:) Scorpions: (L, K:) so called because they are in a tract such as is called mq~ydpAlHmAr. (L.) [See an ex. in some verses cited voce rumoHN.]

[
taqoyiydN *
A note which determines the correct reading or meaning of a word or phrase or the like: and hence, any marginal note: pl. taqoyiydaAtN.]

2 qy~r *
He smeared a ship, or boat, (S, A, Msb,) or a jar [for wine], and a skin for wine or the like, (K,) with qiyr or qaAr. (S, A, Msb, K.)

qiyrN *
i. q. qaArN [Tar: or pitch]: (S, A, Msb, K:) a certain black thing with which are smeared ships, (K, TA,) to prevent the water from entering, (TA,) and camels, also, (K, TA,) for the mange, or scab, and whereof there is a species with which anklets and bracelets are filled: it is extracted by melting from [the] SEd: (TA:) [SuEudN is the name of a certain tree from which tar is melted forth: (L, art. SEd:)] or i. q. zifotN: (A, K, TA:) and the best thereof is of the colour termed $uqorap. (TA.) [See also kuforN.]

qay~aArN *
A possessor, (K,) or seller, (A,) of qiyr or qaAr: (A, K;) or a maker of it. (So in a copy of the S, but not mentioned in another copy.)

qay~aArapN *
A place where qaAr is generated. (Mgh, in art. nfT.)

qayorawaAnN * , an arabicized word, (K,) from [the Persian] kaArowaAno, (TA,) and signifying A caravan; a company, or an assemblage of persons, travelling together; syn. qaAfilapN: (K:) or the main part of a qAflp: and of an army: (A. IAth, and so in a copy of the S:) or of [such a collection of soldiers as is called] a katiysbap: (ISk:) and the companions and assistants of the devil. (IAth.) It has the last of these significations in a trad. of Mujáhid, in which it is said, yagoduw Al$~ayoTaAnu biqayorawaAnihi A_ilaY Als~uwqi falaA yazaAlu yahotaz~u AlEaro$u mim~aA yaEolamu A@ll~`hu maA laA yaEolamu [The devil goeth in the morning with his companions and assistants to the market-place, and the empyrean ceaseth not to shake in consequence of the assertions that God knoweth what He knoweth not]: meaning, that the devil incites men to say “ God knoweth such a thing, ” of things whereof God knoweth the contrary: [as for instance, “ God knoweth that such a commodity cost me (the seller) such a sum of money: ”] yaEolamu A@ll~`hu being a form of asseveration. (IAth.) [qyrwAn is written qayoruwaAnN in some copies of the S and K. It is mentioned in this art., and in art. qrw, in the K: in the S, only in the latter art., and part of the above trad. is there cited.]

1 qAs Al$aYo'a bigayorihi * , and EalaY gayorihi, (S, A, * Msb, * K *; the first and last in this art. and in art. qws;) and A_ilaY gayorihi, (A, TA,) aor. yaqiysuhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. qayosN (S, A, Msb, K) and qiyaAsN, (S, A, K,) [which latter is the more common,] He measured the thing (S, A, Msb. K) by another thing (S, Msb, K) like it; (S, K;) [both in the proper sense and mentally; often meaning he compared the thing with another thing;] as also qaAsahu, aor. yaquwsuhu, inf. n. qawosN (S, Msb, K; the first and last in art. qws;) and qiyaAsN; (S;) [the latter of which verbs, though the less common, is, accord. to the JK, the original;] and so ↓ AqtAshu; (A, K;) and ↓ qy~shu; (TA;) and so bihi ↓ qAyshu, (Msb,) and A_ilayohi, (TA,) inf. n. muqaAyasapN and qiyaAsN: (Msb:) the first of these verbs is said to be trans. by means of ElY because implying the meaning of founding [a thing upon another thing]; and by means of AlY because implying the meaning of adjoining or conjoining and collecting [a thing to another thing]. (MF.) You say, qaAsahu biA@lomiqoyaAsi [He measured it with the measure]. (A.) And qaAsa AlT~abiybu qaEora AljiraAHapi, (TA,) and qaAsa Al$~aH~apa, (A,) inf. n. qayosN, (TA,) The physician measured the depth of the wound, (TA,) and the depth of the wound in the head, (A,) biA@lomiqoyaAsi with the probe. (A, TA.) And jaAriyapN taxoTuw qayosFA (tropical:) A damsel that steps with even, or equal, steps: (A:) or qayosFA signifies with measured steps, at a moderate and just pace, as though with equal steps: (IAth:) or qayosN signifies the walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (K.) And fulaAnN yaA^otiY bimaA yaA^otiY qayosFA (tropical:) [Such a one does what he does, or says what he says, by measure, or by rule]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) He determined, or judged of, the thing by comparing it with another thing; i. e., by analogy: and he compared the thing with another thing. And qaAsa Ealayohi He judged by comparison therewith. And He copied it as a model.]
2 qay~asa see 1.

3 qAyshu bihi * , and A_layohi: see 1. You say, qabaHa A@ll~`hu qawomFA yusaw~iduwnaka wayuqaAyisuwna biraA^oyika [May God remove far from prosperity a people who make thee lord, or chief, and who measure things by thy judgment, or by thine opinion]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- qaAyasotu bayona AlA^amorayoni, (S, K,) or Al$~ayoy^ayoni, (A,) inf. n. muqaAyasapN and qiyaAsN, (S,) I measured, or compared, the two things, or cases, together; syn. qad~arotu, (K,) or qaAdarotu biyonahumaA. (L.) ― -b3- qaAyasotuhu, (K,) i. e., qaAyasotu fulaAnFA, (S,) i. q. jaArayotuhu fiY AlqiyaAsi [I vied, or contended, with him, namely, such a one, in measuring, or comparing; app. meaning, in measuring, or comparing, myself, or my abilities, with him, or his: see qaAdarotuhu]. ― -b4- [This verb is mentioned in the S in art. qws.]

6 tqAys Alqawomu *
The people mentioned [and app. compared] their several wants (maA=ribahumo [but I
think it probable that this is a mistranscription for maA=virahumo their generous qualities or the like]). (TA.)

7 AnqAs *
It was, or became, measured by another thing like it. (S, in art. qws; and K, in the present art.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) [It was, or became, determined, or judged of, by comparison, or analogy.] You say, h`*ihi masoy^alapN laA tanoqaAsu (assumed tropical:) [This is a question not to be determined, or judged of, by comparison, or analogy]. (A, TA.)

8 A_iqotayasa see 1. ― -b2- huwa yaqotaAsu biA^abiyhi He follows the way of his father, and imitates him. (S, K, in art. qws; and mentioned in the K in the present art. also.) The medial radical is both w and Y. (K.)
qaAsu rumoHK * : see qiysu rumoHK.

bayonahumaA qiysu rumoHK * (S, A, K *) and rumoHK ↓ qaAsu (S, K) Between them two is the measure of a spear: (S, K: *) like qiydu rumoHK (TA) [and qaAdu rumoHK]. And h`*ihi Alxa$abapu qiysu A_iSoyaEK This piece of wood is of the measure of a finger. (A, * TA.) [Both are said in the A to be tropical; but wherefore, 1 see not.]

qiyaAsN * : see 1 and 3. ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst., Measurement. ― -b3- Comparison. ― -b4- Ratiocination. ― -b5- The premises of a syllogism, taken together: and also applied to a syllogism entire. ― -b6- Analogy: rule. You say, h`*aA EalaY AlqiyaAsi This is according to analogy, or to rule. And h`*aA EalaY gayori qyaAsK This is contrary to analogy, or to rule. And EalaY qiyaAsi ka*aA After the manner of such a thing.]

[
qiyaAsiY~N *
Mensural. ― -b2- Comparative. ― -b3- Ratiocinative. ― -b4- Relating, or belonging, to the premises of a syllogism: and also, syllogistic. ― -b5- Analogous; regular: as also ↓ maqiysN, improperly written by some European scholars muqay~asN.]
qay~aAsN * A man who practises qiyaAs [i. e. measurement, or comparison, &c.,] much, or often. (TA.) -A2- Also, i. q. qaw~aAsN, q. v. (TA.)
qaAy^isN * act. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- One who measures the depth of a wound in the head [&c.] with a probe. (TA.)

maqiysN * pass. part. n. of 1. You say, huwa maqiysN Ealayohi [and bihi, meaning, He, or it, is a person, or thing, whereby others are measured; to which others are compared; an object of imitation; a model, an exemplar, or a standard]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also qiyaAsiY~N.

miqoyaAsN *
A measure, or thing with which anything is measured; syn. miqodaArN: (S, Msb, K:) pl. maqaAyiysu. (A.) You say, qaAsahu biA@lomiqoyaAsi [He measured it with the measuring-instrument]. (A.) And qaSura miqoyaAsuka fiY miqoyaAsiY Thy measure (mivaAluka) fell short of my measure. (TA.) ― -b2- A probe with which the depth of a wound is measured. (A, TA.) ― -b3- miqoyaAsu Aln~iyli The Nilometer. (TA.)
1 qaASa * , inf. n. qayoSN: see 7, in two places.
5 taqay~aSa see 7, in three places.

7 AnqAS * , said of sand, (A, K,) and of dust, or earth, (K,) It poured forth, or down: (K:) or it fell, fell down, or collapsed; and so when said of a building; (A;) and so AnqASt said of a well (biy^or); (S, A, K;) it fell; fell down; fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed; (S, A, K;) as also AnqADt, with D; (TA;) and ↓ tqy~St: (A, K:) which ↓ last also signifies it (a well) inclined, and became demolished, or fell in ruins; and in like manner [tqy~S said of] a wall. (TA.) ― -b2- AnqASt Als~in~u The tooth became broken: (A:) or became cracked, or split, lengthwise: (TA:) or fell out: (Lth, K:) and ↓ qaASato, (TA,) inf. n. qayoSN, (S, K,) it fell out from its root; (S, K, TA;) and so with D: (S, TA:) and AnqAS AlD~irosu, and ↓ qaASa, and ↓ tq~yS, the tooth became cracked lengthwise, and fell out. (TA.) ― -b3- AnqAS AlmaA='u fiY Albiy^ori The water became abundant in the well (K, TA) so that it nearly demolished it. (TA.)

biy^orN qay~aASapN *
A well that has collapsed. (A.) And biy^orN qay~aASapu Aljuwli A well having its wall, or casing, or sides, demolished. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
munoqaASN * signifies Uprooted; (S, K;) and munoqaADN, with the pointed D, cracked or split, lengthwise; so says As.: but AA says, that both signify the same. (S, O.)

1 qaADa * , (A, TA,) [aor, yaqiyDa,] inf. n. qayoDN, (K,) He clave, or broke or rent asunder. (A, * K, TA.) You say, qaADa AlbayoDapa He (a young bird) clave, or broke asunder, the egg: and he (a bird) clave, or broke asunder, the egg from over the young one. (Lth, A, * TA.) And it is said in a trad, respecting the day of resurrection, faA_i*aA kaAna ka*`lika qiyDato h`*ihi Als~amaA='u Ald~unubaA Eano A^aholihaA, i. e., [And when it shall be thus, this lowest heaven] shall be cleft, or rent asunder, from over its inhabitants, meaning the inhabitants of the earth (AlA^aroD), which is previously mentioned in the trad.:] or, as Sh says, shall be dissolved. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, first pers. qiDotu, (AZ, S,) or qaDotu, (IAth,) He cracked a glass bottle, without separation of the parts. (AZ, S, IAth.) ― -b3- And qiDotu AlbinaA='a is a dial. form of quDotu [meaning I demolished, destroyed, or threw down, the building]. (Sgh.) -A2- Also, inf. n. as above, It became cleft, or broken or rent asunder. (K, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned.) You say, qaADati AlbayoDapu The egg became cleft, or broken asunder. (TK.) [See also 7.] ― -b2- And qaADati Als~in~u, inf. n. as above, The tooth fell out from its root; as also with S. (S, * TA in art. qyS.) -A3- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He hollowed out a well (K, TA) in a rock. (TA.) And qiyDa signifies It was dug. (TA.) -A4- Also, (TK) inf. n. as above, (K,) He likened, or assimilated. (K, TK.) You say, qaADahu bihi He likened, or assimilated, him, or it, to him, or it. (TK.) [See also 5; and see qayoDo, below.] -A5- See also 3, in two places.

2 qy~D lahu ka*aA *
He (God, Msb) ordained, or appointed, for him such a thing. (Mgh, Msb.) And qy~D A@ll~`hu fulaAnFA lifulaAnK, (S, A, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K, bifulaAnK, which is a mistake, (TA,) God ordained, or appointed, or prepared, such a one for such a one: (A:) or brought such a one to such a one, and ordained, or appointed, or prepared, him for him. (S, K.) Hence the saying in the Kur, [xli. 24,] (S,) waqay~aDonaA lahumo quranaA='a (S, K) And we have appointed, or prepared, for them associates (A, * Bd, * K, TA) whence they do not expect, (A, K, TA,) which shall have possession of them like as the qayoD, or shell, has possession of the egg. (Bd.) And so in the same, [xliii. 35,] nuqay~iDo lahu $ayoTaAnFA We will appoint, or prepare, for him a devil [as an associate]. (Zj.) Accord. to some, the verb is used only as relating to evil; but this is not true, as is shown by the saying of Mohammad, maA A^akorama $aAb~N $ayoxFA lisin~ihi A_il~aA qay~aDa A@ll~`hu lahu Einoda sin~ihi mano yakorimuhu [A young man hath not honoured an aged man for his age but God hath appointed for him in his age such as shall honour him]. (TA.)

3 qAyDhu * , (S, A, K, &c.) inf. n. muqaAyaDapN (S Mgh) and qiyaADN, (A,) He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him; syn. EaAraDahu, (S, O, L, and so in a copy of the K,) bimataAEK; (S;) or EaAwaDahu; (A, and so in some copies of the K; in the CK, EAyaDahu;) and baAdalahu; (A, K;) i. e. he gave him a commodity and took another commodity in its stead: (TA:) [as also qaAbaDahu, with b:] and ↓ qaADahu, aor. yaqiyDu, he gave him a thing in exchange. (TA.) You say, qAyDhu bika*aA [He gave him in exchange for such a thing]. (Mgh.) Hence, bayoEu AlmuqaAyaDapi The selling a commodity for another commodity. (Mgh.) And hence the saying of Mohammad, A_ino $iy^ota qaAyaDotuka bihi AlmuxotaArapa mino durwuEi xayobara, or bihi ↓ A^aqiyDuka, accord. to different relations; i. e. [If thou wilt,] I will give thee in exchange for it [the choice of the coats of mail of Kheyber]. (TA.) You say also, A^aEoTayotuhu farasFA bifarasayoni muqaAyaDapF [I gave him a horse for two horses in exchange]. (JK.) And maA A^uqaAyiDu bika A^aHadFA (tropical:) [I do not give, or take, in exchange for thee any one]. (A, TA.)
And lawo A^uEoTiytu milo'a Ald~ahonaA='i rijaAlFA qiyaADFA bifulaAnK raDiytuhumo (tropical:) [If I were given what would fill the desert of men, in exchange for such a one, I would not accept them]: (A, TA:) and the like occurs in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, as said by him, with reference to Yezeed. (TA.)

5 taqy~Dt AlbayoDapu *
The egg became broken into. pieces; and in like manner, AlqaAruwrapu the glass bottle. (AZ, S.) [See also 7.] ― -b2- tqy~D AljidaAru The wall fell to pieces, or in ruins, or became a ruin, and broke down; syn. A_inohadama, and A_inohaAla; as also ↓ AnqADt: (K:) or the former signifies the wall broke in pieces, and fell down: but the latter has a different signification, which see in its place below. (AZ, S.) -A2- tqy~D lahu It (a thing, TA) became ordained, appointed, or prepared, for him. (K.) -A3- tqy~D A^abaAhu He resembled his father; (AZ, S, K;) as also taqay~alahu. (TA.) [See qayoDN.]
6 tqAyDA * [They two bartered, or exchanged commodities, each with the other; like tqAbDA: see 3]. (JK.)

7 AnqADt AlbayoDapu *
The egg cracked, without splitting apart; and in like manner, AlqaAruwrapu the glass bottle. (AZ, S.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- AnqAD AljidaAru i. q. tqy~D: (K:) or the wall fell to pieces, or in ruins, from its place, without being pulled to pieces: (Lth:) or cracked, without falling: but if it have fallen, you say, tqy~D: (AZ, S:) ― -b3- Accord. to AA, as related by ElMundhiree, AnqAD and AnqAS both signify It split, or cracked, lengthwise: but see munoqaADN. (TA.) You say, accord. to As, AnqADt Als~in~u The tooth split, or cracked, lengthwise; and in like manner, Alr~akiy~apu the well: (S:) or it (the well) became broken in pieces: or fell; fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed; (TA;) as also AnqASt. (S, A, K, in art. qyS.) AnqAD belongs both to this art. and to art. qwD. (TA.)

8 AqtADhu *
He extirpated it; destroyed it utterly. (K, TA.) -A2- [Also, He received it, or took it, in exchange; like A_iEotaADahu: see muqotaADN; and see also 3.]

qayoDN * [An egg-shell;] the upper hard covering that is upon an egg: (K:) or [an egg-shell cracked in pieces;] what is cracked in pieces of the upper covering of an egg: (S, * IB:) or one from which the young bird, or the fluid, has gone forth. (Lth, K.) -A2- A compensation, or substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in the place of, or in exchange for, another thing. (K.) You say, baAEahu farasF bifarasayon qayoDayoni [He sold to him a horse for two horses as substitutes]. (TA.) ― -b2- humaA qayoDaAni They two are likes; they two are like each other; (A' Obeyd, A;) each of them is fit to be a substitute for the other. (A, TA.) [See also humaA qawoDaAni.] ― -b3- h`*aA qayoDN lahu, and lh ↓ qiyaADN, This is equal, or equivalent, to it. (O, K.)

qiyDapN *
A small piece of bone: (AA, K:) pl., accord. to the K, qiyoDN; but correctly, accord. to AA, qiyaDN. (TA.)

qay~iDN *
A barterer, or an exchanger of commodities: (S, Msb:) of the measure fayoEilN. (Msb.) You say, humaA qay~iDaAni They two are barterers, or exchangers of commodities; like as you say bay~iEaAni. (S.)
qiyaADN * : see qayoDN.

maqiyDN * The place in which is [an egg-shell, or an egg-shell cracked in pieces, or empty, or] the part of an egg called qayoD. (K, TA.) -A2- bayoDapN maqiyDapN An egg cleft, or split. (TA.) ― -b2- biy^orN maqiyDapN A well abounding with water, having been hollowed out, (K, TA,) or cleft. (TA.)

AlmuqotaAD * in the following verse of Abu-shShees,
bud~ilotu mino burodi Al$~abaAbi mulaA='apF
xalaqFA wabiy^osa mavuwbapu AlmuqotaADi
[I have been given in exchange, for the mantle of youth, an old worn-out covering; and very evil is the recompense of the receiver in exchange] is from qayoDN as signifying the “ bartering, ” or “ exchanging commodities, ” (TA,) [or rather the “ giving in exchange: ” see 3.]

bayoDapN munoqaADapN *
An egg cracked, without being split apart; and in like manner, qaAruwrapN a glass bottle. (AZ, S.) As says, that munoqaASN signifies uprooted; and munoqaADN, with the pointed D, cracked, or split, lengthwise; but AA says, that both signify the same. (S, O, in art. qyS.)

1 qaAZa biAlmakaAni * , (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaqiyZu, inf. n. qayoZN; (Msb;) and bihi ↓ tqy~Z; (S, K;) and bh ↓ qy~Z; (K;) and ↓ AqtAZ; (TA;) He, (a man, Msb,) or it, (a people, K,) remained, or abode, in the place during the season called qayoZ, (K, * TA,) during the summer, (S,) or during the days of heat. (Msb.) Dhu-r-Rummeh makes the second of these verbs trans. by itself, [without a preposition,] saying Alr~amola ↓ taqay~aZa [He remained, or abode, during the summer, or hot season, in the sands]. (TA.) ― -b2- qaAZa yawomunaA Our day became vehemently, or intensely, hot. (S, Sgh, K.) ― -b3- See also 3. -A2- qiyZuwA They were rained upon by the rain of the season called AlqyZ; similar to SiyfuwA and rubiEuwA. (TA.)

2 qay~aZa see 1. -A2- qy~Zhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taqoyiyZN, (K,) It (a thing, S, K, such as food, and a garment, TA) sufficed him for his [season called] qayoZ; (S, K;) similar to Sy~fhu and $t~Ahu. (TA.)

3 qAyZhu * , inf. n. muqaAyaZapN, He remained, or abode, during the season called qayoZ with him. (AHn.) ― -b2- EaAmalahu muqaAyaZapN, and qiyaAZFA, and quyuwZFA, with damm, which last is extr., (K, TA,) not being an inf. n. of this verb, (TA,) [but, by rule, of ↓ qAZa,] He made an engagement, or a contract, with him for the season called qayoZ: (TA:) from AlqayoZu, like mu$aAharapN from Al$~ahoru. (K, TA.) And A_isotaA^ojarahu muqaAyaZapF, and qiyaAZFA, He hired him, or took him as a hired man, or hireling, for the season so called. (TA.)
5 taqay~aZa see 1, in two places.
8 A_iqotayaZa see 1.

qayoZN * The most vehement, or intense, heat of summer; (S, K;) from the [auroral] rising of the Pleiades, [which, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, was about the 13th of May, O. S.,] to the [auroral] rising of Canopus, [which, at the same period, was about the 4th of August, O. S.:] (K:) or vehemence, or intenseness, of heat: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aqoyaAZN and [of mult.] quyuwZN. (K.) ― -b2- Also, The quarter which people [commonly] call the Sayof; (Msb;) the summerquarter, commencing when the sun enters the sign of Cancer; so termed by some, who called the spring-quarter the Sayof, and the autumnal-quarter the rabiyE; others [in later times] calling the summer-quarter the Syof, the spring-quarter the rabiyE, and the autumnal-quarter the xariyf; but agreeing with the former in calling the winterquarter the $itaA=': (Mir-át ez-Zemán:) the Arabs say, that the year consists of four seasons, every one of these being three months; namely, the quarter called the Sayof, which is that called rabiyEu AlkalaA_i, consisting of [the Syrian months] Ádhár and Neysán and Eiyár [or March and April and May, O. S.]; then, the quarter called the qayoZ, consisting of Hazeerán and Temmooz and Áb [or June and July and August, O. S.]; then, the quarter called the xariyf, consisting of Eylool and the two Tishreens [or September and October and November, O. S.]; and then, the quarter called the $itaA=', consisting of the two Kánoons and Shubát [or December and January and February, O. S.]. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- laA taquwmu Als~aAEapu Hat~aY yakuwna Alwaladu gayoZFA wAlmaTaru qayoZFA, a saying of Mohammad, meaning [The resurrection, or the time thereof, will not come to pass until the birth of a child be an occasion of wrath, or rage, and] rain be accompanied by air like the qyZ [or most vehement heat of summer]. (TA.) ― -b4- A_ijotamaEa
AlqayoZu is an elliptical and abridged phrase, meaning The people, or company of men, assembled themselves in the qayoZ [or summer]. (TA.)

qayoZiY~N *
What is brought forth [of sheep or goats] in the season called the qayoZ. (K, TA.) [See also SafariY~N, in three places.]
qiyaAZN * Seed-produce [or wheat] that is sown in the autumn and the beginning of winter [so as to be reaped in summer]. (JK, TA.)

yawomN qaAy^iZN *
A day vehemently, or intensely, hot: and qayoZN qaAy^iZN a summer vehement, or intense [in heat]. (TA.)

maqiyZN *
A place where people remain, or abide, in the summer; (IAar, S, K;) as also maqoyaZN. (K.) And A place of pasturing in summer. (IAar.) ― -b2- Also, (JK,) or ↓ maqiyZapN, (K,) A plant, or herbage, that remains green until the qayoZ [or summer], (Lth, JK, K,) although the land and leguminous plants be dried up, (Lth, TA,) being a means of subsistence for the camels when other herbage has become dry. (Lth, JK, K.)
maqiyZapN * : see maqiyZN.
muqay~iZN * A thing that suffices one for the [season called] qayoZ. (S.)
See Supplement
